Summary Sentence: Texas biotech firm create ‘gold hydrogen’ from depleted oil well residue
Justification: The Environment Agency may be called on to weigh up the costs and benefits of this method and the technique would likely require regulation. The biotech company Cemvita Factory has created a concoction of bacteria and nutrients that can break down oil residue in disused bore holes. The breakdown process creates hydrogen and CO2. A recent small scale field test was a “huge success.” Cemvita hopes to produce hydrogen for $1 per kilogram, which would be competitive against other methods and estimates there are more than 1,000 depleted oil wells dotted around the United States that might be suitable. Cemvita’s goal is to treat oil wells with microbes to enable steady, long-term hydrogen production—conceivably lasting for decades. Existing, disused infrastructure around old oil wells, once used for collecting off-gasses, could be brought back into service to collect the hydrogen. It will, however, be important to prevent the CO2 by-product from leaking into the atmosphere. The hope is that the CO2 can be locked underground, using other microbes to fix it somehow, or find commercial uses for the greenhouse gas. Another potential issue is contamination with hydrogen-consuming microbes which would consume the hydrogen gas. There are also concerns around whether such technologies could potentially shore up fossil fuel firms, in contrast to hydrogen production systems that rely on renewables.
Primary Article Title: ‘Gold Hydrogen’ Is an Untapped Resource in Depleted Oil Wells
Author: CHRIS BARANIUK
Keywords: Hydrogen “Gold hydrogen” Bioengineering Biotechnology Oil “Oil well” “Residue oil” “Microbial breakdown” “Hydrogen production” Microbes Waste “Waste oil” Recycling Reuse “Oil treatment” “Oil breakdown”&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Photonics computing has the potential to provide high power computing at lower energetic cost.
Justification: Photonic computing is a much more efficient process than electrical computing and could lower the energetic costs of computing, which will be important for achieving net zero. Photonics uses light rather than electricity to transmit signals, which is a much more efficient process and when applied to computing and has the potential to reduce power consumption and increase processor speed (something that is becoming more relevant in this world of big data). Photonic computers can be entirely optical (using light only) or electro-optical (light is used for specific tasks but electronic components are also used). All-optical systems have the added benefit that computing operations can be completed during data transfer, potentially removing the need for data storage. Currently, most of the commercially available photonics computing devices are electro-optical and use silicon as an optical medium. In the future a CMOS (complementary-metal-oxide-semiconductor) like process could be used to create photonic and electronic circuits on the same wafer. The application of photonics goes beyond computing and photonic technology has already become dominant in communication, with the application of fibre optics. The improved efficiency of photonics could also be applied to improve datacentres and lidar sensing technologies.
Primary Article Title: Teaching photonic chips to 'learn'
Author: Volker Sorger

Summary Sentence: Rapidly melting glaciers are releasing a staggering amount of unknown bacteria.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be aware of potential new sources of disease and anti-microbial resistance as well as drivers of ecosystem damage. Research on glacial runoff from Aarhus University studied 10 sites across the Northern Hemisphere. The findings showed that continued global warming over the next 80 years could release hundreds of thousands of tonnes of bacteria into environments downstream of receding glaciers. Microbes entombed inside glaciers could be a rich source of useful, new compounds, such as antibiotics. However, the researchers behind this new study say melting glaciers are releasing tonnes upon tonnes of bacteria faster than scientists can possibly catalogue them. In addition, this microbial input is concerning from an ecosystem and public/ animal health perspective with unknown bacteria entering sensitive ecosystems or catchments used by communities that depend on glacial runoff as a water source. Individual strains of bacteria were not studied, instead the researchers estimated their combined biomass. This meant they could not identify particular species that might pose a threat to human health – nor could they determine whether microbes were active, dormant, damaged, or dead.

This release of bacterial biomass is calculated to be the equivalent of 650,000 tonnes of carbon released per year into rivers, lakes, fjords, and oceans across the Northern Hemisphere. On top of this, bacteria and algae found in icy environments often contain pigments to shield themselves from damaging sunlight. But these pigments, in absorbing solar energy, could add to warming that is already accelerating glacial ice loss.
Primary Article Title: Rapidly Melting Glaciers Are Releasing a Staggering Payload of Unknown Bacteria
Author: CLARE WATSON

Summary Sentence: A range of synthetic biology breakthroughs have been achieved recently, each with the potential to revolutionise a range of industries.
Justification:
Combined, these developments illustrate the trend toward more sophisticated and complex applications of synthetic biology affecting a range of Environment Agency relevant industries. As the technology improves and pushes into new fields there is potential for radical change but, at the same time, risks of associated ethical issues.

Brain cells grown in a lab have learned to respond to stimuli and play the game pong. The ‘mini-brain’ senses and responds to surrounding conditions but should not be considered sentient, according to researcher Dr Brett Kagan of Cortical Labs. The long-term goal is to produce biocomputing solutions but in the short term, a supply of ‘cheap brains’ could be used for chemical testing. &%23160;The Environment Agency should track the progress of such testing with a view to informing policies around chemical regulation

A research group at University of Bristol have made progress in the production of synthetic cells with lifelike functionality. The researchers have demonstrated a method for building highly complex protocells using viscous micro-droplets filled with living bacteria as a microscopic building site. Such cells could be used for medical research but also offer potential for developing lab-grown meat alternatives, which could fundamentally change the agriculture industry. The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have already approved the creation of lab grown meat created from living cells from chickens by California company Upside Foods.

Personalised medicine using CRISPR can edit T cells so that they can recognise cancer mutations. The complicated treatment involved sequencing the DNA of each patient using blood samples and tumour biopsies, to look for mutations that are found in the tumour but not in the blood. Personalised medical treatments have the potential to improve individual health and wellbeing as well as prevention of excessive use of medication, including chemotherapies. This process could eventually reduce medical waste, reduce pharmaceutical water pollution and reduce anti-biotic and anti-microbial resistance. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: Lab-grown brain cells play video game Pong

Summary Sentence: The Pacific island nation of Tuvalu has announced that it is turning to the metaverse to preserve its lands,people and culture in the face of rising sea levels caused by climate change.&%23160;
Justification: Simon Kofe, Tuvalu foreign minister Simon Kofe made the announcement recently, generating significant media interest. While other nations have experimented with a digital first philosophy, notably Estonia (%2313752), and others have experimented with virtual embassies in Second Life, Tuvalu is the first to explicitly signal intentions to function as a nation completely within a sensory virtual environment, which would be able to preserve a virtual copy of territory onto which citizens could interact to preserve governance and culture. While the announcement could be seen in the context of a publicity campaign to raise awareness of the nation’s plight, the technological, social and political implications of this proposal raise questions as to what the viable and sustainable responses to threats of this nature should be, and what is at stake through not taking concerted action to both mitigate and adapt to climate change, particularly as the resources involved in creating and sustaining a metaverse environment can themselves contribute to environmental pressures. It may also set a precedent for other environments to be captured digitally, weakening interest in preserving them physically.
Primary Article Title: An entire Pacific country will upload itself to the metaverse. It’s a desperate plan – with a hidden message
Author: Kelly, N & Foth, M
Keywords: "climate change" metaverse virtual environment VR "virtual reality" Tuvalu politic social environment adaptation mitgation "Simon Kofe" resource energy "sea level"&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Researchers have enabled plants to grow using a type of artificial photosynthesis that requires no light of any kind in order to work.
Justification: This discovery should be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as it presents challenges to strategic assumptions around food production, biomass production and land use. In the experiment, the plants had zero contact with light. The researchers used an electrocatalytic process involving a tool called an carbon dioxide electrolyzer, where water, electricity and carbon dioxide were converted to acetate,which replaces the plants need for glucose during photosynthesis. The acetate was then given to the plants hydroponically. While the plants themselves didn’t come into contact with sunlight, the energy used in the electrolyzing process came from renewable energy in the form of solar panels. However using the sun’s energy in this way meant that overall the process was more efficient than biological photosynthesis. Plants successfully grown included foodstuffs such as tomatoes, peas and lettuce, and also yeast, algae and mushroom-producing fungus. This discovery suggests a potential paradigm shift in how land is used in food production, as less land could be needed to grow food in non-traditional environments.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Cultivating crops, no sun required
Author: Swenson, S
Secondary_URLs: A hybrid inorganic–biological artificial photosynthesis system for energy-efficient food production | Nature Food

Summary Sentence: A growing interest in nuclear power to help the World transition away from fossil fuels and make domestic provision more resilient may be baking future geopolitical tensions into the energy supply market.
Justification: As a regulator of radioactive materials and waste the Environment Agency should be interested in considering how future resource supply issues could impact on the energy landscape. The upsurge of interest in nuclear power has in turn increased demand for uranium, widely used as nuclear fuel. While most nuclear power generation takes place in the USA and Europe, global uranium ore reserves tend to be located elsewhere, including Australia, China, Kazakhstan, Russia, India and African countries. The dramatically falling costs of renewable energy up until recent times has meant that global interest and investment has moved away from nuclear power and uranium prices fell considerably. But recent geopolitical developments, including Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have renewed interest in nuclear power as a reliable alternative energy source to fossil fuels, and prices have once again risen, leading to greater competition for uranium resources. As with other resources such as oil, increasing demand collides geopolitics with economics. There is a risk that cost could trump resilience, locking nuclear power into fragile supply chains with potentially hostile actors and territories. Conversely it may provide a springboard for unlocking new supply chains with new producers, but this in turn could present wider ethical and environmental concerns, as with expanding extraction of cobalt and lithium have demonstrated, and as Niger exemplifies with uranium itself. New reserves of uranium recently discovered in China using a new remote sensing method may suggest that there are other new potential supplies out there, but again this expansion may help to keep uranium economically affordable but with significant environmental costs. Energy policies and their consequences for suppliers, regulators and societies may need careful consideration in the light of these developments around uranium to ensure that the same fragilities exposed by recent systemic shocks are not repeatedly built into fossil fuel alternative energy supplies.
Primary Article Title: Uranium risks becoming the next critical minerals crisis
Author: Fickling, D

Summary Sentence: Researchers have devised a process for producing ‘green hydrogen’ directly from moisture in the atmosphere.
Justification: &%23160;This process should interest the Environment Agency from a regulation perspective as it considers what potential impacts such technology could have on water resources, including abstraction and environmental processes, if scaled. Green hydrogen is generally accepted as hydrogen produced from using renewable energy sources to power electrolysis to split water into hydrogen and oxygen. Instead of using a liquid body of water, the researchers were able to achieve similar results from sourcing water molecules in the air. They used a hygroscopic electrolyte to absorb moisture from the air, which was tested in arid environments, where it performed satisfactorily. The scalable nature of the technology means that it could be deployed to provide green hydrogen fuel in dry and remote environments sustainably.
Primary Article Title: Scientists successfully turned thin air into green hydrogen for 12 days
Author: Paleja, A

Summary Sentence: There are signs that Europe is considering space solar energy more seriously.&%23160;
Justification: The director general of the European Space Agency (ESA) recently spoke about pushing “the envelope of technology” to help address terrestrial energy issues, off the back of two commissioned reports on space energy. Space-based solar power involves deploying solar panels into the Earth’s orbit, converting the energy captured into microwaves or lasers (%236751) which are broadcast to Earth before being converted back into usable energy (%2313658). While the concept is reasonably sound, the practicalities and potential impacts on the environment and biodiversity are less clear. Producing energy in this way could help relieve land use pressure from renewable energy schemes such as solar and wind which can be installed on land suited for food production, and therefore could be of interest to the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: Europe is seriously considering a major investment in space-based solar power
Author: Berger, E
Keywords: energy solar renewable space satellite microwave land wind regulation "European Space Agency" ESA&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A species of insecticide resistant mosquitos is leading to urban out brakes of malaria in parts of Africa.
Justification: The Environment Agency and wider DEFRA group should be aware of the impact that pesticide resistant insects could have on public health, agriculture and the potential application of alternative, harsher pesticides. The spread of non-native pest species is exacerbated by climate change which allows species to survive outside their normal range (%2315258). In addition, increased rates of flooding can create breeding habitats for pest species including mosquitos. Environment Agency staff could be exposed to invasive pest species in the course of their work and as such their spread should be carefully monitored. Recently, scientist have warned of an insecticide-resistant mosquito that has caused an unprecedented malaria outbreak in urban areas of Ethiopia during the dry season. Research into the outbreak has identified Anopheles stephensi as the culprit, a mosquito usually found in India and Iran, which is thought to have arrived in Africa in 2012. This species is able to resist some standard insecticides and survive all year, round, particularly in pools that have collected in human-made water storage containers often seen in urban neighbourhoods. Sarah Zohdy, from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said, “It could cause malaria to expand from a predominantly rural disease to a rural and urban challenge.”
Primary Article Title: Invasive mosquito could disrupt Africa’s ‘landscape of malaria’ after cases rise
Author: Lizzy Davies

Summary Sentence: A range of researchers and start-ups are working on gene editing to produce single gender litters or identify gender at egg stage in non-mammals.
Justification: This technology could be used in agriculture to control the gender of livestock and may require regulation by the Environment Agency. This could be game changing for animal welfare in agriculture and scientific research, reducing the number of animals of undesirable gender that need to be euthanised and disposed of. This could be in the lab, when individuals of the same sex are needed for experiments or in farming, where livestock of a particular gender are redundant. The proof-of concept study used CRISPR-Cas9 to edit the gametes of mice so that, upon fertilisation, male embryos (containing an X and Y chromosome, rather than XX) stop developing but female embryos develop normally. A separate start up is working on creating a method of genetically editing chickens to lay eggs that glow if the chick inside is of a particular gender. This would allow farmers to cull non-egg-laying male eggs before they hatch. Farmers usually have to wait until the chicks have hatched, at which time they can be sexed, and the un-needed males culled. These technologies will improve animal welfare as well as improve efficiency in farming; reducing resources used to produce animals that are not required as well as reducing the need for euthanising and disposal of these animals.
Primary Article Title: Gene editing could spare countless animals by creating single-sex litters
Author: Teresa Carey
Keywords: “Gene editing” CRISPR CRISPR-cas9 “Genetic engineering” Farming Research Agriculture Livestock “Lab animals” Breeding “Animal rights” “Animal welfare” “Gender control” “Single gender litter” “Single gender” Culling Euthanasia Disposal Waste Incineration “Biological waste”

Summary Sentence: Researchers in Japan have made progress towards commercial squid farming met.
Justification: Intensive squid farming would require regulation by DEFRA agencies and could be a source of water pollution, parasites and infectious disease. &%23160;Squid is an important source of protein but are notoriously difficult to farm due to aggression, specific food requirements and sensitivity to water flow. Smaller catches in recent years have been linked to rising sea surface temperatures. Farming of squid would reduce pressure on natural populations but could create an industry that requires careful regulation and there are concerns over animal welfare. Researchers found that “by keeping a single squid lineage for 10 generations in very restricted laboratory conditions… that squid aquaculture can work safely.” Animal rights campaigners are concerned that method would lead to undue suffering of sentient beings. Farming of carnivorous species also requires the extraction other marine species from already strained fisheries for use as food.
Primary Article Title: Japan makes squid farming breakthrough as wild catches plummet
Author: Justin McCurry
Keywords: Aquaculture “Squid farming” “Animal rights” “Animal welfare” Fishing Fisheries “Fish farming” Cephalopod Sentience “Ocean warming” “Climate change” “Global warming”

Summary Sentence: Researchers have achieved success in developing carbon capture processes which involve cheap and plentiful materials.&%23160;
Justification: Previously experiments with metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have shown promise but can lack realisation due to the relatively high cost of materials. Researchers at University of California, Berkeley have been experimenting with cheap and plentiful melamine as an alternative. They discovered that their melamine porous network captures carbon dioxide (CO2) as well as MOFs. Adding formaldehyde and cyanuric acid to the melamine polymerisation reaction increased the pore size, which significantly improved CO2 capture efficiency. In simulations nearly all CO2 was absorbed from a flue gas mixture. The cheap and scalable nature of producing the new material could mean that it can be applied to a range of situations, from industrial emissions down to individual vehicle exhausts. The Environment Agency as a regulator of carbon capture processes should be interested in considering the implications that innovations such as this could have on assumptions of operating costs of carbon capture as well as implications for resource use and waste management.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: A simple, cheap material for carbon capture, perhaps from tailpipes
Author: Sanders, R
Secondary_URLs: A scalable solid-state nanoporous network with atomic-level interaction design for carbon dioxide capture | Science Advances

Summary Sentence: A novel method has been described for carbon sequestration and utilisation that could contribute to net zero while creating useful bio-cement.
Justification: This new method could be utilised for carbon sequestration to help achieve net zero as well as production of functional biocement for use in construction activities but would need environmental consideration and regulation. Oceans sequester carbon through several naturally occurring carbon dioxide removal (CDR) processes, one of which includes microorganisms that utilize dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) in their metabolic processes. The recent publication examines the capacity of utilising ocean chemistry and ecology to increase rate of dissolution of CO2 which can then be precipitated and used as a functional material. In a closed system a ‘bipolar membrane electrodialysis’ (BPME) manipulates seawater pH. Cyanobacteria are grown in low pH water, leading to increased CO2 uptake as they photosynthesise. High pH water created by the BPME is then used to precipitate the carbon (using microbes as nucleation seeds) which can then be removed from the water via sedimentation and filtration and used for biocement.
Primary Article Title: Biocement from the ocean&%2358; Hybrid microbial-electrochemical mineralization of CO2
Author: Atsu Kludze
Keywords: Biocement “Carbon sequestration” “Carbon utilisation” “Net zero” “Alternative material” “Carbon removal” “Ocean chemistry” “Dissolved inorganic carbon” “Ocean carbon”

Summary Sentence: A Dutch Court has ruled that demanding employees turn on their webcams is a human rights violation.
Justification: The Environment Agency should consider the result of this hearing when setting policies for home working. This court hearing could feed in to the ‘back to the office’ narrative being pushed by some businesses and also raises questions around the balance between employee productivity and ethics of monitoring home workers. In the hearing, Florida based company Chetu demanded a Dutch employee turned on their webcam for monitoring purposes for the full “9-hour workday.” When they refused to do so they were fired for what the company stated was “refusal to work” and “insubordination.” The Dutch court however ruled that “instructions to keep the webcam turned on is in conflict with the respect for the privacy of the workers.” In its verdict, the court goes so far as to suggest that demanding webcam surveillance is a human rights violation. The verdict sets a precedent for the level of employee monitoring that is considered ethical in Europe. It also highlights the disparity in employee privacy and wellbeing in different parts of the world. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: The Dutch court stated that “Tracking via camera for 8 hours per day is disproportionate and not permitted in the Netherlands,”
Author: Haje Jan Kamps
Keywords: Privacy Monitoring Home-working Productivity Webcam Ethics Wellbeing Welfare Surveillance “Webcam surveillance” “Employee rights” “Unfair dismissal” ”Human rights” “Fundamental freedom” Autonomy

Summary Sentence: Researchers have made a nanomaterial from seaweed that is effective at separating battery components.
Justification: This work could facilitate the development of sodium-metal batteries which would shorten supply chains, reduce reliance on rare earth elements such as lithium and cobalt, as well as enable the transition to electric vehicles and renewable energy. One of the major stumbling blocks to the development of sodium-metal batteries is uncontrolled dendrite growth, which penetrate the battery’s separator and result in short-circuiting. The team of researchers from Bristol and University College London used brown seaweed to produce cellulose nanomaterials. Fibres containing these seaweed-derived nanomaterials not only stop crystals from the sodium electrodes penetrating the separator, they also improve the performance of the batteries. First author Jing Wang said “We have shown that seaweed-based materials can make the separator very strong and prevent it being punctured by metal structures made from sodium. It also allows for greater storage capacity and efficiency, increasing the lifetime of the batteries.” Upscaling the production of these nanomaterials and integrating them into manufacturing processes will be the next step for the researchers.
Primary Article Title: Seaweed-based battery powers confidence in sustainable energy storage
Keywords: Nanomaterials Seaweed Battery Technology “Alternative materials” “Sodium-metal batteries” Dendrite ”Battery separator” Cellulose “Battery performance” “Battery efficiency” “Storage capacity” Energy “Energy storage”

Summary Sentence: Signs of the menopause being recognised in employment legislation are emerging.
Justification: The Environment Agency often positions itself at the forefront of changes to workforce conditions, so should be interested in this development. As Europe continues to experience an ageing demographic there is a need to recognise the health and wellbeing issues that come with an ageing workforce. While other biological phenomena are increasing recognised in legislature, such as Spain recently introducing menstrual leave (%2315296), the menopause has until recently been a subject of stigma. The physical and mental impacts of the menopause can include hot flushes, night sweats, insomnia, fatigue, anxiety, mood changes and ‘brain fog’, all of which could impact on workplace performance and wellbeing. Some of these symptoms can have a debilitating effect for years. Currently no European country has policies to address the impact of the menopause in the workplace, such as menopausal leave. However some are taking steps to address this. A group of UK MPs are campaigning for the menopause to be a protected chracteristic, recognising that failing to address the issue in the workplace could push talented women out of work, &%23160;after a report showed the UK is currently “haemorrhaging talent”. The report also called for government to amend the Equality Act accordingly to include a duty for employers to provide reasonable adjustments for menopausal employees. It also called for a pilot menopausal leave scheme to be trialled in the public sector. As with similar situations there is great potential for the Environment Agency to embrace changing approaches to menopausal leave early and lay the foundations for its introduction. There are also potential risks to privacy, equality, recruitment and progression if its implementation does not happen in the right way, impacting negatively on workplace demographics.
Primary Article Title: Menopause leave&%2358; Is it time for new legal rights to break the stigma in the workplace?
Author: Carbonaro, G

Summary Sentence: A Nigerian company has developed a process for converting urine into a hydrogen rich flammable gas that can be used for cooking and energy generation in off-grid locations.
Justification: The Environment Agency may be interested to consider the regulatory implications of this process. The patent for the process was granted in 2014, and since then the company, called Lumos Laboratories, have been partnering with the Nigerian government to develop real world applications of the technology, which can also be used to convert urine waste into flammable gases and biomethane. Byproducts are also used to manufacture flame resistant paints. The technology is currently being applied to waste from correctional facilities to enable them to produce their own energy and cooking gas while at the same time reducing the impact of human waste on the local area. It is calculated that the potential of this technology from the quantity of animal waste Nigeria generates could produce over 10,000 Megawatts of electricity, though the practicalities of achieving this are not discussed. A Canadian company recently acquired Lumos, suggesting wider deployment could occur. Urine has previously shown potential as a construction material (%2314761) and agricultural fertiliser (%2312331), providing that an adequate means of separation and collection can be achieved. However urine has been shown to carry some persistent substances (%2313564), which could mean that any waste generated from using urine in this way may need regulating. Using urine and biowaste in this manner could also mean a decentralisation of energy production, particularly at farm level in a similar manner to aerobic digestion (AD), which already falls under Environment Agency regulations, suggesting additional regulatory burden.
Primary Article Title: Generating electricity, cooking gas from urine, biodegradable waste
Author: Onyedika-Ugoeze, N

Summary Sentence: A floating transportable ‘blowhole’ is generating electricity for the Australian energy grid.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in the potential of this concept and how its potential implications on coastal flood management and other marine activities. The wave power generator is located offshore of King Island, Tasmania, and is made by Melbourne based Wave Swell Energy. The generator doesn’t have moving parts. Instead it sits on the sea bed and uses the natural movement of waves in and out of its chamber to push air up and through a turbine, mimicking the process observed at a natural blowhole. A similar design is also being trialled in Scotland. The company is looking to scale up its current design to produce more power. The concept can also be incorporated into static situations, such as in sea walls, combining coastal flood and erosion protection with power generation, which may be of interest to the Environment Agency when constructing hard flood defences. Wave power technology has some advantages over solar and wind in that it isn't reliant on particular weather conditions. The mobile nature of the blowhole also suggests that it could provide a solution to temporary energy in coastal situations, should other infrastructure be unavailable, and therefore may have some application in incident management.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: The wave power generator experts say 'proves ocean energy can work' is already powering Australian homes
Author: Moran, J
Keywords: energy flooding flood defence blowhole tidal wave electricity power generator Australia "King Island" Tasmania Melbourne "Wave Swell Energy" Scotland concrete incident infrastructure

Summary Sentence: A new UK poll suggests that the majority of young people wouldn’t be prepared to work for a company that profited from unsustainable business practices.
Justification: This suggests that employers who are able to clearly demonstrate sustainable business practices could be an attractive career proposition for younger recruits, suggesting a tactical direction for Environment Agency recruitment. The survey, conducted by a business software development company, found that of those surveyed 68 per cent believed it was important for their employer to act sustainably, and 44 per cent wanted to see a clear demonstration of sustainability across all business activities. Over half of employees also said that they would be more likely to work for an employer who can provide tools and resources for them to practise sustainability. However, pay remains the most attractive job feature for most surveyed, including young people.
Primary Article Title: Quarter of young people don’t want to work for firms with unsustainable practices
Author: Franklin, N
Keywords: workforce employment employee employer recruitment young demographic sustainable sustainability operation

Summary Sentence: A publication on the ‘Ecological Limits of Work’ argues that shorter working weeks would reduce greenhouse gas emissions and could be implemented in such a way that productivity is not disproportionately reduced.
Justification: The concept is useful for the Environment Agency to consider for its own net zero goals as well as from a regulated business and advisory perspective. Reduced hours also tackles “individual wellbeing, productivity and gender equality whilst simultaneously potentially contributing to a reduction in unemployment.” Based on published data “a 1 percent decrease in working hours could lead to a 0.8 percent decrease in GHG emissions… the climate crisis calls for an unprecedented decrease in the economic activity, this confronts us with, to adapt Paul Lafargue’s phrase, the ‘necessity to be lazy’.” The paper focuses on the emissions produced per industry in each economy but does not take into account other environmental advantages of reducing working hours, from less commuting to fewer goods produced and resources used. Shorter working weeks also potentially mean that work would be more evenly distributed, lowering unemployment rates, while reducing stress levels and improving productivity. Plus, businesses looking to automate some of their processes could do so without firing staff, meaning the British economy could develop without a negative social impact.
Primary Article Title: The Ecological Limits of Work&%2358; on carbon emissions, carbon budgets and working time
Author: Philipp Frey
Secondary_URLs:

Summary Sentence: A Japanese firm have developed a solar powered device that is attached to cockroaches and allows researchers to control their behaviour remotely.
Justification: The Environment Agency could use such devices to aid survey work, such as identifying infrastructure damage in inaccessible pipework but should consider ethical issues involved in using live insects in this way. Potential uses include searching for survivors trapped in rubble and collecting data in hazardous zones. The device was developed by researchers at the state-backed Riken research institute and consists of an ultrathin solar cell film and small circuit board controller. Despite the attached electronic components, the Madagascan cockroaches could still move freely as the team interleaved adhesive and non-adhesive sections onto the solar cell films to accommodate the insects' natural movement. The solar cell supplies electricity to the wireless control module attached to the thorax and applies electrical stimulation to a sensory organ called the cercus at the rearmost segment of the insects. Currently a 30-minute charge allows only around two minutes of remote-control capacity. Future developments could include the control of other insects such as those necessary for pollination. No mention of ethical considerations are made in the research publication.
Primary Article Title: Japan-led researchers develop rechargeable cyborg cockroach
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.nature.com/articles/s41528-022-00207-2
Keywords: Cyborg “Behaviour control” “Machine brain interface” “Brain chip” “Solar film” “Cyborg insects” “Remote control” “Ultrathin file electronics” Electronics “Remote control device” “Search and rescue” “Remote control”

Summary Sentence: The prospect of cryopreservation appears to be gaining plausibility with a number of academics working on the development of freezing and thawing processes for organ preservation with a view to move on to small mammals
Justification: The progression of cryobiology technologies could be revolutionary and would lead to new regulated industry, such as the farming of animals for organs that can be indefinitely cryo-frozen. It does seem almost impossible today. The field of cryobiology is not standing still. Cryopreserved human oocytes, sperm, and fertilized embryos have been used for years in successful in vitro fertilization births. One of the major problems in freezing organs and living systems is the formation of ice crystals – something which is being addressed by researchers. Development of cryoprotective agents (CPAs) that prevent the formation of ice crystals is the focus of many cryobiology research groups. Prof Gao from University of Washington's Centre for Cryo-Biomedical Engineering and Artificial Organs believes that “converging the current technologies in cryoprotecants, vitrification, isochoric cryopreservation, rapid rewarming, and noble gas chemistry, in 3-5 years will enable the first “killer experiments”. In cryo, the equivalent of the ImageNet moment in deep learning would be an experiment where a small mammal would be cryogenically preserved and later unfrozen with minimal damage.”
Primary Article Title: The Spring Of Cryobiology&%2358; One Enabling Technology That Will Help Build The New Industry Of The Future
Author: Alex Zhavoronkov
Keywords: Cryo Cryobiology Cryopreservation “Cryogenic freezing” Cryogenic Biomedicine “Biomedical engineering” “Organ preservation” Medicine “Medical technology” Resurrection

Summary Sentence: Increasing numbers of Chinese Scientists based at U.S Universities are returning to China due to heightened US-China tensions.
Justification: Increased isolation between ‘western’ and Chinese institutions has the potential to reduce access to technological innovation that would be useful to the Environment Agency. &%23160;China’s growing importance in the field of science and innovation, along with associated security concerns is highlighted in the 2021 Integrated Review from the Cabinet Office. The report states ‘Cooperation with China will (also) be vital in tackling transnational challenges, particularly climate change and biodiversity loss.’ More than 1,400 U.S.-trained Chinese scientists dropped their U.S. academic or corporate affiliation for a Chinese one in 2021, a 22% jump from the previous year, according to data gathered by researchers from Princeton University, Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Chinese scientists trained in the U.S. have returned to China in increasing numbers over the past two decades as the country has grown more affluent and gained stature as a centre of scientific research. In the past decade, China has tried to recruit top researchers through talent programs, but historically the majority elected to stay in the U.S. Departures from the U.S. rose sharply starting in 2020, however, when the Covid-19 pandemic coincided with an increase in criminal cases filed against academics under the China Initiative, a Trump-era Justice Department program intended to counter national security threats from China. In addition to this, there have been reports that Chinese companies are struggling to recruit foreign talent following strict covid lockdowns (%2315247). This pattern could increase isolation between Chinese and western businesses and universities, reducing much needed cooperation. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: U.S.-China Tensions Fuel Outflow of Chinese Scientists From U.S. Universities
Author: Sha Hua and Karen Hao

Summary Sentence: Several successful medical trials involving different types of brain-computer interface have been published recently. &%23160;
Justification: The hope is that such devices could eventually be used to treat disorders such as depression and anxiety. This could improve staff welfare and reduce problems with pharmaceuticals entering water courses. In one trial, a pacemaker-like device was implanted in the brain in order to help reduce food cravings. In the study, surgeons implanted a device deep in the brain that learned to detect when the patients had food cravings, and then deliver a small zap to the brain to lessen the craving. This device is wired to the nucleus accumbens, an area of the brain that plays a vital role in how people experience reward and satisfaction. In a separate study, part funded by Facebook, a neuroprosthetic device has successfully translated the brain waves of a paralyzed man into complete sentences. Over several months, the team recorded his neural activity as he attempted to say 50 words and used artificial intelligence to distinguish subtle patterns in the data and tie them to words. Decoding of the complex brainwaves associated to speech is an important technological milestone in this field. Development of brain-computer interfaces could eventually be used to treat conditions such as depression and anxiety. They could also be used by commercial companies to develop augmented reality systems offering new ways of working and interacting (%2314957). Past work has used brain implants to treat epilepsy and decrease Parkinson’s related tremors.
Primary Article Title: Experimental brain surgery quelled cravings in 2 people with binge eating disorder
Author: Erika Edwards

Summary Sentence: Scientists can now coordinate swarms of flying drones to build structures on the wing.
Justification: As this technology develops, the Environment Agency could begin to utilise this it to facilitate construction in isolated or inaccessible areas as well potentially automating infrastructure repairs in future. The next step in 3D printing for construction, researchers in Switzerland and the UK have developed a method of controlling drones in tandem to allow creation of 3D structures. &%23160;The fleet consists of “BuilDrones”, which deposit materials during flight, and quality-controlling “ScanDrones” that measure their output and help control them. BuilDrones alter their movements based on feedback from the ScanDrones. 3D printing is becoming more mainstream in building projects (%2315272) but requires the instillation and set up of a lot of hardware. The use of drones as vehicles for 3D printing creates a more mobile, flexible system.
Primary Article Title: Scientists can now build structures with swarms of flying drones
Author: David Rogers
Keywords: Drones Construction “3D printing” “Automated construction” “Drone swarms” Technology Automation

Summary Sentence: Researchers have created ‘artificial leaves’ which use sunlight and water to create syngas.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be aware of this as a product that would require careful regulation before and during deployment. Cambridge University researchers have developed a light weight, floating, solar power device that can be used to generate clean fuels from sunlight and water. In theory these devices could float on ponds, canals, or other waterways to generate fuel where it is needed, while at the same time reducing evaporation. The prototype uses two light absorbers and several catalysts to convert water into hydrogen and oxygen or reduce CO2 to syngas. Syngas can be used as a key intermediate in the production of many chemicals and pharmaceuticals. The device bridges the gulf in weight between traditional solar fuel approaches, allowing for floating systems that could enable open-water applications, thus avoiding competition with land use. While additional improvements are needed before the leaves are ready for commercial applications, the researchers say this development opens whole new avenues in their work.
Primary Article Title: Floating ‘artificial leaves’ ride the wave of clean fuel production
Author: Sarah Collins
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-04978-6
Keywords: Solar Syngas Energy Renewable ‘Green energy’ Photosynthesis Hydrogen ‘Floating solar’

Summary Sentence: NASA and the Department of Energy (DOE) have awarded three companies $5 million each to make it possible to put nuclear power on the moon by 2031.
Justification: Lunar nuclear reactors would likely generate geopolitical problems as well as increase the risk of technological and environmental damage should a nuclear incident occur. Increasing commercial and governmental activity in space has led to increased risks from space junk with the potential to impact satellite technology and other functions. Through its Artemis missions, NASA plans to return humans to the moon as soon 2025. This time, it wants to establish a long-term presence there, so astronauts have plenty of time to explore the lunar surface and conduct research that could one day help us reach Mars. Astronauts will need a reliable source of power while on the moon, and while solar panels can help meet that need, they won’t work during the long lunar nights or underground — and subterranean lava tubes are among the moon’s most scientifically intriguing features. The reactors would need to be lightweight and capable of continuously providing astronauts with 40 kilowatts of power — enough for 30 households here on Earth — for 10 years. They would also need to be ready for an actual demonstration on the moon by 2031. The three companies - IX, Westinghouse, and Lockheed Martin – must further develop their submitted design concepts over the next 12 months.
Primary Article Title: NASA is closer than ever to generating nuclear power on the moon
Author: Kristin Houser
Keywords: Space “Space exploration” “Multi-planet species” Nuclear “Nuclear power” Lunar Moon NASA

Summary Sentence: ‘Quantum sensors’ for biological measurements is emerging as a new field for investigation of fundamental biological processes.
Justification: Novel environmental sensors could be useful for both Environment Agency monitoring (for example the detection/ characterisation of micropolutants) and for regulated industry (such as detecting leaks in water pipes). “Quantum gravity sensors could also guide environmental work like carbon sequestration, spot threats like magma flows, and uncover new minerals and water resources.” Quantum sensors use a range of quantum phenomena to measure extremely small changes in the environment. Although very much in the early stages, these sensors have the potential to detect biological processes at scales inaccessible with conventional techniques. Uses include nano-scale measurements of biomolecules such as proteins as well as gravity sensors that can detect (theoretically) all the way to centre of the earth.
Primary Article Title: Biocompatible surface functionalization architecture for a diamond quantum sensor

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed an upcycling approach that adds value to discarded plastics for reuse in additive manufacturing, or 3D printing.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be aware of this novel method of recycling and increasing the lifetime of plastics due to the potential to reduce plastic waste. The readily adoptable, scalable method introduces a closed-loop strategy that could globally reduce plastic waste and cut carbon emissions tied to plastic production. Researchers at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory have applied "click" chemistry to convert the chemical makeup of ABS into a ‘vitrimer.’ Vitrimers are a class of renewable plastics, which are derived from thermosetting polymers. This type of polymer combines the processability and recyclability of thermoplastics with the superior mechanochemical properties of thermosets, such as epoxy. The synthesis uses widely available medical compounds that are mixed in a single step under mild conditions, followed by curing with heat. Results show upcycled ABS achieved approximately double the toughness and strength of standard ABS, with enhanced solvent resistance. The processed ABS can be used in fused filament fabrication and overcomes the major challenge of “(re)printing cross-linked materials and produces stronger, tougher, solvent-resistant three-dimensional objects directly reprintable and separable from unsorted plastic waste”. This process offers a significant step towards a circular plastic economy.
Primary Article Title: Closed-loop additive manufacturing fuelled&%23160;by upcycled plastic
Author: Ashley C Huff

Summary Sentence: There is a growing trend in the open-source software development community of including sabotage code, known as ‘protestware’, which can be activated if the developer feels it is justified.
Justification: Open-source code is used in commercial apps and software (including data analysis packages like R and Python) and protestware could interrupt Environment Agency operations. By adding a ‘self-destruct’ mechanism into their software, developers can at any point sabotage anyone who is using their code. This allows them to corrupt applications that use their code if they feel it us being used unethically or inappropriately. For example, developer Marak Squires intentionally corrupted his own work to send a message of protest to big corporations after Log4Shell security flaw burdened project maintainers, mostly open-source volunteers, with patching the critical vulnerability over the December holidays. More recently coders have modified the popular project node-ipc code (scripts that deal with the management of shared data) so that is wipes the computers of suspected Russian and Belarusian developers in protest of the invasion of Ukraine. There are concerns that this trend may signal the end of open-source software (OSS) as people lose trust in the community, however, the foundations of countless organizations’ systems and products run on OSS. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: Protestware on the rise&%2358; Why developers are sabotaging their own code
Author: Ax Sharma
Secondary_URLs: Protestware - How node-ipc turned into malware | LunaSec
Keywords: OSS “Open source” Open-source Software Protestware Sabotage Apps “Sabotage code” Developers Coders

Summary Sentence: A researcher from Sweden used an AI algorithm known as GPT-3 to write an academic thesis about itself.
Justification: As AI gets better at producing content in response to a command, the risk of convincing misinformation created by bots increases as well as the automation of more complex tasks like journalism or scientific writing. GPT-3 is well known for its ability to create humanlike text, but it’s not perfect. Even so, it has written a news article, produced books in 24 hours and created new content from deceased authors. Similar algorithms are used by tech companies for chat-boxes and autocomplete services, but the companies that create these algorithms are secretive about their inner-workings. AI has been flagged in the past for exacerbating inequality by analysing overly simplified, real-world data that over looks more nuanced factors. For example, an algorithm used to predict whether criminals were likely to re-offend was found to be heavily biased against black people leading to black people receiving much harsher sentencing. AI is also getting better at modelling human behaviour. Even simple algorithms are able to adjust the content that you see based on things you have interacted with in the past. Coupling this with an ability to generate text leads to a concerning possibility that AI could generate addictive content that feeds a person’s world view by creating reports that confirm their biases. Concerns over the use of AI text generation continue to grow as the sophistication of the AI increases.
Primary Article Title: We Asked GPT-3 to Write an Academic Paper about Itself—Then We Tried to Get It Published
Author: Almira Osmanovic Thunström

Summary Sentence: A new survey of young people in the UK suggests that evidence of commitment to sustainability is an important consideration in choosing an employer.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency may wish to consider how its own values and practices could be used to attract new talent during recruitment. A quarter of ‘Generation Z’ (18 - 24) surveyed in a recent poll by PLAY said that they wouldn’t work for a business that profits from unsustainable practices. Over two thirds felt that employers needed to be committed to sustainability and nearly half wanted businesses to demonstrate sustainability initiatives. This figure was higher with older employees and as high as 84 per cent for people working in IT. The data also suggests that employers could attract and retain talent with genuine commitment to sustainable practices. However salary, benefits and convenient office location still came out as the most attractive job features with young people.
Primary Article Title: Quarter of young people don’t want to work for firms with unsustainable practices
Author: Franklin, N
Keywords: workforce employment sustainability employer business salary recruitment values retention "Generation Z"

Summary Sentence: Numerous organisations have been experimenting with alternatives to the typical five-day, 40 hour weeks in attempts to improve staff wellbeing without compromising productivity.
Justification: The Environment Agency should consider emerging work-force trends, both to attract new talent and to improve staff welfare and productivity, particularly for neurodivergent people. An alternative to reducing the number of days worked per week is reducing the number of hours worked per day. The 4-hour workday is based on the premise that people are only truly productive for a certain number of hours each day, and that trying to work beyond that is counterintuitive. One study of UK office workers concluded that a majority of workers are only productive for two hours and 53 minutes per day. Proponents of the 4-hour workday believe that people should work when their energy is at its peak, and they should focus on a single task. The 40-hour working week can be seen as a relic from the industrial revolution when most work was manual. But this routine is nonsensical when work is largely cognitive. In recent times, work culture in many fields has led to people working long hours, either because of the logic that that more hours guarantees more work or out of a desire to show ambition and drive. However, pilot tests of the short working day have indicated that productivity actually increases with several recent studies indicating that workers’ focus and productivity tend to plunge after about five hours of work. In Europe, the Netherlands, Denmark and Norway have the shortest working week, with an average of 32.7 hours per week against the standard average of 40 hours per week in 2021. All three countries rank among the top countries in the world with the highest levels of productivity. The four-day work week has long been proposed to improve staff welfare, increase productivity and benefit the environment (%237978). Trials of four-day working weeks have been hailed as successes, with employees given the opportunity jumping at the chance to have an extra day to themselves (%2315217, %2315270). However, the Spanish company Telefonica struggled to get staff to sign up to their four-day scheme. Reasons suggested include the fact that Telefonica’s scheme came with a reduced salary. It’s also suggested that younger employees may reject the voluntary scheme as it could be viewed as counterproductive to progression, whereas older employees would be more comfortable with the compromise. The Centre for Cities think tank is also expecting post-pandemic experiments in working practices to recede, with five-day office weeks to becoming the norm again by the middle of 2023.
Primary Article Title: The 4-Hour Workday&%2358; Why You Should Only Work 4 Hours Instead of 8?
Author: Akash Peshin

Summary Sentence: Rice University mechanical engineers have repurposed an inanimate spider as a ready-to-use actuator requiring only a single facile fabrication step, initiating the area of “necrobotics.”
Justification:
Of relevance to the Environment Agency as a low-cost, biodegradable and simple to produce device as well as the possible regulation concerns around the production and use of insects for the emerging field of ‘necrobotics.’ Researchers have illustrated how to use deceased spiders as mechanical grippers that can blend into natural environments while picking up objects, like other insects, that outweigh them. This new field of necrobotics, in which biotic materials are used as robotic components, utilises designs perfected through evolution to perform simple mechanical tasks. The lab specializes in soft robotic systems that often use non-traditional materials, as opposed to hard plastics, metals and electronics. Deceased arthropods act as a readymade articulating form that is easier to produce than constructing a synthetic mechanical gripper of the same scale. Potential uses include pick-and-place tasks, repetitive tasks like sorting or moving objects around at these small scales, and maybe even assembly of microelectronics or deploying it to capture smaller insects in nature, because it’s inherently camouflaged. The wolf spider gripper produced for this research can lift 1.3 times its own weight, exert a peak gripping force of 0.35 millinewton, and can actuate at least 700 times before the limbs or the valve system start to degrade in any significant way. The researchers think that by coating the spider in something like beeswax, they could likely forestall this breakdown a great deal.

&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A new video calling device could replace cashiers with low paid, remotely connected ‘virtual cashier.’
Justification: The Environment Agency could use similar systems and outsource some tasks to remote workers abroad as a cost saving mechanism but would need to consider security and ethical implications. Percy, the “virtual cashier” was tested by the Canadian fast-food franchise Freshii and now has more than a dozen clients in North America and employs nearly 100 workers in Nicaragua, Pakistan and Bolivia. A real person, physically located at a call centre in a low-income country takes your order via webcam. These remote workers are paid as little as $3.75 an hour; Freshii’s in-person servers make at least $12 an hour. Despite Freshii giving people in developing countries jobs that pay slightly above the domestic minimum wage, there is concern that this new technology amounts to “exploitation.” Freshii argues that “Unlike a kiosk or a pre-ordering app, which removes human jobs entirely, Percy allows for the face-to-face customer experience that restaurant owners and operators want to provide their guests, by mobilizing a global and eager workforce.” While Amazon’s till-less grocery stores use a combination of sensors, cameras and AI to monitor an individual’s movement and automate their payment, Percy offers a low budget, easily installed way of outsourcing labour instead. While it might be true that this system offers an alternative to automation, it will certainly impact the availability of low-skill jobs, disproportionately affecting young and low-income workers.
Primary Article Title: At Freshii, your ‘virtual cashier’ is actually a person working for $3.75 per hour

Summary Sentence: Multiple articles are reporting on a concerning increase in the frequency and sophistication of cyber-attacks, including one that caused physical damage at a steel plant.
Justification: Due to the increase in cyber-attacks, including an attack that caused a fire at a steel plant in Iran, the Environment Agency should consider their role in the cyber security of the businesses they regulate. Vulnerabilities in the hardware and software used in regulated industry could be utilised by hackers to cause physical damage, including potentially causing a major incident. Currently cyber security is the responsibility of individual businesses, who may lack technical knowledge or awareness of their cyber vulnerabilities. Enforcing a basic level of cyber security would benefit both the business and the Environment Agency. Multiple articles have reported on the recent increase in frequency and sophistication of cyber-attacks with personalised ‘spear’ phishing scams also on the rise. At the same time a hacker collective known as ‘Predatory Sparrow’ recently caused physical damage to an Iranian steel plant. Many companies that suffer cyber-attacks do not report them to authorities in order to avoid reputational damage. Even so, since the beginning the Ukraine war, Bulgaria has had to block about 50,000 IP addresses and 500 domains from Russia and Belarus, from which hacker attacks were attempted. The Polish Prime Minister’s Office recently reported a rising number of DDoS attacks against Polish institutions and domestic entities. In addition, data from Google Safe Browsing shows there are now nearly 75 times as many phishing sites as there are malware sites on the internet. Almost 20% of all employees are likely to click on phishing email links, and, of those, a staggering 68% go on to enter their credentials on a phishing website. A report by Accenture business consultancy states that “NATO countries can also expect an increase in cyber-attacks and may target government bodies or critical infrastructure.”
Primary Article Title: Predatory Sparrow&%2358; Who are the hackers who say they started a fire in Iran?
Author: Joe Tudy

Summary Sentence: Biotech company Fixed Earth is trialling a method using lab-grown bacteria injected into soil to break down PFAS chemicals.
Justification: The Environment Agency should monitor developing technologies that could be used to remove damaging PFAS from the environment. Although Fixed Earth are not sharing the details of the bacteria used, this could be considered a next step from the PFAS digesting bacteria discovered by Princeton researchers (%2315144). Fixed Earth is 10 weeks into a pilot “bioremediation” project using the bacterium it found living in the soil there. Litres of the bacteria are grown in the lab, then injected back into the ground along with an absorbent material. Some of the firm’s injection wells have seen a greater than 99 per cent reduction across all the PFAS chemicals they can measure at the site, including PFOS and PFOA. The bacteria perform better when oxygen is available, so the company is also pulsing electricity through the soil at the injection wells. The electricity splits water molecules, releasing hydrogen and oxygen. The reduction in PFAS contamination at wells without the electrical treatment is around 60 per cent. Existing methods to deal with PFAS contamination are expensive and inadequate, including physically moving contaminated soil to a landfill site, where it can leach out. Incineration is another option, although this produces toxic hydrogen fluoride gas. Existing methods are especially impractical for sites with low concentrations of PFAS. Often called forever chemicals, PFAS have been found in drinking water (%2314130) and in people’s blood all over the world. Some types have been linked to health issues like kidney disease, cancer and severe covid-19. In Maine, there are reports of farmers dumping milk due to PFAS contamination from fertiliser.
Primary Article Title: Biotech firm electrocutes soil so bacteria can eat ‘forever chemicals’
Author: James Dinneen
Keywords: PFAS PFOA PFOS “Forever chemicals” Bioremediation Biotechnology Contamination “PFAS digestion” Bacteria “Bacterial breakdown” “Persistent environmental contaminants”

Summary Sentence: Researchers have quantified the financial damage caused by a nation’s emissions, with the US calculated as having inflicted $2tn of damage on other countries.
Justification: The Environment Agency as a regulator of polluting industries might be held partially accountable for the $245bn of damages caused by UK emissions. The UK is number 11 on the list of most damaging countries and given that there is a move toward holding companies and governments accountable for their carbon emissions (%2315244, %2315116) it is possible that the UK government might one day have to pay compensation. The research hopes to “lift the veil of deniability” by combining historical data with climate models of varying complexity in an integrated framework to quantify each nation’s culpability for historical temperature-driven income changes in every other country. The Dartmouth researchers combined a number of different models, showing factors such as emissions, local climate conditions and economic changes, to ascertain the precise impact of an individual country’s contribution to the climate crisis. They looked for these links over a period spanning 1990 to 2014. Quantitatively assessing individual nations facilitates conversations around equity-based compensation for the damages caused. It can also inform legal discussions around liability claims. Greenhouse gasses have caused harm to other, mostly poor, countries through increased climate volatility, causing a range of damage including heatwaves, crop failures and powerful storms. Wealthy nations, especially those in northerly latitudes such as the UK and USA have disproportionally contributed to emissions but have not yet been severely harmed by it. The research excluded factors not included in GDP, such as biodiversity loss, cultural harm and deaths from disasters, meaning the damage is, in reality, far greater.
Primary Article Title: Nearly $2tn of damage inflicted on other countries by US emissions
Author: Oliver Milman
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10584-022-03387-y
Keywords: “Climate crisis” “Climate change” “Climate damage” “Greenhouse gas” Emissions “Climate accountability” Liability Compensation “Financial cost” “Economic damage” “Economic compensation”

Summary Sentence: Carbon removal with kelp farms in Maine can threaten interconnected coastal and ocean ecosystems.
Justification: Running Tide, an aquaculture business venture in Maine, use floating kelp farms to remove carbon from the atmosphere and entice businesses to purchase blue carbon credit from them.&%23160;The Environment Agency should be aware of the potential risk to biodiversity and delicate interconnected coastal ecosystems from engaging in sequestering blue carbon in this way. Running Tide states that their nature-based solution provides an initiative for mitigating climate change, and that this is an excellent tool for the carbon market. Carbon sequestration is realised with the help of tens of thousands of small, floating kelp rafts, the growing kelp captures carbon and eventually sinks after six to eight months, taking the carbon to the ocean floor for ever. Critics of this carbon-removal initiative claim that there is not enough research about the possible harmful effects, that this activity is novel and hence poorly regulated, and that Running Tide is not taking ecological concerns seriously enough. Some of their practices such as ocean fertilisation are highly controversial as they add nutrients to the ocean to stimulate macroalgal growth. Nevertheless, Iceland has just signed a five-year contract with Running Tide to follow Maine’s example. Further scrutiny is required to study the seaweed raft related activities and their impact on ocean ecosystems, especially as with Running Tide’s ambitious plans and commitment for carbon sequestration there is potential for the activities to scale up to large areas.
Primary Article Title: Running Tide is facing scientist departures and growing concerns over seaweed sinking for carbon removal

Summary Sentence: A semi-amphibious bus can become a rescue vehicle for flash flooding emergencies.
Justification: A design competition for future mobility has received a proposal for a novel type of adaptable vehicle that can be used as a bus in peace time but altered to become a semi-amphibious emergency vehicle during flash floods.&%23160;This is relevant to Environment Agency as a first responder to flood incidents as this type of multipurpose vehicle could be added to their fleet for use in incident management. The aesthetically pleasing vehicle called an Estuary Hopper was designed for the Gloucestershire floodplains as a multipurpose vehicle; used as a bus day-to-day but, when River Severn floods, it can be quickly converted to help members of public. Its amphibious chassis can adjust to changing water levels, the tyres can grip on waterlogged ground and other surfaces, exterior pontoons can be utilised, and its roof can mount a rescue boat. The vehicle has foldable seats that allow space for luggage under normal circumstances but during flooding can create space for wheelchairs or stretchers.
Primary Article Title: Jordan Barnes designs semi-amphibious bus that can double as emergency vehicle during floods

Summary Sentence: Inactive yeast could provide a simple, inexpensive and abundant material for removing lead and other heavy metals from water.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this research into discarded brewer’s yeast as it could provide innovative water treatment processes that may also have application in remediation and incident management. Lead and other heavy metals can make significant contributions to water pollution, impacting on wildlife and human health through their persistence and bioaccumulation. Researchers studying the properties of S. cerevisiae (widely used in brewing, and a waste product currently discarded at the end of the brewing process), found that it was able to remove even trace amounts of lead from water through biosorption. The same process could also be configured for targeting the removal of other heavy metals, such as cadmium and copper, with further research. A process to separate the lead from the yeast for recovery and re-use is also in development. It is envisaged that the yeast could be used in some kind of filter to remove lead from drinking water, but it is also possible to envisage some kind of configuration being used for remediation purposes, such as mine water, or as part of the recovery stage of a pollution incident.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Could used beer yeast be the solution to heavy metal contamination in water?
Author: Chandler, D L
Secondary_URLs: Lead removal at trace concentrations from water by inactive yeast cells | Communications Earth & Environment (nature.com)

Summary Sentence: Spain is piloting a programme called 'proMETEO Seville' which aims to alert the public of the impacts of extreme heat waves.
Justification: Seville in Spain is now the first city in the world to give names to heat waves, rank them by severity and keep records in a similar way to how treat storms. The aim is to increase public awareness of the severity of this threat and guide them on what actions they should take. This is relevant to Environment Agency as this weather warning system is the first of its kind, linking weather and human health with a view to build resilience and offer resources people can use to protect themselves. ProMETEO Seville was developed collaboratively in partnership with the Arsht-Rock’s Extreme Heat Resilience Alliance and a network of other academic and meteorology partners. It uses a novel algorithm that can forecast heat waves up to 5 days beforehand, automatically categorising them from 1 to 3, with 3 being the most severe, based the impact on human health and mortality. After a heat wave has been categorised, subsequent actions are triggered, for example deploying ‘heat workers’ to check on the elderly and other vulnerable groups, something that is essential during heat waves which have extreme impacts on vulnerable people. Other cities showing an interest and following suit include Athens, Melbourne and many in the USA including Los Angeles and Miami.
Primary Article Title: Seville, Spain to Be World’s First City to Name and Rank Heat Waves
Author: Rosane, O.

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a process with which to create carbon neutral portland cement from biologically grown limestone.&%23160;
Justification: Cement and concrete production is a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution, and used widely by the Environment Agency in flood management asset construction, such as flood defence. Taking inspiration from coral, whose structures consist of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) deposits, researchers wondered if CaCO3 could be similarly grown rather than extracted for concrete production via limestone quarrying. They cultivated coccolithophore microalgae and found that the coccolithophores produced CaCO3 at a significantly quicker rate than geological formation, almost in real time. This suggested that &%23160;biogenic limestone as a source for construction purposes could be realised. The microalgae can also be productive in both salty and freshwater bodies, suggesting that they could be used in limestone production in multiple environments across the World. The team’s calculations suggest that growing microalgae for limestone over two million acres (around 0.5 per cent of the USA) would be enough to supply the country with all its cement needs, while at the same time sequestering carbon dioxide from the environment. Replacing quarried limestone this way could bring significant sustainability gains to the construction sector, in which the Environment Agency is involved.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: In a world-first, scientists create eco-friendly cement from algae
Author: Brahambhatt, R
Secondary_URLs: Cities of the future may be built with algae-grown limestone | CU Boulder Today | University of Colorado Boulder
Keywords: construction concrete cement "calcium carbonate" CaCO3 coccolithophore&%23160;microalgae geological USA sequester "carbon dioxide" sustainability "climate change" asset flood defence management biogenic limestone quarry

Summary Sentence: A court ruling in New York against a company challenging environmental regulations around certain types of &%23160;PFAS (perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances) suggests a legal precedent for successfully challenging sources of water pollution even if the level of contamination is below regulated concentration limits.
Justification: The legal system in the United States is very different to the United Kingdom, however the ruling may be of interest to the Environment Agency in its potential to set precedent. PFAS manufacturer 3M attempted to legally invalidate the New York Department of Health’s maximum contamination level (MCL) of 10 parts per trillion for certain kinds of PFAS contamination in drinking water supplies. 3M maintained that the MCL was scientifically flawed, amounting to “... a regulatory guess”. The court dismissed all of 3M’s arguments, one of which was based on 3M’s stated fear of potential liability for PFAS remediation expenses, as a leading manufacturer of the PFAS-containing compounds and products that caused PFAS contamination. The court ruled that regardless of the MCL, the New York Attorney General would be able to bring a lawsuit for PFAS contamination of public water resources, as if a defendant contaminates drinking water, it can be held liable regardless of whether or not there is an MCL in place for that contaminant&%2358; in effect the regulation does not create itself any potential liability. It is believed that this ruling could set a precedent for other jurisdictions facing legal challenge from PFAS manufacturers, regardless of whether specific PFAS regulations are in place. A similar interpretation of UK law could lead to manufacturers facing legal challenges, despite compliance with existing regulation.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: New York Supreme Court rejects 3M's challenge to PFAS MCL
Author: Miele, T
Keywords: water pollution pollutant chemical manufacturer PFAS "perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances" USA "New York" court law legal 3M "maximum&%23160;concentration limit" regulation lawsuit

Summary Sentence: Scientists have announced that the planetary boundary for freshwater has been significantly transgressed.
Justification: The Environment Agency as a regulator of water resources should be interested in the nature of the latest assessment, which now includes “green water” - rainfall, soil moisture and evaporation - as well as blue water. Previous evaluations had only considered rivers, lakes and groundwater.The latest assessment also concludes that this situation will continue to worsen. Up until this assessment freshwater had been considered to be in the safe zone. The planetary boundaries framework describes a safe operating space for humanity, beyond which civilization could collapse. &%23160;It is recommended that the situation could be reversed by addressing climate change, deforestation and soil degradation issues,to increase the chances of remaining in a safe operating space.
Primary Article Title: Freshwater planetary boundary “considerably” transgressed&%2358; new research
Author: Kotzé, P
