Summary Sentence: A teenager has developed an insect pest control solution that doesn’t rely on potentially toxic chemicals.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency as similar solutions to this could help reduce the quantities of toxic chemicals applied to the environment by the agricultural sector. US teenager Aseel Rawashdeh's innovation has developed a larvicide targeted at controlling disease carrying mosquitoes, but leaving other beneficial mosquitoes unaffected, from baker’s yeast and essential oils. Basing her research on a previous paper that used an essential oil carrying yeast to control termite populations by killing cellulose-digesting protozoa in the termite gut, Rawashdeh hypothesised that mosquitoes, which feed on wild yeasts in the water as juveniles, &%23160;could be targeted in a similar manner. Other previous research also revealed that essential oils from the Piper species of plants were effective against disease carrying Aedes mosquitoes, which had become immune to pyrethroid pesticide treatment. Through experimentation using a variety of combinations of essential oils and mosquito species larvae, Rawashdeh found a combination that created neurotoxicity for Aedes larvae alone, leaving all other test species unaffected. Her essential oil and yeast based larvicide costs around $10 a pound, and has a toxicity concentration of LD50, meaning it is effective at killing less than 50 percent or half of the mosquito larvae in a concentration of 50 milligrams per litre. Essential oil based pesticides are already used for addressing agricultural pests in some countries, namely USA and Australia. However, lack of support from regulatory agencies has been connected to commercial use lagging behind promise. Other recent research has demonstrated that non-target insects, some of which are beneficial pollinators, are exposed to lethal levels of insecticide through feeding on honeydew. This contributes to making a case for non-toxic chemical solutions to pest control (such as essential oils) needing greater research and regulatory support. The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider what their role in supporting cheap, less toxic alternatives should be.
Primary Article Title: This teenager found a way to control mosquitoes using essential oils and baker's yeasts.

Summary Sentence: New research suggests a link between electromagnetic frequency exposure and Alzheimer’s disease.
Justification: Evidence of electromagnetic radiation presenting a health risk is contested, but emerging research such as this could provide reason for new health and safety implications for the ways in which the Environment Agency’s staff operate and communicate. Alzheimer’s has long been linked to excessive intracellular calcium in the brain. Pulsed electronically generated electromagnetic fields (EMFs) used for wireless communication, such as mobile phones. Research which models non-animal brains suggests that strong electric and magnetic forces activate &%23160;voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs), leading to rapid increases in intracellular calcium levels, increasing the risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. Sources of EMFs are expected to increase from continual adoption of connected ‘smart devices’, such as cell phones, smart metres, smart cities and radar in self driving vehicles. The latest research is reported to provide powerful evidence that EMFs can cause Alzheimer’s disease via the calcium hypothesis.
Primary Article Title: EMFs, calcium and Alzheimer’s disease&%2358; a closer link

Summary Sentence: MIT researchers have developed a new form of geo-engineering for tackling climate change – ‘space bubbles’.
Justification: Emerging geoengineering solutions are important from an environmental risk perspective, as a form of mitigation that does not address the root cause of climate change and could have unforeseen environmental consequences. Consisting of a thin-film silicon structure and manufactured in outer space they could reflect 1.8% of the solar radiation, reducing temperature increases driven by climate change. By creating a raft of thin-film silicon bubbles deployed from Earth into outer space and stretching to the size of Brazil, they could potentially block the Sun’s solar radiation from further warming Earth. “Unlike other Earth-based geoengineering efforts, such as dissolving gases in the stratosphere for increasing its albedo effect, this method would not interfere directly with our biosphere and therefore would pose less risks to alter our already fragile ecosystems,”. The raft would be suspended at the ‘Lagrangian Point’, the location between the Earth and the Sun where the gravitation influence of both bodies cancel out. The team suggests having some sort of system to ensure the raft stays in place and that may provide the ability to move the bubbles closer to the Sun for optimal impact. Researchers tested the bubbles in outer space conditions and their findings suggest that these assemblages would be one of the most efficient structures for reflecting solar radiation. The researchers are careful to note that this would be an emergency solution to tackle increasing temperatures. Deflecting the suns rays may reduce warming but it will not counteract the underlying cause or any of the other wide-ranging effects of climate change (such as ocean acidification).
Primary Article Title: MIT Scientists Propose ‘Space Bubbles’ to Deflect Solar Radiation, Ease Climate Change
Author: Tim Newcomb
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//senseable.mit.edu/space-bubbles/
Keywords: Geoengineering “Solar reflection” “Climate change” Cooling “Solar radiation” “Space bubbles” Innovation “outer space” “Space raft”

Summary Sentence: New research on the impacts of adding hypersaline water from desalination plants to coastal water has found that some fish are attracted to these areas.
Justification: The Environment Agency may want to consider this research in relation to regulating the treatment of saline wastewater, for example after road after road gritting, as well as in the regulation of Thames Water desalination plant. Desalination facilities typically discharge excess salt as hypersaline brine back into the ocean, with uncertain ecological effects. Now, researchers in Environmental Science & Technology report that a large desalination plant in Australia has the unexpected benefit of attracting some species of fish, increasing their abundance at the discharge site. However, the physiological impacts of the hypersaline discharge have not been investigated. &%23160;Scuba divers took videos of fish at the outlet sites over a 7-year period before and after the desalination plant's operation, as well during a timeframe when the plant temporarily ceased operations. Fish, including some commercially important species, were three times more plentiful around the outlet during hypersaline discharge than before or after. The largest increase was observed for fish, such as the one-spot puller, that feed on zooplankton. The researchers hypothesise that the turbulence caused by the high-pressure release of the salty solution could have attracted the fish. Although the findings show that fish are attracted to the outlets, the physiological impacts of the hypersaline discharge have not been investigated.
Primary Article Title: Australian desalination plant attracts fish
Keywords: Hypersaline “Waste water treatment” “Waste water” Runoff Desalination “Desalination plant” Fish

Summary Sentence: Changing economic conditions may mean that cheap services, once propped up by venture capitalist investment, will be a thing of the past.
Justification: This is a complex issue with the potential to impact Environment Agency operations and staff welfare by contributing to rising costs, as well as possibly changing urban landscapes by reducing the availability of low-cost services. This may encourage more people to use alternative services such as public transport, cycling or walking, alternatively it might lead to more people driving. Investment from venture capitalists, lured in by rapidly increasing customer numbers, have financially subsidised start-ups and tech companies such as Uber and Just Eat, believing that they were investing in the next Google or Amazon. Venture capitalism has propped up many start-ups, allowing them to charge prices that actually make a loss (but encourage more customers to join), now, thanks to rising interest rates and less-willing labour markets, these super-cheap prices are forced to increase. The concept has been dubbed the ‘millennial lifestyle subsidy’, having allowed (mainly millennials) a higher standard of living for very little financial cost. Due to falling markets, rising inflation and changing labour markets, investment in unprofitable companies is much less viable, meaning that they are no longer propped-up by investor funding. Loss of investment does mean that customers will have to pay a more realistic price for once-cheap services such as food delivery. It will also likely lead to low-income workers being paid more fairly for their work.
Primary Article Title: The End of the Millennial Lifestyle Subsidy
Author: Derek Thompson
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.nytimes.com/2021/06/08/technology/farewell-millennial-lifestyle-subsidy.html
Keywords: “Millennial lifestyle subsidy” Start-ups “Venture Capitalist” Investment Anti-competitive “Cost of living” “Predatory pricing” Profitability

Summary Sentence: Scientists have designed a tiny ‘robot-fish’ that adsorbs microplastics for sampling from water.
Justification: The Environment Agency could use this technology for sampling microplastics from waterbodies for further analysis or fingerprinting (%2315228). Researchers at Sichuan University have designed a tiny self-propelled ‘robo-fish’ that can latch on to free-floating microplastics, and fix itself if it gets cut or damaged while on its expedition. The robo-fish is just 13mm long and uses a light laser system in its tail to propel itself forward at almost 30mm a second, similar to the speed at which plankton drift around in moving water. The researchers created a material similar to nacre (mother-of-pearl) by layering various microscopic sheets of molecules, emulating nacre’s specific chemical gradient. The material created is stretchy, flexible to twist, and even able to pull up to 5kg in weight, according to the study. The organic dyes, antibiotics, and heavy metals in the microplastics have strong chemical bonds and generate electrostatic interactions with the material meaning that they cling on to its surface. The fish can therefore collect and remove microplastics from the water. This is a proof of concept and is still in development for real world use. Adsorption of microplastics could be useful for collecting microplastic samples for analysis and potentially for removal of microplastics from contaminated waters. The team will soon be working on more functionally complex robo-fish that can go deeper under the water.
Primary Article Title: Scientists unveil bionic robo-fish to remove microplastics from seas
Author: Sofia Quaglia
Keywords: Microplastic Pollution Sampling Adsorption Robot Material Nanotechnology

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a fast and economical method of converting methane into liquid methanol at ambient temperature and pressure.
Justification: This technology could be of interest to businesses that the Environment Agency regulates including landfill sites and could help contribute to the UK’s net zero targets. Excess methane is commonly burned off, or flared, to reduce its environmental impact. However, this combustion process still produces carbon dioxide, which itself is a greenhouse gas. Industry has long sought an economical and efficient way to convert methane into methanol, a highly versatile feedstock used to make a variety of products including antifreeze, synthetic fabrics, adhesives, paint, plywood and chemical agents used in pharmaceuticals. Not only would this conversion help to reduce methane emissions, but it would also provide an economic incentive to do so. This new method takes place under continuous flow over a photo-catalytic material using visible light to drive the conversion. In the past high pressures and temperatures have been necessary to convert shale gas to methanol and other products (%2314129), a process which is energetically costly. The method occurs at ambient temperatures and pressures and involves a continuous flow of methane/oxygen-saturated water over a novel metal-organic framework (MOF) catalyst. The MOF is porous and contains different components that each have a role in absorbing light, transferring electrons, and activating and bringing together methane and oxygen. The process is selective and does not produce any unwanted by-products.
Primary Article Title: Scientists Discover “Holy Grail of Catalysis” – Converting Methane Into Methanol Using Light
Keywords: Methane Emissions Technology “Chemical conversion” Methanol “Metal organic framework” “Greenhouse gas”

Summary Sentence: Development of two new technologies could improve law enforcement&%2358; Brainwave analysis for eyewitness assessment and AI algorithms for predicting crime.
Justification:
Both technologies could be used by the Environment Agency to aid convictions or predict crime such as fly tipping. EEG analysis of a specific brainwave, known as the P300, could be used to determine if a witness or a suspect recognises crucial pieces of information related to a crime. P300 is an electrical brainwave detectable via EEG electrodes as a positive or negative deflection &%23160;about 300 to 600 milliseconds after presentation with a meaningful stimulus. This reaction is considered a reliable index of memory recognition. A statistical calculation then determines if the stimulus—the face of an attacker or a weapon—is recognised. This method has been the subject of dozens of experiments across four independent laboratories spanning at least four countries, but more independent testing is needed to verify it’s reliability.

Researchers have also developed a new AI algorithm that predicts future crime and claims 90% accuracy within 1000ft of crime. The algorithm uses publicly available urban crime data to train the model, which forecasts homicide and burglary crimes using city specific ‘spatio-temporal dependencies’ from event reports. The new tool was tested and validated using historical data on violent crimes and property crimes. These data were used because they were most likely to be reported to police in urban areas where there is historical distrust and lack of cooperation with law enforcement. Such crimes are also less prone to enforcement bias, as is the case with drug crimes, traffic stops, and other misdemeanour infractions. There are still concerns that the data used to train the algorithm could contain systemic biases, mirroring police enforcement’s complex relationship with crime and society. A separate model showed crime in wealthier areas resulted in more arrests, while crime in poor neighbourhoods didn’t, suggesting bias in police response and enforcement.
Primary Article Title: How your brainwaves could be used in criminal trials

Summary Sentence: The UK Government is to fund several ammonia energy projects.
Justification: This suggests growing confidence that an ammonia energy economy could become nearer to realisation, and that any environmental and regulatory considerations for the Environment Agency may need prioritising. The Tyseley Ammonia to Green Hydrogen Project, will be a demonstration plant, cracking ammonia to deliver 200kg per day of hydrogen transportation fuel to a neighbouring refuelling station. The cracking process will be based on H2SITE’s integrated membrane reactor technology. The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) funded £6.7M project consortium includes H2SITE, Gemserv, EQUANS, the University of Birmingham and Yara. BEIS are also funding development of the World’s first high pressure, ultra-efficient electrolyser, which utilises waste heat to produce high-pressure hydrogen, eliminating the need for a compressor. Supercritical, ScottishPower and Proton Ventures are building and operating a pilot operation to produce renewable ammonia. BEIS has also awarded funding to partners the Science and Technology Facilities Council (STFC) and Frazer-Nash Consultancy for the Ammonia Synthesis Plant from Intermittent Renewable Energy (ASPIRE) project. Potential sites include the Harwell EnergyTec Cluster, near Oxford. ASPIRE will look to produce hydrogen using only intermittent renewable energy as the source of power.
Primary Article Title: Government funding for ammonia energy in the UK

Summary Sentence: Developments are making nuclear power more portable, with the potential to be used in more diverse environments and at a smaller scale.
Justification: The Environment Agency as a regulator of the nuclear industry may need to consider how these developments could impact on current regulatory enforcement and monitoring of both operators and waste. Portable nuclear devices may also have a role in infrastructure provision during major incidents. There have been previous examples of portable nuclear generators, though these have tended to be floating and still quite sizeable (%2315263). The US Department of Defence recently contracted out for development of a fourth generation portable nuclear reactor which could fit inside a standard container, making it readily transportable by land, sea and air. The system, developed by a consortium headed by BWXT Technologies Inc, is expected to generate between &%23160;1-5 MWe and will use TRISO fuel, high-assay low-enriched uranium (HALEU) fuel that can withstand extreme heat and has low environmental risks. Development and testing is suspected to last for several years before wider deployment as part of the Department’s goal of achieving Net Zero by 2050. The system may also find applications in disaster responses, providing power to remote locations. A private company is taking a fresh look at the quest for nuclear fusion power through developing a backpack sized reactor. Current projects to harness the power of nuclear fusion are large scale, resource intensive and so far use more energy than they generate. Avalanche Energy’s orbitron fusion battery is taking a different approach, using a small scale design and principles of rapid prototyping to overcome the limitations that large scale projects bring. Rather than relying on magnets to heat and squeeze hydrogen plasma. The orbitron will generate two jets of hydrogen plasma, a process already well understood. When the jets collide they should realise enough kinetic energy for fusion to occur. Through small scale rapid prototyping, including using additive manufacturing and 3D printing, Avalanche Energy believe that they can ‘catch up’ to the level of larger projects such as tokamak (%2313297) and have a small unit producing 5 kW of power, enough to power a home, in a matter of years. Their modular design could mean that orbitron use could be scaled up to meet larger demand such as cities. While nuclear fusion is still a challenging goal even on a small scale, realisation could lead to a significant decarbonisation of energy demand, but lead to a proliferation of decentralised small scale devices requiring regulation under a completely different regime to existing installations.
Primary Article Title: The fusion reactor you can carry in a backpack
Author: Lockett, W
Secondary_URLs: The US Army will have a portable nuclear reactor ready by 2024 (interestingengineering.com)

Summary Sentence: Spain is planning to introduce legislation which will allow women to take leave if suffering from severe period pain.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in how similar legislation could impact on workplace dynamics within its own organisation. While menstrual leave has existed in some countries for decades, and some private companies have trailed similar menstrual leave schemes (%2313531), Spain would be the first European country to introduce such legislation. With a doctor’s note, women with severe period pain would be able to be granted three days leave. The draft legislation also includes extended paid maternity leave before childbirth and changes to abortion laws . While the Environment Agency is very supportive of its staff, it should be mindful that similar legislation to this in the UK has the potential to create tension and divisiveness, while also raising issues around personal data and management practices if not introduced and managed with sensitivity to all concerns across the workforce.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Spain plans menstrual leave in new law for those with severe pain
Keywords: health workforce workplace employment employee employer women period pain "menstrual leave" legislation regulation Spain

Summary Sentence: Increasingly sophisticated citizen science is being employed in environmental monitoring that is challenging environmental legislation and regulation activities.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners may need to establish new working relationships with activist science, which may bring complementary benefits, or may wish to risk creating divergent narratives on the state of the environment and expose itself to criticism and legal action. A group of citizen scientists based in Bristol, UK recently ran a project for the local council looking into the potential toxicity of wood burning stoves in urban areas. The group targeted the Ashley area of the city with a high concentration of domestic wood burning stoves, where their network of air quality sensors recorded 11 breaches of World Health Organization daily guidelines for ultra-fine particulate pollution (PM 2.5) over a period of six months.The council hopes the project will raise awareness of the health impact of wood smoke on public health and lead to greater use of gas and electric heating, which is overall less impactful on urban air quality. However, rising energy costs are making wood burning a more economically attractive option. Wood burners and open fires are thought to cause 17 per cent of the UK’s PM 2.5 pollution – more than the pollution caused by road traffic. A proposed new government target for small particulates of 10 micrograms per cubic metre for England by 2040 is close to existing levels in cities such as Bristol and double safe concentrations set by the WHO. In the USA residents of Belmont County, Ohio recently challenged the accuracy of the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)’s air quality sensors with their own rival network. The health of residents had long suffered from a range of symptoms, including headaches, fatigue, nausea and burning sensations in their throats and noses, which was attributed to local fracking activities. However the EPA dismissed their concerns based on its own monitoring data. With assistance from Columbia University’s Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, MIT and the American Geophysical Union’s Thriving Earth Exchange, local activists ran an alternative 60 node low-cost sensor network, monitoring for particulate matter and volatile organic compounds, which verified that the EPA’s sensors were not accurate, therefore distorting the true level of air pollution. The sensors showed that many areas were experiencing air pollution levels exceeding WHO recommendations. The data have allowed community leaders to submit targeted public records requests about these operations and their compliance with air quality standards. The project has generated an academic paper, but more relevantly demonstrates the ability of community activism and citizen science to challenge both operator and regulator, especially aided by academia. By embracing activities similar to this it may be possible for the Environment Agency to increase the granularity of its own monitoring programmes and build trust with communities, however it must also be mindful of the need to respond to challenge swiftly and constructively to avoid damaging the potential benefits offered by increasingly sophisticated citizen science.
Primary Article Title: Community-led science uncovers high air pollution from fracking in Ohio County
Author: Fecht, S

Summary Sentence: Magnesium and sodium are gaining ground as potential substitutes for lithium in battery production.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in these developments from a waste management and circular economy perspective. Lithium is widely used in batteries but it is a relatively rare element on Earth, and tends not to be recycled. Research is commencing to look into the possibility of replacing lithium in batteries with a magnesium based alternative. Magnesium is more plentiful and can perform at a similar level to lithium under the right conditions. The environmental impact of rare earth element extraction is well documented. Much of the World’s magnesium supply comes from China in a fossil fuel intensive process. As the price of magnesium has risen recently the economics of exploiting other sources start to look more favourable. One such proposed scheme in northern Australia is looking to use on-site solar generated electricity and hydrogen extracted from plentiful water sources to produce ‘green’ magnesium ready for domestic use and export. Battery technology based on sodium is also emerging as a viable alternative to lithium, again driven by rising global commodity prices. Sodium-ion (Na-ion) batteries offer some advantages to lithium. It is one thousand times more abundant with cheaper extraction costs. This makes them potentially cheaper than lithium based batteries, but only if they are produced at scale. However, many manufacturers are investing in Na-ion manufacturing, and sodium could complement lithium as the dominant battery technology, including in electric vehicle (EV) use, using both systems to balance component availability against energy density. The Environment Agency may need to consider if waste regulations are adaptable to cover a range of element recovery in battery recycling as alternatives to lithium come onto the market at scale.
Primary Article Title: Magnesium in batteries&%2358; a sustainable alternative to lithium

Summary Sentence: Recent innovations suggest that the components of electronic devices could be manufactured from regenerative organic materials rather than rare earth elements.
Justification: These innovations should be of interest to the Environment Agency’s waste management activities, where recycling and disposal of waste electronics equipment (WEEE) can be problematic. Cellulose, a constituent of wood, is known to be able to carry an electric current when heated under certain conditions. It has previously been possible to create ‘nanopaper’ circuits through submitting the nanopaper to carbonisation, ‘burning’ a circuit onto it. However the same process can easily destroy the three dimensional nanostructures, preventing useful deployment. Researchers have now overcome this issue with a new treatment process. Firstly an iodine treatment protects the nanostructure of the nanopaper. Secondly a spatially controlled drying process prevents the carbonisation pyrolysis from further damage and the paper to be ‘tuned’ for specific purposes. Proof of concepts created a sensor to monitor water vapour passing through a face mask and a semiconductor in a biofuel cell that significantly outperformed a conventional graphite equivalent. &%23160;In separate research scientists have been able to create a semiconductor manufactured from honey. &%23160;Neuromorphic systems are being developed that promise faster computing through mimicking the structure of the human brain. Key to this development are components called memristors, similar to transistors but with the added ability to store memory. Scientists have been able to construct a memristor from honey sandwiched between two electrodes, emulating a human synapse. Proteins and sugars from Aloe vera leaves have also been trialled but honey shows the greatest potential as it can tolerate higher temperatures.Using honey in memristors would also contribute to reducing electronic waste, being easily dissolved in water come disposal and heralding renewable and biodegradable neuromorphic systems and further driving sustainable electronics made entirely from natural, regenerative materials.
Primary Article Title: Honey holds potential for making brain-like computer chips
Author: Zaske, S

Summary Sentence: 'Superworms' can digest polystyrene and other plastics using special gut enzymes.
Justification: University of Queensland researchers conducted a three-week study into the ability of superworms to consume and digest polystyrene using their gut microbiomes.&%23160;This is significant to Environment Agency because in future these superworms could be used for enzymatic biodegradation of plastics as part of the recycling processes allowing for reduced plastic waste. In laboratory conditions, the superworm (Zophobas morio)&%23160;ate polystyrene, digesting it using several of its extraordinary bacterial enzymes, and even gained some weight. However, there were indications that a mixed diet could lead to less damaging impacts on the worms’ gut microbiome, diversity and health. Further research is needed into how best utilise the superworm microbiome, particularly if the enzymes associated with polystyrene and styrene degradation could also metabolise other components such as flame retardants.
Primary Article Title: Superworms capable of munching through plastic waste

Summary Sentence: The impacts of sizeism and weight bias are not considered enough for professionals in science and research.
Justification:
In science and research workplaces, many professionals feel they face constant scrutiny and biases because of their race or gender, but recently people have been highlighting the biases they suffer due to sizeism. Weight and size based biases inevitably lead to issues with wellbeing, career progression and inclusion. This is relevant to Environment Agency as no organisation is free from the widespread negative stereotypes associated with fatness. Victims of sizeism encounter poor attitudes from colleagues, fewer opportunities to progress and a lack of personal protective equipment for larger body types or sizes. Lack of diverse role models discourages larger people and can make them feel unwelcome and not taken seriously at a professional level. Prejudices against their looks and size can hinder people’s career progression. Organisational culture changes are needed along with and focus on practical adjustments such as availability of larger size PPE, appropriate laboratory furniture, or ergonomic office chairs without arm rests. These relatively small things demonstrate a significant message and acknowledge the problem with weight bias.

&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Mycelium is a perfect natural construction material but its use is hindered by psychological perceptions.
Justification: Mycelium is a bioengineered construction material that is biodegradable, fast-growing, cheap to produce and non-toxic, with excellent qualities for acoustics, insulating and fire-proofing buildings. In the move to net zero carbon, Environment Agency can influence construction industry for a more advanced biologically informed approach towards design, engineering and building, and lead by example for a more sustainable future. Studies for mycelium composite materials are currently under development.to replace less environmentally friendly foams and plastic insulation, but also for flooring, door cores, panelling and replacing timber. For construction work the challenges are complying with building standards, developing new industrial processes for producing the materials, and developing an acceptable level of durability. However, the deeper challenges arise from customer acceptance and willingness to embrace something different for environmental reasons. These challenges are mainly psychological with perceptions and fears of mold, dry rot and spores everywhere in the lived environment. For aesthetic acceptance the materials can be developed to look and feel like leather. Visual marketing, customer education and sensorial design introduction are used to counter the fears for a more sustainable way of building.

Summary Sentence: A novel gravitational-based energy storage solution can be used in high-rise buildings.
Justification: As approximately 40% of electricity worldwide is used in&%23160; buildings, researchers have suggested a novel concept of&%23160; Lift Energy Storage Technology (LEST) that can be a solution for a decentralized urban&%23160;energy storage. Environment Agency may be interested in novel sustainable but flexible storage technologies such as LEST because they are likely to be of use when more electricity comes from renewables in the future. Tall buildings with lifts can become gravitational-based batteries for sustained source of power in urban environments, increasing their energy efficiency by generating low but constant quantity of energy over a long period. There is also potential to share distributed storage resources with the central power grid. Another advantage of this innovative approach towards net zero carbon is that there is no need for additional investment as high-rise buildings already have lifts in place.

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed fluorine-based nanostructures that successfully filter salt from water.
Justification: Development of alternative drinking water sources are important for the Environment Agency as a way to ease water shortages, reduce pressure on water abstraction and from a water regulatory perspective. The team created test filtration membranes by chemically synthesizing nanoscopic fluorine rings, which were stacked and embedded in an otherwise impermeable lipid layer. As fluorine is electrically negative, it repels negative ions such as the chlorine found in salt. An added bonus of this negativity is that it breaks down ‘water clusters’, essentially loosely bound groups of water molecules, so that they pass through the channels quicker. Test samples were created with nanorings between 1 and 2nm. To test the effectiveness of their membranes the team measured the presence of chlorine ions, on either side of the test membrane. “The smaller of our test channels perfectly rejected incoming salt molecules, and the larger channels were still an improvement over other desalination techniques and even cutting-edge carbon nanotube filters. Our sample worked around 2,400 times faster than experimental carbon nanotube-based desalination devices.” At present, the synthesis of these materials is relatively energy-intensive but given the longevity of the membranes and their low operational costs, overall energy costs will be much lower than with current methods. Compared to current desalination methods, these fluorous nanochannels work faster, require less pressure and less energy, and are a more effective filter. Current methods of desalination are energetically costly and this innovation is a step toward low energy filtration of saltwater. If successful this technology could help to ease water shortages and reduce abstraction from water courses in the UK.
Primary Article Title: The future of desalination?
Author: Joseph Krisher
Keywords: Desalination “Drinking water” “Fresh water” Filtration “Water filtration” “Salt removal” Nanochannels “Flourous nanochannels”

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a low CO2 method for producing hydrogen from bananas using flash light irrigation.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be aware of this potential alternative source of green hydrogen as the UK scales up a ‘hydrogen economy’ in line with the Hydrogen Strategy (2021). Banana waste is common because as they ripen brown spots appear on the skin, often leading to supermarkets disposing of them as unsellable. Now, this waste could have an alternative use. Researchers have developed ‘photo-pyrolysis’ to produce hydrogen from banana peel and were able to capture all of the waste products. Pyrolysis decomposes the biomass at temperatures of 400 to 800°C, in containers without oxygen, but requires specific reactors that can handle high temperatures and pressures. Photo-pyrolysis using a xenon lamp emits a bright white light and one powerful flashlight shot can trigger biomass conversion in just a few milliseconds. First, the banana peels must be dried at around 100°C for 24 hours, then ground and sieved to a fine powder with each kilogram of dried biomass can creating around 100 litres of hydrogen and 330g of biochar. A major concern with biomass conversion is that it can actually release more CO2, for example where forests are logged, to fuel power stations. But the team of Swiss-based scientists explain that all the products from their photo-thermal technique can be captured, making it economical and climate-safe.
Primary Article Title: Blasting bananas with light could pave the way for more ‘eco-friendly’ biomass | Euronews

Summary Sentence: Researchers from Lassonde School of Engineering have made progress using enzymes to degrade groundwater contaminants.
Justification: The enzymes, from microorganisms identified in petroleum hydrocarbons, accelerate the rate of chemical reaction. Improving bioremediation technologies should be of interest to the Environment Agency, particularly when it comes to improving water quality and removal of hydrocarbons. Alcanivorax borkumensis microbes were treated with a fermentation process to produce large volumes of petroleum degrading enzymes cocktail (∼900 L). The application of these enzymes results in the degradation of petroleum compounds by reducing the activation energy for a particular reaction. Using enzymes to break down hydrocarbons removes the risk of injecting live micro-organisms into the environment, the long-term effects of which are often unclear. The enzymes isolated are also cold-active enzymes meaning that they function at low temperatures.&%23160; The next stage for the research is to test the enzymes in situ at petroleum sites in northern Canada and the Arctic.
Primary Article Title: York researchers make headway using enzymes to degrade groundwater contaminants

Summary Sentence: An Argentinian company is planning construction of a building with a profitable bitcoin mining facility in the basement.
Justification: . If this concept proves successful it may catch on UK leading to excessive energy use in residential buildings and implications on net zero. The 24-floor "smart" building with a Bitcoin mining farm in its basement aims to generate an income for the building's operations, allowing it to cover the cost of the edifice’s maintenance and upkeep —and savings its residents the costs of having to do so. It has already been pre-launched, although actual construction is not slated to not start until the second quarter of 2022. The building is planned have more than 100 apartments and many of them have already been pre-sold, with prices of around US$ 2,500 dollars per square meter (about US$ 120,000 dollars for a 2-bedroom apartment). &%23160;Bitcoin mining is prohibited in China, Nepal, Morocco, Iraq, Bangladesh, Egypt, Qatar, and Tunisia due to excessive energy concerns, however, this move suggests that Bitcoin’s costly ‘proof-of-work’ mining will stick around for some time. Electricity in Argentina is considered inexpensive because it is heavily subsidized (which led to a major boom in Bitcoin mining in the country), which allows this project to be feasible. Alternative crypto-currencies now use less energetically costly ‘proof-of-stake’ mining which may be more viable in the UK.
Primary Article Title: Next Pampa 2.0&%2358; The world's first Crypto building with a Bitcoin mining farm
Author: Maia Mulko
Keywords: Bitcoin ‘Bitcoin mining’ Cryptocurrency ‘Bitcoin mining farm’ ‘Net zero’ Energy ‘Crypto building’

Summary Sentence: Emissions from an increasing number of rocket launches may be having unforeseen impacts on the Earth’s atmosphere.
Justification: The Environment Agency is already involved in regulating space launch and should therefore be interested in potentially far reaching impacts from this activity. Concerns have been expressed previously about the impact of emissions created from space debris burning up in the atmosphere (%23****). Compared to sectors such as aviation, the volume of emissions from space flight is currently extremely small. However the number of space launches is increasing, with a new record of 133 flights per year set in 2022. What is also of concern is that the emissions from rocket exhausts are being deposited in layers of the atmosphere in relatively high concentrations. A single rocket launch produces significantly more carbon dioxide than a single commercial airliner flight, as well as alumina and black carbon particles, which can scatter sunlight and impact temperature and circulation in the stratosphere. Recent research has focussed on the substances emitted during launch. Researchers modelled exhaust emissions from SpaceX’s Falcon Nine rocket against changing conditions as it moved up through the atmosphere above the Earth. They found that while the overall amount of emissions is relatively small compared to the surrounding atmosphere, the amount of CO2 is highly significant at higher levels of the atmosphere. The model suggests that once the Falcon Nine reaches 43.5 miles (70 km), it releases more than 25 times the amount of CO2 found in a cubic kilometre of air at that altitude. Carbon monoxide (CO) and water are also being released in similarly high relative concentrations. It is not known as to the fate and impact of these emissions, but water is known to immediately freeze, and carbon monoxide reacts with hydroxide (O2) to form more CO2. Thermal nitrogen oxides (NOx) were also discovered to persist in hot rivers before dispersing throughout the atmosphere, especially at lower altitudes. New research due to be published later this year will link rocket launches to ozone depletion. And elsewhere it is suggested that pollution may be contributing to increasingly frequent noctilucent cloud formations at an altitude of about 80km, which is virtually the edge of space. With launch numbers still relatively low, some think that atmospheric impacts are relatively low. However the conclusions of this research challenges that assumption. More research may be required to establish what the impacts are, but increasing numbers of space launches may exacerbate any issues discovered. The Environment Agency and partners may therefore need to consider regulatory regimes which can adequately accommodate space and high atmosphere activities.
Primary Article Title: Physicists figured out how launching a Falcon 9 changes the atmosphere
Author: Currin, G

Summary Sentence: Ørsted and ARK Nature work together in a marine rewilding project for the biodiversity of North Sea.
Justification: A pioneering partnership at the North Sea is underway to combine the efforts of a marine biodiversity organisation and wind energy company for rewilding, with conservation as an essential feature of the new way of working. This is of relevance to Environment Agency because of Environment Agency’s interest in marine environment, marine biodiversity, and impacts of offshore wind development. Experiments of marine rewilding will be carried out with governments and organisations for more sustainable special planning in the North Sea, as ARK and Ørsted state that they want to be part of the solution. Efforts include creating new software with AI to identify bird species automatically, to find out more about the avoidance behaviour of protected bird species around wind turbines. &%23160;The initial focus of the rewilding project is restoring shellfish reefs that ecologists find vital for the restoration. The reefs can bring back stability to marine ecosystems by restoring and establishing new coral reefs that can anchor the seabed and encourage diversity of the species. Presently there is no adequate locations for the shellfish larvae to attach in the North Sea. Climate change places demand on expansion of renewable energy and therefore the global wind energy leader Ørsted wants to work in a way that can also improve the health of the oceans and improve biodiversity.
Primary Article Title: Ørsted and ARK Nature to Pioneer Marine Rewilding

Summary Sentence: Smart technology use in digital agriculture means there are novel cyberthreats to food production.
Justification: Smart technology utilisation for digital agriculture increases the vulnerability to cybersecurity threats, according to a complex modelling completed by researchers from several universities. The relevance to Environment Agency is that even though smart technology in agriculture has many benefits, it also brings risks that may impact how Environment Agency can best regulate farms in future. In the UK, in particular the shortage of agricultural and seasonal skilled workforce and the growing need for food self-sufficiency have placed pressure on digitalisation of agriculture. Increased awareness and taking precautions within agricultural technology users are required to minimise threats to food supply chains and labour in agriculture. Incidents of interference have been reported related to a US watering system, a meatpacking company, wool broker software and a beverage company. The vulnerabilities need to be taken into consideration at early stages as counteractive action may be expensive and require substantial resources.
Primary Article Title: Forecast of Food Cyber Attacks
Author: Flinders University
Keywords: agriculture cybersecurity digitisation security threats vulnerability “digital agriculture” “smart farming” “smart agriculture” “smart sensors” internet connectivity sensors “smart technology” agtech

Summary Sentence: Dried willow moss can clean surface water by absorbing hydrocabrons.
Justification: Researchers were astonished to find out the potential of dried willow moss, also called sphagnum moss, to clean up water of hydrocarbons, pollutants from cars, oil spills and other industrial contamination, entering road runoff and stormwater systems. It proved to be an environmentally friendly phytoremediation method, absorbing both lower and higher concentrations. The experiment was carried out in laboratory trials after placing bags of the dried moss into 22 streams in northwest Spain. Due to the large surface area of willow moss, as a biomaterial it can efficiently remove organic pollutants from surface waters, without having any adverse effects that other remediation technologies may have. The dried moss may also be used as an environmental monitor, absorbing pollutants which are then measured in laboratory conditions.
Primary Article Title: Can a moss help clean up waterways?
Author: Soil Science Society of America

Summary Sentence: Global warming impacts freshwaters through anoxia and the breakdown of nutrients in runoff also leads to loss of oxygen availability.
Justification: Over the course of seven years of study at a whole ecosystem scale, researchers observed a higher-than-expected magnitude of oxygen levels change in freshwater, where the lake no longer acted as a sink for caron, nitrogen and phosphorus but these nutrients moved downstream. The importance to Environment Agency is that these sediment-water interactions manifest a risk, potentially increasing toxic algal blooms, harming freshwater organisms, and therefore impacting the ecosystem functioning. Although the lake in question is larger than the freshwater systems in England, the principles of the changing freshwater quality, the loss of oxygen&%23160;availability, and risk to increased anoxia in downstream are the same. Environment Agency ecologists are increasingly studying sediments and they release more nutrients and carbon than previously, hence it is necessary to protect freshwaters from receiving even more nutrients from fertiliser use.
Primary Article Title: A vicious cycle of oxygen loss threatens water quality in lakes
Author: Irby, S.

Summary Sentence: A recent review of academic literature suggests that the last 20 years of ecotoxicology research has focussed on a relatively limited number of substances.
Justification: This could be indicative of significant gaps in ecotoxicological knowledge and by consequence, &%23160;regulatory regimes which are effective at preventing exposure to safe environmental limits. Researchers examined over 98,000 papers published over the last two decades, representing research on over 18,000 chemicals. They found that the 65 most frequently named chemicals accounted for 50 per cent of references, and that the top 11 chemicals accounted for 25 per cent of references. Metals including cadmium, copper, mercury and arsenic were often mentioned, as were the female hormone, estradiol and the herbicide atrazine. Over the study period it was found that the prominence of &%23160;pharmaceuticals had increased, whereas plant protection products had decreased. Some chemicals also occurred more frequently in corporate publications compared to academic ones. Of the 253 chemicals occurring in at least 100 papers, some that were absent in 2000 became commonplace by 2019, such as the anti-inflammatory diclofenac. Chemicals that were widely banned during this period were observed to decrease in frequency, such as atrazine. While there are caveats to acknowledge on limitations to study and data inaccuracies the research suggests that there may be significant ecotoxicological knowledge gaps due to a high over-representation of a small number of substances and little or no information on many chemicals with the potential to be hazardous. The researchers suggest that more needs to be done to reconsider and reprioritise research funding to fill the knowledge gaps needed for effective regulation of potential pollutants. The Environment Agency and partners may need to reflect on this analysis to influence their own research programmes and regulatory remits to help fill these evidence gaps.
Primary Article Title: Twenty years of ecotoxicology studies&%2358; review finds focus is on a&%23160;narrow range of potentially hazardous substances

Summary Sentence: As inequality and the environmental emergency rise up the agenda, there are signs that even the ultra-rich are demanding systematic change.
Justification: This is of interest to the Environment Agency and partners of signs of social change which may aid the environmental agenda, as well as potentially generate more funds for environmental work through both taxation and donation. A group of millionaires have joined forces at the recent World Economic Forum meeting in Davos to demand that World leaders tackle the cost of living crisis by increasing taxes for the ultra-rich. The group called Patriotic Millionaires is concerned that recent global events including the coronavirus pandemic have led to an increase in wealth accumulation amongst the wealthiest people. Signatories of the letter that went to Davos include Abigail Disney, heir to the Disney empire. Disney is also cited as one of a growing number of millionaires who have inherited great wealth and are now giving their money away to charitable causes and social enterprises. Some of this seems motivated by a desire to ‘do good’ and alleviate current issues such as climate change and inequality, but there are also steps to make amends for past exploitation on which the fortune had been built, such as slavery. Organisations such as Resource Generation in the USA and UK based Resource Justice bring together communities of the richest 18- to 35-year-olds “committed to the equitable distribution of wealth, land, and power.” Both have seen rapid growth in recent years. This could be seen as reflecting generational values of what has been dubbed The Great Wealth transfer, as over the next decade the generational cohort known as Millennials (born approximately 1981 - 1996) are set to inherit £327bn from their parents. However, wealth may not be the barrier to taking action, as it was recently reported that an oil company consultant recently made headlines for quitting the business on grounds of “failing on a massive planetary scale” to limit climate risks. These stories suggest that assumed socioeconomic driving forces may be changing, particularly amongst demographic cohorts which will have increasingly more political and economic influence over the coming years. This has implications for the socioeconomic and political operating space for the Environment Agency, presenting opportunities to increase political and economic support for its work.
Primary Article Title: Millionaires join Davos protests, demanding ‘tax us now’

Summary Sentence: Manipulating green algae diatoms can potentially lead to outcomes fundamentally changing environment.
Justification: University of Missouri fellow explores how to grow type of green algae called diatoms in large, controlled populations, for the advantage of the potential revolutionary role of diatoms for sustainability goals. The significance to Environment Agency’s work is that the diatom structures may be used for sustainable products and technologies, for instance to bioenergy and bioproduct technologies to clean air by removing carbon emissions and purify water by removing pharmaceutical molecules. In addition to this, they could become sources of green energy as a biofuel, the residual biomass can be utilised for anaerobic digestion, the nanostructures can be transformed into metamaterial to design nano materials and nano devices. All these products and technologies are important in mitigation for climate change and more sustainable consumer products within circular economy.
Primary Article Title: Studying ways to maximize environmental benefits of green algae

Summary Sentence: New process enables growing three-dimensional structures to size and shape required has a lor of potential for future applications.
Justification: As trees are regarded an asset for climate change mitigation, researchers have suggested saving these resources by creating a process where they attempt to grow plant material in a customised shape and size, with the physician and mechanical characteristics required. The relevance to Environment Agency is the potential from a massive reduction in waste and energy when materials can be grown locally without further manufacturing processes, hence also reducing impacts from transport. The process involved a 3D bioprinter instead of a mold and, therefore, scientists also focus on investigating lignin and lignification, as this polymer makes the plant cell walls more rigid. The process itself is significantly faster than trees naturally growing in the forest and can be further manipulated depending on the hormones level in the plant material used.&%23160;New process enables growing three-dimensional structures to size and shape required has a lot of potential for future applications.

Summary Sentence: Artificial intelligence has potential as an urban planning tool to ensure planning is grounded on evidence and data.
Justification: Barcelona municipal authorities are utilising Mare Nostrum supercomputer to analyse how to improve and maximise urban development and city planning, avoiding blind spots and human errors that can occur especially where politics are involved. What may be of interest to Environment Agency is that this type of urban planning tool can ensure that planning is grounded on evidence and data, for instance when planning housing development on flood plains or urban schemes where it is in our interest to locate green spaces in strategic locations for maximum impact, human health and wellbeing, and connection with nature. Barcelona has created a digital replica of the city with the Barcelona Supercomputing Center, first to analyse their ‘superilles’, superblocks scheme and to their shock discovered that the success was very limited in comparison to what they attempted to achieve. Therefore, they want to anticipate impacts, in particular the negative outcomes, by using data modelling at early planning stages. Barcelona has used Artificial intelligence and information technology to tackle issues including insufficient parking space and endeavour to use this now for the needs of ageing population for certain infrastructure, for example with neighbourhoods, the 15 min city concept, with access to green spaces and public transport. Supercomputer can also increase the citizen science aspect and participation in planning process, in particular to challenge planning decisions and social acceptance and transparency of projects.
Primary Article Title: Barcelona bets on ‘digital twin’ as future of city planning

Summary Sentence: A Japanese research group have developed a method of direct from air carbon capture that removes 99% of carbon and is twice as fast.
Justification: Carbon capture will be necessary in order for the UK to meet its net zero ambitions and this offers a promising development in this field. Direct air capture (DAC) is the processes of removing carbon dioxide directly from the air. The system works like a liquid direct air capture, where the gas is bubbled through a liquid solution. However, instead of getting trapped in the solution, the chemical reaction occurs so that the trapped carbon is insoluble and comes out of the solution as a solid. The captured carbon can either be stored in deep geological formations or used in various human activities such as food processing or making synthetic fuels. Using liquid amine compounds, including isophorone diamine, the research group achieved >99% CO2 removal efficiency under a 400 ppm CO2 (approximately the same as atmospheric concentrations) flow system. The trapped carbon precipitated out as carbamic acid, and the rate of this reaction is twice as fast as that of leading DAC systems around the world. Trapped carbon is released by heating the precipitate up to 60 degrees Celsius and the recovered liquid can be reused. The major drawback of carbon capture systems is their lack of efficiency. Although large-scale systems are currently being built or put into place to trap carbon, the systems lose efficiency as they trap carbon and are marred by high costs of recovery of the gas.
Primary Article Title: The Japanese carbon capture method is 99 percent efficient and twice as fast
Author: Ameya Paleja
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsenvironau.1c00065
Keywords: “Carbon capture” “Direct air capture” Carbon “Carbon dioxide” Carbon capture and storage” “Carbon removal” “Greenhouse gas” “Net zero”

Summary Sentence: The former director general of the WTO has urged countries to establish a scheme of global governance in the event of future climate geoengineering attempts.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in such developments as the responsibility for such governance could plausibly fall to the Environment Agency, which already regulates industrial emissions. Pascal Lamy, currently president of the Paris Peace Forum suggests that countries are increasingly likely to explore geoengineering as a means to mitigate climate change as other mechanisms seem incapable of cutting the impacts of greenhouse gas emissions to the scale needed to reach global warming targets. Some are concerned that geoengineering if not properly managed could accidentally change global climate patterns, or that individuals may have the power to instigate global change through geoengineering without consent. Commonly discussed geoengineering methods involve seeding the atmosphere with sulphur particles to reflect sunlight, or spreading iron in the ocean to absorb carbon dioxide. There are concerns that either could be potentially dangerous, changing rain patterns and causing crops to fail. While the science behind geoengineering is sound, any actual deployment would need careful global cooperation, the mechanisms of which Lamy points out are currently non-existent. This could suggest a future governance role for government bodies such as Defra, or more the Environment Agency directly.
Primary Article Title: Climate geoengineering must be regulated, says former WTO head
Author: Harvey, F

Summary Sentence: Further examples are emerging of automation becoming a mainstream aspect of construction and asset maintenance.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency’s own construction and maintenance programmes could make use of these innovations. In Japan a large ‘robot’ is being employed to fix power lines on a railway line. The robot is controlled by a human operator using virtual reality (VR) and remote controls. It is lifted into the air on a crane, where the operator can then control it to conduct repairs and lift heavy components into place in complete safety to the human crew and increasing productivity. Developers in China are set to apply automated construction on a large scale, by completing automated construction of a hydropower dam using robotics, artificial intelligence(AI), 3D printing and zero human labour. The Yangqu dam on the Tibetan plateau is set to be assembled layer by layer, and at 590 feet tall will likely be the world's tallest structure built using 3D printing once completed in 2024. A central AI system will oversee the automated assembly line, including unmanned trucks that will transport materials to the site. Unmanned bulldozers and pavers will turn them into a layer of the dam, which will then be pressed into place by automated rollers. The robotic vehicles will send information about the state of construction back to the AI system, eliminating human error such as delivering to the wrong part of the site. Raw material extraction will still employ human labour. Successful deployment could lead to other large scale construction projects taking a similar approach, which in turn may form a blueprint for construction generally, including flood defences, so should be of interest to the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: China is using AI and 3D printing to build a 590-foot-tall dam without the need for human workers, scientists say

Summary Sentence: Mitigating climate change through tree planting could be more effective with species optimised for carbon capture.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be considering the most effective tree planting solutions in the face of concerns around biodiversity and climate change itself, which will affect species suitability for carbon sequestering. Researchers are currently looking at ways to make plant photosynthesis more efficient as a way to capture more carbon through tree growth. Photosynthesis as a process is extremely inefficient. However experiments involving genetically altered tobacco plants suggest that it may be possible to increase this efficiency, which would translate into greater growth and therefore more rapid carbon capture compared to non-modified trees. A Californian startup called Living Carbon has already taken steps in this direction through experimenting with genetically modified poplar trees that can grow up to 53 per cent quicker than non-edited trees. Further research is needed to determine if the increased growth occurs throughout the trees’ entire life cycle. Others believe that it may be possible to improve tree carbon capture potential through natural cross-breeding, which may in turn prove to be more resilient to changing climates and habitats. The debate between genetic modification and selective breeding of trees for carbon capture purposes in some ways mirrors similar debates in agricultural circles. But with development and tree growth taking place over decades rather than years and the pressing need for climate action it is unclear currently which direction it may take. The overall impacts on biodiversity and conservation may also need factoring. There may be regulatory implications and environmental concerns for the Environment Agency and partners should either approach gain traction and approach to realisation.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: A bold idea to stall the climate crisis - by building better trees

Summary Sentence: Sixty UK companies are to participate in the largest four day working week trial ever, taking place between June 2022 and January 2023.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in the results of this trial as it could impact on its future workforce. The trial is being organised by a consortium of researchers including Cambridge University. Researchers will work with the employers of the 3000 UK participants to measure the impact of reduced hours on productivity, well-being, equality and the environment. Participants will be paid at their full salaries. Employees will commit to the “100&%2358;80&%2358;100” model of 100 per cent of the pay for 80 per cent of the time, in exchange for a commitment to maintain at least 100 per cent productivity. Previous smaller studies have concluded better staff outcomes with no overall impacts on productivity. Participants in the UK study range from the Royal Society of Biology to a fish and chip shop. Similar schemes will run concurrently in the USA, Australia, Canada and New Zealand. In Scotland the Scottish Government has also embarking on a four day week public service pilot which is thought in the long term could limit the financial burden of pay awards, improve productivity, and optimise automation and digitalisation of services, and contribute to job opportunities and wellbeing. However it is not clear if this would also mean four days work for five days pay. The coronavirus pandemic has demonstrated that work practices, and expectations of work, can change quickly and dramatically. The Environment Agency may need to consider the implications of a four day working week becoming normalised, and how this could impact on recruitment, retention and overall staff resourcing.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Four-day week&%2358; 3,000 employees in the UK to take part in the biggest trial of its kind

Summary Sentence: A team of Korean researchers have developed an innovative manufacturing technique for producing methane gas from coal and wood derived charcoal, using commercially available machinery.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in the regulatory implications of such a process becoming realised at a commercial scale, and may also wish to consider wider aspirations towards Net Zero of this technology. The new process uses a ball milling technique and a cobalt catalyst to decompose charcoal to a stage where it produces methane at lower temperatures to existing processes. The researchers believe that it could similarly produce methane from coal, which has a similar chemistry to charcoal. The researchers claim that producing methane from wood charcoal through their mechanochemical carbon hydrogasification (CHG) process is carbon neutral and may even be partially carbon net-negative. While the process could offer potential to produce methane gas with less resource footprint than current methods, there may be concerns that it could be used to extend fossil fuel extraction via coal and would also need careful governance to ensure that wood charcoal inputs were produced in a sustainable way.
Primary Article Title: Extreme enhancement of carbon hydrogasification via mechanochemistry

Summary Sentence: The countryside charity CPRE has found significant reduction in people experiencing severe light pollution levels.
Justification: Reduced light pollution and the associated impacts on health, energy use and wildlife should be of interest to the Environment Agency from net zero, biodiversity and staff welfare perspective. A survey by the countryside charity CPRE has suggested that light pollution has decreased as a result of fears over soaring energy costs and increased home working. Like all forms of pollution, light pollution is damaging our mental and physical health, and also having a severe impact on wildlife, especially insects. On top of this the energetic cost of street and office lighting is a hindrance to the UK’s net zero targets. Light pollution sharply dropped during the pandemic lockdowns and the levels continue to fall despite restrictions having been lifted. Light pollution levels are now at the lowest they have been since 2011. The increased cost of energy has led to households reducing energy waste by turning off the lights. Furthermore, local councils have followed suit, reducing street lighting to limit costs. This coupled with a rise in home working reducing the need to light and heat office buildings has encouraged the reduction in lighting. This is good news for reducing carbon emissions and prove that small adaptations can have a significant effect. Reduced light pollution is also beneficial for wildlife, particularly nocturnal insects. The impact of light pollution on insects is well known and has contributed to their declining numbers. A recent survey by Buglife suggests that flying insect numbers have reduced 65% since 2004. Insects are essential for ecosystem functioning and are economically important for agriculture. Reduced light pollution could offer some mitigation to these declines.
Primary Article Title: Light pollution falling amid soaring energy prices, star survey finds

Summary Sentence: Chemical pollution in the environment has been linked to the global obesity epidemic, according to a major scientific review.
Justification: The Environment Agency should consider this public health issue in terms of their regulation of water treatment as well as chemical regulation and waste regulation. The existence of obesogens – chemicals that affect people’s hormones and lead to a build-up of fat in the body - has been debated by scientists for several years (%2314396). Recent publications confirm that plastics contain a potent mixture of chemicals that promote adipogenesis, a key process in the development of obesity. The pollutants can also directly affect the number and size of fat cells, alter the signals that make people feel full, change thyroid function and the dopamine reward system. Finally, these pollutants can affect the microbiome in the gut and cause weight gain by making the uptake of calories from the intestines more efficient. The review identifies about 50 chemicals as having good evidence of obesogenic effects. Pollutants cited by the researchers as increasing obesity include bisphenol A (BPA), which is widely added to plastics, as well as some pesticides, flame retardants and air pollution. Past research has linked various types of bisphenol with endocrine disruption and chromosomal abnormalities (%2314698, %2314305, %2314277, %2313012). Researchers are especially concerned because these pollutants are widely used&%2358; in water and dust, food packaging, personal hygiene products and household cleaners, furniture and electronics. In addition, some chemical impacts that increase weight can be passed down through generations by changing how genes work.
Primary Article Title: Environmental toxins are worsening obesity pandemic, say scientists
Author: Damian Carrington
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.est.1c06316
Keywords: Bisphenol BPA “Bisphenol A” Obesity “Chemical pollution” “Plastic chemicals” “Endocrine disruption” “Public health” “Plastic packaging” “Plastic pollution” Obesogen

Summary Sentence: A North American solar panel manufacturer is to manufacture sunlight optimising technology based on quantum dots in a new range of solar generating glass designed for agricultural settings.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this technology that could help to alleviate tensions in land use between energy, development and farming. The glass is designed to be used in commercial greenhouse where it will generate electricity from sunlight falling on it, but also allow the remaining light to pass through to the crops inside. The quantum dot technology provided by UbiGro converts direct UV/blue light from the sun’s spectrum into an orange/red glow that improves plant growth. This is an example of “Agrivoltaics” &%23160;where crop production and electricity production occur simultaneously and in the same area. It is currently not clear what the exact specifics of the glass, produced by Heliene will be, but it is worth noting that there are also similar research initiatives taking place elsewhere (%2314968).&%23160;

Summary Sentence: The Royal Mint has announced plans to open its own facility to recover gold from UK circuit board waste
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in the realisation of a domestic e-waste recovery business, which could grow in the coming years and impact on other aspects of the waste management sector currently involved in WEEE e-waste export. The Royal Mint is looking to establish the new facility at its plant in South Wales, generating around 40 jobs. The Royal Mint is employing a patented chemical process developed by &%23160;Canadian based Excir, which they will use to recover gold from 90 tonnes per week of circuit boards from laptops and mobile phones. Currently 99 per cent of Uk circuit boards are believed to be shipped overseas. It is unclear if there are still regulatory issues for the Royal Mint to negotiate, however as environmental regulation is similar between England and Wales it may transpire that similar facilities could easily be accommodated by current regulations. The Environment Agency however may wish to consider if the patented chemical process mentioned may present a novel environmental risk.

Summary Sentence: A power plant in India is trialling a co-firing of coal with 20 per cent ammonia.
Justification:
The consortium involving an Indian and Japanese company is also looking to increase the ammonia mix up to 100 per cent over the length of the trial. The aim of the trial is to investigate how ammonia could contribute to India’s greenhouse gas reduction targets. Success could suggest a wider uptake of green ammonia as a viable fuel in combustion based energy generation. This could also mean that coal is not phased out on the timescales currently envisaged needed for Net Zero transition. This may all have implications for regulators in this area, including the Environment Agency.
&%23160;

Summary Sentence: An industrial consortium is developing a floating nuclear plant that could be deployed to provide energy to any coastal location.
Justification: The Environment Agency may wish to consider the regulatory implications of such power sources, alongside any potential incident management implications. Other countries have been associated with developing floating nuclear in recent years, including China (%2313342) and Russia (%2314377). This particular initiative involves Samsung Heavy Industries (SHI) and Seaborg, the latter of whom have developed a Compact Molten Salt Reactor (CMSR), powered by thorium, which potentially could be derived from the waste of other nuclear plants. In the context of the Ukraine crisis, or similar future strategic crises, floating nuclear has been framed as a way to create a flexible, green infrastructure that isn’t reliable on long supply chains and overseas fossil fuels (though this is debateable). It’s also been suggested that floating nuclear infrastructure like this presents the potential for producing e-fuels (such as ammonia) offshore, &%23160;creating strategically flexible refuelling points for maritime transport.&%23160;

Summary Sentence: &%23160;A cyber attack focussed on a satellite network has brought widespread and long term disruption.
Justification: This occurrence should be of interest to the Environment Agency in terms of operational work and incident response, as a similar attack could disrupt GPS services or monitoring and surveillance activities which could be significant particularly if it coincides with a major incident response. In February 2022 the KA-SAT internet satellite network experienced a ground-based cyber attack which took its services offline. It is believed that the attack was intended primarily to disrupt Ukrainian communications, hampering its efforts against Russian invasion. However the service’s customers extend beyond just Ukraine&%2358; thousands of users across other European countries also experienced a loss of service, which continued for at least a month. In Germany 2000 wind turbines were still offline, and the attack has rendered many users’ modems “unusable”. Intelligence agencies are investigating the attack. What has become apparent however is the ‘spillover’ effect of the attack, where impacts were felt beyond the intended target (assumed to be Ukraine), with services affected in Germany, UK, Czech Republic and as far away as Morocco. This demonstrates that the impacts of conflict related cyber attack can be felt beyond nations directly involved in that conflict. At the 2018 launch of UK Government’s defence space strategy, ‘jamming’ of satellites was recognised as a potential threat (%2314739). As satellites increasingly show potential in diverse uses such as blockchain provision (%2314969) and of particular note, environmental monitoring (%2314834), risks to service provision may increase in step. Some technologies are coming online which may negate the need of such as services as satellite based navigation (%2314739), however with realisation still some time away the risks for satellite network cyber attack may become more prevalent and therefore need consideration on mitigation measures.
Primary Article Title: A Mysterious satellite hack has victims far beyond Ukraine
