Keywords: communications monitoring cyber attack satellite Ukraine Russia internet Germany UK Czech Morocco turbine energy wind router incident emergency GPS space strategy jamming spillover&%23160;KA-SAT

Summary Sentence: Local waste management company shows initiative by using traditional methods for waste recovery and repurposing.
Justification: A small waste management company dealing with organic waste in Newfoundland aims totally alter how waste is dealt with by repurposing it utilising a molecular disassembly line. What should be of interest to Environment Agency is the approach to work with what’s available and the spirit of resourcefulness and a high level of self-sufficiency at small-scale and very local level, traditional reuses such as repurposing instead of only focussing on new technologies for circular economy. The innovative waste company called 3F Waste Recovery works with organic waste from fishing, farming and forestry and their waste management model currently is mainly at research and development stage. They want to show innovative leadership, inspire globally with their ability to 2make something out of nothing”, and believe in holistic approach for waste management, by demonstrating a paradigm shift with their example. Anything can be repurposed for example they are not specialised in repurposing high technology products but operate with products, available locally, as diverse as gardening products, pet snacks and pharmaceuticals due to location in rural Newfoundland. 3F Waste Recovery could potentially lead the way by building relationships with coastal primary industries for other waste recovery initiatives, such as the oil and gas industry who are keen to recover rare minerals like lithium and magnesium from their wastewater.

Summary Sentence: A novel mechanically strong building product is created by ‘healing’ waste wood.
Justification: Millions of tons of wood are sent to landfills but a novel chemical treatment method can be utilised for waste wood so it can be strengthened and repurposed for construction. This is of importance to Environment Agency as this innovation reduces the pressure on landfills and boosts sustainability and circular economy objectives. The treatment process in question ‘heals’ old wood by turning it to a material that is stronger than steel; five times stronger than natural wood in general and can be manufactured even from sawdust. The process typical to wood processing means dissolving lignin, a glue-like inside wood cells, and creating hydrogen bonding which then enhances the mechanical properties for wood. The process can be repeated, hence maximising the usability of originally low value wood, and making it more sustainable.
Primary Article Title: Waste wood chemically recycled to produce material stronger than steel

Summary Sentence: Solar power can now be harvested in the night-time.
Justification: University of New South Wales scientists have been able to demonstrate measurable power generation from a device that can be described as a heat engine, functioning in a opposite manner of a standard solar cell. The idea of “emissive energy harvesters” for thermoradiative power generation was introduced in 2014 but only now have researchers been able to obtain a measurable outcome. Although the power efficiency measured was only 1.8 %, this, when developed further, could prove to become a valuable technology for industry needs. Its application in night-sky power generation could ultimately enable harvesting approximately one tenth of power of what a conventional solar panel does. If industry could see this as a valuable technology for their needs, it can drive the research further with a current estimate of a decade of research required to develop the innovation. Potential uses include recovering energy from waste heat or designing bionic devices utilising body heat as energy source.
Primary Article Title: Bizarre night-time solar cell generates power in a backwards process

Summary Sentence: Climate change heightens the risks from viral outbreaks of zoonotic pathogens and spill overs.
Justification: American researchers, who have attempted to establish how better detect future zoonotic threats, have established that urban wildlife may be of a lower significance as a threat for future pandemics than previously believed due to urban pests such as rats carrying pathogens. Following Coronavirus pandemic, scientists attempt to focus where to look for next viral threat, to be more efficient in identifying next emerging future viral outbreak or pandemic, and what species could be super spreaders, something that is also relevant to Environment Agency as a potential major incident. Future research, using machine learning and artificial intelligence to explore intelligence on this complex problem, could establish patterns of the scale and magnitude of bird flu outbreaks increasing over time. This can include information such as how many pathogens animals carry, geographic range of Avian flu outbreaks and which other species are impacted, to gain a better understanding of the occurrence and transmission of diseases. Another study warns that climate change has an impact increasing the risk of viral spill overs when viruses move from one species to another.
Primary Article Title: New study exonerates some urban pests as one-of-a-kind disease reservoirs

Summary Sentence: Ore-sand could be the sustainable solution for construction industry’s biggest waste stream.
Justification: Mineral waste, the world’s largest waste stream, could be reduced in quantity by a change in mineral processing which additionally could create sand for construction as a by-product in a sustainable way. This is relevant to Environment Agency because sand extracted from quarries, rivers and other locations is the most exploited natural resource, yet even Environment Agency needs it for their own construction work including flood defences. The extraction of sand at large quantities evidently leads to environmental impacts such as erosion, loss of habitats and carbon emissions originated from the sand production process. Instead of ending up as mining waste, the so-called ore-sand can be repurposed and therefore this finding has potential to reduce sand extraction and support the trend towards circular economy, by providing a more sustainable option for substituting sand as construction material and for industrial use. The researchers estimate that potentially half of sand markets globally can locate a local source for gaining ore-sand, hence reduce carbon emissions from lorries. The mining companies are likely to take advantage of this benefit because the waste product can generate them additional income.
Primary Article Title: Solution To World’s Largest Waste Stream&%2358; Make Sand

Summary Sentence: Sugar concentrations underneath the seagrass meadows can tie blue carbon long term.
Justification: Researchers from the Max Planck Institute for Marine Microbiology in Germany have completed research on seagrass, Posidonia oceanica, a species belonging to critical coastal ecosystems, discovering that seagrass meadows release a large quantity of sucrose into the soil beneath them, the so-called rhizosphere. It is already known to Environment Agency that seagrass meadows perform as one of the most efficient carbon dioxide sinks, removing twice as much as woodlands but 35 times faster. The new finding is significant because the amount of sugar released is at least 80 times more than previously thought for the marine environments, with an estimate of more than one million tons of sucrose worldwide, indicating significant consequences for carbon burial. Due to seagrasses excreting phenolic compounds that prevent most microorganisms from degrading the sucrose, the sucrose remains buried under the seagrass meadows. This means it cannot be converted into carbon dioxide&%23160;and returned to the seas and atmosphere, preserving blue carbon long-term in these coastal ecosystems.
Primary Article Title: Sweet spots in the sea

Summary Sentence: A court has applied rights of nature to an individual wild animal, linking the legal system and justice to the legal rights of ecosystems.
Justification: Ecuador is the second country in the world that has brought ‘rights of nature’ into legislation and this year for the first time a court in Quito applied them, in this case to a single woolly monkey that had been kept as a pet. This may be of interest to Environment Agency because rights of nature have now reached a different, more central, level than previously now that they can be applied to individuals or smaller groups, and government has an obligation to develop new legislation to ensure these legal rights are considered. In Ecuador, with oil and mining industries, this development is significant change because any human can now declare themselves as a guardian of animal or animals, acting on their behalf and ask judges to enforce those rights. Chile and Ecuador are paving the way towards a more just future by having granted rights to nature at this level, and other countries may follow. Bolivia, New Zealand, Colombia, and Bangladesh recognize the rights of nature, for example rights of a river as an entity that could be murdered.&%23160;It is noteworthy that the rights of nature movement in Ecuador may be linked to the strong rights for young people, with voting age of 16, and a president that is second youngest in the world.
Primary Article Title: Ecuador’s High Court Rules That Wild Animals Have Legal Rights

Summary Sentence: Methane reducing seaweed diet supplement for Ben& Jerry’s dairy cows.
Justification: This is an interesting development for the Environment Agency as a regulator of agriculture as well as for the potential future growth commercial seaweed production industry which will need to be regulated. In the US seaweed is grown inland in tanks by a company called Blue Ocean Barns. Seaweed diet supplements have been developed for use in cow feed because they produce large methane reductions (%2313800). Asparagopsis taxiformis, which is a seaweed produced for human consumption, was found to reduce methane emissions in cows by more than 99%, at fairly low doses (2% of the cow’s total diet). The seaweed contains a compound called bromoform that prevents cows from producing methane as a by-product by altering micro-organisms in the gut. Now, the use of seaweed as a feedstock has been approved by the California Department for Food and Agriculture in the US and is being used in commercially viable dairy farms. The supplement developed is called Brominata, and is made from a dehydrated form A. taxiformis. The addition of this supplement has been shown to reduce methane emissions from cows' burps by up to 80%. In cows, belched methane is lost energy, meaning that if a cow can retain it, then it actually needs less food to create the same amount of milk. Ben & Jerry’s “Project Mootopia” will roll out initially to 15 farms in the U.S. and the Netherlands. The cows will be monitored and all findings will be made public to benefit the entire dairy industry. The company hopes that by 2024 these farms will emit half the industry average for greenhouse gas emissions. One quarter of global methane emissions are produced by cows and improvements like this could make a real difference.
Primary Article Title: Ben & Jerry's Puts Cows on a Special Diet to Curb Methane Emissions

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a new ‘biocement’ using two common waste materials&%2358; industrial carbide sludge and urea.
Justification: The Environment Agency could utilise this new material in construction and flood defence as a more sustainable alternative to cement. Researchers from Nanyang Technological University, Singapore developed the process in which the reaction of urea with calcium ions in industrial carbide sludge forms a hard solid, or precipitate. Firstly, the carbide sludge is treated with an acid to produce soluble calcium. Urea is then added to the soluble calcium to form a cementation solution, then a bacterial culture is added to this. The bacteria from the culture break down the urea in the solution to form carbonate ions. These ions react with the soluble calcium ions in a process called microbially induced calcite precipitation (MICP). This reaction forms calcium carbonate—a solid material that is naturally found in chalk. When this reaction takes place in soil, the precipitate binds soil particles together and fills the gaps between them, creating a compact mass of soil. This results in a strong, less permeable block of biocement. The new material could offers a sustainable and cost-effective method for soil improvement. Uses include; strengthening the ground for construction or excavation, controlling beach erosion, reducing dust or wind erosion in the desert, and building freshwater reservoirs on beaches or in the desert. The team is also exploring further large-scale applications such as road repair, sealing gaps tunnels to prevent water seepage, or even as a growth media for coral reefs as coral larvae are attracted to calcium carbonate. Soil improvement by MICP can meet the requirement of green construction because the process exerts minimal disturbance to the soil and environment. It involves the natural process of in situ urease hydrolysis by selected micro-organisms that can be found in abundance in soil and groundwater. Nevertheless, the MICP technique may not be entirely environmentally friendly. The process may still generate by-products, i.e., ammonium and its oxidized by-product nitrate, which can be hazardous to human health and soil organisms, particularly at high concentrations.
Primary Article Title: Scientists create renewable biocement made entirely from waste materials

Summary Sentence: French start-up Glowee is using bioluminescent bacteria for indoor lighting.
Justification: This would be interesting to the Environment Agency both in terms of low energy lighting for net zero ambitions and as a regulatory body when considering the disposal of bioluminescent biological waste and the regulation of GM plants. Glowee uses a marine bacterium collected off the coast of France called Aliivibrio fischeri is used to produce bioluminescent the light. The bacteria are stored inside saltwater-filled tubes, allowing them to circulate freely. Since the light is generated through internal biochemical processes that are part of the organism's normal metabolism, running it requires almost no energy other than the nutrients needed to produce the food the bacteria consume. A mix of basic nutrients is added and air is pumped through the water to provide oxygen. To "turn off the lights", the air is simply cut off, halting the process by sending the bacteria into an anaerobic state where it does not produce bioluminescence. The manufacturing process, consumes less water than manufacturing LEDs and releases less CO2, while the liquid is also biodegradable. The lights also use less electricity to run than LEDs, according to the company, Carl Johnson, professor of biological sciences at Vanderbilt University, believes there are serious challenges. These challenges include; providing enough nutrients, diluting the bacteria as they grow, temperature dependence of the bioluminescent reaction, extending duration of bioluminescence and increasing the brightness. As an alternative, Glowee is investigating "chemiluminescence", the chemical process that produces bioluminescence and removes the need for live bacteria. A separate group in Russia have developed bioluminescent plants able to glow 10 times brighter and for longer than previous efforts which could offer an alternative solution to Glowee’s luminescent tubes.
Primary Article Title: The French town where the lighting is alive
Author: Peter Yeung
Secondary_URLs: Plants with genetically encoded autoluminescence | Nature Biotechnology
Keywords: Bioluminescent Bioluminescence Lighting “Natural lighting” Sustainability “Nature based solutions” Chemiluminescence “Urban lighting” “Street lights”

Summary Sentence: Google CEO Sundar Pichai teased a smart glasses prototype the company is working on that can translate languages in real time.
Justification: The Environment Agency could use this technology in their operations when communicating with non-native English speakers or the deaf or hard of hearing, but need to be aware of the risks around relying on imperfect translation software. The glasses work by translating spoken language into text in the users chosen language with text appearing on the glass. These glasses can also transcribe the spoken word to text for those that struggle with hearing. The possibility of removing language and hearing barriers with real time translation would be revolutionary. In the future this could transform how we interact with non-English speakers and those that are hard of hearing, providing a platform for improved acceptance. Google translate has improved a lot over the last decade but is far from perfect, particularly when translating from logogram (character) based languages such as Chinese. Translation software also struggles with the subtlety of linguistics and precise meanings can be lost. This could be problematic if using the glasses translation to convey legal or technical information with potential for miscommunication or deniability of understanding. Google translate is likely to continue to improve, especially for widely spoken languages, and eventually translation should be consistently reliable.
Primary Article Title: GOOGLE AR GLASSES WITH LIVE TRANSLATIONS COULD CHANGE THE WORLD
Author: Melissa Truth Miller

Summary Sentence: A new study suggests that people could be carrying microplastics in their blood.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in yet further examples of the extent of microplastics contamination and the potential health and environmental impacts. In a study of 22 individuals, 17 were found to have plastic particles in their blood between 700 and 500,000 nanometres (nm) - 700 nm is around 140 times smaller than the width of a human hair. Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) and polystyrene were the two most commonly found plastics. The exact routes of contamination aren’t currently known, and neither is it clear if any plastic in blood accumulates in the body or if it is excreted in some form.
Primary Article Title: Microplastics detected in human blood in new study
Author: Osborne, M
Secondary_URLs: Discovery and quantification of plastic particle pollution in human blood - ScienceDirect
Keywords: health waste pollution plastic microplastic human blood regulation

Summary Sentence: Human trials of a male contraceptive pill could start before the end of 2022.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this development and the impact it could have on water quality and aquatic life, as chemicals from female contraceptive pills, such as oestrogen are already recognised as having endocrine disrupting properties in fish and amphibians. The experimental pill is non-hormonal. It works by blocking proteins from binding to vitamin A, which is known to be crucial to fertility and virility in mammals. The drug was found to be 99 percent effective at preventing pregnancy in mice, with no apparent side effects. Mice became sterile after four weeks of dosage, which quickly returned to normal in a similar period once dosage had stopped. A gel for male birth control, applied topically, is also undergoing trials.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Male birth control pill expected to start human trials this year
Author: Wetzel, C
Keywords: water pollution pollutant "water quality" chemical chemistry women men contraception health pill oestrogen EDC "endocrine disrupting chemical" hormone "vitamin A" mice sterile regulation wildlife fish amphibian

Summary Sentence: Renewable energy systems need to be designed to cope with changing wind and solar patterns.
Justification: As the world is shifting towards expanding use of renewable energy sources, researchers have used an algorithm for modelling the wind and solar energy potential variability over different periods of time. They concluded that with renewables there could be even a four - six months’ gaps in energy in future, or even a year of a so-called ‘energy drought’, hence backup energy sources are always required, something that should be of interest to Environment Agency. The threshold level for changing wind and solar patterns was established at the 30th percentile, meaning if 30 % are low production days this may lead to an energy drought. The study was conducted in Texas because the state is the largest generator of wind power and the fifth largest solar power producer, additionally the state already has a grid larger than many countries do. The recommendation is for this research to guide investment decision-making for renewable energy sources as we combat climate change, to ensure we split the risk by investing in multiple technologies. For the next stage of the research project, the focus is on forecasting energy floods, not just periods of energy droughts.
Primary Article Title: You've heard of water droughts. Could 'energy' droughts be next?

Summary Sentence: Talent shortages can impact organisational resilience in science and technology for pushing for innovation both in China and in the UK.
Justification: Shortage of foreign workers with the right talent and skills seems to be causing serious implications to organisations and companies in China, enthusiastic to collaborate and do business with Western countries. This is significant because China’s technological power is still on the rise, and they need a supply of talent and skills to push for this objective. The potential similarity lies with European Union Exit and what the short- and long-term impacts are for United Kingdom in attracting especially science and technology students from abroad and specialists in areas that are relevant to innovation and science. Talent acquisition is of importance as United Kingdom attempts to remain as a one of the top soft power countries in the world and a world leader in many areas linked to science and technology and innovation such as flood management and climate change mitigation. In the long term this may impact Environment Agency’s organisational resilience, workforce planning and skillsets required to fulfil our aspirations, hence there is a need to attract talent as a key resource in technological innovation.

Summary Sentence: Construction for world’s biggest and nature-centred animal crossing in California has started with mainly private funding.
Justification: The Wallis Annenberg Wildlife Crossing in California is a new restoration project, mainly funded by private donations, bringing novel design and scale for wildlife crossings, allowing especially nocturnal animals pass safely without noise, light or scent from humans. The novel consequence to Environment Agency and Natural England, who already build habitat corridors and do habitat restoration, is that we may have a larger scale need for more wildlife crossings as wildfires become more frequent with climate change, especially with peat areas on the Pennines at risk. The highway with ten lanes has been lethal for many animal species especially the protected mountain lions, and the new 210-foot long, 165-foot wide has sound walls and is topped with soil and native vegetation and provides a safe pass in the mountains. The studies demonstrate that it can take even five years for some species to learn to use a wildlife corridor such as this, with the smaller species becoming comfortable of accessing it before the large mammals. Not only the freedom of movement across habitats may enhance genetic variety for rare species in future, but this crossing also sets a precedent for use of nature-centric design in rewilding and habitat restoration. As this highway location has over 300,00 cars crossing daily, investing in wildlife crossing makes sense from economic and human safety point of view. A study from Banff National Park in Canada, where they increased the number of both under and overpasses, establishes that there was a 90 per cent decrease in collisions between wildlife and vehicles.
Primary Article Title: World’s Largest Wildlife Crossing Will Soon Stretch Across California’s Highway 101

Summary Sentence: CRISPR tool reverse one big consequence of "teenage" drinking in rats
Justification: The Environment Agency should monitor the development of novel epigenetic editing tools as they offer potential for future treatment of DNA damage caused chemical substances, such as pesticides. Epigenetic editing has been used to reverse the impacts of teenage binge drinking in rats. Epigenetics refers to changes in gene expression rather than the gene itself. Binge drinking during adolescence has a serious impact on the brain. One of the consequences of heavy drinking is a change in the gene that influences the operation of part of the brain. This change can cause anxiety in later life. Adolescent binge drinking is also a major risk factor for psychiatric disorders later in life including alcohol use disorder. Adolescent alcohol exposure induces epigenetic reprogramming and decreases Arc (a cytoskeleton protein) expression in the amygdala of both rodents and humans. Researchers used a gene-editing tool called CRISPR-dCas9 to physically manipulate the DNA by histone acetylation and removing deficits in Arc expression, leading to attenuation of adult anxiety and excessive alcohol drinking in a rat model of adolescent alcohol exposure. In the past CRISPR has been used to treat genetic disorders such as sickle cell disease via direct gene editing. This research illustrates the possibility of repairing DNA damage using CRISPR, rather than cutting and editing DNA directly. The development of novel epigenetic editing tools allows for the treatment DNA damage and gene expression potentially could be used to repair damage caused by a range of factors, such as chemical exposure.
Primary Article Title: CRISPR tool reverse one big consequence of "teenage" drinking in rats
Author: Grant Currin
Keywords: CRISPR Epigenetics Genetics “Epigenetic editing” “Disease treatment” “DNA damage” Alcoholism “Gene expression”

Summary Sentence: An inquiry brought about by Filipino typhoon survivors has found that the world’s most polluting companies have a moral and legal obligation to address the harms of climate change.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should keep ahead of movements that push for climate accountability by polluting companies both as a regulator of polluting industries and as a foundation to encourage more stringent regulations. The Philippines Commission on Human Rights have concluded that the world’s most polluting companies are morally and legally liable for the impacts of the climate crisis because they have engaged in wilful obfuscation of climate science and obstructed efforts towards a global transition to clean energy. While the commission does not have the power to hold the companies legally responsible or to fine them, experts hope the report will inform the development of new laws and lawsuits in the Philippines, and the vast body of evidence it has collected will be used by policymakers, lawyers and climate campaigners around the world. Yeb Saño, the executive director of Greenpeace Southeast Asia said “This report is historic and sets a solid legal basis for asserting that climate-destructive business activities by fossil fuel and cement companies contribute to human rights harms.” The report builds on other recent lawsuits, including a Dutch court ruling that Shell had to cut its emissions by 45% by 2030.

&%23160;

Summary Sentence: The AI Company Hypervine uses data to improve construction efficiency.
Justification:
The Environment Agency could consider utilising similar methods to reduce costs and carbon emissions in their construction activities or as a tool for improved monitoring of regulated businesses. &%23160;The AI Company Hypervine has successfully partnered with Morrison Construction to provide data based improvements in site use and construction efficiency. Hypervine is a ‘cleantech’ construction start up that “provide end-to-end site data for construction and mining firms, boosting efficiencies whilst enabling massive reductions in carbon emissions”. Hypervine, in partnership with the European Space Agency, uses real time high resolution satellite data to analyse site use and identify efficiency improvements. Hypervine’s partnership with Morrison Construction apparently created a competitive advantage over other bids, allowing the construction firm to win its DV2 bid with Scottish Water. Collecting real time data on construction also creates accountability, both in terms of meeting deadlines and adhering to planning regulations. DV2 is one of Scotland’s largest capital investment infrastructure programs to date, and an opportunity to showcase how technology can augment the construction process to improve operations for years to come. Morrinson’s Construction have trialled Hypervine’s system on some of their construction sites and were “impressed with the initial outcomes”.

&%23160;
Primary Article Title: AI and Blockchain start-up brought into major Scottish infrastructure framework

Summary Sentence: Researchers from Hull York medical have found microplastics in the lung tissue of living humans.
Justification: The Environment Agency and its partners should consider monitoring microplastics as a form of air pollution and track research into their associated health impacts. The research identified 39 microplastics found in 11 of 13 samples tested, which is a much higher occurrence than expected. The samples were collected from individuals undergoing chest surgery, but it is unknown whether the presence of microplastics was having an impact on health. Past research has found microplastics in the lung tissue of deceased people but this is the first instance in living people. &%23160;The range and quantity of microplastics present were higher than in any previously recorded study with 12 different types of plastic identified, 49% of which were in fibre form. The microplastic particles were also larger than expected, with the largest being beyond the size previously thought possible for inhalation to the lower airway. One of the researchers, Dr Sadofsky said “microplastics are present in the air that we breathe, so it is possible that we are inhaling these particles without noticing." Interestingly, males had more particles than females which could be due to the larger sized respiratory tract in men.
Primary Article Title: Microplastic Particles Are Found Deep in Human Lungs
Author: Katherine Martinko
Keywords: Microplastic “Human health” “Public health” “Air quality” “Lung tissue” Plastic “Plastic pollution”

Summary Sentence: Invasive insects are predicted to kill 90% of all urban trees in the next 30 years in the USA and the same can happen in the UK.
Justification: Ecology researchers combined modelling of invasive species spread and mapping of trees in urban setting, finding out that invasive insect species have the potential to kill a substantial number of urban trees by 2050. The implications to Environment Agency are that this needs to be considered from biodiversity perspective and to inform urban planning, management and policies since urban trees provide well-being value for human health and happiness, reduce air pollution, collect dust and in other ways are great nature-based solutions. Many cities tend to do monoculture planting which increases the risk of invasive species impacts, and the financial impacts of removing dead trees and replacing them at this scale is considerable. According to The British Ecological Society, 90% of trees will be attacked by emerald ash borer larvae, and in “mortality hot spots” including New York City and Chicago, even 95% of trees, particularly killing all ash trees. In future, other wood borer species are likely to attack maples and oaks in a similar manner. The cost to the society will be on average of US$ 30&%23160;million annually. Before this large-scale study of over 30,000 urban centres and 57 insect species the spatial distribution and magnitude of the risk to urban trees was not known, and therefore, urban planners must urgently diversify the tree species they have planted as diversity of species delivers greater resilience against invasive species
Primary Article Title: Invasive Insects Will Kill 1.4 Million U.S. Street Trees by 2050, Scientists Estimate
Author: Hemingway Jaynes, Christen

Summary Sentence: Privacy and technology challenges were experienced with the cryptocurrency company that wants to scan everyone’s eyes for a biometric data base.
Justification: Ambitious start-up company Worldcoin attempts to move towards using digital money and for this purpose they want to scan and digitise irises of every person globally. The significance to Environment Agency is that this type of digital identity systems could improve access to our initiatives and services, yet privacy and secure data storage issues can deter people from participating and reduce trust. Worldcoin’s intention of using irises to create digital identities for individuals has been delayed by fraud and technological challenges. One of the main issues was the need for a smartphone which immediately limits the scope of the endeavour in a global scale and fraudulent activity, the problem this was designed to stop. Nevertheless, the have already scanned and collated digital images of&%23160;about half a million people in over twenty countries, and Worldcoin is a guardian of very sensitive biometric data. Europe is moving from simple fingerprinting to creating an international facial recognition system, available to police to view millions of pictures of people’s faces. Better data protection and more trust in this type of Government systems is vital for any future success.
Primary Article Title: Crypto Startup That Wants to Scan Everyone’s Eyeballs Is Having Some Trouble

Summary Sentence: Researchers have created a polymer membrane that improves efficiency of carbon dioxide capture from mixed gasses.
Justification: Carbon capture will be necessary in order to meet the UK’s net zero targets and the Environment Agency as a regulatory body should take an interest in the development of this technology. Membranes are an attractive technology for removing CO2 from mixed gases because they do not take up much physical space, they can be made in a wide variety of sizes, and they can be easily replaced. The membrane developed in this study focussed on the removal of CO2 from mixed gasses such as those emitted from power plants. They were able to improve the selectivity CO2 removal, while retaining relatively high CO2 permeability for both CO2/ nitrogen and CO2/ methane mixtures. These gas mixtures are particularly relevant in the context of reducing greenhouse gas emission from power plants. These membranes work by allowing CO2 to pass through more quickly than other gasses, meaning you end up with a higher percentage of CO2 compared to other gasses on the other side of the membrane. The gas that passes through the membrane can be captured and removed. In the past membrane filters have struggled to deal with the issue of permeability versus selectivity. The more permeable a membrane is, the faster gasses can pass through. However, more permeable membranes are less selective, allowing non-target gas through at the same time. To tackle this the team grew hydrophilic and CO2-philic polymer chains on the membrane surface which increased selectivity with little impact on permeability. This work was a proof-of-concept and optimisation, scaling and cost need to be addressed in future research. Membranes offer an alternative to CO2 absorption which have a significantly larger footprint, and use liquid amines that tend to be toxic and corrosive.
Primary Article Title: New polymer membrane tech improves efficiency of carbon dioxide capture
Keywords: CO2 “Carbon dioxide” “Carbon capture” Membrane “Membrane filter” “CO2 filter” “Polymer membrane”

Summary Sentence: A mass demonstration swim is planned at Kinder Reservoir in the Peak District to protest the lack of access to open water swimming sites in England.
Justification: The Environment Agency regulates the water companies that own these reservoirs and they may be liable if an accident occurs. In addition, swimming may increase contamination of the water – with cosmetics like sun cream known to be damaging to wildlife. The Environment Agency may want to consider initiating a “before and after” contamination study to investigate impacts if swimming is permitted. This “swimpass” is reminiscent of the Kinder mass-trespass of 1932, which protested the lack of countryside access and eventually led to the creation of the UK’s first national park. Organised by the Outdoor Swimming Society (OSS) who dispute the “widespread lack of undisputed access to inland open water in England and Wales, and the disconnect this causes between people, water, and each other”. Concerns over safety have been the main counter-argument by United Utilities who own the reservoir and operate a blanket no swimming ban. The OSS argues that water companies have a statutory duty to provide recreational access to waterways, not just for angling and dog walking but also swimming. In Scotland, swimmers have since 2003 enjoyed a right to swim freely in almost all Scottish reservoirs. Catherine West MP attended and supported the event. Since covid lockdown, visitor numbers natural beauty sites have risen sharply and, at Dovestones Reservoir near Oldham this has led to emergency order due to the sheer number of visitors. There is concern that allowing swimming may exacerbate these issues, with the potential for contamination of waterbodies.
Primary Article Title: The right to swim&%2358; mass trespass of Kinder reservoir planned
Author: Helen Pidd
Secondary_URLs:
https&%2358;//www.outdoorswimmingsociety.com/kinder-mass-trespass/

Summary Sentence: A research group has compiled a list detailing the jobs that are most to least likely to be replaced by automation in the future.
Justification: for both manual and office-type work. To achieve this a team of roboticists from EPFL and economists from the University of Lausanne by combining their expertise on robotic abilities with employment and wage statistics. The group reviewed research papers, patents, and description of robotic products to assess the maturity level of robotic abilities. By comparing the technology readiness level for each of these abilities to the skills required for about 1,000 occupations they were able to assess probability of automation. The tool also are also offers advice on how to transition to more secure roles. In general, jobs in food processing, building and maintenance, construction and extraction appear to have the highest risk. It is hoped that this method can be used by governments to measure how many workers could face automation risks and adjust retraining policies, as well as by companies to assess the costs of increasing automation, by robotics manufacturers to better tailor their products to the market needs; and by the public to identify the easiest route to reposition themselves on the job market.
Primary Article Title: How to compete with robots
Keywords: Automation “Job security” Robotics “Role transition” “Skill shortage” “Job market”

Summary Sentence: A recent boom in research involving nano-particles can provide solutions ranging from novel pesticides to eco-friendly asphalt but associated environmental issues are coming to light.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be aware of the impacts and environmental endpoints of nano-particles, which can contaminate water sources and are not removed by wastewater treatment. There seems to have been something of a nano-revolution brewing, with nano-particles providing the ‘magic ingredient’ for a range of innovations, often marketed as eco-friendly. Even Ikea have capitalised on this trend, adding “air purifying” titanium dioxide to curtains. Nano-particles include any molecule smaller than 100 nanometres (a human hair is approximately 80,000nm thick). Although nano-particles exist in nature, they can be manufactured and their small size means that they have a range of useful properties. In medicine, they can transport cancer drugs directly into tumour cells, in agriculture they could direct pesticides to specific parts of a plant. Already nano-silver is added to textiles to provide antimicrobial activity. Scientists are worried that nano-particles will end up in the environment, particularly through washing of nano-infused clothes. Some nano particles have been shown to negatively affect marine wildlife including fish and crustaceans and resistance to antimicrobial nano-silver can develop – silver-tolerant soil bacteria have now been found. Little is known even about where nanoparticles are, let alone their effects on the environment. As they are so tiny, most experiments are conducted in labs, and it can be hard to pin down where they are applied. Scientists are concerned that nano particles could bind to and transport toxic pollutants, and possibly be toxic themselves by generating reactive free radicals. By binding to toxic compounds these nano particles could act as toxic delivery systems, able to be absorbed by marine organisms. From August, the EU will ban use of TiO2 in food (where it is called E171) and the European Commission recently announced that 12 nanomaterials would soon be prohibited in cosmetics.
Primary Article Title: Nano state&%2358; tiny and now everywhere, how big a problem are nanoparticles?
Author: Anna Turns
Keywords: Nano-particles “Nano particles” “Environmental endpoints” “Harmful effects” “Environmental impact” “Materials science” “Toxic particles” “Water contamination”

Summary Sentence: Pintrest is the first social media company to directly ban climate misinformation.
Justification: Disinformation can be very damaging to the Environment Agency and society as a whole and this move could limit its spread. Where other social media companies have shirked their responsibility on the spread of misinformation on their platforms, Pintrest is setting a precedent in this field. The image-based social media company will remove content that denies or distorts facts about climate change. The move by Pintrest could also create a ‘bubble’ effect where mainstream platforms are ‘sanitised’ and only certain, less conventional platforms deal in disinformation. In contrast, Elon Musk, who is a free speech advocate, has made an offer to buy Twitter and may be keen to influence the company on this issue, counter to the move made by Pintrest. In addition, the relevance of Pintrest as a social media platform is also debatable, with only 431 million, compared to 540 million on Telegram and 1 billion on TikTok. Therefore this move may be less impactful than hoped. The demographics of users on social media platforms varies, with younger users tending toward TikTok (the largest age group being 10 to 19 year olds) and older users tending toward Pintrest (Largest age group being 50-64). The impact of removing disinformation is debatable but older users are likely to be more easily influenced by disinformation with over 65s sharing more fake news than any other age group.
Primary Article Title: Pinterest announces ban on all climate misinformation
Author: Alex Hern
Secondary_URLs:
https&%2358;//www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/jan/10/older-people-more-likely-to-share-fake-news-on-facebook

Summary Sentence: Researchers have created a nano asphalt binder that reduces energy consumption and slows asphalt aging.
Justification: The Environment Agency could implement this new asphalt into their construction supply chains to reduce their associated carbon footprint and help achieve net zero. The product is part of a new class, known as ‘warm mix asphalts’ which are produced at temperatures of up to 40°C lower than ordinary asphalt. Switching to warm mix asphalts, therefore, would save roughly 61,000 tonnes of CO2 each year in the UK, which is the equivalent of reducing 300 million miles of automobile travel. The novelty, developed by researchers at the University of Swansea and the Technical University of Braunschweig, is the addition of engineered clay/fumed silica nanocomposites during the production of the asphalt. This acts as a binding material and provides anti-aging properties to the asphalt. Not only this, the new mixture serves to further reduce temperatures and also overcomes significant limitations caused by moisture susceptibility in the asphalt. Researcher, Prof. Andrew Barren claims "Compared to commercial materials, our solution requires lower concentrations (less than 0.3 wt.%) of additives due to their superior surface activity, and as such has the potential to solve some of the challenges associated with, less durable the roads." The fumed SiO2 nanoparticles are considered to be non-toxic and environmentally friendly.
Primary Article Title: Improving asphalt road pavement using engineered nano mineral composites
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/ntrev-2022-0062/html
Keywords: “Nano particles” “nano materials” “Low carbon construction” “Warm mix asphalt” “Asphalt binder” Asphalt Anti-aging&%23160; “Fumed SiO2” nanoparticles Nanomaterials

Summary Sentence: Researchers have discovered an enzyme that breaks down terephthalate (TPA), one of the chemical building blocks of polyethylene terephthalate (PET).
Justification: As regulators of the waste industry, the Environment Agency should monitor the development of new methods of tackling plastic waste. This is an important development in the field of plastic digestion because PET is currently broken down to ethylene glycol, which has several uses, and TPA, which is generally pretty useless. TPA does not have many uses outside of PET, nor is it something that most bacteria can even digest. However, the Portsmouth team revealed that an enzyme from PET-consuming bacteria recognises TPA like a hand in a glove. The group then demonstrated that this enzyme, called TPADO, breaks down TPA and pretty much only TPA, with amazing efficiency. The break down products could potentially be used for other applications or be broken down further. More than 400 million tons of plastic waste is produced each year and the overwhelming majority of this ends up in landfills. It is hoped that this work will open the door to improve bacterial enzymes, such as TPADO. This will help tackle the challenge of plastic pollution and develop biological systems that can convert waste plastic into valuable products.
Primary Article Title: New enzyme discovery is another leap towards beating plastic waste
Keywords: Plastic “Plastic waste” “Plastic recycling” Recycling Digestion “Plastic digestion” “Plastic breakdown” Enzyme

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a method for turning pitch, the waste material from the refining of petroleum, into a useful carbon fibre like material.
Justification: This new material is a light-weight, low cost alternative to carbon fibre and could be utilised by the Environment Agency when upgrading their vehicle fleet in order to reduce fuel consumption as well as for the move to electrical vehicles. &%23160;Cars have become heavier over the past 30 years, driving up their fuel consumption. Heavier cars also require larger components such as a bigger engine and stronger brakes, leading to a ripple effect. Carbon fibre is a strong, lightweight alternative material for the production of car panels, but due to its high cost it has only been used for luxury cars. Now, the search for a tough, low cost, lightweight material may be over. This new material could offer a cheap alternative to carbon fibre, with the added benefit of having compressional strength. The feedstock material, pitch, is a waste product that is too dirty to use as a fuel and often ends up in landfill. Not only does this offer a new way of recycling pitch but the cheap, lightweight materials could be used to reduce vehicle weight and tackle transport related emissions.
Primary Article Title: Could we make cars out of petroleum residue?
Author: David L. Chandler
Keywords: “Material science” “Carbon fibre” “Alternative material” Lightweight Low-cost Recycle Pitch “Automotive industry”

Summary Sentence: An environmental activist group is calling for a change in the way that Bitcoin works, which could greatly reduce the cryptocurrency’s energy use.&%23160;
Justification: This development may overcome an issue in wider adoption of virtual currencies and some applications of blockchain technology, which could lead to wider acceptance and adoption of a technology already recognised as having potential business use for the Environment Agency and partners. Bitcoin has gained attention and concern from the environmental community due to the significant energy and hardware resources required to ‘mine’ it, i.e. process transactions on the Bitcoin decentralised network. Verifying a transaction involves solving a complex mathematical equation, for which the solver is paid a fraction of Bitcoin. In order to remain competitive and profitable Bitcoin miners must constantly invest in faster processing hardware and the energy needed to run large Bitcoin mining operations. Sites such as defunct aluminium smelting plants (%2315142) have been repurposed for mining. It is currently estimated that Bitcoin mining has the equivalent energy footprint of Sweden. A campaign called Change the Code Not the Climate is coordinated by Environmental Working Group, Greenpeace USA and several groups battling the impacts of bitcoin mining facilities in their communities. They are calling on the Bitcoin community to change the way bitcoins are mined to greatly reduce its carbon footprint. Rival cryptocurrencies, such as Etherium, have already moved from the energy intensive “proof of work” verification to “proof of stake”, which could reduce energy consumption by 99 per cent. &%23160;With proof of stake, miners pledge their coins to verify transactions with inaccurate information leading to penalties. The campaigners argue that as the World’s biggest virtual currency that Bitcoin needs to follow Etherium’s example, otherwise its continuation incentivises greater energy use, which renewables would be unable to meet. Other protocols exist for processing virtual currency payments which have advantages over Bitcoin in terms of energy efficiency (%2314124) and volume (%2314281), which could suggest that unless Bitcoin changes environmental concerns could lead to it being abandoned for other less impactful currencies.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Climate groups say a change in coding can reduce bitcoin energy consumption by 99%
Author: Rushe, D
Keywords: energy "climate change" "virtual currency" cryptocurrency cryptocurrencies BitCoin Etherium resource carbon renewable hardware mining Greenpeace "Environmental Working Group" Sweden "Change the Code Not the Climate" regulation information technology IT

Summary Sentence: Exon Mobil is planning to use the energy from flaring excess natural gas to power bitcoin mining.
Justification: If this catches on in the UK the Environment Agency will need to closely monitor regulated businesses because the move has the potential to make flaring a profitable activity which will need to be considered when issuing permits. The move is being marketed as ‘reducing waste’ but may in fact encourage continued flaring and discourage more effective measures such as transitioning away from fossil fuels. If this proves to be a profitable activity in the UK, it may have an impact air quality and climate targets by encouraging flaring under the guise of reducing waste gas. Currently Exon Mobil is piloting the scheme in cooperation with Crusoe Energy Systems Inc. in North Dakota, utilising up to 18 million cubic feet of gas per month that would have otherwise been wasted due to a lack of pipelines. The excess gas is used to generate electricity which powers large Bitcoin mining servers meaning that “greenhouse gas emissions are not simply created as waste”. Bitcoin mining is a very energy-intensive process consuming more electricity than even entire countries. If this generates profit, then it might be tempting for companies to produce additional waste gas that could be used to increase Bitcoin mining. According to an anonymous source, Exxon Mobil is considering similar pilots in Alaska, Nigeria, Argentina, Guyana, and Germany.
Primary Article Title: Exxon Mobil has a pilot project for using excess gas to mine Bitcoin
Author: Loukia Papadopoulos
Keywords: Flaring Cryptocurrency Bitcoin "Crypto mining" "Bitcoin mining" "Waste gas" ExxonMobil "Natural gas"

Summary Sentence: Researchers from the University of Waterloo have launched a website with a ‘microplastic fingerprinting library’ that can use to identify the source of plastics found in waterbodies.
Justification: The Environment Agency should monitor the success of this project as similar tools would help to inform water quality strategies. The project aims encourage contribution from citizens and other research groups to build a database of microplastic compositions and location. Currently, the group are asking for people to send in plastics collected from the environment. These will be analysed and their properties mapped into the fingerprinting library for future comparison with microplastic samples. This information can then be used to track the source, movement and fate of microplastics through a watercourse. Currently the project is aiming to ‘fingerprint’ the chemical properties of weathered plastic on a broad scale, so that, for example, crisp packets or bottles can be identified from microplastic samples. However, as the fingerprinting library becomes more detailed it might be possible to trace microplastics back to specific manufacturers. Improved understanding of the lifecycle of microplastics will help to pinpoint and eliminate major contributing sources as well as persistent sources. The project as a whole has four major objectives; Firstly to improve microplastic detection, secondly to track movement and fate of microplastics, third to assess climate vulnerability and finally to reduce point source inputs. This project is focussed on the Great Lakes but a similar project could be implemented in the UK.
Primary Article Title: UWaterloo launches Microplastics Fingerprinting Research Project website
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//uwaterloo.ca/microplastics-fingerprinting-research-project/news/call-microplastic-samples
Keywords: Microplastics "Microplastic fingerprint" "Fingerprint library" "Microplastic source" "Microplastic life-cycle"

Summary Sentence: Researchers at the University of Cincinnati have developed an electrochemical system that can convert emissions from power plants into valuable ethylene.
Justification: Once efficiency is improved the process could be implemented in some of the business that the Environment Agency regulate in order to reduce emissions in a cost effective way. The process takes place on an electrochemical plate and uses a two-step cascade reaction to convert carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide and then into ethylene. However, it is currently too energetically costly to be viable. Tandem catalysts enable sequential conversion of CO2-to-CO and then CO-to-ethylene. This new process design uses additional segmented electrodes in which a CO-selective layer at the inlet prolongs CO residence time which enhances conversion to ethylene. Ethylene can then be used to create a range of products including tyres and food packaging. This process allows the removal of greenhouse gasses while at the same time creating useful materials. Although not currently energetically viable, this new technique offers a promising step forwards. The hope is that this process can be optimised to make carbon conversion into ethylene a profitable process.
Primary Article Title: Conversion process turns carbon dioxide into cash
Author: Michael Miller
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.nature.com/articles/s41929-022-00751-0
Keywords: "Carbon emissions" "Carbon conversion" "Greenhouse gas" Electrochemical "Electrochemical conversion" Ethylene&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A multi-company collaboration has led to the development of the first recyclable wind turbine blade.
Justification: With the UK ramping up targets for wind power, the Environment Agency may want to promote the use of recyclable blades as part of their waste management remit when consulting with turbine construction companies. The turbine blades, which need to be light weight and robust, have been constructed using fibreglass (%2314254) and thermosetting plastic foam. The resin used in the turbine blade can be chemically treated to depolymerise and separate from the fibre, which can be reused again. In addition to this, the production method is automated which has the benefit of reduced waste as well as reduced energy consumption. Wind turbines are designed to last around 20 to 25 years and estimates suggest that 720,000 tonnes of wind turbine material will need to be disposed of over the next 20 years. The project was run by LM Wind Power, a GE's renewable energy company, and brought together experts from manufacturing, material science and recycling to develop the blade. The project is now conducting full scale testing after which validation of the recycling procedure will be run. This is due to be completed be 2023 after which time the blades will begin to be manufactured commercially. Elsewhere a Polish real estate developer has established a project for repurposing discarded wind turbine blades as architectural features. Turbines are currently constructed of difficult to recycle composite materials, which otherwise could be destined for landfill. Yareal has devised designs to repurpose segments of discarded blades as street furniture such as shelters and seating, as well as a footbridge constructed of recycled turbine blade parts. By 2023 14,000 wind turbine blades in Europe alone will reach the end of their lifespan, equating to 60,000 tonnes of composite waste. The problem of turbine blade waste could generate 43 million tonnes by 2050, which could make ;’wind waste’ a significant issue without innovative solutions in recycling and recovery.
Primary Article Title: The 203 ft wind turbine blade GE built is the world's largest
Author: Ameya Paleja
Secondary_URLs: Warsaw firm to turn old wind turbines into sleek outdoor eco furniture – The First News

Summary Sentence: Taking inspiration from dandelion seeds, researchers have created battery free, wireless sensors that drift in the wind collecting data.
Justification:
The Environment Agency could use these simple devises to monitor air quality after a polluting incident. The sensors are designed to be as light as possible and mimic the aerodynamics of dandelion seeds in order to maximise dispersal. Currently, the major challenge is reducing weight, given the electronics that are required. The sensors contain a solar panel to remove the need for a battery and a capacitor to store energy overnight. Data is transmitted wirelessly to detectors using backscatter which sends information by reflecting transmitted signals. The hope is that these low cost devices can be used in high numbers to easily cover large areas. At the moment, the sensors are about 30 times as heavy as a 1mg dandelion seed but can still travel up to 100 meters in a moderate breeze. Once on the ground, the device, which can hold at least four sensors, uses solar panels to power its onboard electronics and can share sensor data up to 60 meters away. The sensors monitor temperature, humidity and air pressure but could potentially be modified to monitor air pollution. The devices are designed to be dropped from a drone and spread across a monitoring site, collecting and sending data.

&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Tiny battery-free devices float in the wind like dandelion seeds
Keywords: "Environmental monitoring" Electronics Sensor "Data collection" Wireless "Sampling technique" Sampling Technology

Summary Sentence: Researchers from the University of Verona have found that long term exposure to air pollution increases the risk of auto-immune disease.
Justification: The Environment Agency needs to consider the mounting evidence linking air pollution to a variety of public health impacts when assessing their regulatory remit around air quality. In this study, long-term exposure to high levels of air pollution was associated with an approximately 40% higher risk of rheumatoid arthritis, a 20% higher risk of inflammatory bowel disease such as Crohn’s and ulcerative colitis, and a 15% higher risk of connective tissue diseases, such as lupus. Exposure to air pollution has been linked to a myriad of health issues, including&%2358; sex ratios (%2315155, %236835), gout (%2315147); chronic kidney disease (%2314686, %237577); kidney, bowel and bladder cancer (%2314105); brittle bones (%2314105) and dementia (%2313859). However, this is the first time it has been linked to auto-immune diseases. Although researchers were careful to point out that “their findings do not prove a causal link and that other factors may be at play”. The study analysed data from 81,363 people, comparing health issues to PM10 and PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) exposure. Concentration levels of 30µg/m3 for PM10 and 20µg/m3 for PM2.5 are associated with a 12% and 13% increased risk of autoimmune disease respectively, with every 10 µg/m3 increase in PM10 concentration associated with an incremental 7% risk of having autoimmune disease.
Primary Article Title: Air pollution linked to higher risk of autoimmune diseases
Author: Anna Bawden
Keywords: "Air pollution" Particulates "Air quality" Pollution "Public health" "Auto-immune" "Long term exposure" Health Disease

Summary Sentence: Researchers in Florida have identified a low bias method of amplifying trustworthy news sources on social media.
Justification: Disinformation that propagates over social media impacts public opinion on issues that are important to the Environment Agency such as climate change and can even influence political outcomes such as in the Brexit referendum. Disinformation spreads quickly on social media because engagement is used as a measure to boost posts within like-minded communities and users are shown similar posts to those that they have engaged with in the past. On top of this, low quality content that confirms what you already believe is engaging and this exacerbates the development of conspiracy theories. Researchers are attempting to break this cycle by looking for engaging posts that are aimed at a diverse audience. Rather than focusing on the number of views, the new algorithm uses a reliability score and the political diversity of their audience to boost content. Previously social media platforms have been reluctant to integrate algorithms that filter out misinformation due to the potential for partisan bias to be introduced. However, this algorithm specifically boosts content with a politically dispersed audience, which also tend to be more reliable. Researchers say that platforms could easily include audience diversity into their own recommendation algorithms because “diversity measures can be derived from engagement data, and platforms already log this type of data whenever users click "like" or share something on a newsfeed”.
Primary Article Title: Researchers find new way to amplify trustworthy news content on social media without shielding bias
Keywords: Misinformation Disinformation "Conspiracy theory" "Social media" "Trusted source" "Media content" "User engagement" Algorithm&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Several research groups have developed mechanisms to genetically modify pest insects causing them to produce sterile offspring and plans to release billions of these GM insects has been approved in America, but don’t worry because researchers have engineered a genetic kill switch to help quell concerns about modified genetic material escaping to the environment.
Justification:
The move toward genetic modification for pest control should be of interest to DEFRA and the Environment Agency because it may reduce reliance on damaging pesticides, however, unforeseen impacts of releasing GM insects into the environment should be monitored. The Environmental Protection Agency has approved plans by the biotech company Oxitec to release billions of male mosquitos with a modified gene that allows the expression of a protein called tTAV-OX5034. When these modified males reproduce with wild females the protein expression kills the female offspring. The hope is to reduce the spread of mosquito-borne diseases, however, Friends of the Earth have already raised concerns because genetic material from modified mosquitoes has been found in wild populations at significant levels suggesting that the mosquitos are not fully sterile. In addition, evolutionary pressure may drive new hybridisations between different species. The second species being targeted by researchers at North Carolina University is a type of fruit fly that can devastate fruit crops. The flies are modified with a female lethal gene that works when a common antibiotic is not provided in larval diets. Researchers at Washington State University are working on creating a kill switch – currently only targeting microbes – which integrates into any genetically engineered microbe, causing it to self-destruct under certain defined conditions. If a similar mechanism could be introduced into GM insects to allow activation of an emergency kill switch in the event of unforeseen environmental damage, this could improve confidence in the research. However, combating damage caused by genetic modification with more genetic modification seems somewhat risky and will be a hard sell to the public. &%23160;

&%23160;
Primary Article Title: The EPA approves plans to release billions of genetically modified mosquitos.
Author: Loukia Papadopoulos

Summary Sentence: The city of Paris, France has launched a project seeking to make the River Seine clean enough to swim in by 2024.
Justification: This ambition should be of interest to the Environment Agency, as it may herald similar ambitions from other cities around the World and in the UK. Paris is to host the Olympic Games in 2024, and there is an ambition to be able to hold swimming events in the Seine. However swimming has been banned in the river since 1923 due to pollution leading to poor water quality. Several administrations have attempted to clean the river in the past but with limited success, although fish species diversity has markedly improved. A canal in Paris is now open to swimming however this has to close periodically as water quality deteriorates. In order to fulfil the current ambition Paris is constructing a giant subterranean stormwater storage tank which will prevent sewage overflow during heavy rains. Sewage will then be pumped back into the water treatment system once heavy rain has passed. It will cost 1.4 billion euros ($1.6 billion) and have a capacity of 46,000 cubic metres. However it will still not be large enough to capture all estimated discharges, meaning that 100,000 cubic metres will still enter the river each year, creating ‘no swim’ conditions periodically. In Germany Berlin is creating a similar scheme on a branch of the river Spree which will reed beds to treat and clean water entering the river. A private funded scheme is also looking to introduce bathing pools sitting on the Thames in London, fed by river water. The Olympics are a major global media event, which could mean that, should Paris be successful in cleaning up the Seine, coverage could spark interest in similar ambitions in other cities around the World. Similar initiatives to Paris could help the Environment Agency and partners achieve its ambitions around water quality and public access to blue space. However, as recently demonstrated by activist groups who recently managed to achieve bathing water recognition for the River Wharfe in Ilkley, new bathing water designations could lead to greater monitoring and regulatory activity for the Environment Agency.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Paris has a new plan to make the Seine swimmable
Author: O'Sullivan, F

Summary Sentence: An inexpensive solar powered passive evaporation system could help to bring clean potable water to off-grid areas.&%23160;
Justification: This technology should be of interest to the Environment Agency as it suggests alternative, decentralised operational models to those currently associated with water supply provision, including the notion of water independence. The new desalination system overcomes a previous problem of salt accumulation (build-up) on components, which has previously hindered efficiency. The resulting wick free layered system consists of a dark heat absorbing material on the top which first absorbs the sun’s heat. A second thin perforated layer of water sits atop a reservoir of salt water. The sun’s heat generates a convective flow which draws salt out of the warm thin layer and down into the reservoir. While many similar systems have focussed on the use of advanced materials, this system consists of cheap and readily available materials. A one metre square device capable of providing enough water for one family would cost around $4, and there are the opportunities to scale up. The developers see their system as being particularly applicable in off-grid locations and disaster relief. The system could be used to desalinate water from a variety of sources including seawater, brine, or brackish groundwater. While primarily designed with the developing World in mind, the Environment Agency could see similar systems deployed in the UK, either to contribute to large desalination installations, or to provide smaller decentralised utility provision in community and domestic settings, providing owners with water independence from water companies and opening up a wider variety of water sources. The latter may become particularly prevalent if the cost of water bills continues to rise.
Primary Article Title: Solar-powered system offers a route to inexpensive desalination
Author: Chandler D. L
Secondary_URLs: Highly efficient and salt rejecting solar evaporation via a wick-free confined water layer | Nature Communications

Summary Sentence: Polish scientists have made a breakthrough in bioplastics manufacture, which could lead to more widespread use.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this breakthrough from a waste management perspective. While recycled starch based bioplastics are not a new innovation in itself, their application has been so far limited as it was weak and susceptible to tears. The Polish team have addressed this by making starch based plastics stronger and more durable, improving its prospects as a replacement for thin film like plastics used in food soft packaging and cling film like applications. The team achieved this through adding an organic acid present naturally in grains to the starch, which caused the starch molecules to cross link, reducing their water absorption, gas permeability and tearing susceptibility. The plastic film also has antimicrobial properties from a second ingredient derived from chicory root extract. The team are now working on a hydrophobic layer for their foil which will enable it to be more practically used in storing moist products.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Łódź scientists create revolutionary ‘heavy-duty’ biodegradable materials from modified starch
Author: Konopka, B
Keywords: waste resources packaging plastic starch recycled recycling bioplastic film "cling film" molecule "organic acid" antimicrobial chicory root Poland Polish food regulation&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Tiny 3D printed ‘skyscrapers’ could lead to the electricity generation from just bacteria, sunlight and water.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this new approach to renewable energy, which could bypass the current mineral based system of electricity provision, and therefore remove existing and future concerns around waste and resources from installations such as solar panels and wind turbines. This new approach is potentially competitive with other bioenergy methods such as biofuels, presenting challenges to existing notions of bioenergy and the land and resource implications that come with them. Researchers have previously managed to generate electricity from ‘spare’ electrons produced by certain bacteria during photosynthesis. This new study found that providing photosynthetic bacteria, or cyanobacteria with the right home conditions greatly increases the amount of electricity they could produce, to a level where its solar conversion efficiencies outcompetes many biofuel generation methods. Cyanobacteria need lots of sunlight to perform photosynthesis well. The 3D printed ‘nano skyscrapers’ help to increase the bacteria’s surface area and therefore photosynthesise more efficiently. The electrode nanostructures are made from highly branched densely packed pillars of metal oxide nanoparticles that are tailored to work with the cyanobacteria as they perform photosynthesis. The level of performance surprised the researchers who are now looking to better understand the potential pathways to renewable fuel or chemical generation.
Primary Article Title: Tiny ‘skyscrapers’ help bacteria convert sunlight into electricity
Secondary_URLs: 3D-printed hierarchical pillar array electrodes for high-performance semi-artificial photosynthesis | Nature Materials

Summary Sentence: Post pandemic changes in working practices are leading to more initiatives to explore the concept of a four day working week.
Justification: The Environment Agency, as with all employers should consider how large scale changes like this could impact on its business activities. One of the consequences of the coronavirus pandemic and its associated lockdowns has been many people reassessing their working lives, spurred arguably through the move to more remote working and home working. This has been termed ‘The Great Resignation’ as a wave of workers quit their jobs and move to roles more in line with their new priorities. A consequence of this has been that corporations are having to address the resulting skill shortage with better pay, terms and conditions, plus other perks to tempt and retain workers. These include better maternity arrangements, extra leave for pet adoption, and even cash just to attend interviews. One analyst identifies employers demonstrating care for staff well-being and future success being seen as a greater benefit than ‘perks’. Against this backdrop, some countries are starting to experiment with the notion of a four day week. In Belgium new labour reforms have given workers the right to request a four day working week. Employers will have to justify why employees couldn’t take this option. Employees will have to condense their contracted hours into a four day period, rather than work less time, but will have an extra non-working day a week. Workers are entitled to try the format for a period of six months, after which they can either continue or revert back to a five day week without penalty. It is expected that it will take time for the reforms to make it into legislation. In Wales, the future generations commissioner Sophie Howe has called for the Welsh Government to trial a shorter working week in the public sector. Many people are supportive of the move, which could create a deficit of 27,000 employees and an initial cost of £1bn. However a better work life balance could lead to other benefits such less sickness leave, less pollution due to less commuting, and a 10 per cent increase in efficiency across the public sector would offset the initial costs in the long term. One Cardiff hairdressing salon is already applying the four day work principle with staff reporting greater levels of energy, well-being and work engagement. The Environment Agency already embraces flexible working and compressed hours for some employees. As moves towards shorter working weeks gain legislative traction, the Environment Agency may need to consider what steps may need to be taken to address any potential shortfalls in business cover, plus additional costs and opportunities to offset these through greater efficiencies. There may also need to be considerations of current salary and benefit offers to ensure that we remain competitive across a changing public and private sector.
Primary Article Title: Welsh government urged to trial four-day week for public sector

After the Great Resignation, Tech Firms Are Getting Desperate | WIRED UK
