Summary Sentence: A leading agricultural machinery manufacturer has launched a fully autonomous tractor.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency may be interested in the potential implications of this innovation for farming practices and also its own fleet. John Deere earlier this year launched the 8R tractor. The tractor can operate completely independently of a human driver, other than to programme it and monitor real time data. The 8R is equipped with GPS navigation, along with six pairs of stereo cameras, which constantly feed data to neural networks which classify images in a fraction of a second. The manufacturers identify the efficiency saving and health and safety benefits of the 8R, compared to the conventional alternative of a person being behind the wheel of a tractor for up to 18 hours a day. The Environment Agency may wish to contemplate how autonomous vehicle use may impact on soil compaction and other field characteristics. Other partners across Defra may also consider how automation could impact on the rural economy. The Environment Agency may also need to consider how the advent of realised autonomous technology in plant equipment may be just around the corner and what implications that could bring to its activities in asset construction and maintenance, such as hard flood defences.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: “The future of agriculture starts now” – John Deere launches autonomous 8R tractor
Author: Peskett, M
Keywords: farming agriculture tractor machinery plant vehicle fleet "John Deere" autonomous "neural network" "image recognition" AI GPS 8R rural economy unemployment jobs efficiency

Summary Sentence: The village home of Britain’s first climate refugees has seen a recent boom in house prices.&%23160;
Justification: Fairbourne, on the coast of Gwynned, North Wales received wide media attention in 2020 (%2314877) when the local council announced that it was to ‘decommission’ the village in the face of mounting flood protection costs due to climate change, as the village was forecast to be underwater by 2054 from rising sea levels. At the time house prices were reported to have collapsed, leaving residents with a loss of capital needed to relocate. However, Fairbourne has experienced a recent property boom following a surge of interest from prospective buyers, with prices increasing 35 per cent in the last year. This flies in the face of other research which suggests that in some parts of the World property purchasers may be becoming more cautious towards climate change impacts on their investments (%2314992). Prices started to climb during the coronavirus pandemic from an increase in UK based holidays. It is now estimated that a quarter of Fairbourne’s properties are second homes, all of which have been purchased by cash buyers - no lenders are prepared to approve mortgages due to the inevitable sea level impacts. Many buyers are reported to be retired people who accept Fairbourne’s fate but are worried about the longer term consequences in 25 years' time. Others are looking at buy-to-let holiday homes, where they believe they may be able to recoup their initial investment regardless of the longer term consequences. Coastal areas have traditionally attracted retired people and in this sense Fairbourne is no different. However the prominence of Fairbourne’s precarious status in the media may influence the narrative around coastal retreat more difficult for the Environment Agency and partners to influence. A growing concentration of older people in a single vulnerable community similar to Fairbourne may also make evacuations more difficult in the event of a major flooding incident.
Primary Article Title: House prices soar in village set to disappear under the sea in the next 30 years
Author: Forgrave, A & Jobling, P
Keywords: "climate change" flooding coastal sea marine beach Fairbourne Wales Gwynned property housing price investment tourism cash "sea level rise" older people retired incident emergency evacuation narrative communication legal

Summary Sentence: Indoor vertical farming seems increasingly to be heading towards mainstream food production.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this trajectory as indoor vertical farming promises to deliver significant water use and pesticide reductions as well as repositioning food production as a potentially more urban activity with point source discharges, compared to the current situation of rural based, diffuse discharges. The World’s largest vertical farm is currently being constructed on a four acre site in Norfolk. The Norfolk facility is being developed by Fischer Farms, who already operate a large vertical farm in Staffordshire. The four acre site will create 25,000 m² of growing space, which will supply over six tonnes of fresh produce every day, including leafy greens (rocket, lettuce etc.) and herbs. Crops are grown in controlled environments let by LEDs. The equivalent quantity of produce would require 1000 acres of conventional British farmland. Fischer farms plan to move to growing competitively priced soya beans, rice and wheat in significant volumes over the next 10-15 years. The site is powered by renewable energy and also avoids issues associated with traditional farming such as topsoil erosion or chemical run-off. Across the Atlantic a vertical farming company has just signed a deal with a major US retailer. San Francisco based Plenty has just received a $400 million investment from Walmart, with a look to provide leafy greens to its California stores, signalling a turning point for the mass appeal of vertical farmed produce. Plenty are also looking to provide other perishables, including strawberries and tomatoes. Vertical farming looks to be diversifying into a range of crops, not just perishables, which has the potential to significantly change farming practices, rural landscapes and economies. The Environment Agency and partners may need to consider the potential risks and opportunities to regulation and environmental gain from wider scale adoption of indoor and vertical farming practices.
Primary Article Title: Fischer Farms building world’s largest vertical farm in UK

Summary Sentence: A UN report introduces the concept of ‘sacrifice zones’ where air pollution is so high that public health suffers significantly.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be aware of this branding and potential reputational damage that would be incurred if areas of England were labelled ‘sacrifice zones’ in the media. With air quality being linked to more health conditions and the death of Ella Kissi-Debrah in 2020 (which was linked to air pollution), advocacy groups could use the term to highlight problem areas in England. In addition, many of the business that are regulated be the Environment Agency are considered to be exacerbating the issue, prioritising profits over public health. Sacrifice zones tend to be in poorer areas of the world, however, the USA is highlighted as having several sacrifice zones including Louisiana’s ‘cancer alley’. The report names several of specific region in Europe that are already considered sacrifice zones and a separate recent publication in Nature highlights a link between localised pollution and cardiac dyspnoea in the South of France. The report highlights the intensity of this crisis with reporting that&%2358; One in six deaths in the world involves diseases caused by pollution; and in Kabwe, Zambia, 95% of children had elevated levels of lead in their blood, putting them at risk of lifelong intellectual impairment. The Royal College of Physicians report that 40,000 deaths in the UK per year are attributed to outdoor exposure to air pollution. The rise of HVAC air filters during the covid pandemic may take on another function if air quality continues to worsen, providing safe air in public spaces. The tendency for low air quality to be focussed in poorer areas will likely lead to a demand for low cost air filtration and the covid pandemic has led to a number of low cost filtration designs that can be assembled from easily purchased parts.
Primary Article Title: Millions suffering in deadly pollution ‘sacrifice zones’, warns UN expert

Summary Sentence: A team of researchers at MIT has devised a way of automatically cleaning solar panels, using electrostatic repulsion, in a waterless, no-contact system that could significantly reduce water use and improve efficiency.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this technology in terms of water conservation as well as to improve the effectiveness of solar panels in order to achieve 2030 net zero targets. Solar panel cleaning is thought to use up to 5million gallons of water per 100MW of electricity generated and dust on solar panels can reduce the output of photovoltaic panels by as much as 30 percent in just one month. In addition, water cleaning of solar panels can make up 10% of the operating costs at some solar farms. This system can be operated automatically using a simple electric motor and guide rails along the side of the panel. To activate the system, a simple electrode passes just above the solar panel’s surface, imparting an electrical charge to the dust particles, which are then repelled by a charge applied to the panel itself. The electrostatic repulsion generated caused dust particles to ‘jump’ off the surface of the solar panel. Although the electrodes require a high voltage, because the electrodes are separate there is no current generated and therefore very minimal power is required.
Primary Article Title: How to clean solar panels without water
Author: David L. Chandler
Keywords: "Water conservation" Solar "Solar power" PV "Solar panel cleaning" "Electrostatic cleaning"

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a method of capturing trace chemical contaminants, known as micro-pollutants, using soap particles.
Justification: This is another potential method for the treatment of micro pollutants (%2315193, %2314363, %2313343) that the Environment Agency should be aware of for water quality and regulation work. Micro-pollutants are hazardous to human and environmental health even at very low concentrations and current water treatment methods are largely ineffective on this type of pollutant. Currently, the most common practice for removing micro-pollutants from water is activated carbon adsorption. In this process, water passes through a carbon filter, removing only 30 percent of micro-pollutants. Activated carbon requires high temperatures to produce and regenerate, requiring specialized equipment and consuming large amounts of energy. With this new method, when water comes in contact with soap, the hydrophobic parts of the surfactant stick together, assembling into spherical structures called micelles. These micelles are chemically bonded to a hydrogel using ultraviolet light. When water flows through the micro-particle system, micro-pollutants latch onto the micelles and separate from the water. Hydrogels can be cleaned and regenerated by soaking in ethanol. The researchers believe this could be scaled up for effective waste water treatment.
Primary Article Title: Using soap to remove micropollutants from water
Author: Carolyn Blais

Summary Sentence: There are strong indications emerging that the car industry is taking significant steps to decarbonise its supply chain.
Justification:
Such measures should be of interest to the Environment Agency as it could lead to customer led decarbonisation of regulated heavy industries, such as steelmaking and the adoption of ‘green steel’ as the norm. Two vehicle manufacturers recently announced their intentions towards carbon-free steel. Mercedes-Benz has committed to using carbon-free steel from 2025 onwards as part of its commitment to a carbon neutral fleet by 2039. They are achieving this through investment in H2 Green Steel, a green hydrogen powered steel manufacturing plant in Sweden. Volvo is similarly investing in cleaner steel manufacturing, also in Sweden, teaming up with steemaker &%23160;SSAB, replacing coking coal with fossil free electricity and hydrogen. BMW Group has recently signed a contract with German firm Salzgitter for carbon-free steel to use in its European plants from 2026 onwards. The steel will be produced through a mixture of renewable energy and hydrogen. In Canada a mining company has just outlined its plans to develop the World’s first all electric lithium mine, which will provide raw material for the electric vehicle (EV) industry. Snow Lake Lithium Ltd is looking to provide lithium for battery construction to the automotive industry with 100 per cent renewable energy, but there are few details currently on how exactly it will achieve this. A growth in demand from other car manufacturers and indeed other sectors could lead to a significant de-carbonisation of steel making over the coming years. The Environment Agency may need to consider what responses would be needed to ensure a smooth transition to a new regulatory regime.
&%23160;

Summary Sentence: An investigation into the World’s first operational carbon capture plant has concluded that the plant produces more emissions than it captures.
Justification: This research should be of interest to the Environment Agency and its Net Zero goals as it has a regulatory role in &%23160;carbon capture and storage (CCS) schemes. The plant in question is Shell's Quest plant its Scotford refinery in Alberta, Canada, which produces hydrogen from processing oil sand bitumen. A recent study of the plant from human rights organisation Global Witness suggests that the plant has prevented 5 million tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO2) from entering the atmosphere since 2015. However at the same time it has generated 7.5 million tonnes of other greenhouse gases, including methane which has a higher global warming impact than CO2. This means that only 48 per cent of emissions were captured, well below the 90 per cent stated by the operators. Global Witness expect their report to present a challenge to further CCS activity. However Shell maintain that the report’s conclusions are incorrect. This all suggests that further research may be needed to ensure that CCS is an appropriate technology to employ alongside fossil fuel refining. The Environment Agency and partners may therefore need to conduct further investigations to ensure that any regulated activities using these processes properly contribute to reducing climate change impacts. This may become more pertinent as the UK pivots towards fossil fuel derived alternative energies such as blue hydrogen.
Primary Article Title: Shell’s carbon capture plant creates more emissions than it captures
Author: Ozdemir, D
Keywords: energy oil hydrogen "carbon capture and storage" CCS Shell Canada Alberta&%23160;Scotford refinery Quest regulation "carbon dioxide" "climate change" "greenhouse gas" CO2 hydrogen "blue hydrogen" "net zero" "Global Witness"

Summary Sentence: Levels of chemicals in the environment are now thought to be at a level high enough to destabilise global ecosystems.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners may need further powers for regulating chemicals in light of this new assessment. A new study has concluded that the Earth has now passed the planetary boundary for chemical pollution. This makes it the fifth such planetary boundary to have been crossed. The study concluded this through a combination of measurements, such as the rate of production of chemicals, which is rising rapidly, and their release into the environment, which is happening faster than the ability of authorities to track or investigate any impacts. The researchers suggest that stronger regulation, plus a move towards a circular economy would be two ways with which to mitigate the situation. However one commentator suggests that more research is also needed into detection and impacts due to existing uncertainties on the range of effects from chemical pollution. This also suggests that further research would also be needed in support of greater regulatory remit for the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: Chemical pollution has passed safe limit for humanity, say scientists
Author: Carrington, D
Secondary_URLs: Outside the Safe Operating Space of the Planetary Boundary for Novel Entities | Environmental Science & Technology (acs.org)

Summary Sentence: Artificial intelligence (AI) could increasingly be used in determining the result of legal cases, following experiments that demonstrate comparable rulings to human courts.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency is engaged in multiple legal actions and prosecutions, and could therefore benefit from such technology in terms of costs and time. A recent systematic study of judicial decisions from the European Court of Human Rights employed Natural Language Processing to analyse the data for patterns in terms of outcomes on whether there has been a violation of an article of the convention of human rights. Following this analysis a model was developed that could predict the outcome of court decisions on these cases with an accuracy of 79 per cent. The research revealed that formal facts of a case were the most important predictive factor, just as in cases involving human judgement, suggesting that further development of the model could aid judicial decision making. A similar system employing AI technology has been developed in China with a reported accuracy of 97 per cent. The system can identify 'dissent' against the state and suggest sentences for supposed criminals, removing people from the prosecution process. The algorithm bases decisions on a training set of 17,000 real life cases and can run on a standard desktop computer. &%23160;It has been tested by the Shanghai Pudong People's Procuratorate, the biggest and busiest district prosecution office in China. The system could allow human prosecutors to focus on more complex cases, representing an efficiency saving. However there are concerns that such a system could remove humans from the decision process altogether. It also may not take account of changing social factors, nor bias in the training data, which may in turn lead to poor decision making. AI presents huge potential benefits to legal procedure, however the Environment Agency may need to ensure that all ethical concerns are properly addressed before it becomes an operational tool in legal proceedings. The Environment Agency may also need to consider how AI technology such as this may be used against them in a legal setting.
Primary Article Title: China develops AI 'prosecutor' that can identify 'dissent' and press charges for common crimes 'with 97% accuracy'

Summary Sentence: Researchers in Saudi Arabia have combined a water harvesting hydrogel with solar panels to produce a system that can absorb water from ambient air, then use waste heat from the solar panel to extract that water.
Justification: The Environment Agency regulates abstraction and this technology could be utilised as an alternative source for irrigation in an effort to conserve water resources. Enough water was extracted to grow spinach in Saudi Arabian summer conditions and the efficiency of the solar panel was improved by 9% due to the cooling effect of the hydrogel. The system, called WEC2P, is composed of a solar photovoltaic panel placed on top of a layer of hydrogel, which is mounted on a large metal box where the water is condensed and collected. The hydrogel relies on variations in ambient conditions during day night. When the humidity is high and the temperature is low at night, water vapour sorption is facilitated. On the other hand, when the humidity is low and the temperature is high during the daytime, the evaporation process and thus cooling is promoted, leading to a higher evaporative cooling performance. The researchers hope to market the technology as a decentralized power and water system to light homes and water crops.
Primary Article Title: These solar panels pull in water vapour to grow crops in the desert

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a new, non-destructive method of detecting cracks in concrete using laser-induced plasma (LIP) shock wave excitation.
Justification: This technology could be used by the Environment Agency and partners to survey drainage pipes, flood defences and dams. The technology works by exposing concrete to a high power pulsed laser which generates vibrations that can be analysed. Where defects occur, the surface waves generated by the vibrations move faster creating a detectable phenomenon called Raleigh waves where particles move in ellipses. Detection of Raleigh waves can be used to identify both the location and the size of the defect. This method is faster than traditional defect detection and requires fewer data points. In the past, detecting defects in concrete structures has been conducted by skilled building inspectors using acoustic tests. These tests can vary in effectiveness depending on the expertise of the inspector.
Primary Article Title: A laser-quick, non-destructive method to detect cracks in concrete structures
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0020740321007256
Keywords: "Concrete defect detection" "Concrete crack detection" Concrete Survey LIP "laser-induced plasma" "Non-destructive testing"&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Researchers have created a way to deliver genetic material into crops using a high throughput spray system.
Justification: The Environment Agency and its partners at DEFRA should consider the environmental endpoints of solutions of genetic material that are able to penetrate plant cells and impact plant DNA. &%23160;Cell penetrating peptides mixed with DNA and RNA were found to effectively enter the cells of target plants via stomata. Using this method researchers were able to introduce interfering DNA plasmids into plants that successfully silenced a target gene. This technology enables effective non-transgenic engineering of economically important plant traits in agricultural systems. The system uses nano-carrier molecules to deliver short section of RNA and DNA into plants via a foliage spray. The nano-carrier consists of short chains of amino acids that are able to infiltrate the cell wall and even target specific organelles within the cell, including the nucleus. Introducing genetic material in this way enables the large scale engineering of metabolic traits and economically important characteristics of plants without permanently changing the plant genome. The negative public image of genetic modification is based on transgenic methods that produce a permanent change to the genome that is passed on to offspring. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: Non-transgenic Gene Modulation via Spray Delivery of Nucleic Acid/Peptide Complexes into Plant Nuclei and Chloroplasts
Author: Chonprakun Thagun
Keywords: "Genetic modification" GM Transgenic Agriculture Crops Nano-molecules "genetic material" "Gene silencing" Plasmid DNA Plants Absorption "DNA delivery" "Gene modulation" "DNA spray"&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Virtual and cryptocurrency initiatives are being mobilised to crowdfund projects and procedures more conventionally associated with services provided by government organisations.
Justification: Several examples exist of UK groups using conventional crowdfunding platforms to finance infrastructure projects associated with flood defence, though the success has been apparently limited. More recently there are reports of the Ukrainian government appealing for BitCoin donations to fund military efforts against Russia. This mirrors similar strategies previously employed by separatist organisations in Ukraine. Cryptocurrency appeals have financed military hardware, cyber operations and a facial recognition app to identify people in Ukraine thought to be working for Russia. Cryptocurrencies so far represent a small percentage of the donations received. However unlike fiat currency transitions cryptocurrency accounts operated outside of the financial system. There is also a degree of anonymity, making it difficult to identify supporters or their motives. A cryptocurrency based start up in the USA called Ryval has developed a crowdfunding platform to finance lawsuits. Donors contribute to the plaintiff's legal fees. If the lawsuit is successful then the platform converts any compensation awarded into a share for the crowdfunders. Ryval’s founders say that their platform will use gamification to help make the legal system more accessible and affordable to people. It may be of use for the Environment Agency to consider how anonymous cryptocurrency based funding schemes could help to deliver some of its own projects through accessing larger potential funders. However it may also need to consider how funding schemes could be used in opposition to its best interests, particularly as virtual currency gives donors anonymity.
Primary Article Title: Crypto startup lets you fund other people’s lawsuits against each other

Summary Sentence: A Dutch company has developed an undersea energy storage solution designed to work&%23160; in close proximity to offshore wind and wave renewable energy.
Justification: The Environment Agency may wish to contemplate how technology similar to this could impact both the energy sector and the marine and estuarine environments. Ocean Grazer consists of a ‘bladder’ reservoir of fresh water located on the ocean floor. Excess energy is used to pump fresh water from the reservoir into the bladder above it. When energy is required the bladder then releases the water through a series of turbines back into the reservoir. It is a reasonably cheap solution which requires little maintenance once established, though the sea bed requires excavation to install the reservoir and turbines. The team behind it hope to have operational examples in the Netherlands by 2023. The system uses freshwater, presumably to prevent decay within the turbine system, though this isn’t clarified. Such a system could have significant benefits in providing cheap energy storage to complement offshore and nearshore renewable energy installations. However the Environment Agency may need to consider potential implications for navigation, flood management, and environmental damage from installation. There may also be consequences from taking large volumes of freshwater out of circulation.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: What is the Ocean Battery? It could be crucial for renewable energy storage

Summary Sentence: Researchers have come up with new design for the removal of suspended grit from wastewater that would have been near impossible to achieve using traditional engineering methods.
Justification: The Environment Agency is responsible for maintaining and improving water quality and this new method would lead to better wastewater treatment, potentially reducing water pollution. Suspended solids carried in water can cause a range of harmful effects in rivers, lakes and oceans, making the capture and removal of these solids critical for effective environmental protection. The new design used computer modelling to create a new design that optimised the removal of suspended grit particles. Thanks to the computational modelling method used&%23160;and the computing power available at the Universities of Exeter and Bristol, each optimisation run modelled 300 designs at a time making this a very powerful technique. The final design uses a new stacked tray system which improves grit removal performance and enables the production of more compact systems that can handle higher wastewater flows and requires less maintenance. Physical testing was done to corroborate the results of the computer simulation. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: Ground-breaking project leads to advanced wastewater grit removal system
Keywords: "Water treatment" Grit "Grit removal" Pollution "Water pollution" "Waste water treatment"&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A new material created from crop waste converts UV light to visible light that can be used for solar power offering the potential for more effective solar technology, particularly on cloudy days.
Justification: The Environment Agency would need to consider the implications of widespread use of this material in terms of pollutants produced by water runoff and end of life disposal, but, it could be of use in terms of achieving net zero – some offices already have solar power and this is a more ubiquitous option. The versatile material (called AuREUS) which could be clad on the outside of buildings, added to the roof of e-vehicles or even woven into some fabrics. The material, designed by engineering student Carvey Ehren Maigue won the James Dyson Foundation Sustainability Award in 2020. It uses luminescent particles from fruit and vegetable waste which take UV light and converts them to visible light which is then reflected to the edges of the panel where regular PV cells are used to generate electricity. UV is able to penetrate clouds and this material would improve the effectiveness of solar power on cloudy days. It also offers scope to collect reflected UV in urban areas that are not in direct sunlight.
Primary Article Title: Solar panels built from waste crops can make energy without direct light
Keywords: Solar "Solar power" UV PV "Solar energy" "Material science" "UV power"&%23160;AuREUS

Summary Sentence: Electrochemical detectors are emerging as a low cost, portable method for pesticide detection on food.
Justification: DEFRA is required to monitor and report on pesticide residues found food and this technology could streamline this process. The Environment Agency could also use the same devices to monitor pesticide residues in soils, water samples and on vegetation. Current monitoring methods including HPLC and mass spectrometry, are slower, non-portable and can be costly. Pesticide residues on food are a concern for ecosystems and human health and given the recent media coverage around the UK’s continued use of glyphosate, electrochemical detectors could offer the ability to easily monitor pesticides on food. Electrochemical sensors work by measuring an electrical current passing through a set of electrodes caused by chemical reactions between the target chemical and a reactor molecule. These reactions are catalysed using nanomaterials, such as silver nano-particles, which also provide additional surface area for the reaction to take place.
Primary Article Title: Portable electrochemical sensing methodologies for on-site detection of pesticide residues in fruits and vegetables
Author: Reddicherla Umapathia

Summary Sentence: A study has found that more mental health emergencies occur during the hottest days of summer.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be aware of such a link and may want to consider stepping up wellbeing support for staff during heat waves and hot days. In addition, broader impacts, such as overuse of green spaces on hot days and increasing pollution from mental health related medication entering water bodies, should be considered. The study, which analysed medical records from millions of Americans, indicated an average 8% rise in hospitalisations in the hottest 5% of days. This encompassed nearly all mental health conditions including stress, anxiety, schizophrenia and self-harm. All genders, age groups and regions analysed showed the same pattern, suggesting that everybody is at risk. Climate change is causing an increase in extreme temperatures and an associated upsurge in mental health issues is projected.
Primary Article Title: Hot days lead to more mental health emergencies, study finds
Author: Damian Carrington
Keywords: "Mental health" "Heat wave" "Extreme temperatures" "Climate Change" "Well being" Stress Anxiety Heat Temperature Hot

Summary Sentence: Quaise Energy, a start-up based out of MIT, is applying new microwave powered drilling technology to make it possible to get geothermal energy anywhere.
Justification: The Environment Agency would likely be involved in permitting and regulating geothermal drilling in the UK and would also need to consider the use of groundwater reservoirs which would be required for steam generation. Universal access to geothermal energy using deep drilling technology has long be hypothesised (%234926), but, thanks to this technology, drilling to depths of 12 miles is now feasible. The company uses technology based on breakthrough fusion research and well-established drilling practices to create a microwave powered drilling platform which vaporizes boreholes through rock and provides access to deep geothermal heat without complex downhole equipment. The drill uses a microwave beam which is hot enough to evaporate rock, and the vaporized rock is pumped back to the surface. Until now it has only been practical to utilise geothermal energy from volcanic or plate boundary areas.&%23160; Quaise plans to approach existing power plants, offering to drill geothermal fields customized to match their existing equipment creating additional energy sources that are already connected to the grid.
Primary Article Title: You Can Have Geothermal Power Everywhere If You Drill Deep Enough
Author: Lloyd Alter
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.quaise.energy/
Keywords: Drilling Geothermal "Deep Geothermal" "Deep drilling"&%23160; Technology "Microwave drilling"&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Utilis has just completed a successful trial in the south of Africa using satellite-borne radar analytics to narrow down locations of leaks, followed by specialist acoustic leak detection equipment to identify leak hotspots.
Justification: Knowledge of emerging technologies will allow the Environment Agency to work with water companies to find the best solution for sustainable water abstraction. The Environment Agency’s Water Abstraction Plan aims to improve adherence to sustainable abstraction in England and the Water Industry National Environment Programme (WINEP) aims to engage with industry to ensure that water companies take a leading role in addressing unsustainable abstraction. Over abstraction is still an issue and pipe leakage is a major problem for water companies, with Thames water losing 22,000L of water per day per km of pipe. Utilis’ new technology would allow water companies to conduct large scale surveys on pipes that run through rural environments. Their remote-sensing technology uses a sensor mounted on a satellite orbiting at 637km above earth, which can capture an entire network in one shot. Potential hotspots are identified using a patented algorithm that looks for the unique signature of drinking water escaping into the ground. Leak validation is than conducted using Gutermann’s AQUASCAN TM2 trunk main leak correlator which analyses the leak noise on large-diameter pipes at distances of up to 1km. Using pipe distance and properties (material and diameter) the correlator is able to accurately pinpoint leaks.
Primary Article Title: Tackling leakage from all angles
Keywords: "Leak detection" "Water conservation" "Water preservation" "Drinking water" Satellite "Near earth observation" "Water abstraction" Radar "Water companies" Technology

Summary Sentence: New innovations suggest ways that could be adapted to mitigate water resource shortages at a domestic scale, leading to improved water efficiency.&%23160;
Justification: As a regulator of water resources and responder to drought based incidents the Environment Agency may be interested to consider how such new technologies could be strategically deployed to address water resource issues. A recent white paper entitled ‘Water-Energy-Carbon Nexus in our homes. A blind spot for climate crisis?’ found that 90 per cent of energy consumed and 80 per cent of the carbon produced in the water treatment cycle is consumed during domestic water heating. The report also advocates for the ‘50 litre home’, where a combination of technologies and behaviours limits per capita water use to sustainable levels, saving water, and lowering energy use and carbon emissions. One of the innovations coming to light that suggests a technological solution is a compact water recycling system designed for domestic use. Hydraloop is a slim wardrobe sized system installed in the home that collects greywater from baths, showers, hand basins, washing machines, and air conditioning units, which it then disinfects and cleans for reuse in other domestic settings such as toilet flushing, washing machines and garden watering. The chemical and filter free cleaning process involves a six-step purification process of UV light disinfection, enforced skimming aerobic bioreactor, flotation, dissolved air flotation, and sedimentation. A Hydraloop system can reputedly cut water domestic water consumption by 45 per cent. Researchers in Toruń, Poland have developed a similar solution in the form of what they claim is the World’s first no-energy no-pressure water purification and desalination system, called NanoseenX. NanoseenX is primarily designed with providing drinking water and prevent disease in the developing world. It consists of a large cylinder which contains several nanomembranes which progressively filter out a range of contaminants under gravitational force, including salts, microplastics and nanoplastics, bacteria, viruses and light and heavy metal ions. NanoseenX can produce clean water in two minutes and could process 1000 litres per day for the cost of $0.50. Crucially NanoseenX can be installed in any climate or location and doesn’t require electricity to work. While the technology here has a specific purpose in mind, application of the same principles in more developed countries could similarly assist with the energy, carbon and resource costs of conventional water treatment, while also contributing to the idea of domestic water independence and reducing piped water supply demands. This may also present a challenge to current water supply business models.
Primary Article Title: Toruń scientists create world’s first no-energy no-pressure water purification and desalination solution to help fight global drinking water shortages
Author: Konopka, B

Summary Sentence: Carbon-based organic micropollutants (OMPs) can be removed from water by treatment with high-intensity pulses of light.
Justification: This technology offers a potentially important development for the Environment Agency as the body responsible for monitoring and improving water quality. Researchers from KAUST used high-intensity light pulses generated from a xenon flash lamp to break down OMPs and have reduced processing times down to several seconds. Using 2 millisecond pulses which trigger decomposition of OMPs. The improvement offers the potential to develop high throughput treatment for OMPs which are known as emerging contaminants. Xenon lamps are an easy to install, cost and energy effective alternative method for removing OMPs compared with alternative developing technologies such as microfiltration and ozonation. OMPs include compound groups, such as pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PCCPs), pesticides, PFASs, flame retardants, industrial chemicals, hormones, phthalates, and food additives. They pose a threat to environmental and public heath through water contamination and are currently not entirely removed by wastewater treatment. There is some concern over the formation of toxic breakdown products and research into this still needs to be conducted.
Primary Article Title: Making light work of emerging micropollutants
Keywords: Micropollutant OMP "Organic micropollutant" wastewater "Wastewater treatment"

Summary Sentence: ‘Web 3’ or “Internet 3.0” is the idea for a new iteration of the internet based around block chain technology offering the potential for a decentralised internet, initially envisioned by Tim Berners Lee (%2314701), the idea is now being developed by multiple tech companies and start ups.&%23160;
Justification: Web 3 promises&%23160;anonymised, unregulated internet which could make it very difficult for the Environment Agency to regulate and convict environmental crime. Decentralising control of the internet would remove any regulatory control held by the government and could lead to new opportunities for anonymised crime and hate speech. In addition, block chain technology is power hungry and large scale adoption of Web 3 could lead to additional carbon emissions. Currently the idea is still in its infancy and defining what Web 3 will do is difficult and will depend on how users engage with the technology. In an idealistic view it offers individual control to the user, preventing data harvesting and government control. Block chain works by storing encrypted chunks of data in a ledger spread across many connected nodes. When a node is full it is ‘closed’ and linked directly to the previous node creating an un-editable time stamp. Encrypting the data means only the data owner can access it and spreading the data between nodes means hacking is virtually impossible. Block chain removes the need for server centres which are housed in one place making them vulnerable to incidents such as fires. Block chain internet would appear similar to the kind of websites we see today but ownership would be decentralised, with users paying a ‘token’ (in reality this is likely to be a cryptocurrency fee) to use and influence the functioning of site. The token could be sold if the site is no longer of interest.
Primary Article Title: What Is Web3 All About? An Easy Explanation With Examples
Author: Bernard Marr
Keywords: "Internet 3.0" "Web 3.0" Technology Communication "Decentralised internet" Anonymity Privacy&%23160;

Summary Sentence: An MIT spin-off company has created a solar powered device which monitors, collects and pre-treats landfill methane by automating and optimising vacuum adjustments, increasing collection by at least 20% with no additional infrastructure needed.
Justification: The Environment Agency produces guidance on dealing with landfill methane and a device that optimises collection and pre-treats methane without the need for additional infrastructure would be beneficial to sites not currently connected to the grid and could become important if electrical generation subsidies are reduced. Currently in the UK methane is burned on site to produce electricity which is then sold to the national grid, a process heavily subsidised by the government. Where it is not possible to generate electricity, usually because the site is not connected to the grid, the methane is flared. A device that automatically optimises collection of methane also removes the need for technicians to manually adjust collection vacuums and can provide 24/7 control. The device can also flag up any technical issues that occur and respond to events such as flooding automatically. Combined with being solar powered, this device offers a cost effective alternative to current methods. A new airborne methane sensor deployed by NASA, found that California landfills have been leaking methane at rates as much as six times greater than estimates from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The Environment Agency relies on landfill site owners to monitor and report their emissions as laid out in their gas management plan. The implementation of cost effective, easily installed devices may be beneficial if significant leaks are detected.
Primary Article Title: Reducing methane emissions at landfills
Author: Zach Winn
Secondary_URLs: Loci Controls | How it works
Keywords: Methane Landfill "Landfill gas" Emissions "Greenhouse gas" "Gas management"

Summary Sentence: As climate change looks set to place unsustainable demands on conventional air conditioning solutions, a low cost, low energy innovation may suggest a possible solution.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in these developments as inspiration for achieving Net Zero ambitions from existing and future estate management, as well as understanding how the wider energy market may change. New research focussing on the US state of California suggests that future residents may lose air conditioning for one week each summer as energy demand for air conditioning cooling will exceed that of the entire grid supply. Such an occurrence would have a range of consequences for food preservation, healthcare and others. Increasing energy production could alleviate this issue, but may be counterproductive if not based on clean renewable energy sources. While the UK has a very different climate to California, the notion of hotter, drier summers creating greater demand for artificial cooling is in line with current projections of climate change impacts. Offering the building blocks of a potential solution is a low-cost, electricity free cooling system developed in Saudi Arabia. Peng Wang’s system draws on the cooling effect generated when salt crystals are dissolved in water. Having tested numerous salts, Wang and team found that ammonium nitrate offered the right balance of solubility, cooling effect and price. By melting the salt slowly in a metal cup in a polystyrene box Wang and team managed to produce a cooling effect down to 3.6 degrees celsius. The salt was then recovered by placing the saline solution in a container made of absorbent material, which drew the salt to the exterior. While still in early stages Wang and team are looking to develop their process into a cooling system for use in medicine, food storage and air conditioning, particularly in remote areas away from the grid. However the same principles could also be applied to energy saving cooling systems in less remote areas, helping to alleviate the projected impacts of climate change on energy demands for air conditioning.
Primary Article Title: Cool runnings

Summary Sentence: Scientists are starting to look into the medicinal properties of the psychoactive drug DMT.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in considering the environmental impacts of any pharmaceuticals that have the potential for widespread use. Scientists and pharmaceutical companies have been interested in the medicinal properties of illegal and restricted substances for some time, such as cannabis (%2314944) and psychedelics such as LSD and psilocybin (%2314694). A few are now starting to look at N,N-Dimethyltryptamine, better known as DMT. DMT as a hallucinogen is known to create intense and profound experiences for the user. many report encountering 'entities' during their experiences.&%23160;There are already signs that it may lead to a promising treatment for depression and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). There are examples of people turning to DMT in an attempt to ‘self medicate’, but with long term negative consequences, which increases the need for more research in this field. As the World acknowledges a mental health crisis, exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic, it is possible that psychedelic based treatments may become more popular, and therefore increase the levels of these chemicals entering the environment through sewage. The Environment Agency and partners may therefore need to better assess the potential impacts, particularly around persistence and impacts on aquatic wildlife behaviour.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Scientists are now testing medical DMT on human subjects
Author: Tran. T

Summary Sentence: China has installed the World’s first operational small modular nuclear reactor (SMR) connected to the grid.
Justification: As a regulator of the nuclear energy sector and of radioactive waste the Environment Agency should consider how a realised working example of an SMR could lead to regulatory changes, and other consequences, particularly as companies are already looking to building SMRs on UK soil (%2315017), and there is some evidence to suggest that SMRs present a greater security risk and longer term environmental issues during dismantlement (%2315070). China’s Huaneng Group Co. have connected a 200MW SMR reactor to the power grid in Shidao Bay, Shandong province. The new reactor is also the world's first pebble-bed modular high-temperature gas-cooled reactor, heating helium to produce energy rather than water. The reactor can shut down quickly in the event of an incident. The smaller builds, resilience from decentralisation of power and lower upfront costs mean that other countries are similarly developing SMR capabilities, including the UK. There may therefore be lessons in regulatory approaches to also gain from overseas examples like the Chinese SMR.
Primary Article Title: China powers up the World’s first commercial onshore small modular nuclear reactor
Author: Young, C

Summary Sentence: A newly developed portable sensor is able to quickly detect plant stress.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in similar monitoring technology to this as it could help provide a rapid or real time indicator of plant and crop health which in turn could indicate the onset of pressure on water resources such as drought. This may have applications in environmental monitoring and incident management situations. Developed by Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology (SMART), the Raman leaf-clip sensor employs principles of mass spectrometry to give an early warning of nitrogen deficiency in plants, which in real world conditions could be used to interpret correct fertiliser applications to crops. The same principle could also detect other stress factors of plant stress phenotypes such as drought, heat and cold stress, saline stress, and light stress. The simplicity of the Raman’s ‘clip-on’ use means that it could be easily deployed in the field with little specialist training required. The developers believe the Raman could help farmers to maximise crop yield whilst minimising environmental impacts, such as surface water pollution and nitrogen runoff and infiltration into the water table.
Primary Article Title: Portable device can quickly detect plant stress

Summary Sentence: An international study is investigating the feasibility of capillary heat pumps that are laid on shallow sea beds.
Justification: The Environment Agency issue permits and advice on installation of ground source and surface water heat pumps as part of sustainable abstraction and would need to consider the environmental impacts of such devices. The study shows that during winter – with a seawater temperature of only 3.7°C – it can produce up to 60W/m2 of heat energy to nearby coastal properties. The amount required to heat an average UK home is 100W/m2. Unlike ground source heat pumps, minimal excavation is required. This technology could only provide heat to coastal locations but with the UK having a large coastline it would be a good candidate for trials. If proven successful, this could be incorporated into sustainable urban designs in coastal areas as an alternative to ground source heat pumps. A pilot study in Qingdau, China laid 250m2 of 4.3mm capillary tubes on the seabed at 5m depth and found the water exiting the seabed was 40.6C. The water was then pumped 300m to a hotel where an indoor heat exchanger was used to warm the air. Similar principles can be used to provide cooling power. Assessment of environmental damage to the seabed, issues with sea water abstraction and biofouling of the tubes would be required before committing to such technology.
Primary Article Title: UK could heat coastal homes with capillary heat exchangers
Keywords: "Heat exchanger" "Capillary heat pump" Renewable "Renewable energy" "Heat pump" Seabed&%23160;

Summary Sentence: An artist has employed artificial intelligence (AI) to design a garden for the benefit of pollinating insects, such as bees, rather than human aesthetics.
Justification: &%23160;The project suggests ways that the Environment Agency and partners could similarly employ algorithmic technology to optimise habitat restorations to maximise the benefits for wildlife flora and fauna. The project also so some extent recognises ‘insect personhood’ in that the pollinators are the primary consideration rather than human desires. Dr Alexandra Daisy Ginsberg employed an algorithm to design the garden which selected and arranged plants based on supporting pollinators' behaviours and tastes, rather than human ones, to support and encourage as many pollinators as possible. The resulting garden has an array of colours, flower sizes and seemingly odd juxtapositions of tall and short plants. Ginsberg plans to make the algorithm available via the internet so that others can take similar steps to design pollinator orientated garden spaces. The garden itself is at the Eden Project in Cornwall.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Exploring interspecies art
Keywords: insect garden design pollinator pollinating bee flower plant "Dr Alexandra Daisy Ginsberg" "Eden Project" "artificial intelligence" AI algorithm habitat restoration flora&%23160;fauna wildlife internet interspecies personhood

Summary Sentence: A Japanese scientist has invented a lickable display screen that generates flavours when a person licks it.&%23160;
Justification: The screen is equipped with an array of ten flavour canisters which are mixed to produce a variety of flavours. The developer sees applications in entertainment, however the same principles could be used for marketing foodstuffs. The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider how similar interactive media like this could be used to convey data and information in alternative ways to current approaches, such as conveying air and water quality. It may also need to consider how the emotive response that senses produced could also be used by third parties to influence perception of environmental issues that evidence alone cannot do, potentially using experiences like this in conjunction with environmental campaigns critical of the Environment Agency’s work.
Primary Article Title: Taste the TV&%2358; Japan invents lickable screen to imitate food flavours

Summary Sentence: Supercritical fluids have been used to dissolve rare and toxic metals to separate them from electronic waste, the fluid is then evaporated away leaving only the target component for recycling or safe disposal.
Justification: The Environment Agency, as waste regulators should be aware of this technology because if it proves efficient, it offers a better way of dealing with electronic waste. Supercritical fluids are formed by heating liquids under high pressures and these fluids allow non-soluble metals to be dissolved. Rare or toxic metals can be separated from electronic waste and the supercritical fluid can be evaporated away leaving only the target component for recycling or safe disposal. Rare earth metals are scarce and a recycling stream could reduce environmentally damaging mining in politically unstable regions. Different metals can be dissolved in different supercritical fluids opening up a range of new methods for disposal or reuse of previously unusable electronic waste. There is also some evidence that similar methods could be used to treat used engine oil. The energetic cost of producing supercritical fluids need to be assessed as does the presence of any other waste products or harmful chemicals produced by this method.
Primary Article Title: Extraction of precious metals from electronic waste by using supercritical fluid technology
Author: David Bradley
Secondary_URLs: Supercritical answer to waste oil found (phys.org)

Summary Sentence: Researchers have received funding to reduce the carbon footprint of new 6G technology, however 6G roll out is still likely to have extremely&%23160;high energy costs.
Justification: The energetic cost of 6G needs to be considered in terms of the Environment Agency’s net zero goal, which may be hindered if this technology is utilised. There is a linear increase in energetic cost with increasing bandwidth meaning The SAMBAS project (Sustainable and Adaptive Ultra-High Capacity Micro Base Stations) need to achieve significant levels of energy saving in order to make this technology efficient and cost effective. &%23160;In addition, the installation of new 6G base stations will need to be regulated and any harmful effect of this high energy technology considered. The researchers plan to utilise energy efficient hardware and energy harvesting technology to reduce net demand and by combining this with energy aware protocols and intelligent resource allocation the group plan to reduce energy demand without effecting latency.
Primary Article Title: SAMBAS project aims for sustainable 6G
Author: Jason Ford
Keywords: Telecommunications 6G Sustainability "Net Zero" Energy "Carbon footprint" Wireless Technology "Energy harvesting"

Summary Sentence: Researchers from Macquarie University have successfully used neutron imaging techniques to investigate degradation in concrete sewer pipes.
Justification: Researchers from Macquarie University have successfully used neutron imaging techniques to investigate degradation in concrete sewer pipes. Relevant to the Environment Agency in terms of water drainage and abstraction regulation, offering potential for water companies to improve maintenance and reduce leakage as well as the possible future development to survey other structures such as flood defences. Currently Thames Water loses 22,000L of water per day per km of pipe in London due to leaks, contributing to unsustainable use of water resources. Application of new methods of monitoring pipes could help to improve infrastructure in a cost effective way. The acidic environment in drainage pipes can lead to relatively rapid deterioration and currently manual inspections and cores are used to investigate damage to concrete pipes. This technology uses a neutron tomography instrument called Dingo which fires neutron waves to penetrate into materials and take an image (similar to an x-ray). Computer software stacks multiple sequential images to produce a 3D visualisation (this is the tomography bit). This is a non-destructive method for surveying pipes. The research has revealed areas at high risk of corrosion and estimate the remaining service life of drains.
Primary Article Title: Understanding corrosion in concrete sewer pipes
Keywords: Drainage "Sewer systems" Repair Maintenance Imaging Tomography&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Poland is testing a smog ‘cannon’ which uses sound waves to blast toxic particles higher into the atmosphere.
Justification: The Environment Agency responds to pollution incidents, taking a leading role in air quality monitoring after major fires and the use of a pollution reducing cannon could be implemented following incidents to diffuse harmful&%23160;particles more quickly. Given the risks that air pollution poses on public health, technology that allows rapid dispersion of pollution particles could be developed as a temporary solution for areas that are exceeding pollution limits, for example after wildfires. The canon uses “vertical shockwaves” to reduce the concentration of PM2.5 and PM10 particles in the air by forcing them several hundred meters higher into the atmosphere. In the most recent tests a sound blast every 6 seconds for an hour reduced pollution by 15-30% for a two to three km radius which lasted for two to three hours. Researchers are testing the cannon to find the most efficient frequency and duration of sound blasts in order to reduce pollution. Currently it is being tested to disperse smog in the town of Kalwaria Zebrzydowska in Poland. The cannon does not remove pollution, rather it blasts particles higher into the atmosphere where it can disperse. In addition, fuel is required to power the cannon, which will produce some pollution.&%23160;Although this technology is not a solution to air pollution, it could be developed as a tool&%23160; to disperse toxic particles following heavily polluting incidents such as fires or chemical leaks.
Primary Article Title: Polish town tests anti-smog sound 'cannon' to tackle pollution
Author: Euronews
Keywords: "Air pollution" "Air quality" fires smog "smog removal" Anti-smog

Summary Sentence: Researchers have established a potential link between flame retardant chemicals and autism.
Justification:
Flame retardants are chemicals of interest to the Environment Agency, which needs to understand the full range of existing and prospective impacts on human and environmental health. Researchers have discovered that female mice exposed to Polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) can pass on the chemicals to their offspring, and when they do their female offspring show traits relevant to autism spectrum disorders (ASD). The mice showed impeded olfactory senses, a trait which is also associated with humans exhibiting ASD. They also exhibited changes to pro-social genes, suggesting that PBDEs target distinct brain systems to promote neurodevelopmental abnormalities. PBDEs are applied to many indoor products such as furniture foam, making it difficult to avoid exposure. &%23160;A significant amount of domestic waste contains PBDEs, which enters landfills, and can subsequently contaminate the surrounding soil, groundwater, and atmosphere, causing harm to humans and ecosystems. Further evidence of their potential as neuroendocrine-disrupting chemicals such as this study could mean that further action is needed to prevent, research and monitor their wider environmental impacts, such as wildlife health and behaviour.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Flame retardants linked to autistic-like behavior

Summary Sentence: A design student has invented an autonomous seed planting robot designed to combat desertification.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in the concept behind ‘Seedbot’ as it suggests possible technological directions for cost effective habitat restoration. Seedbot, invented by Mazyar Etehadi, spends the day recharging its on board batteries using its array of small solar panels. At night it propels itself across the desert, using sensors to identify fertile areas based on soil moisture, upon which it deposits and buries seeds in the sand. Seedbot also collects mapping and statistical data on its travels. Seedbot is still at an early stage of development. However the principles behind its realisation, such as robots able to identify optimum areas for replanting species in order to restore particular habitats, could mean that future restoration projects are more effective. Using robotic units in this manner could also lead to more cost effective habitat restoration compared to human labour costs, or where it is difficult to secure volunteer help.
Primary Article Title: This tiny autonomous robot transforms the desert into a verdant landscape
Author: Petridou, C
Keywords: autonomous robot habitat restoration conservation rewilding Seedbot desert seed sensor data map moisture soil "Mazyar Etehadi" energy solar battery cost labour volunteer sand biodiversity agriculture "climate change"

Summary Sentence: A design graduate has invented reusable bread packaging, which itself is made of bread.&%23160;
Justification: Similar developments to this help to reduce packaging waste and therefore may be of interest to the Environment Agency. This product may also present a challenge to other Environment Agency regulated sectors such as paper and packaging. Hind Rais combined her passion for baking with the challenge of sustainability to create a packaging, called ‘Beyond Bread’, made of baked dough, consisting of nothing more than the main ingredients of flour, water and salt. The dough is moulded, then baked on a low heat for several hours, creating a bowl shaped receptacle with a texture akin to wood. The robust container can be reused in bread deliveries, lasting up to several months before needing replacement. This development would be particularly suited to small-scale localised food production and delivery and is a way to reduce waste and packaging. However a more comprehensive lifecycle overview may be needed to compare the total supply chain impacts of using foodstuffs in packaging compared to alternatives such as plastic and paper.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Four inventions by UAE students&%2358; from home composting solutions to modular chairs
Author: Rodrigues, J
Keywords: food waste packaging bread dough yeast flour water salt "Beyond Bread" "Hind Rais" localism bakery regulation paper plastic farming crop wheat

Summary Sentence: ‘Sponge cities’, designed to control floods; harvest rainwater; improve water quality; and restore ecosystems, have taken off in China and should be a template for construction of new urban developments.
Justification: A shift to construction based around natural flood management and improving water quality would align with Environment Agency objectives and the success of sponge cities in China strengthens the case for committing to such innovative developments.&%23160;‘Sponge cities’ employ many of the same strategies as SuDS in the UK, but with an additional emphasis on designing cities around managing water, rather than adding SuDS principles to an existing urban design. With extreme weather events increasing in frequency, urban water management is becoming more critical for both flood and drought prevention. Changing the vocabulary around sustainable design from ‘SuDS’ to ‘sponge cities’ could improve accessibility and engagement from developers as well as the general public. Sponge cities conform to four main principles&%2358; firstly, they mitigate stormwater runoff via absorption and storage; secondly, they utilise self-purification systems and provide provision for water ecology management; thirdly, they use green infrastructure to purify, restore, adjust and reuse stormwater; finally, they employ permeable pavements in urban road construction.
Primary Article Title: Review on sponge city construction for flood management

Summary Sentence: Green LEDs attached to fishing nets found to significantly reduce bycatch without affecting target species catch.
Justification: The Environment Agency and its partners in DEFRA issue licences for the use of fishing instruments in England and should be made aware of this research for consideration when issuing gill net permits. Researchers from the University of Arizona have found that attaching simple green LEDs to gill-nets reduces bycatch by 63%, including 52% fewer turtles and 95% fewer elasmobranchs (sharks and rays). Gill-nets are essentially a wall of floating net that drift for several days indiscriminately trapping marine life. Not only did the application of LEDs reduce bycatch, it had the added benefit of reducing processing time by 50% when the nets were hauled in. By reducing processing time the LED attachments maintained catch values while improving operational efficiency. This research was conducted off the coast of Mexico and it is as yet uncertain how successful this method would be in other marine environments. The researchers note that although the LEDs are robust and relatively easy to attach the current cost would be in the range of 140USD per gill-net which may be prohibitively expensive for some fishers.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: These simple green lights could save sharks and turtles from fishing nets.
Author: Tess Joosse

Summary Sentence: Researchers at the University of Copenhagen and Queen Mary University have published a proof of concept for ‘air eDNA’ with the potential to revolutionise terrestrial habitat monitoring.
Justification: Air eDNA would be applicable to any monitoring or planning advisory roles undertaken by the Environment Agency, where air eDNA could be used to assess for the presence of protected species, potentially replacing less accurate manual surveys. Researchers used a water vacuum and fan to draw air through a filter where the DNA is collected. After sample processing, metabarcoding is used to compare the DNA collected to that of known vertebrates. The research, conducted at Copenhagen Zoo and Hamerton Zoo, positively identified up to 49 vertebrate species. Detection was highest when samples were collected within internal enclosures but open air samples were also successful. This technique would be revolutionary for habitat monitoring and could be utilised to assess for presence of protected species such as red squirrel, invasive species such as American mink or monitored species such as Eurasian beaver. This technology would also improve the types of ecological surveying used in planning applications such as transect type bird and bat surveys and &%23160;which are expensive, time consuming, require specially trained staff and can be very inaccurate. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: Measuring biodiversity from DNA in the air
Author: Elizabeth Claire
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.cell.com/current-biology/fulltext/S0960-9822(21)01690-0%23%20

Summary Sentence: As the UK Government unveils plans to pay farmers for rewilding areas of their land, new initiatives are coming to light that demonstrate the rewilding potential of publicly owned land in urban environments.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be mindful of the opportunities that growing interest in urban rewilding could present in achieving some of its own strategic objectives such as natural realignment of rivers and flood management. Though levels of funding and final scale have yet to be disclosed the UK Government is to run 10-15 pilot projects focussed on landscape recovery. There are also plans to pay farmers to focus on local nature recovery. In total such schemes could cover a land area the size of Lancashire by 2042. One criticism of the scheme has been that encouraging rewilding in this way may be vulnerable to changing market prices for crops and other agricultural products, either leading to waning impact or food shortages. At the same time there are other signals pointing towards greater rewilding of more urban land, some of which is publicly owned. Naturalist and campaigner Chris Packham has met with the Crown Estate to discuss the prospect of rewilding aspects of its holdings, which includes farmland, woodlands and uplands, but also urban areas such as Regent Street in central London and Windsor Great Park. A recent study of London’s publicly owned golf courses established a case that their combined land area (equivalent to the borough of Brent) could become more accessible to residents through including biodiverse green space, amongst other uses. Derby city council recently approved the UK’s largest urban rewilding project for Allestree Park, the city’s largest urban green space. Ideas for rewilding the park include new habitat creation, community orchards reintroducing key species, such as water vole and harvest mouse. This project and others mentioned could inspire other publicly owned and urban spaces to follow suit, bringing environmental benefits in terms of mitigating climate change impacts, carbon sequestration, and water quality benefits through fewer chemical and fertiliser applications. Such schemes could also provide ‘blue space’ benefits, including natural realignment of rivers and natural flood management such as providing areas for flood water storage. The Environment Agency may wish to ensure that it is proactively advising and influencing urban rewilding schemes to maximise the benefits to its own strategic objectives and interest in urban rewilding grows.
Primary Article Title: ‘Natural Health Service’&%2358; Derby approves UK’s largest urban rewilding project

Summary Sentence: Pollutants from wood burning stoves in urban areas have been found to produce almost half of residents’ exposure to carcinogenic chemicals.
Justification: The Environment Agency may need to consider how research like this could alter its regulatory remit around air quality to better protect people’s health, particularly as there is currently interest in urban agendas and environmental inequalities. Research based on Athens, Greece found that burning wood produced more polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) than petrol or diesel emissions. Different PAHs have different carcinogenic properties. The potency of those arising from wood burning was calculated to represent 43% of the cancer risk to people compared to diesel and oil at 36% and petrol at 17%. While this research focused on Athens the researchers believe their conclusions to be applicable to other European cities where people use wood burning stoves. Other recent research found that ecodesign wood burning stoves emit 750 times more particulate pollution than a modern HGV truck and that UK domestic wood burning is the single biggest source of small particle air pollution. Suggestions to remedy the problem in the short term is to move to more electric vehicles and introduce ‘no burn’ days, depending on meteorological conditions.&%23160;
Primary Article Title:
Wood burners cause nearly half of urban air pollution cancer risk – study

Summary Sentence: A Turkish dairy farmer has fitted his cows with virtual reality (VR) headsets in an attempt to increase milk yields.&%23160;
Justification: The implications of this could impact on the Environment Agency’s regulatory remit around agriculture and intensive farming installations. Farmer Izzet Kocak has put VR headsets on his cattle, showing them images of sunny grasslands. His theory is that the VR experience makes the cows more content so that they produce more milk. Kocak sees this as being particularly important during winter when his cattle spend more time indoors. Initial results seem promising in terms of raising milk yields. However the experiment’s success raises a number of issues around the ethics of animal treatment. Creating an optimised virtual environment that leads to contented cows and higher yields might weaken the ethical case for not pursuing intensive dairy and livestock farming. This in turn could mean a greater regulatory role for the Environment Agency. This could also contribute to wider scale land use change away from dairy farming. Dairy is already considered a carbon intensive industry - including digital infrastructure in a manner similar to this could increase the resource footprint even more.
Primary Article Title: A Turkish farmer tests out VR goggles on cows to get more milk
Author: Bayrakdar, I

Summary Sentence: &%23160;A Guardian literature study on seafood fraud found that nearly 40% of seafood was mislabelled globally, with the UK fairing particularly badly with a rate of 55% mislabelling.
Justification: The Environment Agency and DEFRA issue permits and regulate a range of fishery and seafood processing activities and may come under scrutiny if these industries are found to be fraudulently labelling seafood. The use of genetic analysis such as DNA barcoding combined with supply chain tracking could be used by regulatory bodies to track down fisheries or processing plants that are committing fraud. Although some mislabelling is accidental, evidence suggests that highly prized (and therefore more expensive) seafood tended to be substituted with similar, less coveted species, suggesting that active fraud is occurring. Seafood fraud poses a risk to food integrity, the economy, public health and consumers’ ethics. Some organisations, such as the Marine Stewardship Council (MSC), the world’s leading seafood certifier already undertake DNA testing on samples of their certified products to prevent fraud.
Primary Article Title: Revealed&%2358; seafood fraud happening on a vast global scale

Summary Sentence: Waste sugar beet is gaining traction as an alternative de-icer for city streets but research suggests it can harm aquatic environments.
Justification: The Environment Agency needs to be aware of the potential damage to aquatic habitats that could be caused if sugar beet brine de-icer is used on UK streets. New research suggests that sugar beet brine has a detrimental effect on aquatic invertebrates including mayflies which are an important water pollution indicator due to their sensitivity to runoff.&%23160; Beet brine also contributes to harmful algal blooms by adding nutrients to water ways. Waste sugar beet molasses has been used as an alternative de-icer on city streets across North America. The mixture is a more effective and less corrosive option and the hope was that it may be less environmentally damaging than salt, which runs-off into aquatic habitats and corrodes infrastructure. The use of salt as a de-icer has long been linked to toxic levels of chloride in adjacent aquatic habitats (%2312624) and sugar beet brine has been used previously as an &%23160;alternative de-icer as far back as 2010 (%2310090). It has been used in several US and Canadian cities in the intervening years. Marketed as being fully biodegradable, longer lasting than salt and containing a scant 12% sodium chloride, the benefits seem appealing, but more research is needed to assess long term environmental impacts.
Primary Article Title: The Cities That Battle Winter With Beets.
Author: Sarah Holder
