Summary Sentence: Higher ambient temperatures increase the chance of women giving birth prematurely while exposure to wild fire smoke increases the risk of severe birth defects and air pollution is linked to reduced fertility.
Justification: Regulatory bodies such as the Environment Agency need to be aware of such socio-economic and public health impacts when considering how to regulate industry, monitor air quality and produce climate adaption strategies. A recent study in Australia found that, even in more temperate climates such as New South Wales, the hottest periods of the week before birth were associated with a 16% higher risk of premature birth. In addition, hotter temperatures were linked to rapid weight gain in babies, a factor that leads to a higher chance of obesity in later life. A separate study found that exposure to wildfire smoke in the month before conception has been found to double the chance of babies being born with severe birth defects. Air pollution, which has already been linked to higher risks of premature birth; low birth weight and stillbirth, has now been found to also effect fertility. A Danish study has found that even small increases of particle pollution can lead to an 8% reduction in conception. Air pollution levels in this study would be deemed safe under EU legislation suggesting a need to reassess air quality standards.
Primary Article Title: Global heating linked to early birth and damage to babies’ health, scientists find.
Author: Damian Carrington
Keywords: “Climate change” “air pollution” “public health” warming legislation pollution

Summary Sentence: Nanopesticides are emerging as a new form of agricultural pesticides, but there is currently little understanding of potential environmental impacts.
Justification: Although HSE is responsible for the regulation of pesticides, the associated environmental impact are the domain of the Environment Agency. Nanopesticides utilise nano-scale particles to produce more effective and highly targeted pesticides for use in agriculture. Nanopesticides consist of conventional pesticides contained in molecule sized droplets, ranging in size from five to thousands of nanometres in width, similar to the size of human hair. Nano-capsules containing pesticides will likely be the first versions of these to become available.&%23160; Although their mechanisms of action vary, smaller particles size and higher surface area allow for more targeted application and lower volume requirements, along with improved solubility, slow release of active ingredients and better mobility. However, these properties also raise environmental and health concerns and issues such as environmental fate, uptake by biota, bioaccumulation and ecotoxicity in aquatic environments. The Environment Agency and partners may need to address these concerns before nanopesticides become readily available commercially.
Primary Article Title: Everything You Need To Know About Nanopesticides.
Publisher: Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment
Author: Bhabesh Deka
Secondary_URLs: Everything You Need To Know About Nanopesticides - Modern Farmer
Keywords: Farming agriculture pesticide chemical nanotechnology conservation pollution

Summary Sentence: A UK based social enterprise is pioneering a decentralised citizen led approach to conservation and rewilding.
Justification: The Environment Agency has an interest in citizen science and therefore should be interested in novel examples from this field. Citizen Zoo is running a citizen keeper concept to breed the rare English large marsh grasshopper. People are given the equipment and training needed to hatch and rear the grasshoppers. On reaching adulthood Citizen Zoo collects the grasshoppers from their citizen keepers for release at specific sites of suitable habitat. The project has been running since 2019 and has raised sufficient numbers that the wild populations are almost self-sustaining. The project challenges conventional notions of captive breeding by removing the process from zoological institutions and democratising conservation action currently perceived as prohibitively expensive. The project has received support from several corners, including Natural England. The Environment Agency may consider how similar projects could compliment its own biodiversity and conservation work and acknowledge the potential power that increased active citizen involvement in projects could bring.
Primary Article Title: Citizen Zoo Is Rewilding the UK, One Grasshopper at a Time

Summary Sentence: A biomaterials company is hoping to take its kelp based yarn into mainstream textile production.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency regulates the textile industry and therefore should be interested in the potential environmental consequences of novel textile materials. The fashion industry is responsible for a significant contribution to global climate change emissions, and therefore there should also be an interest in novel materials that reduce this impact. The new yarn may also represent a less impactful alternative to terrestrial based yarns such as wool, potentially bringing opportunities to change land use and landscape for environmental gain. The company in question AlgiKnit previously developed its kelp based bioyarn, first seen in 2017, and has been refining the product ready for a commercial rollout. AlgiKnit is set to launch with one manufacturer some time in 2022, but a current lack of production facilities is limiting the larger rollout. Seaweed is an important plant for remediation and carbon sequestration, therefore expanding the use of seaweed for textile in a sustainable manner could provide multiple environmental benefits to biodiversity as well as climate.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: From kelp to catwalk

Summary Sentence: Several projects have been investigating the viability of recovering ammonia from wastewater and agricultural waste for use in energy production.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as ammonia is considered a problematic emission from some regulated settings such as pig and poultry installations. Researchers based at Delft University of Technology have recovered a gaseous ammonia-water mixture from wastewater using membrane stripping, which was used to power a solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC). Even with relatively low ammonia concentrations the set up recovered more energy than it consumed, suggesting commercially viable ammonia recovery & use from wastewater feeds. A UK based research consortium, partly funded by Defra, are similarly investigating the potential of harvesting green ammonia from pig waste. Previous research using similar methods with digestate from wastewater treatment plants suggested 82 per cent of ammonia could be recovered that would otherwise require energy intensive processes to destroy. Ukrainian researchers have been making similar in-roads using poultry waste as a feedstock. They were able to extract ammonia and biogas from anaerobic digestion of poultry waste through carefully controlling ammonium levels in the digester. Producing ammonia in this way was found to be more energy intensive than the Haber Bosch process conventionally used for industrial scale ammonia production, but this could be mitigated through scaling this process up at poultry farms, adding co generation facilities and utilising waste heat from biogas combustion. Poultry waste has the highest nitrogen content of livestock waste and potentially 8 million tonnes of ammonia per year could be generated in both the US and the EU via this anaerobic digestion process. Recent research estimates that 60 per cent of particulate air pollution (PM2.5) in the UK originates as ammonia emissions from farms, and that the introduction of simple mitigation methods could save £23 in health damage for every £1 spent in the UK. The advent of these technologies could provide mechanisms to reduce fossil fuel dependency and improve air quality, however their introduction may fall under similar regulatory requirements as anaerobic digestion and therefore require Environment Agency roles and resources.
Primary Article Title: Recovering ammonia fuel from wastewater & agricultural waste

Summary Sentence: Gorse bushes, conventionally seen as a problematic invasive plant, could be a valuable source of plentiful future protein.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners may need to consider the implications of this and other novel protein sources in terms of how it views land use, biodiversity, agriculture and food production in the context of external pressures such as climate change and population growth. Gorse is an important habitat for insects and birds, but it can spread quickly to choke out other plants and is therefore seen as invasive. It is particularly problematic in some areas of Scotland where there is a concerted effort to prevent it colonising valuable agricultural land. Livestock and fodder production occupies 83% of the world’s farmland but produces only 18% of protein. Gorse has historically been used as livestock feed on the occasions when other crops have failed. Recent research looking at the protein content of invasive plants found that gorse contains 17 per cent protein. It’s ability to thrive on marginal land therefore suggests that with further development gorse could become a valuable source of nutrition from marginal land for livestock and potentially even human consumption. Calculations have shown that there is potentially enough gorse protein on marginal land in Scotland to feed its entire population. The carbon footprint of gorse protein is also significantly smaller than that of meat. There is still much to develop - for example it is difficult to gauge the processing needed to extract the protein and how this would compare to gorse fed livestock or livestock in general.&%23160;But with evidence that the population is also more willing to embrace alternative proteins, sources such as gorse could become increasingly important as both a food source and a means of providing biodiversity protection, reducing competing pressures on land use.
Primary Article Title: Protein from gorse bushes could feed millions of people, says expert
Author: Carrington, D
Keywords: farming agriculture conservation biodiversity meat livestock protein plant gorse invasive "land use" flooding food regulation habitat insect bird regulation human "climate change" "carbon footprint"

Summary Sentence: In the wake of mounting evidence scientists are beginning to reconsider if insects are capable of experiencing and expressing emotions.
Justification: Research suggests that insects can experience a range of states akin to delight, depression, and fright just like other animals might do. Emotions can be framed as mental programmes that change our behaviour in certain situations. In evolutionary terms these help us survive. It is possible that insects experience similar ‘programmes’ for the same reasons. Experiments involving fruit flies and bees demonstrate that they can experience hunger and trauma respectively. And a colour change response in the golden tortoise beetle to stress has been shown to be a consciously controlled action rather than a passive reaction. There’s also mounting evidence that insects can feel depression and long term pain, changing their behaviour to prevent an injury happening again. Currently insects experience a significant level of systematic destruction - it’s believed that 3.5 quadrillion insects a year are killed with pesticides per year on US farmland alone - to the point where the World is experiencing an ‘insect Armageddon’. Knowing that insects can experience complex feelings and emotions could reframe the way in which humans view the impacts of agricultural practices. This could include the emerging field of farming insect protein for livestock and human consumption. The existence of insect emotions also raises ethical questions for research programmes, just as it has previously for other living things. These in turn may contribute to wider societal changes in industrial practices regulated by the Environment Agency and indeed also has the potential to change regulatory remits by broadening concepts of animal welfare and sentience.
Primary Article Title: Why insects are more sensitive than they seem
Author: Gorvett, Z
Keywords: insect behaviour personhood emotion sentience legal legislation regulation law "fruit fly" bee "golden tortoise beetle" animal wildlife meat research livestock protein ethics rights farming agriculture pesticide depression pain trauma&%23160;

Summary Sentence: New Zealand is to introduce new legislation that will ban young people under the age of 14 from buying cigarettes for the rest of their lives.&%23160;
Justification: This novel approach to legislation, regulation and behaviour change should be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as it presents a realised mechanism of applying legislation demographically, rather than democratically and could therefore help to bring longer term generational changes which may be difficult to implement in the present. New Zealand is to introduce a blanket ban on cigarette sales to young people under the age of 14. The ban will come into force in 2027. Anyone aged 15 in 2027 will still be able to buy tobacco once they reach the age of 18. Anyone 14 and younger will be banned for the rest of their lives. This is because the evidence suggests that lifetime smoking habits become established during early teenage years. One reason the law is being introduced is to tackle the disproportionate impacts of smoking on the health of the indigenous Maori community. The law is being phased in to lessen the economic shocks &%23160;on retailers and give people with mental health issues - a group with far higher smoking rates - time to manage the change. It isn’t yet clear how the law will be policed effectively. The law could be approved in 2022. The existence of this proposed law suggests that other similar demographically based laws could be introduced for environmental improvements, such as personal resource budgets (e.g. water, carbon, meat). A younger more environmentally conscious electorate could be more receptive to such lifestyle changes than older members of the population, allowing for policy makers to ‘kickstart’ longer term changes without encountering political and social blockers in the present day.
Primary Article Title: Explainer&%2358; How will New Zealand's lifetime ban on cigarette sales work?
Keywords: health behaviour law legislation smoking regulation demographic "New Zealand" 2027 tobacco "climate change" resource water waste Maori

Summary Sentence: A US lab specialising in identifying and destroying PFAS chemicals is experimenting with new discovered ionomer filters.
Justification: PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) chemicals are of great interest to the Environment Agency and partners due to their longevity in the environment and links to health impacts including cancer. Based in Delaware the Center For PFAS Solutions has been experimenting with PFAS-filtering products called ionomers. An ionomer is a polymer composed of repeat units of both electrically neutral repeating units and ionised units covalently bonded to the polymer backbone as pendant group moieties. Commercial applications include golf ball covers, sealing tape, thermoplastic elastomers, and of interest to PFAS removal, semipermeable membranes. Conventional carbon filtration systems are only able to filter out“long-chain” PFAS. The ionomers are able to filter out “short-chain” PFAS chemicals. The Centre is also working on technology that could destroy PFAS from contaminated well water in situ - currently PFAS contamination needs to be transported to incinerators. These technological developments should be of interest to the Environment Agency in its regulatory activities with water, chemical and waste sectors as they could offer the possibility to reduce pollution from operational sites. In addition the capability to destroy harmful persistent chemicals in situ as opposed to collecting and transporting for destruction could be of interest for deploying during pollution incidents involving a range of chemicals beyond PFAS.
Primary Article Title: How a lab works to seek and destroy the harmful chemicals known as PFAS

Summary Sentence: Spain has passed a new bill which recognises animals as having the legal protection of sentient beings.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this development as a growing recognition of animal personhood could impact on regulated industries, particularly in the agricultural sector. Spain already offers some legal protection for animal sentience, but the new bill adds legal guidance to civil cases involving property, family, and divorce so that the best interests of animals are considered in line with those for their humans. While the move received broad support across the political spectrum there was noted opposition from the political far right, with one politician quoted as saying “It humanizes animals and dehumanizes man.”
Primary Article Title: Spain passes new law recognizing animals as sentient beings and not “objects”

Summary Sentence: The European Environment Agency says that most city-dwelling Europeans live amongst health damaging levels of pollution despite historic improvements.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency (EEA) as an air quality regulator, particularly as the UK maintains EU environmental standards. Despite causing a third less deaths than in 2005, air quality was still thought responsible for 307,000 premature deaths in the European Union in 2019. Around 97% of the EU’s urban population was exposed to fine particulate matter levels above World Health Organization guidelines in 2019, while 94% faced WHO-breaching levels of nitrogen dioxide (NO2). The impacts varied geographically, for example Bosnia, Turkey, Poland and Bulgaria had some of the highest levels of particulate pollution due to burning solid fuels for home heating. The EEA’s report highlighted &%23160;a significant gap between EU air quality limits and the World Health Organisation’s (WHO) limits which have recently tightened. The EU is to revise its air quality standards next year. The health impacts of current standards could lead to similar tightening of standards in the UK, impacting on emitters the resources needed by the Environment Agency for regulating this space.
Primary Article Title: Most city-dwelling Europeans face damaging air pollution – EEA
Author: Abnett, K

Summary Sentence: Scientists have developed a passive atmospheric water harvester, working at close to the theoretical maximum efficiency and using zero energy for collection.
Justification: Such a system suggests the potential for a decentralised decoupling from conventional water provision and reduces water scarcity, and could therefore be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners in addressing future water resource challenges. Existing passive atmospheric water harvesting systems effectively collect dew and so can only function at night when the collected water is not evaporated by the sun. The researchers have developed a technology that enables 24 hour passive water harvesting, even under i blazing sunlight. A special glass pane coated with silver and polymer, which both reflects solar radiation and also radiates away its own heat through the atmosphere cools itself down to as much as 15 degrees Celsius below ambient temperature. A cone shaped radiation shield also protects the glass pane from incoming solar radiation and aids passive self-cooling. Water vapour condenses on the underside of the glass, which has a super-hydrophobic coating, causing the water to run down and gather in the collector without the need for wiping mechanisms. The current technology is at a model stage but could easily be scaled up to produce a 0.53 decilitres of water per square metre of pane surface per hour - close to the theoretical maximum value of 0.6 decilitres per hour. The future could see several modules working side by side in a similar arrangement to how solar farms function and could also be combined alongside desalination installations. The technology was designed with water scarcity issues, particularly in developing countries in mind. However the technology could also see applications in the UK particularly an ‘off grid’ small scale decentralised context, particularly as climate change starts to bring potentially drier conditions to the UK.
Primary Article Title: Harvesting drinking water from humidity around the clock
Author: Bergamin, F
Secondary_URLs: Exploiting radiative cooling for uninterrupted 24-hour water harvesting from the atmosphere (science.org)

Summary Sentence: A US wastewater treatment plant recently installed technology based on algae designed to strip out phosphorus to sell on as a commercially viable product.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested to see this as phosphorus is a problematic nutrient in water quality associated with eutrophication. Phosphorus is also a limited resource and therefore installations like the one described suggest pathways towards a circular economy. The City of Waupun in Dodge County, Wisconsin updated their wastewater treatment plant to include an Advanced Biological Nutrient Recovery (ABNR) system from a company called CLEARAS Water Recovery. The ABNR system uses algae to remove phosphorus from wastewater and recover the phosphorus in a marketable algae co-product. This dried algae product can generate extra revenue as an industrial feedstock, offsetting some ABNR system expenses. An initial customer plans to produce insoles from the dried algae. Once fully operational the ABNR system is expected to produce two tons of algae per day, generating an annual revenue of $500,000.
Primary Article Title: USDA celebrates City of Waupun wastewater treatment plant upgrade groundbreaking&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A new study of six million people in the USA has discovered a link between the sex ratio of humans at birth and presence of air and water pollutants.
Justification: As a regulator of emissions to air the Environment Agency should be interested in how these emissions could be impacting on health and future demographics. Researchers based their research on the IBM Health MarketScan insurance claim dataset, covering 3 million births in the United States from 2003 to 2011, and the weather and pollution at each point in time from 1983 to 2013. This was supplemented with additional data to increase the sample size. Sex ratio at birth (SRB) was found to be unrelated to season, ambient temperature, violent crime rate, unemployment rate, or commuting time. Instead SRB was found to be closely related to levels of many pollutants, including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), iron, lead, mercury, carbon monoxide, aluminium in the air, chromium and arsenic in water. Extreme drought was also found to be associated with SRBs. While the study doesn’t establish causality it does raise interesting questions for further research.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Studies have discovered new pollutants associated with changing proportions of boys and girls
Author: Ryder, W

Summary Sentence: Nature-related images have been found to impact positively on investor behaviour, regardless of the relevance to the investment in question.&%23160;
Justification:
This intelligence could be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners where there is a desire to generate financial interest in ‘green investment’, nature based solutions and natural capital investment.

In a recent study participants were exposed to a measured range of nature-related and a non-nature set of images during several investment decisions. It was found that positive images significantly increased investment (and vice versa), despite the images not providing any additional investment relevant information. It was further shown that exposure to nature-related images results in significantly higher investment compared to non-nature images. As interest in sustainable investment increases, understanding the consequences of using nature related imagery for investor decision-making of such displays may have increasing relevance. Regulators like the Environment Agency and partners may need to consider the effects of imagery in designing or implementing legislation with the purpose of increasing transparency and decreasing green-washing in sustainable investment.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Positivity and Nature&%2358; how images increase investment
Author: van Boxel, K; et al
Keywords: regulation investment greenwash nature "natural capital" image sustainable sustainability decision

Summary Sentence: Conspiracy theorists are starting to shift their attention from the coronavirus pandemic emergency to the climate emergency.
Justification: With recent evidence of civil unrest and communication challenges arising from belief in conspiracy theories, governments and organisations including the Environment Agency may need to consider how a change in focus to climate change could present future communication and operational challenges. The BBC reports that online anti-lockdown and anti-vaccine groups are starting to inject climate change into the conspiratorial narratives they use to explain the pandemic. Climate change is being portrayed as overexaggerated or as a hoax designed for population control. One manifestation of this is “climate lockdown” - the notion that Covid-style lockdowns could be introduced to counteract climate change. As with most conspiracy theories there is an element of truth at the core - climate emissions did fall during lockdown - &%23160;but not to a level that came near to reversing anthropogenic climate change in any way. The atmosphere of distress and distrust created in the wake of Covid is potentially primed for a similar trajectory for climate change misinformation, particularly as the scale of the current climate emergency and response needed echoes that of Covid. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: Covid denial to climate denial&%2358; How conspiracists are shifting focus
Author: Spring, M
Keywords: "climate change" Covid pandemic conspiracy information internet online misinformation disinformation communication influence politics behaviour

Summary Sentence: A recent study has found variations in key personality traits by geography.
Justification:
While the differences are small this study could be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners in terms of influencing and communication strategies. A study has examined geographical variations in the ‘Big Five’ personality traits recognised by psychology, also known as CANOE&%2358; Conscientiousness; Agreeableness; Neuroticism (a.k.a., Emotional Stability); Openness; Extraversion. This recent study has looked at the USA and Germany, but a previous study performed a similar study for the UK. Looking at the results, geographic location seems to have a significant effect on the prevalence of these traits. The study is keen to point out that none of these traits should be taken in isolation, nor is there evidence for cause, nor effect. Exposing such statistically relevant variations in personality type by region, “geopsychology” &%23160;may prove an important tool for marketeers, political activists or others interested in influencing at a regional and national scale.
&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Innovations in renewable energy are suggesting ways to increase the amount of energy that can be generated through tidal power and in urban environments.&%23160;
Justification:
Experimental underwater rigs known as "sea dragons" or "tidal kites" are currently operating in the Faroe Islands. They resemble aircraft with single propeller tidal turbines towards the rear. The sea dragons &%23160;move underwater in a figure-of-eight pattern, absorbing energy from the running tide. The moving "flight path" allows the kite to sweep a large area at greater speed than the current, amplifying the power generated. The process is optimised using an algorithm. Each kite can produce enough electricity to power approximately 50 to 70 homes, but larger kites are to be deployed in 2022 that can generate 1.2 megawatts. An artist has designed a vertical array of small wind turbines which could be easily incorporated into urban environments. Joe Doucet’s aim was to create a turbine that fit into a wall, rather than require flat open space. His prototype Wind Turbine Wall &%23160;is a 25 x 8- oot grid of vertical rods with spinning square panels that generate around 10 000 kilowatt-hours of electricity a year. Both designs could be of interest to the Environment Agency as innovations to incorporate into its own asset portfolio. The sea kites may also need consideration in terms of how such developments could impact on navigation and coastal flood defence, if realised.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Bringing wind turbines into urban spaces
Secondary_URLs: The underwater 'kites' generating electricity as they move - BBC News

Summary Sentence: A newly designed plastic meat tray that absorbs moisture could save tonnes of packaging waste going to landfill.
Justification: Currently pre-packaged meat contains a separate absorbent pad. A scientist working at Swansea University has developed a new tray design with an integral solution which draws in moisture and converts it into a gel which cannot physically leak back out into the meat. About 800,000 tonnes of UK meat packaging plastic waste is produced each year, of which five to eight per cent comes from the absorbent padding. Should this innovation reach the market it could signify a significant reduction in consumer waste, and possible changes to recycling technology due to mixed materials, even though the tray itself is 100 per cent recyclable.
Primary Article Title: Plastic pollution&%2358; new meat tray 'could save tonnes of waste'
Author: Prior, N
Keywords: regulation waste plastic meat tray gel absorption Swansea recycling landfill

Summary Sentence: Scientists have recently discovered that whales play a significant role in natural carbon capture and sequestration.&%23160;
Justification: This discovery could have implications for future nature based approaches to terrestrial carbon capture approaches such as reforestation, offer different perspectives on where climate change action might focus and reframe concerns around land use challenges. The marine environment is known to offer potential to store ‘blue carbon’ through coastal and marine habitats such as mangroves, seagrasses and tidal marshes (%2310740). This new discovery offers another potential ‘non-tech’ solution to carbon storage in contrast to technology led carbon capture solutions. Great whales were found to sequester 33 tons of CO2 on average, accumulated over their lifetimes, taking the carbon out of the atmosphere for centuries. A tree only absorbs up to 48 pounds of CO2 a year. Historic commercial whaling significantly reduced whale populations, with today’s numbers representing a quarter of overall numbers, but as low as three per cent for blue whales. Protecting whales to increase their numbers could therefore deliver significant carbon capture benefits. Whale waste is rich in nutrients iron and nitrogen, which stimulates phytoplankton growth, as does the ‘whale pump’ of nutrients that they bring to the surface through their vertical movement in the water column. Phytoplankton currently absorb 40 per cent of the World’s carbon dioxide, and therefore show further potential for carbon capture. Even a one per cent increase in phytoplankton productivity from whale activity could capture the equivalent to the sudden appearance of 2 billion mature trees per year. Conservation efforts to increase whale numbers would need funding. However, allowing whale populations to recover to pre-whaling levels would cost $13 per person a year to subsidise, capturing 1.7 billion tons of CO2 annually. Without such efforts it would take &%23160;30 years to double whale numbers at current rates.
Primary Article Title: Nature’s solution to climate change
Author: Chami, R; et al
Keywords: "climate change" biodiversity "carbon capture" CCS sequestration whale marine sea ocean mangrove seagrass mud flat tidal sea conservation phytoplankton iron nutrient nitrate phosphorus whaling land tree land use forest reforestation

Summary Sentence: Post pandemic supply chain issues threaten to disrupt and delay solar energy projects around the World for at least 12 months.
Justification: Shipping costs for containers leaving China, where most solar panels are made, have increased significantly. Component costs have also increased significantly, particularly for polysilicon which is currently in short supply. The cost of solar panels are therefore rising for the first time in over seven years. Utility companies are most exposed to this cost increase. The delay has been calculated to impact on 56 per cent of utility scale projects globally planned for 2022. However higher costs may also deter consumers and businesses from investing. It is uncertain how long this delay and cost rise could last, though experts estimate the supply chain impacts may be felt until at least 2023. Even if only temporary these supply issues may impact on ambitions to address environmental ambitions issues such as Net Zero.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Supply chain chaos threatens the growth of solar energy
Author: Rivero, N
Keywords: energy economics price cost supply photovoltaic solar renewable utility 2022 2023 "Net Zero" target&%23160;polysilicon resource regulation

Summary Sentence: Hospital admissions for gout have been linked to short-term exposure to air pollutants.&%23160;
Justification: As a regulator of air pollution the Environment Agency should be interested in emerging evidence of the diverse impacts of air pollution on health. The link comes from a study based on data from the city of &%23160;Anqing in a humid subtropical region of China. The researchers looked at data from three pollutants&%2358; nitrogen dioxide (NO2), ozone (O3), and carbon monoxide (CO), and data on hospitalisations for acute gout, caused by a buildup of sodium urate (MSU) crystals in joints. They found a strong association between short term exposure to exposure to NO2 and CO had a significant impact on hospitalisations for acute gout, which was particularly strong during cold season. The scientists also found an intriguing negative association between O3 and hospitalizations for gout. The team acknowledges their study is restricted to only one city. However with increasing traffic volumes and associated urbanisation this study suggests that increased incidents of gout may be a consequence. Gout is associated with inflammatory disease, which also has existing connections with air pollution.
Primary Article Title: The Relationship Between Ambient Air Pollution and Hospitalizations for Gout in a Humid Subtropical Region of China
Author: He, Y et al

Summary Sentence: Advertising and media companies are becoming more active in shaping public opinion towards action on climate change.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as changing attitudes to the environment may also impact on public opinion towards organisations working in the environmental field. There may also be some lessons to learn in persuasive communications around environmental issues. Several surveys conducted recently paint a mixed picture as to the public’s attitudes and behaviours towards climate change. The Global Consumer Barometer Study suggests that nearly three quarters of UK consumers believe that the responsibility for action on the environment was down to governments. However, 61% said companies must take the lead and 60% said driving change is down to individual behaviour and responsibility. A different global survey, which included subjects from the UK found that most people believe that they are already doing as much as they could to address environmental issues, with few willing to rate measures that impacted their own lifestyles as important. Another survey from the World Economic Forum also revealed that there has been a global decline in people practicing climate-conscious lifestyles since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic. Fewer than one-in-five people are changing their lives significantly for reasons of climate, and a third making no changes at all. Against this backdrop of attitudes to climate action are initiatives from the media sector to encourage more environmentally sustainable choices. Leaders at the Advertising Association’s Ad Net Zero summit recognised that their industry has a role to “change the way people think, feel and act”. Advertising was seen as having a role in helping to fill information gaps with accurate information and ensuring advertisements do not appear beside articles that contradict scientific evidence. The broadcaster Sky recently worked with the Behavioural Insights Team (BIT) across several European countries. Their research demonstrated that four-fifths of people across Europe support the idea of broadcasters using content and advertising to encourage people to adopt more environmentally positive behaviours. Sky and BIT have published a report outlining ten new behavioural science principles to guide broadcasters on helping their viewers to take action. The Environment Agency may need to consider how an emerging willingness to approach environmental issues from the media industry could provide opportunities for communications to help it achieve environmental objectives.

Summary Sentence: A US steel mill has been converted to run entirely on photovoltaic energy.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this example which demonstrates that decarbonising heavy industry is technologically feasible. The project, located at Rocky Mountain Steel property in Pueblo, consists of more than 750,000 solar panels providing almost all of the plant’s annual energy needs for recycling scrap steel into new products.The project is expected to prevent 433,770 metric tons of carbon dioxide from being released into the atmosphere, the equivalent of taking 92,100 cars off the roads a year.

Summary Sentence: A microbe discovered in the wetlands of New Jersey could be used to break down PFAS chemicals.&%23160;
Justification: The discovery should be of interest to the Environment Agency as Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are pollutants of interest due to their “forever chemical” status and the impacts they can bring to environmental and human health. Scientists took an isolated bacterium which had been found effective at breaking down ammonium. Acidimicrobiaceae sp. A6 (A6) is unusual in that it can break down ammonium using iron present in soil. This reaction is known as Feammox. The scientists wondered if the same principle could be applied to PFAS. &%23160;They grew cultures of A6 in iron rich mediums, into which were added perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) or perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS). They found that A6 used the Feammox reaction to transfer electrons from ammonium or hydrogen gas to PFAS, removing the fluoride atoms and rendering the substances harmless. The microbes degraded up to 60% of the PFOA and 50% of the PFOS over a 100 day period. These results suggest that under the right conditions a similar process could biodegrade PFAS in contaminated soil and groundwater.
Primary Article Title: Microbe from New Jersey wetlands chomps PFAS

Summary Sentence: A robot has been developed to prune and thin trees in peach orchards.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners may be interested to consider how such developments could impact on agriculture and the rural economy. Previous examples of fruit harvesting robots exist (%2315020) but little attention has so far been paid to pruning and thinning, which are equally labour intensive processes. The Georgia Tech developed robot recognises and removes undeveloped peaches known as peachlets. It can also assist with pruning, selectively removing branches prior to the spring growing season. Robots have yet to replace humans entirely, due to the nature of unstructured environments, which includes unpredictable weather, uneven terrain, and trees' different shapes and sizes. Further development however could lead to significant disruptions to farming and horticulture. IN another development an Australian company has recently won a multi-home construction contract, which it will fulfil using Hadrian X, its bricklaying robot. This is the first multi-home contract for Perth based FBR to build eight two storey houses using its Wall as a Service (WaaS) construction system. Similar systems have been seen previously (12943, %2312865). Bricklaying robot Hadrian X has a top building speed of 200 large blocks per hour, which is the equivalent of 2,200 standard bricks using manual labour. Similar technologies could be of interest to the Environment Agency for asset management and construction such as flood defences, significantly reducing construction time.
Primary Article Title: Intelligent robots pick, prune in the peach orchard

Summary Sentence: Further developments in virtual currency and blockchain technology suggest further ways in which digital currency could transform financial systems, yet also demonstrate the potential for such systems to impact negatively on the environment, particularly around energy use and climate change.
Justification: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) &%23160;have recently emerged as a new development in digital currency and assets. An NFT is a digital asset can represent a real-world object, or a completely digital asset. Whereas the key property of digital is that it can be easily copied and replicated an NFT might be a one of a kind digital asset, or be of a limited run. An example could be digital art or a video clip. The NFT confirms who owns that particular digital artefact, though they may not own the rights to it. Crucially NFTs can also be configured so that the original artist automatically retains a percentage of any future sales. NFTs have been around for some time, but their popularity has soared, coinciding with the pandemic. NFTs remain controversial as not everyone believes that the NFT has any intrinsic value next to a physical piece of art. The market is also unregulated - one collector was recently tricked into paying $336,000 for a fake Banksy NFT - the hacker later returned the money, less a transaction fee. &%23160;However NFTs are seen as valuable and collectable by some&%2358; a British 12 year old recently created a series of NFTs called Weird Whales, pocketing £290,000 in the process. Other platforms are emerging with elements of NFTs and blockchain technology behind them, from which it’s possible to earn a living. One such gaming platform is Axie Infinity&%2358; an online, blockchain-based game where players can earn tokens and cash out in local currency. The game involves cultivating in-game creatures called Axies, which can be battled or sold at a profit to other players. The game is popular in the developing World. One player in the Philippines claims to earn $2000 a month from an hour’s play per day. Some teams receive sponsorship from wealthy patrons in the form of an entry stake, looking to profit further down the line. Virtual currencies are also gaining more mainstream interest. The UK Government is launching a consultation on a potential central bank digital currency (CBDC) next year, assessing the case for digital pound and whether to run a development phase. A recent survey of finance industry executives also revealed that the majority of respondents expect digital assets to serve as a strong alternative, or a replacement of fiat currencies within the next five to ten years. Hand in hand with increased interest in the potential of distributed ledgers and blockchain is the environmental impacts, particularly around energy use. China’s recent ban on currency mining has led to many Chinese miners relocating to Kazakhstan, leading to an eight per cent increase in annual energy demand, compared to a normal level of one to two per cent. America is also experiencing an influx of cryptocurrency miners, interested in establishing in old industrial facilities such as former aluminium plants, which already have the infrastructure installed to handle large electricity demands. Activists are concerned that the heat generated from a hydropower plant serving crypto mining in upstate New York is warming a nearby lake. Both the energy and hardware demands of cryptomining are significant, with one recent study equating a single BitCoin transaction generating as much electronic waste as two iPhone 12s. With many potential benefits from digital currencies, and interest from central government, the Environment Agency and partners may have a role in advocating the environmental and resource impacts of these technologies, as well as being mindful of the potential impacts they could bring to energy infrastructure and waste management.
Primary Article Title: Workers in the Global South are making a living playing the blockchain game Axie Infinity

Summary Sentence: Experiments involving ‘microflyers’ made novel materials may provide ways in which environmental monitoring equipment could be deployed to the mesosphere.
Justification: This may be of interest to the Environment Agency’s research interests in earth observation and monitoring. The mesosphere is between 31 and 53 miles above the Earth. The combination of thin air, yet close proximity to Earth make it unsuitable for deploying either satellites or flying aircraft and balloons. &%23160;Scientists have simulated the mesosphere in experiments in order to test out microflyers which employ a novel method for achieving lift. The microflyers consist of six millimetre wide disk with a top layer of mylar and a bottom layer of a very thin layer of carbon nanotubes. When exposed to bright light the disc heats up. When a molecule in the air comes into contact with it, the disk transfers some of its warmth, making the molecule move faster and push back on the disk. The disks heat up when they are exposed to bright light. Then, when individual air molecules bounce off of a disk, the disk transfers some of its warmth to the molecule, which makes the molecule move a little bit faster. By Newton’s Third Law, which states that every action has an equal and opposite reaction, the air molecule pushes back on the disk, too. Carbon nanotube are comparatively better than mylar at transferring energy in this way, leading to an imbalance in force which translates into upward movement. This experiment has provided sufficient data to calculate that a two inch disk could carry ten milligrams worth of payload, enough to carry small sensing equipment. Further development is needed to ensure the disks are robust enough to endure the harsh conditions of the mesosphere. However their existence creates the prospect of deploying multiple disks to provide new insight on atmospheric processes and potential new approaches to monitoring in harsh environments such as on Mars. Separate research recently suggested that the Earth’s auroras may be contributing to mesospheric ozone layer depletion, a process which has implications for climate change. Microflyers may therefore provide a timely innovation for investigating this and other environmental phenomena.
Primary Article Title: New microflyers could soar in the Atmosphere’s most mysterious layer
Author: Machemer, T

Summary Sentence: Scientists have calculated that two asteroids in Earth’s vicinity could contain around $11.65 trillion &%23160;in precious metals - more iron, nickel and cobalt than the Earth’s entire reserves.
Justification: Interest in space mining has relevance for the Environment Agency and partners as it could suggest a way to minimise terrestrial environmental damage from resource extraction. However also of consideration are the environmental and atmospheric impacts of developing an extra-terrestrial extraction industry. The two asteroids of interest measure over a mile wide and resemble a large asteroid of interest called 16 Psyche, thought to contain the equivalent of $10,000 quadrillion in metals and minerals, but are closer to Earth. Space mining has been considered previously (%2314827, %2314734, %2312991) in terms of economic viability and potential for environmental damage, ranging from atmospheric damage and debris, to the introduction of harmful substances. And while the certainty of the presence of high value minerals on the asteroids is being challenged, such potential riches could further lead to asteroid mining becoming realised.
Primary Article Title: Rare asteroids near Earth may contain precious metals worth $11.65 trillion

Summary Sentence: Two new developments in recycling suggest progress towards electric vehicle recycling processes and a circular economy.
Justification: Both processes should be of interest to the Environment Agency from a waste management and regulation perspective. Japanese vehicle manufacturers Nissan have co-developed a process to recover 98 per cent of rare earth elements (REEs) from electric vehicle motors at end of life. Instead of going down a disassembly route the motor is made molten a mixture of iron oxide that oxidises the REEs. Adding a borate-based flux dissolves the oxidized REEs, which rise to the top of the molten mixture for where they can be easily separated. &%23160;The process is 50 per cent quicker than dismantling, and Nissan are looking to establish a larger text facility. A company in Sweden has announced that it has recycled a lithium-ion battery cell containing a nickel-manganese-cobalt (NMC) cathode, using only metals recovered via battery waste, making it the first company to recycle a battery with 100 per cent recycled materials. The process recovers materials at a purity level comparable to virgin materials. Cobalt, manganese, and nickel were recovered from battery waste using a low-energy hydrometallurgical treatment which uses an aqueous solution to isolate the metals and remove impurities.
Primary Article Title: A Swedish firm has created the World's first fully-recycled EV battery

Summary Sentence: A team of academics are working to field demonstrate a tractor powered by ammonia.&%23160;
Justification: Ammonia is a substance of interest for the Environment Agency as a pollutant from agricultural installations and also as a constituent of fertiliser. Rather than using ammonia as an energy carrier for hydrogen extraction, Project ACTIVATE is looking to use ammonia in combination with biodiesel directly as a fuel in a combustion engine powered tractor. The aim is to reduce the carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from the farming sector through retrofitting existing compression ignition engines for liquified ammonia combustion, sourcing ammonia from both green sources. The close association with fertiliser also means that the farming sector already has the infrastructure closely aligned to ammonia distribution. Previous research has also suggested that decentralised ammonia production could occur at farm level, providing localised fuel and fertiliser production. It is unclear however what the impact of nitrate based emissions from farm vehicles could be if scaled, and how that could add to existing nutrient related issues such as water pollution, which the Environment Agency may wish to consider.
Primary Article Title: Project ACTIVATE&%2358; ammonia combustion engine R&D
Author: Atchison, J
Keywords: regulation farming agriculture energy ammonia tractor vehicle emission "carbon dioxide" CO2 pollution nitrate fertiliser pollutant water biodiesel "Project ACTIVATE" chemistry chemical

Summary Sentence: Experiments involving starving bacteria are suggesting potential new approaches for tackling metal contamination in the environment.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this research for applications in contaminated land and potential deployment for mitigation in incident management. Extremophiles are organisms known to survive in extreme environments. Experiments with bacteria extracted from high altitude geysers in Chile suggest that starving microorganisms forces them to adapt and seek new sources of nutrition. In test tube experiments over two years the time taken for the bacteria to consume a nail has gone from two months to just three days. The resulting &%23160;lixiviant liquid shows form as a substance for further copper recovery from rock in a more environmentally friendly way than current chemical leaching techniques. For this reason mining companies have shown interest in the research. However the potential applications in remediation could mean that environmental regulators also show interest in the process reaching commercial realisation. &%23160;
Primary Article Title: Chilean scientist plans to clean up mining with 'metal eating' bacteria
Author: Bustamante, P
Keywords: regulation mineral metal mining mine bacteria microorganism microbe extremophile geyser starve experiment iron copper incident land contamination remediation chemical chemistry biochemistry&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A new treatment process can turn clay soil contaminated with PFAS chemicals into clean bricks suitable for construction.
Justification: PFAS are a family of chemicals of signficant regulatory interest to the Environment Agency, which should therefore be interested in novel remedial techniques for dealing with persistent chemicals in the environment. The Netherlands previously introduced a ban to prevent building on land contaminated with PFAS. PFAS (Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) derive from cleaning products, fire-fighting foam, fast food packaging and other sources. They have been associated with health complications in fish, animals, drinking water, and humans, such as diseases and autoimmune dysfunctions. PFAS do not break down readily, earning them the label “forever chemicals”. The Netherlands has banned construction development on PFAS contaminated land, effectively reframing the environmental health crisis as a housing crisis. While there are some remediation practices such as washing contaminated sands, but turns land pollution into a water pollution issue. It’s also not suitable for clay. Heating the clay to a high temperature in a process known as Thermal Treatment burns of PFAS, leaving a dead soil. However this can easily be turned into ceramic products such as bricks for a localised market. The process is not at a commercial stage yet but the developers are looking to collaborate with industry to take it to market. The Environment Agency may wish to consider any additional regulatory processes needed for PFAS thermal treatment activities. It may also wish to consider if PFAS clean bricks could be incorporated into its own construction and asset management activities as a way to reduce their environmental impacts.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: No Waste Challenge winner, Packing Up PFAS creates clean bricks from polluted clay
Author: Bensdorp, E
Keywords: regulation construction pollution pollutant chemical chemistry PFAS "Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances" clay land Netherland Holland brick "Thermal Treatment" water sand clay health&%23160;disease&%23160;&%23160;"autoimmune dysfunction" wildlife

Summary Sentence: A dual purpose light installation in the Netherlands is creating a striking visual landscape while simultaneously boosting crop yield.
Justification: The Environment Agency may be interested in the principles behind this project as it can reduce pesticide applications. The installation, called Grow, is located in a 215,000 square feet Dutch leek field. It consists of twinkling red and blue ultraviolet lights. The UV light is tuned so that it provokes the leeks’ defence system, reducing the need for chemical pesticides, and therefore providing the potential to limit pollution. It should also be mindful that recent research elsewhere (%2315119) has demonstrated that LED lights could be having a negative impact on insect behaviour, which could also potentially affect pollination, however no such impacts have been reported from the Grow project. The project was designed by Studio Roosegaarde in conjunction with Wageningen University and BioLumic, a New Zealand-based agricultural technology&%23160;start-up that harnesses the power of UV to enhance crop yield. Further success could see such a project move from art into commercial realisation, providing both the economics and environmental benefits outweigh conventional agricultural pest control.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: This stunning light installation could make agriculture more sustainable
Author: Brandon, E.M

Summary Sentence: Changing to posthumanism approach can help in technology designs and problem solving by making people see and think differently.
Justification: Shifting relationships are required to move human and Anthropocene era from the centre of focus towards posthuman design and non-human stakeholders in decision making and design technologies. “More than human perspective” could be utilised in human-computer interaction to create visions of what could be when posthuman concept is put into practice. Currently, technological innovations concentrate around human needs which automatically come at an ecological cost whereas to shape future for a more sustainable way of life it is necessary for researchers to us consider developing systems that influence users to sustainability. Posthuman approach makes researchers and designers rethink their relationship and to train themselves to notice things differently. It uses concepts such as “natural culture,“ ”companion species,“ and ”notice different“ when attempting HCI practice but bringing theory to operation is challenging. In this case study, a PhD student used autoethnography as a research method which led to abjection; her experiencing kinship with non-human species.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Treating Non-Humans As Stakeholders Key To Sustainable Technologies

Summary Sentence: The chair of the UK Hydrogen & Fuel Cell Association (UK HFCA) has resigned over controversy around the environmental impacts of blue hydrogen.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency works in the regulatory space that technologies such as blue hydrogen occupy, and therefore should be interested in the changing nature of nascent energy technologies. &%23160;Blue hydrogen is formed through extraction from methane gas. It produces carbon dioxide as a by-product, and so therefore depends on carbon capture and storage to a low impact energy. Chris Jackson, who is also the CEO a green hydrogen and fuel cell project developer Protium Green Solutions, stood down over what is reported to be his inability to support blue hydrogen due to its dependence on fossil fuels, namely gas, as a feedstock. Jackson states that reliance on blue hydrogen delays meeting decarbonisation goals. There is also some CO2 leakage of around five per cent associated with blue hydrogen, compared to green hydrogen produced from renewably powered electrolysis which produces zero CO2 during production. Jackson also acknowledges green hydrogen isn’t a ‘silver bullet’ and that other energy pathways are needed. Jackson has also claimed that oil companies have made false claims to the government over the true costs of blue hydrogen production, which if true, would mean that the subsidies currently being offered by the Treasury would be unnecessary in order to be profitable in a relatively short timescale. &%23160;Commentary on the Government’s hydrogen strategy elsewhere highlight that the estimated future costs of production are notably dissimilar to estimates from the EU and the USA. Green hydrogen is seen as becoming more expensive to produce than blue hydrogen, whereas the reverse is seen elsewhere. The commentator also notes that even if the UK’s estimates of green hydrogen prices do come to pass then it would make economic sense to import hydrogen gas from elsewhere, rather than build production in the UK. Moving the focus away from hydrogen the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) recently published new estimates of levelised costs of electricity (LCOE), which are the average cost of electricity, per megawatt hour (MWh) generated, across the lifetime of a new power plant. The estimated costs of solar and wind in particular have fallen dramatically since the last published estimates. In 2013, offshore wind was estimated to generate electricity for £140/MWh by 2025. A 2016 revision brought this down by 24%, to £107/MWh. The latest estimate puts the cost at just £57/MWh, another 47% reduction. Similar trajectories are reported for onshore wind and solar, with levelised costs in 2025 now thought to be some 50% lower than expected by the 2013 government report. There is the possibility that costs may follow the same trajectory, becoming even cheaper by 2025, well below the estimated costs for both green and blue hydrogen. This uncertainty over economic viability and environmental impacts may in turn impact on the Environment Agency’s strategic planning for regulatory activities. Further investigation of these may therefore be required to ensure more resilient forward planning. There is also reputational risk if the Environment Agency is perceived to be supporting activities which are more expensive and damaging than cleaner alternatives.
Primary Article Title: 'Betraying future generations'&%2358; chair of UK hydrogen group quits over blue H2 support

Summary Sentence: There are signs that DNA based evidence could become more prevalent in environmental prosecution.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency is already researching using eDNA as a biological monitoring technique for water quality sampling, and therefore may be interested in considering wider applications of this technology for other operational areas, including enforcement. Tree DNA has recently been used for the first time in conjunction with federal crime proceedings in the USA. DNA analysis of lumber sold to a sawmill in Washington state proved that it matched the stumps of three bigleaf maple trees that were discovered to have been illegally logged from protected national forest. Ultimately the accused persons were being charged with illegally starting a forest fire, rather than illegal logging - the jury found them not guilty. Having failed to tackle the issue of dog fouling with increasing fines the city council in Tel Aviv, Israel, has approved setting up a DNA database for pet dogs. Owners will be obliged to submit DNA samples of their pets when they renew their dog owner’s licence (guide dogs and animal protection agencies are exempt). The data will be used in conjunction with prosecuting owners not clearing up their dog’s poo. Operatives will test DNA in the streets, sending fines to owners automatically (it’s not clear if the testing itself takes place in the street or in a laboratory). Technologies have, and are being, developed that would allow for DNA testing and identification to happen in the field without the need for laboratory analysis (%2313489, %2312709, %2312535), suggesting that DNA sampling and processing could become an increasingly important tool for environmental enforcement, the applications of which the Environment Agency may wish to consider.
Primary Article Title: Tel Aviv will test dog poop DNA to fine owners who don’t clean up

Summary Sentence: Protein production from methane fed bacteria
Justification: Producing protein from bacteria fed methane has now moved from concept to production. The biotechnology firm Calysta are using a bioreactor to ferment methane, nitrogen and oxygen, which is then consumed by the bacteria Methylococcus capsulatus. The bacteria produce a single cell protein that Calysta process into a fish food pellet with the trade name FeedKind. The firm has a test facility in the UK and has now commissioned a commercial scale unit in China. The new protein source has had successful nutritional trials. It has the potential to reduce pressures on wild fish as it reduces the demand on them for fishmeal and also on water demand and land as it displaces the need for soya. Further trials are also exploring the feasibility of using the protein in pet food. The development has global implications for food security, with direct implications for the Environment Agency in regulating the industrial process if it is developed in the UK.
Primary Article Title: Trial shows Calysta’s FeedKind can replace 30 percent of fishmeal in yellowtail feed

Summary Sentence: Putting evidence at the heart of environmental decision making &%23160;may become more difficult due to transfer of knowledge from physical to digital mediums.&%23160;
Justification: This has implications for all evidence based organisations, including the Environment Agency. &%23160;A recent article from the Atlantic illustrates how moving to digital media has led to knowledge being left to rot in a way that it wouldn't in a physical media world. This is due to a combined effect of the plummeting costs of digital and 'link rot' across the web. One study found that 75% of academic reference URLs no longer work. Information can be deleted and changed, even after it has been published, without a reference copy to verify the content. At the same time, artificial intelligence (AI) generated language is leading to rapidly increasing volumes of ‘tortured language’, citations of non-existent literature and ad hoc, uncredited image reuse in previously respectable scientific literature. There are also some suggestions that AI is even being used to formulate core theorems and data. Despite it not being seen as an academically robust source of information a new study suggests that content from Wikipedia is shaping the language that researchers are using in their outputs. A study showed that words and phrases in recently published Wikipedia articles subsequently appeared more frequently in scientific papers. However there is some debate that this phenomena may also reflect academics using Wikipedia as a way to standardise their language when writing papers. Another recent study based on German citizens has attempted to gauge public ability to assess the trustworthiness of digital media. It found that people often find it difficult to distinguish between different forms of communication, i.e between advertising, information, disinformation, and opinion. While trustworthiness was reasonably easy to identify, people were less likely to recognise, nor articulate conflicts of interest, such as an airport operator extolling the merits of flying. Efforts from social media to label disinformation were not found to be effective, and many people believed that journalism works in partnership with politics to manipulate public opinion. Competency in differentiating between trustworthy and non-trustworthy sources was found to be closely linked to younger age groups, education level but also democratic attitudes, with more &%23160;progressive political beliefs linked to higher levels of media literacy. Better education and greater transparency from media outlets, including social media is recommended as means to rectify this issue. All of the above examples highlight challenges that technology brings to both providing evidence and provoking decision making and action. &%23160;Maintaining access to impartial, verifiable and durable evidence may become increasingly challenging and costly as digital prevails. The ability to spread misinformation, particularly among harder to reach sections of the public may also prove challenging for evidence based institutions. Transformation to digital information may therefore require more, rather than less investment in management and education to fully embrace the benefits of frictionless distribution and use.
Primary Article Title: The Internet is rotting
Author: Zittrain. J
Secondary_URLs:

Summary Sentence: UK based firm aims to start selling solar film by 2022
Justification: The UK based company Power Roll has developed a thin solar film that could drastically increase the amount of suitable sites for energy generation. Currently only around 4% of UK energy consumption is supplied by solar power. A fraction of the weight of traditional solar panels which are often too heavy for roofs, this technology could mean more businesses could use existing sites to generate their own electricity. If compatible in more industrial settings, this could free up land being targeted for large solar arrays for other purposes. The Environment Agency will be interested in this new technology and the potential to support their Net Zero goals, however, as a waste regulator they will need to be mindful of the end of life treatment for this product. It is not clear what the film is made of and if it can be sustainably produced. It would be useful to understand how it can be removed from infrastructure at the end of its life in order to reduce the risk of future pollution.
Primary Article Title: Wafer-thin solar film could be a game-changer for harnessing British sunshine as renewable power
Author: Bawden, T

Summary Sentence: The discovery of an environmentally self-degradable plastic can eventually reduce the pressure to the environment from plastics waste.&%23160;
Justification:
Researchers in China developed a novel type of plastic that is biodegradable and completely decomposes when exposed to air and sunlight in a week, without leaving any microplastics in the environment. This is of interest to Environment Agency because the discovery of an environmentally self-degradable conjugated polymer that can be used in flexible electronics and smart devices can eventually reduce the pressure to the environment from plastics waste. The novel sun-sensitive material remains stable and could be used for years when kept in the dark and with no oxygen, making it suitable for inside electronic devices or smartphones, where it would be isolated from light and oxygen throughout its service life.&%23160;Although this makes it not suitable to be utilised in plastic bottles or bags, if a small quantity of the polymer was used as an ingredient in the manufacturing process, they would degrade faster when disposed of in landfills. Afterwards, it can be exposed to the elements, biodegrading rapidly through photo-oxidation, leaving behind mainly nontoxic succinic acid. This by-product would not leave any microplastic fragments in the environment and it could also be reused commercially in the pharmaceutical and food sectors.&%23160;
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Novel plastic disintegrates in a week in sunlight and oxygen

Summary Sentence: Mass retrofitting of residential housing in urban areas could help with greenhouse gas emissions and to reduce energy costs and carbon footprint.
Justification: Cheap method for transformation of urban residential buildings is to create tailor made thermally insulated covering to be fitted into place, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and energy loss with this retrofitting technology. Normally a lot of the energy used for heating buildings is wasted or in summertime the temperatures indoors could become too high, impacting human health and wellbeing, for instance in energy-inefficient council housing. This technology utilising highly insulating material is suitable for terraced housing or blocks of flats, wrapping them in custom made manufactured wraps of principally fire-resistant expanded polystyrene that has hollow structure to trap air as an insulating layer. This solution can provide long-term environmental benefits but only if they are mass produced to push the prices lower, after successful pilots in the Netherlands and the United States where it is estimated that a large scale overhaul could reduce long-term energy use by as much as 80 per cent. The remaining 20 per cent need for energy could be met with solar power, and ideally the usage of solar panels could enable house owners sell their excess to the national grid during the hot summer periods.

Summary Sentence: Half a million indigenous trees will be planted in Madrid to form an urban forest to mitigate climate change.
Justification: such as the plan for Madrid’s urban forest of half a million indigenous trees. This is of interest to Environment Agency with the increasing evidence of the need for habitat corridors in England and interest in the concept of rewilding. Madrid’s urban forest is meant to become a low maintenance sustainable solution to mitigate climate change and adapt to cope with the urban “heat island” effect, capture emissions from urban pollution and lifestyle and to improve the air quality in the city. It is noteworthy that they have decided to use indigenous tree species, and emphasis is also on creation of habitat corridors by connecting existing forest areas around Madrid and utilising derelict urban areas and spaced between roads. Madrid building a 'green wall' is a key step not just reducing carbon but in education people about the change towards sustainable living and reduced carbon footprint, to embrace new greener culture alongside restricting traffic and promoting pedestrianisation and cycling. Nature-centric Singapore is planning to use nature-based solutions to enhance urban ecosystem services and to make them more sustainable, with plans for “Forest Town”.

Summary Sentence: Sponge material for pavements mitigates flash floods and helps water being absorbed into the ground.
Justification: As urban areas have been expanded and green areas reduced, there is nowhere for the runoff to go from pavements and roofs but transforming cities with this novel alternative material could be a cost-effective way to combat flooding. Converting the material of urban pavements and car parks could mitigate the rainfall and flash flooding impacts due to the new innovative material that is porous enough to let the rainwater through into the ground but keeps pollutants out. Adding more green space in urban settings is not always realistic and therefore the improved alternative materials such as provided by AquiPor, a new urban stormwater systems solution, can mitigate the impacts of flash flooding cheaply in urban areas. Permeable pavement materials are not a novel concept, but the previous porous materials had not solved the challenge of filtering out pollution the way AquiPor does. Nevertheless, the amount of water running off from pavements increases during heavy downpours and storms and the intensity and frequency of these rainstorm events has increased because of climate change. Recently, one of the Chinese “sponge cities”, where their infrastructure had been retrofitted, could not cope with the heavy rain as the volume of stormwater was above the capability of what Zhengzhou's drainage system could handle. Stormwater could be viewed as an asset in a geographical location that has drought-floods cycles such as Los Angeles and ensuring it goes into the ground rather than flows into drain system and to the ocean.
Primary Article Title: Can ‘sponge’ pavement save us from urban flash floods?

Summary Sentence: New research suggests that covering canals with solar panels could help to conserve water resources, save valuable land and generate renewable energy.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this idea as a means to preserve water resources in the face of increasing temperatures. &%23160;It’s also been previously recognised that tree planting by rivers can reduce evaporation rates from rivers. Canals are man made channels, therefore it is interesting to apply a man made approach to addressing similar challenges. Canals are important for irrigation in many areas of the World. California relies on 4,000 miles of canals for drinking water and agricultural uses. Researchers have calculated that suspending solar panels above these canals could save 63 billion gallons of water annually, as well as making considerable land savings from not using it for solar farms. Not only does the canal provide space for solar panels it also acts as a cooling mechanism, allowing the solar panels to operate efficiently. A similar solar canal scheme in Gujarat, India has produced favourable results and encouraged other states to commission similar projects. The UK’s canal network could be utilised in a similar fashion, however with much of this network currently used for leisure and tourism there may be potential conflicts associated with deployment without full considerations. The Environment Agency is also&%23160; responsible for some canal based assets, and therefore may be in a position to realise the potential of this idea.
Primary Article Title: Solar panels and water canals could form a real power couple in California
