Summary Sentence: Gamification as a tool to reduce energy consumption and emissions.
Justification: CUBE is a new competition that has been set up as a way to reduce energy use in buildings to help achieve net zero targets. Behavioural insights have been incorporated into a game that rewards players for reducing their energy consumption. It is applicable to commercial buildings in both the private and public sector, and has achieved reductions in energy use averaging 12% in the first year alone and in some cases as much as 55%. A competition is due to launch later this year for the UK. This new development in gamification highlights the pain free behavioural change that can be achieved and may be something the Environment Agency could explore to achieve their own challenging net zero targets.
Primary Article Title: New competition to deliver significant energy savings in commercial buildings
Keywords: Gamification energy “climate change” waste pollution climate “net zero” efficiency behaviour behavioural competition

Summary Sentence: Consumer trends galvanised and increasingly habitualised by the coronavirus pandemic may have the effect of reshaping city life away from currently desirable models of urban sustainability.&%23160;
Justification: These changes could be of interest to the Environment Agency, which considers itself a placemaker with a placed based agenda, and may also provide it with opportunities to partner on certain activities. Many planners are increasingly interested in Carlos Moreno’s concept of the 15 minute city, where cities are designed so that urban residents are able to meet most of their needs within a 15 minute walk or bicycle ride from their homes. Post Covid-19 pandemic the concept is accelerating consideration of the 15 minute city concept, with cities including Paris and Portland, USA taking steps to introduce the concept through new trees and cycleways, community facilities and social housing, homes and workplaces. Key to developing this is to introduce areas of mixed use, rather than ‘mono-activity’—a single commercial activity occupying a whole street. &%23160;Space and time are key to defining the ‘radius ’ of the 15 minute city, which could be anything from three quarters of a mile (walking) to three miles (bicycle), which in turn defines the potential urban density and area of such a community. Crucially however transport networks favour pedestrians, cyclists and e-cyclists rather than private combustion engine vehicles. One of the consequences of pandemic lockdown was a move away from physical high street presence to virtual business models for many goods and services, who in turn relied upon third party logistics services to connect to customers. UK examples of these services include Deliveroo, Just Eat and Uber Eats, where orders of takeaway food and groceries are collected and delivered locally, often by couriers on bicycles and e-cycles, but also motorised vehicles. These are examples of ‘Q-commerce’, (‘Q’ for ‘quick’), seen as the next evolution of online retail, where groceries and other items are available in minutes via a network of locally operating couriers. Speed plays into the human desire for instant gratification&%2358; a focus on customer satisfaction and economic competition could mean that such services question the viability of the recognised 15 minute city model, and produce a very different one. For example ‘cloud kitchens’ (commercial kitchens without an expensive high street presence) have increased in prominence during the pandemic, many of which are turning to autonomous cooking processes to speed up fulfillment. ‘Dark stores’ or ‘D-marts’ are also appearing with similar business models for groceries and other household items. The desire for speed and convenience threatens the viability of local physical businesses and jobs. The proposed infrastructure of the 15 minute city actually facilitates Q-commerce models rather than discourages them. However there are currently some signs that the business models underpinning food delivery are economically unsustainable in the long run. Less social visibility may also encourage certain criminal activities to flourish in ways that make it difficult for authorities to monitor and act. Neither are ‘fast-cities’ conducive to building neighbourhoods and communities - places indeed, hence the ‘Slow Cities’ movement. There are some suggestions that taxation, business rates could encourage a hybrid model where virtual and physical businesses operate together, but there is also a question of personal choice. Some also see potential utility in delivery drivers being trained to spot crimes for example. There may also be environmental monitoring opportunities from engaging in educating delivery services in spotting environmental crimes too.&%23160;The Environment Agency and partners may need to be mindful of all the direct and indirect forces shaping the urban agenda to ensure that future planning decisions create sustainably liveable spaces for all.
Primary Article Title: The instant city&%2358; how the desire for speedy gratification is reshaping our urban lives

Summary Sentence: Researchers find a new quality of water that could impact all water related process such as water purification.
Justification: Interdisciplinary collaboration between two researchers, a chemist Alexander Benderskii and an electrical engineer Stephen Cronin, at the University of Southern California led to an unexpected revelation of how water collectively responds to a current. The research could well be ground-breaking because it can influence all water related processes, predominantly water purification for clean drinking water. When water is in contact with an electrode surface, all the molecules do not react in a similar manner but the top layer of water molecules located nearest to the electrode respond in a different way to the rest of the water molecules. This can have remarkable implications on how various substances dissolve in water and enable scientists with technology to have desalinated water more efficiently than before.
Primary Article Title: What is known about water may have just changed dramatically

Summary Sentence: Recovery of recyclable natural resources plays a role in a society promoting circular economy and more sustainable processes.
Justification: There are several new technologies paving the way for a more sustainable use and reuse of resources as the amount of valuable materials that end up as waste must be reduced. Recovery and reuse of recyclable natural resources can also reduce the adverse impacts of waste to human health and environment. As disposable nappies manufactured in the 1960s are still sitting in landfills, and are likely to be there for 500 years, a new project has produced a sustainable alternative to the current cloth and disposable nappies by using citrus agricultural waste, a process that is cheaper and uses considerably less water than typical nappy manufacturing process. &%23160;To save citrus waste from landfills in California, researchers used it to grow bacterial cellulose that is highly absorbent and then permeated them with mushroom spores which enables composting in only a year’s time. Likewise, shells of a common tropical fruit tamarind normally end up in landfills as an agricultural waste. However, they can be processed to make perfectly functioning carbon nanosheets for electricity storage as the porosity of the shells increases the area of carbon in the nanosheets which means they can store more electricity within supercapacitors. Supercapacitors are used to store energy in cars, electric vehicles, trains, and lifts. These nanosheets not only cut waste but offer an eco-friendly alternative that performs as well as industrially made nanosheets. For fans of Italian design, “in synergy with nature”, it is possible to purchase a table lamp 3-D printed from the skin of oranges from Sicily, giving a soothing scent of oranges. Scientists in Singapore used poultry wastewater for microalgae production, to cultivate algae for animal feed production.
Primary Article Title: Can Orange Peels Make Diapers Green?
Author: Gonzalez, S., Nieberding-Swanberg, J., Wang, A., Xu, J.

Summary Sentence: Light pollution impacts predator and pollination behaviours due to complex effects on animal vision.
Justification: This new study from University of Exeter indicates how light pollution from artificial lighting sources such as LED streetlights, and particularly Phosphor Converted (PC) amber LED lighting, can have complex and unpredictable effects on ecology for instance impacts on animal vision. The article highlights how artificial lighting can affect visual ecology, especially colour perception, in comparison to natural light, as the scientists studied over 20 different types of artificial lighting for their impacts on the vision of moths, and birds, their predators. The researchers concentrated in using the eyed hawkmoth (Smerinthus ocellata) colour vision as a case study because hawkmoths have an essential role as nocturnal pollinators, therefore impacting agriculture. This study is relevant to our work as moths are equally important pollinators as bees and their numbers have been in decline for decades, which has been increasingly linked to the increased light pollution, especially for the nocturnal moth species. These impacts on hawkmoth visual ecology suggest a need for a more nuanced approach of artificial lightning limiting the amount and intensity of light at least in environmentally sensitive areas.
Primary Article Title: Light pollution has complex effects on animal vision
Author: University of Exeter

Summary Sentence: Targeted dream incubation is a method to manipulate person’s behaviour via dreams.
Justification:
Targeted dream implantation (TDI) received wider attention with the Coors Big Game Dream, a marketing campaign by Molson Coors Beverage Company just before Super Bowl LV. Other brands including Microsoft, Sony, Burger King, and various airlines have also shown interest in this new type of advertising for manipulating your dreams when you are asleep and therefore more vulnerable to suggestions. Molson Coors, the big beer corporation with mountains and waterfalls on their logo, collaborated with a Harvard researcher to create a curated soundscape with mountains, waterfalls, and Coors beer, to play for eight hours whilst participants were asleep. Many of them woke up fancying a cold refreshing Coors beer. This advertising campaign titled %23CoorsBigGameDream alarmed scientists to the extent that 40 sleep scientists and dream researchers from 11 countries wrote a letter warning government of marketing and advertising manipulating people’s dreams, an area with no regulations or legislation. Advertising tactic could pose a threat as intrusive dream advertising can change behaviours and outcomes in the real world, and the potential for misuse is enormous, even weaponizing dreams, while people are in a susceptible dream state.&%23160;
USA Federal Trade Commission limits hidden advertising such as flashing of words or images during television programmes but there is no similar restriction against interfering with consumers’ dreams.
The relevance to us is the potential positive use of this type of technology, for instance, according to an experiment from 2014, smokers were able to reduce smoking cigarettes by 30 per cent, and perhaps we could use dream incubation technology to make people more sustainable and environmentally-friendly in their behaviours.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Advertisers could come for your dreams, researchers warn

Summary Sentence:
The volume of cyber attacks is continuing to rise, disrupting critical infrastructures and industries.&%23160;
&%23160;
Justification: &%23160;The World has seen an increase in cyberattack, such as ransomware over the past couple of years. One reason given for this is that the increase in home working due to the coronavirus pandemic has created weaknesses in many corporate IT systems. At the same time an increasingly sophisticated attacks have been able to exploit legacy systems. In March 2021 , brewing giant Molson Coors experienced a “system outage” originating from a “cybersecurity incident, believed to be a ransomware attack, which shut down many of its key systems including drinks production and delivery. In April a Dutch cheese logistics business ground to a halt when a ransomware attack led to distribution issues and shortages of cheese on shop shelves. In June 2021 JBS the World’s largest meat producer was impacted by a ransomware attack which took out operations in multiple countries and affected thousands of workers. it also impacted one fifth of US beef capacity.&%23160;A Russian based ransomware attack paralysed the networks of at least 200 US companies in July 2021, forcing users to shut down their servers. The attack was seemingly planned to coincide with a public holiday. While Governments tend to advise companies not to pay ransomware demands as it may encourage repeat attacks, bosses of the US Colonial Pipeline paid a $4.4M ransom to restore operations to the pipeline which supplies 45 per cent of East Coast diesel fuel. The Environment Agency may need to consider its position on ransomware attacks, particularly if they are timed to occur with major incidents, compromising our ability to respond. There is also the possibility that cyber attacks on operators could lead to significant civil disruption, and may also cause environmental harm through pollution incidents, for example. This may raise the question of whether some assurance of digital security could become part of conditions to operate and prevent environmental incidents and civil unrest.
Primary Article Title: Hundreds of US companies hit by 'devastating' ransomware attack, cyber experts say

Summary Sentence: Governments and corporations around the world are increasingly the subjects of litigation to reduce the impacts of climate change.&%23160;
Justification: Globally this number stands at around 1500 climate related lawsuits and is thought to likely increase. There is both ample evidence and a growing awareness of climate change becoming one of the most significant drivers of biodiversity loss. It may therefore follow that both evidence and awareness similarly lead biodiversity to the courts. Climate litigation has driven mitigation, as exemplified recently by action the Dutch government brought against a major oil company. Previously biodiversity litigation has focussed mainly on remedying pollution, remaining largely untested in addressing leading drivers of biodiversity loss. This presents an opportunity for conservation strategy to leverage liability litigation to better &%23160;address the actual drivers of biodiversity loss, such as illegal harvest, with the goal of making the injured parties ‘whole’ through e.g. species rehabilitation, public apologies, habitat conservation and education. The embryonic conservation lawsuit movement currently lacks specialist legal skills and knowledge needed. But this could change&%2358; a recently convened legal definition of ‘ecocide’ paves the way for it to become a new crime under international law. New frameworks could allow government agencies, individuals, NGOs and corporate plaintiffs, to more easily seek remedies for ecosystem harm. In parallel the financial sector is increasingly concerned with liability risks associated with biodiversity related losses. This all highlights how the courtroom may increasingly be an effective conservation tool, creating new avenues for justice and financial support.
Primary Article Title: Environmental liability litigation could remedy biodiversity loss
Author: Phelps, J; et al

Summary Sentence: Using nature based solutions to solve climate and nature emergencies in unison
Justification: Healthy biodiverse ecosystems help absorb carbon emissions. The concept of solving nature and climate problems at the same time is not novel, however action still seems to be lacking. Climate change and reducing emissions are now concepts familiar to many and often a large focus of corporates. Unfortunately the nature crisis and threats to biodiversity do not have the same level of attention and often get overlooked. Scientists are now calling for more dual action that focusses on solving both crises at the same time. They argue that without this joint effort, both problems will never be solved. Climate change solutions risk unintended negative consequences for nature unless the sustainable use of natural capital is considered. Nature based solutions if properly set up can help address both issues. As a trusted partner the Environment Agency would benefit society by sharing best practice on nature based solutions and encouraging other organisations to consider solutions that tackle both crises together.
Primary Article Title: Climate and nature crises&%2358; solve both or solve neither, say experts
Author: Carrington, D

Summary Sentence: France is in the process of approving legislation that will allow owners of internal combustion engine vehicles to trade them in for grants that allow them to buy electric bicycles.
Justification: &%23160;The measure which would award participants the equivalent of $2,975 (approx £2140) electric bike or folding bike grant to trade in their car vehicles for scrap. The measure is being passed as a part of climate change target strategy, and would make France the first country to introduce such a scheme if it passes the next stage of legislation. This is an interesting development in that it challenges the assumption that car sized electric vehicles are the natural successor to petrol and diesel cars, whereas this measure promotes both clean transport and health, through increased exercise and reduced air pollution. This development may also present a challenge to the assumptions on urban road design and use currently in formation. Elsewhere a new report suggests that electric&%23160;cargo bikes&%23160;deliver about 60% faster than vans in city centres, while cutting carbon emissions by 90 per cent &%23160;compared with diesel vans, and by a third compared with electric vans as well as reducing air pollution. This suggests further benefits from more widespread adoption of two wheeled travel for&%23160;urban transport solutions.
Primary Article Title: Trading clunkers for electric bikes&%2358; France moves to offer financial incentive
Secondary_URLs: Cargo bikes deliver faster and cleaner than vans, study finds | Road transport | The Guardian
Keywords: transport car "climate change" "greenhouse gas" emission vehicle France legislation scrap grant bicycle "e-bike" electric bike vehicle urban city planning health air pollution

Summary Sentence: Edible insects for human consumption now authorised by EU can potentially bring environmental and economic benefits.
Justification: European Union member states have approved the use of yellow mealworms, meaning the larvae of the beetle Tenebrio molitor, as the first insect forming a high protein novel food for human food, although not as high as meat, dairy or eggs but similar level to soya. The significance to Defra and Environment Agency is that edible insects provide a more environmentally friendly source of protein and thus will contribute to Farm to Fork strategy and as a part of the solution to climate change mitigation. Achieving authorisation for insects as human food can be regarded as a step towards cutting the emission of greenhouse gases in food production because insects require less feed to grow and produce less carbon dioxide and waste than other similar food sources. It is necessary to bear on mind that insects have been historically consumed as a source of protein around the world but in European Union they are regarded as a novel food that requires a change in legislation to assure consumers of the safety of eating insects, and for example assessing the risk of possible allergic reactions after consumption. The regulation of the edible insects farming may be under Environment Agency’s remit and regulatory responsibility as part of agriculture or animal products, and we can look forward to other insect-based foods, including certain cricket and locust types, and lesser mealworms.
Primary Article Title: Approval of first insect as Novel Food

Summary Sentence: A South Korean university toilet is crediting users digital currency in exchange for the energy derived from their poop.
Justification: &%23160;This experiment suggests novel ways to encourage behaviour change in thinking toward resources and circular economy principles, and therefore should be of interest to the Environment Agency. It also suggests that novel technologies like this may produce anaerobic digestion type facilities at scales below current regulatory thresholds. The toilet is called BeeVi - from the words ‘bee’ and ‘vision’. BeeVi uses a vacuum pump to transfer waste material from the toilet to an underground processing unit, where it is used to create methane gas to power stoves, boilers and fuel cells. An average 500g excrement&%23160;a day can produce 50 litres of methane gas, equivalent to &%23160;0.5kWh of electricity. Users are rewarded with a virtual currency devised specifically for BeeVi called Ggool (Korean for honey), which can be exchanged for goods and services around the University campus.
Primary Article Title: South Korean toilet turns excrement into power and digital currency
Author: Park, Minwoo
Keywords: waste energy fuel excrement poop South Korea toilet BeeVi Ggool "anerobic digestion" regulation University "digital currency" behaviour change resources nutrients methane "fuel cell" gas vaccuum

Summary Sentence: A Singapore based start-up has developed a milk substitute derived from microalgae.&%23160;
Justification: &%23160;The Environment Agency has a regulatory role in dairy farming and is also aware of land use pressures and changes required to meet Net Zero aspirations, and therefore should be interested in products offering resource efficient alternatives to conventional livestock. This is reportedly the World’s first algae based milk. It is manufactured through fermentation, using food waste such as spent beer grains as feedstock. The fermentation produces a water-soluble protein flour, which is nutritionally equivalent to cow’s milk, and superior to current plant-based milk alternatives, &%23160;but uses a fraction of the land and water. The flour can then be used to create milk substitutes and other dairy alternative products. The company, BioNutrients, believes their new product will be cheaper than cow’s milk or soy milk within 5-10 years, and that it is already cheaper to produce than newer dairy alternatives, like cellular lab-grown milk. A realisation of similar products could lead to significant changes in land use, bringing with it changes to pollution pressures on land and water from the farming sector.
Primary Article Title: In the race for planet-friendly milk, Singapore startup substitutes dairy with algae
Author: Hicks, R
Keywords: farming agriculture "land use" landuse regulation dairy livestock milk "water quality" pollution cow microalgae algae Singapore nutrient BioNutrients fermentation protein flour plant-based&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A US company has launched an app which summons a private security force at the user’s request.
Justification: The Citizen app was initially designed as a mapping tool, used as means for people to report crime incidents in their neighbourhood, which in turn sent out real time alerts to other users in the same area. In the latest version users are able to summon a private security force. One anonymous Citizen employee has described the company’s intentions to “create a privatized secondary emergency response network”. There are currently questions over the legality and jurisdiction of what a private security force is allowed to do, plus also concerns of a discrepancy in training next to trained police officers. There is also the potential for private security forces operating in this manner to further drive inequalities as security and law enforcement becomes distorted by market forces, serving those who can pay. At the same time “on demand” security services similar to this present a means for citizens to be able to take real time action in the face of crime or antisocial behaviour. Such services could either provide a challenge or a compliment to Environment Agency incident response activities, depending on approach, should services similar to Citizen become available in the UK. Such a service could also be open to abuse and fakery, tarnishing reputations and wasting resources.
Primary Article Title: Leaked emails show crime app Citizen is testing on-demand security force
Author: Cox, J
Keywords: communication telecommunication smartphone app Citizen privatisation inequality people security crime police legislation incident emergency USA&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Changing generational economic and environmental values may contribute to future declines on birthrates.
Justification: In the face of climate change impacts and environmental degradation, it’s reported that those in the ‘Generation Y’ or ‘Millennials’ cohort (those born roughly between 1981 and 1996) are choosing to “birthstrike”. The Birthstrike movement centres on the idea that people choose not to have children due to the perceived political inaction on climate change. Several criticisms have arisen from people taking this position&%2358; that not becoming parents won’t make a huge difference to reducing climate pressure; that there are more pressing systematic causes; that it absolves policy makers of responsibility. However the birthstrike movement sees itself more as a statement than a solution&%2358; many birthstrikers would wish to be parents but equally wish to highlight fault lines in climate change action and inertia. Some young people from Generation Z (considered to be born 1997 onwards) are making similar decisions on not starting a family. Research suggests that one in 10 childless 18- to 23-year-olds are considering not having children. Gen Z-ers are basing their choices on a raft of pressures including climate change, but also the coronavirus pandemic and general social anxiety are also referenced as drivers towards choosing not to have children. &%23160;However there is also a financial element at play&%2358; some are considering not parenting in order so that they can retire early or afford less work-orientated lifestyles. Childless by choice also has a regional perspective, with Londoners being more likely to not have children if it meant bringing forward retirement. While the scale of impact of these choices may not impact population trends on a global scale, it may have some localised impacts in terms of future service provision and housing planning, which in turn may also have indirect impacts on Environment Agency activities around water resources and flood management. It may also influence workplace demographics, particularly if less women take parental leave as tends to be the current norm.
Primary Article Title: ‘I had second thoughts’&%2358; the Gen Z-ers choosing not to have children

Summary Sentence: New wind turbine design could make urban wind energy a reality.
Justification: Bladeless wind turbines could make wind generation in urban areas more feasible. The designs are not meant to challenge traditional wind power generation, instead they are complimentary. They are much smaller in size and therefore can be sited in urban areas that are not suitable for large scale wind farms. As wind speeds are generally higher at night, they could be complementary to home solar, filling the gap in production at night. The turbines also have a number of other benefits such as a reduction in noise pollution, lower cost and lower environmental impact. As they are smaller they require fewer resources to produce, assemble and maintain. Being bladeless they also reduce the risk of bird strikes. This is another example of decarbonisation solutions emerging that have the potential to drive energy generation decentralisation. The Environment Agency will need to take a holistic systems based approach to assess the multiple different solutions and where they are best suited if they are to successfully regulate such technologies in the future.
Primary Article Title: Good vibrations&%2358; bladeless turbines could bring wind power to your home
Secondary_URLs: PowerPod, the safest, most powerful wind turbine designed for urban spaces

Summary Sentence: Credibility of carbon offsets called into question.
Justification: The benefits of nature based solutions to carbon emissions can be significant for both the environment and people by restoring habitat and creating jobs. However, an investigation by Greenpeace suggests that the accounting in these schemes is flawed, which risks companies overstating the carbon emissions they are removing from the atmosphere when they use them. Carbon offsets are used as a mechanism to offset the residual emissions that companies cannot currently eliminate. It is hoped that the need for these offsets will reduce as technology and reduction strategies further drive down emissions. Consumer awareness of the need to reduce emissions has rapidly increased during the pandemic. This has led to a surge in demand by businesses for offsets from the voluntary market. The complicated accounting methods, the need for additionality (proving these schemes would not have happened anyway) and permanence all add to the difficulty. As a result industry have launched the Taskforce on Scaling Voluntary Carbon Markets as a way to manage and certify the market. Unfortunately this too has faced criticism for being run by industry for industry. As the Environment Agency strive to meet their Net Zero commitment they will need to address the uncertainties and carefully assess the offsetting schemes they join to prevent the risk of being accused of greenwashing. It is clear that there can be significant environmental benefits from the conservation work achieved from funding carbon offset schemes, but careful management on emissions claims will be required.
Primary Article Title: Carbon offsets used by major airlines based on flawed system, warn experts.
Author: Greenfield, P
Secondary_URLs:
Businesses and experts reveal plans for carbon offset regulator

Summary Sentence: The United Kingdom could be heading towards devolved powers along regional as well as national lines.
Justification:
A recent poll of residents in Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic suggested that the majority see Northern Ireland separating from the United Kingdom within the next 25 years. When asked if they thought NI would be part of the UK in 25 years, 51% of people in NI and 54% in the Republic said NI would have left the UK. 56% of those surveyed in Northern Ireland want their assembly members (MLAs) to vote to stay within the EU Single Market when the matter is put to a vote at Stormont in three years' time. Only 38% indicated they wanted to leave the EU Single Market. All this is suggestive of a further fracturing of the UK on top of growing support for Independence in Scotland and Wales. There has also been a recent resurgence in interest for some degree of political autonomy for Cornwall. This ranges from more devolved powers to interest in becoming a sovereign state, but centrally is a perception that Westminster, urban based policies are not suited to the social, geographical and economical realities of the county. Experiences from the coronavirus pandemic, such as influxes of tourists attempting to escape to a relatively unimpacted area, plus increased interest in property forcing up prices are cited as helping to focus attention on greater autonomy for Cornwall. Cornish is already recognised as a national minority under the European Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities, and more people are identifying as ‘Cornish’ rather than ‘English’. Whereas full independence may seem less plausible, greater devolved powers for Cornwall could materialise with growing support. This also raises questions for similar calls for other regions in the UK, though which don’t have the same minority recognition. Yorkshire for example is comparable population-wise and economically with Scotland, and there is also growing interest for more devolved powers within the county. A politically fractured landscape could in turn manifest as a fractured regulatory landscape, which may present both opportunities for operators and challenges for regulators such as the Environment Agency due to the differences which may occur between borders, which seemingly have the potential to multiply beyond those currently envisaged with devolution of power at nation&%23160;level.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Why Cornish independence could be no joke
Author: Leigh-Hewitson, N

Summary Sentence: Increasing reproductive problems leading to infertility crisis are linked to the chemicals such as phthalates and bisphenols in our environment.
Justification: There’s a huge a body of evidence indicating that Endocrine Disrupting Chemicals (EDCs) are causing human fertility to decline and this fertility trend pervasive for all age group suggests the year 2045 as the median sperm count of zero which means that majority of people would not be able to reproduce naturally. Examining the impacts of hormone disrupting chemicals such as phthalates and bisphenols, especially Bisphenol A, is a cross-governmental issue where Environment Agency has an advisory role for the environmental perspective, contributing to Defra’s chemicals strategy. &%23160;Health and Safety Executive, Food Standards Agency, and Public Health England are involved on the reproductive health aspect, addressing the growing concern of microplastics and chemicals in plastics. Everyone is exposed to these chemicals and they accumulate so more research is needed into the environmental fate and a combined effect. The chemical industry should start producing chemicals that are non-hormonally active and hence safe for everyday use. However, there are huge economic interests preventing tougher regulation, and therefore for example in the United states most chemicals have not been tested but are simply assumed to be safe. In Europe they have the EU’s Reach (Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals) regulations and Environment Agency’s Chemical Assessment Unit is currently involved in the work for post EU Exit policy and regulation for the UK.

Summary Sentence: New method aims to help researchers track nanomaterials through the food chain.
Justification: The environmental and health implications of nanomaterials (NMs) have been speculated and reported on for a number of years. However, the research into the impact of NMs on organisms through the food chain is still relatively limited. A new method published in Nature Communications aims to help researchers trace the movement of NMs through the food chain so that they can better understand how this could influence the health of organisms. Different shapes and sizes of NMs can influence how they are absorbed and what impact they may have on receiving organisms. This makes it very difficult to understand how specific materials influence health, especially as they change in shape and size all the time both in the environment and once inside an organism. For example spherical NMs of the same substance may have a different effect to rod shape NMs. The findings of this research seem to suggest that NM’s can accumulate in the brain. Regulating NMs is difficult due to the fact that they cannot be measured in the traditional way by mass, as they have an effect at such small levels. From a consumer perspective, the authors also highlight that products may already contain NMs, but as it is in such small levels they are not listed in the ingredients list. This makes it impossible for consumers to avoid if they wished to. Recommendations include the importance of assessing the risk of NMs before they are used in large amounts commercially. As a regulator, there still seems to be a considerable level of uncertainty on the influence of NMs in the environment and how that may affect health, making it very difficult to ensure regulations are fit for purpose.
Primary Article Title: An invisible killer is lurking in our consumer products, warn scientists

Summary Sentence: Female farmers could help to inform environmentally friendly farming practices.
Justification: In many European countries an increasing number of women are moving to agricultural work, either as farmers or as farm managers; for example in France 30% of farmers, 25% of farm managers and 37% of new farmers are women, whereas according to Defra in 2016, only 15% of registered farm holders in the UK were women. Studies indicate that younger farmers and female farmers are keener on practising biodiversity-friendly farming management, and with the advances in agricultural technology, making muscular strength superseded, this is seen as the main driver of enabling more women get into farming. Therefore, the role of the women farmers could be utilised by Environment Agency in a move towards more environmentally friendly farming practices to protect biodiversity and in other rural development programmes. It is suggested by researchers that there is a need for improved communications and cooperation between scientists and farmers, and a platform is required to facilitate this type of open dialogue and discussion between researchers, policy makers and farmers. Women farmers could be at the lead of this type of sustainable farming discussions as it seems they are more open to experimenting to find best practice sustainability.
Primary Article Title: Women farmers ‘essential’ for future, says French agriculture minister

Summary Sentence: Balancing animal welfare and religious freedom can cause problems and have media interest even from fake news.
Justification: In March this year French religious leaders expressed their concerns when it was suggested that the Ministry of Agriculture had proposed a ban on the slaughter practices of poultry, effectively banning slaughter of ritualistic slaughter of chicken following religious practice. If the legislation in the United Kingdom eventually followed France Ministry of Agriculture example and decisions, there could be potential consequences for Environment Agency’s operational work as we support Food Standards Agency. The main approved method for slaughter for religious purposes, and the one practiced in the United Kingdom, Estonia, Slovakia, Finland, Denmark, and New Zealand, is slaughter without prior stunning authorised, but stunning imposed after bleeding. If the halal, meaning “permissible” in Arabic, slaughter is banned here, this could lead to illegal halal slaughtering as is already happening elsewhere in the world, for example the case from Finland with more than a thousand sheep illegally slaughtered for the purpose of providing halal meat for the growing demand. Environment Agency is responsible for monitoring odour and water issues from abattoirs even though they are mainly the responsibility of Food Standards Agency. If rituals related to slaughter were banned by law, there is likelihood of illegal slaughter carried out on sites for black markets, with no permits which could increase the risk of environmental pollution. Eventually the ministry reassured religious communities that the concern was unfounded and that the Islamic slaughter of poultry animals will not be banned in France from July 2021, as stated widely in the news. Quickly slitting the animal’s throat can be seen as a “less humane” method of slaughter, especially by the animal rights activists.

Summary Sentence: The changing light availability leading to coastal darkening can change phytoplankton composition which has widespread consequences for the ecosystem.
Justification: Scientists have researched the changing light availability in the seas such as Arctic Sea and North Sea, but the constant darkening of coastal areas is an environmental threat that has been overlooked and therefore more research is needed to understand the impacts and to consider potential solutions. The significance to Environment Agency is that the physical changes of clarity and water colour will lead to biological and chemical changes in marine ecosystems, such as timing for phytoplankton which forms the base of the food web and hence can have huge consequences to the whole marine ecosystem. Darkening has already caused a delay of three weeks to the phytoplankton blooms that fish require to spawn in North Sea. Any change in phytoplankton timing and composition has widespread consequences to the marine ecosystems such as favouring certain species over others, for instance fish, kelp, seagrass would suffer as they depend on sunlight but species such as jellyfish would gain a competitive advantage. They don’t rely on clarity of water and sight to feed but instead use their sense of touch which has already led to jellyfish blooms in some locations. Coastal darkening may also have a distinct chemical effect as there will be less sunlight to break down toxic contaminants such as the chemical methyl mercury which then has more time to accumulate and transfer through the food web to human nutrition from fish. A range of processes caused by human activity can make coastal waters become darker, and some of these could be mitigated by enhanced environmental regulation, stricter land use to reduce nutrient run-off for areas that drain to rivers, and hence eventually to the sea. Other activities for environmental regulation could be fertilizer use and timing of agricultural tillage, or requirement to preserve wetlands or to limit boats stirring light-blocking silt as they move.

Summary Sentence: Fashion is set to join food and energy in competition for land.
Justification: The interdependences between biodiversity and climate change are clear and the benefits that a healthy system can have, can no longer be ignored. The fashion industry is awakening to the fact that it is being increasingly scrutinised for its environmental impact. Researchers are encouraging transparency of supply chains so that consumers know the lifecycle impact of the products they buy, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions that reflect their values. This has led some progressive fashion brands to explore regenerative farming, as a way to improve their sustainability and by association their reputation. Although these projects are only small scale at the moment, there is potential for rapid increase in the future. Regenerative farming can have significant benefits for climate and the environment, however this will add more competition for land, which is already facing higher demands to supply food and energy to an expanding global human population. As the economy moves to one that values the services nature provides and sees investment in this area, clear oversight and governance will be required to ensure truly sustainable use of land. The Environment Agency may be well placed to help develop the systems thinking that will be required to ensure sustainable land management across the many different sectors involved, in order to achieve the greatest benefits that are future proof for a changing climate.

Summary Sentence: A campaign is drawing attention to the growing proliferation of &%23160;plastic plants and shrubs appearing in urban areas.
Justification:
Hedgerows are important habitats for wildlife (at least 2,000 species have been recorded visiting one hedge) and have recently been cited in a government report as effective at storing significant amounts of carbon, if managed properly. Natural hedges have also proved effective at reducing the impacts of roadside air pollution, providing the right plants are used. &%23160;This is now being countered by an emerging trend for plastic hedges and shrubs, echoing a previously identified trend for ‘synthetic nature’ (%2313777), which may jeopardise shelter and food sources for wildlife including pollinators like bees, while also potentially becoming a source of plastic pollution in water through run-off. Artificial greenery can also have a negative impact on run-off in relation to flood management. Celebrities including Julia Bradbury and Chris Packham have drawn attention to this issue. Current planning policies require developments to enhance the natural environment, but there is currently nothing in place to limit the use of plastic plants, which require less maintenance. The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider to what extent the rise of synthetic nature in urban landscapes could work against biodiversity, pollution and flood management objectives.&%23160;
&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Several innovations point towards a future where solar energy may have multiple uses in infrastructure beyond photovoltaic power.&%23160;
Justification: &%23160;The Environment Agency should be interested in these developments which may have applications within its own assets and buildings as well as suggesting possible solutions to water resource pressures. Australian researchers have developed a cost effective water purification technique that could deliver enough fresh water for a family from one square metre of source water. This innovation is based around a &%23160;highly efficient photothermal structure sitting on the water’s surface, which converts sunlight to heat. This is focused on the water’s surface to create rapid evaporation. The 3D shape of the new photothermal evaporator is extremely efficient and also draws energy from the water around it, meaning it operates at 170 per cent efficiency. This cheap low maintenance solution could be ideal for small communities where other purification and desalination processes such as reverse osmosis would be too expensive. A team of researchers in Singapore has developed a smart sunlight harvesting device that can relay daylight efficiently into underground spaces for a fraction of the cost of LEDs. The device consists of an off-the-shelf acrylic ball and fibre optic cable. Computerised motors are used to track the sun for optimum light capture, which is then refracted from the ball into the cable and onto the underground location where light is needed. The device can easily be incorporated into existing infrastructure. Such a device could have applications in buildings, particularly with vertical and underground farming, reducing production costs during daylight hours.
Primary Article Title: Bright idea&%2358; 'Smart’ device to harvest daylight

Summary Sentence: As investment in alternative proteins increases, new research suggests that consumers are open to eating meat grown in bioreactors.
Justification: oth developments should be of interest to the Environment Agency as they both portend to significant disruption to livestock farming, which has regulatory implications for its remit. Recent market research revealed that cultivated meat companies received investment totalling €300 million in 2020, with the number of companies operating in this space growing by 43 per cent to 76. Cultured meat recently was approved for retail in Singapore and many companies are looking to move beyond the laboratory stage and into production. In parallel a recent survey conducted in the UK and US (funded by a cultivated meat start up) revealed that 80 per cent of respondents were open to trying cultivated meat, with 85 per cent of under 39 years old likely to try it. Overall people could see cultured meat making up 40 per cent of their meat intake. Elsewhere a vegan cheese manufacturer has been bought out by a large international dairy brand, suggesting that a non-livestock based meat and dairy industry is being taken seriously by current operators. A reduction of demand for conventional meat and dairy could bring significant changes to rural land use and pollution from the farming sector, as well as contributing to wider environmental targets such as Net Zero.

Summary Sentence: Researchers are turning to music as a medium to explore and communicate environmental experiences.&%23160;
Justification: Spiders use vibrations to perceive and even communicate with the world around them. In one experiment scientists have created an interactive 3D virtual spider web, based on the scanned dimensions of a real web. Taking into account thread properties such as length and elasticity, they were able to recreate vibration frequencies, scaled to human hearing levels. People could then interact virtually with the model, effectively producing a new form of musical instrument and helping to gain an insight into life as a spider. The researchers also lightly suggest that one day it may be possible to communicate with a spider through a similar interface. Elsewhere researchers have turned to music as an alternative medium for understanding historic activity of a river basin catchment. Precipitation (one input) , streamflow and potential evapotranspiration data (two outputs) from the Ardèche river at Sauze were assigned digital musical instruments playing a predefined scale based on levels recorded so that an increasing activity in the basin is represented as increasing musical activity. While a novel means of scientific engagement, changes in the music also signify water management questions - for example why do outputs not correspond to inputs at certain times? - provoking challenge and debate. The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider similar approaches in communication and engagement, particularly with audiences for which visual communication may be challenging.
Primary Article Title: The frequencies of a vibrating spider web have been made into music

Summary Sentence: New evidence is coming to light on the impacts of particulate matter on human health.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency as a regulator of particulate matter (PM) emissions. Particulate emissions are generally classified by size into PM10 and PM2.5. It’s the oxidative potential (OP) of a Sources of UFPs include vehicles and wood burners, and tens of thousands of particles can be found in each sugar cube-sized volume of city air. They are thought to pass through the expectant mother’s lungs and into her bloodstream, causing damaging inflammation. They are also likely to cross the placenta into the foetus’s circulation.particle that determines how reactive it might be with other molecules, and therefore its potential to cause inflammation leading to health impacts in humans. Currently there is limited understanding of how different sources contribute the most to each emission category. Recent analysis of air quality data from Switzerland and Liechtenstein has looked at primary and secondary sources of PM and OP. The analysis found that PM with the highest OP came from two anthropogenic sources&%2358; people burning biomass (i.e. from logs) in &%23160;their homes; and &%23160;non-emissions metals, such as copper or chromium from vehicle brake wear. The latter was found to be particularly high in cities. The results suggest that future strategies to reduce overall PM levels may not reduce concentrations of PM with high OP, and therefore not produce the desired effects on human health goals. Separate research has established a link between asthma in toddlers and in-utero exposure to poor air quality, specifically ultra-fine particles (UFPs) with an aerodynamic diameter of 0.1 µm or less. Sources of UFPs also &%23160;include vehicles and wood burners. It is thought that they pass from an expectant mother’s lungs and into her bloodstream, causing damaging inflammation to the unborn baby. The new study followed 400 mothers and babies through pregnancy and beyond. The researchers found that where mothers had been exposed to levels of 30,000/cm3 during pregnancy their children were approximately four times more likely to develop asthma than those whose mothers had been exposed to half of this level - equivalent to a difference in pollution seen when going from a backstreet to a busy road. Currently UFP levels are not regulated by governments. It is suggested that this may be an area of environmental monitoring, protection and regulation that needs more focus.

Summary Sentence: A group of academics have recently published research suggesting behavioural changes in people and animals from chemical exposure need to be better accounted for in chemical risk assessments.
Justification: The Environment Agency may need to alter its own chemical risk assessment activities in relation to these new recommendations. A scientific forum of 30 experts have united in concern about behaviour altering chemicals. Science already knows that chemicals affect human and wildlife behaviour, and recent work has highlighted that a wide variety of contaminants and other environmental stressors adversely affect behavior and subsequent ecological outcomes in terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. However the group have expressed that a lack of standardised toxicity methods means that behavioural impacts are not properly considered in regulatory toxicology and therefore are absent from chemical risk assessments, meaning current processes are not fit for purpose. The group have proposed a roadmap to addressing these shortfalls, which focuses on&%2358; improved studies of contaminated-induced behavioural changes; new and adapted standard toxicity tests; integrating behaviour into environmental risk assessment alongside mortality, growth and reproduction; &%23160;and better guidance, training and integration of human and wildlife behavioural studies into ecotoxicology.
Primary Article Title: Are chemical pollutants altering the behavior of wildlife and humans?

Summary Sentence: Significant interest in global human resources technology may signal the level of interest in flexibility for the future workforce.
Justification: The article details the growth in demand for HR technology that is able to deal with global workforces. The rise in distributed workforces has been amplified by the recent pandemic, where homeworking as a necessity has allowed people to work in theory from anywhere in the world with a stable internet connection. This trend was already in the early stages of development before the pandemic arose, but has sped up since. These concepts will be of relevance to the work of the Environment Agency when considering the future workforce and how to support them with the correct collaboration tools. Business models based on a globally distributed workforce may also have implications for how the Environment Agency engages with and regulates them.

Summary Sentence: A criminal has been brought to justice based on fingerprint analysis of a picture of his hand posted on social media.
Justification: The criminal&%23160;was suspected of involvement in a large drugs conspiracy. He had posted an image of himself holding a block of blue stilton cheese on the EncroChat encryption service, popular with criminals. Police were able to crack the encryption and following analysis of the picture were able to produce an incriminating fingerprint match. The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider the implications of this, particularly if biometrics&%23160;become part of IT deployment. The case in question suggests that social media posts could similarly be used to identify and potentially copy fingerprint information, which could in turn be used to bypass biosecurity measures on Environment Agency devices.
Primary Article Title: Block of Stilton cheese led to the downfall of EncroChat drug dealer

Summary Sentence: Challenges of sustainable buildings and clean energy could both be addressed through the realisation of concrete based rechargeable batteries.
Justification: Though still at the conceptual stage, such a development could be of interest and impact to the Environment Agency’s construction and asset management activities, particularly in flood management. The concept developed by Chalmers University is based around a cement-based mixture containing carbon fibres to increase conductivity. The mixture is embedded within two metal coated carbon meshes of iron for the anode and nickel for the cathode respectively. The research has been refined over several years to the stage where current performance of a prototype cement battery, which has a low energy density compared to other currently available batteries. However the potential volume that a concrete battery could offer in conjunction with use in buildings and other construction projects could address this. Coupling concrete batteries with renewable energy sources such as solar could contribute significantly to a renewable energy economy by adding additional functionality to future construction projects. Questions may also remain about the ease by which a new form of concrete could be recycled at end of life, alongside the overall carbon neutrality of concrete manufacture.&%23160;

Summary Sentence: A new method of safely storing hydrogen in a medium that is ten times the energy density of lithium ion batteries could herald a new range of small hydrogen powered devices.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interest in the manufacture and logistics of the new substance, which could fall under similar regulatory frameworks as other fuels. Fraunhofer Institute have developed ‘Powerpaste’, a grey like sludge made from hydrogen with magnesium and stabilisers which allows hydrogen to be stored in cartridges at room temperature. Powerpaste is ten times more energy dense than current lithium batteries and could therefore be adapted to extend the &%23160;range of many currently electrically powered devices, including electric cars, scooters and &%23160;drones. The paste is injected into a chamber where it reacts with water, releasing hydrogen at a &%23160;controlled rate which can then be fed into a fuel cell. The paste contains hydrogen and magnesium in the form of magnesium hydride, along with an ester and a metal salt. Powerpaste can be stored safely at room temperature, and can also be pumped and distributed via pre-existing fuel lines with minimal conversion, and is therefore compatible with existing infrastructure, considerably cheaper than distributing the equivalent power in hydrogen gas form.

Summary Sentence: Researchers have outlined an app that could better optimise smartphone communications during a disaster.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners may be interested in this approach for developing community resilience but also resilience in their own communication networks during incidents. The new emergency communication system, called SOS (Self-Organisation for Survival), has arisen from the realisation that people are motivated to help in a crisis but often don’t know how, and secondly communications are most important in the immediate aftermath of a disaster. Once installed on people’s smartphones the app &%23160;establishes a communications network between phones optimising battery use to keep communications going as long as possible. Phones with hire charge act as hubs to relay text messages. As phones become drained of power, other phones are activated to take their place. Models of the SOS system demonstrated it to be more effective than conventional mesh networks and still had the majority of mobile phones operating after the first 72 hours. A similar system could be of benefit to communities caught in major flood events or similar. The Environment Agency could therefore include promotion of such as system as part of its incident preparation communications.

Summary Sentence: Growing interest in synthetic fuels could influence the transition to a low carbon economy.
Justification: The synthetic fuels currently of interest to industry are hydrocarbon based like those derived from oil, which means they can be used without any problems in traditional vehicles. Unlike oil based fuels, synthetic fuels derive their hydrogen from water and carbon from the air. Supporters of the technology believe renewable energy can be used to create the hydrogen, and carbon captured from the atmosphere could offset the carbon released from burning the fuel, which is why it is branded carbon neutral. Although currently expensive and uneconomic to produce, a number of investors are exploring due to the expectations of costs reducing with economies of scale and any potential carbon pricing in the future. The application of this fuel also has potential wider than the auto industry, and is why there are trials underway in conjunction with the airline and shipping industries as well. Porshe have teamed up with Siemens to develop a plant in Chile using wind to power and Repsol are investing in a plant in Spain near an oil refinery to capture the carbon dioxide emitted. This again hints at the hub based approach to future industry, siting different organisations together to achieve dual benefits from partnership working. This adds to the intelligence already highlighted of how the Environment Agency may need to consider the impact of geographically distinct hubs on regulation. It remains to be seen if the environmental credentials of this process will stand up to scrutiny and a lot depends on whether it can be made into an economically viable process.

Summary Sentence: A new approach to ammonia manufacturing could help to mitigate against the environmental impacts of nitrogen oxide while simultaneously reducing the energy demands and emissions associated with commercial scale ammonia production via the Haber-Bosch process.
Justification:
This development could be significant to the Environment Agency’s remit as it suggests pathways to improved air quality, climate change mitigation and future regulated activities, particularly around fertiliser production and use. The new approach involves reducing nitrogen oxide (NO), the main cause of fine dust, into ammonia (NH3) without releasing carbon dioxide (CO2). Current chemical reactions in this space are slow and energy inefficient. The new approach focuses on a nanostructured Ag electrode in conjunction with a rationally designed electrolyte containing the EDTA–Fe2+ metal complex (EFeMC). This gives a near 100 per cent efficiency for NH3, without degrading the catalyst. The new approach is therefore significantly more energy efficient and cost effective than the Haber-Bosch process. It is envisaged that emissions from other industrial processes could provide the feedstock for this process, which may also be of relevance to an emergent hydrogen energy economy using ammonia as an energy storage medium.
&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Noise could be impacting on plant health, even after the source of noise has long been removed.
Justification: This research could be significant in terms of the environmental impacts of installations that the Environment Agency regulates and location of future operations. &%23160;A recent study has looked at the long term impacts of noise on plant communities surrounding natural gas wells in New Mexico, USA. Researchers found that there were 75 per cent less piñon pine seedlings at noisier sites than quiet ones, thought to be due to noise driving away jays which would naturally store seeds underground. On revisiting once noisy sites 12 years later, numbers of seedlings were still low. It’s suggested that the jays have episodic memory (corvids like jays and crows are known to be highly intelligent %2314976) &%23160;and that previous experience of the once noisy sites has stopped them returning and storing seeds underground, hence fewer seedlings. However other differences in juniper seedlings and communities of flowers could not be so easily explained, but it’s suggested that noise has similarly kept grazing animals such as deer and insect pollinators away from the sites. Further research is needed, but it’s suggested that tighter noise regulation may be a consequence of this discovery. The UK has a different regulatory approach to noise than the USA, nonetheless as noise is increasingly recognised as a factor in biodiversity, more evidence in this area could mean factors of noise play a greater role in environmental assessments and environment related site regulation than they do currently.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Cascading effects of noise on plants persist over long periods and after noise is removed

Summary Sentence: An activist group is launching a UK legal challenge to attempt a ban of factory and intensively farmed animal produce.
Justification: This challenge may have consequences for the Environment Agency as a currently regulator of intensive farming practices such as pig and poultry farming. The challenge is being brought under the banner of Scrap, standing for “suffering, climate chaos, ravaging the planet, antibiotic resistance, pandemics, and disease”. It’s aims include agreeing on a formal definition of factory farming; acknowledging the need for change; ensuring farming subsidies are given to sustainable farming; providing training for factory farmers; stopping new factory farms from being built; helping factory farmers transition and setting clear phase-out goals. The campaign is launching, with a letter to Environment Secretary George Eustice, asking for clarification of any plans or measures to ban factory and intensive-farmed produce. Scrap’s legal challenge is being brought by barrister Michael Mansfield, known for work on Hillsborough and Grenfell cases amongst others. Scrap has also reached out to a range of experts for written submissions for use as evidence. While this is the first legal challenge to factory farming, the reasons for demanding change such as climate change have parallels with other legal challenges to business practices on environmental grounds, such as a growing number of climate change related legal claims across Europe, typically seeking to impose obligations on governments.
Primary Article Title: The world’s first legal challenge against factory farming
Author: Mridul, A
Secondary_URLs: Climate change disputes in Europe and beyond%23%23https&%2358;//www.lawgazette.co.uk/legal-updates/climate-change-disputes-in-europe-and-beyond/5108149.article

Summary Sentence: Russia is believed to have developed a weapon that could flood cities with radioactive water.
Justification: The Poseidon 2M39 torpedo was initially identified in 2015 but was thought to be a ‘paper tiger’ intended for use in defence propaganda. More recent intelligence suggests that the 2M39 is rapidly approaching completion. The torpedo is designed to bypass coastal defences before unleashing a nuclear warhead equivalent to several megatons. This would create a tsunami of radioactive water directed at coastal communities producing an immediate flooding event, followed by a prolonged period of radioactive contamination over a large coastal area that would be extremely difficult to decontaminate. The Environment Agency has an interest in both flooding and environmental protection. Normally weather forecasting etc gives some notice of the start, duration and scale of major flood events. Weapons similar to the 2M39 could remove this vital preparation window, suggesting that major flood events could occur without sufficient warning, bringing with them more concerns than the immediate danger of flood water.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: A new Russian weapon can flood coastal cities with 'radioactive tsunamis'
Author: Bergan, B
Keywords: Russia weapon war defence missile flooding nuclear radiation radioactive tsunami&%23160;Poseidon 2M39 coastal defence contamination incident disaster water marine ocean sea urban population health

Summary Sentence: Signs of the trends that could be shaping the post-pandemic urban landscape are starting to emerge.&%23160;
Justification: These signals of change should be of interest to the Environment Agency’s placemaking agenda. The coronavirus pandemic has dramatically altered the economic viability of towns and cities. It’s been estimated that the UK has lost over 17,500 chain outlets, and that there could be as many as 80,000 vacant shops once the impacts of a withdrawl of government support are finally felt. As with many trends Covid has accelerated rather than caused a decline in the high street, particularly in small urban areas. This decline is also offering the potential for experimentation and reinvention of urban space, exemplified by Stockton-on-Tees, where there are plans to demolish one side of the town’s high street and replace it with green space. Similar ambitions can be seen in Nottingham (%2315027). Urban areas are also providing scope for new blue space&%2358; a former shopping mall in Tinan, Taiwan, has been repurposed as an urban lagoon and park, demonstrating further how former urban retail space could be repurposed. In tandem with a reshaping of urban centres the pandemic has led to a house price boom across the globe focussed on suburban locations. One factor is a greater acceptance of remote working practices, but Covid has also revealed a certain resilience of suburban design not present in urban development. Suburbia has historically been viewed as culturally dull and poorly designed with little public space and urban zoning, which encourages reliance on private vehicles. Under pandemic conditions private garden space, private transport and zoned purpose have emerged as advantages, allowing people to work, exercise, shop and travel without in keeping with social distancing. Conventional assumptions of urbanisation have previously focused on high density living, urban infilling of brown space and public green space&%2358; post coronavirus the need for development with a more suburban flavour could influence planning and development, increasing pressure on resources, including that of flood plain development, water resources and construction materials, all of which could impact on the Environment Agency’s remit.
Primary Article Title: Revenge of the Suburbs
Author: Bogost, I

Summary Sentence: A new type of underground enclosed hydropower system may enable gentle slopes to become batteries of the future.
Justification: Instead of a traditional system using water and steep slopes, this new system uses a dense mineral rich fluid which means it only needs a gentle slope to generate electricity. This system would be underground and enclosed which reduces some of the negative environmental impacts that are now associated with hydropower, such as impacts on the health of river based organisms. Just like traditional hydropower, excess energy could be used to pump the fluid uphill to be stored until it is needed in times of peak demand. The energy company RhrEnergise that are developing the technology have identified approximately 700 sites around the UK that may be suitable. It is unclear the exact nature of the fluid that would be used in the system, and the impacts this could have on the surrounding environment in the event of a leak. Understanding the technology in more detail if it nears market viability will be important to incident response planning. Any engineering work involved to create these sites would also need careful planning to limit the environmental impact.
Primary Article Title: Powering up&%2358; UK hills could be used as energy 'batteries'
Keywords: Waste pollution energy renewable hydropower climate change transition storage battery incident water

Summary Sentence: Smoke from more frequent and larger wildfires impacts public health more than previously suspected.
Justification: Wildfires are becoming more extreme, more common as the “fire season” has become longer, and destructive due to climate change, and a new study suggests that smoke and particles from wildfires may be a more pressing public health concern and more harmful source of pollutants to human health than previously thought. Emerging actions for Environment Agency and Defra might include rethinking human activity such as addressing changes in land-use and landscape management for example the benefits from large-scale habitat restoration, or improved early wildfire detection systems to mitigate climate change, although this can be a challenge for example in case of peat fires on moorlands, sometimes called ‘zombie fires.’. Wildfire specific air pollution is potentially even ten times more harmful than other air pollution such as from traffic and industries. The problem is how to identify specific signatures in fire; the lack of marker in the air particles and therefore it can be hard to identify specific sources of pollution with certainty even though this is critically important for understanding the risks. As smoke, soot and other pollutants are released into the air with uncontrolled large fires, the smoke may rise many kilometres high, crossing oceans and countries affecting public health and as it travels, it can make urban air quality and environmental exposures worse. What is not known is exactly how much more toxic the smoke becomes as it ages in the atmosphere, and therefore more research is called for to understand the processes to be able to monitor air pollution better.&%23160; Health officials in Colorado, USA recommend people construct “safe rooms” to protect themselves against “multiple” air pollutants including particulates from wildfires. Wildfires and the air pollution they cause is another vital reason why Environment Agency must work to reduce greenhouse emissions as we cannot regulate the air pollution from fires. Additionally, brown carbon, the soot released by fires, can absorb heat from the sun and hence can make global warming worse.
Primary Article Title: Wildfire Smoke Is More Toxic Than Other Forms of Air Pollution, Study Finds

Summary Sentence: Graphene and biochar can be used to boost anaerobic digestion process efficiency.
Justification: Anaerobic digestion (AD) is a commonly used natural process where micro-organisms break down organic waste materials and produce biogas as a biofuel, and it is receiving increasing attention because of its role to play to reduce greenhouse gas emissions as AD makes use of organic waste. The European Commission’s Direct Interspecies Electron Transfer (DIET) project that has recently concluded was able to find solutions to overcome essential problems in aerobic digestive process; resulting to increased efficiency and thereby permitting the reduction of the digester’s size yet producing the same quantity of biogas. &%23160;This was possible by adding an electrically conductive material, in this case graphene, to a digester, thus enhancing the biomethane production rate by 20-40% in comparison to the currently existing technology. This evidence supports need for further research into pyrochar that is almost as effective as a conductive material as graphene that was used for these laboratory experiments, but 200 times cheaper. Introduction of pyrochar to the process can further facilitate advances in anaerobic digestation process efficiencies and develop circular economy systems for the future. The cost of sustainable renewable gas can be reduced and increasing biogas sector supports going carbon neutral and negative.
Primary Article Title: Graphene spiced-up anaerobic digestion substantially increases biogas production potential
Author: European Commission

Summary Sentence: New type of hybrid robotics are developed for environmental monitoring.
Justification: A new European Union project started in January 2021 aiming to utilise materials science and artificial intelligence in order to develop soft robots called “intelligent seeds” because their design is inspired by nature; how seeds fly and become dispersed. The relevance to Environment Agency is that this is another novel technology that could be used to monitor the quality of air, water, and soil, especially top soils, without causing further environmental damage as the I-seeds are biodegradable and do not require any energy supply to function. The project aims to replicate the morphology of plant seeds and study most suited biodegradable materials including polymers and hydrogels that would simultaneously act as sensors and actuators. Focus will be on developing two types of I-seeds&%2358; I-Seed ERO will have a screw type shape that enables penetrating the soil whereas I-Seed SAM remains monitoring the soil surface. Deployment will be done with drones, and the researchers will use a specific software to control the I-seeds for them to be dispersed in the desired geographical locations, then track their position and monitor according to required data needs. Use of LIDAR system permits tracking I-seed robots over long distances and thus enables environmental monitoring of areas that are normally hard to reach. Through this innovative technology, Environment Agency could be one more step closer toward delivering a sensor network for in-situ detection of a variety of environmental parameters such as water quality, temperature and humidity, presence of pollutants in air, water or top soils.
Primary Article Title: I-Seed project for intelligent biodegradable soft robots mimicking plant seeds behaviour
