Summary Sentence: New analysis from the German nuclear authority suggests that small modular reactors (SMR) may have greater environmental and strategic risks over their lifetimes than larger centralised nuclear power stations.&%23160;
Justification:
The Environment Agency regulates the nuclear sector and so should be interested in the implications of this report, as interest in SMRs in the UK is growing. The report from BASE (Bundesamt für die Sicherheit der nuklearen Entsorgung TRANSLATION&%2358; Federal Office for the Safety of Nuclear Waste Management) claims SMRs carry significant risks in terms of the proliferation of weapons grade nuclear material in order to power them. The report also concludes that the costs of SMRs may be much higher than claimed - advocates suggest that the small plants are cheaper and safer thanks to advanced reactor designs and can be operated with converted short-lived radioactive materials, solving waste issues. Rolls Royce are planning to construct 16 SMRs in the UK (SP%2387). A second BASE report testing three scenarios concludes that a nuclear waste repository would remain necessary with SMRs, and that the amount of low and medium level radioactive waste would increase “massively” during their dismantlement. Germany is accelerating a phase out of nuclear power and replacing it with renewables including biogas. The Environment Agency and partners may need to consider if similar implications may arise as the UK begins to adopt SMR technologies.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Small modular reactors not the solution, says German nuclear authority
Author: Appunn, K
Keywords: waste energy nuclear "small modular reactor" SMR radioactive waste regulation disposal defence security scenario cost&%23160;BASE "Bundesamt für die Sicherheit der nuklearen Entsorgung" Germany

Summary Sentence: New analysis of historic climate data suggests that summer could last for six months by 2100.&%23160;
Justification: This could be of significance for the Environment Agency’s remit as such an occurrence is associated with increased frequency of droughts and wildfires. Researchers analysed six decades of climate data, looking for daily records exceeding summer temperatures, defined as “onset of temperatures in the hottest 25 percent during that time period”. Winter was similarly defined as “ temperatures in the coldest 25 percent.” The study found that summer days in the Northern Hemisphere increased from 78 to 95 between 1952 and 2011, with all other seasons contracting. Modelling similar future changes revealed that summer could last almost six months by the end of the century, impacting on agriculture, &%23160;human health, breeding and migration of wildlife, as well as drought and wildfire. An increasingly prolonged summer season could significantly affect how the Environment Agency deploys personnel and resources, particularly around incident management, and may require new approaches to recruitment, training and priorities.
Primary Article Title: Summer could last six months by 2100, study finds
Secondary_URLs: Changing lengths of the four seasons by global warming
Keywords: "climate change" drought wildfire summer season winter autumn spring incident emergency disaster workforce recruitment resource model farming agriculture biodiversity breeding migration health

Summary Sentence: A newly developed app could provide individualised evacuation plans for people caught up in wildfires.&%23160;
Justification: Though this technology has been developed specifically for wildfires, similar applications could be of use in response to other incidents such as flooding, and therefore should be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners. Wildfire frequency is also expected to increase in the UK from the impacts of climate change. The mobile phone app is designed to connect via mobile phone network to a server running a fire simulation program which uses publicly available data on geography, weather and vegetation type to predict how a fire might spread at &%23160;15-minute intervals. Using GPS on a phone the app then calculates several evacuation routes before selecting the one that keeps the user at minimum risk. Directions can be selected as text or map versions. Though the app has responded well in terms of success and usability, further work is needed to improve, add more features and test it under a range of more challenging scenarios. It’s also acknowledged that an untrained user could misinterpret the current system leading to more and not less risk.
Primary Article Title: Fire safety app simulates wildfires and shows a route to avoid them
Author: Gent, E
Keywords: disaster wildfire incident "incident management" emergency evacuation flooding app mobile phone map server model&%23160;geography weather&%23160;vegetation GPS "climate change"&%23160;scenario

Summary Sentence: An experimental energy generation system has been developed that can quickly produce hydrogen and electricity, while at the same time eliminating carbon dioxide emissions.
Justification:
The system can also produce value added chemicals and therefore may be of interest to the chemical sector, which, along with the energy sector, &%23160;the Environment Agency regulates. A research team has developed a membrane-free aqueous metal–CO₂ battery which is easy to manufacture and can operate continuously with one type of electrolyte. Carbon dioxide is introduced to an aqueous solution containing a Mg-metal negative electrode, an aqueous electrolyte, and a positive-electrode catalyst. It is similar to current fuel cell technology but utilise aqueous electrolytes instead. The battery outputs hydrogen which could be tapped directly for fuel and other applications. Bicarbonate arises as a bi-product.&%23160;&%23160;As a result, the newly-developed MF Mg-CO2 battery had successfully sequestered CO2 emissions by generating electricity and value-added chemicals without any harmful by-products. This newly-developed MF Mg-CO2 battery technology could be adapted to produce various value-added chemicals as well as electricity (via hydrogen from CO2 without waste, and may therefore be of interest to both the chemical and power sectors for a way to reduce CO2 emissions and address feedstock chemical needs.&%23160;
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Indirect surpassing CO2 utilization in membrane-free CO2 battery
Author: Heo, J
Secondary_URLs: Indirect surpassing CO2 utilization in membrane-free CO2 battery

Summary Sentence: Continued growth under current economic models will lead to an increased risk of global pandemics.
Justification: Academics from UCL have outlined how prioritising economic growth over environmental sustainability will create conditions in which epidemics flourish, as ecosystems are encroached upon, leading to biodiversity loss and climate change acceleration from reduced carbon absorbing natural systems. The World is failing to meet commitments on both biodiversity, climate change and sustainability. While there are models of sustainable living such as Kate Rayworth’s doughnut economics, the big question is whether society is prepared to forego pure economic growth for lifestyles that live in agreement with nature. Botswana is highlighted as an example of where such a balance is possible, but wider adoption would require ecological issues to become front and centre in the political arena. The recent Dasgupta review highlighted similar issues, which may influence the types of projects that the Environment Agency and partners prioritise as biodiversity moves up the political agenda.
Primary Article Title: Global obsession with economic growth will increase risk of deadly pandemics in future
Author: Pegram, T & Kreienkamp, J
Keywords: biodiversity "climate change" conservation pandemic economic growth politics ecosystem consumption Botswana sustainability regulation

Summary Sentence: A new approach to DNA editing could make it much easier to make genetic modifications and design synthetic organisms.
Justification: This development arrives at a time when questions over the precision of current techniques are coming to the fore. The Environment Agency and partners may have regulatory roles regarding genetically altered life forms, which may prove challenging if the output of these greatly increases from ease of design and production. A recent study has revealed that CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing could lead to unintended DNA mutations, despite CRISPR being widely regarded as a precision technique. Retrospective analysis of data from human embryo experiments found large unintended mutations in approximately 16 per cent &%23160;of samples. Conventional assessment methods would have missed these DNA changes, and emphasises that unintended mutations can develop without rigorous assessment. A new app has been developed by a separate team of researchers to more readily identify what has changed in a DNA sequence during CRISPR alteration. Elsewhere researchers have taken a CAD (computer aided design) approach to genetics, developing a platform that enables the costs of genome design to be slashed while bringing a degree of utility far beyond current approaches such as CRISPR. Using CAD means that adding for example a new metabolic pathway, CAD will make all the necessary changes in the genome, and catch coding errors, which could produce a dysfunctional cell, which today requires expert human assessment. The CAD platform will be freely available to academics, and some companies&%2358; others will be charged. The platform will also facilitate users sending their CAD files to synthetic DNA manufacturers. While the CAD will meet current safety regulations there are ethical concerns from some that an easy-to-use platform could make less experienced users overestimate the reliability of the CAD’s predicted outcomes, and that a review of regulations is needed to account for the differences in different types of organisms and different applications internationally.
Primary Article Title: With this CAD for genomes, you can design new organisms
Author: Strickland, E

Summary Sentence: Vegetable proteins from farming waste could be used to replace petroleum-based products used in the chemical industry.&%23160;
Justification: This breakthrough could be important in taking forward &%23160;the decarbonising agenda and may coincide with the Environment Agency’s regulatory interests in both agriculture and the chemical sector. Currently the chemical and pharmaceutical industries derive raw materials from fossil fuels. Transitioning to renewable materials is therefore important in making the sector sustainable. Vegetable proteins have always been used in chemical manufacturing, but their use has decreased in favour of fossil fuel based raw materials. Researchers attempting to reverse this trend looked to agricultural waste such as byproducts of rapeseed oil processing, rapeseed meal, which contain large quantities of proteins. These proteins could be used to form foams, gels and films and retain water, and therefore could have applications as paint additives, varnishes, adhesives, lubricants, building materials, detergents, and polymers. Researchers were able to recover and isolate four types of of potentially useful proteins through different processes. While still at the experimental stage the aim is to replace petrochemical-based products with bio-based ones such as the vegetable proteins isolated here on a commercial scale.
Primary Article Title: Vegetable protein waste from rapeseed farming replaces petroleum-based raw materials

Summary Sentence: Governments are taking action to formalise consumers’ &%23160;right to repair their purchases.&%23160;
Justification: This is significant for the Environment Agency as it could impact on levels of WEEE waste and also help to move society towards a more circular economy. France has recently launched the World’s first repair index for small electronics and appliances, including smartphones, laptops, television sets, washing machines and lawn mowers, though the range of products is expected to expand. The scores appliances from 0 to 10 based on five criteria&%2358; ease of disassembly, availability of repair information, availability of spare parts, price of spare parts and conformity to norms on repair problems specific to each class of product. The repairability index is intended to influence consumers to purchase longer lasting, easier to repair products, which in turn would reduce consumer waste and encourage manufacturers to design products with greater environmental considerations. In a similar step the UK government is introducing laws in the Summer of 2021 to give consumers the right to repair the goods they buy. Manufacturers will be legally obliged to make spare parts for products. The new rules could extend product life spans by up to ten &%23160;years, and save consumers an average of £75 a year on bills over their lifetimes. The laws should also reduce electronic waste by 1.5 million tonnes annually.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: 'Right to repair' law to come in this summer
Author: Harrabin, R
Secondary_URLs: France launches anti-waste 'repairability' rating for smartphones, laptops

Summary Sentence: Green hydrogen to ammonia production appears to be edging ever closer in the UK, Europe and further afield.&%23160;
Justification: This should interest the Environment Agency as establishing facilities like this could bring immediate regulatory issues to the energy and agricultural sectors. Two announcements signal that green ammonia facilities are to be built in Denmark and the UK. The former project will be located in the coastal town of Esbjerg offshore wind power will be used to produce green ammonia for use as CO2-free green fertiliser and CO2-free green fuel for shipping. Excess heat will provide domestic heating for local households. The facility will reduce CO2-emissions by about 1.5 million tons CO2 yearly. The other project based in Orkney will similarly use renewable electricity from &%23160;wind to produce hydrogen from water, and then combine the gas with nitrogen from the air to form ammonia. This will be the first commercial facility of its kind in the UK. Further afield the Indian government recently announced plans to replace ten per cent of imported ammonia in farming, petroleum, steel and other sectors with domestically produced green ammonia as part of its National Hydrogen Mission.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Orkney planners back green ammonia plant

Summary Sentence: A US water treatment plant has narrowly avoided a potentially lethal hack, occurring against a backdrop of increasing sophistication in cyber-crime and subsequent financial pressures on businesses to protect themselves.&%23160;
Justification: The Environment Agency may need to take a more considered approach to cybersecurity both in terms of incident potential and regulations. Organisations have a number of tools and techniques at their disposal to prevent and mitigate cyberattack. However a recent report has highlighted that many businesses have experienced ‘counter incident response’, where cybercriminals identify and counter remediation methods. Many UK businesses were impacted by a major cyberattack in early March 2021, of which Microsoft identified four never-before-seen hacking techniques. The company has issued software updates to counter these, but until companies install them they are still vulnerable to attack without knowing it. Despite the obvious benefits of cybersecurity another recently published report suggests that many UK companies aren’t in a position to finance it. Two thirds of UK firms claim to have experienced an attack in the last year, of which half were successful and a third costing the companies the equivalent of $240,000. Covid has been identified as a factor affecting cybersecurity, alongside a scarcity of the necessary expertise. These issues are given context by a recent cyberattack on a water treatment plant in the United States. In February 2021 the city of Oldsmar, Florida experienced a cyberattack on its water treatment system. The perpetrators managed to access the computer controlling drinking water chemicals and attempted to increase levels of sodium hydroxide to 11,100 parts per million (the normal amount is 100 ppm), which would’ve been toxic and damaging to human tissue. Fortunately the attack was thwarted, but only because an employee happened to observe suspicious cursor movement on a control screen. A second incident at another water treatment plant, this time in Kansas, USA resulted from a man allegedly logging into the Kansas public water system from home with the intention of shutting down safety processes which would have rendered the water unfit to drink. The man in question was an ex-employee of the Post Rock Water District facility, when the attack happened, in March 2019. These incidents highlight the importance of cyber-security in running critical infrastructure. It is suggested that companies review their IT security including IoT (internet of things) devices. &%23160;As more operations become digitally controlled, so might the risk of cyber-attack may increase. The Environment Agency currently does not require any indication that an operator’s IT systems meet cyber-security criteria. As more realised examples of cyber-attack emerge it is plausible that digital assurances of safety may become integral to permitting as physical assurances as the boundaries between digital and physical continue to blur.
Primary Article Title: Oldsmar’s cyber attack raises the alarm for the water industry

Summary Sentence: Connected lighting systems are emerging as a way to contribute to sustainability and green recovery and to digitalise societies but environment may be adversely impacted.
Justification: Moving from traditional bulbs to LED for street lighting can bring both green recovery for achieving carbon neutrality and digital value, furthermore saving up to 40% of energy expenses and therefore is likely to become a key component of “smart city” initiatives. Conversely, the evidence points that the growth of LED lighting inevitably creates profound concerns about the impacts on the environment, especially grassland species including plants and animals, as raised by a study published by the University of Exeter. When the lights are dimmer or completely switched off between midnight and 4 am, grassland predatory spiders, among other species, are less affected. &%23160;Street light poles are not just for public lighting needs in urban areas but a method which provides an opportunity to make money out of it by leasing space, another step to digitalise societies. The LED lighting not only provides an energy efficient solution that can be programmed to dim or brighten as required but also has potential for "smart" lights that help site, campus or smart building management to maximise the use of the existing infrastructures. The vision of smart connected lighting networks has made urban lighting an asset for smart cities to use surveillance to collate and provide information that goes to the cloud and, for cities to compile and sell for profit. Sensors placed on streetlights can have assorted future applications from simple such as finding parking spaces for cars to environmental such as monitoring air quality or warn people of a storm approaching or of a need to evacuate. China, USA and India are leading the way globally as the connected lighting networks are predicted to become the main component of the smart city infrastructure.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: The future of "smart" cities is in street lights
Author: Kingson, J.A.

Summary Sentence: Rust could form the basis of a low energy alternative material to silicon.
Justification:
&%23160;The Environment Agency should be interested to consider the implications on manufacturing and waste management of commonplace materials such as iron oxide replacing more exotic materials, alongside the wider organisational and societal benefits of transitioning to more energy efficient digital infrastructure. Researchers in the UK have been experimenting with iron oxide (rust) in an attempt to find an alternative to silicon, which is energy inefficient despite its wide use. Metal oxides are good at storing information, but are less suited to transporting it. However magnetic oxides have shown the potential to move magnetic bits of information with little energy. At the nanoscale iron oxide (Fe2O3) contains magnetic whirls known as merons, which could be manipulated through passing an electric current through them. Thin layers of Iron oxide could therefore be manipulated electrically so they could be used as low-energy spintronics at room temperature. Iron oxide is a cheap plentiful material, but the current costs of nanoscale fabrication are prohibitive for immediate roll out, though this may change with time.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Rust as an alternative to silicon in computer technology
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.nature.com/articles/s41586-021-03219-6
Keywords: half-skyrmion bimeron meron chemistry electronic&%23160;waste WEEE energy "iron oxide" rust Fe2O3 metal spintronic silicon manufacture nanoparticle nanoscale magnetic information data storage infrastructure regulation

Summary Sentence: The Governor of Nevada is laying the foundations for companies to establish their own administrative areas within the State, in exchange for investment.
Justification: Governor Steve Sisolak has outlined plans for technology companies in particular to construct “Innovation Zone” greenfield cities of at least 50,000 acres. &%23160;An Innovation Zone is defined as “a self-governing community, organised much like a traditional city or county but wholly focused on the development of innovative and advanced technologies”. Prospective applicants have to demonstrate they have a track record in advanced technology, and agree to initially &%23160;invest US$250 million, followed by a further US$1 billion over ten years. The governor would initially appoint a board to run the zone, but this would be replaced with an elected board over time as the zone grows and takes on responsibility for more local services, including taxes, schools and courts. One cryptocurrency magnate, Jeffrey Berns, CEO of Nevada-based Blockchains LLC, &%23160;is already interested in the proposal, envisaging a city where all payments, transactions, records and data are recorded on blockchain. The company already has plans &%23160;to break ground by 2022 and to build 15,000 homes and 33 million square feet (3 million square meters) of commercial and industrial space within 75 years. Berns believes that traditional government doesn’t offer enough flexibility to innovate and create a community where people can invent new uses for this technology. Some are oppposed to this programme due to the increased pressure it would put on state water resources, whilst at the same time removing responsibility from state authorities.&%23160;These proposals for Nevada echo the recent announcements by both the UK and Scottish Governments to establish Freeports and ‘Greenports’ (%23154). A further expansion of autonomous zones may lead to regulatory differences across borders that could generate environmental impacts, which the Environment Agency may need to be mindful of, in the event of similar developments to the Nevada proposals appearing on UK soil.
Primary Article URL: Nevada governor opens up on tech company ‘Innovation Zones’

Summary Sentence: The UK Government’s recent plans to develop eight low tax ‘Freeports’ are being adapted by the Scottish Government into ‘Greenports’ to help deliver on inclusive growth, fair work practices and delivering a net zero economy.
Justification: Building on tax breaks rebates investment, zero business rates, and lower tariffs and customs obligations promised by freeports, the Scottish government proposes that greenports will also pay the real Living Wage, &%23160;commit to supporting sustainable and inclusive growth in local communities and contribute to Scotland’s just transition to net zero. Freeports are controversial, with some critics citing the creation of tiered working conditions, deregulation and criminality in some instances&%2358; the Scottish proposal looks to precipitate socially and environmentally positive second order benefits. The Environment Agency may wish to consider how regulatory regimes may be maintained and enhanced through any further introductions and changes to areas of greater economic autonomy.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Green ports to aid economic recovery

Summary Sentence: Researchers are experimenting with the interface between the digital and biological realms, which could eventually deliver the ability to reprogramme cells as if they were like any other digital device.&%23160;
Justification: Swiss scientists have been experimenting with creating information switching systems in biological cells. They recently successfully created an OR switch in human cells. Previous biological OR gates were designed by combining two systems that responded separately to two different stimuli. The new OR switch is a true OR switch in that it is contained within a single system, in this case a DNA sequence. With further development the OR switch could find application in medical diagnostics and treatment. &%23160;This could lead to &%23160;artificially reprogrammed cells designed to perform medical tasks in our bodies, such as preserve or destroy cells based on their &%23160;genetic characteristics, e.g tumor cells. DNA has previously been shown to have promise as an efficient and durable data storage medium (%23****). Researchers in the USA have brought this realisation closer through developing an approach that converts digital electronic signals into genetic data stored in the genomes of living cells. Previous work had created a sensing module that responded to a ‘trigger’ sequence of DNA. Building on this the team incorporated a biosensor that responds to electrical signals. When an electric current was passed through a series of 24 cells containing bacteria, the trigger sequence levels were elevated, representing “1” and likewise the opposite to represent “0”. This represented a total of 72 bits, which were able to encode the message “hello world”. The configuration would require significant scale up beyond this proof of concept to be of true practical use. However storing data in this DNA form could mean cheaper to amplification or duplication through simply growing more cells. It also suggests the possibility of creating biocomputers through engineering cells’ DNA to perform logic and memory operations, and creating a direct interface between silicon and genomes that could mean direct reprogramming of cells. This could mean a proliferation of genetic modifications amongst other environmental implications.
Primary Article Title: New research could enable direct data transfer from computers to living cells
Author: Gent, E
Secondary_URLs:

Summary Sentence: Potassium-independent cesium transporters indicate promise for promise for future bioremediation using plants.
Justification: Ten years after Fukushima Daichi nuclear plant&%23160; disaster, when a large amount of radioactive cesium was released to the environment, contaminating it for a long time, researchers have discovered a way to genetically manipulate plants to draw toxic components from the contaminated soil. This evidence supports collaborative research across fields to find successful solutions to scientific problems and may lead to discovering potential of the same technique being adapted for crop plants to make them more resilient for growth in contaminated soil. The radioactive cesium that spreads to ecosystems after nuclear accidents has long term consequences due to the length of its half-life. But the newly discovered cesium transporters in plants are a significant development because they are potassium-independent, hence not hindering plant growth but able to remediate the soil and remove the toxic cesium using phytoremediation. That being said, it may be possible to continue research to find other currently unknown cesium transporters for future bioremediation demands.
Primary Article Title: Plant as superhero during nuclear power plant accidents
Author: IWATE UNIVERSITY, JAPAN
Keywords: radioactive pollution nuclear cesium potassium yeast remediation phytoremediation plants “root biology” soil cells molecules “molecular biology” transporters pathways research accidents

Summary Sentence: The revolutionary process, developed in Finland, for making textile fibre out of wood cellulose and textile waste, will be utilised in a new plant in collaboration with H&M.
Justification:
Finland’s Spinnova is a sustainable textiles company that is developing an entirely new process aiming for producing 100% circular materials from renewable sources such as wood-based fibres and waste in a partnership with a Brazilian pulp group Suzano. The breakthrough process can produce textile fibre from waste streams and cellulose with no need for harmful pollutant chemicals in dissolving the materials, with less energy and with less water than cotton production.&%23160;
As the world’s second largest fashion retailer H&M joins as a new partner, a new plant will be built in Finland by the end of 2022 and another in Sweden in collaboration with IKEA and Stora Enso, because pine and spruce are ideal for the wood-based textile fibre production due to their long fibre structure. This breakthrough innovative technology that is unique in the world also makes it possible to use discarded textiles, recycling their fibres and with prolonging textiles’ life cycle towards circular economy. The production technology could be developed further to use waste such as wheat or barley straw, or to scale up the production volumes if consumer behaviour is supportive to this sustainable alternative.
&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Higher educational institutions become more responsive to the fast changing needs of society.
Justification: competition between universities and faster research, which is called the “Fifth Wave” of higher education and an evolution as traditional higher education is no longer adequate to respond to the fast changing needs of the modern society. This is relevant to us in England because the change in higher education institutions is as response to the emerging needs in the society, to become truly democratic,&%23160;inclusive and research-intensive to focus on solving interdisciplinary problems such as climate change, water issues, sustainability. &%23160;A key feature of the novel educational philosophy is that all people should become lifelong learners to be more resilient members of society, continuously responding to new demands and change, creating and contributing towards further discovery and innovation. &%23160;An example of a new type of university in contrast to the traditional institutions from the end of the 19th century is the Aalto University in Helsinki where arts and science are combined for greater innovation.

Summary Sentence: Mining firms seek to electrify and decarbonise their facilities.
Justification: Swedish state owned utility firm Vattenfall has signed a deal with an iron ore mining company on the Finnish border, forming a partnership to decarbonise mining operations. Vattenfall will use the development of their onshore wind projects to supply Kaunis Iron with renewable energy, so they can increase electrification of their mining operation and displace the use of fossil fuels. This is a significant development for an industry that has found it difficult to decarbonise due to the remote nature of many of their sites. It is not clear what part of the mining operation will undergo electrification yet as it is still early on in the planning process. This is the third fossil free project for Vattenfall, which is part of a consortium that is developing a site to produce ‘green steel’, and working with another mine to explore electrification of their mining and smelting. Developments to decarbonise mining and steelmaking are also in early stages in Germany with steel-maker Thyssenkrupp and the utility RWE, and Italy’s steel pipe facility Tenaris’s, which is exploring the use of hydrogen at their site. Economic viability will still need to be proved, but the partnership between utility firms and mining and or processing plants suggests that in the future industry could become based in hubs geographically where renewable energy such as wind is more readily available. This could have big implications for landscape and historic industrial inertia. Large scale movement of industry would not only have impacts on the way the Environment Agency regulates these new sites and processes, but would also result in significant resource being needed to ensure the planning is sympathetic to the local environments and biodiversity.
Primary Article Title: Vattenfall wants wind to power fossil-free mining project in Sweden
Keywords: Mine energy renewable carbon decarbonisation wind solar industry planning biodiversity economics social steel chemical waste pollution transition hydrogen resource efficiency industrialisation industry utility electricity&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Governance needs to be improved to ensure the benefits of biodiversity net gain are realised.
Justification: The findings in this initial report although only based on limited evidence suggest that large areas of low quality habitat are being lost and replaced with smaller areas that are planned to be of higher quality, but at a much later stage in the development cycle. The concern is that without proper governance the developers will not be held accountable to follow through with their commitments to create new or enhance existing habitats as this happens so many years later. The authors plan to create a database to track both existing and new commitments in order to monitor the situation. As an operator, regulator and adviser, the Environment Agency have an extensive role in place making and share the ambition for achieving net gain through spatial planning, so may wish to maintain a watching brief on this issue.
Primary Article Title: Mandatory Biodiversity Net Gain may not deliver the desired outcomes for nature
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//policy.friendsoftheearth.uk/publications/net-gain-new-threat-nature
Keywords: Planning development nature biodiversity economics 'habitat loss' 'net gain' ecology research climate extinction "environmental policy' urbanisation 'land management'&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Investments that may finally drive the hydrogen economy.
Justification: The hydrogen economy has been hailed as imminent for a number of years, however recent investments and projects suggests there may be some movement towards this aim. Seven of the largest hydrogen developers have formed a consortium called the Green Hydrogen Catapult initiative, which has the aim to drive down the costs of green hydrogen and increase the scale of production 50 fold in the next six years. Green hydrogen is formed using renewable energy to split water. It is different from grey and blue hydrogen which is produced using fossil fuels, but is currently cheaper. It is hoped this will help to speed up the move to a low carbon economy for hard to abate industries such as shipping, chemicals and steel. The consortium believe that if they can generate green hydrogen below $2/kg it will be the tipping point for the industry as it will become cost competitive against alternative fossil fuel technologies. In other developments, more than 30 countries now have hydrogen strategies, with £billions in investments already committed. The UK is looking at the feasibility of creating a hydrogen super hub port in Southampton, as well as industry initiatives looking at the use of hydrogen in the Zero Humber project. Although both would not involve green hydrogen initially, they could lead to technology advancements as they focus on carbon capture and storage. Sweden is aiming to open a ‘green steel’ production plant by 2024. This will be produced using green hydrogen as an alternative to coking coal. All this could have significant implications for the industries that the Environment Agency regulate, and how they may evolve around these hydrogen producing locations and hubs in the future.
Primary Article Title: Green hydrogen, the fuel of the future, set for 50-fold expansion

Summary Sentence: Increasing commercial activity in space could bring telecommunication opportunities, but may also bring with it environmental degradation - both terrestrial and celestial.&%23160;
Justification: It’s already well established that the planet has a growing space junk issue&%2358; millions of pieces of space debris orbit between 200 to 2,000 kilometres above the Earth’s surface, representing a threat to over 2,000 satellites that currently operating at low earth orbit (LEO). Researchers are now photographing the debris to help prevent collisions. However, some commercial space companies plan to greatly increase the number of satellites, placing thousands more into orbit over the next few years. One company at the forefront of this is Elon Musk’s SpaceX, which is establishing Starlink, a global network of satellite based high-speed internet. Starlink has permission to launch 11,943 satellites, and &%23160;hopes to deploy 4,425 satellites in orbit by 2024, and possibly 40,000 satellites in total. Other companies also have ambitions for this space, including Amazon. Pentago scientists have also been successful in beaming solar energy from space, via Photovoltaic Radiofrequency Antenna Module (PRAM) - similar projects have previously explored the same concept (%23****). Some commentators see parallels between these activities and a Wild West style ‘land grab’. &%23160; Some astronomers are concerned that a blanket of satellites and other objects could hamper observations. While Starlink has taken steps to reduce satellite ‘glare’ on observations, many satellites will remain above a critical brightness threshold, meaning that they could be seen with the naked eye. Light pollution is not a new environmental issue, but this new take on it also challenges notions of heritage and culture as well &%23160;as aesthetics and natural capital&%2358; losing the night sky for the sake of a technological convenience parallels other examples of losing a publicly available good to a luxury saleable item. Many nocturnal animals use the stars to navigate, including moths, frogs and migrating birds. Very little is currently known about how these animals integrate and interpret celestial cues. It is unclear if introducing multiple bright objects to the night sky could impact on these natural processes. There is no doubt a balance between technological utility and environmental protection, as with all emerging technologies&%2358; there may therefore be a role for the Environment Agency and its partners to factor in approaches and technologies in the upper atmosphere into wider environmental systems analyses.
Primary Article Title: What did we lose when we lost the stars?
Author: Sacasas, L.M

Summary Sentence: Perovskite is a promising new compound for use in solar panels and other industrial technologies.
Justification: Current efficiency of solar panels averages around 20%, incorporating perovskite offers the potential of achieving 29%. The costs associated with solar power generation have already dropped significantly over the last decade, so that in many cases it is currently cheaper than the fossil fuel equivalents. Increasing the efficiency of solar panels is only likely to increase this trend. However developments in energy storage will also need to be made to harness the energy generated for use in times of low sunlight and when other renewable technologies are not generating. Perovskite is a naturally occurring mineral, but can also be a synthetic compound with a similar chemical structure. As well as being of interest for solar generation, the compound has characteristic that mean it is of interest for use in the telecommunications and microelectronics sectors as well. It can be generated cheaply and easily, which means that industry is increasingly exploring how to commercialise its use. Some research on the toxicity of breakdown materials from solar cells containing perovskite suggest that aquatic toxicity could be a problem due to the other compounds associated with its use. It is believed that with proper end of life planning, this toxicity can be mitigated. As perovskite becomes increasingly incorporated into other products, the Environment agency may wish to engage with industry now to ensure end of life policies are put in place to make sure it does not become a pollutant of the future. &%23160;&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Solar power world record set with miracle material Perovskite

Summary Sentence: Some companies in the UK and elsewhere are starting to experiment with limitless leave for their employees.&%23160;
Justification: The philosophy for the companies involved is that as working for them is a privilege rather than a punishment then taking time off is not a reward. Advocates of the system note that employees continue to take modest amounts of leave, and employers recognise that the system is an indication of trust in their staff. Such an arrangement may not suit larger companies or be favoured by HR departments. However flexible working arrangements adopted during the coronavirus pandemic have proven popular with workers, with many not wishing to return to the office full time. With this has had to come an increased trust in staff, and a shift along from ‘working at home’ to ‘living at work’. The new found flexibility and trust could mean that the HR landscape is potentially more receptive to new ideas around working arrangements. For some non UK nationals an increased flexibility could mean prolonged periods of working remotely overseas whilst visiting family. Staff with few domestic responsibilities could similarly wish to work from outside of the UK for extended periods of time, and outside of Uk time zones. Management may be unwilling to adopt such a policy. IT security issues may hinder people working from outside of UK infrastructure. Ultimately not adapting limitless leave may mean that people look for employment elsewhere that has greater flexibility. These are just some of the possible consequences. The Environment Agency continues to support flexible working and wishes to be a life affirming place to work - limitless leave may therefore promote these values further.
Primary Article Title: An innovative HR policy to attract staff - unlimited vacation!
Author: Sloane, P
Keywords: employment workforce leave UK overseas coronavirus "remote working" home working employee management "human relations" IT security foreign recruitment Covid-19

Summary Sentence: UK researchers have created material from folded two dimensional graphene that behaves like a transistor, opening up the possibility of creating tiny organic microchips.&%23160;
Justification: This could be of interest to the Environment Agency from a waste management perspective as it could pave the way from electronics with less environmental concerns than those manufactured from rare metals, and also reduce global resource demands due to carbon’s ubiquity. Researchers at the University of Sussex created kinks in a layer of graphene, dubbed “nano-origami”. The kinks modify the electronic properties of the graphene, making electrons flow through it in a manner more akin to logic gate transistors, on which microchip technology is based. “Straintronics” that used folded nanomaterials such as graphene as opposed to electronics could allow for increased processing power inside electronic devices, effectively increasing processing speed. The creation process can occur at room temperature using just graphene, and therefore has the potential to be significantly more energy efficient in production compared to conventional microchips.`
Primary Article Title: Graphene “nano-origami” creates tiniest microchips yet
Author: Vowles, N
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsnano.0c06701
Keywords: waste mineral metal chemistry electronic microchip graphene nano-origami straintronic resources WEEE regulation energy "logic gate" transistor

Summary Sentence: 3D microbial printing has multiple future applications for environment such as biosensing, rare earth-metal recovery, barnacles removal from ships and bioremediation.
Justification:
Research into 3D bioprinting has increased recently as it has been acknowledged that 3D printing can work as a platform for advanced tissue biofabrication, to 3D print human tissues and even organs with controlled precision. The significance for Environment Agency is that now the potential for applications based on this technology is expanding for environmental uses such as biosensing, wastewater treatment and detection of rare or heavy metals, through the invention of a new method for 3D printing living microbes in controlled patterns.

Microbes are indispensable organisms in all ecosystems, yet under-investigated and not much is known in how they function, just that microbial behaviours are extremely complex. This novel culturing technology allows researchers to gain greater control for the patterns forming more than any previous method, allowing them to design communities of microbes in the desired patterns. This enables us to learn more about how microbes behave and function in the natural environment, something that can enable scientists to develop this technology for its many potential uses. When producing 3D-printed microbial patterns, the fabricated biofilms can be as thin as the diameter of a human cell, hence resemble microbes in the natural environment.

The 3D-printed biofilms and engineered bacteria could be utilised for recovery of rare earth metals, wastewater treatment, detection of uranium, removal of barnacles from ships, and for biosensing contaminants, eventually even hopefully the development of engineered living materials.
Primary Article Title: 3D-printed microbes open door to enhanced performance of biomaterials
Author: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

https&%2358;//pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.nanolett.0c04100

Summary Sentence: Marine conservation and supporting oceans recovery could create 100,000 new jobs in the UK by 2050.
Justification:
A new report by WWF and Sky Ocean Rescue suggests that by protecting seas the UK Government could realise the potential of our marine economy, and in the process of boosting it, not just protect the coastal and marine ecosystems but also create 100,000 jobs both offshore and onshore. The economic benefits are estimated to boost the economy by £50 billion by 2050, mainly in the marine renewables sector. The environmental benefits are, in addition to mitigating climate change and ocean recovery, restoring blue and green carbon sinks including habitats such as seagrass meadows, kelp forests and salt marshes, bird and fish habitats including seabeds.

A majority of coastal habitat areas such as salt marshes and carbon sequestrating seagrass meadows have been destroyed, and the report pointed out that UK Government had failed in 11 of 15 indicators relating to marine health. Therefore the report called for stopping industrial trawling and allowing time for recovery of fish stocks to rebuild fisheries after over-fishing and improve regulation of protected areas is especially necessary for the North Sea.

The ‘Value of Restored UK Seas’ report further indicates that the UK should show leadership with COP26 in Glasgow later this year, setting an example by adopting a holistic approach towards restoring both healthy seas and economy, as well as climate recovery and net zero carbon targets. The report was written based on modelling and use of Business as Usual and Recovery scenarios.
Primary Article Title: Protecting UK seas could create thousands of new jobs, says report

Summary Sentence: Super strong self-assembled nanomaterials have multiple future uses including environmental remediation.
Justification:
After years’ of research, MIT has succeeded in creating self-assembling nanoribbon structures, inspired by Kevlar, that are stronger than steel and could have numerous potential applications ranging from removal of heavy metals such as arsenic or lead for water purification and use in electronic devices and batteries.

The small molecular structures created by researchers were further improved by their own highly controlled self-assembling behaviour that guided the molecules to form nanostructures. The nanoribbons have unique robust mechanical properties, this time also able to retain their structure outside water, which was the previous complication in the MIT research. The nanoribbons can support 200 times their own weight and the extremely high surface to mass ratio of 200 square meters for one gram of materials provides great potential opportunities to be utilised in miniaturising technologies.
Primary Article Title: Kevlar-inspired, self-forming nanoribbons are stronger than steel
Author: Lavars, N.

Summary Sentence: A novel environmentally-friendly method for waste water treatment can degrade microplastics at the point of origin.
Justification:
Microplastics are small polymer particles below 5 mm in size and they can enter waste water as microfibres from people’s clothing when being washed, then entering aquatic ecosystems and contaminating them. A new method has been invented to degrade microplastics at source where their concentration is high, by treating them with electrodes whereby electrolytic oxidation breaks these particles down, the benefit being that this process does not require any use of chemicals and breaks them down into carbon dioxide and water molecules with no waste.

Research team achieved a degradation efficiency of 89% when carrying out laboratory tests where water was contaminated with polystyrene. The next step in the research is to conduct tests with this experimental technology at a larger scale and with real water outside laboratory conditions, to find out if it can be adapted for implementation at laundry facilities in future.
Primary Article Title: Eliminating microplastics in wastewater directly at the source
Author: INSTITUT NATIONAL DE LA RECHERCHE SCIENTIFIQUE - INRS

Summary Sentence: The success of recent experiments with bacteria and yeast suggest that engineered living materials could be manufactured in a decentralised production model, as opposed to centralised industrial settings.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as it could suggest new areas of regulation, as well as regulatory applications in environmental monitoring and water treatment. The researchers have been experimenting with a mixture of bacteria and yeast similar to that used in kombucha fermented tea. &%23160;The &%23160;mixture, known as a SCOBY (symbiotic culture of bacteria and yeast), used the bacteria to produce cellulose embedded with enzymes, the latter derived from the yeasts. These enzymes could perform functions including detecting and breaking down target environmental pollutants, or &%23160;“living materials” for use in water purification. The production method is simple enough that it could happen at a localised or even domestic scale. This decentralised biological approach is less &%23160;resource-intensive than centralised manufacturing. The researchers envision that cultures could become customised for different purposes with people growing them at home for water filters or other useful materials&%2358; all that would be needed is sugar, you need tea to provide the nutrients, and a Syn-SCOBY “mother”. There is potential for ‘home grown’ solutions to align with Environment Agency objectives. Equally there may be concerns as to home this technology could be used for purposes that go against objectives, and challenges in regulating this space.
Primary Article Title: Inspired by kombucha tea, engineers create “living materials”
Author: Trafton, A
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.nature.com/articles/s41563-020-00857-5

Summary Sentence: Newly developed calculations could aid the removal of specific and targeted nutrients from wastewater, bringing environmental and economic benefits to the wastewater treatment process.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency as a regulator of waste water discharges as it could provide a means to significantly reduce the impacts of excessive nutrients in the aquatic environment while also providing the means to finance such measures for water companies. Many commercially valuable nutrients remain in wastewater after treatment, such as potassium, nitrogen and phosphorus. Concerns around increasing mineral scarcity and interest in the circular economy are generating interest in mineral recovery from waste water&%2358; phosphate for example is expected to reach its global peak production in the next decade and the remaining world reserves are predicted to be depleted within 50–100 years.An international team of researchers have developed a technique based on capacitive deionization (CDI), already used in desalination, to selectively ‘fish’ for ions of interest from water in an efficient manner, using pursue electrodes made from a range of intercalation materials. New alternative intercalation materials to carbon such as the dye Prussian Blue and its analogues (PBAs), titanium disulphide (TiS2), N-Methylmorpholine N-oxide (NMO) and layered hydroxides showed great potential in inherent selectivity towards certain substances of interest.
Primary Article Title: Separating specific nutrients from wastewater is getting closer and closer

Summary Sentence: Signals are surfacing that may indicate that large oil companies are starting to turn their business models away from oil in response to climate change moving up the political and economic agenda.
Justification:
Europe’s largest oil and gas produces Royal Dutch Shell recently announced that 2019 marked a peak in its production, from which point this will be consciously reduced by up to two per cent annually. Other oil companies have made similar commitments to reducing fossil fuel extraction for climate change related reasons. Changing attitudes to investment in oil and gas may also partly be a factor. This is exemplified by Norway’s $1.3 trillion sovereign wealth fund which recently announced that it was to take a critical look at its holdings in oil and gas from an ethical, rather than an economic perspective, also declaring that oil holdings had underperformed next to holdings in other stocks such as technology companies.
And in the USA an auction for oil rights for drilling in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge generated no interest from major oil companies who are focusing their spending on renewable energy, amid a huge slump in oil prices, in part triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. The lack of interest may also have been linked to the prospect of Joe Biden becoming president&%2358; Mr Biden has since signed executive orders to ban new oil and gas permits on public land, including the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Together these events could suggest that large corporations with oil interests currently are moving into alternative and ‘greener’ sources of revenue. However oil and gas demand may remain for decades to come, suggesting significant changes to business models involving carbon capture and storage and off-setting, or newer, smaller companies coming into the operating space, which may not have the same business models or reputational concerns as established energy companies. This in turn could impact on the influencing aspect of the Environment Agency’s role in regulating this sector.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Shell, in a turning point, says its oil production has peaked

Summary Sentence: Limited number of transnational corporations dominate ocean economy as the economic value of oceans rises, threatening governments’ biodiversity and sustainability objectives.
Justification:
The majority of the revenue extracted from the world’s oceans belongs to just 100 transnational corporations, the “Ocean 100”, who collectively benefited so much from ocean economy that if they were a country, their ranking would have been the 16th largest economy in the world. The relevance to us is that the importance of oceans in the global economy is increasing, and as governments endeavour to work for healthy ocean ecosystems, sustainability, maintaining biodiversity and transparency, large private corporations could have an “ocean stewardship” role to play in this.&%23160;


Eight core industries in the ocean economy were analysed by the researchers&%2358; offshore oil and gas, marine equipment and construction, seafood, container shipments, ship building and repair, tourism such as cruises, any port activities and offshore wind energy. Across all eight industries evaluated, the top ten largest companies received the large majority of the revenue accrued, and approximately a third of high-seas fishing boats are owned by these large corporations.


When it was discovered that just one German chemical company now owns 47% of patented marine gene sequences as their intellectual property, this inevitably alarmed many concerned parties. In this case, the question is for the ownership of biodiversity and centralised or monopolised ownership or a common resource, with companies that have headquarters in just a few countries controlling marine genes, which are of importance to the entire world.&%23160;


Ocean economy and centralised ownership issue is also connected to wider geopolitical interests such as China’s interest to gain a foothold in Northern Europe and Arctic; centralised private land ownership in the UK; and reduction in the portion of black farmers’ land ownership in the USA agriculture.&%23160;
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Majority of ocean revenue is dominated by just 100 companies

Summary Sentence: Japan has set out its intentions towards ammonia fuel for the next decade.
Justification:
Japan has previously set ambitious goals for becoming a hydrogen economy (%23*****), to which ammonia could make a significant contribution as an energy storage medium. The Japanese government aims to boost the country’s demand for ammonia fuel to three million tonnes by 2030, creating a new supply chain in a bid to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and contribute to the country’s ambitions in this space - previously Japan has claimed that it is certain to reach carbon neutrality by 2050. Japan currently uses 1.08 million tonnes of ammonia for fertiliser and industrial materials, 80% of which is produced locally. They will have to increase this to 3 million tonnes a year by 2030, which means establishing an international supply chain. They also hope that unit prices will also reduce as imports increase to 30 million tonnes by 2050. Japan’s biggest power generator JERA plans to pilot an ammonia fuel mix at its coal-fired power plants, becoming mainstream by 2035. It should be noted that if all of Japan’s coal-fired plants use ammonia for 20% of their fuel source the volume of ammonia needed would equate to the World’s current trade volume per year, demonstrating the ambition in this plan. Japan hopes to export the technology it develops through embracing ammonia fuel, which may in turn lead to greater adoption in other parts of the World. However, the energy intensive nature of ammonia production would also imply that green ammonia production would be a key part of this strategy. Greater uptake also implies a greater regulatory role for the Environment Agency as ammonia is an air pollutant of note for its environmental impacts.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Japan aims to boost ammonia fuel demand to 3 mln tonnes a year by 2030
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.ammoniaenergy.org/articles/meti-forms-ammonia-energy-council/

Summary Sentence: Microsoft could be adding more sophistication to the technology it has already developed to ‘score’ employee performance.
Justification: Microsoft has already developed a system that allows employers to generate a “productivity score” based on an employees use of Microsoft 365. The system has sparked criticism from privacy campaigners for enabling “workplace surveillance” due to the ability to track behaviour to an individual level. A recently filed patent outlines a system whereby tracking takes place through direct monitoring of people’s behaviour during a meeting. Cameras and other sensors gather data on body language, level of contribution, facial expressions, room temperature, time of day, and number of people in the meeting. The system uses these to generate an “overall quality score” to reflect the productiveness of the meeting. It must be stressed that this is a patent filing and not a product in development. The concept however does raise interesting questions for all employers, including the Environment Agency as to how to balance the need for greater productivity, efficiency and staff well-being that digital data offers, with the need to respect data privacy, which may become a more prevalent workplace concern in an increasingly digital working environment.
Primary Article Title: Microsoft patents tech to score meetings using body language, facial expressions, other data
Author: Bishop, T
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.theguardian.com/technology/2020/nov/26/microsoft-productivity-score-feature-criticised-workplace-surveillance
Keywords: workforce employer employee data protection privacy productivity Microsoft patent meeting score "body language" monitoring algorithm health and safety

Summary Sentence: Some innovative pathways for producing hydrogen for fuel are emerging from recent experimentation with algae and waste plastic.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may have a role in regulating this emerging energy sector and therefore should be interested in understanding processes, particularly if they coincide with other regulatory activity such as waste management. Scientists have discovered that algae compressed together in water droplets produce hydrogen instead of oxygen through natural photosynthesis.Because there isn’t sufficient oxygen atoms for photosynthesis to occur, hydrogen-yielding enzymes take over instead.While still in very early stages the discovery could be refined to improve hydrogen fuel cells and ultimately create an environmentally benign approach to hydrogen production. Another project has led to a faster, cleaner, one step process that converts plastic into clean hydrogen that could be used as fuel. Plastic pieces were broken down with catalysts of iron oxide and aluminum oxide. The mixture was then heated in a microwave, leading to the plastics releasing 97 per cent of their hydrogen molecules in mere seconds, leaving a residue consisting of mainly carbon nanotubes, which could have commercial value. The experiment used only 300 grams of plastic, so is not yet at a stage for commercial use. However the realisation of such a process at an industrial scale could have implications for waste management and emissions to air, and is therefore relevant to the Environment Agency.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Scientists turn plastic into hydrogen by microwaving It
Author: Lang, F

Summary Sentence: Atmospheric moisture harvested for drinking water with a novel MOF-polymer hybrid matrix.
Justification:
National University of Singapore research team has developed an aerogel to harvest water from the atmospheric moisture, which in itself is not a new technology, but the scientific innovation is that the process does not require any external power source such as battery, electricity or solar power, or any complicated moving parts in its simple design. The aerogel provides a sustainable source of high standard drinking water in arid regions or anywhere where water supply is not adequate.&%23160;
The fundamental part of the design to offer its water-capturing capacity is the metal-organic framework combined with hydro-active polymer that enables the material perform both sorption and desorption. When tested, this polymer-MOF matrix aerogel provided water continuously for months at an efficiency of 95%, making it a top performer in atmospheric water harvesting technologies.
The scientists have invited contacts from industry to manufacture aerogel for domestic or industrial use for a larger scale launch in the future, with potential usage for outdoor sports such as endurance races or survival kits. What is beyond the scope of the article is whether a large scale use of aerogels could impact weather patterns when a considerable amount of water was removed, and what is the quantity to make a difference to weather conditions.
&%23160;
Primary Article Title: NUS engineers create ‘smart’ aerogel that turns air into drinking water
Author: National University of Singapore

Summary Sentence: New fungal materials emerging as alternative for buildings, textiles, environmental monitoring and biowearables.
Justification: Fungi and fungal materials are emerging in many areas as sustainable resources that are capable of biosensing and information processing, therefore offer endless possibilities from smart biowearables to self-growing and self-healing construction with “myco-materials”, and environmental monitoring by fungal networks. The significance to Environment Agency is that fungal materials have interesting qualities such as sustainability, durability, reparability and adaptability and as 21% of carbon dioxide emissions come from the making of steel and concrete, fungal materials could enable the move away from concrete. The research provides critical evidence for a potential to radically rethink architecture and construction industry; perhaps even move away from the permanence of our buildings to be shorter term and then finally recycled. Fungal materials can be used to create small modules such as bricks, as isolation materials between the walls and are useful because they can repair damage and behave in a self-healing manner. Fungi as construction material combines embedded artificial intelligence with eco-friendliness, low repair costs and eventually recycling of all materials. But this can be taken one step further, as NASA is exploring ways to build bases for human settlement on the Moon and Mars. The researchers found that mycelium networks are capable of information processing similar to computers and can sense and process environmental stimuli, for instance light, temperature, electrical signals and presence of chemical substances. This biosensor property can be utilised in producing textiles and smart biowearable devices such as mobile phones or growing fungi largescale to monitor an entire ecosystem.

Summary Sentence: Spin waves can revolutionise computer technology; how information is processed and transmitted.
Justification:
Spin waves are used to develop the next generation of computer systems as they can carry a far greater quantity of information that our current computers and require less energy and components to do it. This is relevant to our work because currently vast majority of information is processed and transmitted by photons or electric currents whereas computers or other devices using processing based on spin waves accomplish the same tasks more efficiently, with less power, fewer components and with a faster speed. Instead of processing information as binary, spin waves based devices utilise neuromorphic computing, meaning they process data in a similar way as a human brain.

Quanta (unit for package of electromagnetic energy) of spin waves is called magnons, and their parameters are amplitude (wave height) and phase (wave angle); these waves are made by distortions of magnetic materials on the quantum level of these solid materials, like a ripple effect. This is what makes these type of computers more practical and energy-efficient. Through this innovative technology, using learning from quantum mechanics, particle physics, microelectronics and photonics to further develop computers, spin waves can change computer technology.&%23160;
Primary Article Title: Spin Waves for next-generation computing

Summary Sentence: A drone has successfully completed a test flight carrying freight from mainland England to the Isles of Scilly.
Justification: The Environment Agency may be interested in similar applications to its activities in logistics and transport. The drone, which is similar in appearance to a light aircraft, but much smaller, took off from Land’s End airport carrying NHS supplies, landing at St Mary’s airport, then returned carrying gin and flowers, a 60 mile round trip in total. Trials are continuing, but an operational service carrying urgent supplies and small scale freight could be running in two years. Unmanned flights reportedly generate 98 per cent less emissions than manned flights. The company behind this project is called Flylogix. The Environment Agency may wish to consider similar applications, for example in transporting urgent and essential equipment to field staff, shipping water quality samples for analysis, surveying and observation,&%23160;amongst other applications.
Primary Article Title: Drone completes first freight flight to Isles of Scilly
Keywords: transport drone UAV "unmanned aerial vehicle" Isles Scilly "Land's End" air aeroplane logistics freight monitoring sample surveying observation regulation FlyLogix NHS

Summary Sentence: A newly developed membrane that can separate out crude oil fractions could help reduce carbon emissions and energy associated with fossil fuel refining.
Justification: This development should be of interest to the Environment Agency as it is a regulator of the sector. Membrane technology can be used to separate molecules based on their size and is already widely used in other sectors such as desalination. The complexity of petroleum refining has prevented similar applications until now. The new polymer based membrane separates complex hydrocarbon mixtures using pressure rather than heat. It has tested well with deriving a range of products such as jet fuel and diesel from a crude oil mixture. Crude oil refining accounts for nearly one per cent of the world’s energy use. Employing technologies like this could signify reductions in environmental impact of the refinery sector, and may have associated regulatory, advisory and influencing implications for the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: New membrane could cut emissions and energy use in oil refining
Author: Brogan, C

Summary Sentence: Innovative terahertz technology project in Denmark can increase sorting purity of recycled plastics.
Justification:
&%23160;

An innovative R&D project at Aarhus University in cooperation with the Danish waste industry aims to recycle plastics according to the polymer types using terahertz technology that addresses problems with separation accuracy for plastics. The goal is recycling plastics with a plastic purity of at least 96 per cent by polymer type and sorting according to unwanted colours, filler materials, and other characteristics. Traceability in the circular economy is improved by the use of Artificial intelligence controlling the separation process, using three different type of cameras&%2358; a CMOS camera, a hyperspectral camera and a terahertz camera, that take images of the plastic recycled materials as they move along the conveyor-belt, continuously assessing the properties of the plastic material. This innovative technology has the potential to considerably escalate the purity of recycled plastic waste, and the reason why this is so significant to Environment Agency is because of our circular economy objectives and because Britain is one of the biggest producers of plastic waste in the world, exporting most of it, with export to poorer countries impacting our reputation.
Primary Article Title: Intelligent camera technology to revolutionize plastics recycling

Summary Sentence: AI and robotics are transforming farming with potential ethical and socio-equity implications.
Justification: Researchers from Australia’s Monash University detect conceivable ethical concerns rising from transformation of future farming with new technologies such as agricultural robots and artificial intelligence, potentially also leading to negative consequences to the environment by poor management of chemicals, soil and food waste in the search of perfect products in perfect time to maximise profits. As the future of farming, especially precision farming, is increasingly becoming automated and traditional methods are replaced by Artificial Intelligence, there is apprehension among researchers and farmers that smaller farms cannot afford AI or robotics and hence will not be able to keep up with the bigger ones, leading to socio-equity questions. There are fears about security and cyber-attacks to hack AI systems, robotics intensifying agriculture further to the detriment of biodiversity, robot welfare eventually dominating animal welfare, and prospective centralisation of ownership in agriculture. Therefore public concerns must be addresses and consideration must be given to the social and political impacts from this change. Facial Recognition technology (FRT) systems have already attracted attention of large data-handling companies such as Alibaba and Tencent in China, making them turn to agricultural production for the first time due to its importance in the economic sector. Farming with FRT has already proved to increase profits and as world’s population increases with urgency to increase food production, for example China’s pork industry is predicted to increase, there is an opportunity for significant profits to be made here.
Primary Article Title: Ethical problems may arise with farm robotics, study says
Author: FarmingUK Team

Summary Sentence: Replacing empty retail space and urban wastelands with rewilding will support goals of going carbon neutral.
Justification: Nottingham has an ambitious plan to become UK’s first carbon neutral city and as part of the actions is looking to go beyond urban green parks to wildscaping, creating wilder greener spaces. That will inevitably create concerns whether using an infrastructure suited for example for urban farming is best utilised by demolishing it for rewilding, and what the actual carbon costs of the project would be. Nevertheless, in this case, the plan for the vacant 70s Broadmarsh shopping centre is evidence of the change in the residents’ values and what they want to see in the urban landscape. Interestingly, this may be the first stage in a new type of town planning to radically increase habitats such as wetlands, wooded areas and wildflower meadows in the urban areas to go carbon neutral, utilising grubby waste lands and post-Covid empty retail spaces. The local authority together with Nottinghamshire Wildlife Trust proposed this new rewilding model for city regeneration and Nottingham could be creating a model of a new wilder greener vision for other cities to follow, rethinking the urban design.
Primary Article Title: Going wild? A radical green plan for Nottingham's unloved shopping centre

Summary Sentence: Geobacter wrapping itself in toxic cobalt for survival  has implications for recycling and remediation.
Justification:
&%23160;

A small team of scientists at Michigan State University have challenged conventional thinking by demonstrating with laboratory testing that microbes such as bacteria species Geobacter sulfurreducens has the ability to survive toxic cobalt by coating themselves in it rather than letting it penetrate their cells for destruction. This capable bacteria could be developed for a novel biotechnology; used to limit dependency on foreign cobalt, valuable but increasingly rare metal, by recycling it from electric vehicle lithium-ion batteries and alloys for spacecraft, or for environmental remediation. The next stage of the research is to investigate whether Geobacter could also be used in a similar way to absorb cadmium, another toxic metal that is associated with industrial pollution. In this case, it is also interesting to note that the research project lead was thinking out of the box and therefore the researchers almost did not receive funding, as others could not see the connection between their work with microbes and any impact on environment.

Summary Sentence: Excavated soils should be reused in circular economy rather than categorised as waste and taken to landfills.
Justification: Demand to accelerate transition to a circular economy, where everything should have a reuse value, has made the classification of excavated soils as waste, to be taken to be disposed of at landfill sites, a real issue to be changed at the European level. The significance to Environment Agency is that as circular economy is built on renewable materials, it seems an inefficient policy to consider excavated soils from construction sites as waste, especially as 80 per cent of the soils are not contaminated in any way but could be utilised somewhere else. Soils from construction sites are the largest source of waste in volume produced in Europe yet governments are only now realising what a major issue this is, requiring urgent attention. In most countries in Europe the soils in question equal five times the volume of all household waste. There could be a launch of a national database to ensure a better traceability system and in order to promote circular economy, particularly as it could potentially be very cost-effective at construction sites, cutting down waste transport needs. Moving to low carbon cement for construction needs is not enough but by addressing excavated soils and their reuse and transport construction companies can save approximately 7-8% in carbon costs.
Primary Article Title: Excavated soils&%2358; The biggest source of waste you’ve never heard of
Author: Simon, F.
