Summary Sentence: Road construction and associated materials should be more sustainable in future.
Justification:
Road construction design and related materials have remained unchanged for a long time and therefore researchers are investigating how to make the materials and process more sustainable and environmentally friendly, and in the process also reduce noise pollution linked to human health issues and make pavements safer with falls. The interest for Environment Agency is that public agencies tend to choose materials based on short-term costs of road construction and filling potholes rather than environmental concerns and considerable reduction in emissions and pollutants, and long-term costs including road maintenance. This tendency acts as a barrier to reducing environmental impacts originating from roads, highways and pavements.

The developments in road materials means substituting conventional materials such as limestone aggregate or adding recycled materials such as plastics or powdered glass into the mix. This change alters the characteristics of pavements such as stiffness, reflectivity and porosity, composition and stiffness, with varying implications to behaviour, road wear and traffic. Paved surface emit organic pollutant compounds especially during hot weather, and hot sunny days will increase with climate change. Changing materials and their composition can make pavements become less icy during the winter months and thus prevent impacts from slips and falls. Most of the noise originates from the vehicle tires and reducing vibration in tires reduces noise from traffic and a porous pavement can even help absorb noise.
Primary Article Title: Realizing the roads of the future

Summary Sentence: Earthworm-inspired robots can be used to collect data from below ground to predict above ground crop production.
Justification:
New York's Cornell University is running a project to develop agricultural robots for soil analysis, inspired by earthworm activities, to gain a better understanding of activities below ground such as the complexities of plant and soil interactions, soil properties, chemicals and water. The relevance to Environment Agency is that this could be used not only for soil monitoring but also potentially in incident management and soil remediation work. This novel technology can give us a great deal of information about the below-ground environment of plants and soil characteristics and interactions, such as roots growth, water properties and soil microbiome.
The robots are one to two foot long and as they burrow into the ground, they copy the wriggling movement of earthworms as they move, creating an underground tunnel. As they move, integrated sensors take measurements of temperature and humidity, recording the data ready to download when returned to the surface. As they burrow, they already can collate data on soil density and compactness. Fibre optic cable can take images of roots and record micro-organism activity and measure carbon compounds released by plant roots.
The project is currently focused on maize crops, testing the robots along the planted rows, to collect data on how the roots grow, since root growth is a key indicator in understanding how plants adapt to water availability and hence enhances understanding or corn plants’ stress tolerance, how they cope with drought and other effects of climate change. This data is utilised in soil management, plant breeding and genetics for further crop production and food security as researchers use predictive models to predict above ground properties based on below ground properties.
Primary Article Title: Worm-like, soil-swimming robots to explore crop underworld

Summary Sentence: Hydrogen-Metal Energy (HME) is a potential new carbon free energy source.
Justification: An EU Horizon 2020 sponsored work stream is investigating the potential of a little known zero-emissions energy technology based on Hydrogen-Metal and plasma. HME has the potential to be used in both private and industrial systems. HME is generated when hydrogen under pressure and increased temperature reacts with certain metals. The energy produced during this process is many times higher than the energy needed to create it. If renewable energy can be used to facilitate the start of the process, it has the potential to be a carbon free. As well as being explored in Europe, the technology is also being investigated by USA, Canada, Japan and China.
Primary Article Title: Exploring a new source of clean energy with CleanHME
Keywords: Energy hydrogen EU carbon emissions research

Summary Sentence: The fifth Lancet countdown report on climate change and human health highlights increasing inequality, with the most vulnerable shouldering the greatest risk.
Justification: Environmental justice is a growing concern in relation to climate change, with advocates highlighting the disparity of risks between the most vulnerable and those that have the resources to adapt. This report highlights that the gap between the most vulnerable and those with capacity to adapt has continued to increase. In the last 20 years heat related deaths in the over 65’s have increased by over 50%, during the same time wildfire risk has increased in over 114 countries. Climate change related deaths and health problems are now being experienced all over the world. Climate change has been linked to an increase in the risk of diseases with pandemic potential. Therefore global Covid19 recovery plans need to be equally aligned to tackle the climate crisis so that the risk of further human pandemics is reduced.
Primary Article Title: Exposure of vulnerable to heat reached new record in 2019, says Lancet

Summary Sentence: New advancement in robot crop-harvesting technology will eventually replace agricultural labour.
Justification:
A robotic platform, which can be fitted with an agricultural implement of choice, has been designed as part of the ongoing robot harvesting technology project in Devon and Cornwall where the availability of seasonal and farm labour has been an issue for some time. The implications to Environment Agency are that the deficit in available agricultural and seasonal labour as one of the EU Exit consequences could open up a space for these type of robotic technologies to move into sooner in the future, and doing so might result in increased agricultural efficiencies and changed environmental impacts.
This new agricultural -technology invention called Robotriks Traction Unit (RTU) was launched to replace agricultural labourers, especially for harvesting vegetables and soft-fruit, with the next stage looking into Brassica harvesting. Hence it answers a demand in agriculture.
It can provide an affordable and reliable with no worry for health and safety, transforming future sustainability of farming, keeping small farms going as it has been tested in real life situations and environmental impacts such as compaction of soil have been accounted for. Robotriks RTU costs less than a tenth of the current products available but some further development is required before it can be commercially available.

Summary Sentence: Flying taxi service will operate in Spain in 2022.
Justification:
A new stage has been achieved towards urban air mobility as the first air taxi Volocopters are planned to fly in Barcelona and Santiago de Compostela in 2022. The relevance to us is potential impacts on the environment as Vertical Aerospace in Bristol has revealed plans for 'flying taxi' to carry up to four passengers between London and Brighton in near future and there is also a European urban air mobility project with Enaire, planned to fly in Cranfield and Amsterdam.
Enaire, the air navigation manager in Spain, is at the forefront of the new sector in urban transport, has stated that they plan to carry it out in as efficient and sustainable way as possible but it is not yet known exactly how the air taxis utilised will operate or look like. However, the prototype used for demonstrations in 2019 was a pilot-less air taxi, designed to carry one passenger or deliver goods up to 150kg. The expectation is for the air taxis to fly above the traffic, 100-300 metres in the air, with speeds of up to 150 miles per hour and in ideal circumstances a maximum range of 100 miles, normally covering cover distances of up to 15km – in 15 minutes. The flying taxis use only electricity so there should be no emissions or noise, and they are tested to comply with safety legislation.

Summary Sentence: Genetically modified organisms by the use of synthetic and systems biology could help us in tackling climate change.
Justification:
Using synthetic and systems biology (SSB) is a novel strategy to support activities towards mitigating climate change as genetically engineered organisms (GMOs) can potentially benefit us by reducing atmospheric carbon. The relevance to Defra is that deployment of SSB brings new possibilities to the current land management practices in the UK and this has many environmental and economic advantages which makes it worth consideration although there is likely to be resistance on ethical grounds.
Researchers suggest creating an effective plan as a high priority for a large collaborative engineering project between countries to utilise SSB in tackling the climate change and recommend a less fragmented and better articulated approach in future. Nonetheless, manipulating ecosystems using biotechnology takes us to an unknown territory which necessitates careful consideration for weighing risks and opportunities. Therefore it is sensible to start with smaller scale experiments before large scale ecosystem manipulation, as this enables gaining a better understanding of biological engineering including preparing for unintended consequences.
Some of the potential ideas presented in the research paper are plants engineered to reduce carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, plants engineered to self-fertilise or plants being genetically modified to enhance their biomass and root architecture, and bacteria engineered to decrease atmospheric methane.
These methods sound promising but lead to many unknowns, especially to the field of philosophy and religion, with political and ethical concerns about who carries the burden of responsibility in case of detrimental results, and it can be very challenging to gain public acceptance.
Primary Article Title: Engineering a way out of climate change&%2358; Genetically modified organisms could be the key

Summary Sentence: Rolls-Royce plans to deliver sixteen new small modular reactors to support our net zero carbon objective and to make green and reliable nuclear power affordable.
Justification:
The UK Small Modular Reactor consortium (UK SMR) together with Rolls-Royce and their small modular reactor (SMR) group have announced plans to build up to 16 mini-nuclear plants in the UK, first one to be operational within ten years, as part of Government’s objective of net zero carbon ambition.

This links to Environment Agency and our decarbonisation targets as the government points toward new nuclear seen as a green energy option and being essential if the UK is to meet its target of reaching net zero emissions by 2050, rather than increasing investment in hydrogen or geothermal power.

After the project has built the first mini-unit in the next ten years, they aim to have another until built every two years, creating employment markets and opportunity for export of this know-how as part of government’s green plan for economic recovery. Instead of building very few very large nuclear power stations, the idea is that smaller projects are cheaper, less complicated, and provide opportunities to learn and adjust easier than massive projects. Hence they are able to fill the gap in electricity supply better as the 20 % of our electricity is provided by our seven nuclear reactor sites; six of which are due to go offline by 2030 and the seventh, Sizewell B, is due to be decommissioned five years later.

Summary Sentence: Alternative drinking water can be supplied by using a metal-organic framework to desalinate seawater with sunlight.
Justification:
Researchers from Monash University in Australia have developed a new breakthrough technology&%2358; a more environmentally friendly and low-cost method of desalinating brackish water and seawater into clean drinking water using an extremely porous material with high surface area called metal-organic framework, with sunlight for energy. The relevance to us is that access to safe and sufficient water supply of fresh drinking water is a challenge in many countries, including the UK in future and MOF can provide a sustainable efficient solution for desalination.
This adsorbent technology acts in 30 minutes, faster than other methods, using less energy, to filter harmful particles from water. It can be swiftly cleaned for reuse by placing it in daylight, to release the collected salts in only four minutes of exposure to sunlight. The experiments achieved to reach the World Health Organization threshold for good quality drinking water. Treated desalinised water can be integrated with existing water systems with marginal health risks, which accentuates the applications and possibilities not only for clean and ecological water solutions for future but also for more sustainable mineral extraction and mining practices.
Primary Article Title: Highly efficient process makes seawater drinkable in 30 minutes

Summary Sentence: Advances in gene editing therapy look promising after the first stage of human trials for hereditary blood diseases is completed.
Justification:
There has been a fundamental shift in the effectiveness of highly experimental gene editing therapy with CRISPS Therapeutics conducting the first human subject trials outside China, for hereditary blood diseases, as the promising early clinical data has been published. In the first phase of the trials, after fifteen months of work, CRISPS therapy reveals remarkable ability treating two rare genetic blood diseases; sickle cell disease and beta thalassemia.
The preliminary results from the experiment demonstrate a cure for people with these hereditary conditions as five people with beta-thalassemia and two with sickle cell disease had been treated with the CRISPR therapy. The early evidence indicates that up to now the patients were able to produce mature red blood cells after the stem cells which were genetically edited had been transplanted back into them. This is called engraftment and no complications have so far been identified which is yet promising early evidence of the durability of the therapeutic effect for the patients and researchers getting closer to their goal of transformative change in health for everyday quality of life.

Summary Sentence: Change in use and design of shared public indoor spaces is instigated&%23160;towards minimising risk and increasing self-containment since Covid-19 epidemic.
Justification: In the months following the emergence of covid-19 the use of shared public indoor spaces has become impregnated with risk, with direct consequences for the EA. The prospect of contracting the virus from unknown others who may not be visibly symptomatic has radically altered the way we approach previously unquestioned spaces, changing and limiting their ability to fulfil the functions for which they were designed. In this way the hither too unconsidered ways in which the built environment assumes and requires a level of immunity to the micro-biological world around us has been drawn out and exposed for all to see. The resulting juxtaposition of the need to ‘get on’ with our everyday lives with the need for us to remain safe has opened up a new space for innovation that is re-working how indoor spaces are arranged and function. In east London entrepreneur Xu Weiping has created an indoor office comprised of individual 3 x 3 metre cubes that ‘contain’ each employee by removing the need for them to move around. Each space contains its own toilet and basic kitchenette, as well as workspace, so the range of needs an office normally fulfils can be serviced individually. At the same time the Arrival bus company has designed a modular interior for one of its new electric models, allowing its internal space to be flexibly re-organised to accommodate social distancing. In South Korea a new bus shelter is being made safe by technology that takes the temperature of entrants, and refuses access to anybody with an abnormally high reading. This developing trajectory in indoor space innovation is important to the EA as an employer with its own office spaces, and a proportion of employees who may rely on public transport to get to work.
Primary Article Title: South Korea installs anti-virus bus shelters with temperature sensors and UV lamps

Summary Sentence: Bricks and construction materials could be molded from recycled materials.
Justification: Scientists in Australia have developed a new method of pressure molding polymers into building bricks – reactive compression molding. Their work shows that when polymers that have previously undergone inverse vulcanisation are subject to heat and pressure they can be used to bind various ‘filler’ materials into structurally useable shapes. That opens the way to constructing building bricks out of a range of waste materials like plant fibres, sand or recycled PVC. As such it could be important step towards a circular economy, where materials that might otherwise have gone to landfill can be combined to make them economically useful once more. It may also displace processes like cement production that emit significant amounts of carbon dioxide. All of this is important to the EA as a waste regulator that could need to concern itself with the production and disposal of these new materials, and a proponent of climate change mitigation and adaptation.

Summary Sentence: Technological innovations are making farming smarter for crop production and livestock monitoring via wireless sensors.
Justification:
Researchers and engineers from different disciplines are producing technological innovations that could lead to improvements in farming methods and, as a consequence, increased resource efficiency. Collectively these developments are being termed ‘precision farming’. They’re important to the EA because they could eventually lead to reduced agricultural demand for water and application of water polluting substances, such as fertiliser. In one example a collective of European farmers is working alongside technologists to introduce smart sensors onto their farms. The sensors have multiple uses, one of which is being attached to the ears of dairy cattle. When used in conjuction with automated feeding systems they can enable famers to identify when each cow feeds and the exact quantity of nutrients it takes in. Preliminary data points to improved diets and, in turn, a greater quality and quantity of milk production as a result. A second set of sensors are being attached to crop plants to monitor their immediate environmental conditions and health. Where a crop is lacking nutrients, water, or any other required resource, farmers can be alerted quickly and shown exactly where deficiencies lie in the field. They then need to use less resource to resolve the problem than they otherwise might have done using a less targeted approach.
Separately from the sensors, agronomists are also making advances in understanding how crop planting patterns can impact yield. In a large meta-study of available evidence, researchers in north-eastern China determined that uniform spatial planting patterns have the potential to result in improved crop yields and reduced weed production. At the moment crops are kept fairly uniform distances apart between rows, but within each row seeds can fall randomly resulting in a mix of patterns. However, when instead they are placed at equal distances apart along a row, to form a grid pattern, average crop yields rise by 20%. Average weed production in several studies also fell by 30%. The implication is that the same amount of crop could eventually be raised on less land, using less water and other treatments.
Primary Article Title: How crop and animal sensors are making farming smarter

Summary Sentence: Orbital use fees are suggested to regulate space debris – could this potentially be our future remit?
Justification: Economists in the US have proposed a new set of regulations for space travel intended to combat the issue of growing amounts of space debris. Currently operators are required to pay a launch fee designed to dis-incentivise unnecessary entry into space, but once in orbit operators have no further incentive to return their craft to earth or dispose of it properly. To address this gap a new orbital use fee is proposed – charging operators on the basis of the continued occupation of an orbit. If the craft is abandoned in orbit as debris then the charges continue. The proposal points to the continued development of space as a used and valued part of our environment. In doing so opens up a range of questions for the EA around the role it should be playing in developing the regulatory framework for use and protection of the space environment. Is space a part of our environment and, if it is, then how do we protect it? If it isn’t how can we protect the terrestrial environment from the potentially new and complex waste streams that could emerge from it in the coming years?
Primary Article Title: Could orbital fees force satellite operators to deal with space junk?

Summary Sentence: Big data is analysed to tackle variable crop yields and vulnerability in Midwest United States.
Justification: Researchers at Michigan State University have become the first to employ big data techniques to identify how and why crops are vulnerable to periods of water excess and deficit across the US. They analysed an array of data from satellites, research aircraft, drones, remote sensors and the geospatial sensors on modern combine harvesters to determine the variables most strongly associated with reduced yields. They found that the position of a crop within the landscape and the soil type it was growing in were key. Micro variations in terrain like depressions, summits and slopes determined how water moved through a crop and were associated with two-thirds of the zones of ‘unstable’ yield production identified. The findings are being presented in the form of yield stability maps that can be used to inform local adaptive practices. The implication for the environment agency is that the ‘big data’ methodological approach can be used to generate similar maps in the UK. That could have implications for water resource consumption and fertiliser use across a wide area.
Primary Article Title: Big data helps farmers adapt to climate variability

Summary Sentence: Bayesian data analysis methods can be used for enhanced detection of water leaks in water distribution networks.
Justification: Statisticians have developed a statistical approach that could help reduce leakage from the water pipe network. The availability of future water resources is a top priority for the Environment Agency, including in its capacity as a regulator of the water industry. Water loss through leaks in the pipe network accounts for a substantial proportion total water consumed and reducing it is therefore a priority cross the sector. At the moment leaks are detectable through a system of pressure gauges along the pipes, but being able to precisely identify the location of a leak is a barrier to being able to deal with it in a timely and economic manner. Operators often use what are termed ‘hammer tests’ to narrow down their location. The flow in a pipe is abruptly halted and the resulting shock wave is monitored as it propagates back up through the pipe. Statistical techniques are then used to interpret the data and narrow down the possible area the leak could be in. At the moment that’s a slow computational process conducted by computers and accuracy is a problem. To improve it statisticians at Stanford have now developed a Bayesian approach that both improves the accuracy of the end results and significantly reduces the amount of computational time required to get there. The implication is that leaks could be found quicker and more precisely located. That operational teams on the ground spend have to spend less time digging and less water lost.
Primary Article Title: A better way to detect underground water leaks
Author: Stanford's School of Earth, Energy & Environmental Sciences
Secondary_URLs: Application to Leak Detection in Transmission Mains

Summary Sentence: New technology enables energy generation using "solar power skins”.
Justification: Researchers at the University of Queensland have set a new world record for the amount of electricity generated using quantum ‘dots’. Their achievement marks a significant step forwards in efforts to develop solar ‘skins’ that could be placed on ordinary surfaces, in order to turn them into sites of energy generation. Where current solar energy generation takes place in rigid cells that are cumbersome and fragile, quantum dots can simply be printed on to different types of surface, including flexible ones. Technology of this sort could eventually hold the potential to drive a radical shift in energy generation, away from central or even local power stations, towards a device centric arrangement. If that were to happen it could have important consequences for the EA in terms of the track of future energy requirements, with implications for carbon emissions and water resource use. There may also be resource and waste implications, particularly around how to dispose of these devices and how to separate out the materials they’re made of. At the moment the technology isn’t commercially viable, which is why the reported increases in efficiency reported by the Queensland team are so significant.
Primary Article Title: New world record for conversion of solar energy to electricity using quantum dots

Summary Sentence: Concerns for China’s influence on internet regulation indicate a need for regulatory data privacy framework.
Justification: US technology companies have been hostile to the development of regulatory frameworks designed to structure the use of online space Link to %2315082. But in recent months Mark Zuckerberg has signalled a shift in Facebook’s posture towards regulators on the international stage. His comments point towards a stance of cooperation with European officials who have concerns around the impact of social media on the blocks democratic and market processes. Facebook’s position frames the issue in terms of competing international models of regulation, notably with China. Inherent in these discussions is the acceptance that an international system of online regulation is now both necessary and that different visions of what it should look like are already under construction. Such a regime is likely to have an important impact on the way online spaces develop, what they’re used for and by who, across the globe. It potentially opens up a new space for governance processes at the global scale, and the failure to settle on any single system might give rise to new forms of global division. All this is likely to have a considerable impact on the environment the EA operates within.
Primary Article Title: Mark Zuckerberg ‘worried’ about China’s influence on internet regulation

Secondary_URLs:

Summary Sentence: Circular economy may threaten our privacy and data security as large tech companies handle our data.
Justification:
Our goal of a circular economy is dependent on a complete true life cycle management at all stages, from source to final use and disposal, which requires data collection and storage with digital technologies, to ensure lifelong responsibility of the materials. Yet data protection may become an obstacle for circular economy as the data and data ownership accumulated may threaten our privacy if hacked or misused, for example for personalised advertising.

The large tech companies that are most capable to handle these Cloud applications are Microsoft and Amazon who have partnered with large industrial companies to bring profits and efficiencies, not just environmental benefits.

For car manufacturing industry, Amazon Web Services has co-operated with Volkswagen to track all of the components and share data and similarly, Microsoft enables BMW to track throughout the supply chain.
This has inevitably raised serious concerns for data ownership, potential data breaches and security, privacy, as well these big tech companies monetising the data they collate of consumer behaviour and gaining unprecedented power. Many drivers may not be aware that their movements are tracked and may not be willing to trade off their privacy for environmental gain so perhaps the car manufacturers could offer opt-out clauses or change the way they handle the data or dispose of it in the end, or have policies in place to be regulated by external bodies to do this.
Primary Article Title: A circular economy could end waste – at the cost of our privacy
Author: Walton, N. and Chinnaswamy, A.
Secondary_URLs:
https&%2358;//environmentjournal.online/articles/a-circular-economy-could-cost-our-privacy/

Summary Sentence: New type of shielding fabrics can protect people from electromagnetic radiation.
Justification:
New type of MXene coated textiles can block and protect from electromagnetic radiation more effectively than any metal-coated materials and also have other applications such as enclosing modern technology devices in the material to protect from electro-magnetic interference and ensure stable functionality or shielding people from radiation in wearables such as protective clothing. The implication to Defra is that developing MXene is a key step in enhancing technological capabilities into personal protective clothing and wearable devices we use, with the benefit of MXene being very effective at only a few atoms deep coating which keeps devices and protective clothing light.
Mxene is more sustainable to use in comparison to previous metal-coated layers as the effectiveness and performance has lasted better in tests completed and it in fact absorbs signals rather than reflects them. As MXene can be applied as a paint, spray or ink, there is no need to manufacture new materials or textiles in order to use it, you just apply it to existing materials without any chemicals or pre-treatment processes required.
Primary Article Title: Faraday fabrics? MXene-coated fabric could contain electronic interference in wearable devices
Author: DREXEL UNIVERSITY
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//newatlas.com/materials/faraday-fabric-mxene-blocks-electromagnetic-waves/
Keywords: materials textiles fabrics MXenes radiation electromagnetics “electromagnetic radiation” EMI "electro-magnetic interference" superconductors conductors telecommunications “health and safety”

Summary Sentence: A novel invention for secure way is to transfer information via your fingertip.
Justification:
Human-computer interaction BodyWire is a novel technology that makes it possible to use human body, such as fingerprint touch, as a link to transfer information keeping the digital signal within the body for security, consecutively making intercepting digital signals very hard. This has implications for Environment Agency as staff would no longer need, for example, physical keys to access water company assets or other stakeholder buildings but simply to touch door handles, or for Defra as it enables secure transmission of information, with applications to transform how we interact with devices.
This novel prototype for communication during touch safeguards a secure way, in comparison to current Bluetooth signalling techniques, as close proximity, so called near-field communication, is not enough to transmit information, you need to physically touch the machine or device surface with your finger. As well as security, this method demonstrates selectivity, hence a person can switch off passing the information and only use it when necessary. As it relies on digital signals that are sent via human body, instead of biometrics, the device or surface in question needs to have the correct hardware for recognising your finger or hand.
Primary Article Title: Tech makes it possible to digitally communicate through human touch
Author: Purdue University
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.nsf.gov/news/mmg/mmg_disp.jsp?med_id=187014%23&%2358;~&%2358;text=Transferring%20data%20through%20your%20fingertip%20A%20new%20technology,with%20support%20from%20the%20U.S.%20National%20Science%20Foundation.
Keywords: communications “communication hardware” interaction security interface “human-centered computing” BodyWire “human computer interaction” HCI "digital communications" touch fingertip finger

Summary Sentence: A novel autonomous drone uses live moth antenna to detect smells from environment.
Justification:
Washington University researchers have created a “smellicopter” by adding live hawkmoth antenna to an autonomous drone to detect smells in locations that are too difficult or dangerous for people to go to or simply to smell more effectively than people or sensors created by humans could do. The potential use of this biomimicry development for Environment Agency could be in enforcement work and odour monitoring, or monitoring anything of interest to us that has a smell; and to use a camera on the drone to survey location. Original applications listed were uses for detection of gas leaks, explosive materials, locating people after natural disasters.
Once the antennae are separated from a live moth they are functional for up to four hours and potentially longer after being refrigerated. Tiny wires are added to the antennae in order to connect to an electrical circuit, to record the responses made, and then these antennae with sensors are attached to a standard drone, adding plastic fins to the back to create drag so that the drone would be facing upwind to maximise smelling opportunities. Researchers created a search protocol for the drone and when the required threshold of smelling is reached, it moves towards the detected source. Nonetheless, further work is still prerequisite to alter the smells that smellicopter searches to make it navigate towards sources such as hazardous chemicals in air instead of hawkmoth’s favourite flowers.
Primary Article Title: "Smellicopter" drone uses live moth antenna to sniff out targets
Author: Irving, M.

This smellicopter drone uses live moth antenna to hunt its targets - YouTube

Summary Sentence: China invests in weather modification to new unseen scale to combat climate change and water scarcity.
Justification:
China has confirmed a cabinet plan to expand its weather modification programme, including making or preventing rainfall, fog reduction and air quality improvement, to a grander scale, covering almost 60% of China by 2025. Weather modification technology can potentially help responding to incidents such as forest fires and prolonged dry weather, or high temperatures endangering agricultural production.
Key areas for China’s plan are Asia’s largest freshwater reserve in the Qinghai-Tibet plateau, and the major ecological protection zones of Yellow and Yangtze rivers where scientists plan to divert water vapour from the Yangtze River basin to the Yellow River basin as rainfall.
There are concerns that China ramping up its weather modification research and capabilities would lead to weaponisation of weather or “rain stealing”; neighbouring India in particular suggesting it could unsettle their weather patterns for example monsoon rains that India’s agricultural productivity depends on. If there is no regulations for this activity, the consequences of China’s programme can potentially lead to adverse outcomes to other countries.
However, many scientists are sceptical about the effectiveness of geoengineered cloud seeding at this unprecedented scale; 2.1million square miles (5.5m square kilometres); over 1.5 times the size of India.
Primary Article Title: China is scaling up its weather modification programme – here's why we should be worried

Summary Sentence: Hydrogels for self-watering soil can improve farming potential in dry areas.
Justification:
The research group at The University of Texas has invented an atmospheric irrigation system technology; a new type of soil that can harvest water from the air during the night and release it in the soil for plants when the temperature rises during the day. This is relevant to Environment Agency as it reduces the need for irrigation in the drier regions of England, especially in the times of prolonged dry weather, as the soil quality is not an issue but the agricultural potential is limited by limited water resource or unsuitability for irrigation systems. The same technology with absorbent gels could potentially be also utilised for keeping solar panels and data centres cool.
100-1100 grams of hydrogel is required to provide enough water for growing crops in one square meter of agricultural land. When the soil releases the moisture, some of it returns into the air hence contributing towards the continuation of the water harvesting cycle.
Primary Article Title: Self-watering soil could transform farming

Summary Sentence: US space travel company SpaceX is recruiting engineers to develop offshore rocket launch platforms.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency, which is already involved in future regulation of launch sites within England. Off-shore launch sites could effectively sit outside of current regulatory jurisdictions, meaning unregulated environmental impacts. SpaceX already makes use of floating landing platforms for booster rockets. Ocean spaceports form part of Elon Musk’s vision for global travel, where a combination of hyperloop travel and offshore rocket launch slashes global travel times (%23*****) and (%23*****) between major cities. A rocket could launch vertically from New York and land on an off-shore barge in Shanghai 30 minutes later, for example. Musk has suggested that existing offshore oil rig platforms could make for suitable infrastructure, but other infrastructure could also be developed that sits outside of regulatory controls, which may bring concerns particularly where rocket fuel, combustion and air and water pollution is concerned.
Primary Article Title: SpaceX pursues ocean spaceports for hypersonic Earth-to-Earth travel
Keywords: space travel transport regulation emission air water pollution fuel rocket SpaceX Hyperloop "Elon Musk" floating infrastructure ocean marine coast

Summary Sentence: An innovative cleaning system could remove plastics, other debris and polluting liquids such as oil from rivers efficiently and with relatively little cost.
Justification: Both of these applications could see practical application for the Environment Agency in terms of waste and pollution reduction and also in remediating pollution incidents involving oil and other substances. The River Cleaning System consists of a row of floating discs that sit side by side diagonally across a stretch of river and can be deployed as a modular system. Each disc has a series of vertical ‘paddles’ that intercept waste on the river’s surface. As the river current turns the discs waste is passed along the line until it accumulates on the bank side where it can be removed from the river. A similar proposition with slightly different discs can be applied to pollution incidents such as oil spills when they occur. The River Cleaning System doesn’t impede navigation for boats etc. Oil pollution is often treated with chemical dispersants, which reduce concentration rather than remove oil, and come with an associated cost. A set up similar to the River Cleaning System could provide a more reusable and cost effective remediation tactic, and could potentially allow for oil to be reclaimed, offsetting operational costs.
Primary Article Title: Cleaning rivers to clean the seas
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.innovationnewsnetwork.com/cleaning-rivers-to-clean-the-seas-part-ii/7811/
Keywords: water quality pollution pollutant river "River Cleaning System" navigation disc oil spill incident dispersal chemical chemistry regulation

Summary Sentence: Discovery of new crystalline material offers new solution for storing energy from the sun.
Justification: The crystalline material is a 'metal-organic framework' (MOF), and can capture and store the energy from the sun at room temperature for a couple of months. It can later discharge the energy as heat when a small amount of warmth is applied to stimulate the release. This has potential for storing energy in the summer months to provide heating in the winter when there is less sun. Although this is only a proof of concept idea at the moment, it offers up new avenues of research that may uncover many different low carbon uses for this material in the future. The Environment Agency will need to assess the environmental impact of increased use of MOF’s, as their porous nature means they can often become composites with other materials. Operationally is may also become something the Environment Agency may need to use as a solution to limiting our own emissions.
Primary Article Title: Study shows promising material can store solar energy for months or years
Keywords: Energy "climate Change" emissions solar sun heat "waste management" waste pollution industry renewable sustainability material

Summary Sentence: A British engineering team is developing a floating platform to harness the potential of ocean thermal energy conversion.
Justification: The Environment Agency should be interested in the potential of this renewable technology in this portable, floating form. It could represent a solution to power generation during coastal flooding incidents, and may provide a cost efficient alternative to marine solar and wind renewables without taking valuable land out of action. OTEC works through utilising the temperature difference between warmer surface water and cold water at depth. The warmer water is vapourised to make a “working fluid” with a low boiling point, which drives a turbine. This is then cooled by water drawn from lower in the water column, before returning to the boiler to complete the cycle. For every 2.5MW of energy generated, 1.5MW can be captured as electricity – with the “lost” energy used to keep the system running. While other OTEC projects exist (%23*****) in this particular project all the energy capture takes place offshore, so little land needs to be converted to infrastructure in support. OTEC has an advantage over wind and solar in that it can run almost constantly regardless of weather conditions. The developers have small island nations in mind as a potential market, but success could mean wider deployment in the energy mix of coastal nations including the UK.
Primary Article Title: BETTER WETTER Ocean heat ‘could power entire COUNTRIES’ using ingenious British eco-boat
Keywords: energy floating infrastructure renewable solar wind OTEC "ocean thermal energy conversion" marine coast incident landuse island coastal habitat marine

Summary Sentence: Flowers are altering the ultraviolet (UV) pigmentation in their petals in response to climate change.
Justification: The change is thought to have occured over the last 75 years in response to increasing temperatures and decreasing ozone levels, and can be detected in samples from across the globe using UV photography of current and archive specimens.On an average, UV-pigmentation in flowers increased at a rate of 2% per year from 1941 to 2017. UV-absorbing pigment increased in flowers with exposed pollen, but decreased in flowers with closed pollen, thought to be an attempt to prevent overheating of the closed pollen. The changes in UV pigment, and indeed further changes in pigmentation could have an impact on reproduction, which relies on pollination by insects such as bees. Insects are thought to be attracted to the contrasting UV hues between lighter petals and darker centres. Flowers with rising UV levels may lose this contrast and be missed by pollinators entirely. This new development adds to pressures of habitat loss and pollution, could impact on the viability of crops and food security, and is therefore of interest to the Environment Agency and partners.
Primary Article Title: Flowers are changing colors to adapt to rising temperatures, declining ozone
Keywords: "Climate change" biodiversity ozone flower plant "ultraviolet light" UV pigment temperature farming agriculture crop pollination insect bee "food security" habitat pollution regulation

Summary Sentence: Innovations in personal protective equipment, some of which have evolved in response to the coronavirus pandemic, suggest future impacts on workforce health safety and wellbeing (HSW).
Justification: The Environment Agency prioritises HSW and therefore should be interested in the potential opportunities and issues that these may present. A new study has assessed the level of workplace interruptions on stress biological stress, rather than productivity and performance. An experiment suggested that workers with frequent interruptions from emails, messages and colleagues had up to twice the levels of cortisol in their system than the control. However the workers didn’t perceive their heightened stress level - they reported being less stressed than the control. The results of this study are providing the basis for developing a digital early warning system team that uses machine learning to detect and pre-​empt stress in the workplace in real time. A new virtual reality (VR) headset takes a similar direction, monitoring the users eye movement, face and lip movement, pupil size and heart rate. Algorithms will monitor this data to infer behaviour, attention and cognitive load, such as how overwhelming a task could be to someone. VR is expected to grow in prevalence in the workplace, there may be an expectation to adopt similar monitoring for HSW reasons. A new exosuit takes a less digital approach to improving physical HSW. It employs low-profile, elastic assistive forces to compliment back strength of the user. This could be of benefit to field workers who stand for long hours, but could equally be of use desk workers who regularly have to move around or pick up objects. The suit can reduce muscle fatigue up to 47 per cent. A company called Microclimate has designed a lightweight helmet with HEPA filters attached for use when travelling by air. The helmet’s filters can remove 99.97 per cent of particles as small as 0.03 micros, using two high-powered fans to pull air through and keep the mask free of fog and users safe from airborne contaminants. The helmet seals around the neck rather than the face, so it doesn’t interfere with facial expression. Two different research teams have been using vocal analysis to diagnose a range of symptoms, including coronavirus. A team at MIT developed an artificial intelligence (AI) powered framework that had used a learning algorithm to detect possible signs of dementia voice recordings. The team applied their framework to helping tackle the coronavirus pandemic and found a correlation strong enough to suggest that it could detect Covid-19 even in otherwise asymptomatic patients. A voice analysis company called Vocalis have previously developed an app that could detect flare-ups of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease by listening for signs that users were short of breath when speaking. They applied their algorithms to recordings of voice samples from people testing positive for Covid-19. The resulting tool can’t provide a definite diagnosis, but it can be used to screen for people most in need of quarantine or treatment. Others are using vocal biomarkers to screen for a range of neurodegenerative diseases, including Parkinsons. While this field is still developing, analysis of voice through phone calls etc could provide a way to detect a range of illnesses early, including mental health issues including depression. All of these technologies provide a way to enhance health safety and wellbeing of staff. However many of them also rely on a trade-off with employee privacy (including contractors) to be effective, which could be met with resistance from individuals and also demographics who have differing attitudes to data privacy. Policies may need adapting now in anticipation of increased collection and use of biometric data and physical enhancement technologies.
Primary Article Title: Artificial intelligence model detects asymptomatic Covid-19 infections through cellphone-recorded coughs

Summary Sentence: UK's Cornish Lithium finds high-grade material in govt-backed project
Justification: Cornish Lithium have confirmed that they have found high grade lithium in geothermal waters in Cornwall. The company suggest that the lithium can be extracted sustainably, but recent articles on the environmental damage caused by lithium mining will invariably raise concerns for local communities. The Environment Agency may be required to regulate certain aspects of this industry going forward. As the company suggests new technologies will be used for this extraction there may be resource requirements for engagement to develop ongoing monitoring to ensure the surrounding environment is protected. There is a growing interest in EU sources of lithium to secure access to this increasingly sought after metal. Finland and Portugal both have sites that have been identified as having potential. It is essential that any extraction is done in a sensitive way to ensure surrounding habitats and water resources are protected.
Primary Article Title: UK's Cornish Lithium finds high-grade material in govt-backed project

Summary Sentence: Rising climate litigation could have unknown consequences for policy and regulation.
Justification: Litigation in relation to climate change has been steadily increasing over the last three decades. It is difficult to assess whether these cases actually have a global impact, however it is clear they can affect government policy and regulation on a local level. Studies need to be undertaken to assess if litigation indirectly affects large corporations share prices and subsequently their value. If climate litigation is found to have an impact on a company’s value, it is likely they would take climate related decisions more seriously to protect their profits. A recent example is the settlement of a case brought against an Australian pension fund about their failure to protect retirement savings against climate change risk. This may have implications for pension funds in the future and mean they will need to justify investments in high carbon industries. The current inquiry into the death of a London child whose mother believes illegal levels of air pollution contributed to the death may have further implications. If the coroner rules that air pollution is a cause of death, this would be a first in the UK. This could then have implications for the government, as it is not clear who would be held responsible in this case. As the Environment Agency holds certain regulatory responsibilities for monitoring air pollution it could also mean changes for the way we work.
Primary Article Title: Global trends in climate change litigation&%2358; 2020 snapshot

Summary Sentence: Prospective house buyers may be becoming more cautious about buying properties potentially at risk from the impacts of climate change.
Justification: The conclusions of a US based study of the Florida property market may be of interest to the Environment Agency as it comes from an area of more acute flood risk compared to the UK at present. Changes in the property market and land values could have implications for the economics of flood defence construction along with changes to the socioeconomic structure of communities in the most ‘at risk’ areas. A 2019 study of the Florida property market demonstrated that homes exposed to sea level rise (SLR) sell for approximately 7% equivalent unexposed properties despite being the same distance from the beach. This suggests buyers are increasingly sophisticated in their understanding of climate change risks. At the same time, rental rates were not noticeably impacted. This more recent study which also focuses on Florida found that even though SLR exposed properties were cheaper, their overall prices rose in tandem with less exposed properties between 2013 and 2018. From 2018 however there has been a marked decrease in at risk property prices of 5 per cent. Once differences in finance options have been discounted, the study concludes that the downturn in price is from buyer awareness of sea level rise and climate change impacts. However sellers are not recognising nor responding in the same way, potentially ending a property price bubble. These studies are US based, but may be seen as indicative as a wider recognition of climate change moving up the social, political and economic agenda. As has been seen in Fairbourne Wales (%23******) recognition of SLR’s impact on a community can dramatically impact property prices, but stimulate a rental market, changing the relationship that the community has with its surrounding environment and impacting the dynamics of flood management.
Primary Article Title: Neglected no more&%2358; housing markets, mortgage lending, and sea level rise

Summary Sentence: Autonomous and semi-autonomous robotic combat units could become a key feature of future defence forces.
Justification: This is of interest to the Environment Agency in an operational context as technologies often ‘trickle down’ from military to civilian settings and secondly increasing automation could impact on the numbers of human operatives which sometimes form a significant aspect of incident response. The US Army has outlines its plans for Robotic Combat Vehicles designed for a range of purposes in the field. Common to many of them is a modular design which soldiers can reconfigure and experiment with in the field, depending on the situation. Many have a degree of autonomy in terms of navigating to the front line. However certain maneuvers, including combat would be overseen by a human controller. Head of the British armed forces, General Nick Carter, recently suggested that ‘robot soldiers’ could form a significant proportion of the armed force working alongside human operatives. While stressing that he wasn’t setting any targets, General Carter suggested a UK fighting force of 120,000 could consist of 30,000 robotic units by the 2030s. The Army has set itself a recruitment target of around 80,000 but has struggled to recruit beyond 73,000. The target may also be reduced by impending spending reviews. Robots could be a potentially cost effective way to make a recruitment shortfall, though this would also require significant investment in research and development. A stretched human force could reduce availability for assistance during major incidents such as flooding where the Army has previously been drafted in. The Environment Agency may need to both consider how it might utilise other avenues of human resources for incident support, but it might also consider how military robotics, particularly if of a modular design, could be repurposed to support incident roles. This may also lead to considering how robotics could contribute to its own vehicle fleet.
Primary Article Title: Robot soldiers could make up quarter of British army by 2030s'
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//breakingdefense.com/2020/11/meet-the-armys-future-family-of-robot-tanks-rcv/
Keywords: automation defence army US military UK "General Nick Carter" robot soldier autonomous AI modular recruitment incident operations field flooding employee employer workforce

Summary Sentence: Lawyers donate time to create climate friendly legal text that is free for all to use
Justification: The Chancery Lane Project is a ground roots movement where lawyers volunteer their time to help create an open access source of environmentally friendly precedents and definitions for lawyers to use. The project was set up to help facilitate the inclusion of more climate conscious contracts, by creating text that could be used by those who don’t have time to develop their own. It has already been downloaded over 15,000 times in 76 countries. The recognition that law firms can play a role in enabling climate friendly policies has also been seen in reverse as activists target big law firms that work for the fossil fuel industry. The climate groups are targeting these large law firms who work on behalf of fossil fuel industries, but are usually not the focus of attention. Climate activism and targeting of fossil fuel industries has led to a smaller pool of graduates willing to work in the fossil fuel sector. It is possible that some of the bigger law firms may not wish to work with fossil fuel companies if they fear they may suffer the same fate. The Environment Agency is already engaged with the Chancery Lane Project, but it will be of interest to see how the inclusion of such legal text may influence our partners and industry in the future.
Primary Article Title: UK Lawyers work together to tackle climate change
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.businessinsider.com/big-law-firms-climate-change-activists-strategy-pressure-politics-2020-10?r=US&IR=T
Keywords: "climate change" activism policy regulation law legal contract recruitment

Summary Sentence: 100% of energy demand supplied by solar, wind and battery storage feasible by 2030.
Justification: An independent think tank has launched a report suggesting that data shows solar, wind and battery (SWB) storage is both physically and economically possible to meet 100% of energy demand by 2030 in the majority of places. The report implies current models of the technologies are too linear and do not show how quickly product development and business change could alter the market. They argue that a more holistic approach is needed by taking a systems approach to energy focusing on market forces. The report highlights the risk of investing in coal, gas and nuclear as these systems will soon be much more expensive than SWB and therefore investments may become stranded. This is at odds with the governments recently published 10 point covid recovery plan which supports the development of small modular reactors. Should SWB become a large part of the future energy mix it will likely cause disruption to existing systems and will require new infrastructure requiring different policy and regulatory frameworks. This is likely to be happening alongside other disruptions in both the food and transportation sectors, which reinforces the need for a systems based approach to assess the risks and opportunities all these changes may have on the environment.
Primary Article Title: Rethinking Energy 2020-2030

Summary Sentence: Government and business interest in developing a hydrogen economy is gaining traction.
Justification: Hydrogen has been hailed as a potential energy supply medium of the future for a number of years, due to its abundance, versatility and the fact it can be used without emitting any greenhouse gasses. The difficulty however lies in the energy needed to produce the hydrogen in the first place, which can result in the use of fossil fuels and thus has associated emissions. Blue hydrogen is produced using natural gas or gasification of coal with carbon capture and storage (CCS). Green hydrogen can be generated using energy from renewables such as wind or solar, but is currently more expensive. Economics and the cost of producing hydrogen and converting infrastructure mean that it is not currently cost effective without market interventions. Both the EU and the UK have produced covid recovery plans that aim to drive the development of low carbon hydrogen in the future. Businesses such as Siemens are trialling technology such as hydrogen fuel cells in off grid locations and have also made a commitment to explore the development of hydrogen powered trains. The Humber Zero project is a collaboration between multiple organisations to look at the feasibility of developing an industrial hub powered by hydrogen. All these signals of change together suggest a growing momentum of support for hydrogen to play a part in the future energy mix as we move to a lower carbon world. This has huge implications for how the Environment Agency may need to regulate in the future. Industry based on hydrogen at least in the beginning would likely be more location dependant, and therefore certain areas may need more resource to support this growing industry.
Primary Article Title: Separating Hype from Hydrogen – Part One&%2358; The Supply Side

Summary Sentence: UK’s first vegan butcher opens but copies the looks and product names of a traditional meat butcher’s.
Justification:
The first vegan butcher’s shop opening is not astounding news in itself as it simply demonstrates the vegan consumer trend, but what is significant is that the looks and language the entrepreneur has decided to use resemble traditional butcher’s shop and meat-based looks and language rather than attempting to align to vegan values by creating new names and products. This is of interest to Defra as it reveals that plant-based diets are not established sufficiently on their own yet as they seem to require “meat” concepts to validate their existence, and as long as the language used in the society is meat-free "meats" and dairy-free cheeses, the change is not substantial.
One of the arguments towards this behaviour has been that many are inspired to try a plant-based alternative vegan diet when the “fake meat” or “meat-free meat” product names, shapes and looks are similar to meat products, and tasting them makes consumers realise that there are tasty alternatives to meat. The products made from soya and seitan are designed to resemble the taste and texture of meat.
There is also research conducted in the consumer and purchasing behaviour of vegans and vegetarians regarding meat-based names, indicating that it attracts many vegetarians but deters vegans from purchasing. Examples of plant-based consumer language is vegan “butcher’s” or “carcass wholesalers” for the store; and for products “lobstah salad”, “rack of jack”, chilli-non carne, “chick’n lover plate”, “shredded BBQ pulled porc”, and for the Christmas season “roast turk’y” or “tofurky.”
Primary Article Title: Bringing home the fake-on! UK's first vegan BUTCHER serving trendy plant-based alternatives sells out on its first day - with 100 online orders in ten minutes

Summary Sentence: A software engineer who formerly worked on Amazon’s Alexa voice activated assistant has devised an app that claims to be able to interpret and translate sounds a cat makes into human language.
Justification: Javier Sanchez has created the app “MeowTalk” as an out of the box model, which will learn and adapt to an individual cat through artificial intelligence and machine learning. MeowTalk promises to remove the barrier between pet and person. It listens for cat sounds, which are categorised into ten universal intents such as “feed me” and “let me outside”. The app will also learn new words and phrases it hears and anticipate their meaning. It could be assumed that the more data collected via the MeowTalk app the more sophisticated further versions of the app could become. While this may seem a relatively trivial development on the surface, it parallels developments elsewhere of using artificial intelligence to communicate with animals in their own language (%23***** dolphin), which could contribute to the notion of personhood amongst non-humans, changing our relationships with animals and the environment in general, and is therefore of interest to the Environment Agency and partners.
Primary Article Title: MeowTalk,’ an app that translates cat sounds, is a pet project for this former Alexa engineer
Keywords: biodiversity habitat nature conservation personhood brain biology intelligence regulation cat MeowTalk voice "artificial intelligence" Ai "machine learning" app Alexa Amazon "Javier Sanchez" pet cat dog human translation dolphin

Summary Sentence: A clothing retailer has developed an instore manufacturing process to recycle old clothes into new ones.
Justification: This example of a circular economy approach should be of interest to the Environment Agency as a regulator of the textile sector as well as the links to reducing landfill, water and resource use of this approach. H&M’s “Looop” recycling system has opened to the public in Stockholm, Sweden. Old garments are transformed into first yarn, then new machine woven items, over an eight stage process, which includes, cleaning, shredding, plus the addition of some virgin material. The technology has been developed in collaboration with the Hong Kong Research Institute of Textiles and Apparel (HKRITA), who plan to license their system more widely. It is not clear if there are limits to the type of fabrics that can be used in the looop system, or if these can be mixed.
Primary Article Title: H&M's 'looop' recycling system transforms unwanted garments into new fashion favorites
Keywords: waste resources textile material "circular economy" clothes clothing H&M Looop yarn recycling water energy Stockholm Sweden "Hong Kong Research Institute of Textiles and Apparel" HKRITA

Summary Sentence: The enzyme rubisco enhances photosynthesis towards increased crop production.
Justification:
Researchers have finally moved closer to their ultimate goal of enhancing photosynthesis towards increased crop production, and food security, by identifying how the enzyme rubisco, a crucial part of the photosynthesis process, can be activated to become more effective. With further research towards optimisation of this technology, the potential implication for Environment Agency is impact on regulating farming, and to establish whether increased crop productivity also means that the crops would have an amplified requirement for water and chemicals.
Rubisco is a fundamental enzyme involved in the first step of carbon fixation and due to its slowness and behaviour as an inefficient catalyst, researchers had focused on attempting to enhance its effectiveness by increasing the speed, in order to acquire major improvement in crop production. Until now it was not possible to play with all of the components of rubisco simultaneously in bioengineering but now the researchers can work with rubisco’s CO2-fixing properties, to ensure the high concentration of CO2 generated that is essential to facilitate the functioning of rubisco in leaf chloroplasts.
Primary Article Title: Back to the future&%2358; New study could lead to bumper crops

Summary Sentence: Worms can clean up soil by consuming oil.
Justification: Zoo remediation in the form of worms that can digest oil and petroleum,altering it to a format that bacteria can break down into fatty acids, is a potential solution to soil remediation in the event of incidents such as oil spills.Nematodes are used as a means in biological remediation to bring in marine bacteria that consume oil or petroleum, and this laboratory test used one type of oil from Tatarstan in Russia, discovering that if the worms have nothing else, they will digest crude oil as their food source, for the bacteria brought by nematodes to break further down. Researchers are yet to test other types of petroleum from other locations. The assumption is that this method would be functioning both in soils and water, with the worms living approximately three weeks consuming only oil.
Primary Article Title: Oil-eating worms provide valuable assistance in soil remediation

Summary Sentence: Artificial intelligence registers bring transparency to a new level in public services.
Justification: Helsinki and Amsterdam have become the first cities to open artificial intelligence registers to promote transparency and responsibility in how they use algorithms and AI in providing public services in their municipalities and hence impacting people’s lives. This is important to us as it is a way to increase public trust and demonstrate not just openness but also a responsible and secure use of AI and algorithms by cities and governments,and also to utilise chatbots to enhance customer service experience and better services. Their AI registers include an overview of the systems and describe their use such as how data is processed, how cities ensure inclusion for all residents, what the risks are and how AI systems are accounted for, ensuring there is a human oversight. Currently AI systems in Helsinki and Amsterdam include a variety of issues including pregnancy, car parking compliance, library resources, or report illegal holiday rentals. Giving feedback is made easy via chatbots, and as a result enabling city residents to have a direct impact on how the system learns more about its applications and is built in future, based on their experience and creating the human-centred approach via AI as the city constantly learns more. There are plans to increase applications as residents become more used to them, and other cities including London and New York City plan to follow the example.
Primary Article Title: Amsterdam and Helsinki become first cities to launch AI registers explaining how they use algorithms

Summary Sentence: Scientists develop an enzyme that offers hope for a plastics circular economy
Justification: This research follows on from a discovery in 2018 of an enzyme that breaks down PET plastic. The new research was able to use genetic engineering to combine the known enzyme PETase with another one called MHETase to create a ‘super enzyme’ that can now break down the plastic into its constituent parts. This offers hope for the circular economy, as if the broken down material can then be reused it reduces the need for virgin feedstock. The new super enzyme works six times faster than the originally discovered PETase, and is also now able to break down PEF (polyethylene furanoate) plastic as well as PET (polyethylene terephthalate). The researchers will now concentrate on how to speed up the process further in the hope that it can be made commercially viable.
Primary Article Title: Super-enzyme breaks down plastic bottles in ‘a matter of days’
Keywords: Pollution, "waste management" plastic "fossil fuels" emissions "genetic engineering"

Summary Sentence: The emergence of the ‘honjok’ lifestyle in South Korea gives an idea of what a society of increasing numbers of single people could look like.
Justification: The emergence of the ‘honjok’ lifestyle in South Korea gives an idea of what a society of increasing numbers of single people could look like. Around the World marriage is on the decline and more people are remaining single late into life. For example, it has been estimated that by the time today’s young adults in the USA reach 50, one in four will have never been married. Outside of the USA the four countries with the highest rates of solo living are Sweden, Norway, Finland, and Denmark, where up to 45 per cent of all households contain just one person. The single lifestyle is known as “honjok” in South Korea which translates as “alone tribe”. The equivalent in Japan is the “ohitorisama” movement, meaning “party of one”, or “hitori”, “one person”. Both societies are traditionally collectivist, with little culture of doing things alone. In South Korea honjok has arisen as a push back against rigid social and cultural demands to study, find a job and start a family. While it is difficult to define what constitutes honjok, those identifying with tend to be single, live and partake is social activities alone. Some identify more with the ‘tribe’ aspect of single life, but interactions tend to take place online. Many honjok are women, rejecting marriage, child-rearing and even relationships. As living alone has risen in prominence the market has responded to what is a lucrative market&%2358; bars, sports clubs, food delivery, restaurants and even karaoke bars now cater for single people. The rise of mobile internet is seen as either a trigger or a facilitator for a societal change that was already brewing. Technology use has been cited as both a cause of and a solution to growing social seclusion in that it allows people to connect but at the same time there is a correlated risk between isolation and mental health issues. What is apparent however is shifts in economic models that were already in play but that have been accelerated by the coronavirus pandemic are conducive to the honjok lifestyle. These include the rise of “untact” contactless interactions such as ordering food, taxis and sending gifts without the need for human interaction. Other emerging technologies which receive government interest such as remote work systems, high-speed internet and 5G, and self-driving cars, drones, robots, and other AI initiatives further remove the need for human interaction. Indeed examples of untact technologies can be found in the countries already mentioned, including robot couriers in Helsinki, remotely controlled shelf stacking robots in Tokyo, and unstaffed digital supermarkets in rural Sweden. Novel social practices such as ‘social distancing’ may become normalised in a post Covid-19 world, further driving isolation. What is happening in South Korea and Japan could spread elsewhere. It is estimated that there will be a 128 per cent growth in single-person households worldwide between 2000 and 2030. A future “super solo society”, may be characterised by young people who never marry and elderly who become single again after being widowed. This has social, political and demographic implications but also environmental ones. More individual households could increase consumption patterns of energy, water, goods and waste. Land use and planning decisions around construction being made today may not be fit for increasing single occupancy households. In this context the single lifestyle may factor directly or indirectly into the Environment Agency’s future remit.
Primary Article Title: Tune in, drop out

Summary Sentence: Viruses may be able to develop resistance to warm temperatures, potentially increasing their range and resilience under a changing climate.
Justification: This discovery could have implications for water quality and water treatment under climate change, and should therefore be of interest to the Environment Agency. Researchers have experimented with viruses in laboratory conditions to simulate warmer lake water. Some of the viruses developed resistance to warmer water and certain disinfectants including chlorine, both in the presence and absence of sunlight. This could suggest that viruses may become increasingly hard to kill in a warming climate using standard water treatment technologies and may also present an increased risk to human health in bathing waters. Increasing global travel and trade could exacerbate the issue as contaminated products are moved about more readily into regions with increasingly warmer, more favourable climates. Elsewhere newly discovered marine organisms have been discovered that appear to eat viruses for nutrition. Simple two celled organisms called protists from the coastal waters of Maine, USA were examined, only to find that their stomach contents contained traces of virus DNA, but not bacteria DNA. This suggests that they feeding exclusively on viruses, which are rich in phosphorus and nitrogen. It is possible to envisage protist affinity for viruses playing a role in water treatment where virus content of water becomes problematic.
Primary Article Title: Viruses could become harder to kill

Summary Sentence: Technology company Apple recently filed a patent for an air quality sensor powered by lasers for use on a smartphone.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners may be interested in this development for use is citizen science projects but also by its own workforce who are currently iPhone users. Apple has filed patents on air quality monitoring features before (HSDBi %23******). The new patent features an array of three lasers and three total-internal-reflection lenses. Light from the lasers passes through the lenses to a sensor, which detects backscatter and reflections of the light beams, implying the volume of particulates in the air. It is suggested that such a device would be primarily designed to detect pollen or poisonous gases in the home such as a carbon monoxide leak, but the same technology could be applied to detecting other air pollutants of interest. Wider application as crowdsourced pollution data may require navigating social, privacy, security, participation, ande cost issues.
Primary Article Title: Future iPhones could use laser detection of poisonous gas, air quality, or pollen
Author: Owen, M
Keywords: monitoring air quality air pollution pollutant particulate matter pollen gas Apple iPhone smartphone workforce "citizen science" data regulation hardware

Summary Sentence: The Welsh government recently stated an ambition for 30 per cent of Wales’s workforce to be working remotely in the future.
Justification: Changes in the devolved administrations such as this could lead to other countries adopting similar targets, which could in turn impact on the Environment Agency’s workforce and workplace arrangements. Covid-19 has seen a huge increase in the numbers of people working from home, bringing with it reductions in congestion, pollution and private car use. The Welsh Government wishes to see these environmental improvements continue beyond the coronavirus pandemic through developing a working culture that helps productivity as well as their work-life balance. In support of this they are exploring the idea of community-based remote working hubs to offer choices beyond a simple home/office split. These hubs would be within walking and cycling distance of people’s homes and could be used by public, private and third-sector employees. They could also help encourage new partnerships between government, industry, and others. Recent analysis by the Office of National Statistics (ONS) has revealed that the ability to work remotely is closely linked to pay, with people in higher paying jobs more likely to be able to work from home. The median earnings of employees in the 20 per cent of the workforce most likely to be able to work from home is £19.01, compared with £11.28 for workers in the 20 per cent of workers in jobs least likely to be adaptable to home working. The majority of employees not able to work remotely are men - 78 per cent despite making up 48 per cent of the workforce. Jobs based in workplaces in London and the South East are much more likely to be possible to do from home compared with the rest of the UK, probably due to a higher proportion of professional occupations in the region. The current data could therefore suggest achieving a greater proportion of remote working could require marked structural changes to the economy and the infrastructure that supports it (assuming that employment levels remain at a constant level), applying to all areas of the UK.
Primary Article Title: Aim for 30% of the Welsh workforce to work remotely
