Summary Sentence: New experiments into the behaviour of crows suggests that corvids may be capable of subjective experiences, placing them alongside humans and some primates.
Justification: An increasing awareness of the consciousness and personhood of some animals is leading to greater recognition both ethically and legally. Similar recognition for corvids could lead to greater considerations in conservation and planning activities, and therefore may have relevance for the Environment Agency’s role in these matters. Corvids have been known to be highly intelligent birds for some time. The new experiments however imply that despite having different brain structures to humans and great apes they are capable of subjective experiences. The brain activity of two crows was monitored as they were shown a figure on a screen of varying brightness, which they reported by activating coloured lights. The time lapse between seeing and reacting to the stimulus for a positive recognition implied a secondary layer of processing of the visual stimulus. This is as would be expected from neurons that participated in building the thoughts that we later report. suggests these birds could be as cognitively capable as monkeys and even great apes.
Primary Article Title: Do crows possess a form of consciousness?
Author: Fox, A
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//science.sciencemag.org/content/369/6511/1567
Keywords: biodiversity habitat nature conservation personhood ethics planning corvid bird crow brain biology intelligence ape regulation

Summary Sentence: Researchers are already starting to develop sixth generation (6G) mobile communication technologies, even though 5G has yet to have a wider commercial roll out.
Justification: 5G is a technology of interest for Defra, but there are concerns around its environmental and health impacts from some quarters, therefore 6G development should have equal interest, particularly as 6G is expected to be over 100 times faster than 5G which is already expected to be ultra-fast. However it should be noted that these new developments don’t necessarily suggest that 6G roll out is imminent. China recently launched "the world's first 6G satellite" with the purpose of testing out the performance of the 6G frequency band in space. Elsewhere US researchers have developed a smartphone antenna to handle the terahertz-frequency signals that would characterise a 6G network. The antenna includes a new form of “n-polar” gallium nitride (GaN) high-electron mobility transistor (HEMT). HEMTs are already used in 5G technology, but don’t currently operate at the levels of efficiency needed for the higher frequencies of 6G.
Primary Article Title: World's first 6G satellite sent into orbit by China
Author: Papadopoulos, L
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/semiconductors/devices/breakthrough-could-lead-to-amplifiers-for-6g-signals
Keywords: telecommunications 5G 6G mobile network infrastructure space China satellite "gallium nitride" "high-electron mobility transistor" HEMT regulation biodiversity resources mineral metal waste

Summary Sentence: The demand for rare metals and minerals needed to transition to a low carbon economy could have devastating impacts on the environment.
Justification: As the world transitions to a low carbon economy, demand for the resources that will facilitate this are set to grow drastically. The World Bank suggests demand for materials such as lithium, cobalt, zinc, copper and many other metals and minerals could see an increase in demand of 500% by 2050. Mining these resources can have a negative impact on the environment, with many local communities already protesting as they fear they will destroy local heritage sites. Communities in Portugal are already protesting about the exploration of sites for Lithium mining, with some licences revoked after local opposition. A group of researchers have mapped known mining areas around the world and have found that 82% of all mines are targeting minerals or metals that are required for renewables technologies. 8% of sites were linked to protected areas, 7% with key biodiversity areas, and 16% with wilderness sties. As demand increases, this competition for land is only set to increase. This is a global problem that requires strategic oversight and planning to ensure mining for metals, minerals and other resources for renewables technologies are done in the most sustainable way. Without this oversight, the move to a low carbon economy risks the destruction of habitats and is a threat to biodiversity.
Primary Article Title: Worldwide renewable energy could do more harm than good.
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.reuters.com/article/us-portugal-environment-lithium-insight/portuguese-communities-lock-horns-with-lithium-miners-to-save-their-land-idUSKBN2080GV
Keywords: Energy, renewables, technology, mineral, resource

Summary Sentence: Careful and coordinated planning of new forestry is required to get the best outcome for both biodiversity and carbon sequestration.
Justification: A report commissioned by the RSPB to look at the benefits of forestry for climate change mitigation and biodiversity conservation suggests that it is a complicated picture. Not all forestry is equal, with the report suggesting that current commercial tree plantations do not sequester carbon as more than half of that harvested is used in products with such a short shelf life that the emissions are returned to the atmosphere. Furthermore of the 2018 timber harvest in the UK, 23% was burnt directly as fuel. Afforestation needs careful planning in order to prevent insensitive planting on peat bogs that have a negative impact on both carbon sequestration and biodiversity. The report suggests slower growing diverse broadleaved plantations are better for both biodiversity and long term carbon sequestration. This needs to be balanced against the need for timber, if we cannot match demand in the UK, the carbon footprint would just be exported overseas. The report suggests significant investment is needed to ensure there is a more strategic assessment of the best sites for forestry to prevent inappropriate planting causing more harm than good.
Primary Article Title: Trees on commercial UK plantations 'not helping climate crisis'
Keywords: Emissions, "climate change", energy, forestry, biodiversity, planning, strategic, data, "carbon capture and storage"

Summary Sentence: Burning metal powder is a promising clean alternative to fossil fuels.
Justification:
A Dutch family business brewery has invested in sustainability and circular economy, becoming the first in the world to burn iron metal powder as a clean alternative fuel at an industrial scale with resulting in zero carbon emissions. Silicon, aluminium and iron are among the most commonly found elements and also metals that can have potential as energy carriers, releasing a lot of energy.
As iron is already cheap and the most commonly used metal, it is available to be recycled from industrial manufacturing operations, from metallurgy and also from chemical and electronic industries, and therefore burning it as a metal fuel could be a way to dispose of metal waste in future, leaving just a recyclable oxidized by-product. Iron powder burns cleanly in very high temperatures, up to 1,800 °C, and the remaining emission of iron oxide can be reused. For electricity generation the theoretical efficiency is approximately around 40 per cent
This innovative technology was made possible with the collaboration towards advancement of metal fuels between the researchers at TU Eindhoven and the Metal Power Consortium. The Dutch plan to convert early coal power stations to use iron powder, retrofitting them by 2030.
Primary Article Title: World first&%2358; Dutch brewery burns iron as a clean, recyclable fuel
Author: Blain, L.

Summary Sentence: Reflective super-white paint on buildings reduces the need for energy-consuming air conditioning.
Justification:
Researchers from Purdue University have provided critical evidence from outdoor tests for a potential of a “super-white” CaCO3-acrylic paint to reflect 95.5 per cent of sunlight to cool buildings, hence reducing the need for energy consuming air conditioning and related environmental costs. It can also be used to stop electrical systems located outdoors overheating. Various radiative cooling paints have been developed in the past but all had their disadvantages, and only Teflon coating has a higher reflection rate of 98 per cent than this new paint. Radiative cooling technology reflects sunlight and emits solar radiation back into space, and this passive technology can be used to cool down urban centres.
Roofs painted with white have already been implemented in New York City as part of their strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, resulting in reduced summer temperatures of 24 Centigrade or 43 Fahrenheit at the roof tops by creating a microclimate. During nights the paint made temperatures less than ambient temperature.
Next the researchers need to ensure the paint can cope with weathering from the elements, therefore also assess the potential frequency for repainting.
Primary Article Title: Super-white paint reflects 95.5 percent of sunlight to cool buildings
Author: Irving, M.
Secondary_URLs:

Summary Sentence: Longer-term environmental monitoring is made possible by sensors airdropped by tiny drones and insects.
Justification:
A new type minute sensor can be attached to either small drones or insects such as moths to carry them to the area that needs to be monitored and then dropped there for years to come, sending environmental monitoring data of the location, for example temperature and humidity readings. In order to take advantage of this approach and technology of delivering sensors to create a “sensory network” running over a relatively long time, the main technological features must be fine-tuned according to the location.
First of all, the sensor must be lightweight – the researchers used sensor systems weighing 98 milligrams – for the drone or moth to carry effortlessly. When in the right location, a command is sent via Bluetooth so the sensor is released. The heaviest part, the battery, is located in the corner of the sensor system and this makes it spin and then land safely from as high as 22 metres without damage to the system from the freefall. Current batteries can transmit data up to one kilometre and the batteries last two and half years, but researchers are looking to replace them with solar cells in future.
Drones and live moths have their own advantages&%2358; working with the drones is more measured as they can be controlled directly but they are limited by battery lives. The benefit of using moths is that they can fly for hours and fit into smaller spaces if required.
Limitations that need to be considered for the sensor systems are their contact with the environment where they fall; withstanding weathering, staying in the original location, not impacting nature in the location in any negative way, including the need to pick them all up after the batteries are finished. This type of miniscule sensor network also raises ethical questions about monitoring and surveillance.
Primary Article Title: Tiny sensor system can be airdropped by drones and insects where needed
Author: Iyer, V., Kim,M., Xue, S., Wang,A., Gollakota, S.

Summary Sentence: Recent innovations add to the picture of a departure from terrestrial cable based infrastructure.
Justification: These developments should be of interest to the Environment Agency both as a means of ensuring corporate resilience but also in terms of the potential impact on land use and landscapes that infrastructure choices can have. HAPSMobile, a Japanese company recently test flew a giant solar powered drone that beamed internet access from the stratosphere. The 80 metre wingspan Sunglider drone hosted video calls from 19 kilometres above New Mexico during a 20 hour test flight. Providing internet access in this way has parallels with other projects to use both balloons (%23*****) and satellites (%23*****), negating the need for conventional telecommunications infrastructure such as mobile phone masts. Google is experimenting with a wireless high speed internet network using light. Project Taara is being trialled in Kenya. The network functions on the same principle as fibre optic cable, but without the cabling, transferring high speed internet between terminals up to 12 miles. The system could have applications in providing high speed connectivity where its challenging, dangerous or too costly to lay fibre cables, such as over rivers, rural areas, or in post-conflict and disaster-stricken spots. &%23160;In another recent development a cryptocurrency startup used satellite technology to facilitate transactions of virtual currency BitCoin without access to the internet. The experiment took place in Venezuela, a country with limited and intermittent access to both the internet and electricity. The startup created a “space node” that uses an established system which uses satellites to broadcast data between points called BlockStream. The node on the ground sends and receives BitCoin transaction data directly via satellite. Using local mesh networks it would be possible to connect devices and exchange data, increasing usability of BitCoin in a country with low technological infrastructure, bypassing the internet and demonstrating the open and borderless character of BitCoin and blockchain systems.
Primary Article Title: No internet, no problem. Venezuela gets bitcoin satellite node

Summary Sentence: Developments in transparent materials, silicon recycling and heat absorbing liquids suggest that architecture, specifically windows, may become an increasing important aspect of solar energy generation.
Justification:
These developments should be of interest to the Environment Agency from the perspective of contributing to net zero through asset management. It should also be of interest from a waste management perspective and also from a land management angle. Specially tinted solar panels could allow for photovoltaics and farming to take place on the same land. The orange coloured solar panels absorb specific wavelengths of light for energy generation, but still allow the wavelengths needed for plant growth to pass through. A similar system could allow farmers to profit from crops and energy simultaneously and even grow food with superior nutritional value through optimised light wavelengths. Researchers have reached a new efficiency record for transparent solar cells, designed to sit between panels of window glass. The solar panel is made of an organic, or carbon-based, design rather than conventional silicon. UbiQD, an advanced materials company, has developed transparent solar panels based around quantum dots. Quantum dots are nanoparticles that become excited from exposure to UV light. They release photons that travel along the transparent panel towards its edge. The perimeter is fitted with solar cells, which convert the photons into electrical current. The solar cell edging sits in the frame of a window, out of sight. As these technologies come to the fore, innovations in conventional silicon solar panel recycling are emerging. Researchershave demonstrated a simple efficient method to recycling silicon wafers into nanoparticles in an aqueous solution without using toxic chemicals. The process can control the sizes of the nanoparticles which can then be reused in optics, photonics, medicine, and other fields. The system proved successful with HR (High resistivity), N-type (Nitrogen-doped), and P-type (Phosphorus-doped) and Si-ITO heterostructure solar panels. While not energy generating, a team of Singapore scientists have developed a “smart window” that uses a liquid solution trapped between two glass panels to trap thermal heat during the day and release it at night, potentially cutting down on the need for air conditioning systems. The liquid consists of micro-hydrogel, water, and a stabilising compound.
As well as trapping heat the liquid becomes opaque as it warms, further helping to block out the light and keep the room cool. It returns to its transparent state as it cools. The team believes their system could reduce office energy demands by 45 per cent, but it remains to be seen whether potential consumers would be willing to trade lower visibility for greater energy efficiency. Researchers have developed a transparent material made of wood that can potentially outperform glass in terms of durability, weight and safety (splintering rather than shattering). Transparent wood is made by oxidising and treating balsa wood at room temperature with oxidisation and bleaching. The wood is then penetrated with a synthetic polymer called polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), creating a product that is virtually transparent.Glass comes with a large carbon footprint. Transparent wood is five times more thermally efficient than glass, cutting energy costs. It is from a sustainable materials with low carbon emissions. It’s also compatible with existing industrial processing equipment, promising an easy manufacturing transition.
Primary Article Title: Tinted solar panel farms can grow food while generating electricity

Summary Sentence: Just as recent advances move the World closer to a quantum computing future, it’s been discovered that natural cosmic rays could hold development back.
Justification: Among the many applications and transformations that quantum computing promises the Environment Agency may be interested most in those around modelling of environmental phenomena, including catchment behaviours and chemical reactions. In this vein Google recently announced that they had successfully modelled the first quantum simulation of a chemical reaction. Google used its Sycamore computer to perform the simulation. In previous experiments Sycamore completed a calculation in 200 seconds that would take a state-of-the-art supercomputer 10,000 years to finish. Sycamore simulated a diazene molecule undergoing a process where the hydrogen atoms rearranged themselves around the nitrogen ones.The same process was modelled on normal computer for comparison. Google believes that they will be able to scale up the algorithm for more complex chemical reactions with greater numbers of qubits (the quantum version of the classical binary bit physically realized with a two-state device). A Toronto based start up called Xanadu suggests a way to address this by putting access to quantum computing available through the cloud. Xanadu’s computer is based on photonic quantum computing which is more stable than other technologies and can more easily integrate into telecommunication systems, potentially paving the way for connecting quantum computers together into powerful networks, known as “time multiplexing” architectures. Amongst the many technical issues for quantum developers to overcome is the discovery that background environmental radiation is of a sufficient level to disrupt quantum computing systems based on superconducting materials that produce qubits via charged pairs of electrons. This could limit the locations in which such computers could be used as they may need to be shielded e.g. through underground locations or material such as lead. While this discovery may present technological, geographical and economic barriers to realisation, it also suggests that qubits could present a new avenue to pursue in developing radiation monitoring technologies.
Primary Article Title: Google achieves first quantum simulation of a chemical reaction

Summary Sentence: Renewed interest in the Moon for exploratory and potentially exploitative purposes is rising at the same time as a call for greater protection for Earth’s nearest celestial neighbour.
Justification: The USA is not alone in its interest in the Moon - at least ten other missions are scheduled before the end of 2021. Nasa has outlined plans to return astronauts by 2024 as part of its Artemis programme, including the first female astronaut to visit the Moon. The plan also calls for the establishment of a base known as Artemis Base Camp to create the infrastructure needed for long term exploration. Deposits of water ice have been discovered at the lunar South Pole, which could support humans or make rocket fuel at a lower cost than transporting it from Earth and serve as the foundation for a lunar economy. Nasa has already funded a project to develop drilling equipment and a mass spectrometer to measure how much ice in the sample is lost as the ice turns from a solid to a vapour in the vacuum of the lunar environment. Nasa have approached telecommunications company Nokia to build a 4G network to support communications on the lunar surface. Uses will include command and control functions, the remote control of lunar rovers, real-time navigation, and high-definition video streaming. With this comes ambiguity over how individuals, nations and corporations can use lunar resources. President Donald Trump has signed an executive order on off-Earth resources which suggest that celestial resources including the Moon are framed in commercial terms. The Moon is known to be a source of helium, which is becoming increasingly rare on Earth (%23*****). There is also the potential for rare earth element extraction. Some are proposing that the Moon should be granted legal personhood in order to give it legal protection from overexploitation and environmental damage. Similar protections have already been granted to rivers including the Ganges (%23*****). Areas such as the Sea of Tranquility where Neil Armstrong first set foot on the Moon could be granted special protection. The Moon has both a physical (tides) and spiritual agency on the Earth, being a part of cultural myths and religious beliefs. Granting the Moon personhood In practice could mean regulated activities on resource extraction and other activities and limits on how its geological features can be used, ensuring that our presence on the Moon reflects changing attitudes to environmental exploitation on Earth. In this sense experience of best practice in environmental regulation could become valued, particularly as the Environment Agency is considered ‘a world class regulator.
Primary Article Title: Can the Moon be a person? As lunar mining looms, a change of perspective could protect Earth’s ancient companion

Summary Sentence: The first global standard for graphene (Gr) has just been established.
Justification: This could be significant in leading to a wider uptake of graphene production and applications, some of which could be of interest to the Environment Agency in areas such as water quality (%23*****), manufacturing and construction(%23*****), and electronics (%23****) alongside considerations around waste management. The Graphene Flagship Standardization Committee (GFSC) has recently launched a Standardization Certificate, which recognises the efforts and expertise of those developing international standards or technical specifications in graphene and related materials. The aim of the award is to standardise commercial graphene. The global graphene market was valued at $35 million in 2018, and could reach $406 million by 2026. Standardisation may therefore become increasingly important in realisation. There’s already an issue with ‘fake graphene’ which doesn’t have the properties of ‘true’ graphene. The lack of consistency and fraud is thought to essentially be holding back both research and industry. Establishing standards may catalyse innovation, increase efficiency and reduce costs and lower barriers to market entry. Standardisation may also lead to regulation, which in turn could have implications for the Environment Agency’s regulatory remit.
Primary Article Title: World's first graphene standardization certificate and awards
Author: Fourtané, S
Keywords: regulation graphene Gr standardisation standardization "Graphene Flagship Standardization Committee" GFSC fraud "fake graphene" waste "water quality" manufacturing construction waste

Summary Sentence: Two Microsoft projects could suggest a way to reduce the energy and resource burdens of data storage.
Justification: Recently Microsoft revealed that their experiments with marine data storage (%23*****) had been successful. Placing data centres underwater avoids the costs of cooling servers and greater energy efficiency. Over half the world’s population lives close to coastal areas, potentially creating smoother web access through having data centres nearby. Data creation and storage is also increasing at a significant rate. Microsoft have attempted to address this through the creation of a data storage medium made of quartz glass. They’ve experimented with DNA data storage, as have others (%23*****), but found glass storage to be more practical. Just like DVDs are burnt and read, infrared layers are used to distort the glass, which can be read by lasers and decoded back into data. Microsoft was able to put 75.6TB of data onto fused silica, which is a 2.5-inch hard disk drive. By comparison the largest hard disk drives in the world currently have a 20TB data storage capacity on a 3.5-inch hard disk drive. Quartz is one of the most ubiquitous minerals on Earth, meaning that glass storage devices may be less tied to access to rare minerals and metals. This may mean that end of life electronics are easier to recycle, impacting on waste management issues of waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE).
Primary Article Title: Microsoft retrieves its Underwater Data Center, reveals findings
Author: Papadopoulos, L
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.sciencetimes.com/articles/27396/20200921/petabyte-hard-disk-drive-glass.htm

Summary Sentence: A New Zealand startup is trialling a commercial long range wireless power transmission.
Justification: This development should be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as it has the potential to alter approaches to infrastructure provision and the environmental impacts it generates. The company called Emrod has developed a method to safely transmit electricity without the use of copper wire between two points within line of sight of each other. They are currently trialling the system with a power generation company, Powerco. The prototype can currently transmit only a few kilowatts of power, but it’s thought that this could easily be scaled up to transmit 100 times the power over longer distances at around 70 per cent efficiency.The system uses a transmitting antenna, a series of relays and a receiving rectenna capable of converting microwave energy into electricity. The beams use the non-ionizing Industrial, Scientific and Medical band of the radio spectrum, including frequencies commonly used in Wi-Fi and Bluetooth. A "low power laser safety curtain" immediately shuts down power transmission before any object, like a bird, drone, power thief or helicopter, can touch the main beam. Atmospheric conditions don’t impede efficiency, and the only limiting factor being line of sight to transmitting power at a fraction of the infrastructure costs, maintenance costs and environmental impacts of conventional wired solutions. The technology is not particularly new - Nikolai Tesla envisaged such as system and power has been transmitted from space to Earth using similar principles (%23*****). It is mainly the advances in metamaterials technology that allow microwave energy to be converted back into electricity efficiently.Powerco envisage using Emrod’s technology to deliver electricity in remote places, or across challenging terrain, or continue power supply during maintenance activities. It could also be used to transmit power from remote renewable energy plants to markets. This could also see temporary deployment to address shortfalls in conventional infrastructure compromised by incidents.
Primary Article Title: NZ to trial world-first commercial long-range, wireless power transmission
Author: Blain, L

Summary Sentence: Cyanobacteria growth controlled by fungal parasites adds nutrition to aquatic food webs.
Justification:
Cyanobacteria, otherwise known as blue-green algae, covering lakes and rivers during warm summers, not only produces toxins but also reduces the oxygen concentration in the water leading to fish kills and death of aquatic organisms that Environment Agency monitors. Researchers have now discovered that fungal parasites cause infection that can be used to control the growth of cyanobacteria algal blooms in our freshwaters and impact the stability of ecosystems, and moreover add valuable nutrients into food cycle by making cyanobacteria an easier prey to consume.
The greenish-bluish algal blooms cause various water quality concerns worldwide; and higher temperatures and increased quantities of nutrients in water bodies lead to excessive development of blue-green algal blooms that affect water quality. Yet the blue-green algae can be infected and eventually killed by a fungus called Chytrids, and then broken down to shorter pieces, to be consumed by aquatic organisms such as zoo plankton. Without this breaking down of the infected cyanobacteria filaments they could not become easy prey for their natural predators, and in the process of doing so, the fatty fungi themselves become a valuable dietary addition to the aquatic food webs.
Primary Article Title: Parasitic fungi keep harmful blue-green algae in check
Author: Forschungsverbund Berlin

Summary Sentence: Future living in an Artificial Intelligence city can be more sustainable.
Justification:
Collaboration between the world’s leading technology companies has resulted in designing Terminus AI City in Chongqing, China; the first urban centre called Cloud Valley, to be completely operated by an artificial intelligence system. It was designed by BIG to be sustainable living for future and to create a space where people, nature and technology can prosper together. BIG is the company known for their environmental ambition and also recognised for designing the power station covered by a ski slope.
Terminus AI City Operating System, or TACOS software, operates everything for example buildings including green roof panels and adjusting solar panel movements, fire and rescue, digital assistants to support the residents, and the TACOS system constantly collects data to improve efficiencies and impact various features of city planning. This is done by the Internet of Things-enabled devices.
With constantly increasing amount of data that is also analysed by the artificial intelligence, the AI city is endlessly advancing.
The sustainable architecture enhances your life and wellbeing, the personal assistant suggests your clothing according to the weather and reminds you what to do, and you have e-bikes and intelligent, self-driving cars if you cannot work from home. People and technology not just co-exist but work together harmoniously.
Primary Article Title: BIG plans artificial intelligence-run city campus in China

Summary Sentence: New research suggests that direct air capture technologies (DAC) could exacerbate demand for energy and water, yet overall would help to avoid rising food costs from land use competition between bioenergy, afforestation and farming.
Justification: DAC may be an essential strategy in negative emissions technologies (NETs) if the UK wishes to successfully realise its Net Zero ambitions, and may be an emerging sector requiring regulation. DAC is an engineered separation process that uses aqueous or amine sorbents to remove CO2 from ambient air, compress it and inject it into geologic reservoirs. DAC is currently not sufficiently factored into carbon capture plans, which mainly focus on bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) and afforestation. Both approaches create clashes with themselves and other land uses, including food production and biodiversity. DAC offers a solution but is itself reliant on energy and water resources. However DAC can help ameliorate food-water-energy trade-offs when deployed alongside BECCS and afforestation, particularly if renewable energy is scaled up to power it. Delaying introducing DAC approaches could lead to worse issues around energy and water further down the line and increase reliance on BECCS and afforestation, increasing pressures on crops and habitats. DACs effectively provides a ‘backstop’ on the cost of dealing with carbon and could start to remove multiple GtCO2 yr−1 from the atmosphere as early as 2035. Unlike bioenergy and forestry DACs are reasonably independent of location, requiring only a suitable geological storage. The physical footprint of these units would be much smaller than BECCS or afforestation, and it would not require any particular land type, only proximity to a geologic reservoir for storage. The regions with the greatest potential are the USA, China, South America and Australia, where there is suitable geology, plenty of natural gas supplies and further potential for transition to renewable energies. DACs solutions may also appear within the UK. There is the potential also for chemical impacts on water from the chemistry of storing carbon dioxide underground. Such impacts, alongside the potential for a new regulatory remit for the Environment Agency may need to be considered.
Primary Article Title: Food–energy–water implications of negative emissions technologies in a +1.5 °C future
Author: Fuhrman, J; et al
Secondary_URLs: Startup Sucks Carbon From the Air, Turns It Into Rock | IE (interestingengineering.com)

Summary Sentence: As corporations, regions and nation states make public pledges on achieving Net Zero, one company commits to putting more water back into ecosystems than it consumes.​
Justification: The Environment Agency as a regulator of the water environment should be interested in this early example of “net positive water” and consider the impacts of how this movement could develop. Retail giant Walmart has announced that it will reach Net Zero in its global operations by 2040, without offsetting. It’s strategies for achieving this include a commitment to renewable energy and electrifying its vehicle fleet, using low energy cooling systems and habitat restoration of terrestrial and marine ecosystems. The state of California has vowed to ban the sale of gasoline powered vehicles from 2035, joining 15 other nations who have made similar pledges. This clashes with the pro-fossil fuel policies of President Donald Trump’s White House. China recently announced that it’s emissions will peak in 2030 before achieving carbon neutrality by 2060. China is the world's biggest source of carbon dioxide, responsible for around 28% of global emissions. Building on this trend for environmentally positive pledges Microsoft recently announced that it intends to achieve a net positive water footprint by 2030, meaning it intends to contribute more energy back into the environment in the places it operates than it is drawing out across all river basins inside its footprint. This will be achieved through reducing the intensity of water use across its operations, measured in amount of water consumed per megawatt of energy. Secondly Microsoft intends to replenish water into water stressed areas through investment in area wetland restoration, removing and replacing non water-permeable surfaces such as asphalt, which prevent rainfall absorption. Microsoft intends to use artificial intelligence (AI)to provide identify and optimise where their efforts will have greatest impact. With some areas of the UK already water stressed the Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider how investment from the private sector could help achieve net positive water footprint, should other companies or organisations decide to follow Microsoft’s example.
Primary Article Title: California sets goal to ban sale of new gasoline-powered passenger vehicles starting in 2035

Summary Sentence: One of the many legacies of the coronavirus pandemic could be significant changes to current acceptable geographical barriers to employment and education.
Justification: The Environment Agency could be impacted by these changes as all employers will be and could lose a competitive edge without changing terms and conditions to mirror emerging societal expectations. National lockdowns have provided a catalyst for accelerating the move to remote working across the globe. Many organisations are planning to continue with a significant remote working presence. Nearly three quarters of UK company directors said they would be keeping increased home-working after coronavirus, while 43% have embraced aspects of flexible working such as compressed hours. Many employees experienced reduced hours during lockdown&%2358; evidence suggests that reducing the length of the working week could help to save jobs&%2358; a four-day week could save half a million jobs in the public sector alone (it’s worth noting that the two day weekend was introduced in the 1930s to stimulate employment). While this is not a novel proposition the idea of alternative working practices has gained greater focus in the wake of Covid-19. Similar ideas are being discussed in education circles, including formalising rights to remote working to ensure that there is flexibility and resilience to learning, in the event of future systematic shocks. As work and education become less reliance on presence and more on connectivity, responses are emerging. Croatia is on the verge of being one of the first countries to offer Digital Nomad visas. These will allow and encourage workers who need nothing more than a good internet connection to work. The visa will encourage people regardless of citizenship the right to work in Croatia for up to 12 months, in return stimulating the local economy. The American hospitality industry has been responding to the current crisis through the notion of the ‘Schoolcation’. With many students learning remotely, families are looking to take their families on vacation at a time of year when it would typically not be practical, saving money in the process. Hotels are in turn offering distance-learning vacations that includes dedicated “classroom” space for connecting to lessons back home and private tutors and tech support, plus extra-curricular educational activities. If such concepts become more mainstream then the Environment Agency’s workforce could be impacted. It could mean that seasonal impacts on productivity and availability become muted. Employee wellbeing may improve, and there may be a reappraisal of salary demands alongside changes to terms and conditions. It could also mean that employment conditions around geography and citizenship make the Environment Agency a less attractive employee next to other organisations, and may also make some roles harder to recruit for. It may also drive a distinct difference in working practices between field and office staff.
Primary Article Title: Coronavirus has shown why we need a four-day working week
Author: Bernal, N
Secondary_URLs:

Summary Sentence: Several new developments highlight that a merge of ‘man and machine’ may be coming ever closer.
Justification: Tech entrepreneur Elon Musk recently generated headlines with a demonstration of a brain computer interface called ‘Neuralink’, developed by Musk’s company of the same age. Neuralink is a coin sized device that would be placed in contact with the top of the brain through a robot conducted operation. It is charged via induction. Musk also displayed three pigs representing a ‘before, during and after’ of Neuralink function and removal. Intended applications could include humans to control computers and phones and access information with just their thoughts. It may also help treat neurological disorders including memory and hearing loss, blindness to paralysis, depression and brain damage. The technology is still in its early stages, but the apparent simplification of insertion and use may prove an important step forward. Such interfaces however may not require surgery in the brain. A successful experiment in Australia was able to wirelessly restore the transmission of brain impulses out of the body of patients with upper limb paralysis, enabling them to complete daily tasks such as online banking, shopping and texting, which previously had not been available to them. The Strentrode implant was placed alongside their brain’s motor cortex via keyhole surgery in the neck. Another brain computer interface has been developed that uses artificial intelligence to generate images based on faces that people were looking at. The system was trained on analysis of brain waves generated from people looking at a range of faces. Scientists in China have developed an implantable data storage material made from silk proteins. The silk has a capacity of 64 GB per square inch and can operate under harsh conditions including bacterial contamination, high humidity, high magnetic fields and clinical-level gamma radiation. Infrared light etches information onto the silk, which was still retrievable after 30 minutes of high level microwave exposure. Due to the biocompatible nature of the organic material it could be used to store personalised medical information, but further development is needed to match current data extraction speeds. Australian doctors are preparing to trial a bionic eye that may be able to restore vision to the blind. ‘Gennaris’, which includes a camera and a wireless transmitter bypasses damaged optic nerves, allowing the retina to transmit signals to the brain. It is hoped that Gennaris will have medical applications to restore blindness. Successful transplants in sheep may pave the way for human trails in the future. While there are some significant potential medical benefits of these and similar technologies there may also be moral and ethical issues should the technology become more prevalent, for example around data ownership and personal privacy. To focus on the operational implications there may be issues around the security of such devices, for example there have previously been concerns around the prospect of ‘brainjacking’ (%23*****). Technologically enhanced senses could bring the ability to ‘see’ ‘smell’ or ‘hear’ outside of normal human parameters, which may have applications in monitoring and surveillance. People with such transplants may therefore be at an advantage for certain job vacancies. The transformation from analogue to digital information storage and retrieval has reduced the time and distance from knowledge to brain. A direct link between the brain and digital information could reduce this even further, potentially down to seconds, with significant potential for increasing productivity in the knowledge economy.
Primary Article Title: Opening eyes to a frontier in vision restoration

Summary Sentence: Low-cost and non-toxic nanofluid provides a sustainable way to recover oil.
Justification:
New study demonstrates that the use of nanotechnology delivers cheaper and more environmentally sustainable way of producing oil until we can move completely to renewable energy sources. Utilising sodium nanofluid, it is possible to recover so called “heavy oil” in a more sustainable way; this low-cost and sustainable nanofluid removes the need for heat, hence reducing green gas production in the process, and the sodium dissipates automatically following the chemical reaction, with no contamination by chemicals in environment. Approximately 70% of the world’s global oil reserves consist of heavy oil, characterised by high viscosity but the sodium nanofluid technology can be used for recovery of any viscosity type oil. The researchers note that the recovery in the field is likely to be less efficient than in the laboratory conditions, also impacted by the conditions of the oilfield. The type of solvent the sodium nanofluid is mixed with also impacts the oil recovery rate.
The researchers from Houston focused on the enhanced oil recovery in the oil fields, but this nanotechnology could be used to make light oil, for instance mixing sodium nanofluid with silicone oil, for households uses such as clearing pipes blocked by grease.
Primary Article Title: Inexpensive, non-toxic nanofluid could be a game-changer for oil recovery
Author: UNIVERSITY OF HOUSTON
Keywords: pollution petroleum oil contamination remediation “oil recovery” technology nanotechnology nanofluid pipes hydrogen sodium&%23160;

Summary Sentence: Waste-to-energy process is lacking waste for production of heat for households.​
Justification:
A case study from Denmark, Europe’s number one waste burner with 23 incinerators, demonstrates how previous processes of dealing with waste through burning, to generate “renewable” energy, are no longer suited due to climate goals. Instead of increasing waste import for burning from countries such as the UK and Germany, which accounted for third of the waste burnt in 2018, Denmark has plans to overhaul their entire waste management system, to comply with their new climate law, with the aim to reduce incineration, to cut greenhouse gas emissions and to move to offshore wind power for their electricity and heating needs.
Previous investment in building incinerators was seen as an improvement in comparison to landfills or shipping waste to other countries, yet the process increases CO2 emissions. As increased recycling and circular economy incentives are now mainstream and are reducing waste burnt in incinerators, new plans are needed for energy production, in particular for district heating in Denmark where 60% of households use district heating, generated from incinerating municipal solid waste. This also impacts us when Denmark is no longer accepting waste from the UK and is improving recycling further. Taking into account all types of most common waste materials will have considerable impacts for the Danes’ lifestyle and country’s sustainability.
Primary Article Title: Denmark’s ‘devilish’ waste dilemma - Its state-of-the-art trash incinerators are sending its climate ambitions up in smoke.
Author: Schaart, E.

Summary Sentence: New practical low-cost format of MoS2 has various applications including water treatment.
Justification:
One of the most useful functions of Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is to remove mercury from water, but with its unique properties it has potential to be utilised for gas, chemical and light sensing, energy storage, generating hydrogen fuel from water, and as a component in light-based microprocessors, making faster computing speeds. The new powder format of MoS2 lowers the cost and enables producing it in large quantities, and is practical for dispersal into liquid solutions, specifically impactful for water treatment.
Until now, the challenges experienced with the fabrication process have restricted the wider use of this material, but now the researchers have refined a method to fabricate powder instead of nanoribbons of MoS2, enabling production at a large scale, reducing the cost of this material by 3,000 times. Mercury consumption from contaminated water sources or from eating fish can lead to brain and kidney damage, with younger people more at risk. The new format of MoS2 makes it a new alternative for mercury removal from water.
Primary Article Title: The right formula for scaling production of promising material to decontaminate water
Author: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT AUSTIN

Summary Sentence: Specially designed synthetic substrates can help to accelerate natural habitat recovery.
Justification: These innovations may be of interest to the Environment Agency in the context of natural capital and habitat restoration, particularly where it can bring benefits to flood management, coastal defence and water quality. Many coastal ecosystems are in decline around the World. At the same time the ecosystem benefits of habitats are being recognised, such as salt marsh from a flood defence perspective. Many coastal plants have ‘emergent traits’, meaning that while they are resilient in large numbers, individual plants can easily be swept away. This can make re-establishing habitats challenging. One experimental approach has used biodegradable mats made with the by-products of potato processing to help restore seagrass meadows - the same approach could also work with salt marshes and other coastal ecosystems. By mimicking stems or roots, the mats protect the young plants. As the plant matures the mats disappear. A similar approach is being used to encourage coral reef growth with 3D printed terracotta tiles. The interlocking textured hexagonal tiles create a structurally complex foundation for coral attachment and to prevent sedimentation, one of the major threats to corals.Tiles seeded with coral fragments have already been deployed. The production of the tiles themselve is more environmentally friendly than similar structures in concrete or metal. Artificial reef tiles such as these could help to conserve reef biodiversity worldwide. A similar approach may also be of benefit to other marine habitats.
Primary Article Title: Improving coastal restoration by temporarily imitating nature

Summary Sentence: Detecting lead in environment can be faster and cheaper with no lab testing required.
Justification:
Researchers from Rutgers University, New Jersey, have succeeded in creating a new type of low-cost device for detecting lead contamination in-situ, which means that Environment Agency would be able to rapidly identify toxic contamination. This consequently allows timely interventions to appropriately manage the contaminated areas such as waterways or dykes with dredged materials or sediments in question, and hence limit the potential effects on wildlife and environment. The rapid detection is beneficial in comparison to the current process of collecting the samples, then sending them to laboratory to be tested, receiving results days later, with an expensive bill to pay for this service.
This low-cost portable tool could be utilised in detecting lead not only in environment but also by water companies, home-owners, local authorities or schools to test water their water supplies. The focus of the research focused was find a way to test heavy metals in contaminated land, particularly to analyse lead from river sediments or from the bottom of harbours. The new sensitive device extracts lead from the sediment sample taken on site, purifies it using a thin film of graphene oxide to examine the sample and measure trace levels of lead within minutes.
Nevertheless, further research is required to verify the performance standard and to develop the device for markets in two to four years’ time.
Primary Article Title: New device can measure toxic lead within minutes

Summary Sentence: A new material that can self-heal in air and underwater has been developed.
Justification:
Discovery phase work is done towards a future platform suited for both air and ground missions by the USA Army and Texas A&M University researchers, and they have now reached an exceptional scientific advancement with development of a new epoxy material that can autonomously heal in both air and underwater at room temperature. The relevance to wider Defra is that this opens unprecedented opportunities outside military, such as air vehicles not needing a crew or robotic applications.
The synthetic material in question, due to its 3D printable soft polymer networks and their ability to interbond, is capable of spontaneously regenerating itself when damaged and can be programmed to shift shape. In 30-50 years from now, after further research, the material could be embedded with intelligence, programmed to autonomously adapt to its environment or to return to a memorised shape, allowing it to change between liquid and solid form multiple times.
The focus of the research project was to create a system of materials that can simultaneously provide structure, sensing and response. Further research needs to find answers to many scientific questions to focus on improving knowledge of material behaviours and enhancing performance and durability. Materials with an elastomeric network can simultaneously demonstrate structure, sensing and response abilities. Currently it responds to temperature and light only but in future it could also respond to other stimuli, controlled remotely.
Primary Article Title: Researchers explore self-healing materials
Author: U.S. Army Research Laboratory

Summary Sentence: 3D printing soil explored can become a sustainable alternative to concrete in construction.
Justification:
As the extensive environmental costs of the construction industry are receiving increasing criticism, a new technology is developed to be a sustainable alternative for replacing concrete manufacturing, which accounts for circa 7% per cent of international carbon dioxide emissions, according to the International Energy Agency, and cannot be recycled. 3D-print buildings using local soil can reduce not only the carbon footprint from the concrete manufacturing itself but also from energy, transporting it long distances and high amount of waste, leading to reduced costs.
The next challenge is to investigate how the soil's load-bearing capabilities can be improved to ensure a high standard in order to meet existing building regulations. As soil properties vary, it is necessary to ensure they are suited to be improved or converted into printable building material.
This eco-friendly technology has a potential of manufacturing building structures quickly and cheaply, also pioneering building designs that are specifically adapted to the needs of local climatic needs. It can create a new paradigm of green construction that uses local, sustainable materials, the way humans used to build with locally sourced materials before the widespread use of concrete and the conventional mass-production construction industry.
The move to 3D-print concrete would not only facilitate replacing concrete but allowing for construction projects in challenging environments such as building all-weather roads in the subarctic. Researchers will also plan to explore the use of this technology to build human settlements on the moon or Mars.
Primary Article Title: In situ Resource Utilization and Reconfiguration of Soils Into Construction Materials for the Additive Manufacturing of Buildings

Summary Sentence: UK psychiatrists are proposing that adding lithium to tap water could help address mental health issues.
Justification: The Environment Agency may wish to consider the implications of this on water quality and aquatic wildlife while it is still in a conceptual stage. Previously it has been highlighted that adding lithium to tap water could help to address issues of depression in some areas (%23***** - need to rewrite this sentence when HSDBi online). The latest research a UK research team found a strong link between geographical areas with high levels of lithium in public drinking water and lower suicide rates. This suggests that higher trace levels of lithium in drinking water may exert an anti-suicidal effect, potentially to improve community mental health. Lithium has been used in psychiatric treatment since the 1940s as a mood stabiliser. Previous studies suggest that lithium can be highly bioavailable to fish, and can influence gill activity in rainbow trout, but that water chemistry, particularly sodium concentrations, can influence this. Measures to address public health in this way could add to lithium levels downstream of sewage treatment, if not removed, and impact on fish and other organisms. The prevalence of lithium is already growing through battery availability.
Primary Article Title: Scientists propose adding psychoactive drug to our water supplies

Summary Sentence: It may soon be possible to visit space in a six hour balloon trip.
Justification: New developments in space travel should be of interest to the Environment Agency as any launch activities may have regulatory implications, particularly where there is combustion, fuel and emissions. Currently there is already regulatory activity around this embryonic industry such as Newquay, Cornwall. Space tourism and payload deployment is anticipated to be a growth industry globally, with the many business models based on combustion and propulsion, either directly from the ground or from planes. Start up Space Perspective is taking a different approach based around a high altitude balloon called Spaceship Neptune. Their design consists of a pressurised capsule suspended below a hydrogen balloon. The capsule can carry eight passengers over a six hour flight at the anticipated price of $125,000, half of that offered by other space tourism operators. Moving to this model for space tourism could conceivable change the regulatory effort and mechanisms applied to the sector. Another development which could also impact on current assumptions of the growing space sector can be seen through China’s development of a floating spaceport for rocket launches. The Eastern Aerospace Port is being developed off the coast of Haiyang city in Shandong province. The American company SpaceX is similarly looking to develop off-shore launch facilities which reduce the risk to populated areas near to terrestrial launch sites. The prospect of offshore launch facilities in UK waters could alter or indeed remove the regulatory remit for the Environment Agency in this sector, but present a different set of potential environmental impacts that currently anticipated. The prospect of launch capabilities in international waters also suggest that space launches may sit outside of any regulatory remit, despite concerns that not enough is currently known about the environmental impact of rocket emissions (%23*****).
Primary Article Title: Discover a new perspective of Earth with Spaceship Neptune
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//futurism.com/the-byte/china-building-floating-spaceport-rockets
Keywords: regulation space air pollution launch tourism transport balloon China marine sea spaceport rocket offshore SpaceX "Eastern Aerospace Port" "Spaceship Neptune" "Space Perspective" Haiyang hydrogen

Summary Sentence: A major global fast food chain is set to add a bioprinted meat product to its menu.
Justification: While the technology has been developing for a while (%23*****) the significance of adoption by a large global brand could signify mainstream realisation at a commercial scale, and may also have an impact on the Environment Agency regulated poultry sector. KFC has collaborated with 3D Bioprinting Solutions to produce the World’s first bioprinted chicken nuggets. The nuggets are produced from a meat cultured from a single cell sample, plus plant based ingredients. The product isn’t technically vegetarian because of this, but no animals are further harmed or killed during production. KFC believes that their approach could reduce energy consumption by half, greenhouse gas emissions 25 fold and land use by a factor of 100 compared to traditional meat production. This echoes a wider trend to move away from livestock farming. Meat and dairy still remain significant sources of human calories, but health and environmental concerns see tastes moving to alternatives. The coronavirus pandemic seems to have accelerated this trend as disruptions to supply, sick workers and higher prices led to consumers looking for alternatives. By way of example the USA saw plant-based meat sales surge 264% in the 9 weeks ended May 2nd 2020, and in the first week of March 2020, oat milk sales were up 347% year-over-year against a backdrop of declining dairy demand. As dairy sales continue to decrease and plant based milk sales increase, examples are emerging of some dairy farmers embracing a switch to arable in order to serve both markets. Plant milk companies such as Oatly have announced partnerships to help dairy farmers transition. Dairy companies are also adding plant based milk to their portfolios. Some farmers are splitting their land between pasture and crop. Dairy milk has a much greater carbon, land and water footprint than plant based milk, but plant based milk has been associated with pesticide use and biodiversity issues, though there are also sustainable examples in existence. Transition programmes allow farmers to continue to earn a living off the land whilst continuing to serve similar markets, and demonstrate that as the livestock industry slowly wanes that both approaches can be complementary rather than in competition whilst maintaining a focus on positive environmental outcomes.
Primary Article Title: KFC to 3D bioprint chicken nuggets soon
Author: Papadopoulos, L

Summary Sentence: Artificial intelligence (AI) is being used to define and map what humans consider to be the qualitative attributes of landscapes.
Justification: A project in Switzerland is using AI to assist with a statutory stocktake of one region’s different landscapes and their qualities in order to decide which ones should be preserved and promoted. Determining qualitative landscapes, rather than being in the eye of the beholder actually has common understandings, widely accepted across different cultures. This same consensus has been modelled within the AI system, allowing it to recognise spatial clusters which can be reinforced through ground truthing. This in turn can be used to automatically delineate land units to build up a comprehensive picture of widely accepted landscape typologies, which can inform spatial planning and conservation decisions. Similar systems could be useful in automating natural capital and ecosystems assessments. However the notions of beauty are being continuously constructed and re-constructed. An intervention like this may risk shaping expectations of what can be considered ‘beautiful’ and ‘valuable’ potentially limiting aspirations for environmental improvement in the long term without a considered application.
Primary Article Title: Who’s evaluating Swiss landscapes?
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" AI landscape mapping biodiversity beauty "nautral capital" landuse

Summary Sentence: New research suggests the World is set to experience a population decline, for which it is little prepared.
Justification: Population and demographics are one of the key global megatrends and as such will influence the Environment Agency’s own projections and expectations around environmental pressures. Falling fertility rates globally could mean that almost every country experiences a drop in population by the end of the century. This means that global population is expected to peak at around 9.7 billion in 2064, before falling to 8.8 billion by the end of the century, going against many expectations that populations will continue to grow. The UK is predicted to peak at 75 million in 2063, and fall to 71 million by 2100. Globally women had on average 2.7 children in 2017, compared to 4.7 in 1950. This number is expected to fall below the sustaining level of 2.1 to 1.7 by 2100. The driving force behind this is thought to be women having better access to education, work and contraception. Some countries, particularly those with a markedly ageing population could see dramatic population crashes by the end of the century. This could have significant repercussions for ageing populations, reducing both the tax base and labour force need to support their care. Immigration is one possible solution, with African countries possibly holding surplus labour. There is also emerging evidence that the economic uncertainty that the coronavirus pandemic has caused could further impact birth rates, leading to 500,000 less births in 2021, possibly further compounding the trend. A manifestation of a smaller population could challenge the current long term strategic and planning assumptions behind many areas of the Environment Agency’s work, such as flood management, water resources and land use.
Primary Article Title: Researchers say Earth is headed for “jaw-dropping” population decline
Author: Tangermann, V
