Summary Sentence: A clinical trial recently demonstrated that microdoses of the psychoactive compound THC, the main psychoactive constituent of cannabis, can relieve pain without the side effects normally associated with cannabis use.​
Justification: There is already evidence that common self administered painkillers and narcotic substances can impact on aquatic environments (%23*****), therefore the Environment Agency and partners may need to consider any wider implications for medical THC use becoming a widespread in medical use. The study showed that extremely low concentrations (microdoses) of Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) of around 500 micrograms administered three times a day was an effective pain reliever. Typically medical doses of cannabis are one gram of 15 per cent THC cannabis per day, equivalent to 150,000 micrograms of THC. The study therefore demonstrates that much lower doses could be as effective as those currently prescribed. The study could pave the way for more standardised use of cannabinoids in medical treatment, which in turn may lead to a more widespread environmental presence, though there may be a trade off between current levels of exposure and future lower medical doses. With some evidence to suggest that THC already negatively impacts important species (%23*****)this development could suggest a balance between human medical need and environmental impact.
Primary Article Title: Israeli researchers present first clinical evidence that cannabis at microdosing levels relieves pain
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ejp.1605
Keywords: "water quality" biodiversity pollution health medicine cannabis THC microdosing regulation Tetrahydrocannabinol

Summary Sentence: Innovations in data transfer suggest that internet speeds could start to get much faster.
Justification: A new microchip design addresses signal quality loss when electronic signals are converted to light signals for transmission via fibre optic cable. Normally this conversion takes place on separate microchips. In the new microchip electronic and photonic components sit tightly on top of one another, shortening transmission paths and reducing signal loss - termed ‘monolithic co-​integration’. The realisation of this microchip signifies that plasmonics, a branch of photonics, could provide the foundation for ultrafast chips. Such components are needed to serve the growing demand for faster data flow to meet demand for services such as high-​speed internet, digital telephony, and video and audio streaming. In a separate breakthrough researchers have achieved “breakneck” internet around one million times faster than current speeds. This has been achieved via a new cable containing a microcomb, which replaces the conventional array of lasers used to transmit data via fibre optic cable. The microcomb generates very sharp and equidistant frequency lines in a tiny microphotonic chip, which results in data flowing faster. The microcomb is compatible with current telecommunications infrastructure. Average internet speed in the USA is 50.2 megabits per second. The microcomb generated speeds of 44.2 terabits per second. Roll out of these technologies would impact all internet usage, including the Environment Agency’s. Such technologies may represent an overall efficiency gain for internet energy use, or may instead lead to increasing volumes of data which require more energy for transmission and storage, which in turn could have consequences for global climate change ambitions
Primary Article Title: Researchers squeezed breakneck 44.2 tbps through ordinary fiber optic cables
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//ethz.ch/content/main/en/news-and-events/eth-news/news/2020/07/new-plasmonic-chip-for-ultrafast-data-transmission-using-light.html
Keywords: Internet data "climate change" plasmonics laser microcomb "fibre optic" energy regulation "Net Zero"

Summary Sentence: The human labour currently involved in restoring ecosystems and fighting climate change is generally poorly paid and lacks protection, according to new research.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency as Defra is named specifically as being one organisation currently relying on volunteer labour to manage the impacts of climate change. Around the World environmentally focussed work is carried out by people who are either poorly paid or not paid at all. Reforestation, precious metal and mineral recovery and forest firefighting to name some activities are carried out with little or no wages to speak of - Defra itself is cited as relying heavily on volunteer labour for flood management. This situation creates concepts such as ‘green gig-economy’ and ‘eco-precariat’, suggesting that mobilising the labour force needed to realise global environmental protection and climate change adaptation requires careful consideration to ensure that this work is appropriately valued in terms of wages and health, safety and wellbeing protection. This is particularly acute where voluntary work has risk associated with it, such as fighting wildfires, which are increasing in frequency and scale. With increasing pressures on the military (%23*****), there are risks in relying on volunteers for this increasingly critical work. Schemes that utilise prison labour are already established in some countries (%23*****), but these also come with health and safety considerations. As with other aspects of human labour automation may have a role to play in complementing or competing with the green economy workforce. This is exemplified by Dendra, a start-up that intends to use technology to increase tree planting. Dendra uses a combination of image capture and artificial intelligence to map and assess degraded land to create restoration plans unique to a site’s ecological conditions. Drones are then used to plant seeds at the rate of 120 seeds a minute per drone, claimed to be significantly faster than traditional manual planting methods.In light of the reliance on green gig economy and eco-precariat concepts the Environment Agency and partners may have to consider the full picture of the environmental workforce, both paid and unpaid, in order to ensure future resilience in objective delivery.
Primary Article Title: The green gig economy&%2358; precarious workers are on the frontline of climate change fight
Author: Mahanty, S & Neimark, B
Secondary_URLs: https&%2358;//www.siliconrepublic.com/machines/dendra-funding-drones-biodiversity?
Keywords: "Climate change" biodiversity workforce labour costs reforestation flooding incident volunteer prison "green gig economy" "eco-precariat" automation drone Dendra

Summary Sentence: A lickable electronic screen can recreate almost any taste.
Justification: The device called the Norimaki Synthesizer triggers five different tastes on the users tongue - sweet, sour, salty, and bitter&%23160; and umami. Varying the degree of stimulation creates the sensation of different tastes. Previously similar devices have used electricity to stimulate the tongue directly (%23*****). The Norimaki Synthesizer works differently. It uses a series of five agar based flavoured gels. The user experiences all the tastes at once. However the flavours are ‘mixed’ through the device forming an electric circuit with the body. This allows for electrophoresis to take place. This is a process that moves molecules in a gel when an electrical current is applied, allowing them to be sorted by size based on the size of pores in the gel. The stronger the current the further the ingredients in the agar gels move from the tongue, allowing a mixture of currents on the five gels creating different tastes. With further development the device could simulate&%23160; the experience of smoking, or eating unhealthy foods, which may have benefits for public and environmental health. It may also have uses in marketing, effectively allowing people to ‘sample’ produce remotely before purchase, which help generate wider interest in UK produce.
Primary Article Title: This Lickable Screen Can Recreate Almost Any Taste or Flavor Without Eating Food
Author: Liszewski, A
Secondary_URLs:
https&%2358;//gizmodo.com/this-lickable-screen-can-recreate-almost-any-taste-or-f-1843609903

https&%2358;//dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3334480.3382984?
Keywords: Farming agriculture food regulation health "Norimaki Synthesizer" electrophoresis gel taste virtual

Summary Sentence: There are signs that urban farming is starting to scale as three large projects come to light.
Justification: A growing move towards urban agriculture and food production could mean the Environment Agency needs to refocus regulatory activities within both sectors away from rural settings. Thammasat University in Bangkok, Thailand recently unveiled the largest rooftop garden in Asia. The 22,000 square metre garden has been conceived for climate resilience and will grow organic produce, including rice without pesticides or fertilisers. A water management system that captures rainwater which is stored and re-used to water the fields and grow food. Any leftover water is filtered and led to one of four retention ponds, which are a back-up in case of drought. The World’s largest urban rooftop farm is currently under construction in Paris. The farm will grow soil free produce without pesticides or fungicides and reducing water use by 90 per cent vertically over a 14,000 sq metre site, where 20 staff will harvest up to 1,000kg up to 35 different varieties of fruit and vegetables, every day. The coronavirus pandemic has helped to illustrate the resilience that urban farming can bring to local communities. The World’s largest rooftop greenhouse now spans 15,000 square metres in Montreal, Canada. The greenhouse will meet growing demand for locally sourced foods, producing enough food to feed 10,000 families. Urban farming could reduce agricultural chemicals and water use significantly and bring great resilience to food supply. Regulation may also be easier through a transition from diffuse to point source pollution. Seeing several examples at scale suggests that other urban areas may follow suit.
Primary Article Title: Rooftop Garden&%2358; Sustainable Urban Agriculture
Author: Hoekema, S
Secondary_URLs:
https&%2358;//www.bbc.co.uk/news/video_and_audio/headlines/53853788/paris-world-s-largest-urban-rooftop-farm-in-progress

https&%2358;//www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/agriculture/worlds-largest-rooftop-greenhouse-opens-in-montreal/article32559909.ece
Keywords: Farming food agriculture urban Bangkok Paris Montreal pesticide fertiliser soil water regulation

Summary Sentence: A new method of molding plastic waste into usable forms could have implications for waste streams and the circular economy
Justification:
Scientists in Australia have developed a new method of pressure molding polymers into building bricks – reactive compression molding. Their work shows that when polymers that have previously undergone inverse vulcanisation are subject to heat and pressure

 they can be used to bind various ‘filler’ materials into structurally useable shapes. That opens the way to constructing building bricks out of a range of waste materials like plant fibres, sand or recycled PVC. As such it could be important step towards a

 circular economy, where materials that might otherwise have gone to landfill can be combined to make them economically useful once more. It may also displace processes like cement production that emit significant amounts of carbon dioxide. All of this is important

 to the EA as a waste regulator that could need to concern itself with the production and disposal of these new materials, and a proponent of climate change mitigation and adaptation.
Primary Article Title: New method of molding plastic waste into usable building bricks
Author: Flinders University
Keywords: waste; building materials; circular economy; recycling
GT: waste; building materials; circular economy; recycling

Summary Sentence: New regulations to dis-incentivise the creation of space debris point to the potential for new complex waste streams and pose the question, should the EA be involved in regulating the space environment?
Justification:
Economists in the US have proposed a new set of regulations for space travel intended to combat the issue of growing amounts of space debris. Currently operators are required to pay a launch fee designed to dis-incentivise unnecessary entry into space, but

 once in orbit operators have no further incentive to return their craft to earth or dispose of it properly. To address this gap a new orbital use fee is proposed – charging operators on the basis of the continued occupation of an orbit. If the craft is abandoned

 in orbit as debris then the charges continue. The proposal points to the continued development of space as a used and valued part of our environment. In doing so opens up a range of questions for the EA around the role it should be playing in developing the

 regulatory framework for use and protection of the space environment. Is space a part of our environment and, if it is, then how do we protect it? If it isn’t how can we protect the terrestrial environment from the potentially new and complex waste streams

 that could emerge from it in the coming years?
Primary Article Title: New regulations proposed to combat space debris open up questions around waste and remit
Author: Nick Lavars
Keywords: Space debris; waste; regulation

Summary Sentence: Statisticians have developed a new method of analysing water leak detection data, meaning leaks could be found quicker and water losses reduced.
Justification:
Statisticians have developed a statistical approach that could help reduce leakage from the water pipe network. The availability of future water resources is a top priority for the Environment Agency, including in its capacity as a regulator of the water

 industry. Water loss through leaks in the pipe network accounts for a substantial proportion total water consumed and reducing it is therefore a priority cross the sector. At the moment leaks are detectable through a system of pressure gauges along the pipes,

 but being able to precisely identify the location of a leak is a barrier to being able to deal with it in a timely and economic manner. Operators often use what are termed ‘hammer tests’ to narrow down their location. The flow in a pipe is abruptly halted

 and the resulting shock wave is monitored as it propagates back up through the pipe. Statistical techniques are then used to interpret the data and narrow down the possible area the leak could be in. At the moment that’s a slow computational process conducted

 by computers and accuracy is a problem. To improve it statisticians at Stanford have now developed a Bayesian approach that both improves the accuracy of the end results and significantly reduces the amount of computational time required to get there. The

 implication is that leaks could be found quicker and more precisely located. That operational teams on the ground spend have to spend less time digging and less water lost.
Primary Article Title: New Bayseian statistical techniques that could help detect water leaks faster and reduce water loss
Author: Science Daily
Keywords: Blank - DFOS

Summary Sentence: A new world record for electricity generation using quantum dots points to a future of device centric and even wearable electricity generation. That would have implications for both the energy and waste sectors.
Justification:
Researchers at the University of Queensland have set a new world record for the amount of electricity generated using quantum ‘dots’. Their achievement marks a significant step forwards in efforts to develop solar ‘skins’ that could be placed on ordinary

 surfaces, in order to turn them into sites of energy generation. Where current solar energy generation takes place in rigid cells that are cumbersome and fragile, quantum dots can simply be printed on to different types of surface, including flexible ones.

 Technology of this sort could eventually hold the potential to drive a radical shift in energy generation, away from central or even local power stations, towards a device centric arrangement. If that were to happen it could have important consequences for

 the EA in terms of the track of future energy requirements, with implications for carbon emissions and water resource use. There may also be resource and waste implications, particularly around how to dispose of these devices and how to separate out the materials

 they’re made of. At the moment the technology isn’t commercially viable, which is why the reported increases in efficiency reported by the Queensland team are so significant.
Primary Article Title: New step forward along trajectory of 'solar skin' development
Author: Science Daily
Keywords: Solar power; energy generation; wearable technology; waste; circular economy
GT: Solar power; energy generation; wearable technology; waste; circular economy

Summary Sentence: A shift in Facebook's position on international regulation points to the development of a new international regulatory regime for digital spaces that could reshape how we use the internet.
Justification:
US technology companies have been hostile to the development of regulatory frameworks designed to structure the use of online space (see %2315082). But in recent months Mark Zuckerberg has signalled a shift in Facebook’s posture towards regulators on the international

 stage. His comments point towards a stance of cooperation with European officials who have concerns around the impact of social media on the blocks democratic and market processes. Facebook’s position frames the issue in terms of competing international models

 of regulation, notably with China. Inherent in these discussions is the acceptance that an international system of online regulation is now both necessary and that different visions of what it should look like are already under construction. Such a regime

 is likely to have an important impact on the way online spaces develop, what they’re used for and by who, across the globe. It potentially opens up a new space for governance processes at the global scale, and the failure to settle on any single system might

 give rise to new forms of global division. All this is likely to have a considerable impact on the environment the EA operates within.
Primary Article Title: Mark Zuckerberg signals cooperation with development of international regulatory regime
Author: Thierry Breton
Keywords: Regulation; internet; social media; governance

Summary Sentence: Public acceptance of future technologies for food production is essential
Justification:
Some of the novel technologies that are required to ensure significantly greater food supply, food security and sustainability in the next thirty years may not be easily accepted by the consumers due to a variety of negative perceptions associated with

 them. Yet we won’t be able to increase food production by the necessary 30-70% globally unless we can introduce technologies such as artificial intelligence, robotics, genetically modified organisms (GMOs), micro-algae production, aquaponics and vertical farming

 - their use necessitates them being accepted by consumers. Other future solutions for food security include nitrogen-fixating cereals that can reduce the use of chemicals, biodegradable polymers and the breeding of insects for animal feed and foodstuffs. Due

 to public’s lack of familiarity with most of these food technologies, even if majority of them are already fully developed, people often rely on simple heuristics when evaluating them. Therefore, in order to generate public support, transparency and clear

 information with the public with a buy-in from the politicians is crucial to enable the change. The consumers’ acceptance or lack of acceptance depends on a variety of factors such as cultural values, more diversity among the consumers, their need to be able

 to stockpile for future crises etc. and these differ across food technologies. The “natural-is-better” perception can make some technologies seem unnatural or controversial to them, and the food produced through this technology seem disgusting, unsafe, unhealthy

 or unnatural to many, not just the neophobic consumers. Taking into account the factors influencing consumers’ perceptions of novel food technologies during the early stage of development and introduction, then later adapting and developing further, indicates

 that there is likely to be a need for trade-offs consideration for the authorities involved, across the entire food chain, “from farm to fork”.
Primary Article Title: The future is knocking&%2358; Global food production to be transformed using new technology
Author: University of Copenhagen
Secondary_URLs: Consumer acceptance of novel food technologies - Nature 17/06/2020
Keywords: “agricultural production” “agri-food technologies“ “agricultural economics” “climate change” food “food security” “food supply” “cultured meat” “food irradiation”
GT: “agricultural production” “agri-food technologies“ “agricultural economics” “climate change” food “food security” “food supply” “cultured meat” “food irradiation”

Summary Sentence: Several examples of how developments of materials at the microscopic and nanoscopic scale could deliver benefits in tackling pollution.
Justification:
These may be of interest to the Environment Agency from a regulatory position but also as possible tactics for dealing with the effects of pollution incidents. Previously ‘smart’ materials that target pollutants of interest (%2314283) and nano-sponges (%2314306)

 have come to light. Researchers have recently developed a new nano-sponge fabrication technique that greatly reduces costs, bringing the prospect of real world applications ever closer. Currently nano-sponges are constructed through a slow 3D printing technique

 that only produced small quantities. The new method instead blended two liquid polymers into a finely distributed emulsion, which harden before one of the two components is dissolved to leave behind a network of extremely fine labyrinthine pores. This is then

 coated in aluminium oxide before dissolving, the second polymer component, leaving behind a nano‑network of extremely thin “shells” of aluminium oxide. The method allows nano-sponges to be produced at the centimetre scale, so there this still progress to be

 made until commercial scale production. The resulting material is as strong as steel yet is extremely light and can be compressed multiple times. Another team of researchers have created a reusable ‘smart’ nano-sponge that can absorb up to 30 times its own

 weight of oil at a time. A nano-composite coating of magnetic nano-structures and a carbon-based substrate that is Oleophilic (attracts oil), Hydrophobic (resists water) and Magnetic (OHM). is applied to a regular commercially available sponge. The nano-composite's

 nano-porous three-dimensional structure selectively interacts with and binds to the oil molecules. Currently used solutions to oil spill clean up include burning, using chemical dispersants, skimming oil or absorbing it with unrecyclable sorbents, all of which

 have their disadvantages, including cost, which the new sponge addresses. Oil can even be collected and sold back to the polluter. The OHM slurry may also have a second life as an anode for lithium ion batteries, another potential source of revenue. The team

 is also developing sponges that can selectively absorb other substances such as phosphates, from fertiliser runoff and agricultural pollution. A third project sees scientists experimenting with pollen based microrobots that target mercury pollution. Some pollen

 grains are already known to have an affinity with mercury. Researchers used pollen from a plants, including dandelion, pine, lotus, sunflower, poppy, camellia, lycopodium and cattail. The pollen was cleaned before a platinum particle was attach to one side

 of each pollen grain. The pollen was added to water containing mercury. Hydrogen peroxide was also added to the water. Hydrogen peroxide reacted with the platinum to form a chemical motor for each pollen grain. Similar propulsion methods for pollution cleaning

 microbots have been tested previously ( %2313907, %2313447). After two hours in solution at 80 per cent of the mercury had been absorbed. Grains from a lotus flower had the highest velocity in the water – about 78 centimetres per hour – while cattail adsorbed

 the most mercury – around 90 per cent. The next step is to use enzymes to power the microrobots. All these developments suggest pathways for improved and more efficient water treatment, pollution clean up and pollution incident response, if further realised

 and may therefore be an area for the Environment Agency to explore. The Environment Agency may also need to consider if these exotic materials may have environmental impacts beyond their immediate use and therefore may have consequences for waste and pollution

 regulation.
Primary Article Title: Nano-sponge with extreme properties
Secondary_URLs:
Microrobots derived from variety plant pollen grains for efficient environmental clean up and as an anti-cancer drug carrier - Advanced Functional Materials 13/03/2020

OHM sponge&%2358; a versatile, efficient, and ecofriendly environmental remediation platform - Industrial Engineering and Chemistry Research 12/05/2020

Game-changing new smart sponge soaks up oil spills, saving water and wildlife - forbes 21/06/2020

Microrobots made from pollen help remove toxic mercury from wastewater - New Scientist 01/04/2020

Extreme mechanical resilience of self-assembled nanolabyrinthine materials - Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 17/03/2020
Keywords: pollution nano-sponge microrobot waste regulation manufacturing "3D printing" material "smart material" nanosponge mercury propulsion enzyme regulation waste "water quality" "water treatment" platinum "hydrogen peroxide" dandelion pine lotus sunflower poppy camellia lycopodium cattail anode lithium battery energy sorbent pollen fertiliser polymer "aluminium oxide"  Oleophilic Hydrophobic  Magnetic OHM dispersant oil spill incident

Summary Sentence: New developments in body implants and wearables could help people to better adapt to the impacts of a changing environment.
Justification:
This should be of interest to the Environment Agency in terms of innovations in health and safety for field workforce. Sony have recently revealed a personal air conditioner. Intended for launch at the now delayed Tokyo Olympics, the smartphone sized device

 fits into a pocket on the yolk of a specially designed t-shirt. It’s called Sony Reon Pocket, and uses the Peltier effect to serve as a heat pump that could cool the wearer’s body by as much as five degrees celsius and even raise temperatures during the winter

 but to a lesser extent (the Peltier effect is the presence of heating or cooling at an electrified junction of two different conductors). The device can be adjusted via Bluetooth connection to a smartphone. The US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency

 (DARPA) are developing another device, this time an implantable one, which will help soldiers adjust to disrupted sleep cycles, such as from jet lag, and limited access to safe food and water. The ingestible bioelectronic carrier could provide soldiers more

 control over their physiology. This could allow them to rapidly adapt to new time zones, or eliminate bacteria from contaminated food and water that can cause diarrhea. Both devices could have benefits for Environment Agency field staff. Climate change could

 lead to much hotter operating temperatures, therefore cooling devices may be of use. Incident management normally revolves around shift work and can be a stressful working environment. A device that could help manage sleep patterns and reduce the risk of illness

 could therefore be of benefit - the risk of some illnesses may also increase with a warmer climate. However there may need to be considerations that such devices are used to support existing health, safety and well-being policies, rather than erode them.
Primary Article Title: DARPA program to build travel adapter for human body
Secondary_URLs: Sony's wearable air conditioner is finally available to help make the summer less sweltering - Gizmodo 07/06/2020
Keywords: workforce "incident management" wearable "climate change" Bluetooth smartphone contaminated food health safety well-being wellbeing water "Tokyo Olympics" illness disease bacteria "jet lag" sleep shift diarrhea bioelectronic Sony "Reon Pocket" "Peltier effect" personal air conditioner operation field

Summary Sentence: Plants could be pollinated with soap bubbles.
Justification:
There’s a recognised global decline in natural pollinators such as bees, raising concerns for the viability of many crops that rely on pollination to flower and fruit. Previously people have experimented using drones to pollinate apple trees (%2314790) and

 developments in robotics (%2314669, %2314610) also suggest that insect-like automatons could also be used. In a new experiment researchers found that soap bubbles based on a formulation of shampoo ingredient lauramidopropyl betain were able to carry pollen. Using

 a bubble gun the researchers successfully pollinated a pear orchard. Experiments were also conducted using a drone that fired soap bubbles directly at flowers. More research is needed into finding more precise ways to aim the bubbles and how to account for

 different weather conditions. This and similar alternatives offer hope that food production may be resilient in the event of a continuing decline in natural pollinators. At the same time technological alternatives may also undermine the imperative to protect

 biodiversity for pollination purposes. There may be other secondary environmental impacts, including regulatory concerns around spraying other chemicals associated with pollination, and therefore should be of interest to the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: Scientists find way to pollinate plants with soap bubbles as bees decline
Author: Kooser, A
Secondary_URLs: Soap bubble pollination - iScience 17/06/2020
Keywords: farming agriculture pollination crop "food supply" insect bee conservation biodiversity soap bubble pear orchard fruit flower robot drone regulation shampoo "lauramidopropyl betain"

Summary Sentence: Newly discovered properties of bacteria could provide useful tools in reducing the impacts of waste and greenhouse gas emissions.
Justification:
Both waste and industrial emissions are relevant to the Environment Agency’s regulatory remit, and so should be of interest from a mitigation perspective. A bacterial strain called Pseudomonas sp. TDA1 has been found thriving in municipal waste sites,

 consuming polyurethane plastic. Polyurethane is a tough plastic with multiple uses, such as insulation, sports shoes and nappies, but it is difficult to break down or recycle. Polyurethane is also flammable, meaning it is often coat it in flame retardants,

 suspected to be carcinogenic. Bacteria have previously been identified that breakdown plastic (%2314728, %2313837, %2312311), but this is the first time one has been found feeding on polyurethane. TDA1 only breaks it down partially, suggesting that further study

 and refinement is needed before it could be used in waste management. Elsewhere a methane-oxidizing bacteria has been found in upland Arctic soils. Their discovery could mean that methane levels emitted from melting permafrost soils could be smaller than previously

 modelled, but not to the extent to change the current trajectory. Like TDA1, the discovery of this particular example of high affinity methanotrophs, or HAMs could suggest further research pathways for biological mitigation tactics of greenhouse gas emissions

 in industrial situations.
Primary Article Title: Scientists discover plastic-munching microbe in waste site
Author: Wu, K J
Secondary_URLs: Methane-eating bacteria could help decrease greenhouse gas emissions from thawing Arctic tundra - Yale Environment 360 31/03/2020
Keywords: waste plastic bacteria emission methane "greenhouse gas" "climate change" regulation "Pseudomonas sp. TDA1" polyurethane "high affinity methanotroph" "HAMs"

Summary Sentence: Cities are stepping up zero waste initiatives.
Justification:
These developments should be of interest to the Environment Agency as successful application in the Uk could help achieve strategic objectives and change regulatory activities. The Slovenian capital of Ljubljana is the first European capital to commit

 to zero waste. Since 2002 Ljubljana has introduced doorstep recycling initiatives, and reduced residual waste collections, encouraging people to recycle rather than send to landfill. Today Ljubljana’s recycling rate is 68%, putting it at the top of the recycling

 leaderboard of EU capitals. Residents now produce only 115 kg of residual waste per capita annually. While investment in collection and processing technologies have been important, equally important has been prevention, reuse and recycling. There are still

 challenges however, particularly in identifying residents in apartment blocks who aren’t following the rules. All municipal institutions now use toilet roll that is produced from recycled milk and juice packaging. Zero-waste stores are appearing. The latter

 trend is similarly seen in hospitality with a rise in ‘Zero Waste’ restaurants. These establishments aim to avoid not just food leftovers, but any waste. Initiatives include set menus to avoid portion waste, onsite composting and customer ‘take away’, reclaimed,

 recycled and biodegradable decor and providing suppliers with reusable containers. Zero waste doesn’t mean zero impact - for example it is still a challenge to find ecological cleaning products. However it is expected that growing awareness of sustainability

 could leads to greater behaviour change towards zero waste and the goods and services to support this. For example several organisations now offering certifications for businesses that reduce their waste by a dramatic amount.
Primary Article Title: The rise of `Zero-Waste' restaurants
Author: Matchar, E
Secondary_URLs: From no recycling to zero waste&%2358; how Ljubljana rethought its rubbish - The Guardian 23/05/2019
Keywords: waste food "zero-waste" restaurant Slovenia Ljubljana recycling landfill regulation EU cities urban

Summary Sentence: Artificial and biological brain cells have been successfully linked to create a functioning network across the internet
Justification:
Researchers based in three different countries were able to create a working neural network that passed information back and forth between artificial and biological brain cells. The neural network comprised two silicone based artificial brain cells that

 were able to communicate information to each other via a biological brain cell. Each of these three brain cells was located in a different country and artificial synapses were created using nanotechnology to transport information between them via the internet.

 Although only a very basic hybrid network that needs considerable development, it offers hope that this could be a way to seamlessly connect disparate technologies around the world, so that geographic location is no longer a barrier to collaboration and innovation.

 Medically it also offers the potential to develop smarter prosthetics and new ways to repair damage to the brain. Maybe one day it will even help facilitate human AI connections.
Primary Article Title: Scientists linked artificial and biological neurons in a network-and amazingly, it worked
Keywords: brain medicine network artificial intelligence innovation technology

Summary Sentence: Artificial Intelligence (AI) may be a useful tool to predict which patients will respond to medicine from data on their brainwaves.
Justification:
Finding the right medicine to treat mental health patients can be a complicated process of trial and error, using multiple drugs until you find the one best suited. A study has compared the brainwaves of patients that responded well to a drug called sertraline,

 compared to those that didn’t, and used an AI algorithm to look for patterns to help identify those that would respond well to the medicine. Typically the drug sertraline is only effective for around 33% of patients, however in this study 75% of those identified

 as having the brainwave pattern most likely to respond well found the medicine beneficial. Although only a small study, if such algorithms prove successful it could change the use of pharmaceuticals drastically. If data on other illnesses could provide intelligence

 on the best medicines to use on an individual level, we could see much more precise and targeted treatment. This could lead to a reduction and or a change in the composition of pharmaceutical residues in our water courses.
Primary Article Title: Brain activity can help predict who will benefit from an antidepressant
Keywords: pharmaceutical chemical water quality medicine drug health waste treatment machine learning data

Summary Sentence: A Dutch court has ruled that a digital system using artificial intelligence (AI) software and government data breached human rights.
Justification:
The system joined data from different government departments such as housing, employment and benefits and then used an algorithm to identify those most likely to commit benefit or tax fraud. The case was brought against the government by community organisations,

 who believed the government was illegally spying on often poor neighbourhoods based solely on a vague computer system. The court found there was a lack of transparency about how the system worked. Far from being a unique system, AI like this is becoming increasingly

 integrated in everyday life, with many unaware of the extent and influence it may have on their lives. In the UK the home office has had to suspend a machine learning visa application system and police have scrapped an expensive AI system that was supposed

 to predict violent crime, as both had bias in the coding of the systems. The Environment Agency has a rich abundance of data that could potentially be used in a positive way for the environment. However these examples highlight the reputational risk of poorly

 developed AI systems. If the Environment Agency wish to be a leader of ethical AI systems, they will need to be fully transparent about how the algorithms they use work and communicate this effectively.
Primary Article Title: Automated welfare fraud detection system contravenes international law, Dutch court rules
Secondary_URLs: Police built an AI to predict violent crime. It was seriously flawed - Wired 06/08/2020
Keywords: AI Artificial intelligence data profiling police law crime waste racism automate automation digital privacy

Summary Sentence: Fungus that absorbs radiation may be used to shield against harmful ionising gamma radiation
Justification:
A fungus called Cladosporium sphaerospermum, that appears to thrive absorbing ionising gamma radiation and taking advantage of it to grow its own biomass, could help in providing an innovative biotechnological answer to construction of protective shielding

 against radiation. According to the American scientists, who have experimented growing it at the International Space Station (ISS), consider that this fungus could be an effectively solve the problem of designing shields against harmful cosmic radiation for

 protecting astronauts. From their petri dish cultivations it was established that a mere 2mm layer of fungus can absorb almost 2% of the cosmic radiation. On the surface of Mars, approximately 21 cm thick layer of this fungus is adequate to negate a year’s

 worth of radiation. The process of growing fungus to act as self-regenerating radiation shields is cheaper and easier than using other traditional materials. Radiosynthesis describes a process where living organisms such as these fungi capture and metabolise

 energy from ionising radiation, utilising pigments to convert gamma radiation into chemical energy. Although the research focuses on space travel and reducing restrictions for up-mass for missions to Mars in future, meaning the transportation of materials

 from Earth to space that have so far limited space exploration, it could hypothetically be also used on the Earth to protect humans from radiation hazard incidents, considering it was found growing near contaminated Chernobyl nuclear reactor site.
Primary Article Title: Fungus growing at Chernobyl could protect astronauts from cosmic rays
Author: Robitzki, D.
Secondary_URLs:
Mould from Chernobyl nuclear reactor tested as radiation shield on ISS - New Scientist 24/07/2020

A Self-Replicating Radiation-Shield for Human Deep-Space Exploration&%2358; Radiotrophic Fungi can Attenuate Ionizing Radiation aboard the International Space Station - Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory 17/07/2020
Keywords: space radiation fungus fungi shield gamma ionisation

Summary Sentence: The “snot palaces” could potentially help innovation and human habitat construction
Justification:
Until now the transparent, flowing snot structures built by larvaceans out of mucus have been too delicate to study but with research, new techniques allowed scientists at Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute to discover that they provide innovative

 structures that may enable humans to explore underwater or outer space. The significant environmental benefits are that these aged snot palaces, when they are abandoned, contribute to ocean’s role as carbon sinks and furthermore take microplastics out of the

 water column, discarding them permanently on the sea floor. These skillful builders, who are humans’ closest relatives with no backbone, construct complex but fragile mucous structures ten times their height - the equivalent of a person making a five-story

 house, every day, all with snot coming out of their heads. The snot mansions both protect larvaceans from predators and provide their food by capturing the floating morsels by funnelling and filtering it straight into their mouths. When the mucus filters in

 these structures become clogged with particles, they are released to the sea floor where they become a food source to bottom dwellers such as sea cucumbers with all the dead organic matter collected as they are sinking slowly down. They also transport plastic

 pollution when entangled in the mucus structures and sequester millions of tons of carbon to the depths, in the process mitigating climate change. Researchers and NASA engineers are fascinated by the structures and want to study them to advance designing more

 effective filters, designing more innovative 3D printers, and for assembling complex inflatable structures for example for human habitation and settlements on the moon or Mars.
Primary Article Title: Scientists Learn How Tiny Critters Make Ocean `Snot Palaces'
Author: Borenstein, S.
Secondary_URLs:
Revealing enigmatic mucus structures in the deep sea using DeepPIV - Nature 03/06/2020

New laser system provides 3D reconstructions of live deep-sea creatures - Oceanography 12/06/2020
Keywords: construction structure engineering mucous microplastics larvaceans "3D printing" space "carbon sequestration" habitat innovation design
GT: larvaceans carbon sequestration plastics habitat construction innovation design

Summary Sentence: Researchers have for the first time successfully extracted chitin from insects.
Justification:
This development is significant for the Environment Agency from a waste and resources perspective as it suggests a localised and decentralised sustainable production of commercially valuable materials which otherwise come with significant environmental impacts.

 Chitin is obtained commercially as a seasonal byproduct of the fishing industry, which means its production is currently restricted to coastal areas. There are also greenhouse gas emissions associated with shipping and transportation, alongside potential questions

 over sustainability of marine extraction. Chitin has previously been cited as a potential sustainable alternative to single use plastic (%2314240). The researchers envisaged a different approach to chitin production, involving Hermetia illucens black soldier

 flies fed on urban waste. Black soldier flies are already being harvested in this manner in the UK for use as food on fish farms. But in this study the researchers successfully extracted chitin from black soldier fly shells using limited energy. Their method

 doesn’t rely specifically on black soldier flies - chitin is present in a myriad of organisms in every ecosystem on earth. This means that their process could be applied in multiple situations, leading to bio inspired manufacturing and urban waste bio conversion,

 within any regional ecosystem, significantly reducing transportation and reliance on long supply chains and stimulating sustainability.
Primary Article Title: Could the shells of insects be the missing link in the circular economy?

Circular manufacturing of chitinous bio-composites via bioconversion of urban refuse - Nature 13/03/2020

Summary Sentence: SGN to build a 100% zero-carbon hydrogen network to heat homes in Scotland
Justification:
A pioneering project using clean energy from wind and tidal sources and then stored as hydrogen would be used to heat homes built in Scotland by SGN. This proposal could provide key evidence for the UK’s long-term national policy decisions towards zero

 carbon and hydrogen’s role in this energy transition. The Aberdeen vision project and H100 Fife are part of the Gas Goes Green initiative that aims to demonstrate the viability of hydrogen for heat purposes, including this Surf 'n' Turf project on Orkney if

 the regulator Ofgem approves the plan. The planned hydrogen production and storage system with connected heating network would run alongside the existing natural gas grid network, which could enable a large scale use of hydrogen in the future, thus providing

 a safe, cost-effective and reliable (with minimal disruption for customers) zero carbon energy source. Electrolysis means a process where tidal or wind energy is used to split water and make hydrogen, and it was first used in Orkney in 2017 for hydrogen production

 by the European Marine Energy Centre (EMEC). Hydrogen provides a practical zero carbon solution as it can be stored, transferred in special containers and shipped to a facility where it is converted back to electricity. SGN (Scotia Gas Networks) proposes to

 build a 100% zero-carbon hydrogen network in where hydrogen can be generated via an electrolysis plant in Eday powered by the offshore wind turbine, then stored before transfer in specially designed hydrogen storage trailers for shipment to Kirkwall; to include

 shore power for the ferries. Sufficient safety measures and procedures must be in place to minimise any associated risks as hydrogen gas is flammable.
Primary Article Title: `World's first' green hydrogen housing project mooted for Scotland
Author: Barrett, T.

Summary Sentence: Models used to form environmental sustainability and climate change policies suggest expansion of agricultural land requiring irrigation
Justification:
New research indicates that the future impacts of agricultural irrigation on environment and other sectors have been underestimated in previous models, and the real figure for 2050 could be far higher than previously projected, leading to a massive strain

 on aquifers and ecosystems. Existing models, with estimated population growth and food security demands, are used for policy making and therefore policymakers now should reconsider their policies for water and agriculture in order to avoid underestimating

 potential environmental costs. This new study, in collaboration between Princeton University in the USA, the University of Reading in the UK, and the University of Bergen in Norway, reminds us of the large amounts of water used for irrigation globally; about

 70% of freshwater withdrawals which, unlike water for residential and industrial uses, does not eventually return to the aquifer. Evaporation, evapotranspiration from plants, and leaky pipework can remove the irrigation water from the water cycle. Hence potential

 future expansion in irrigated agricultural land, to provide food for increasing population, together with increased drought due to climate change, would have consequences for water resources and intensely impact environment, and also require the use of land

 areas that are currently not cultivated. Needing more water for irrigation clearly suggests there would be reduced water supply for other sectors and hence increased stress on water resources. Vaster irrigated areas may lead to spreading agricultural use to

 non-cultivated areas which immediately reduces biodiversity. However, in light of the rapid change towards rewilding schemes, potentially there may be a decrease in agricultural land in England in the future. Many English farmers have their own reservoirs

 but these are intended to cope with only one irrigation season, hence the lack of water resources such as falling river flows is also a threat to the irrigated agriculture and domestic vegetable and fruit production in England, especially in South East. More

 irrigated areas may result in numerous potential impacts such as releasing more greenhouse gases because of irrigation machinery production and operation; increased energy such as fossil fuel use due to this machinery; reduced agricultural gas emissions; altering

 soil surface temperatures and increasing water vapour into the atmosphere; increased nitrates leaching to groundwater and hence limiting drinking water resources. Careful management of water resources relies on collaboration between various stakeholders.
Primary Article Title: Expansion, environmental impacts of irrigation by 2050 greatly underestimated
Author: Princeton University

Summary Sentence: Dramatically underestimating the amount of coarse dust in atmosphere may have led to errors in climate change projections
Justification:
New research has increased our knowledge on the role of atmospheric dust due to its warming effect for Earth’s climatic system and climate change, and claims that the quantity of dust has been underestimated in the past. For more precise and truthful climate

 change modelling and projections, they require correction for the amount of dust in the modelling process, as UCLA scientists suggest the amount of dust is actually four times more than what is calculated in current models. Atmosphere contains two types of

 dust that are key factors in how the climate system works; fine dust that scatters easily, and coarse dust (diameter, ≥5 μm) which impacts atmosphere in a similar way as greenhouse gases, warming up it up. UCLA atmospheric and ocean scientists argue, based

 on the measurements and calculations used, that current widely used atmospheric model simulations are dramatically different from what their results indicated. When multiplying the actual amount of coarse dust in the modelling simulations four fold, to about

 17 million metric tons instead of only 4 million metric tons, it increases the probability of both types of dust warming Earth’s climate system. The researchers report that this includes everything from clouds and rainfall to weather patterns, air to oceans,

 and may affect atmospheric occurrences such as hurricanes as the dust particles impact atmospheric stability and circulation.
Primary Article Title: Climate models miss most of the coarse dust in the atmosphere
Author: Adebiyi, Adeyemi A. and Kok, Jasper F.
Secondary_URLs:
Coarse dust lingers in the atmosphere - Physics Today 27/04/2020

Earth's atmosphere far dustier than previously believed - National Science Foundation 21/04/2020

GT: Atmosphere “climate change” dust forecast prediction modeling model radiation

Summary Sentence: A proposed housing development in Swansea aims to reconnect residents to the environment through “biophilic living”.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested to see how such a scheme helps to enhance the urban environment and enhances urban agriculture and food production. Developers Hacer believe Picton Yard, which will be a mix of homes, shops and offices, is unique

 due to all of the elements included in the plans. Residents will be able to grow vegetables in vertical greenhouses, have fish tanks in the basement and potentially produce honey on the roof. The goal of the development is to change people’s perceptions of

 the possibilities to live alongside nature in an urban environment. . The concept of biophilic living is to incorporate nature into living space, based on the idea that humans are innately drawn to nature. Picton Yard will be 12 storeys high, with a rooftop

 garden, living walls and balcony planters for each apartment. Upside down umbrellas will collect rainwater for irrigation and flushing the toilets, while fish waste would be used on the allotments. Residents will receive expert help and the greenhouses would

 run as a not-for-profit community farm. The project has received Welsh Government funding and was expected to complete in 2022.
Primary Article Title: Swansea city centre residents to live on 'urban farm'
Secondary_URLs: Biophilic Living Swansea - Hacer Developments 04/06/2020

Summary Sentence: Moths as nocturnal pollinators have a vital ecological role that is not adequately understood
Justification:
critical to English countryside and crop pollination on farmlands, hence it is a necessity to consider their role in future agricultural management and conservation strategies to stem decline in moth numbers. The UCL researchers see the role of moths as

 complementary to the more selective daytime pollinators; a kind of critical back-up pollination service, to ensure semi-agricultural environments have a diverse wild plant population. Whereas bumblebees and honeybees target the most abundant sources of nectar

 and pollen, anything goes with the moths who visit any flower that they can access including brambles, legumes and clovers; all those flowers passed by other pollinating insects such as bees, butterflies and hoverflies. Supporting our widely diverse moth populations

 also helps the bats and birds that feed on them, for example cuckoos rely on moths as their critical food supply. Moths have been in decline since the 70s because of increasing intensive farming and related use of pesticides. Not only is more research required

 on the unique role of moths as pollinators and in how they support crop yields, but the public perception of moths needs to become more positive. Moth conservation is recommended to be integrated into modern agricultural management to stop the decline of moth

 populations urgently, as otherwise there are likely to be concerning consequences for our pollinator and plant interactions in agro-ecosystems which are complicated and inadequately studied.
Primary Article Title: Moths have a secret but vital role as pollinators in the night
Secondary_URLs:
Nocturnal pollinators strongly contribute to pollen transport of wild flowers in an agricultural landscape - Royal Society 13/05/2020

Nature crisis&%2358; Moths have 'secret role' as crucial pollinators - BBC 13/05/2020
Keywords: agriculture, agro-ecosystem, pollination, moths, biodiversity, “agricultural practices”, legumes, clovers, Lepidoptera, “ecosystem services”, crops, “plant-pollinator relationship”, “ecological network”

Summary Sentence: Increased temperatures due to climate change will impact the health and safety of outdoor workers
Justification:
With climate change, summers are getting hotter which means that outdoors workers such as harvest pickers and some of our staff are at exposure from excessive heat more frequently, and it is employers’ responsibility to provide workers with regular rest

 periods, shade and enough drinking water while doing outdoor work. In England at present, many seasonal agricultural workers are experienced and therefore familiar with the scope of the role, willing to start working day before dawn to avoid the midday heat;

 nevertheless, this American study encourages employers to prepare for future conditions as the outdoor working conditions will worsen. California has been the first state in the USA to introduce a heat illness and fatality prevention related Act in 2019, to

 enforce standards to protect workers from heat-related risks on the job. Currently only Washington and Minnesota, in addition to California, have heat stress workplace protection standards although high heat temperatures can and have led to workplace fatalities.

 With temperatures increase brought by the climate change, this study is concerned for the health and safety of around 2 million agricultural workers in the USA. They are likely to become increasingly vulnerable due to these working conditions and more likely

 to suffer from health risks associated with pickers such as heat stress, heat stroke and kidney problems. The study draws our attention to a projection which suggests that under 2 degree increase, heat waves will become five times more common; and the number

 of dangerous heat days, defined by heat and humidity factors and exceeding 40 degrees Centigrade, will increase from 21 days a year to 39 days by 2050, and to 62 days by 2100. Workers’ health during rising temperatures can be lessened by adaptation strategies

 such as new type of protective clothing and regular breaks in cooled shelters. There could also be experiments to replace human pickers by robots, but the driving motivation for agricultural robots is not related to health and safety issues.
Primary Article Title: Agricultural pickers in US to see unsafely hot workdays double by 2050

Summary Sentence: A multidisciplinary project in investigating how to employ synthetic biology principles to allow trees to generate electricity through their natural movement.
Justification:
This idea should be of interest to the Environment Agency as synthetic biological applications may have regulatory concerns. This project also raises questions around habitat and land use, where currently land for energy provision and biodiversity may

 be seen as in competition, rather than as complementary. Industrial designer Catalina Lotero is hopes to address the global energy crisis with a simple, off-the-grid, plant-based solution. Lotero’s system intends to capture the friction generated electricity

 made when a tree’s leaves brush against its trunk. Synthetic biology principles are being investigated to make this conversion more efficient. One tree could generate 103kH per hour, enough energy to power seven houses in decentralised off-grid situations.

 Further refinement and optimisation through further synthetic biology principles, genetic technologies and electronic engineering could see woodland become a potential source of renewable energy as well as habitat. However this would depend on the biological

 changes being compatible with supporting biodiversity.
Primary Article Title: Synthetic biology&%2358; Catalina Lotero's plan to generate electricity with trees
Keywords: energy renewable "synthetic biology" friction electricity off-grid tree woodland habitat biodiversity conservation genetic engineering landscape regulation decentralised decentralisation "Catalina Lotero"

Summary Sentence: The Royal Society has recently published a policy briefing on the potential of ammonia as a zero-carbon fertiliser, fuel and energy store.
Justification:
Transitioning to green ammonia has regulatory implications for the Environment Agency sectors including agriculture and chemical manufacturing. Having the Royal Society take interest in this issue may potentially indicate the start of a policy shift towards

 more consideration of ammonia’s potential as a fuel and energy carrier. The report acknowledges ammonia’s relatively high energy density (3 kWh/litre) and existing global infrastructure for transport and storage, which is currently employed for chemical distribution

 for fertiliser manufacturing and other uses. Much of this infrastructure is already associated with shipping routes, indicating great potential for use in marine transportation, but also by rail and road.The report also considers the wider longer lasting potential

 environmental impacts from increased nitrogen emissions if NOX emissions are not factored into the energy transition. The report highlights that the infrastructure for a shift to an ammonia economy already exists to support the agrichemical sector. It also

 highlights that the risk perception of ammonia is low - many people already live in the vicinity of existing storage facilities. The report also looks at the economics of converting and transporting hydrogen as ammonia, finding it cheaper than transporting

 hydrogen in pressurised of liquified forms via long distance pipeline. The issue of emissions from the sector should be of particular interest to the Environment Agency from a regulatory standpoint.
Primary Article Title: Royal Society publishes green ammonia policy briefing
Author: Brown, T
Secondary_URLs: Ammonia&%2358; zero-carbon fertiliser, fuel and energy store - Royal Society 19/02/2020
Keywords: energy renewable hydrogen ammonia energy storage transport infrastructure cost fossil fuel nitrogen NOX emission air pollution greenhouse gas carbon dioxide "climate change" regulation shipping road rail fertiliser chemical farming agriculture ecomic

Summary Sentence: A statistical association between flu epidemics and preceding temperature variations points to a higher risk of outbreaks in a future more variable climate
Justification:
An international consortium of scientists has indicated that greater amounts of variability in future climates that result from climate change could lead to increased morbidity and mortality from seasonal flu. The hypothesis is based in the identification

 of a statistical association between the severity of flu epidemics in northern hemisphere countries and the degree of temperature variation recorded in the preceding autumn months. They propose that sudden large changes in temperature like those observed could

 be impairing the immune system and leading to reduced immune responses, with the end result that respiratory mortality is increased. Accordingly, increases in autumn temperature variations like those pointed to by modelled climate projections could amplify

 the impact of seasonal flu. The implication for the EA is potentially one of increased sickness and absence amongst its workforce directly, as well as needing to exist in the context of any wider social and economic adjustments that need to be made.
Primary Article Title: Rapid weather swings increase flu risk
Keywords: climate change; infectious disease; influenza; epidemic; health
GT: climate change; infectious disease; influenza; epidemic; health

Summary Sentence: A review of the evidence of the impact of deep sea mining on marine microbial communities highlights their potential vulnerability
Justification:
While interest in mineral extraction from the sea floor continues to increase, an international group of scientists has highlighted the potential impacts those sorts of deep sea mining activities could have on marine microbial communities. In particular

 they draw attention to the services those communities provide to human societies and the losses that might result if they were impacted by deep sea mining activities. They find potential impacts could vary considerably between different services, from minimal

 interference in some cases to total losses in others. Focusing on the example of microbial communities that exist around deep sea thermal vents they describe the potential for major losses. They also speculate that there could be major ecosystem service degradation

 at inactive massive sulfide deposits. But they describe only minor disruption in relation to the carbon sequestration processes of manganese nodule fields. All this matters because it points to a building evidence base around the potential environmental impacts

 of deep sea mining that could inform regulatory limitations on what activities are permitted. In turn that might inform how, where and when deep sea mining takes place in the future, and how viable it might be as a sector. This is of interest to the EA as

 both a potential future regulator, and agent of healthy ocean ecosystems.
Primary Article Title: Deep-sea mining's impact on microbes
Keywords: Marine ecosystems; deep sea mining; microbial communities; ecosystem services

Summary Sentence: The European Union is being urged to adopt a red meat tax to address the impacts of farming on climate change.
Justification:
A similar scheme in the UK could change the character of agriculture and therefor the Environment Agency’s regulatory activities. A new report from research group CE Delft suggests that a ‘sustainability charge’ is needed to cover the costs of greenhouse

 gas emissions, other air and water pollution, and losses of wildlife associated with livestock production. Such a levy would increase the price of beef by the equivalent of 40p per 100g. Pork and chicken would also have a lower levy of 31 and 14p per 100g

 respectively, due to the lower environmental impact of their production. The report suggests that the sustainability charge could reduce consumption of beef in the EU by 67%, pork by 57% and chicken by 30% by 2030. A further report from the UK’s Behavioural

 Insights Team (Bit) A also backs a carbon tax on high-impact food. Implementation of such a tax could lead to the Uk beef industry shrinking, reducing environmental issues around water consumption and slurry. A move to cheaper meats such as chicken and pork

 could also lead to greater numbers of intensive farming pig and poultry installations, for which the Environment Agency also has a regulatory remit. More plant based agriculture could also change the profile of agricultural chemicals entering the environment,

 leading to changing water quality issues.
Primary Article Title: EU urged to adopt meat tax to tackle climate emergency
Author: Carrington, D
Keywords: farming agriculture food meat livestock poultry tax "climate change" regulation pollution water resources slurry beef chicken pork installation intensive farming Uk Eu "European Union" Bit "Behavioural Insights Team"

Summary Sentence: A German steel manufacturer has taken a big step towards carbon neutral production through powering a blast furnace with renewable hydrogen.
Justification:
The Environment Agency regulates heavy industries including steel manufacturing, making this development significant for regulatory work and overall UK Government ambitions for Net Zero. Manufacturing giant Thyssenkrupp recently demonstrated using renewable

 hydrogen to power one of the 28 tuyeres, or nozzles that normally supply coal to the blast furnace. They plan to gradually increase the number of hydrogen powered nozzles until the entire furnace runs on hydrogen by 2023. This marks a significant move towards

 carbon neutral steel production, a notably carbon heavy industry. Thyssenkrupp is one of the world’s largest steel producers and produces around 12 million tonnes of crude steel annually. The company has committed to achieving a 30 per cent reduction in the

 company’s greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 to help address climate change. The company is also aiming to become carbon neutral by 2050.
Primary Article Title: How to power a steel blast furnace using only hydrogen
Author: Delbert, C
Secondary_URLs: Another nail in coal's coffin? German steel furnace runs on renewable hydrogen in world first - RenewEconomy 19/11/2019
Keywords: energy renewable hydrogen steel regulation emission "climate change" "greenhouse gas" pollution Germany Thyssenkrupp manufacturing "carbon neutral" nozzle tuyere "blast furnace" coal "pig iron" "fossil fuel" 2030 2050

Summary Sentence: Recent research reveals some of the expectations and concerns of young people entering the workforce.
Justification:
Consideration of the conclusions of this study from the Health and Safety Executive’s (HSE) Foresight Centre could help the Environment Agency ensure that it remains an attractive employer for the next generational cohort of workforce. A group of students

 born 2000-2001 (corresponding to ‘Generation Z’ %2313473) participated in a workshop to discuss their perceptions of their future working environment and associated health safety & wellbeing (HSW) concerns. ‘Good’ work would be characterised by reliability in

 terms of knowing what work they will get, flexibility and freedom in how they work, and social interaction with ‘easy to get along with’ colleagues. Sufficient salary would still be important, but other aspects would be equally or more important, including&%2358;

 enjoyable work; work/life balance; job security with an employer (or employers) who will enable them to gain experience; minimising travelling to permit time with family; and options to work from home. Essential future skills would include communication and

 friendliness, and IT skills including programming skills, as a lot of science involves modelling. Team working would also be important to increase productivity, relieve pressure and remove boredom and isolation. Not all tasks would be suited to home working.

 Views on team structures varied. Flat structures were preferred but thought to inhibit promotion prospects. Managers would preferably be interesting and approachable, involved and with a good sense of humour, who value their ideas and be knowledgeable. Occupational

 health risks of concern included slips, harm from other people, repetitive strain from inappropriate IT and air pollution. Overall many of the insights gleaned indicate that young workers concerns may not be that different to the concerns of current workers.

 However of particular note are uncertainties around pensions and not set end point to work, indicating that expectations and choice about retirement are changing. Continuing to ensure that these concerns are properly address could help the Environment Agency

 to attract talent in the future, particularly in the face of a future of fewer young people entering the workplace.
Primary Article Title: Understanding the next generation of workers&%2358; insights on expectations of work and perceptions about health and safety
Author: Beers, H
Keywords: workforce generation demographic young people employee employer health safety wellbeing career salary management leadership

Summary Sentence: Vaccination programmes globally can be a tool towards microbial resistance.
Justification:
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) could be decreased with effective vaccination programmes that prevent children getting ill with childhood illnesses, leading to a reduced need for antibiotic treatments, according to a study from University of California,

 Berkeley. The overuse of antibiotics has led to an increasing AMR threat with human health and economic consequences, as it can make humanity more vulnerable in the future since we do not have an effective cure or treatment when “superbugs” appear. Correct

 antibiotic use can also reduce the quantity of pharmaceuticals in our water supply and hence alleviate concerns over water quality issues. The focus of this study was on children under the age of five. The researchers at the University of California, Berkeley,

 found out that two common vaccines - the pneumococcal conjugate and rotavirus vaccines - have a considerable impact on how many antibiotic treatments are required in childhood. Therefore these two vaccines can form a key global strategy in controlling resistance

 by protecting people from diseases such as meningitis, sepsis, tuberculosis (London) and pneumonia. Antibiotic resistance is a significant threat to health care systems with inappropriate use leading to the loss of drug-effectiveness, and in countries such

 as the UK it is common for children to be prescribed antibiotic treatment, even when it is clearly not needed, for example for ear infections and similarly for adults, for example for sinusitis. As combatting antimicrobial resistance is a priority for WHO,

 they created a global action plan on antimicrobial resistance, including antibiotic resistance, in 2015. With vaccination programmes globally, even without including effects from improving hygiene and sanitation, Berkeley researchers suggest that even with

 a careful estimate, approximately 40 million cases of antibiotic-treated illness could be prevented annually.
Primary Article Title: To prevent antimicrobial resistance, vaccinate the world's kids
Author: Manke, Kara.

Summary Sentence: A food production company with a water company supporting low carbon and renewable heat initiatives by building gigantic greenhouses
Justification:
A company called Low Carbon Farming has a high-tech innovative farming project for sustainable food security in the UK, to build new types of large greenhouses that utilise waste heat from water treatment facilities for vegetable and flower production.

 Over 40 gigantic green houses in East Anglia are likely to require a large quantity of water which may have water quality and water resources implications in East Anglia, an Environment Agency Area familiar with low rainfall and prolonged dry weather. Each

 greenhouse is planned to be one-and-a-half times the size of the O2, or the size of 26 football pitches, for growing vegetables such as tomatoes, cucumbers and peppers. This is a “world-first” industry response to more people moving towards plant based diets

 and sustainable use utilising the land areas close to water recycling centres. The waste heat would be harvested from local water company Anglian Water owned recycling centres, using the largest heat pumps ever deployed in the UK; hence this renewable heat

 method is supported by the Government’s Renewable Heat Incentive. This project is at the forefront of contributing to the UK’s objectives of becoming carbon neutral, increasing the “clean heat” output and improving food security in a sustainable manner. The

 food miles associated with vegetables production could be reduced if the UK became more self-sufficient than previously, as Low Carbon Farming suggests that this template could be used nationwide. The first two of the UK’s largest greenhouses have already

 been built and they cover 70 acres; with potential to increase British tomato production by 12 percent. Anglian Water has indicated that they are working towards finding innovative solutions to the environmental challenges linked with heating local water courses.

 This project is presented as a neat co-operation opportunity for a food production company with a water company, supporting the low carbon and renewable heat initiatives. Nevertheless, in addition to potential problems with sufficient cooling to avoid heating

 the local water courses and an adverse impact on delicate ecosystems, consideration must be given to water abstraction issues. Low Carbon Cooling suggests that the greenhouses use ten times less water than field farming practices.
Primary Article Title: Wastewater-heated greenhouses could `change the face' of UK sustainable food production
Author: Barrett, Thomas

Low-carbon structures fed by water treatment plants can grow 10% of homegrown crop - The Guardian 03/10/2019

Summary Sentence: A hybrid water supply system with potable reuse of municipal wastewater can efficiently ease pressure on water resources.
Justification:
A new type of modelling framework to assess the environmental and economic impacts of using a hybrid water supply system, with clean water and treated wastewater, has been developed by the researchers at Rice University in Houston, Texas. The hybrid model

 tested with real water and wastewater systems is critical for the UK due to our water resources shortage, as it could significantly improve water quality and water distribution within our limited water supply. This solution could reduce the pressure on demand

 from surface water sources such as reservoirs and rivers by 28%. The researchers at Brown School of Engineering, Rice University in Houston, Texas, compared the costs between bringing fresh surface water from a distance to urban centres and the cost of energy

 that is required to run innovative water treatment systems. The system, using City of Houston as a case study for data, indicates that fusing a central surface water resource with a supplementary recycled municipal wastewater can provide a solution to make

 water supply more resistant for future needs. The problem is that the technology required to achieve drinking water quality is currently expensive, hence the Rice University researchers have studied advanced water treatment and related technologies to find

 more cost-effective solutions at their Nanosystems Engineering Research Center for Nanotechnology-Enabled Water Treatment (NEWT). The research focussed on environmental and economic effects, using a cost-benefit analysis and considering trade-offs. The key

 factors in the model were the acquisition of potable water, energy required for treatment, transport costs, and in particular, how to transport without lowering the water quality. This study evaluated conflicting objectives to establish a balance between these

 factors. Naturally, the water quality is also easier to maintain the shorter the distance it needs to be moved is, minimising the risks of chemical, biological and pharmaceutical contaminants which is an essential feature in our historical pipe network. The

 researchers observed that as Houston has already got an existing dispersed wastewater treatment system and existing detention ponds throughout the city, they can store storm water to treat it for a non-potable use. It seems that the direct potable reuse of

 municipal wastewater could make it a worthwhile change towards advanced treatment technology systems. Treatment would be even cheaper for a newly established community, where the wastewater effluent could be minimally treated to make it suited for similar

 purposes as grey water, such as flushing toilets.
Primary Article Title: Model shows recycling could dramatically slash cities' need for fresh water resources
Author: Willliams, Mike

Rice engineers&%2358; Make wastewater drinkable again - Rice University 27/04/2020

Make wastewater drinkable again - Science Daily 27/04/2020

The importance of system configuration for distributed direct potable water reuse - Nature 27/04/2020

Distributed Mixed Wastewater and Graywater Treatment for Urban Water Reuse - New source 16/06/2020
Keywords: wastewater, "water resources", "drinking water", treatment, engineering

Summary Sentence: The World Economic Forum (WEF) have laid their views for the purpose of a company in the context of the Fourth Industrial Revolution.
Justification:
The implications are of interest to the Environment Agency as it interacts with sector organisations and operators to achieve sustainability goals. The Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) was first outlined in 2015. It is characterised by technologies that
