 combine hardware, software, and biology, with an emphasis on communication and connectivity. Technologies such as robotics, artificial intelligence, nanotechnology, quantum computing, biotechnology, the internet of things (IOT), decentralisation and 3D printing

 exemplify these developments (%2315208). It also links into the UK Government’s Industrial Strategy. The recently devised Davos Manifesto sets out the role of company within this context. There are three main parts to the Manifesto, summarised below. A - a company’s

 purpose is to engage all its stakeholders in shared and sustained value creation, serving not only its shareholders, but all its stakeholders – employees, customers, suppliers, local communities and society at large. The best way to achieve this is through

 a shared commitment to policies and decisions that strengthen the long-term prosperity of a company. B - a company is more than an economic unit generating wealth. It fulfils human and societal aspirations as part of the broader social system. Performance

 must be measured not only on the return to shareholders, but also on how it achieves its environmental, social and good governance objectives. Executive remuneration should reflect stakeholder responsibility. C - a company that has a multinational scope of

 activities not only serves all those stakeholders who are directly engaged, but acts itself as a stakeholder – together with governments and civil society – of our global future. Corporate global citizenship requires a company to harness its core competencies,

 its entrepreneurship, skills and relevant resources in collaborative efforts with other companies and stakeholders to improve the state of the world. The Manifesto steers companies away from profit is the sole motivator and links longer term growth and prosperity

 to serving societal and environmental good as well we shareholder responsibility. The Environment Agency is potentially well placed to echo these messages when engaging with industry to achieve its regulatory objectives, demonstrating the bigger picture of

 localised company activities.
Primary Article Title: Davos Manifesto 2020&%2358; the universal purpose of a company in the Fourth Industrial Revolution
Author: Schwab, K
Keywords: "World Economic Forum" WEF sustainability sustainable "Fourth Industrial Revolution" 4IR company shareholder stakeholder society government environment regulation Davos

Summary Sentence: A new operation in Canada is seeking to extract ‘green hydrogen’ from Canadian oil sands.
Justification:
This process has several parallels with unconventional gas and oil extraction, aka fracking (hydraulic fracturing), and therefore may have regulatory implications for the Environment Agency if a similar process occurs on UK soil. The operation in question

 is located in Saskatchewan, on the Superb oil field, a layer of oil bearing sand 700 metres below the Earth’s surface. Underground burning, also known as fire flooding has been used previously to extract oil, with previously little interest in the hydrogen

 by product. This is changing as hydrogen becomes more significant as an alternative fuel. Instead of extraction, the oil is set on fire, creating a chemical reaction that produces carbon dioxide (CO2) and hydrogen. Compared to current hydrogen production methods

 it is both cleaner and more economical. Hydrogen from methane gas produces GHGs and electrolysis of water is currently expensive. There are still some technical challenges to overcome on the road to achieving zero carbon emissions in this manner. The long

 term plan is to introduce a membrane to the well which allows hydrogen gas to pass through and reach the surface, leaving CO2 trapped underground, effectively producing greenhouse gas free energy from fossil fuel. The membrane that will be used on the well

 is made of palladium alloys, but this has fragility and technical issues that need to be overcome. The market for hydrogen is growing, both as an energy storage medium and as an addition to conventional gas. A UK trial of grid injected hydrogen into Keele

 University’s gas grid is underway to assess the cost and practicalities of using hydrogen in this manner to reduce fossil fuel dependency. A successful roll out could pave the way for increasing demand for hydrogen blending, which in turn may stimulate demand

 for home produced hydrogen. This in turn may create interest in using existing onshore oil and gas reserves to produce hydrogen in this way to contribute to climate change mitigation, which could require a regulatory response from the Environment Agency, amongst

 others.
Primary Article Title: Company to harvest green hydrogen by igniting oil fires underground
Author: Hand, E
Secondary_URLs: UK's first grid-injected hydrogen trials begin in Staffordshire - edie - Environmental Data Interactive Exchange 02/01/2020
Keywords: energy hydrogen "climate change" regulation "fossil fuel" oil gas Canada "fire flooding" underground combustion "carbon dioxide" syn gas membrane palladium Keele Staffordshire gas mix pipeline unconventional oils fracking "hydraulic fracturing"

Summary Sentence: Pesticides and flame retardants have now overtaken heavy metals as the pollutants with the biggest impacts on childhood intelligence.
Justification:
The Environment Agency regulates the sources, use and disposal of both sets of chemicals and therefore may need to consider the impacts of this role on human health. Research in the United States looked at four substances known to impact child brain development&%2358;

 lead, mercury, pesticides, and flame retardants polybrominated diphenyl ethers. The study showed that between 2001 and 2016 lead cost US children 78 million IQ points, and mercury caused a loss of 2.5 million IQ points. Pesticides however caused a loss of

 nearly 27 million IQ points during those years, and flame retardants resulted in a loss of 162 million IQ points over the same period. The researchers conclude that just like lead and mercury that there is no ‘safe’ exposure level for pesticides and flame

 retardants. They have calculated that an individual IQ point is worth roughly 2 percent of a child's lifetime economic productivity. Based on this IQ loss due to lead, mercury, flame retardants, and pesticide exposure combined cost the US around US$6 trillion

 from 2001 to 2016. The research is US based, and may not directly translate to chemical use in the UK. However, further recognition of the connection between these chemicals and brain development could lead to the Environment Agency enforcing stricter regulations.

 There is also the opportunity to consider how advisory and influencing roles may deliver better health outcomes in relation to these substances, framed in the context of economic productivity.
Primary Article Title: Toxic chemicals robbed US children of over 160 million IQ points, scientists warn
Author: Bendix, A
Secondary_URLs: Trends in neurodevelopmental disability burden due to early life chemical exposure in the USA from 2001 to 2016&%2358; A population-based disease burden and cost analysis - Molecular and Cellular Endocrinology 15/02/2020
Keywords: health chemical pollution "flame retardant" waste pesticide farming agriculture regulation brain children IQ "heavy metal" lead mercury economy toxic "polybrominated diphenyl ether"

Summary Sentence: Researchers have discovered a possible link between a gene present in blue green algae and Parkinson’s disease.
Justification:
Algal blooms caused by eutrophication are a consequence of excessive nutrients from field runoff that cause water pollution. They are a health risk for humans and animals that come into contact with them, and as such are of interest to the Environment

 Agency. Exposure to high levels of blue-green algae and their toxins can cause diarrhea, nausea or vomiting; skin, eye or throat irritation; and allergic reactions or breathing difficulties. This latest research adds a new dimension to the potential long term

 health impacts of poor water quality. The researchers found that the neurotoxins in blue-green algae reduce cellular activity in a gene associated with Parkinson’s disease, which could cause higher oxidative stress levels in nerve cells associated with Parkinson’s

 disease. Further research will also consider the link between this gene and pesticides, another area of interest for the Environment Agency’s regulatory activity.
Primary Article Title: Algae toxin linked with Parkinson's
Secondary_URLs: Analysis of DNA methylation associates the cystine-glutamate antiporter SLC7A11 with risk of Parkinson's disease - Nature 06/03/2020
Keywords: "water quality" "water pollution" pollution farming agriculture nutrients fertiliser eutrophication health illness neurotoxin "blue green algae" "algal bloom" incident management Parkinson's gene cellular disease regulation

Summary Sentence: Recent innovations in 3D printing demonstrate the ability to produce materials with unique properties and to deliver objects at scale.
Justification:
Both developments could be of interest to the Environment Agency, in considering novel materials being produced outside of regulated environments along decentralisation models, and entering the waste stream, alongside the potential for additive manufacturing

 in construction and asset management. In Mexico a giant 3D printer is on the way to creating a 3D printed village. A housing charity has partnered with a commercial company to provide a neighbourhood of affordable housing over a short timescale. Two houses

 can be printed in less than 24 hours, but human workers are still needed to provide roofs, fixtures and fittings. As this technology becomes more mainstream it could well find applications in flood defence construction, bringing with it cost savings. Elsewhere

 researchers have used a standard 3D printer to create a bullet-proof material. The polymer structure is based on a scaled up structure of tubulanes, theoretical structures of crosslinked carbon nanotubes predicted to have extraordinary strength. The macroscale

 blocks are full of holes, are highly compressible, yet can stop a bullet without sustaining much damage. Tubulane-like structures of metal, ceramic and polymer could lead to better materials for civil, aerospace, automotive, sports, packaging and biomedical

 applications. They could also find a use in oil and gas extraction due to their ability to stand impact, where standard materials become rubblised during hydraulic fracking. This durability could make the materials particularly problematic during waste recovery

 and recycling if they are used at scale and in a decentralised production environment.
Primary Article Title: Theoretical tubulanes inspire ultrahard polymers
Author: Williams, M
Secondary_URLs:
3D Printed tubulanes as lightweight hypervelocity impact resistant structures - Small 11/11/2019

The world's first 3D-printed neighborhood now has its first houses - Fast Company 12/11/2019
Keywords: "3D printing" "additive manufacturing" waste regulation concrete cement plastic polymer metal construction Mexico housing building tubulane "carbon nanotube" ceramic "civil engineering" recycling decentralisation fracking "hydraulic fracturing" fossil fuel oil gas

Summary Sentence: New modelling data highlights the correlation between climate and violence and points to a potential rise under climate change scenarios.
Justification:
The link between warmer weather and rises in violent crime is increasingly well established, but now new modelling research has attempted to illuminate how crime rates might change under climate change scenarios. The data suggest that as climatic temperatures

 rise there could be a corresponding increase in violent crime. Indeed the data point to a potential near doubling of annual counts of violent crime under a 3 degree scenario and a rise of around 150% under a 4 degree scenario. Although the research took place

 in the United States and is to some extent place specific, many of its assumptions could translate into other social and cultural contexts like the UK, although there may be differences. Ultimately though the research highlights the pressures a changing climate

 may put on everyday social and cultural arrangements, as well as questions of larger scale spatial and political arrangements, and points to the minutiae of life that may need to adapt. At a more direct level it could also be of concern to the Environment

 Agency's frontline staff tasked with interacting with the public in potentially confrontational situations. Indirectly it also asks the more strategic question of how the Environment Agency would adapt itself to a more violent society.
Primary Article Title: Global warming to increase violent crime in the United States
Author: Science Daily
Keywords: Climate Change impacts, crime, temperature

Summary Sentence: A new technological innovation in technologies to separate oil and water could make dealing with oil pollution incidents simpler and more effective
Justification:
Researchers in Germany have developed a new technique for separating oil from water that could make the process of cleaning up oil spills more efficient, effective, and reduce the associated environmental impacts. At the moment practitioners use a combination

 of barriers to contain the slick, surface skimming to remove it, chemical dispersal agents and burning. All of these are potentially problematic in some way. The new method uses biologically inspired superhydrophobic surfaces to adsorb the oil, transport it

 from the surface and deposit it in a safe container. It’s simpler, more efficient and doesn’t require any energy or chemical inputs to the environment. It also works across scales and could be used equally to deal with major oil spills in ocean environments,

 or for smaller scale incidents on rivers, canals, lakes, or other freshwater bodies. The EA might conceivably use it as part of its incident response, potentially improving our ability to deal with these sorts of events.
Primary Article Title: Oil spill clean-up&%2358; Better method
Author: Science Daily
Secondary_URLs: New materials for removing oil from the acquatic environment - Philosphical Transactions of The Royal Society B 16/03/2020
Keywords: Water pollution; oil removal

Summary Sentence: The internet in its current form is unsustainable and could change dramatically as the World feels the effects of climate change and growing inequality.
Justification:
The Environment Agency like many organisations relies on the internet and other information technology to deliver its outcomes. Current arrangements may not be compatible with future resilience or aspirations for Net Zero. Writer Kevin Lozano describes

 the internet as “the biggest coal-fired machine on the planet”. Currently the internet consumes 10 per cent of global energy, which is still provided overwhelmingly from fossil fuels. As more people come online and more people utilise higher internet speeds

 (including 5G), stream more content, this is likely to grow. It is predicted that by 2030 the internet will account for between 20 and 50 per cent of global energy use, producing more carbon than any country other except China, USA and India. This figure will

 likely rise as more of the half of the global population still without internet access come online. Downloading a single web page can generate a significant quantity of carbon, particularly as websites become more dynamic and content rich compared to static,

 text based sites. Developments such as high definition video and 5G, cloud services, live streaming and virtual reality will all contribute to this. Aside from the energy demand impacts on climate change, much of the internet’s infrastructure is located in

 coastal areas potentially at risk from sea level rise. Climate change may also mean increased cooling costs for internet servers. More sunlight could mean more ultraviolet light which interferes with the electromagnetic frequency of Wifi. This could all contribute

 to more unreliable internet access. One of the challenges in reducing the internet’s footprint comes from its current business model. Advertising keeps a lot of internet access free, but adverts also account for a significant amount of energy. Streamlining

 websites would mean that the business model of the internet would have to change. This could mean access for only those who could afford it, driving inequalities in the digital world that climate change is also bringing to the physical world. This is already

 playing out in the difference of internet service between urban and rural areas. Individual behaviour could also go some way to reducing the internet’s impact. We have grown accustomed to posting and reposting content without considering the impact of web

 communication; this may have to change. The wealthier technology companies and their customers could conceivably isolate themselves for the impacts, less so smaller players and the less well off. It’s suggested that breaking Silicon Valley’s hold on the internet

 make it easier to impose environmental regulations on technology companies. Inequality can also be a catalyst for innovation.Moving to a more localised, decentralised internet could also be one solution towards sustainability. Communities may need to become

 more internet resilient in support of this, through building on small scale MESH networks (%2314052) for example. The Environment Agency and partners may need to consider firstly how to limit the impacts of its online activities, including the infrastructure

 and supply chain supporting it. Secondly it may be prudent how reliance on third party internet content and infrastructure may be impacted in the future, and what steps may need to be taken to offer contingencies, both in the short term to have resilience

 during incidents and in the longer term to ensure strategic resilience alongside Net Zero ambitions. Thirdly it may wish to consider how evolving developments in data storage such as DNA (%2314730, %2313922) and others may be adopted into business practices as

 commercial applications come online.
Primary Article Title: Can the internet survive climate change?
Author: Lozano, K
Keywords: "climate change" internet energy infrastructure emission GHG pollution air  "greenhouse gas" "carbon dioxide" CO2 2030 wifi "Net Zero" server IT cooling China USA India 5G streaming data "Silicon Valley"  inequality innovation MESH network sustainability regulation website advertising

Summary Sentence: Milk and cheese are getting the ‘lab grown’ treatment, signalling the possibility of vegan cheese that is molecularly identical to conventional cheese derived from cows milk.
Justification:
This example of innovation in food production could become a significant disruption to the current livestock industry. Current vegan cheese is produced using plant based substitutes to simulate the tastes, textures and properties of cheese. Start ups such

 as Noquo Foods, Legendairy, New Culture, Perfect Day and Real Vegan Cheese are riding a wave of investment in the ‘protein shift’ away from animal based proteins. Noquo is focussing on identifying plant based proteins that mimic the elusive ‘cheese protein’

 casein which so far has not been found to occur in plants. Europe based Legendairy is focussing on microbial fermentation - using yeast to produce dairy protein. Microbial fermentation could also eventually replace meat (%2315240). New Culture, and Real Vegan

 Cheese are taking a similar approach. Producing milk and cheese in this way could drive resource efficiencies and reduce the carbon footprint of farming significantly. The start ups in question face challenges around public acceptance, economic viability and

 regulation - the latter is significant in Europe where current legislation means that the protein made using their particular form of fermentation cannot be legally sold as food. As a regulator of the dairy industry the Environment Agency may need to consider

 what opportunities for environmental improvement could come from a change to protein production and what impacts new food production processes could bring.
Primary Article Title: Dairy-identical vegan cheese is coming to save the cows
Author: Smith, Kat
Secondary_URLs:
New culture is developing creamy mozzarella cheese without the cow - The Spoon 24/04/2019

The startups making vegan cheese taste like the real thing - Sifted 31/01/2020
Keywords: food farming livestock protein milk cheese vegan bacteria microbial fermentation yeast dairy plant crop regulation land use "New Culture" "Noquo Foods" "Legendairy" "Perfect Day" "Real Vegan Cheese" casein

Summary Sentence: More young people are leaning into the rental and sharing economy model, including where and how they live, rejecting private homes for communal living arrangements.
Justification:
Should this trend increase and establish in the UK then it could suggest different models around urban planning and housing, which could impact regulatory and flood management assumptions. Young people in the USA are increasingly adopting a communal urban

 lifestyle, living in close proximity in shared living spaces with very few possessions. The proliferation of ride sharing services such as Uber and Lyft means that car ownership is falling. Companies such as PodShare rent out beds in large collective living

 spaces&%2358; this is also proving increasingly popular. The young residents tend to be young, educated, and relatively affluent, but they are choosing to reject an accepted notion of living. High property prices facing both the buyers and renters of the Millennial

 generation are cited as one factor, but it may also suggest that the younger generations are rejecting the conventional economic model for a life less encumbered by possessions and more about experiences and connections. These ‘affluent homeless’ still accrue

 lots of stuff, however these are digital rather than physical, embodying the notion of data citizens (%2315231). Some people are enjoying pod living so much that they are getting ‘Podestrian’ tattoos. In Japan the societal impacts of the urban sharing economy

 are manifesting in a different way - a car rental firm found that for many of its bookings the car didn’t move, implying customers just wanted temporary access to private urban space. It would seem that a sharing economy lifestyle isn’t a sustainable long

 term solution, particularly as people age and think about starting families. However considering the current demographic contrasts between urban and rural populations (%2314833) it may be that pod living becomes a more commonplace urban phenomena, challenging

 current assumptions on land use, construction and planning.
Primary Article Title: The affluent homeless&%2358; a sleeping pod, a hired desk and a handful of clothes
Author: Sanders, S
Secondary_URLs:
People in Japan are renting cars but not driving them - The Verge 05/07/2019

People love living in pods so much they're getting neck tattoos about it - Futurism 25/04/2019
Keywords: demographics urbanisation population lifestyle urban city housing young people Podshare "sharing economy" "access economy" experience Japan USA car hire "ride sharing" Uber Lyft values economic possessions digital data "data citizen"

Summary Sentence: New modelling evidence indicates that in the case of AMOC collapse agricultural production in the UK would be profoundly affected
Justification:
Climate scientists have now modelled the potential impacts of a collapse in the process of Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) on agricultural production in the UK. It’s one of several systems in the earth’s climate thought to be vulnerable

 to climatic forcing, and that could represent a ‘tipping point’ in climate change. It involves the slowing or stopping of warm water currents that draw up energy from the equator. As freshwater is introduced into the North Atlantic from melting Arctic ice

 sheets it prevents the formation of denser saline waters that would normally sink, drawing warmer waters up and over them. The result for countries like the UK would be a significant reduction in climatic temperatures and amounts of rainfall. The authors suggests

 that this would also lead to widespread impacts on agricultural production, including an effective cessation of arable farming and a reduction in productivity an order of magnitude higher than those already anticipated under climate change scenarios. The implications

 are clearly severe for the EA and wider UK society as a whole. A key driver of the declines are likely to be reductions in precipitation and water availability, implying increased levels of demand for dwindling freshwater resources. Food prices may also rise

 considerably as supply is constricted.
Primary Article Title: New modelling techniques demonstrate potential impact of AMOC cessation on agriculture
Author: Science Daily
Keywords: Climate Change; AMOC; agriculture; tipping points
GT: Climate Change; AMOC; agriculture; tipping points

Summary Sentence: A new innovation in bio-waste management could allow greater levels of energy recovery from plant waste
Justification:
Researchers in China have developed a way of turning bio-wastes into a reliable and uniform biofuel for use in renewable energy production – bio-coal. The production technique involves modifying the process of pyrolosis by speeding it up so that the water

 fraction is removed from the resulting product. Under normal conditions the pyrolosis of biowaste would result in a bio-oil comprising 30% water, which isn’t useful as a fuel because the water significantly reduces the high heating value (HHV). Bio-coal has

 a much higher HHV, comparable to that of commercial coals, and can be burned in their place. If the development was to become more widely adopted in the UK it could offer an alternative pathway for disposing of bio-wastes and a new sustainable fuel for power

 generation. There might be implications for the EA in respect of its role as a waste and energy regulator, and in terms of our ability to meet the government’s goal of achieving net zero by 2050.
Primary Article Title: Bio-coal&%2358; A novel way of extracting energy from plant waste
Author: Bob Yirka
Keywords: Bio-waste; renewable energy; electricity production

Summary Sentence: New theoretical insights in the field of Ecological Economics could help to shed light on why environmental governance regimes like that of the Environment Agency might ultimately fail.
Justification:
The investigation tracked water resource policies in 6 European countries over a period of 254 years, mapping out their developing integration and extent. It identified a tendency for contradictions in institutional policies, particularly at the interface

 of public policy and property rights, to develop as the regimes evolved over time. Those ‘mis-complementarities’ occurred both within institutions and between them, and eventually resulted in a lack of coherence at the policy regime level. This effect was

 captured in a new economic concept – Transversal Transaction Costs (TTCs). As TTCs evolve and increase they eventually act to cancel out the beneficial effects of further policy integration, a situation termed the institutional complexity trap (ICT). Avoiding

 the ICT involves ensuring that the coherence of a policy regimes is maintained. That insight might be particularly useful to the EA, especially given the unavoidable interface between much of our policy work and public rights.
Primary Article Title: Water governance&%2358; Could less sometimes be more?
Keywords: Transaction costs; Economics; regulation, governance

Summary Sentence: The discovery of a protein that mimmicks the benefits of exercise could have widespread implications for health and, potentially, some impacts on water pollution
Justification:
Researchers at the University of Michigan have demonstrated that a naturally occurring protein in the body called Sestrin plays a key role in mediating the benefits of exercise in flies. The findings indicate that artificially enhancing the levels of Sestrin

 in a subset of the population mimicked the benefits of exercise – i.e. their physical performance was improved without any induced activity. The results imply that controlling levels of Sestrin in humans might result in health improvements. The logical next

 step therefore is to see if these effects are replicable in a human population. If they are then groups currently unable to exercise, such as older people, those with physical injuries and those with limiting social commitments, could gain access to its benefits.

 While these lines of enquiry are at an early stage and modes of delivery for any supplement are still unclear, a plausible direct implication for the environment agency of an oral pathway might be an increased level of Sestrin in waste water. There are also

 potentially implications connected to improvements in the general health of the working population.
Primary Article Title: Sestrin - A treatment for people who can't exercise
Author: Science Daily
Keywords: Health; Water pollution; exercise;

Summary Sentence: Discovery of a new mechanism for controlling plant growth could lead to interventions that allow plants to better adapt to changing environmental conditions.
Justification:
Research into the process of cell division has identified a new protein in the cells of plant roots that could be used to control plant growth. Inflorescence and root apices receptor kinase (IRK) has been located in the outer plasma membrane of endodermal

 cells in the root structure, where it appears to inhibit the process of cell division. If that is the case then the discovery opens up the possibility of being able to manipulate the amounts of the protein available to cells so that plants can either be encouraged

 to grow or prevented from growing. That might have implications for future methods of weed control and crop fertilisation, potentially changing the substances involved and the environmental impacts that result. It’s also of significance in the context of a

 changing climate with changing growing conditions for crop plants. As far as the Environment Agency is concerned this could point to changes in future levels of water pollution and may have significant implications for maintaining biodiversity.
Primary Article Title: Research identifies possible on/off switch for plant growth
Author: Science Daily
Keywords: Blank - DFOS

Summary Sentence: A new more energy efficient method of chemically recycling tyres could lead to more effective end of life options
Justification:
Researchers in the U.S have developed an innovative new way of breaking down the rubber compounds used in car tyres, potentially opening up new methods for recycling. At the moment used car tyres are either simply burnt as a fuel, repurposed in their current

 form, or subject to the energy intensive process of pyrolysis. But researchers have now discovered a method of using hydrosalines to break down the rubber of the tyre into polymeric, silyl-protected thiolated organic oils. Once that’s happened they can be

 separated out from the other unreactive solids left over and converted back into different more useful forms of rubber using simple oxidative processes. As a waste regulator the potential implications for the EA are clear&%2358; If the innovation becomes widely

 deployed in the market place it would be a new processes that required regulation. It would also provide a step towards a more sustainable and material efficient economy.
Primary Article Title: Chemists find new way to break down old tires into material for new ones
Keywords: recycling; circular economy; car tyres

Summary Sentence: Advances in material science could make vacuum travel realistically feasible. A proof of concept has yet to be produced, so it's still at a very early stage, but potential consequences for forms of air and space travel.
Justification:
The concept of an airship that uses vacuum technology to generate lift has existed in science fiction for a considerable amount of time. But now researchers based at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and NASA have assessed the theoretical feasibility

 of such a craft and shown that it might be possible to build one. In a paper, as yet unpublished but available on the NASA website, a design using cuboctahedral discrete lattice materials is shown to provide a shell with both the strength and stiffness required

 to meet safety standards. This isn’t the first time that the theoretical feasibility of these craft has been demonstrated. A patent for a separate design was published in 2006, but was so complex that the manufacturing challenges couldn’t be overcome. The

 present design uses the latest advances in advanced architected cellular materials to provide a different solution. If the connected engineering and manufacturing challenges can be overcome on this occasion, and a proof of concept successfully realised, vacuum

 airships have the potential to provide another sustainable transportation option.
Primary Article Title: New developments in material science could allow vacuum travel
Author: Phillip Ball
Keywords: Air travel; vacuum; materials

Summary Sentence: New insights into the atmospheric chemistry of smog formation could open the way for the development of new methods of preventing it.
Justification:
The formation of smog in urban areas is an issue of public health concern globally. While it’s common knowledge that SO4 occurrence in the atmosphere is related to the presence of SO2, the complex processes of oxidation that mediate and enable the transformation

 have, until now, not been well understood. Data generated as part of a collaborative project between U.S. and Chinese researchers are beginning to shed light on this gap in our understanding. They demonstrate that concentrations of NOx play a key role in smog

 formation, and that broadly they enable three pathways through which smog formation can take place. When NOx concentrations are low, NOx catalyses the production of hydroxyl radicals - effective oxidants of SO2 - and thus promote the formation of sulfate.

 When NOx concentrations are extremely high, as is common in fog-haze conditions, NOx are the dominant oxidants of SO2 and thus also promote formation of sulfate. But, importantly, when NOx concentrations are at a medium level they act as a sink for hydroxyl

 radicals and, counterintuitively, supress sulfate formation. That means that in order to control smog formation the management of relative levels of NOx and S02 in the atmosphere is key. This could be a potentially useful insight for members of the EA tasked

 with developing policy instruments to manage and reduce air pollution.
Primary Article Title: Untangling links between nitrogen oxides and airborne sulfates helps tackle hazy air pollution
Keywords: Air pollution; Smog; health

Summary Sentence: The application of new statistical learning techniques to global climate models has made it possible to detect signals of climate change in global daily weather.
Justification:
At the moment, because of the variability in climatic parameters at any single point on the earth’s surface at any given time, climatic changes are only visible in weather averages calculated over elongated periods of time (normally about 30 years). Accordingly

 ‘seeing’ the influence of climate change in a daily weather observation has been extremely problematic. But researchers in Switzerland and Norway have developed a technique that averages spatial differences in global climatic parameters at a given point in

 time to generate a metric (global mean average temperature) that makes it possible to track shifts in the global climate on a daily basis. They’ve discovered that when the spatial variations in global temperatures are averaged out they provide a reliable and

 consistent average temperature with a relatively narrow range of variability. Accordingly daily changes in that global average temperature can be used to track global climatic changes. Characteristic spatial patterns in the anomalous daily data can then be

 then generated via regression modelling to identify the ‘fingerprint’ of climatic change as it applies to different regions of the globe. This means that in situ daily weather observations can be compared against the fingerprint to discern the influence of

 climatic forcing on particular events in particular places. The upshot is that specific weather events can be attributed to climate change in a statistically meaningful way. All this could have considerable consequences for our ability to communicate the risks

 of climate change, but might also usher in an era of more immediate accountability.
Primary Article Title: New statistical techniques allow daily weather events to be connected to climate change
Keywords: climate change; weather; climate forcing;

Summary Sentence: New developments in carbon capture technology arer a step towards viability
Justification:
A new innovation in carbon capture technologies could represent a radical step forward in the efficacy and utility of available techniques. Researchers have developed a device that uses electrochemical reactive adsorption to capture Carbon Dioxide at a range

 of concentrations and across a wide range of different settings. It could be used for removing CO2 from the flu gas of power stations or, equally, reducing the CO2 concentration of a room. It uses considerably less power than most current carbon capture technologies,

 meaning its less of a parasitic draw on power generators. That means the amount of cooling water required to operate a carbon capture process might be reduced, removing a considerable obstacle to its deployment, opening up the potential for more widespread

 uptake of the technology. For the EA it also opens up new possibilities in planning how to achieve policy objectives like the transition to a net zero economy.
Primary Article Title: A 'paradigm shift' in carbon capture technology
Author: Science Daily
Secondary_URLs: Faradaic electro-swing reactive adsorption for CO2 capture - Energy and Environmental Science 01/10/2019
Keywords: carbon capture; water resources; energy;

Summary Sentence: Recently published data indicate that we may be entering a slowdown in the rate at which the world is globalising.
Justification:
If that is the case it could have implications for the amount of materials and people moving between countries and the levels of carbon dioxide they emit as they do. That matters because the EA’s objective of achieving net zero requires it to consider levels

 of embedded carbon in goods and materials, to which the operation of global supply chains is a significant contributor.   The latest update of the Global Connectedness Index indicates that the world’s level of connectedness reached a new record high in 2017 as the shares of trade, capital, information, and people flowing across national borders all increased significantly for

 the first time since 2007. But it also demonstrates that by 2018 the policy environment for globalization had begun to show signs of deterioration as trade conflicts escalated and countries raised barriers to foreign takeovers, immigration, and other flows.

 Those concerns were subsequently borne out by a decrease in the Global Connectedness Index score for that year. Analysis of the shifts underpinning the decline suggest that it’s principally being driven by a contraction in the flows of capital across borders,

 particularly in connection with changes to the U.S. tax system. But data also shows that global trade flows began to contract in the first half of 2019, potentially pointing to a longer term effect. Other metrics considered by the index, such as flows of people

 and information, were either unchanged or continued to grow.
Primary Article Title: Signs of a slowdown in Globalisation
Author: STEVEN A. ALTMAN, PANKAJ GHEMAWAT, AND PHILLIP BASTIAN
Secondary_URLs: DHL GLOBAL CONNECTEDNESS INDEX 2019 Update - New York University School of Business 04/12/2019
Keywords: Globalisation; net-zero; economy; growth

Summary Sentence: Recent media interest in the use of sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) in wind turbines has highlighted that alternatives to this powerful greenhouse gas are in development.
Justification:
SF6 is used to insulate live electrical equipment and prevent fires resulting from short circuits etc. In this context SF6 only gets released if an issue occurs. However SF6 also has global warming properties - it is 23,500 times more warming than carbon

 dioxide (CO2). Alternatives have been proposed. These include a perfluorinated ketone with five carbon atoms (C5 PFK) from 3M called Novec 5110 Dielectric Fluid, trading as AirPlus. AiPlus rapidly decomposes under ultraviolet light in the lower atmosphere.

 In around 15 days, compared to 3200 years for SF6. It decomposes into CO2 which remains in the atmosphere and other molecules which are washed out. Another alternative is “Green Gas for Grid”—or “g³” (pronounced “g- cubed”) developed by GE. g3 gas has a mass

 having less than a 99% reduced CO₂ equivalent value compared to SF6. The g³ circuit-breaker is expected to be the first SF6-free 420 kV gas-insulated substation circuit-breaker in the world, and will be available from 2022. Energy companies including Western

 Power anticipate that these SF6 alternatives will be retro-fitted into existing switchgear and become business as usual following successful laboratory testing. Regulation could plausibly follow to ensure SF6 alternatives as employed as standard, while regulatory

 attention may be needed to supervise phase out of current SF6 usage.
Primary Article Title: EU to help fund SF6-free circuit breaker by GE
Author: Haddad, P
Secondary_URLs:
Climate change&%2358; electrical industry's 'dirty secret' boosts warming - BBC 13/09/2019

SF6 Alternatives - a literature review on SF6 gas alternatives for use on the distribution network - Western Power 26/01/2018

An alternative to SF6 in electrical switchgear - EE Publishers 12/12/2016
Keywords: energy safety "climate change" "greenhouse gas" "sulphur hexafluoride" SF6 CO2 wind g3 "Green Gas for Grid" GE AirPlus 3M perfluorinated ketone Novec 5110 Dielectric Fluid regulation emission air pollution quality
GT: energy, climate change, greenhouse gases, research, regulation

Summary Sentence: Future construction and civil engineering materials may be organic rather than mineral.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is involved in asset construction for flood management as well as its own asset management. An increasing focus on ‘Net Zero’ and other environmental issues could mean that sustainable alternatives to conventional construction materials

 may need to be adopted and developed. Previously engineers took inspiration from nature to try and mimic properties such as materials that self heal on contact with the air. Today’s research is focusing more on incorporating biological functions into building

 materials. Researchers in the USA have been experimenting with bacteria to develop building materials that live, multiply and grow. Under the right conditions cyanobacteria can absorb carbon dioxide from the air, creating calcium carbonate along the way. The

 researchers have been considering how these properties could be turned to making living buildings that can grow and repair themselves, involving a fraction of the resource and carbon footprint equivalent of conventional buildings. In the current experiments

 cyanobacteria are added to a sand and gelatin solution. The calcium carbonate that the bacteria mineralises the gelatin and binds the sand together to make a brick. It’s also possible to chop the brick in half, only for the bacteria to regrow it, suggesting

 self repairing properties. In the future dessicated raw materials could be sent to a construction site, where workers simply add water to grow and shape microbial components or even entire structures. Elsewhere researchers are looking at self healing construction

 materials inspired by plant photosynthesis. Self healing is one aspect of this, as is the idea of self aware living constructions that can change themselves in response to seasonal changes. Questions remain around safety and stability of living structures,

 and also how humans and other living organisms would react to living structures. There may be environmental concerns around pollution or biosecurity. However the potential environmental benefits may make this approach attractive when compared to the carbon

 dioxide (CO2) emissions and sand extraction related to contemporary concrete production, for example. There are also waste management benefits. Rather than creating rubble for landfill living structures, such as bridges made of strong plant fibre could simply

 break down or be composted at the end of life, creating a circular economic model. Much research remains in this field.
Primary Article Title: Building materials come alive with help from bacteria
Author: Strain, D
Secondary_URLs:
Biomineralization and successive regeneration of engineered living building materials - Matter 15/01/2020

Living bridges - ETH Zurich 03/01/2020
Keywords: construction building asset flood defence waste regulation landfill biology biological concrete cement bacteria cyanobacteria water "calcium carbonate" "Net Zero" "carbon dioxide" CO2 plant self healing rubble "circular economy" research USA polymer photosynthesis safety human animal wildlife pollution water quality

Summary Sentence: Scientists recently updated their plan for how 143 countries could switch to 100 per cent clean energy by 2050 and avoid a global temperature increase of 1.5 degrees.
Justification:
This is of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as it may suggest where regulatory activity in support of achieving the UK Government’s own Net Zero by 2050 target. The plan would require a global investment of US$73 trillion, which could be

 recouped within seven years from savings and newly created jobs. The researcher’s believe that a more aggressive timetable could achieve the same results by 2030, but that 2050 is more practical to allow for social and political adjustments. In order to meet

 100 per cent clean energy the UK would have to install an extra 322,225 MW of World Wind & Solar (WWS) beyond 2015 capacity. Of particular interest is an estimated 33,918 MW of onshore wind, 11,380 MW tidal turbine, 159,309 MW solar PV plant, 25,590 MW commercial/government

 rooftop PV and 26,145 MW of residential solar. These particular figures should be of interest to the Environment Agency in terms of planning considerations, planning and development impacts on estuarine environments and trajectories for renewable provision

 from it’s own buildings and assets. No new capacity wouild be required for geothermal, hydroelectric or concentrated solar power (CSP).
Primary Article Title: Stanford researchers have an exciting plan to tackle the climate emergency worldwide
Author: Koumoundouros, T
Secondary_URLs: Health, and climate in 143 countries - One Earth 20/12/2019
Keywords: "climate change" energy renewable "Net Zero" 2050 UK wind solar onshore rooftop PV photovoltaic government commercial asset

Summary Sentence: Advances in artificial intelligence (AI)continue to converge on the question of personhood.
Justification:
This is of interest for the Environment Agency and partners as the relationships and rights of humans, animals, wildlife and machines may become more central to environmental decision making. Of particular interest is also how machines reach decisions

 compared to their human counterparts, and whether these are acceptable, as well as correct. AI and machine learning is being used to translate languages already. This is based on analysis of word relationships - no matter how complicated a language there are

 always relationships between how words are used in relation to the context. Theoretically non-human communication should obey similar rules, for example whale song is already known to be formed from recurring patterns. AI may be able to unlock these ‘rules’

 allowing us to understand and communicate with animals that show some level of intelligence and awareness, including our pet cats and dogs. The normalisation of robots in domestic settings is evident in Japan, where machines are already replacing organic pets.

 Owners are reportedly taking their robotic pets on playdates, just as they would their living counterparts. Sony’s dog like Aibo is the pet of choice&%2358; their personality changing and expanding as it increasingly interacts with its surroundings. Future versions

 of Aibo will have their personalities stored in the cloud, so that they can live beyond the mechanical constraints of their current incarnation. . Robotics may also become more commonplace in zoos. A New Zealand based team have devised a robotic dolphin. The

 realistic nature of its appearance and behaviour, plus its ‘programmability’ have already seen therapeutic applications alongside an increase in orders for countries affected by wildlife trade bans and coronavirus. While voice activated assistants are becoming

 commonplace, physical ‘companion’ robots have yet to be widely accepted, though events such as this demonstrate that this may also be changing. Another example is news that one of the acts announced to perform at the Coachella Festival 2020 is Hatsune Miku,

 a virtual popstar. Miku’s music is predominantly made by developers using tools provided by Miku’s developers. Her set will effectively be the best of these collaborations her fans have made. Considering the size and reputation of Coachella, then this may

 also be a signal that non-organic personalities are becoming more accepted by society. The Beijing internet court in China recently launched an AI judge as part of an online litigation service. The AI judge, based will help the court's judges complete repetitive

 tasks, such as litigation reception, enabling humans to focus on judicial trials. The judge is represented with a female facial expression and voice, and provides users with litigation guidance in real time. As technology advances, the AI judge is expected

 to conduct intelligent question-and-answer communications based on the data of professional knowledge and the guidance from real judges.
Primary Article Title: All robot dogs go to the cloud
Author: Adams, R
Secondary_URLs:
Beijing Internet court launches AI judge - Xinhua 27/06/2019

Robotic dolphin stirs up aquariums while solving ethical dilemma - The New Zealand Herald 11/05/2020

Hatsune Miku is the most exciting addition to Coachella's 2020 line-up - GQ 03/01/2020

Artificial intelligence is helping us talk to animals (yes, really) - Wired 29/12/2019
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" AI robot machine pet animal robot Sony Aibo Japan poaching wildlife crime companion zoo dolphin coronavirus Covid-19 personality cloud death software voice assistant "Hatsune Miko" translate speech communication dog cat whale Coachella 2020 fan music open source China Beijing judge court law

Summary Sentence: Flash joule heating of inexpensive carbon sources creates graphene in milliseconds
Justification:
Currently bulk production of graphene is created using harsh chemicals. This discovery offers the opportunity to develop a process that can use any inexpensive carbon source, such as waste, to produce graphene flakes using only flash joule heating. Graphene

 made this way is named flash graphene (FG). Although any source of carbon can be used to make FG, the higher the carbon content of the base material, the higher the quality and quantity of FG produced. The researchers designed a bespoke reactor to undertake

 the transformation process, so that waste gasses such as oxygen and nitrogen can be captured for economic use. The reaction wastes little heat as the majority is channelled into the carbon material to facilitate the reaction. The researchers believe that incorporating

 this material in material such as concrete will reduce the environmental impact of construction. They suggest including just 0.1% FG in concrete will reduce its environmental impact by a third and increase the strength and longevity of the concrete at the

 same time. The evidence of this analysis would need verifying, but if such composite material is proved beneficial and it is economically viable to produce, this could have waste management implications for the Environment Agency. It could divert some waste

 from current treatment facilities, but there will also need to be considerations about how such composites will need to be treated when they finally come to the end of their use.
Primary Article Title: Lab turns trash into valuable graphene in a flash
Secondary_URLs: Gram-scale bottom-up flash graphene synthesis - Nature 27/01/2020
Keywords: waste material strength energy engineer construction climate recycle "air quality" "global warming" efficient heat industry cement

Summary Sentence: The contact lens uses a display the size of a grain of sand to project information to the wearer over their real world view.
Justification:
This is another example of research into wearable technology. As with clothes that have built in functions to benefit the wearer such as smart technology, these glasses aim to provide the user with information overlaid over the users real world view. Imagine

 having the permitting details of a site in front of your eyes as you look at the site. A similar device is being developed for firefighters, that overlays thermal imaging on a lens like material in front of the eye. The contact lens is the next step in this

 development, designing something that actually fits in the eye. Although there are still years of development needed to realise this product, this type of instant information could be beneficial to Environment Agency first responders attending incidents in

 the field.
Primary Article Title: The making of Mojo, AR contact lenses that give your eyes superpowers
Secondary_URLs: New augmented reality technology could help firefighters save lives - CBS News 31/12/2018
Keywords: contact lens eye sight information wearable AR Augmented reality

Summary Sentence: Researchers use computers to design biological organism out of tissue cells.
Justification:
This engineered organism has been named a Xenobot. It has been created using contracting and passive tissue cells from a frog. The cells have been selected for their different traits and then combined, next their behaviour has been analysed. An algorithm

 is then used to select different combinations of cells so that they can be engineered to undertake different functions. An evolutionary algorithm subsequently models behaviour to look for other combinations for different functions, and these are then tested

 to create a design feedback system. It is hoped that this knowledge will help scientists better understand the complexities of cellular communication, and how it may be controlled in the future to design living robots that can be programmed to behave in a

 certain way. This research is still in the very early stages, but is a good example of how advanced computing is being used to speed up development in other sectors. Biologically controlled organisms such as these could have potential in the future for environmental

 sensing and even remediation.
Primary Article Title: Meet Xenobot, an eerie new kind of programmable organism
Secondary_URLs: A scalable pipeline for designing reconfigurable organisms - PNAS 10/02/2020
Keywords: bioengineering "artificial life" evolution cell biological programmable monitor ethical robot AI artificial intelligence

Summary Sentence: The village of Fairbourne in North Wales could become the first settlement in Britain to be abandoned due to climate change.
Justification:
This development has far reaching potential implications for the Environment Agency and beyond. Fairbourne in the county of Gwynedd looks set to be ‘decommissioned’ by the local council due to the costs of defending it from rising sea levels and associated

 flood events, as well as surface water and fluvial flooding. In 25 years or sooner the council plan to have all residents relocated. As a result of this strategy becoming public, house prices in the village have collapsed, meaning that the current residents

 have lost a source of capital needed to relocate. Properties are still selling for a reduced price to people looking to make money from rental. The long term fate of Fairbourne’s residents is uncertain. They won’t receive compensation for the forced move.

 The villagers have been dubbed Britain’s first climate refugees. However, the term ‘refugee’ currently has a specific legal meaning which also comes with certain legal rights, which wouldn’t apply to Fairbourne residents. As the impacts of climate change become

 more acutely felt, it is possible that more local authorities and other government agencies may take similar decisions due to sprially flood and coastal defence costs. This could have social, political, economic and legal ramifications for all actors in this

 space, including the Environment Agency. For example delaying abandonment due to short term political issues rather than following longer term strategic trajectories could lead to significant losses from maintaining obsolete defences and reduce residents longer

 term financial prospects more than resolute action in the nearer term.
Primary Article Title: `This is a wake-up call'&%2358; the villagers who could be Britain's first climate refugees
Author: Wall, T
Keywords: "climate change" sea level rise flooding Fairbourne Wales Gwynedd "climate refugee" local authority government finance economics politics compensation housing surface water fluvial refugee asset management flood defence
GT: climate change, flooding, politics, local government, refugees

Summary Sentence: Researchers explore the feasibility of extracting carbon-14 isotopes from nuclear power plant waste for use in long lasting batteries.
Justification:
The team have created a man made diamond, which when in a radioactive field generates a small electrical current. They are now exploring the viability of generating that radioactive field by using waste material from a nuclear energy plant. Carbon-14 isotopes

 have a half-life of 5730 years, meaning were they to be used in a battery, they could power the radioactive field for generations. If carbon-14 isotopes can be extracted from nuclear waste, it would change the economic costs of nuclear decommissioning, as

 it reduces the radioactivity of the remaining material, making it easier to treat. Any changes to the treatment of radioactive waste may require regulatory change to facilitate, which could have implications for the work of the Environment Agency. This work

 follows on from research into how to generate ultra-low energy to power remote sensors using radioactive decay.
Primary Article Title: Nuclear waste could be recycled for diamond battery power
Keywords: 'climate change' power energy waste nuclear battery radioactive regulate health monitor sensor

Summary Sentence: Visualisation technology could help communities better understand their flooding risk.
Justification:
The climate emergency continues to receive significant publicity around the world. The likelihood of increased extreme weather events is often discussed, however this is not always easy to translate into likely implications at the local level. Using imagery

 from drones, mapping and modelling, a virtual reality (VR) program has been used in America by planners to show what a different range of sea level rise would mean for local communities. Using imaging to directly overlay levels of flooding during different

 scenarios allowed locals to see exactly what local infrastructure was at risk, and better understand the need for planning how to mitigate this. The concept of using virtual reality to support the work of the Environment Agency is not a new one, however this

 supplies a good example of how the technology has been used in other countries to communicate flooding and to help build community resilience.
Primary Article Title: Climate planners use VR to show communities how sea-level rise decimates them
Keywords: flood flooding communications comms climate VR virtual reality mapping engagement risk coast erosion

Summary Sentence: Ordinary people are utilising the opportunities that the internet presents to gather the knowledge, equipment and substances to ‘self administer’ healthcare.
Justification:
There is evidence emerging from America that the costs of healthcare in a privately funded health system are preventing people from seeking the medical treatment they need. One consequence is that people are turning to online sales of antibiotics intended

 for fish to obtain an alternative to human pharmaceuticals. Analysis of online sales reviews indicated that 2.4 per cent of them indicated that the antibiotics had been purchased with human consumption in mind. These reviews also received more attention and

 positive ‘likes’ than other reviews. There was also instances of retailers assuring that fish antibiotics were safe for human consumption. Fish antibiotics are cheaper than human ones, but they are not regulated to the same extent as other veterinary drugs,

 so there is no guarantee of content, risks of side effects or dose strength. There is at least one instance of someone becoming seriously ill from their consumption. While overall consumption is not high it may be difficult to quantify both volume and impact

 of sales, which is linked ultimately to rising costs and standards of living. In another example of ‘self administered healthcare a biohacker used knowledge and parts gleaned from the internet to ‘hack’ his insulin pump into an artificial pancreas. Frustration

 with healthcare professionals led to software engineer Liam Zebedee converting his pump into a system that automatically measures glucose levels in his blood and dispense insulin accordingly. Zebedee acknowledges the risks of relying on unproven software but

 still believes it safer and more value for money than professional healthcare.Economic stagnation combined with changing models of healthcare delivery in the UK could precipitate the circumstances where some people may similarly turn to alternative sources

 of medicine. This may impact on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in general, but may have specific impacts on the wild aquatic species to which it was intended originally. There are previous cases of the internet enabling use (%2314524 ) and potential manufacture

 (%2314582) of illegal or restricted chemicals, and there are also incidences of similar biohacks to reduce medical costs significantly (%2313874) . There is increasing evidence that medical professionals are increasingly using YouTube to review surgical procedures

 without quality control measures in place. Autonomous surgical procedures and the concept of home ‘DIY’ robot surgeons together with the signals highlighted previously all suggest a movement of healthcare from professional to amateur realms, bringing with

 it both professional and regulatory challenges alongside deeper concerns for health and wellbeing safety.
Primary Article Title: Sick Americans are desperate enough to buy fish antibiotics
Author: Cara, E
Secondary_URLs:
How this engineer hacked together his own "artificial pancreas" - Futurism 15/08/2019

Doctors are turning to YouTube to learn how to do surgical procedures, but there's no quality control - CNBC 24/11/2019

Chinese robot dentist is first to fit implants in patient's mouth without any human involvement - South China Morning Post 21/09/2017

Designer Frank Kolkman hacks 3D printer components to build DIY surgical robot - Dezeen 10/08/2015
Keywords: health medicine medical "3D printing" antibiotics AMR "antimicrobial resistance" internet shopping fish pet animal veterinary cost healthcare regulation YouTube surgery surgeon robot Ai autonomous DIY home hack diabetes pancreas information data maker China dentist dental OpenSurgery insulin pump human

Summary Sentence: Human induced climate change, if not adequately addressed could return future humans to a hunter-gatherer society.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is one of many agents involved in addressing the climate emergency and may need to consider what steps should be taken now that will make the transition from industrial civilisation less devastating for future generations and what

 could be done to improve the prospects for hunter-gatherer descendants. The Holocene (approx 12000 years - present) has been an abnormally stable time in terms of global climate, allowing for agriculture to flourish. Previous climates were not conducive to

 farming, so humans lived a hunter gatherer existence. Agrarian societies of the Holocene have been characterised by population boom-bust, often influenced by changes to the climate. The current climate emergency, if not adequately addressed could similarly

 bring significant instability to conventional agricultural systems, leading to a subsequent collapse. This instability could last for a significant time, prevent agriculture reestablishing, and returning society once again to a hunter-gatherer model. This

 is a conceivable future that could transpire unless the extremes of climate change, population growth are addressed. Policies to ease such a transition include rewilding landscapes and protecting indigenous cultures who hold the skills and knowledge that will

 be required to thrive in a hunter-gatherer future. The timescales of this transformation look beyond 2100, which is on a par with current Environment Agency strategic scope.
Primary Article Title: Our hunter-gatherer future&%2358; climate change, agriculture and uncivilization
Author: Gowdy, J
Keywords: "climate change" civilisation farming agriculture agrarian Holocene Pleistocene population hunting hunter gatherer indigenous culture conservation biodiversity rewilding flooding

Summary Sentence: The president of Indonesia has ordered government departments to replace senior civil servants with artificial intelligence (AI).
Justification:
President Joko Widodo has laid out plans to condense the top four tiers of the Indonesian civil service into two, through combining AI into government processes. Widodo has not given details on which areas of the civil service would be replaced with algorithms,

 or how. The plan is part of the current administration’s desire for the Indonesian economy to transition from mineral extraction to manufacturing and service industries. One example of AI’s use could be in streamlining business permitting. Widodo’s political

 majority should mean that this legislation is likely to be passed into law. Widodo acknowledged that such transformation would require foreign investment. The Environment Agency is already experimenting with automated systems and may need to consider the wider

 longer term implications on the dynamics and demography of its workforce.
Primary Article Title: Senior civil servants to be replaced by AI, says Indonesia's president
Author: Hunt, M
Keywords: automation "artificial intelligence" AI workforce government civil servant workforce management employee Indonesia President Joko Widodo algorithm law legislation regulation investment IT data

Summary Sentence: A robotic system has carried out 100,000 experiments on fluid dynamics in one year - the equivalent of all human conducted experiments in this field to date.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should consider how automation applications in chemistry could have applications for its own laboratory work, and also consider how similar robotic experiment systems could shorten chemical trials, improve ‘chemical cocktail’ understandings

 etc.The ‘Intelligent Towing Tank’ (ITT) works alongside human experimenters. ITT collects data from generated from vortex-induced vibrations. The data is fed into a learning algorithm that predicts a hypothetical numerical target. The hypothesis is then tested

 until the prediction and result are the same several times in a row, at which point the data is collected and the cycle begins again. ITT explored eight different parameters and could complete as many experiments in two weeks as a human would complete during

 a Ph.D.
Primary Article Title: A 'robot scientist' carried out 100,000 experiments in just 1 year, all on its own
Author: Lang, F
Secondary_URLs: A robotic intelligent towing tank for learning complex fluid-structure dynamics - Science Robotics 27/11/2019
Keywords: automation robotics experiment research chemical "Intelligent Towing Tank" ITT parameter workforce laboratory efficiency

Summary Sentence: Internet of Things (IOT), satellites and blockchain technologies have been brought together to improve groundwater monitoring in California.
Justification:
This example could suggest ways in which the Environment Agency and partner could use these technologies for similar purposes. The project in question is investigating how to use these technologies to monitor groundwater use in real time. Blockchain technology

 supports a dashboard that farmers can use to monitor and trade water extraction. Farmers can ensure that their own abstractions occur at a sustainable rate, and can sell any surplus quotas to others within the pilot area in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River

 Delta. The smart IOT sensors allow remote monitoring of groundwater use. The sensors transmit water extraction data to orbiting satellites, which is then fed into an IBM blockchain platform that records all transactions. Smart contracts also feature to automatically

 execute some transactions when the required conditions are reached.
Primary Article Title: IBM pilots blockchain and IoT sensor solution to track sustainable groundwater usage in California
Author: Wolfson, R
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" "water resources" groundwater abstraction regulation farmer agriculture blockchain "internet of things" IOT satellite data IBM California "Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta" farming

Summary Sentence: AI and mirrors concentrate suns energy to produce heat above 1000 degrees celcius.
Justification:
A clean energy startup called Heliogen is using artificial intelligence to calculate where to place mirrors in order to concentrate energy from the sun to create a solar oven. This allows temperatures of over 1000 degrees celsius to be reached, a level

 that is required by industry to produce steel, cement and other energy intensive materials. The company hope that they can help industry reduce the amount of greenhouse gasses they produce by offering a cost competitive technology that is cheaper than the

 fossil fuel alternatives. As the cement industry alone accounts for approximately 7% of all CO2 emissions, this could have a significant impact on global emissions. As the technology generates such high temperatures there are also plans to investigate the

 feasibility of using it to create clean hydrogen. This could then be used as a carbon free fuel.
Primary Article Title: Secretive energy startup backed by Bill Gates achieves solar breakthrough
Keywords: energy green industry efficiency eco cement metal emission emit pollution waste solar "bill gates" carbon artificial intelligence AI  fossil fuel hydrogen heat

Summary Sentence: The emerging field of bioacoustics could offer potential for environmental monitoring.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider how technological development and scientific understanding could unlock the potential of sound to enhance current environmental monitoring programmes. Bioacoustics is an emerging research field that

 usings audio recordings to enhance ecological and environmental understanding. The cost of photographical, video and audio recording devices has decreased significantly in recent years, contributing to the growing interest in this field. Old smartphones for

 example have previously been repurposed as intelligence gathering tools for use in combating illegal logging (%2312696). New purpose built devices such as AudioMoth are very cheap and light, and can record frequencies outside of human hearing. Some devices are

 small enough to be attached to a bird for recording purposes. Artificial intelligence (AI) is emerging that can identify species from recordings, which can otherwise be a time consuming task for humans. Audio recorders are in some ways better than cameras

 as they can cover a larger geographical area than the camera’s field of view. Recording the sounds within a habitat can identify the range of species present. If monitored over time these recordings can indicate changes in biodiversity and habitat, such as

 breeding patterns and spreads of disease and how factors such as climate, weather and human activity impact on biodiversity. As knowledge in this field advances it may be possible to use bioacoustics to infer a range of environmental monitoring criteria. In

 terms of more short term bioacoustic applications has recently been discovered for example that plants can make ultrasonic squeaks stressed by environmental conditions, including water shortage. The sounds are made when air bubbles inside xylem tubes used

 for water transport implode, known as cavitation. These sounds have been observed at distance for the first time in commercial greenhouse crops, and could possibly be detected by insects and animals, altering their behaviour. Moths may not lay eggs on water

 stressed plants for example. Further research could lead to environmental monitoring applications for regulators and farmers alike in terms of identifying and responding to the onset of drought conditions or other environmental stresses.
Primary Article Title: Listening to nature&%2358; the emerging field of bioacoustics
Author: Welz, A
Secondary_URLs: Recordings reveal that plants make ultrasonic squeals when stressed - New Scientist 05/12/2019
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" bioacoustic sound ecology habitat species "climate change" weather reproduction AudioMoth "artificial intelligence" AI smartphone microphone camera video audio media regulation ultrasound squeak insect bord animal moth plant crop drought stress xylem cavitation water resources

Summary Sentence: A test extraction of methane hydrate will shortly take place in Alaska, signifying an expansion of methane hydrate potential.
Justification:
This development is of interest to the Environment Agency and partners due the great potential for disrupting the energy market, but also global greenhouse gas potential of exploiting methane hydrate reserves. Methane hydrate is a solid, also known as

 ‘fire ice’, which forms through a reaction between decomposing organic matter and saline water, when occurring under pressure in the deep sea. The hydrate returns to methane gas form when returned to the surface. There are thought to be significant reserves

 of hydrate worldwide, including potentially in UK waters (%23REF???). Japan and China have already completed successful test drillings (%2314323). The Alaskan test drilling could indicate that hydrate extraction is gathering momentum. Cheap natural gas could potentially

 alter the current trajectory away from fossil fuels (%2313540), and therefore has global as well as local ramifications.
Primary Article Title: Japan, US to test methane hydrate output at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska North Slope
Author: Kumagai, T
Keywords: energy "fossil fuel" gas methane "methane hydrate" "fire ice" Alaska Japan China USA renewable regulation "greenhouse gas" "climate change" "Prudhoe Bay" "Alaska North Slope" marine ocean sea
GT: fossil fuel, energy, regulation, climate change

Summary Sentence: Increasing democratisation and accessibility of technology could allow lone actors to commit acts of crime and even violence anywhere in the World, without fear of consequence - resulting in ‘Omniviolence’.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may need to consider how a realised atmosphere of omniviolence might impact on the safety of its workforce, particularly field workers. Recently a US citizen was found guilty of targeting women with malware that recorded video footage

 intended to be used for blackmail. It’s observed that the perpetrator could equally have resided outside of the USA, which would’ve presented many logistical and political challenges in bringing them to justice, to the point where the is little appetite to

 do so. This in turn may embolden criminals to try this and other tactics. Outside of cyberspace, there are also signs that technology enabled violence is on the rise. One observer notes that the ‘K/K Ratio’ (ratio of killers to killed) is falling, meaning

 that more people are being killed by fewer killers. Professor Stuart Russell outlines a scenario a small team of people could threaten the lives of millions of people. A small drone (UAV) fitted with a charge as small as one gram would easily carry enough

 firepower to kill someone. Significant numbers of these could be purchased for very little cost and fit in a lorry. And unlike guns they would not need soldiers to operate them. They could be pre-programmed with facial recognition software to target individuals

 or groups of individuals and deployed in areas of high population concentration. Terrorists and criminals of the future may also have access to biotechnology, nanotechnology and artificial intelligence (AI) all of which facilitate the opportunities to operate

 across borders. The proposition of an onmiviolent future brings into question what purpose the state system has if is becoming increasingly ineffective at protecting its citizens. In terms of countermeasure one hypothesis could be to increase AI controlled

 surveillance, which would involve a significant curtailment of current liberties in turn for increased protection. This in itself may present opportunities for exploitation from criminals and state operators alike, but may still be preferred to the risk of

 ‘omniviolence’. It may transpire that other existential issues such as climate change may impact before society reaches this state, or that defence institutions are able to anticipate and respond to threats, such as anti-drone jamming technology that Heathrow

 and Gatwick airports purchased following flight disruption in 2018 - although developments suggest that it is possible that this technology could also be circumvented. An increasingly hostile environment may reflect on the experiences of Environment Agency

 workers, particularly those involved in operations and incident management roles, requiring extra resources dedicated to staff protection, health and wellbeing.
Primary Article Title: Omniviolence is coming and the World isn't ready
Author: Torres, P
Secondary_URLs:
Heathrow and Gatwick invest millions in anti-drone technology - Guardian 03/01/2019

Gatwick shutdown&%2358; alarm over `autopilot' drones immune to jamming - The Times 23/12/2018
