Keywords: omniviolence violence criminal crime terrorist terrorism law international "climate change" drone UAV gun weapon people urban city software "facial recognition" jamming Heathrow Gatwick air transport China biotechnology decentralisation "synthetic biology" nanotechnology internet knowledge government state surveillance algorithm data privacy regulation workforce incident management operations

Summary Sentence: A recent futures report provides some insight into the emerging technologies that the UK public would most like to see reach realisation.
Justification:
This is of interest as technologies often require social acceptance alongside economic and other factors in order to evolve. Intelligence on public interest may also provide steer for innovation and research. Many of these developments have already been

 noted through horizon scanning to have potential impacts for the Environment Agency, and it should therefore be noted that these also seem to have some degree of public support. The Samsung report was produced from a collaboration of futurists who identified

 many technological developments that would impact on life by 2069, including flying taxis (%23, space hotels (%23, aquatic super highways (%2314073) and city-to-city space travel (%2315234). However of note are 20 predictions that the UK public would most like to

 see become reality. The list also includes&%2358; self-cleaning homes, using robot technology (%2314758) ; body implants that monitor our health (%2313539) and translate any language (%231512); mass-scale 3D printing of organs (%2313617); robotic surgeons and doctors (as

 recently seen in China) ; virtual companions/carers to support our health; computer games played in suits which create sensations of touch (%2315070); vertical farming on the side of buildings (%2313903) ; Interactive movies, physically taking part in what we

 watch via VR; high street insect-burger takeaways (%2314459) ; earth scrapers (inverted skyscrapers going underground) (%2312994); living forever with our memories uploaded to the Cloud (%2313539); virtual multi-sensory holidays (%2314181, %2313350) ; nutritionally

 personalised food (%2315240); brain-to-internet connectivity (%2315106); TV and movies beamed directly to your brain via optoelectronic devices (%2313539).
Primary Article Title: Experts predict aquatic highways, air taxis and space hotels for life In 50 years time
Secondary_URLs: Dentists in China successfully used a robot to perform implant surgery without human intervention - Business Insider 22/09/2017
Keywords: regulation technology haptic robot implant health translate 3D printing organ VR virtual reality insect protein food earthscraper earth scraper cloud virtual memory data brain internet nutrition surgery surgeon entertainment "vertical farming" hyperloop under sea marine transport care older people

Summary Sentence: Solar energy market evolving, as solar windows join the mix.
Justification:
Solar windows, also known as building-integrated photovoltaics, allow visible light to pass into a building, while invisible infrared and ultra-violet light is directed to the integrated solar cells at the edge of the window. Although not as efficient as

 roof top solar, this is one of a number of solar window technologies evolving to capture energy where traditional solar PV units are not suitable. The technology has been licenced for use in the US, with work being undertaken to get similar approval for use

 in Europe. As efficiencies improve and installation costs reduce it is possible that this type of integrated solar window could become increasingly popular, especially by businesses that wish to improve their energy footprint and boost their environmental

 credentials. There could also be dual benefits from using this type of technology in greenhouses, generating energy while freeing up ground space. It is important to recognise that these types of units will have implications for waste management. Treatment

 of waste glass with integrated solar technology will be very different to traditional windows.
Primary Article Title: Australian solar PV integrated window technology gains US approval
Secondary_URLs:
Solar will power ahead to offer 20% more output for 25% lower module costs within 15 months - PV Magazine 17/12/2019

How to turn a greenhouse into a powerhouse - Science News for Students 25/02/2019
Keywords: solar sun energy renewable PV waste agriculture food efficiency carbon climate change electricity greenhouse photovoltaic recycle reporting

Summary Sentence: Conventional farming, and livestock associated sectors in particular, could be about to undergo a radical transformation.
Justification:
The climate emergency, human health and EU Exit are just some of the issues that create discussion on the future of UK agriculture. Scientists have recently stated that the World needs to reach ‘Peak Meat’ consumption by 2030 to cut emissions from meat and

 dairy and avoid the climate emergency. Think tank Common Wealth have proposed a Green New Deal to tackle these problems synergistically through allocating 25% of land to wildlife and carbon sequestration, alongside behavioural changes towards meat and dairy.

 Sir Ian recently clashed with the NFU over visions for the future of UK farming. Former Defra Chief Scientific Adviser Sir Ian Boyd sees Brexit as an opportunity for similar goals. The NFU sees the opposite occurring as the UK’s well-watered pastures are ideal

 for producing low-carbon livestock for export to less favourable territories. There is emerging evidence on the potential health risks of dairy produce. But as meatless alternatives hit the mainstream there are concerns that the processed nature of their manufacture

 may mean they are less than a healthy alternative. In a sense China’s ‘polar bear’ sized pig breeding can almost be seen as living metaphor of a system reaching its limits of scale and efficiency. These same tensions between environmental, economic and social

 concerns arrive at a time when the World could be on the cusp of the most significant technological disruption to agricultural production in 10,000 years&%2358; Food as Software  Rapid advances in precision biology is making huge strides in precision fermentation, allowing microorganisms to be ‘programmed’ to produce almost any complex organic molecule. In this system the cost of proteins will be five times cheaper by 2030 and 10

 times cheaper by 2035 than existing animal proteins, before ultimately approaching the cost of sugar. Product after product extracted from livestock will be replaced by superior, cheaper, modern alternatives, long before other technologies develop lab grown

 meat.  Food will be superior in every key attribute – more nutritious, healthier, better tasting, and more convenient, with almost unimaginable variety.   The impact of this disruption on conventional farming will be profound. By 2030, the number of cows in the U.S. will halve. The impacts on livestock farming, and related industries (fertilisers, machinery, veterinary services, etc.) will be severe, destroying

 billions of dollars of value. At the heart of the new production model is ‘Food-as-Software’. Individual molecules will be uploaded to databases for food engineers anywhere in the World to use use. Constant iteration means products improve rapidly, with each

 version superior and cheaper than the last. It also ensures a completely decentralised production system that is more resilient than conventional agriculture. Trade relations will shift because decentralized food production doesn’t offer geographic of climatic

 advantage. Major exporters of animal products will lose geopolitical leverage over countries dependent upon imports.  .  Disruption will not be uniform however. Some industries only require a small number of replacement ingredients to be completely disrupted, such as milk, where only 3.3 per cent of its content is protein. By 2035, about 60% of the land currently being used

 for livestock and feed production will be freed for other uses. Farmland values could collapse, providing an opportunity to reimagine and repurpose the whole landscape. ‘Food As Software’ could extend to diner’s needs and expectations. A Japanese restaurant

 concept uses personalised data extracted from bodily fluids to design sushi tailored to an individual’s nutritional needs. Customers would share their biometric information in advance in order for the automated process to create a hyper-personalised meal.  ‘Food As Software’ concept stimulates conversation on the scale, speed, and impact of the modern food disruption. In this sense the changes it proposes could bring significant operational and strategic challenge to the Environment Agency in terms of site

 base regulation of the farming and food sectors. It could also offer opportunities around influencing land use change to address some of the same strategic challenges around flood management and physical modification of rivers. It should also be noted that

 the suggested ‘tipping point’ for Peak Meat and the dawn of a Food as Software future is around 2030, within the scope of the 25 year Environment Plan.
Primary Article Title: We are on the cusp of the fastest, deepest, most consequential disruption of agriculture in history
Secondary_URLs:

Climate policies 'will transform UK landscape' - BBC 01/11/2019

China's breeding giant pigs that are as heavy as polar bears - Bloomberg 06/10/2019

Summary Sentence: Construction and engineering could be transformed by assembler robots that construct large structures from small identical interlocking pieces, called voxels.
Justification:
While the focus of this research is on engineering manufacturing it is possible to conceive of similar applications in flood management asset construction and incident management for erecting and disassembling temporary structures. The system may also

 have the potential to reduce waste from the construction sector and make more sustainable buildings. Large engineering projects such as commercial jet manufacturing are typically manufactured in sections before being brought together for assembly. This process

 is both costly and slow. Researchers have envisioned an alternative approach where robots assemble large complex structures from small pieces in one location, thereby saving costs. The assembler robots are small and designed to work in teams, known as relative

 robotics. The robots and voxels function as a single system, with the robots only needing to know their position and task relative to others in the system. With this system, virtually any shape can be easily represented as nodes and struts for the robots to

 assemble. The system, which has similarities with the Hypercells concept (%2313927) is already gaining interest from the space and aerospace industries.
Primary Article Title: Assembler robots make large structures from little pieces
Author: Chandler, D L
Secondary_URLs: Material-Robot System for Assembly of Discrete Cellular Structures - IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters 23/07/2019
Keywords: robotics construction engineering asset "incident management" flood barrier assembler voxel "relative robotics" building hypercell

Summary Sentence: A new developed compact infrared spectrometer is small enough to be incorporated into a mobile phone.
Justification:
The Environment Agency uses spectrometers as part of its environmental monitoring and analysis work, and therefore should consider how realisation of technology like this could impact on routine monitoring and laboratory analysis work and the wider implications

 for citizen science. Current infrared spectrometers used for such analyses today generally weigh several kilograms and are difficult to integrate into a handheld device. Researchers have developed a two square centimetre chip that can analyse infrared light

 in the same way as a conventional spectrometer. Instead of analysing the interference pattern with mirrors the new chip uses an optical refractive index adjusted externally via an electric field. The “spectrometer on a chip” exploits the electro-optic properties

 of thin-film lithium niobate. It only needs to be calibrated once, requires little maintenance due to no moving parts. Development is still needed before it could be incorporated into a mobile phone or similar, but it is thought that it could be produced at

 scale relatively cheaply.
Primary Article Title: Smaller than a coin
Author: Wursten, F
Secondary_URLs: An integrated broadband spectrometer on thin-film lithium niobate - Nature 07/10/2019
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" infrared spectrometer "citizen science" smartphone mobile phone regulation "lithium niobate" regulation

Summary Sentence: A new battery concept based on aluminium could reduce the costs and environmental impacts of some current technologies.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as it is already considering the regulatory impacts of lithium and other battery technologies on waste management as the renewable energy sector grows and existing devices mature or become obsolete.

 Aluminium as an anode has previously shown potential for electron storage, greater than lithium, but so far it has not been possible to achieve the same energy density in a battery has prevented further development. Researchers have found that this can be

 significantly increased through replacing the graphite cathode with an organic, nanostructured cathode, made of the carbon-based molecule anthraquinone. Anthraquinone enables higher energy density through storing positive charge-carriers from the battery’s

 electrolyte solution. The aluminium battery is still a concept, but the breakthrough suggests huge potential. There are already plentiful quantities of aluminium in the system, as well as the infrastructure to recycle it safely, which should mean that battery

 costs remain low. The team are working to remove chlorine from the battery’s design, but the environmental impacts of other novel chemicals such as anthraquinone may also need to be considered.
Primary Article Title: A new concept for more sustainable batteries
Secondary_URLs:
Concept and electrochemical mechanism of an Al metal anode ? organic cathode battery - Energy Storage Materials 25/07/2019

Weakest Link To EV Growth Is Material Supply Chain – OpEd – Eurasia Review

Battery Charge - Master Investor

Summary Sentence: An artificial intelligence (AI) company has developed an algae powered bioreactor that can absorb as much carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere as an acre of trees.
Justification:
Tree planting is seen as a core strategy for reducing greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The Environment Agency may need to consider the implications of using devices similar to this in its own Net Zero strategy as well as the wider implications for society

 and the environment. Hypergiant Industries have already developed a working prototype of the Eos Bioreactor. Their machine learning expertise is helping to refine design and performance of the unit which is similar in dimensions to a household fridge/freezer.

 Algae grows much more quickly and can sequester more carbon dioxide than trees.Hypergiant estimates Eos can sequester around two tons of carbon out of the air each year. The algae that grows in the unit would need to be harvested regularly, from where it could

 be used as a fuel, fertiliser or in cosmetic production etc. Hypergiant have designed the unit so that it can easily be plugged in alongside current office heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) technology. They envisage it being used to capture

 CO2 and improve air quality in offices, or being run on building rooftops. CEO Brian Lamm believes that Eos can only make a significant contribution to tackling climate change through it being part of a “hyperlocal, decentralized supply chain” that alters

 how goods produced, processed, transported, and consumed. In an attempt to get people and organisations adopting their technology Hypergiant plan to make the blueprints available and provide mobile applications to monitor and run the bioreactors autonomously.

 It isn’t clear however what the resource footprint of running costs of an Eos unit might be.
Primary Article Title: This algae bioreactor can remove as much carbon dioxide as an acre of trees
Author: Brown, M
Secondary_URLs: This `personal carbon sequestration' device uses algae to remove CO2 from the air - Fast Company 17/09/2019
Keywords: energy "carbon capture" biodiversity land use tree woodland forestry fertiliser cosmetic manufacturing farming "climate change" algae Eos "carbon dioxide" CO2 Hypergiant heating ventilation "air conditioning" HVAC "Brian Lamm" hyperlocal decentralised decentralisation "supply chain" blueprint "open source" mobile phone app
GT: energy, climate change, biodiversity, land use

Summary Sentence: A biotech company has discovered several candidate drugs for gene therapy using artificial intelligence (AI).
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this and similar research breakthroughs using data analysis and AI, rather than human powered laboratory work as it could provide a mechanism to identify and anticipate the behaviours of new chemicals on the

 environment prior to the formation of regulations. Toronto based Deep Genomics uses over 20 machine learning systems trained on public and proprietary data to screen for disease-causing mutations. Their system can scan over 200,000 pathogenic patient mutations

 and automatically identify potential drug targets within two hours. Recently Deep Genomics isolated a dozen drug candidates for Wilson disease, a potential fatal genetic disorder that causes a build up of copper in the liver and brain. Current treatments focus

 on stopping the body absorbing copper or passing it through urine. Deep Genomics analysis of genetic mutations have instead suggested chemicals that could restore the patient’s ability to absorb copper, eventually focusing on DG12P1 as the best candidate.

 The whole process has taken 18 months from screening to isolation. While focussing on genetic medicine there could be other applications for similar AI technology that could lead to new compounds emerging faster than regulation can account for. Conversely

 AI may also provide a virtual testing ground for how new chemicals and pharmaceuticals react with other compounds, improving overall chemical risk assessment.
Primary Article Title: In conversation with Brendan Frey&%2358; Deep Genomics reveals the first-ever AI-discovered drug candidate
Author: In conversation with Brendan Frey: Deep Genomics reveals the first-ever AI-discovered drug candidate
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" chemical chemistry drug medicine gene genetic "Deep Genomics" "Brendan Frey" "machine learning" "Wilson disease" "genetic disorder" DG12P1 regulation research

Summary Sentence: The introduction of SpaceX’s ‘Super Heavy Starship’ rocket could mark the beginning of a significant disruption to air travel and cargo shipments on Earth, not just space.
Justification:
Following the unveiling of the Super Heavy, SpaceX’s owner Elon Musk gave a presentation highlighting how the new rocket follows previous disruptions within the sector. The Super Heavy is constructed from 301 stainless steel with a nominal composition

 of 17 percent chromium and 7 percent nickel. Using steel as opposed to carbon fibre reduces the costs of a 120 tonne rocket from $15.6 million to £300,000, whilst also greatly reducing labour costs and construction time. The reductions in cost, build time

 and turnaround of these renewable rockets could translate into significant changes in both freight and passenger transport. The current payload is able to put 300 tonnes into orbit per year. A fleet of 20 Super Heavy rockets flying three times a day could

 increase this to 3 million tonnes a year. It would be possible to deliver a package anywhere on Earth in around an hour (providing the correct infrastructure was in place). Musk has also discussed how Super Heavies could be used for passenger transport. A

 Super Heavy could transport up to 1000 passengers at a time, paying between $500 - $2000, comparable to current long haul flights. The difference is that a Super Heavy would reduce intercontinental travel time from hours down to minutes. The potential disruption

 that technology like the Super Heavy could bring is significant. Details on fuel and emissions suggest that the Super Heavy will burn cryogenic liquid oxygen (LOX) and liquid methane propellants, which may need regulatory regimes, alongside concerns around

 emissions. A transition to this form of transport may present competition to the airline industry, decreasing emissions from an Environment Agency regulated sector. At a time where limiting container ship speeds is being considered as a means to reduce air

 pollution, plans to transport cargo by air may need to be scrutinised for environmental impacts.
Primary Article Title: Age of steel spaceliners
Author: Wang, B
Secondary_URLs:
Climate change&%2358; speed limits for ships can have 'massive' benefits - BBC 11/11/2019

BFR (rocket) - Wikipedia 18/11/2019

301 Stainless Steel Sheet & Coil - AMS 5901 - United Performance Metals 18/11/2019

Summary Sentence: Researchers have discovered a gene implicated in regulating the life span of humans, pointing towards new treatments that could extend longevity.
Justification:
Research investigating factors related to the extension of the human life span has shown an association between the longevity of human lives and levels of neural excitation in the cerebral cortex of the brain. The analysis indicates that reduced neural excitation

 is related to a longer life span and that there is a dynamic relationship between how long people live and the excitatory – inhibitory balance of neural circuits. Levels of neural excitation are regulated by genes. When the expression of those genes was manipulated

 experimentally in worms, researchers found they could extend their lifespan. The suggestion is that this could be a step towards similar gene therapy treatments in humans with the potential to slow the aging process and extend the length of time people live

 for. The possible impacts of being able to control lifespan are clearly profound and could have far-reaching impacts across many areas of the social world. Most importantly for the Environment Agency there might be implications for the length of people’s working

 lives and for the length of time they spend in retirement. It may also alter patterns of consumption and have significant implications for society’s impact on the environment.
Primary Article Title: Damping down brain cell activity may help us to live longer
Author: Ruby Prosser Scully
Secondary_URLs: Regulation of lifespan by neural excitation and REST - Science 16/10/2019
Keywords: life span, time, gene therapy, aging
GT: life span, time, gene therapy, aging

Summary Sentence: A second gene that regulates the amount of sleep people need has been identified, pointing the way towards treatments that could extend our waking hours and perhaps increase our amount of active time.
Justification:
An investigation into the determinants of the length, depth, and continuity of people’s sleep has identified a genetic mutation that appears to be a key regulator of the process. The research studied families identified as normally needing less sleep than

 average and mapped their exomes (part of the genome). When they examined the data they were then able to isolate and identify a mutation preferentially carried by those families, which contributed to their ability to sleep for less time without any of the

 related symptoms of sleep deprivation. The implication of identifying the mutation is that through gene therapy techniques it may become possible to intervene in the process of sleeping and control how much is required. If related safety concerns are successfully

 overcome treatment may allow people to stay awake for longer and be more active and productive in their daily lives. This logically might then mean that employers like the Environment Agency could offer a longer working day or changed working patterns, but

 might also mean that there are implications for resource use and the environment of people being awake and active for longer. Depending on how the treatment is made available there may also be wider social and cultural consequences, in terms of inequality

 of access to the treatment, for example.
Primary Article Title: A second mutation that makes people need less sleep has been found
Author: Michael Le Page
Secondary_URLs: Mutant neuropeptide S receptor reduces sleep duration with preserved memory consolidation - Science 16/10/2019
Keywords: gene therapy, sleep, labour force

Summary Sentence: As new data focused digital communication technologies become incorporated into our everyday lives, the relationship between what it means to be a citizen, the rights we have, and how we participate in the economy is being re-moulded.
Justification:
An investigation into the long term cultural and political evolution of what it means to be a citizen and a consumer in a western capitalist economy has sketched out the emergence of a new state of being for many of us – the ‘data citizen’. The work starts

 with an examination of how our role as traditional ‘consumers’ was originally constructed and has changed over time. Consumers, as we understand them today, first began to emerge in the United States during the early 20th century as people’s rights

 as citizens became linked to their ability to participate in the economy – the beginning of the notion that ‘freedoms’ could be bought through spending. These new circumstances were particularly important for women at a time before they could vote. The power

 to consume provided a pathway to greater levels of independence when many other avenues were still closed. These new arrangements soon brought about the development of entirely new professions, such as marketing and industrial design, that further evolved

 and consolidated the link between consumption and how people were able to participate in society. During this period spending money became akin to voting as an expression of preferences, and consumption took on the political character that is familiar to us

 today. The ‘citizen – consumer’ was born.   But in the last 10 – 15 years the inter-relationship of spending, cultural rights and freedoms has started to change. The appearance of the digital ‘data economy’ has begun to give new meaning to what it means to be a consumer and to consume. Instead of

 simply spending and receiving a stream of ‘stuff’, new ‘data citizens’ are now actively generating value in the economy through the digital footprint they leave behind. In the very same moment they are very often empowered as the producers and distributers

 of their content. So in this new digital sphere rights, freedoms and services are made available not according to an individual’s ability to buy ‘things’ but according to their willingness and ability to participate in the digital world and exchange information

 about themselves for access. Counter-intuitively this has ended up eroding rights like privacy and the control and ownership of personal data, which traditional consumers have come to expect. Consequently it’s also changed the political nature of consumption,

 shifting power away from consumers to providers. When a consumer’s data is used to develop and inform algorithms they’re in effect transformed into little more than the ‘node’ of a massive neural data network built to target them with new tailored advertising

 and services. As these new arrangements become more ‘normal’ and expected so the role of the consumer is morphing into one of simply being a ‘sensory organ’ for a huge Artificial Intelligence and data collecting operation – the ‘data citizen’ is born.  So what’s new here is that our understanding and expectations of what it is to be a consumer – the role we all play – as well as the power relationships around it, are changing to incorporate the digital sphere. That in turn has really important implications

 for the types of services we use, the reasons we use them and what doing so means to us – the digital era is changing not only how we buy stuff, but what we buy, why and what for.   The significance of this to the Environment Agency is clear&%2358; What might be the ramifications of these new types of consumers – empowered to produce, but, stripped of important other rights – be for the way material goods are produced distributed, used and

 disposed of? Will, or to what extent, will material based modes of consumption be displaced or encouraged? How will the EA sit in a world where consumption and demand are more fully shaped by algorithms and their data models? How could the EA position itself

 to benefit from the new methods of data based value creation? And given the ethical complications of doing so, should it?
Primary Article Title: The data economy&%2358; how technological change has altered the role of the citizen-consumer
Author: Minna Lammia, Mika Pantzar
Keywords: digital economy, consumption, cultural change, political change
GT: digital economy, consumption, cultural change, political change

Summary Sentence: Legal sulphur dioxide filters for ships may have unintended consequences on sediments and marine habitats.
Justification:
There is concern among some British port authorities that sulphur dioxide filters commonly called scrubbers are redistributing air pollutants from shipping and transferring them to sediments and the marine environment instead. The devices are legal and many

 shipping companies have spent considerable amounts fitting them in order to meet legal obligations. The open loop scrubbers return wash water containing contaminants to the sea. The shipping industry maintain that the discharges have to meet strict criteria

 for discharge, so they are not a problem. However British port operators are concerned that these discharges although individually small will build up over time causing sediment pollution in the long term. The Environment Agency works to protect and improve

 the water environment, so will have a keen interest in the research on this subject.
Primary Article Title: Environmental `cheat devices' fitted to thousands of ships could render UK ports unusable
Keywords: Marine sea water pollution metal PAH carcinogen hydrocarbon sediment licence dredge dredging waste unintended regulation regulate law

Summary Sentence: Research aims to make artificial womb viable for human trials within ten years
Justification:
An artificial womb has already successfully incubated a preterm lamb for 28 days (HSDBi 15162). Research is now focussing on how to improve this technology so that it can be used for premature human babies. Researchers from the Netherlands have now received

 funding from the EU Horizon 2020 programme in order to make this possible. The study now aims to create a womb where the baby floats in synthetic amniotic fluid and is connected to an artificial placenta and umbilical cord. They wish to more closely mimic

 the natural environment of the womb and the sounds such as the mother’s heartbeat. Although this technology is being developed to help survival rates of babies born pre term, if the technology successfully matures to a stage of full ectogenesis it is feasible

 to see a distant future where parents may elect for this type of pregnancy. This would have all sorts of ethical implications to overcome before it could ever be adopted, but would have significant societal impacts if it did. Such technology could also impact

 on animal farming as breeding cycles may no longer need to be seasonal and medical interventions would be in a closed system, reducing the impact of antibiotics on the environment. The influence on population dynamics as a whole may also have consequences

 for resource use and environmental impacts.
Primary Article Title: The world's first artificial womb for humans
Secondary_URLs: Artificial womb&%2358; Dutch researchers given ?2.9m to develop prototype - Guardian 08/10/2019
Keywords: "artificial womb" birth baby embryo premature health pregnancy biology research farming agriculture livestock children child parent wealth lamb Biobag China food meat clon cloning "synthetic meat" lab sheep grown protein ethic abortion fetus adoption population society law regulation men women sex ectogenesis

Summary Sentence: Resveratol, a chemical extracted from plants including japanese knotweed, shows potential as an anti-ageing drug.
Justification:
With an ageing population globally and in the UK, resveratol’s potential could mean that problematic non-native invasive plants such as knotweed start to be seen as commercially valuable, changing both how they are viewed and treated. Resveratol is a compound

 found in grape skin and blueberries. It also reportedly also found in high concentrations in varieties of knotweed. It’s been previously investigated for its anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidative, and anti-diabetic effects. Knotweed is already known to be edible,

 which has suggested one pathway to controlling it (%2314115 ) Its properties as a treatment against muscle and bone wasting are being investigated to protect astronauts from the rigours of zero-gravity and long space flights. Closer to home resveratol reputedly

 derived from giant knotweed and japanese knotweed is being marketed and sold as a dietary supplement - though the provenance of these products may be in question.. David Sinclair, professor of genetics at Harvard has spent his career studying age related diseases.

 He is focussed on finding a drug to slow these processes and possibly reverse them in the longer term. Sinclair has studied resveratol’s effects on mice. However issues with maintaining high resveratol levels in the bloodstream, coupled with the inability

 to patent resveratol as it’s a natural substance are highlighted as reasons for pursuing other lines of interest. But Sinclair himself takes resveratol supplements, as does his father who is in his 70s. Both giant and japanese knotweed are identified as problematic

 invasive plants, with the latter seen are more problematic. Of further interest is acknowledgement that hybrids of the two plants exhibits hybrid vigour and is reputed to be more invasive than the parents as it has a more varied genome. Commercialised farming

 of giant knotweed could lead to more widespread hybridisation and therefore more problematic plants in the wild, without appropriate biosecurity precautions. Currently problems associated with japanese knotweed cost the UK economy in the region of £165 million

 per year. The global anti-ageing market predicted to be $429 billion by 2022, suggesting that there are potentially significant gains from commercialisation of knotweed harvesting in some form.
Primary Article Title: Will the Government block this geneticist from selling and anti-aging pill?
Author: Fosco, M
Secondary_URLs:
Could a component of red wine help future Mars explorers? - Interesting Engineering 29/07/2019

Know your knot weed advice - Bristol University 04/07/2016
