Summary Sentence: The environmental impact of military activities may becoming under increasing scrutiny.
Justification:
Several examples coming to light suggest this. The US Military (%2312637, %2314134) (amongst others (%2312065) including the UK (%2312974)) have previously highlighted a potential link between continued climate change and increasing civil unrest. It is therefore

 perhaps significant to note recent research that reveals the extent of the US Military’s carbon footprint. The study in question suggests that the US military is one of the largest polluters in history. It consumes more fuel and emits more greenhouse gases

 (GHGs) than most medium sized countries. Were it a country, its fuel usage would rank it the 47th largest GHG emitter, between Peru and Portugal. Closer to home recent evidence has established a link between the UK civilian nuclear programme and the nuclear

 defence industry. Energy bills are being inflated in order to subsidise civilian nuclear power, which in turn cross subsidises defence activities such as nuclear submarines through underpinning the relevant supply chain and skills base for firms that work

 on nuclear submarines. It is claimed that this interdependence, rather than a need for a diverse energy mix, that is partially preventing further financial support and development of renewable energy sources. Current political tensions are seeing rising numbers

 of ballistic missiles, both conventional and nuclear globally, which may mean that the UK is reluctant to reduce its nuclear capability in the short term, further preventing further advancement of renewable energy development. The impact of military operations

 on biodiversity has also recently been raised by a group of prominent scientists who are pressing for environmental damage to be recognised as a war crime. The scientists suggest that international lawmakers should adopt a fifth Geneva convention that recognises

 damage to nature alongside other war crimes. This would safeguard threatened species, and support the livelihoods of rural communities, both during and post-conflict. How these collective signals influence the role of domestic environmental regulators is unclear.

 However a movement for a greater global accountability for the impact of military operations on the environment could lead to changes in some current activities such as regulation of carbon emissions from civilian aviation to also include defence aircraft

 in accounting.
Primary Article Title: Make environmental damage a war crime, say scientists
Author: Watts, J
Secondary_URLs:
US military is a bigger polluter than as many as 140 countries - shrinking this war machine is a must - The Conversation 24/06/2019

Nuclear&%2358; Energy bills 'used to subsidise submarines' - BBC 05/06/2019

The world is heading for a new missile arms race - Quartz 09/06/2019
Keywords: "climate change" defence military army US "greenhouse gas" GHG fuel oil "fossil fuel" "civil unrest" energy carbon nuclear renewable missile weapon missile consumer cost subsidies law regulation crime biodiversity UN

Summary Sentence: An online based global vegan community has been launched, powered by its own virtual currency.
Justification:
VeganNation envisages uniting the growing global vegan movement and share values through its online platform that will encourage real world interactions and a Ethereum blockchain based VeganCoin, the medium of exchange to underpin transactions of vegan

 products and services, as well as ensuring product provenance. As VeganCoin can only be used to purchase vegan products it can ensure that future transactions can’t be tainted from being derived from interactions with the meat industry such as being used to

 buy beef burgers, or through animal derived content in bank notes. The developers observe that if the World’s vegan community was a country then it would have the strongest economy of any nation. VeganNation has recently secured $10 million of investment funding.

 The idea of online communities focussing around specific issues is not a new idea, however the novel aspect of a global currency that can only be obtained and exchanged through customers and suppliers with shared ethics presents questions around access, taxation

 and spending power, which may see more suppliers engaging with such an alternative economy, and the environmental benefits that it could bring. It may also present issues if entities engaging through such communities can exist parallel to accepted standards

 and regulations.
Primary Article Title: Vegan Nation&%2358; Israeli startup builds 1st global ecosystem for plant-based living, powered by own digital currency
Keywords: blockchain "distributed ledger" VeganNation online community veganism economy "virtual currency" VC VeganCoin plant business food digital currency tax regulation safety standards

Summary Sentence: CRISPR gene editing technology has been used to manufacture smart materials that respond to the presence of biological signals.
Justification:
The Environment Agency’s interest in using eDNA techniques for environmental monitoring could be further enhanced through employing these smart materials. DNA hydrogels are water filled polymers held together with strands of DNA. In this particular study

 CRISPR that uses a DNA-snipping enzyme called Cas12a was used to edit the DNA within a hydrogel so that it would recognise another specific DNA sequence if it came into contact with it. The researchers were able to build a series of hydrogels that could respond

 to a range of biological material including bacteria and viruses. Some of these were designed to release enzymes, small molecules and even human cells, which could see them used in medical treatments. The team even used the hydrogels to developed a prototype

 diagnostic tool that sends a wireless signal when it recognizes genetic material from Ebola in lab samples. There is also the potential for using the hydrogels in this way to identify the presence of DNA of interest within a water sample, with instantaneous

 results, thereby reducing the need for laboratory analysis of water samples in environmental monitoring.
Primary Article Title: CRISPR cuts turn gels into biological watchdogs
Author: Callaway, E
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" gene editing CRISPR DNA eDNA Cas12a DNA hydrogel Ebola enzyme polymer "smart material" health illness medicine bacteria "water quality" pollution

Summary Sentence: A newly developed membrane could spark commercially viable uranium extraction from sea water.
Justification:
It is estimated that the ocean contains around four billion tonnes of uranium, which equates to a near exhaustible fuel supply for the nuclear energy industry. However the diluted nature of marine water uranium makes extraction technically challenging and

 uneconomical so far. Researchers have developed a biomass based membrane for capturing uranium from sea water, which is significantly more effective than conventional methods. The membrane is based on metal–phenolic networks (MPNs), a supramolecular coordination

 structure consisting of metal ions and polyphenols. These membrane performed well in a range of factors including selectivity, capacity and renewability both in the lab and during field-testing. These results demonstrate that MPN-based membranes show promise

 in scaling up for economically productive real-world uranium extraction. Technology like this alongside other similar approaches (%2314835) could lead to more plentiful supplies of uranium, which in turn may mean more nuclear power. The Environment Agency’s

 role may intensify as a result in terms of regulating radioactive waste and the handling of hazardous material during the extraction phase, were uranium extraction occur within UK waters.
Primary Article Title: Engineering robust metal-phenolic network membranes for uranium extraction from seawater
Author: Luo, W; et al
Keywords: regulation mineral extraction energy nuclear radioactive waste marine coast ocean sea uranium metal metal–phenolic network MPN biomass membrane seawater

Summary Sentence: Lifetime exposure to contaminants in drinking water at current levels may be increasing the incidence of cancer.
Justification:
Research based on American drinking water standards should be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as initial intelligence suggests that European standards for some of the carcinogenic chemicals mentioned are comparable. Lifetime exposure

 to air pollution is already an accepted approach to air quality regulation, but a similar approach to water pollution hasn’t been applied until now. The study found that, based on cumulative risk analysis of contaminant occurrence in United States drinking

 water for the period of 2010–2017, over 100,000 lifetime cancer cases could be due to carcinogenic chemicals in tap water. The main chemicals responsible for this risk are arsenic, disinfection byproducts and radioactive contaminants. Overall the risk due

 to tap water contaminants is approximately 4 × 10−4, which is two orders of magnitude higher than the minimal cancer risk of one-in-a-million, and comparable to risks reported for air pollutants. The study concludes that decreasing current pollution levels

 even further, beyond current levels may be important for protecting long term public health.This research may be important to the Environment Agency in working with water companies and other interested parties in terms of best practice and technological investment

 for reducing a range of contaminants entering the environment and drinking water supplies.
Primary Article Title: Cumulative risk analysis of carcinogenic contaminants in United States drinking water
Author: Evans, S; et al
Keywords: "water quality" drinking water standards EU USA health illness cancer carcinogenic pollution "air pollution" lifetime chemical arsenic disinfection disinfectant radioactive contaminant regulation standards

Summary Sentence: Virtual reality (VR) technology has been shown to reduce chronic pain in patients.
Justification:
Applying VR technology to pain relief is an example of a ‘digital drug’ and could signify the potential to reduce the volume of chemical pain relief medicines entering the environment and impacting on water quality. In a recent study involved 120 hospitalised

 patients, all of whom rated their pain levels at the start of the experiment. Half of them were given VR experiences six times over two days. The VR patients reported an average decline in pain scores of up to 1.72 points, compared to the control group of

 only 0.46 points, across a range of pain including gastrointestinal, cancer, orthopedic and neurologic. People with the most severe pain saw the greatest difference through VR treatment. Patients wore a Samsung Gear Oculus VR headset and could choose different

 VR experiences, including guided relaxation, natural environments, simulated flights, and animated games. It is thought that VR experiences creates an illusion of time acceleration, effectively shortening the length of pain episodes, halting pain signals at

 their origin and blocking pain from reaching the brain. A reduction on the reliance of pain relief medicine could mean less prescriptions both in hospitals and home environments, reducing pharmaceutical pollutants from these sources.
Primary Article Title: Virtual reality experiences can help ease severe pain
Author: Rapaport, L
Secondary_URLs: Virtual reality for management of pain in hospitalized patients&%2358; a randomized comparative effectiveness trial - PLOS ONE 14/08/2019
Keywords: "water quality" regulation chemical pollution pollutant pharmaceutical drug medicine water pollution pain chronic "virtual reality" VR Samsung Oculus cancer gastrointestinal orthopedic neurologic health illness

Summary Sentence: Agricultural waste could offer an alternative to petroleum based surfactants.
Justification:
Surfactants are used in everyday products such as soap, glue, makeup and medicines to hold the water and oil components of the product together. Traditional surfactants are often chemicals derived from petroleum. Researchers attempting to reduce the use

 of synthetic chemicals in everyday products have discovered that rice straw which is a by-product of rice production could be used to create a bio-surfactant. The rice straw is brewed with enzymes to create a bio surfactant, which the academics believe could

 be a viable alternative. Surfactant production globally is a multi billion pound industry, so any changes to make the production more sustainable could have far reaching impacts. Research on other bio surfactants could open up new markets for using waste agricultural

 products, reducing their impact on the environment, making them more financially viable to produce and potentially creating products that may be more sustainable. However as with any new products, significant testing will be required to ensure there are no

 unintended consequences on the environment or human health.
Primary Article Title: Soap from straw
Keywords: water quality pollution sustainable waste agriculture biotechnology health research farming farm cleaning medicine pharma

Summary Sentence: Speeding up the innovation cycle may put more pressure on water quality
Justification:
Pharmaceutical residues in freshwaters are a growing concern for water quality and the impacts this pollution can have on humans and wildlife. Development of new drugs in the past has often taken multiple years, limiting the amount of drugs that are introduced

 to the market. However with the help of Artificial Intelligence (AI) a company has been able to narrow down what to test in the lab out of 30,000 options, and then identify the best candidate drug, all within 46 days. Although this was only a proof of concept

 study, the authors are showing what is feasible, and at a fraction of the normal development cost. Considerable development is still needed before this would ever be used, but it is an example of how AI is likely to disrupt current innovation cycles. Reducing

 the amount of time it takes to develop new drugs will create new regulatory challenges for the Environment Agency, with additional impacts likely on research and monitoring priorities.
Primary Article Title: How an AI startup designed a drug candidate in just 46 days
Secondary_URLs: Scientists discover new antibiotic in tropical forest - Science Direct 28/10/2019
Keywords: AI drugs pharmaceutical pollution water quality health technology biotech disease economics finance chemical waste

Summary Sentence: Recent research has highlighted the social and environmental impacts of the data and training behind artificial intelligence (AI).
Justification:
As the debate around the ethics of AI systems grows the Environment Agency may wish to consider their position on this issue from an environmental as well as ethical perspective. AI systems and machine learning rely on training systems based on large data

 sets. Some of the learning happens automatically, but there are also aspects of this that require human intervention to train the machine. Some of this work is fulfilled by microworkers - people who complete repetitive tasks that machines alone cannot do.

 Tasks can include drawing boxes around features in video footage of roads to teach driverless cars what a trees or other obstacles look like, or tagging content with feelings such as “sad” songs or “worrying” text. The work is not particularly well paid, but

 people freely partake it in. Amazon is thought to employ up to 2500 microworkers at a time through its ‘Mechanical Turk’ market place each month. Average microworker wage in Europe is around $3 - approximately £2.44. The current UK living wage is £9 per hour.

 The environmental cost of Al training has recently been calculated. It is believed that training a single AI can emit the same carbon footprint as five cars, including manufacture. The in research that look specifically at natural language processing (NLP)

 training such a system emitted more than 626,000 pounds of carbon dioxide equivalent. Training AI is computationally expensive and energy intensive. As AI grows in sophistication so will its resource footprint (assuming all other factors stay the same). The

 Environment Agency in its ambitions around corporate responsibility may need clarification on energy footprint and human workforce implications of any AI it employs to ensure ethics and procurement and to protect its reputation.
Primary Article Title: Training a single AI model can emit as much carbon as five cars in their lifetimes
Author: Hao, K
Secondary_URLs: The 'microworkers' making your digital life possible - BBC 02/08/2019
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" AI "machine learning" "natural language programming" NLP energy "carbon footprint" ethic workforce microworker "mechanical turk" wage pay social responsibility Amazon

Summary Sentence: Autonomous vehicles may become a feature of marine as well as terrestrial transport.
Justification:
This development could be of interest to the Environment Agency’s work, due to the potential to reduce greenhouse gas and other emissions from sea freight transport, which has been shown previously to impact negatively on air quality in coastal regions (%2313624).

 Human error is also a significant factor in maritime accidents&%2358; autonomous shipping could therefore reduce the potential for ocean pollution incidents. However there is also a possibility that an autonomous ship could become a target of cybercrime for piracy

 or to be used as a means to damage coastal settlements and defences. According to Allianz insurers between 75% and 96% of maritime accidents are caused by human error. Autonomous ships could help to reduce this number significantly through machine learning

 and data analysis, which could be used to inform and assist human crew to counteract factors such as fatigue and human error. Autonomous ships may also be able to reduce staff costs making shipping cheaper. Environmental savings could complement cost savings

 through fuel reductions - combined with workforce savings this could amount to over $7 million over 25 years per autonomous vessel (assuming this depends on vehicle size). There are several technical hurdles to overcome to ensure safety, meaning that fully

 autonomous ships may still become realised widely some time in the future. Some companies are building fully autonomous ships from scratch, while other start-ups are developing semi-autonomous systems to be used on existing vessels. There are already examples

 where fully autonomous ships have been trialled. The Norwegian Maritime Authority (NMA) recently tested the outcome of the ROMAS (Remote Operation of Machinery and Automation Systems) project. The aim was to move the engine control room (ECR) from the ship

 to a shore-based engine control centre (ECC), where personnel could operate a single ship, or a fleet of vessels, remotely. In a test a ferry was operated remotely on the 35-minute between Molde and Vestnes. Note that this is not strictly an autonomous operation.

 However an autonomous marine vessel recently carried an oyster shipment between the UK and Belgium. The USV Maxlimer, developed by SEA-KIT International Ltd made the 22-hour journey from Essex to Ostend. The vessel deployed GPS positioning and satellite communication

 to let operators know its position and avoid other vessels. The operating crew used Global Situational Awareness via Internet (G-SAVI) technology, which enabled them to remotely access a CCTV feed, thermal data and radar; as well as communicate with surrounding

 vessels. An inland electric container ship, Yara Birkeland, is curently under construction that is expected to be completed in 2020 and fully autonomous by 2022.
Primary Article Title: The incredible autonomous ships of the future&%2358; run by artificial intelligence rather than a crew
Author: Marr, B
Secondary_URLs:
Autonomous shipping&%2358; first autonomous vessel crosses North Sea - Government Europa 14/05/2019

Fjord crossing another landmark en route to autonomous shipping - Splash247.com 07/06/2019
Keywords: shipping transport water Belgium UK "USV Maxlimer" SEA-KIT autonomonous "artificial intelligence" AI freight cargo energy "Norwegian Maritime Authority" NMA  ROMAS "Remote Operation of Machinery and Automation Systems" efficiency maritime accident human workforce Allianz  "air quality" air pollution "greenhouse gas" GHG emission particulate health coast flood defence cybercrime incident "Yara Birkeland" 2020 2022

Summary Sentence: There is evidence that the fertiliser industry is starting to consider how ammonia could contribute to a future energy economy.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is already involved in regulating ammonia emissions from agricultural installations. These impacts could be potentially dwarfed by the realisation of an ammonia economy. European trade association Fertilizers Europe, which has UK trade

 association connections recently published a report examining the drivers shaping the fertiliser industry out to 2030. Of note in “Feeding Life 2030” is the assumed increased importance of ammonia in the energy mix. The report suggests that ten per cent of

 European ammonia could be produced from renewable electricity power electrolysis to generate the required hydrogen feedstock. This in itself would require green ammonia production to scale up capacity to more than a million tons per year, within ten years.

 The report also outlines a vision for the fertiliser industry using ammonia production as the key to creating a carbon-free energy storage medium. Echoing this ambition are two research projects in Australia and Denmark. The Australian project has developed

 a ‘reverse fuel cell’ that uses renewable energy, nitrogen gas and water to produce ammonia gas without the heat pressure and carbon emissions of conventional industrial production, aka Haber-Bosch process. The ammonia produced can then be piped to ammonia

 fuelled power stations, or be broken down again to extract hydrogen fuel. The Danish project, SOC4NH3 (Solid Oxide Cell based production and use of ammonia) is similar in its concept and aims, but will focus on using wind power, compared to the plentiful supply

 of renewable solar in Australia. Research has also emerged on the feasibility of China adopting large scale ammonia production as a means to transport energy from distant renewable sources in Western and Northern areas to large markets in the Centre and East.

 This suggests the technologies currently being developed may have demand markets opening up to them, both from industry and government. As a regulator the Environment Agency may need to consider the implications of an ammonia economy, which could range from

 production and emission regulations to concerns around leakage from old infrastructure, incident management considerations and wider environmental impacts.
Primary Article Title: Feeding Life 2030&%2358; the vision of Fertilizers Europe
Author: Brown, T
Secondary_URLs:
Ammonia-a renewable fuel made from sun, air, and water-could power the globe without carbon - Science 12/07/2018

Ammonia can become the CO2-free fuel of the future - Haldor Topsoe 21/02/2019

Ammonia as an environmentally benign energy carrier for the fast growth of China - Ammonia Energy 18/03/2019
Keywords: energy ammonia agriculture fertiliser chemical chemistry "Fertlizers Europe" "trade association" "Feeding Life 2030" 2030 energy storage reverse fuel cell Denmark Australia nitrogen hydrogen emission infrastructure catalyst SOC4NH3 "Solid Oxide Cell"  China transport renewable solar wind regulation

Summary Sentence: BSA survey highlights the long term cultural and social changes taking place in Britain
Justification:
British Social Attitudes (BSA) Survey 36 reveals the continuation of a number of long term cultural and social shifts taking place within Britain&%2358;  Secularisation&%2358; The percentage of the population that identify themselves as Christian has reduced from 66% in 1983, when the survey began, to 38% in 2018. At the same time the percentage of people identifying themselves as having no religion has increased

 from 31% in 1983 to 53% in 2018. This marks a long term decline in religious belief amongst the British public, one of the most cultural tends in British post-war history.   Trust in Science and Technology&%2358; The percentage of the population who agree with the statement “we believe too often in science, and not enough in feelings and faith” has decreased from 47% in 1993, when the question was first asked, to 27% in 2018. The

 percentage of the population who disagree with the statement has risen from 19% to 33% over the same period.  Attitudes to same sex relationships&%2358; The percentage of the population who think that same sex relationships are “not wrong at all” has increased from 18% in 1983 to 66% in 2018.   Views on Gender Roles&%2358; The percentage of the population who agree with the statement “a man’s job is to earn money; a woman’s job is to look after the home and family” has decreased from 43% in 1983 to 8% in 2018. Over the same period the percentage of people

 who disagreed with it rose from 38% to 72%.  These fundamental cultural shifts are important to the EA because they point to significant changes in the social operating environment the organisation sits within.
Primary Article Title: Survey data highlights long term cultural shifts taking place in Britain
Author: John Curtice, Elizabeth Clery, Jane Perry, Miranda Phillips and Nilufer Rahim
Keywords: Social trends; Cultural Trends; Great Britain; Religion; Gender; Sexuality; Science
GT: Social trends; Cultural Trends; Great Britain; Religion; Gender; Sexuality; Science

Summary Sentence: US Military reveals that they're recruiting ethicists and lawyers to oversee the development of AI and points to strategic political drivers
Justification:
The U.S Military has revealed some of the core rationales that it considers to underpin its Artificial Intelligence (A.I) strategy. It has also pointed to several key features of the political, social and economic landscape that may shape its development.

 In a press conference Lieutenant General Jack Shanahan (Director of the Department of Defense’s Joint A.I Centre) acknowledged the need to incorporate ethical concerns around the potential future uses of AI into both the initial project problem framing and

 longer term development processes. While making the point was made that the technology was still in its relative infancy he indicated that there was a longer term need to establish a wider set of international norms around its development and use internationally.

 To do that the General highlighted the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons in Geneva as a key forum for discussion. These concerns were framed in the context of wider geopolitical strategic competition between the US, Russia and China.     The event of the press conference itself reinforces this narrative by pointing to potentially important differences in the political environment of each of these countries that could lead to differences in AI’s development. Perhaps in contrast to other

 nations the U.S military have identified a need to garner and maintain public support for what they’re doing. It’s not clear whether comparable challenges are a feature of other socio-political niches. Understanding the dynamics and potential paths of A.I’s

 development in this way may help the EA to understand how the technology will impact its business in the future.
Primary Article Title: US Military signposts future contours of AI development
Author: Lt. Gen. Jack Shanahan
Keywords: Artificial Intelligence; Ethics; Politics

Summary Sentence: Newly published modelling and experimental data suggests that a silica aerogel could be used to terraform the Martian environment.
Justification:
Newly published modelling and experimental data suggests that a silica aerogel of the kind used on passively heated buildings on earth could be used to terraform the Martian environment. While terraforming solutions put forward previously have been shown

 to lack the ability to catalyse changes of sufficient magnitude to make the surface inhabitable, these preliminary investigations demonstrate that a silica aerogel may give rise to a solid state greenhouse effect of the kind identified on Earth. The properties

 of the gel could allow enough visible light to penetrate for photosynthesis to take place, block ultraviolet radiation and raise temperatures to above the melting point of water. While these ambitions are clearly long term they could sit within the time frames

 of some of the Environment Agency’s strategies and the social, economic and environmental consequences of inhabiting Mars could be transformative.
Primary Article Title: A new method for terraforming Mars
Author: R. Wordsworth, L. Kerber, and C. Cockell
Keywords: terraforming; Mars; silica aerogel

Summary Sentence: Modelling data that indicates the magnitude of likely energy demand may increase as a result of climate change
Justification:
Recently published computational modelling data indicates that climatic warming may lead to increases in global energy consumption. The model employs a top down approach that combines econometric estimates of per capita energy demand with projected changes

 in the number of hot (over 27.5 degrees) and cold (below 12.5 degrees) days. Under a vigorous warming scenario global climate dependent energy demand is shown to increase by 25 – 58% between now and, before adaptation, and by 11 – 27% under a moderate warming

 scenario. These increases are in addition to projected rises in demand as a result of socio-economic development over the same period, accounting for the effects of population and economic growth. Importantly changes in energy demand are shown to vary considerably

 across different global regions. The highest increases are projected to occur across the Americas, Africa, the Middle East and South and South Eastern Asia while areas of Europe, Russia and Canada are projected to experience reductions in energy demand. Consequently

 the data point to the potential for changing energy needs to fall unevenly across the global population, further entrenching existing inequalities. These findings should be of interest to the Environment Agency both in terms of there potential domestic and

 international implications. See also articles %2315015, %2313407, %2314448.
Primary Article Title: Amplification of future energy demand growth due to climate change
Author: Bas J. van Ruijven, Enrica De Cian & Ian Sue Wing
Keywords: climate change; energy demand

Summary Sentence: A newly emerging line of enquiry indicates that the vulnerability of populations to the impacts of climate change may be decreasing over time
Justification:
A recently published analysis of country level economic and mortality data suggests that the vulnerability of human populations to climate change impacts may be decreasing globally. The study published in global environmental change analyses the proportion

 of GDP exposed to climatic hazard events and the number of associated deaths in countries across the globe. Both are shown to have decreased substantially over time (by 5 and 6.5 times respectively) across all of the countries included, but the trend is much

 stronger amongst poorer less developed nations, which have adapted more quickly. The reduction is attributed to investment in protective measures against climate hazards both in terms of the response and recovery phases across all nation states. But despite

 the relative narrowing of levels of vulnerability between the richest and poorest nations the evidence indicates that a considerable absolute gap in vulnerability between the richest and poorest nations still remains. The implications of the data for the Environment

 Agency are that they lend support to claims that protective measures being taken are effective, but also that consideration may need to be given to the disproportionate effect of climate hazards in poorer nations.
Primary Article Title: Potential reductions in the vulnerability of global populations to the impacts of climate change
Author: Giuseppe Formetta, Luc Feyen
Keywords: climate change; vulnerability; GDP; mortality

Summary Sentence: New developments in satellite technology could provide new opportunities for cheaper environmental monitoring.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as an industrial regulator may need to consider how these opportunities could be used to enhance its own monitoring programmes. RocketLab is a company specialising in small satellite launches. It recently announced that it will provide

 a customisable service, from build through to launch, where customers can tailor satellite instrumentation to their specific needs, as opposed to utilising third party instrumentation and data which may not be the best fit to their specific need. Customers

 of Photon will have the chance to add their own instrumentation to a satellite’s payload. Photon has a much larger payload compared to Cubesat (%2314139) and also has thrusters for maneuverability. Another cheap access route to satellite launch could come from

 steam filled balloons. This development may challenge the notion of rocket based payload deployment and its associated environmental concerns, such as air pollution and carbon footprint(%2315054). Another company is about to apply knowledge gleaned from satellite

 data to monitor air pollution from every single power plant on Earth in real time. The non-profit company called WattTime, backed by Google, will be using a combination of satellite images from Landsat and other sources and artificial intelligence (AI). The

 data will come from a variety of sensors operating at different wavelengths, including thermal infrared that can detect heat. WattTime will output real time emissions data to the public, effectively exposing any poor on the ground monitoring or discrepancies

 between actual and reported emissions, eliminating a significant barrier to citizen action and providing independent third party data to check emissions data against - much air pollution data is suspected to go unreported. A similar open source project is

 to focus on global methane emissions producing open source data. This development could have a significant impact on holding environmental regulators and the energy sector to account, but could also provide a useful tool for collaborative regulation. Trust

 in third party information may also help the Environment Agency to free up our monitoring budget for other uses.
Primary Article Title: We'll soon know the exact air pollution from every power plant in the world. That's huge.
Author: Roberts, D
Secondary_URLs:
Rocket Lab is now building customizable satellites - The Verge 26/09/2019

Enviros issue contract to build methane-detecing satellite - Houston Chronicle 08/04/2019

Steam balloons could be used to launch satellites - SciTech Europa 22/08/2019
Keywords: environmental monitoring data satellite "climate change" "greenhouse gas" GHG methane regulation Google WattTime public "open data" "Rocket Lab" Photon Cubesat MethaneSAT "Environmental Defense Fund" LandSat information trust emission air pollution citizen science

Summary Sentence: Employees could become empowered to have more say over their pay and leave entitlements.
Justification:
Any changes to accepted norms of the relationship between workforce and companies could impact on the Environment Agency’s position as an attractive employer. Two instances highlight companies experimenting with employees setting their own salaries. The

 exact process varies between companies, but it is currently being embraced by the technology sector. Some processes involve consulting with colleagues before putting in a request. Companies who have pursued this include Smarkets and Corporate Rebels.The thought

 behind this initiative is that it attracts the best talent and increases staff retention. It also relies on and encourages greater transparency between colleagues and the business itself. Another trend growing amongst tech companies is unlimited leave, including

 Evernote, Netflix and UK based consultancy Inbucon. Despite concerns that people would abuse the privilege, it was found that people didn’t take significantly greater time off than previous. Trust was cited as being hugely important in implementing this policy,

 and may not suit larger companies. One potential consequence of these schemes reaching wider acceptance. is that even if the intentions are good it may lead to people taking lower salaries or less leave for fear of appearing uncompetitive next to their colleagues.

 In this respect an organisation that offers fixed but guaranteed leave entitlements and pay structures as the Environment Agency does may appear a more attractive employer to uncertainty. Alternatively the greater flexibility and openness may appeal to a younger

 demographic, which means less flexible employers struggle to attract new talent.
Primary Article Title: `My boss lets me set my own salary'
Author: Hannah, F
Secondary_URLs:
Here's how we let employees set their own salary - Corporate Rebels 24/07/2019

An innovative HR policy to attract staff - unlimited vacation! - Destination Innovation 26/09/2019
Keywords: workforce pay job salary leave trust employer employee "Corporate Rebels" Evernote Inbucon Netflix Smarkets

Summary Sentence: A technology company has announced it has started working on ‘6G’mobile phone network.
Justification:
Fifth generation (5G) is a ‘top technology’ for Defra and the Environment Agency, so developments indicating the future trajectory of this technology should be of interest. There are also some indications of concern for wildlife from the electromagnetic

 radiation that 5G mobile networks may produce (%2314781). A recent news article indicates that Korean electronics company Samsung has opened a 6G research centre, called the Advanced Communications Research Center in Seoul. Details are thin on the ground as

 to what 6G technology will actually mean, but it may be worth considering the longer term implications of investment in 5G technology, which has yet to reach a substantial level of roll out, if 6G technology is waiting in the wings.
Primary Article Title: Samsung starts 6G network research at new center
Author: Su-hyun, S
Keywords: communication mobile network 5G 6G Samsung "Advanced Communications Research Center" Seoul wildlife regulation

Summary Sentence: The Fourth Industrial Revolution has scarcely begun, but already there is speculation on the shape of the Fifth Industrial Revolution.
Justification:
The Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) was first outlined in 2015. It is characterised by technologies that combine hardware, software, and biology, with an emphasis on communication and connectivity. Technologies such as robotics, artificial intelligence,

 nanotechnology, quantum computing, biotechnology, the internet of things (IOT), decentralisation and 3D printing exemplify these developments. One theme perceived to run through this and previous industrial revolutions is a dehumanisation of economic progress

 and an increase in existential threat to both humans and the environment. The technologies of 4IR could exacerbate this trend by eclipsing human performance and capability while failing to tackle issues such as pollution and population increase. The Fifth

 Industrial Revolution (5IR) will see these same technologies ‘bent back’ in the service of humans, contributing to the greater good of environmental outcomes and human wellbeing. 5IR will ask of people how they can make the World ‘better’, rather than ‘more

 efficient’ or ‘more productive’. Companies will seek ‘profit with purpose’, responding to consumer demand for more ethical and environmentally friendly goods and services. AI and robotics will work to enhance an increasingly democratised return on investment

 (ROI), and help to meet sustainable development goals such as closing the gender pay gap. Work will become more flexible, fitting around people’s lives rather than vice versa.New roles could emerge, such as a chief ethical and humane use officer. 5IR could

 mean new economic systems dubbed by one writer as ‘automated luxury communism’ where technology has eliminated jobs, but still provides people’s needs such as food and energy, allowing people to enjoy better lives. Another view of 5ID sees it in the context

 of previous industrial revolutions&%2358; 1IR - mechanical; 2IR - electrical; 3IR - digital; 4IR - virtual (autonomous vehicles, 3D printing etc have at their hearts virtual representations of the real world) to 5IR - neural as the fruits of 4IR enable greater seamlessness

 and potential for creativity between the digital world and the human brain. Recent news emerging of Facebook's purchase of a company called CTRL-labs that specialises in devices that convert electrical impulses from the human body into movements onscreen exemplifies

 the trajectory that neural technology may take. New economic models, repurposing of technology and social priorities could all bring changes and responsibilities to regulators including the Environment Agency in terms of activities and workforce practices.
Primary Article Title: What the Fifth Industrial Revolution is and why it matters
Secondary_URLs:
Facebook acquires neural monitoring startup CTRL-labs - Engadget 23/09/2019

The World is a mess. We need fully automated luxury communism. - The New York Times 11/06/2019

What might the 5th industrial revolution look like? What would it most likely be based on? - Quora 09/08/2017

What is the fifth industrial revolution and how will it change the world? - Metro 10/06/2019

Technological revolution - Wikipedia 26/09/2019
Keywords: "Fifth Industrial Revolution" "Fourth Industrial Revolution" 5ID 4ID technology automation "3D printing" " internet of things" IOT robotics "artificial intelligence" biotechnology communication connectivity workforce jobs "automated luxury communism" values society sustainability regulation virtual neural digital Facebook CTRL-labs

Summary Sentence: Levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the home could already pose a threat to human health
Justification:
A review of research on the impacts of carbon dioxide exposure on human health indicate that levels as low as 1000 ppm which are already exceeded in many indoor environments could cause damage. It is thought environmentally relevant exposure could impact

 on cognitive performance and productivity. Higher levels have been linked to inflammation in animals and may cause damage to kidney function and bone demineralisation. The review highlights the need for more research on chronic and intermittent effects of

 exposure, and how these could affect vulnerable populations such as children, the elderly and those in poor health. As a responsible employer, the Environment Agency may need to mitigate the impacts of poor office air quality in the future if it is found to

 pose a significant danger to human health. This add to the growing body of evidence highlighting the need to better understand the impacts of indoor air pollution.
Primary Article Title: Indoor carbon dioxide levels could be a health hazard, scientists warn
Secondary_URLs: Direct human health risks of increased atmospheric carbon dioxide. - Nature 01/08/2019
Keywords: human health regulation pollution waste emission emit HSW

Summary Sentence: The plant gene that controls the symbiotic relationship between plants and soil fungi has been successfully replicated.
Justification:
Plant fungi relationships facilitate stronger plant growth, as the fungi improves nitrogen and nutrient uptake in the plant. If this relationship can be introduced to food crops that don’t normally interact with fungi, it could improve yields without the

 need for the use of additional resources such as fertilizer. On a similar note other research aims to understand how soybean nodules work to fix nitrogen. The hope is that this knowledge could then be used to develop new breeds that can fix even more nitrogen,

 thereby reducing the need for fertilizer. Ongoing research such as this could help to develop techniques that could change crop production, lowering the impact of agriculture on the environment.
Primary Article Title: Scientists make fundamental discovery to creating better crops
Secondary_URLs: Purdue scientists show how soybeans may get more nitrogen from atmosphere - Purdue University 25/07/2019
Keywords: agriculture food security GM genetic modification botany fungus biotech bioengineering water quality farm

Summary Sentence: The city state of Singapore has revealed ambitious targets for self sufficient food production.
Justification:
Singapore currently produces 10 per cent of its own food, but intends to address concerns around population growth and climate change by raising this to 30 per cent by 2030 - known as the ‘30-by-30’ plan. Only one per cent of Singapore is agricultural land,

 so the state is looking to innovation food production technologies to achieve its goals, including indoor vertical farming (%2312717) and lab grown meat(%2311821) - the latter of which, backed by the owners of UK firm Quorn, hopes to be able to address the whole

 of Singapore’s shrimp demand by 2030. In America one start up has similar ambitions for hyperlocal food production with a subscription hydroponics kit that customers to grow ten per cent of their food needs. It is not the technologies being employed that are

 particularly novel here, but the political ambition behind them. The costs and failure rate of technologies and companies in this area could present challenges in meeting the ‘30-by-30’ target. However, the success of these and similar models could pave the

 way for other cities to follow suit, presenting changes to regulatory pressures in terms of sectors and locations for environmental regulators.
Primary Article Title: From sky farms to lab-grown shrimp, Singapore eyes food future
Author: Geddie, J & Edgar Su, E
Secondary_URLs: Zooey Deschanel's subscription hydroponic service wants you to grow 20% of your food - Modern Farmer 22/05/2019
Keywords: farming food regulation "climate change" urban urbanisation "vertical farming" hydroponic "30-by-30" Singapore population "Zooey Deschanel" "Lettuce Grow" cities 2030 indoor farming lab grown meat shrimp Quorn government

Summary Sentence: Industrial activity of the future may not take place on Earth, but in space.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is already involved in the regulatory implications of a UK space industry, and so should therefore be interested the regulatory implications of the sector’s possible future trajectory. A space probe that recently crash landed on the

 moon containing animal and plant life could be seen as introducing invasive species in a different future context (though this may also prove a valuable ark of species and DNA in the future). An astronaut has also been accused of the first ‘space crime’, allegedly

 hacking into their estranged spouse’s finances whilst on a mission. And the first commercial space terminal on Earth has just opened. These events could represent signals that there could be an increasing need for regulation of space as well as Earth. Considering

 the environmental damage that industry creates there are lots of potential environmental gains from removing industry entirely from the confines of the Earth. There is already private investment going into asteroid mining (%2313368), which could exploit up to

 $8 billion of minerals within ‘easy’ reach. The concept of ‘in-situ utilisation’ would involve extracting, processing and manufacturing products off-planet resources in space, which could have big advantages in terms of reducing payloads and on-planet pollution.

 Technologies such as additive manufacturing using multiple materials could be used, and take advantage of zero gravity conditions, which could, for example, assist with 3D printing body parts (though this need may already have been surpassed by terrestrial

 technology). Space may also be utilised for renewable energy generation in the form of uninterrupted solar power - without a significant breakthrough in semiconductor technology such as quantum computing the Earth could run out of energy to power the World’s

 computers by 2040. Other energy sources in space include ice, which could be separated into hydrogen and water using lasers, providing the building blocks for propulsion fuels for autonomous craft. The costs of launching objects into space using rockets may

 be about to be challenged through the development of a kinetic energy-based launch system that accelerates the launch vehicle to hypersonic speeds using ground-based energy. The company developing this systems is called Spinlaunch. They claim to provide a

 substantially lower launch to orbit cost that can be deployed multiple times per day, without negative environmental impacts. With so much potential for economic and resource gain from space exploitation there may also be environmental considerations for the

 longer term protection of both the Earth and space, such as around waste and emissions. Such internationally agreed regulations are currently absent, particularly for non-governmental agents, presenting a familiar situation where technology and the private

 sector are ‘ahead of the game’ compared to governance and regulation.
Primary Article Title: Made in space&%2358; why Earth's industries might one day leave our planet
Author: Farah, T
Secondary_URLs:
Is it already time to have laws for outer space? - Interesting Engineering 20/07/2019

Why your new heart could be made in space one day - BBC 22/01/2019

SpinLaunch secures first contract for revolutionary new space launch services - Business Wire 19/06/2019

Virgin Galactic opens the doors to the `gateway to space' - Virgin 15/08/2019

NASA astronaut Anne McClain accused by spouse of crime in space - The New York Times 23/08/2019

Crashed Israeli lunar lander left a bunch of microscopic `water bears' on the Moon - BGR 06/08/2019

Israeli scientists print World's first 3-D heart - Haaretz.com 15/04/2019
