Summary Sentence: The National Infrastructure Commission has advocated that Central Government develop the charging infrastructure for electric vehicles in a clear step towards enabling the transition away from fossil fuel based vehicles
Justification:
The need to decarbonise the UKs transport networks is now well established and a key route achieving this is likely to be through the transition from combustion engines to electric vehicles. While the pathway of technological innovation around the cars themselves

 is well developed its clear that less progress has been made towards establishing the UK’s network of electrical charging stations that will be needed to keep them going. It is in this context that the National Infrastructure Commission’s (NIC’s) adoption

 of a policy position that advocates the development of the required charging infrastructure to Government by 2030 is a notable step forward. While it isn’t in and of itself any guarantee that the required programming and funding will be forthcoming, the NIC

 are a key stakeholder and do exert some influence. Their positioning then is a key signal of the trajectory of and momentum within electric vehicle technology and its overall direction of travel.
Primary Article Title: NIC advocate development of charging infrastructure for electric vehicles
Author: National Infrastructure Commission
Keywords: Electric Vehicles; Infrastructure; Policy

Summary Sentence: Recently published evidence adds weight to estimates of the timelines of the development of AI and suggests Higher Learning Machine Intelligence could be achieved in around 50 years.
Justification:
The development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is projected to cause substantial alterations to the global jobs market and economy. As the ability of machines to carry out the tasks of human workers develops and they become able to work more effectively

 and more efficiently than their human counterparts, there is concern that they will begin to supersede people in the work place. For this reason, among others, researchers have over the past few years been attempting to understand the rate at which AI might

 develop, and in particular the point at which it’ll have the ability to surpass the performance of human workers (the point of Higher Learning Machine Intelligence - HLMI). Using survey based methodologies, investigators have focused on drawing together the

 insights of key experts in relevant fields, as well as other well positioned figures, to develop credible estimates of the arrival of HLMI. While there is considerable uncertainty connected with the data, and the conclusions drawn from it should be interpreted

 with caution, these estimates do represent the best available understanding of when these changes might start to take place. Three of the 4 projections included provide substantially similar timelines, which suggest that there is more than a 90% confidence

 level that there is a 50% chance or more of HLMI emerging around 50 years from now, or about 2075. The fourth projection is more conservative in its estimate and indicates that the point at which there is a greater than 50% chance of HLMI arriving will be

 around the year 2100, or shortly afterwards. However, what’s clear is that the development of AI over the intervening period is also expected to begin having significant impacts on the workplace well in advance of these dates, pointing to a need for the EA

 and other employers to take the development of AI seriously in the short term.
Primary Article Title: Forecasting transformative AI&%2358; an expert survey
Author: Ross Gruetzemacher, David Paradice, Kang Bok Lee
Secondary_URLs:
Viewpoint&%2358; When Will AI Exceed Human Performance? Evidence from AI Experts - Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research 31/07/2018

Future Progress in Artificial Intelligence&%2358; A Survey of Expert Opinion - Fundamental Issues of Artificial Intelligence 08/06/2016

Expert and Non-Expert Opinion about Technological Unemployment - University of New South Wales 13/06/2018
Keywords: AI, Artificial Intelligence, Projection, Superintelligence

Summary Sentence: The Dutch Government has developed a novel policy approach to aquatic pharmaceutical pollution that conceptualises the issue systemically
Justification:
A growing body of Biological and Environmental evidence has demonstrated that pharmaceutical compounds are accumulating in the aquatic environment, and that their presence there poses both a risk to human health, through the contamination of drinking water

 supplies, and to the wider ecosystems that the habitat supports. In response the Government of the Netherlands has developed a novel policy approach that sets itself apart from other approaches by conceptualising the issue systemically. It aims to intervene

 at multiple points in the pharmaceutical lifecycle – the ‘chain’ - by identifying points of action across all of the elements of production and consumption, from development and manufacturing to prescription and use, and during the waste water treatment phase.

 Consequently the policy approach has the potential to deliver a coordinated response to the problem, overcoming problems of technological ‘lock in’ that have restrict more sectoral approaches. It’s particularly relevant to us in the EA because of the closely

 cooperative relationship between UK and Dutch policymakers, which has in the past resulted in policy approaches originating in the Netherlands being adopted here.
Primary Article Title: A novel policy approach to aquatic pharmaceutical pollution
Author: Government of the Netherlands
Keywords: Pharmaceutical Pollution; Policy; Systemic

Summary Sentence: Non-native plants may outperform native plants due to climate change.
Justification:
This should interest the Environment Agency’s work with invasive non-native species and may also be considered in terms of natural capital and habitat creation and restoration. A US study looking at how warming temperatures affect native and non-native

 plant species in terms of flowering. Flowering timing is important to plant survival as it determines whether a plant will be pollinated by bees and other insects, and if it will be able to produce seed. When simulating warming conditions on groups of native

 and non-native potted plants researchers observed that non-native species flowered more than 11 days earlier on average. In contrast the flowering times of non-native plants did not change. The earlier flowering species were also found to have a greater geographical

 spread, suggesting that earlier flowering enables this. The study was focussed on the USA, and therefore may not directly apply to other areas of the World. However it does suggest that warming temperatures may be to the advantage of invasive plants, and to

 the detriment of native plants, which over time could significantly alter the biodiversity of what is currently considered ‘natural’ habitat, bringing greater problems associated with invasive plants, e.g. japanese knotweed.
Primary Article Title: Native plant species may be at greater risk from climate change than non-natives
Secondary_URLs: Phenology in a warming world&%2358; differences between native and non-native plant species - Ecology Letters 28/05/2019
Keywords: "climate change" biodiversity USA plant flowering temperature invasive non-native species native geography range pollination seed reproduction insect bee "natural capital" "japanese knotweed" regulation
GT: climate change, biodiversity, invasive, non-native species

Summary Sentence: New research suggests that undersea methane hydrate deposits could be a valid storage medium for carbon dioxide.
Justification:
Methane hydrate, also known as fire ice is formed in the deep ocean floor when rotting organic matter releases methane. The high pressure and cold temperature of sea water causes the ice-like solid methane hydrate to form. There are thought to be vast deposits

 of methane hydrate on the ocean floor with the potential to be a significant source of fossil fuel natural gas. In recent times the promise of cheap and plentiful fuel has led to some countries including Japan, China and India (%2314323) developing the technology

 to exploit these deposits. It’s also thought that some hydrate deposits may be found in UK waters (%2314300). There are also concerns that exploiting methane hydrate could lead to significant greenhouse gas releases which would contribute to climate change.

 New research has modelled the feasibility of using undersea hydrate as a storage medium for carbon dioxide. Computer modelling demonstrated that when air and carbon dioxide are injected into methane hydrate, the nitrogen in the air sweeps the methane towards

 an extraction point, allowing CO2 to replace it, effectively address carbon capture and storage concerns (though it isn’t clear if there is a like-for-like replacement). Proof that methane replacement is possible could mean that climate change concerns around

 hydrate exploitation are addressed. However methane is a more potent greenhouse gas than CO2. While this particular method may be touted as ‘green’ there could be wider concerns from a realised hydrate industry around the impacts of methane leakage and potential

 disturbance of ocean habitats. The Environment Agency may need to have an awareness of this development in terms of its regulatory position on CCS technologies and the wider potential global impacts on energy and climate change.
Primary Article Title: UT study shows how to produce natural gas while storing carbon dioxide
Secondary_URLs: Nitrogen-driven chromatographic separation during gas injection into hydrate-bearing sediments - Water Resources Research 27/06/2019
Keywords: energy "climate change" "methane hydrate" "carbon dioxide" "greenhouse gas" "carbon capture and storage" CCS deep sea ocean marine Japan China Canada UK nitrogen air model computer regulation air pollution leakage

Summary Sentence: The neonicotinoid thiacloprid was shown to have negative effects on a fresh water indicator species.
Justification:
There is limited research on the impacts of neonicotinoids on dragonflies and damselflies. This research exposed freshwater insects to environmentally relevant levels of thiacloprid. Although there was no observed increase in mortality, all sub lethal levels

 monitored were impacted negatively. The study also suggests that laboratory based studies are underestimating the impacts of neonicotinoids as they are not considering the biotic pressures such as predation, which add to the burden on the target species. Other

 studies provide evidence to suggest that neonicotinoid impacts can be altered by the presence of other agricultural pressures, nutrients and sediments. However there is very limited evidence on the effects of these combinations of stressors. As research emerges

 on how such chemicals adversely influence freshwater species, the Environment Agency will likely be required to work with partners to try and reduce levels in water courses.
Primary Article Title: Environmental levels of neonicotinoids reduce prey consumption, mobility and emergence of the damselfly Ischnura elegans
Secondary_URLs: Nutrients and sediment modify the impacts of a neonicotinoid insecticide on freshwater community structure and ecosystem functioning - Science of the Total Environment 11/07/2019
Keywords: sediment pollution neonic chemical combination water quality waste pesticide herbicide insect freshwater contamination bee health

Summary Sentence:
Recent advances in research point towards a future where computers are based on biological based components, which could the demand and supply of current materials used in electronics, and open up the possibility closer connections between the digital

 and physical world through more natural human computer interfaces.
Justification:
These developments could in turn have implications for how electronic waste is produced and disposed, and therefore has implications for the Environment Agency’s waste management activities. Researchers in Switzerland have used CRISPR gene editing technology

 to edit protein genes. The resulting gene represents a flexible core processor, or central processing unit (CPU), that accepts different kinds of programming, and receives inputs as RNA molecules called guide RNA. In responding to the guide RNA sequences the

 CPU regulates the expression of a particular gene, which in turn makes a particular protein. Using this approach it is possible to program scalable circuits in human cells. Such ‘computational organs’ could theoretically attain computing power that far outstrips

 that of a digital supercomputer, using a fraction of the energy. It could also lead to cells that emit warning, or ‘build’ substances in response to the presence of certain markers. Another group of scientists in Italy have managed to significantly increase

 the conductivity of melanin. The billion fold increase was achieved through heating eumelanin in a vacuum. Melanin’s biocompatibility could mean that it may be much easier to create implanted electronic devices. Another exploration of biocompatibility centres

 around experimenting with quantum materials as potential brain/computer interfaces. Quantum materials have electronic properties that classical physics can’t explain, unlike other materials used in electronics, such as silicon. Whereas electronic circuits

 function through the movement of electrons, brains work through the movement of ions. The behaviour of the quantum material (made of perovskite nickelate) placed beneath a brain’s surface suggested that it could provide a potential bridge between ion and electron

 movement. The quantum material is also sensitive detecting brain chemistry levels, and could therefore provide an early sign of decreasing dopamine levels, for example which could suggest the onset of Parkinson’s disease. Biological memory loss could be supplemented

 with digital memory support through the interface, but further development is needed to allow the brain and quantum material to be able to ‘talk’ to each other. These developments have similarities with using DNA for data storage (%2314730).
Primary Article Title: Will cyborg circuits be made from melanin?
Secondary_URLs:
A CRISPR/Cas9-based central processing unit to program complex logic computation in human cells - Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 09/04/2019

New quantum material could warn of neurological disease - Purdue University 10/04/2019

Perovskite nickelates as bio-electronic interfaces - Nature 30/07/2019

A biosynthetic dual-core cell computer - ETH Zurich 16/04/2019

Evidence of unprecedented high electronic conductivity in mammalian pigment based eumelanin thin films after thermal annealing in vacuum - Frontiers In Chemistry 26/03/2019
Keywords: waste management disposal electronic waste WEEE circuit silicon metal biology biocompatability DNA data  "central processing unit" CPU RNA gene expression protein CRISPR "computational organ" melanin eumelanin quantum material perovskite nickelate bio-electronic interface IT data digital health disease brain Parkinson's monitoring electron ion dopamine regulation manufacturing  workforce employee employer health safety wellbeing

Summary Sentence: Commons environmental audit committee (EAC) raises concerns about the level and combinations of chemicals that the UK population are exposed to in new report.
Justification:
The human and environmental implications of exposure to chemical combinations have been of concern for a number of years. This report from EAC highlights that the topic could be rising up the political agenda in the UK. Flame retardant chemicals were of

 particular concern (HSDBi 15010, 13926, 12783), as UK mothers’ breast milk contain some of the highest concentrations of the substances in the world. The report makes a recommendation that bio monitoring of certain substances should occur, so that base levels

 and exposures can be assessed. This may be something the Environment Agency will be required to lead on in the future.
Primary Article Title: Britons being exposed to toxic chemicals from birth, MPs say
Secondary_URLs: Toxic chemicals in everyday life - Parliament 16/07/2019
Keywords: waste management landfill WEEE "Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment" "brominated flame retardants" BFRs hormone "endocrine disrupting chemical" EDC sofa "soft furnishings" curtain cushion leaching groundwater "water quality" "water resources" pollution pollutant incident regulation permitting

Summary Sentence: Facebook's endorsement of distributed digital currency could increase consumer confidence and uptake.
Justification:
Libra is a cryptocurrency based on blockchain technology, like the more well known Bitcoin currency. Facebook's endorsement of Libra will help legitimize the idea of digital currency and build confidence in distributed trust technologies. Many governments

 are uncomfortable with the idea of this new currency, as they fear the impact it may have on traditional government backed currencies, the potential for disruption and the power it may give corporations such as Facebook over global financial systems. The US

 government have even asked Facebook to delay the launch of the currency until they have had chance to investigate it further. This latest cryptocurrency has a number of well known partners (Uber, Ebay, Paypal, Spotify, Visa, and Mastercard), further increasing

 the legitimacy of the product. Facebook has 2.4 billion users worldwide, so if this currency caught on, it could have significant global impacts. It has the potential to help facilitate the development of a decentralised internet (HSDBi 15078), that offers

 users more control of their own data. This would disrupt many business models which rely on this data to create their profits. As users become more familiar with the technology, they may prefer it to traditional banking for its ease and convenience and expect

 government organisations to accept it as a payment method. Regulating for this type of payment will be challenging. Governments are concerned with the potential for illegal use due to the anonymity of transactions. Social media is already widely used to buy

 illegal substances, if you then combine easy anonymous payments, it makes the whole process much easier and appealing to those that are worried about getting caught. This is something that has the potential to be transferrable to the waste crime sector, as

 they could make use of both systems to stay under the radar.
Primary Article Title: Why governments around the world are afraid of Libra, Facebook's cryptocurrency
Secondary_URLs:
How good are social media apps for buying drugs? - Vice News 19/12/2018

Is Facebook today's Compuserve? How Libra could hasten its demise - The Conversation 24/06/2019

Households urged to play their part in tackling waste crime - GOV.UK 03/07/2018
Keywords: internet "world wide web" decentralisation decentralised blockchain government regulation Amazon Alexa data companies corporation privacy Facebook Google Amazon Microsoft trust government marketing WhatsApp "Internet 3.0" currency money

Summary Sentence: A new book builds on the moral case that animals should not be treated differently from humans
Justification:
While the animal rights movement has made the case for some considerable time that animals should be treated in ways that place importance on their own needs and experiences, there has been little consensus in moral philosophy over the obligation that humans

 owe to animals and how that should shape how we relate to them in practice. A new set of arguments moves this discussion on by making the case that humans and animals share common characteristics that need to be accounted for in the way they are treated. In

 doing so they strengthen the moral case that animals need to be treated as inherently valuable. These arguments, as the author makes clear, have implications for conservation science by potentially altering the basis on which we seek support other species,

 as well as the methods we employ to do it. The publication is made more significant because it sits in parallel with ongoing work in other sciences that demonstrate that animals have the capacity to think, feel and suffer to a much greater capacity than had

 been previously assumed. Together these moral and scientific developments point to a trajectory that could signal a future change in the way we understand animals and how we morally justify our behavior towards them.
Primary Article Title: Book presents the case that animals are just as important as people
Author: Manisha Aggarwal-Schifellite,
Keywords: Animal Rights; Moral Philosophy; Conservation Science
GT: Animal Rights; Moral Philosophy; Conservation Science

Summary Sentence: An innovative new compact form of low voltage memory could have significant consequences for the energy consumption of future computers and the space they need
Justification:
Current forms of computer memory can require substantial amounts of energy, have limited endurance, or take up significant amounts of space in a device. Work to develop new emerging memories has been ongoing for some time and the results of a recently published

 project demonstrate the development of a new type of memory that is both compact and consumes relatively little energy. The implications of the work could be to enable future devices that store and retain much larger amounts of information while taking up

 a fraction of the space. In the context of the growing energy demand associated with data centres the innovation is a step towards significant reductions in energy demand, but could also have implications for the form and function of computing technologies

 in the future. The implications for the Environment Agency lie in both potentially being able to harness those technologies and in the transition towards a lower energy more sustainable form of computing.
Primary Article Title: A new form of computer memory that could have implications for the form and energy demands of future devices
Author: Ofogh Tizno, Andrew R. J. Marshall, Natalia Fernández-Delgado, Miriam Herrera, Sergio I. Molina & Manus Hayne
Keywords: Computer memory, energy demand, mobile computing
GT: Computer memory, energy demand, mobile computing

Summary Sentence: Evidence of a newly emerging consensus among experts that climatic changes are causing armed conflict and may be displacing populations
Justification:
Newly published evidence indicates that experts in the area of climate change and security from a wide range of disciplines agree that climate change has affected levels of organised armed conflict within countries. If sustained this newly emerging consensus

 could have strategic and operational implications for the Environment Agency. While debates about the links between climate change and conflict stretch back nearly two decades there has historically been very little agreement about the relationship between

 the two. Using a novel methodology that systematically characterises expert judgments not only about well-quantified risks, but also more uncertain outcomes that they may carry; thoroughly explores how these judgments are underpinned by present-day knowledge,

 and; rigorously combines individual and collective deliberations to minimize biases, the study is able to synthesis evidence of new agreement not documented before. Accordingly claims that there is a link between climate change and armed conflict can now be

 put on a firmer footing, although the authors still point out its relative contribution is likely to be small compared to other contributors. Connectedly new evidence has been published pointing to a possible link between climate change and asylum seeking,

 principally caused by the displacement of populations through increasing episodes of drought. While much work remains to be done in this subject area, collectively the works point to a growing understanding of the potentially negative social consequences of

 climate impacts.
Primary Article Title: Climate as a risk factor for armed conflict
Author: Katharine J. Mach, Caroline M. Kraan, W. Neil Adger, Halvard Buhaug, Marshall Burke, James D. Fearon, Christopher B. Field, Cullen S. Hendrix, Jean-Francois Maystadt, John O’Loughlin, Philip Roessler, Jürgen Scheffran, Kenneth A. Schultz & Nina von Uexkul
Secondary_URLs:
New consensus around the link between climate change, conflict and migration - Global Environmental Change 31/01/2019

The risk of conflict rises as the world heats up - Scientific American 22/07/2019
Keywords: Climate change, conflict, migration

Summary Sentence: The West may be waking up to the potential of wood vinegar as an agricultural ‘catch all’ agricultural chemical.
Justification:
Wood vinegar is scientifically known as pyroligneous acid. It is manufactured through destructive distillation of wood, which produces the acid liquor which is in fact a mixture of many chemicals, but the compounds include acetic acid, acetone and methanol.Wood

 vinegar has a long history in the Far East, but the West has only recently been exposed to its supposed benefits. Wood vinegar in farming terms is marketed as a fossil fuel free fertiliser and pesticide, and also as a dietary supplement for livestock. Scientific

 research has also revealed that it has antimicrobial and antifungal properties. Wood vinegar production compliments other activities such as renewable diesel fuel (RDF) and other biofuel based production from wood, though the miscanthus plant may also show

 potential. With some scientific evidence of its properties and the renewable nature of its production compared to conventional agricultural chemicals wood vinegar could have great potential as an environmentally friendly alternative to current fertilisers

 and pesticides, though its production may be limited by market size of other biofuel initiatives. The Environment Agency may wish to consider the environmental impacts of the farming sector moving from one chemical regime to another, particularly in terms

 of water quality. There may also be implications for waste management from a growth in wood vinegar production.
Primary Article Title: Miscanthus - renewable diesel, the wood vinegar
Secondary_URLs:
Growth inhibition effect of pyroligneous acid on pathogenic fungus,Alternaria mali, the agent of Alternaria blotch of apple - Biotechnology And Bioprocess Engineering 01/06/2007

In vitro evaluation of antimicrobial efficacy of pyroligneous acid from softwood mixture - Biotechnology Research & Innovation 01/01/2019

Physicochemistry and utilization of wood vinegar from carbonization of tropical biomass waste - Tropical Forests 20/04/2018
Keywords: agriculture farming "wood vinegar" "pyroligneous acid" "antimicrobial resistance" AMR antifungal resistance energy "fossil fuel" Asia miscanthus biofuel RDF "renewable diesel fuel" pesticide fertiliser livestock feed "water quality" chemical chemistry distillation regulation

Summary Sentence: Should organisations with sedentary works have a duty of care to encourage physical activity?
Justification:
A recent report from the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) suggests that as employees spend a large part of their waking day at work, that employers have a role to play in encouraging physical activity to improve health and wellbeing. The report

 suggests there are no simple answers on how to increase physical activity. It recommends that there needs to be multiple programmes which are tailored to the individual with flexibility to work with current home and working lifestyles. The Environment Agency

 have many staff groups run by volunteers that encourage activity to improve health and wellbeing. As the benefits to health and wellbeing can result in greater productivity, should there be more investment from the business to encourage this beneficial behaviour?
Primary Article Title: Physical activity interventions need to be tailored to individual needs, report says
Secondary_URLs: Moving matters - National Institutes for Health 17/07/2019
Keywords: health wellbeing productivity workforce planning

Summary Sentence: The medicinal properties of cannabis continue to be discovered.
Justification:
The latest breakthrough in cannabidiol research suggests that the substance offers potential as an antibacterial agent. It was shown to be effective at killing bacteria resistant to some common antibiotics, and didn’t lose its effectiveness over time.

 This is likely to add to the growing research and investment into cannabis based products, which are already being developed to treat anxiety, epilepsy and inflammation. As there is already a highly lucrative industry in the US, it may be prudent for the Environment

 Agency to engage early with industry to try and reduce some of the larger environmental challenges associated with growing the crop in this country.
Primary Article Title: Compound found in cannabis shows promise as a powerful antibiotic
Keywords: cannabis tobacco Marlboro Imperial Coca-Cola farming agriculture crops energy "internet of things" IOT "energy efficiency" "recreational cannabis" "medicinal cannabis" "water quality" workforce "living standard" income government pacification food drink additive "Red Bull" "Pro Plus" "human optimisation" sport work leisure wildlife biodiversity utility "water company" investment "water treatment"

Summary Sentence: Water resource scarcity starting to impact on energy production
Justification:
Nuclear power plants require significant levels of water for cooling purposes. The threat of water scarcity impacting nuclear and hydroelectric energy production has been highlighted in the past (HSDBi 13695). This new evidence suggests predictions of nuclear

 cooling water scarcity appear to be near to realisation in some countries such as France. New technologies aimed at reducing the environmental impacts of energy production such as carbon capture and storage, can add further pressure on water resources due

 to their additional demands (HSBDi 13958). As the UK continues to experience more weather extremes, water availability may become a limiting factor for nuclear energy production. In a world with lower water availability but increasing demands to maintain healthy

 environments, ensure food security and generate energy, the balance will become progressively more difficult to manage.
Primary Article Title: Heatwave may force nuclear power shutdown in France as cooling water runs out
Keywords: "Water resource" Energy Hydropower Rivers "Climate change" "water resources" energy electricity "climate change" CCS "carbon capture and storage" "carbon dioxide" CO2 regulation abstraction power flow drought 2040 Trent river UK "power station" cooling

Summary Sentence: Chemical pesticide chloropicrin could become more widely used in the future.
Justification:
Chloropicrin is a pesticide treatment for soil, with potential for damage to soil health and water quality. Although not currently approved by the EU, it has been granted use in the UK under an emergency authorisation. It is currently used more in the

 US. It has low solubility, so the manufacturer's claim it is not a water pollutant. However some research suggests its use has a significant impact on the bacterial community of soil. If more widespread use in the UK happens, what would the impacts be on soil

 health and water quality? Given the failure of some other pesticides due to resistance (HSDBi 15099 & 15168), this and other currently low use pesticides could see increasingly frequent use in the future.
Primary Article Title: Chloropicrin application increases production and profit potential for potato growers
Secondary_URLs: Effect of fumigation with chloropicrin on soil bacterial communities and genes encoding key enzymes involved in nitrogen cycling - PubMed 09/05/2017
Keywords: Pesticide insecticide herbicide fungicide nematicide herbicide agriculture chemical pollution pollutant food plant crop health disease

Summary Sentence: Using carbon dioxide in hydraulic fracturing could ensure that unconventional oil and gas extraction also doubles as a means of carbon capture and storage (CCS), mitigating against climate change.
Justification:
As a regulator of this industry the Environment Agency may need to assess the regulatory and environmental implications of replacing water with CO2 in fracking activities. Fracking works by injecting liquid under high pressure underground, which fragments

 oil and gas bearing shales, releasing the fossil fuels. However up to half of this water remains underground and cannot be recovered, along with the sand, foaming agents, biocides, and other chemicals that fracking liquids contain. Researchers experimenting

 with alternatives to water found that CO2 performed better at creating complex networks of fractures with significantly higher fuel volumes returned. Though the researchers believe their innovation is scalable, they cited limited access to CO2 resources as

 one potential blocker, due to the costs and impacts of current CCS processes. Critics however have pointed out that unlike dedicated CCS schemes fracking operations aren't currently designed to ensure that CO2 remains permanently underground. CO2 may have

 the potential to reduce pressure on water resources that fracking activities could bring, but may not be a solution to climate change and potential pollution from fracking activities in itself. The Environment Agency may therefore need more research in this

 area to prepare for regulatory challenge or change.
Primary Article Title: Carbon dioxide proposed as alternative fracking fluid
Secondary_URLs:
Fracturing with carbon dioxide&%2358; from microscopic mechanism to reservoir application - Joule 30/05/2019

Expert reaction to study on using co2 as a fracking fluid - Science Media Centre 30/05/2019
Keywords: energy "climate change" fossil fuel oil gas "hydraulic fracturing" fracking rock shale water regulation "water resources" groundwater "carbon dioxide" CO2 sand "foaming agent" biocide "carbon capture and storage" CCS

Summary Sentence: As the 'war on plastics' increases scrutiny of its use and by implication fossil fuel consumption, several innovations are emerging that exemplify alternatives.
Justification:
These should be of interest to the Environment Agency from a waste management perspective, but also from the perspective of considering the full life cycle of new products and processes. Nanostructures on bird and butterfly wings have inspired a paint that

 never fades. Unlike conventional pigments that are chemically degraded by the light they absorb, the new paint allows light not reflected to pass through, creating a “photonic colour”. The paint is also non-toxic and doesn’t release substances such as VOCs.While

 expensive cost savings could be incurred through scaling and reduced need to be reapplied. Dutch researchers are looking for oil alternatives in biomass, including agricultural and organic waste streams, developing ‘green’ cosmetics, detergents, paints and

 plastics that reduce CO₂ emissions and result in a healthier environment. One example is extracting polyacrylates used in dishwasher tablets from sugar beet and isocyanates free resin made from vegetable oil (isocyanates can be harmful to humans). Finnish

 designers have devised environmentally friendly concept headphones, made from naturally derived materials such as 3D printed bioplastics, hydrophobin protein based foam (derived from fungus) and artificially produced spider silk (the headphones don’t currently

 function as electronic devices). While technology alone won’t end the ‘plastics problem’ it is of interest to see that there are many developments waiting in the wing to provide solutions, providing there is political and regulatory support in the future.
Primary Article Title: These `microbe-grown' headphones could be the future of sustainable electronics
Author: Coldewey, D
Secondary_URLs:
Paint that never fades - Wageningen UR 21/05/2019

Green chemistry - Wageningen UR 24/05/2019
