GT: plastics fossil fuel resources waste regulation

Summary Sentence: A study of freshwater shrimp in rural Suffolk has revealed them to contain surprising levels and types of pharmaceuticals and other chemicals.
Justification: New approaches allow scientists to measure chemical levels accumulated within Gammarus pulex, rather than in the water they inhabit. The study identified 56 compounds from illegal drugs, pharmaceuticals and pesticides, of which cocaine was most frequently found. Lidocaine, a local anaesthetic that is sometimes used to dilute cocaine, was the second most frequently detected compound. Ketamine was also widespread. Diazepam (Valium) and alprazolam (Xanax) were also detected. Such chemical profiles are normally associated with urban pollution, rather than rural. Curiously, a number of long banned pesticides including fenuron, were found, but their origin remains unclear. This study shows that the impact of chemicals associated with demographic profiles not removed by water treatment processes may be further reaching than currently thought, extending outside of urban areas. The actual impacts that these chemicals are having on aquatic environments is unknown, ought other studies suggest impacts (%2314955) and may require additional research to assess the full regulatory impacts.
Primary Article Title: Shrimp in England's rural rivers are laced with traces of cocaine
Author: Katz, B
Secondary_URLs: Biomonitoring of pesticides, pharmaceuticals and illicit drugs in a freshwater invertebrate to estimate toxic or effect pressure - Environment International 01/08/2019
Keywords: pollution chemical pharmaceutical drug medicine narcotic shrimp wildlife river water health Suffolk rural urban demographic cocaine lidocaine anaesthetic ketamine Diazepam Valium alprazolam Xanax pesticide regulation farming fenuron banned illegal  wastewater treatment waste water treatment sewerage human health biodiversity shrimp gammarus "Gammarus pulex"

Summary Sentence: Human composting is gaining traction, both artistically and legally.
Justification:
The Environment Agency regulates waste composting facilities and may have to consider what environmental implications human composting could bring. The US state of Washington is close to introducing legislation that will allow human composting from 2020.

 The process would involve placing a body in a chamber that accelerates decomposition, called recomposition. The environmental impacts of conventional funerals is also being explored through art. Designer Shaina Garfield has discarded the traditional wooden

 coffin and embalming fluids in place of a woven rope netting infused with local fungal spores that help to biodegrade the body once it is buried. These join other signals of change that suggest alternative less impactful ways to dispose of bodies at death,

 such as liquified cremation (%2314528), which may contain harmful chemicals such as mercury from fillings and other implants, which may become more exotic as people’s bodies become increasingly augmented by new technologies (%2313948). Human composting may be

 seen increasingly as a viable and acceptable way of laying people to rest, particularly in urban environments where there’s increasing awareness of air quality issues and where spare land for conventional burials is at a premium.
Primary Article Title: Washington is one signature away from legalizing human composting
Author: Houser, K
Secondary_URLs:
Washington may become first state to legalize human composting - The Seattle Times 19/04/2019

Watch&%2358; Designing near death with the student who created her own coffin - Design Indaba 28/02/2019
Keywords: waste composting human death funeral land urban "air quality" cremation burial regulation fungus bacteria pollution Washington "Shaina Garfield" augmented human metal technology resources

Summary Sentence: Governments around the World are acting to include for environmental impacts in national accounting.
Justification:
Switzerland is currently discussing the Responsible Business Initiative, legislation that would extend compliance with human rights and environmental standards on any business trading in Switzerland, regardless of where it was based. This could mean that

 a company could be punished for human rights abuses or environmental damage down the supply chain in other countries, even if it followed Swiss legislation to the letter. About 70 to 80 percent of the ecological footprint created by consumption in Switzerland

 is borne by foreign countries. A survey of Swiss citizens shows that the majority are in favour of such legislation. Other surveys also indicate that captalism may beginning to wane as an acceptable economic model, with 51% of Americans aged 18-29 no longer

 supporting capitalism, and 64% of Britons believe that capitalism is unfair. The New Zealand Government is proposing to place citizen well-being above economic measures. The goal is to downplay the importance of gross domestic product (GDP), normally seen

 as an indicator of ‘success’. New Zealand’s prime minister Jacinda Ardern is spearheading the move, focussing resources on addressing mental health and well-being issues in a country with the highest rate of teen suicide in the Western world. Other countries

 such as Bhutan and the UK have put in place measures of well-being previously, but this is the first time that a country has placed well-being at the heart of the budget, rather than as a peripheral measure to economic growth. Both these examples demonstrate

 that citizens and governments are starting to consider environmental and personal ethics about economic growth in their national finances. Similar moves in the UK may change the relationship and role of environmental regulation and therefore may impact on

 the remit of the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: New Zealand wants to make people happy, not rich - will it work?
Author: Scully, R. P
Secondary_URLs:
What does the public think about corporate responsibility? - ETH Zurich 31/05/2019

Are you ready to consider that capitalism is the real problem? - Fast Company 11/07/2017
Keywords: economics sustainability gross domestic product GDP "New Zealand" Switzerland "human rights" environmental "Responsible Business Initiative" legislation UK Bhutan "Jacinda Arden" regulation industry

Summary Sentence: A brand new ecotown with 1000 homes is to be constructed on the banks of the Danube in Hungary.
Justification:
The 1 billion-euro ($1.1 billion) Hegyeshalom-Bezenye project in northwest Hungary will be the size of about 500 soccer pitches. The town will be carbon neutral and run mainly on solar and biogas power. The town’s economy will be based on market gardening,

 creating up to 5,000 permanent jobs in its greenhouses and feature sustainable water management. A similar trend for community self reliance is gaining recognition in Australia, where many communities are taking ownership of their own renewable energy production.

 While some may question the wisdom of building on a floodplain the project demonstrates that it may be possible to incorporate sustainability and zero carbon principles into new build settlements in the UK, helping to address the government’s net zero ambitions

 and achieving the environmental net gain ambitions of the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: Hungary to build $1 billion green-powered town from scratch
Author: Parkin, B
Secondary_URLs: Communities around Australia are taking clean energy into their own hands, the Indi win built on that - The Guardian 31/05/2019
Keywords: construction urbanisation city development ecotown horticulture floodplain river Danube Hungary Hegyeshalom-Bezenye energy solar biogas renewable Australia community "net zero"  "environmental net gain"

Summary Sentence: Another food crop weed is becoming resistant to multiple herbicides.
Justification:
Resistance to bacteria is well publicised as a human health issue of concern all over the world. There is growing evidence that weed control in food crops could soon be susceptible to a similar resistance. Waterhemp is the latest weed to show resistance

 to multiple herbicides. This adds to both pigweed and junglerice weeds, that have started to show resistance to the herbicide glyphosphate (HSDBi 15099). Combined with evidence that fungal resistance is also on the rise (HSDBi 15168), could mean a significant

 threat to food security and human health. The authors suggest that a more integrated system is needed for weed control, so that farmers are not reliant on chemistry alone. The environmental pathways of resistance, be it bacteria, fungal or plant, are new areas

 of research. As the Environment Agency has a significant role in monitoring change in the natural environment, it is feasible that they may have a role to play in the detection of resistance in the environment in the future. Any change to agricultural methods

 to mitigate these problems, will also have an impact on the environment. Altering herbicide use, using mechanical methods, or the development of new herbicides could all have unknown consequences for water quality, biodiversity and soil health.
Primary Article Title: Superweed resists another class of herbicides, study finds
Keywords: junglerice glyphosate herbicide "herbicide resistance" farming "food security" food agriculture crops AMR health fungi fungicide antifungal resistance

Summary Sentence: Researchers suggest yields of the world’s top ten crops have already been negatively affected by climate change.
Justification:
The study used weather records and food production data to show that a changing climate has likely already had a negative impact on crop yields. However impacts are not uniform in their occurrence, with Europe seeing a negative impact on yields, whereas

 Latin America experienced an increase in yields. Similarly not all crops experience a decline in yields with soya beans having an overall increase. Projections of the impact of climate change on crop yields are incredibly difficult due to multiple variables

 and uncertainties. This study also has uncertainties and is not definitive, but it could be an indicator that food security is already being put under threat.
Primary Article Title: Climate change is already affecting global food production unequally
Secondary_URLs: Climate change has likely already affected global food production - PLOS ONE 31/05/2019
Keywords: food security climate change global warming calories crops agriculture farming

Summary Sentence: Can your DNA help you identify a good career choice?
Justification:
DNA testing is already on the rise for those with an interest in genealogy and also those that wish to understand their risk for certain medical conditions. China have stated they will be undertaking genetic testing to help select athletes’ for the 2022

 winter Olympics. This next step uses genome sequencing to help identify an individual’s likely aptitude for certain tasks. Personal genomics has been discussed by geneticist Robert Plomin who suggests it could be used to indicate certain traits that an individual

 would be good at, such as maths. This in turn could then be used to help select future career paths. The ethical questions that would arise from the use of this kind of information for recruitment purposes would be significant. Should this type of genetic

 testing become more popular, employers of the future may need to consider what safeguards may be needed if this type of information becomes part of the recruitment process.
Primary Article Title: Could DNA testing be the key to developing talent?
Keywords: genetics profiling career DNA recruitment job workforce

Summary Sentence: Monitoring device records outside worker being exposed to six times the level of air pollutants as an office worker.
Justification:
The small scale study fitted ten residents from London with a monitoring device to track their exposure to black carbon over a week. The results highlight the disparity of exposure amongst different professions, with the lorry driver and construction worker

 being exposed to significantly higher levels of pollution that the office worker. The British Safety Council have been working with Kings College London to develop a mobile app that can calculate an outside workers exposure to air pollution in real time. It

 then correlates this against World Health Organisation exposure guidelines, so that the information can be used in risk assessments. As technology for personal monitoring becomes more affordable, the data highlighting local air pollutants will rise considerably.

 How this is captures assessed and analysed will need careful consideration so that it can be best used to help improve air quality in the future. As an employer of field workers, and those that need to travel in vehicles for their job, the Environment Agency

 may wish to explore what technology there is to safely manage the additional risk from air pollution that this group of staff may experience.
Primary Article Title: Outdoor workers overlooked in the air quality debate, researchers claim
Keywords: health air pollution pollutant respiratory lung asthma industry emissions regulation monitoring monitor technology data HSW black carbon traffic road exposure

Summary Sentence: A new start-up company in Silicon Valley, California is attempting to develop a hormone free contraceptive that’s effective in both men and women.
Justification:
While the technology is still in its early stages and may yet be more than a decade away, the potential for widespread use of a hormone free contraceptive could have implications for the way Environment Agency monitors and manages water pollution and the

 health of ecosystems. Current pill based contraceptives are implicated in oestrogen discharging into the environment, which has been shown to impact upon both terrestrial and marine organisms and human health. If those contraceptives were to be replaced by

 a hormone free alternative there may be implications for both the wellbeing of wider ecosystems and human populations. The company developing the technology is drawing on a decade of research that has sought to understand the role of Calcium in sperm functioning

 and how it might be manipulated. The result is that two plant based triterpenoid compounds have been found to act as contraceptives by interfering with sperm motility and the ability of individual spermatozoa to enter an egg, reducing the potential for successful

 fertilisation. The resulting pharmaceutical should be effective in both men and women. The potential for the introduction of significant amounts of different compounds into the environment with as yet unknown consequences should also be considered.
Primary Article Title: A startup seeded by Silicon Valley's hottest mentorship program aims to bring the first male birth control to market
Author: Erin Brodwin
Keywords: Hormone; water pollution; birth control

Summary Sentence: New Nano-coating technology has been shown to increase the rate at which sunlight can degrade microplastics in water and could form a part of future efforts to tackle aquatic plastic pollution.
Justification:
If the new Nano-coating technology is successfully developed and operationalised it could have implications for both the amount and type of plastic pollution in the environment and therefore the role plastic pollution plays in issues around waste treatment

 and water quality. There may also be connected consequences for the packaging industry in terms of the amounts and types of plastic produced as well as its method of production that would have knock on implications for the way the Environment Agency regulates

 plastic production. The Nano-coating technology uses zinc oxide nanorods to activate photocatalysis of the material and initiate a series of reactions at weak spots in the surface of the plastic. This oxidises the material creating cracks and spots in its

 surface. Plastics entering the water environment as pollution could be made to perish more quickly, reducing the amount of time they persist in aquatic systems, and potentially the overall amount of plastic pollution as a result. The technology is being developed

 in the context of a developing evidence base that micro plastics are ubiquitous throughout the biosphere and bring with them potentially substantial health implications, both for human populations and wider ecosystems as a whole.
Primary Article Title: Nanocoating Technology Harnesses Sunlight to Degrade Microplastics
Author: Jessica Miley
Keywords: Nanotechnology, water pollution, microplastics, plastic

Summary Sentence: A new solar hydrogen generator that uses low cost materials has demonstrated the highest performance yet reported for a device of its kind and could represent a step towards the viable use of hydrogen as a domestic fuel.
Justification:
The cost effectiveness of the new technology takes a step towards realising domestic scale hydrogen production. As a result it’s now more plausible that hydrogen could displace fossil fuel use in both the home and transport sectors, potentially contributing

 to reduced carbon dioxide emissions and achieving greenhouse gas emission targets. The small scale of the new technology may also have implications for the way fuels are currently manufactured and distributed, signalling a move away from centralised large

 scale production systems and towards smaller more decentralised and localised neighbourhood or household units. This is potentially significant to the Environment Agency in terms of its role in monitoring and regulating air pollution, its role in helping to

 reduce carbon emissions from the energy sector and the new demands of regulating changes in fuel manufacturing arrangements and their associated infrastructural distribution networks. Hydrogen production currently occurs at relatively large scales but at a

 high price compared to fossil fuels and its reliance on grid electricity has limited uptake. One solution to this has been to try and integrate the function of electrical power generation and electrolysis into single devices, like the generator featured here,

 to increase the efficiency of the process. To date devices have regularly achieved solar to hydrogen efficiencies in excess of 10% but in order to achieve the required cost efficiencies have needed to utilise membranes that are chemically unstable. A solution

 to this, successfully tested under laboratory conditions, has been to use water vapour rather than liquid phase water. The new solar generator incorporates this technology into an operational, deployable device for the first time and in doing so achieves solar

 to hydrogen efficiencies of 15%, significantly more than has so far been demonstrated.
Primary Article Title: Record-breaking device uses sunlight to produce hydrogen at 15% efficiency
Author: Dario Borghino
Keywords: hydrogen, solar, microgeneration

Summary Sentence: As the Earth appears perched on the brink of the 6th Mass Extinction, one designer and artist is envisioning how synthetic biology might be utilised to ‘rewild’ the planet.
Justification:
Alexandra Daisy Ginsberg’s recent project explores the human reaction to what the wilds could look like in a future where synthetic biology is embraced. Ginsberg attempts this through creating realistic looking images of future species created through

 synthetic biology that look familiar to current plants and animals, but have been designed to be ‘better’ than their natural counterparts. Synthetic biologists could design companion species to support endangered natural species and ecosystems, or offer protection

 from non-native invasive species to indigenous species. Patented species, financed through corporate biodiversity schemes could be released into the wild. Preserving wildlife in this way also preserves a greater diversity of DNA, which in turn can be optimised

 through synthetic biology for future uses. Ginsberg highlights that the taxonomic status of such organisms is uncertain - they may not even be considered ‘alive’. Also if nature becomes industrialised in this way for the benefit of human society, would nature

 still exist for conservation? While a conceptual exercise this project raises questions around the concept of natural capital. Assuming that climate change cannot be halted, it is likely that many habitats may be transformed or disappear completely, changing

 the ecosystems services that they provide. These could potentially be addressed through synthetic biological means, allowing systems to continue to function, potentially providing greater value than purely natural systems. There may also be regulatory concerns

 of releasing non-natural organisms into the wild, which may also require careful consideration.
Primary Article Title: The industrialisation of the natural world
Author: Matroos, J
Keywords: "synthetic biology" regulation wildlife extinction biodiversity DNA "climate change" "natural capital" "ecosystems services" plant animal finance invasive non-native incident taxonomy alive "Alexandra Daisy Ginsberg" design art
GT: synthetic biology, natural capital, regulation, climate change

Summary Sentence: Equipping plants with sensors capable of recording and transmitting data could herald the arrival of ‘The Internet Of Plants’ (IOP).
Justification:
The Environment Agency may wish to contemplate how this technology could benefit its objectives around regulation and monitoring of environmental systems. Previous examples have demonstrated how creating plant based monitoring systems (%2313330), or enhancing

 plants with synthetic materials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (%2314189) creates the potential for natural monitoring systems. Another similar study investigated growing metal organic frameworks (MOFs) inside a living plant, rather than using preformed materials.

 Metal salts placed in solution were absorbed by lotuses, which grew a variety of fluorescent MOFs in their vascular systems. The fluorescence diminished when the plants were placed in acetone, demonstrating the plant’s ability to detect the toxic chemical.

 Such ‘cyberplants’ may be able to communicate with each other directly and generated the electricity they need to function through tapping into the natural energy producing properties of the host plant. Plants that carry this information to other plants may

 become known as ‘plantennas’. Similar applications of sensors, exotic materials and plants could provide a variety of useful environmental data such as pollution presence or the early signs of drought in crops - two examples which may be of Environment Agency

 interest.
Primary Article Title: The Internet of Plants&%2358; building a network of cyberplants
Author: Hurtado, J
Secondary_URLs: Glowing, toxic-detecting plants are the green engineering of the future - The Verge 03/04/2019
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" plant cyberplant plantenna "Internet Of Plants" IOP drought pollution pollutant regulation incident "metal organic framework" MOF "carbon nanotube" CNT farming fluorescence lotus
GT: environmental monitoring, incident management, regulation, biology

Summary Sentence: Students have been warned over the dangers of taking a so-called 'smart drug' in a bid to help them study.
Justification:
Modafinil is a prescription drug used to treat narcolepsy, but is being obtained online by students hoping to improve their concentration and stay awake. Side effects of taking modafinil include heart problems, psychosis, hallucinations and severe skin

 reactions. However the full biological impacts, nor the true scale of use is unknown – though one survey suggests that one in four students have taken it at least once. Without knowledge of the scale of modafinil use, nor the environmental impacts of trace

 levels it is difficult to assess if this is a potential risk. However it should be considered in the context of growing evidence on the impact of pharmaceuticals and illicit substances on biodiversity (%2314955), along with growing concentrations of the student

 population in urban areas (%2314833), implying that any such impacts may be localised.
Primary Article Title: Doctor warns stressed-out students buying 'smart drugs' online to help them stay awake and study could be HARMING their long-term health by limiting their sleep
Author: Corner, N
Secondary_URLs: 'Smart drug' taken by one in four students really does boost performance - The Telegraph 20/08/2015
Keywords: modafinil health chemical chemistry pharmaceutical drug narcolepsy online illegal "smart drug" pollution water quality water treatment urban student regulation deomgraphics

Summary Sentence: Borophene, consisting of an atom thick layer of boron is drawing comparisons with graphene as a ‘wonder material’.
Justification:
Graphene has already drawn interest from the Environment Agency for its potential uses in energy storage, water treatment and waste management implications, suggesting that borophene may need similar considerations. There is also potential for incorporation

 into environmental monitoring technology for pollution and air quality applications. Borophene, first produced in 2015, has a range of potential applications, including hydrogen storage, more powerful lithium-ion batteries and as a gas sensor for gas sensor

 for ethanol, formaldehyde, carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, hydrogen cyanide detection, and CO, NO, NO2 or ammonia (NH3) adsorption. Borophene is more flexible than graphene. As such it could be utilised in flexible electronics and could be used to make next-gen

 wearables, biomolecule sensors, and even quantum computers due to its superconductor potential. So far researchers have only been able to produce minute quantities of the chemical, implying that industrial scale borophene production is still some way ahead.

 However it may be prudent to consider the potential technological improvements as well as potential environmental risks to wide scale borophene use.
Primary Article Title: Borophene&%2358; the most exciting new material you've never heard of
Secondary_URLs: Review of borophene and its potential applications - Frontiers Of Physics 10/04/2019
Keywords: chemistry chemical borophene graphene superconductor monitoring electronics waste water treatment regulation battery lithium ethanol formaldehyde "carbon monoxide" "nitrous oxide" "hydrogen cyanide" CO NO NO2 ammonia NH3 detection  adsorption "quantum computing" research energy hydrogen

Summary Sentence: Robots that resemble animals could open up new areas for monitoring and surveillance and even enable cross species communication.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may be able to take advantage of monitoring and surveillance technology in an operational capacity. The ability to communicate and influence animal behaviour with robotics is also of interest from a wider environmental perspective

 as it may offer the potential for monitoring and improving the resilience of ecosystems in the face of large scale systematic change. A UK based company, Animal Dynamics, is one of several to be exploring the potential of replicating animal characteristics

 in robots designed for air, land and water. One of its most promising developments is a pen sized insect-like drone for military reconnaissance called Skeeter. Others are experimenting with robotic insects for pollination and surveillance purposes (%2314610,

 %2314669, %236809). One group of researchers has been investigating how robots can influence groups of animals. Robotic bees and fish have been used to influence the direction taken by swarms and schools respectively. In one experiment enticing the fish in one

 direction led to communication with the bee robot, who reciprocated the same influence on the swarm, effectively creating primitive cross species communication. It is envisaged that such robots could adapt by evolutionary algorithms, learning to interact with

 animals in a desired way. This could lay the foundations for a new mechanism for humans to interfere with animal societies in order to manage the environment and utilise the collective unrivalled perceptual capabilities of animals to enhance decision making,

 and making the selective rewiring of ecosystems an outcome. The term for this new branch of technology has been coined&%2358; “biohybridity”. It is suggested that animal-robot hybrids could even replace us as the new 'toiling masses' of the 21st century. The prospect

 of using such technology for managing environmental systems may create uncertainties over what the ‘correct’ approach could be, however with a rapidly changing climate, more technologically enhanced solutions may be needed to keep natural ecosystems functioning,

 which in turn may need monitoring and regulation to ensure that benefits materialise as intended.
Primary Article Title: Bees talk to fish&%2358; a new technology enables cross species communication
Author: Miley, J
Secondary_URLs:
Insect-size drones, coming on a spy mission near you - Ozy 03/04/2019

Robots mediating interactions between animals for interspecies collective behaviors - Science Robotics 20/03/2019
Keywords: robotics communication nature algorithm "artificial intelligence" AI bee fish insect influence robot biohybridity "Animal Dynamics" drone monitoring surveillance military Skeeter regulation "environmental management" "natural capital" "ecosystem services" technology swarm workforce "21st century"

Summary Sentence: Drug resistant fungi could pose a significant threat to food security and human health.
Justification:
Antifungal resistance is something that is already appearing in hospitals around the world, yet receives far less press attention than bacterial resistance. Candida auris is a fungal infection that has appeared in hospitals around the world. The strain

 of concern is resistant to antifungal medication and worryingly invasive, so much so that specialist cleaning equipment is needed to clean the rooms of patients that contract the fungus. Antifungals are routinely sprayed in large quantities each year to protect

 food crops. It is not clear if the use of these fungicides could have played a part in the development of resistant strains. However it is troubling that the majority of antifungals all work the same way, meaning if more strains become resistant there are

 limited alternatives to protect both food crops and human health. The Environment Agency may wish to assign similar resource and research into fungal resistance as it does to bacterial resistance.
Primary Article Title: A mysterious infection, spanning the globe in a climate of secrecy
Keywords: Antifungal resistance, human health, food security AMR fungi fungus fungicide

Summary Sentence: As investment in innovation starts to give diminishing returns, the scientific community may increasingly look to artificial intelligence to advance research.
Justification:
The implications of this could be felt across all research and development disciplines, including the Environment Agency’s own research programmes. An increase in the rate of innovation could also create greater challenges for regulation, which historically

 has always lagged behind. Recent research has demonstrated that the cost of producing new ideas is increasing - productivity has been sluggish for several decades, despite increasing numbers of researchers. This pattern can be seen across disciplines including

 crop science, drug discovery and semiconductor development - Moore’s Law for example has remained true but at a significantly growing cost to research. The implications are significant. Some suspect that humanity has already harvested the ‘low hanging fruit’

 of innovation at a time when significant existential threats such as climate change and antimicrobial resistance are coming to the fore. As the sheer volume of knowledge expands it becomes harder for humans to master their whole fields of knowledge, so they

 tend to specialise. This makes it necessary to employ larger teams to solve complex problems, which in itself increases potential costs. While some of the issues could be resolved through economic means, such as tax breaks for R&D, the most impactful solution

 may be in embracing the potential of artificial intelligence and machine learning. AI is already helping to explore the properties of molecules with the potential to create new pharmaceuticals, which a human workforce could never screen in an effective time

 frame. The discovery of new materials could take 2-5 years, rather than the expected 10-20 years within the current paradigm. AI also has the potential to come up with ideas that humans would never have thought of on their own - Google’s AI discovered strategies

 for the game Go that no human had ever conceived. At the same time human input would still be needed - our understanding of the systems we wish to improve are imperfect - human disease mechanisms for example - and machine intelligence could only help to solve

 these issues if it is presented with the right data in the first place.
Primary Article Title: AI is reinventing the way we invent
Author: Rotman, D
Secondary_URLs: How AI could spur drug development - ETH Zurich 28/03/2019
Keywords: research development innovation "artificial intelligence" "machine learning" productivity investment economics tax resources Google "Alpha Go" AI drug pharmaceutical chemical "semi conductor"  "Moore's Law" AMR "climate change"

Summary Sentence: Floating city plans gain support of UN
Justification:
Although the floating city idea is not new, the current partnership with a government organisation is a positive development for those wishing to secure funding for the project. The concept is to have a moveable, module based city that floats in shallow

 coatal waters near land. Sustainability and the ability to adapt to climate change is forefront in the design. The proposed idea sees six independent modules, each housing up to 300 people join together to create a hexagonal unit. These could be further joined

 to create a city housing approximately 10000 people, with associated areas for leisure, energy generation and food production. The modules would be tethered to the ocean floor in shallow coastal waters, built to withstand sea level rise, and the ability to

 be moved if needed. It will be interesting to see what funding may now be generated to develop a concept that hopes to address some of the problems of coastal flooding. There will be many other obstacles the project will need to overcome if it is ever to be

 built. A recent project for a similar design with French Polynesia (HSDBi 14256) is currently on hold due to community distrust that this would just be a tax haven for the rich.
Primary Article Title: The UN just unveiled a design for a new floating city that can withstand Category 5 hurricanes
Secondary_URLs:
UN brings back controversial floating city concept - Engineering.com 15/04/2019

Floating cities aren't the answer to climate change - CityLab 10/04/2019
Keywords: flooding "climate change" city urban architecture floating city "sea level rise" incident emergency planning government construction building

Summary Sentence: Evidence suggests that road salts have a negative impact on multiple aquatic species.
Justification:
The concentration of salt in freshwater environments such as rivers, lakes and wetlands is increasing due to human activities. De-icing of roads is one source of this salt, but other activities such as agricultural practices, mining, and irrigation all add

 to the rising concentrations. Although there has been research on the ecological effects of salinization in the past, it took until 2001 for a review of the evidence of these impacts across species. Since this point research in the topic has increased significantly.

 This current review looked at the research available on the effects of salinisation on aquatic species. It found that although not lethal, it had an impact on species growth and reproduction as well as altering nutrient flows in the waterbodies. This was the

 case for both fish and biofilms, with the authors highlighting evidence gaps for a number of other species that need further research. As the evidence builds on the impacts of salinization on freshwater species there will likely be a push to find alternatives

 to keep roads safe. The Environment Agency will likely have a role to play in helping reduce the impacts, and will need to be mindful of any innovative alternatives and what their ecological impact could be. This has already been seen with beet juice deicer

 impacting on insect health (HSDBi 15117).
Primary Article Title: A review of the species, community, and ecosystem impacts of road salt salinisation in fresh waters
Keywords: deicer salt "aquatic insects" "beet juice" road-salt insects biodiversity salinity health ecotoxicology de-icing salinization salinisation fish plankton

Summary Sentence: With no limit on attention span or conflict of interests, could appointing an algorithm to the board be good for business?
Justification:
Board members roles can be varied from company to company, but generally they are there to have a strategic oversight of the company and to ensure that it is being run well. Often members of the board can have multiple roles and therefore only have limited

 time to fulfil their duties, with potential for conflict of interest with the other roles and responsibilities they hold. Having an algorithm as a board member could be a way to harness machine learning to process large amounts of data to make decisions based

 on the best available evidence. An algorithm would not be swayed by group think, and the board would have to justify why it is making a decision if it goes against the evidence of the algorithm. It would not have time restraints, and may be able to highlight

 conflicts of interest which could lead to a more transparent decision making process. Theoretically using a similar tool in government could improve impartiality as there would need to be an evidence trail of why decisions were made if they contradict the

 data. It is important to remember that AI (artificial intelligence) is only looking for patterns in data, and therefore poor decisions are likely to be made if they are based on a flawed dataset. AI can quickly identify patterns, but which patterns are the

 most important may not always be as clear.
Primary Article Title: Why not appoint an algorithm to your corporate board?
Secondary_URLs:
Amazon scraps secret AI recruiting tool that showed bias against women - Reuters 10/10/2018

Notes on AI bias - Benedict Evans 15/04/2019
Keywords: AI machine learning corporate responsibility policy politics bias

Summary Sentence: A US startup has developed a microbe based agricultural spray that removes the need to apply chemical fertiliser.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as a possible mechanism to combat the environmental pollution of excessive nitrate and phosphate nutrients in water from farming applications, such as eutrophication and reduce carbon emissions

 from chemical fertiliser production. The company is called Pivot Bio. Their first product is a spray for use on cornfields. The spray is applied in the same manner as chemical fertilisers. The difference is that the spray contains a microbe that consumes nitrogen

 and emits ammonia, a nitrogen form that plants can easily absorb. The microbes remain in the soil, feeding the crops so successive fertiliser applications aren’t needed. Pivot Bio calculate that their products could eventually remove half a million metric

 tonnes from (presumably) US waterways. The company is developing similar products for application to wheat and rice, which together with corn represent a third of the World’s fertiliser consumption.
Primary Article Title: These microbes could be the secret to eliminating polluting fertilizer
Author: Peters, A
Keywords: farming food agriculture crop rice wheat corn fertilizer fertiliser nitrate spray pollution eutrophication "Pivot Bio" microbe nitrogen ammonia plant protein carbon emission "climate change" pollution pollutant "water quality" regulation USA

Summary Sentence: Successful experiments with artificial wombs could impact on the livestock sector and may even bring significant changes to human reproduction, including ethical concerns.
Justification:
Artificial wombs have the potential to impact on the breeding cycles associated with seasonal farming. The energy and resource differences between artificial and conventional livestock rearing could also bring significant differences to the sector’s environmental

 impacts. Medical researchers have developed an artificial womb known as a Biobag. The Biobag contains an electrolyte solution similar to amniotic fluid and a way for the fetus to circulate its blood and exchange carbon dioxide for oxygen - similar to a uterus.

 The researchers have used Biobags to bring eight fetal lambs to term. The intention is for the Biobag to offer a more natural environment for premature births to develop in, and to offer an alternative to situations where there are health risks to natural

 pregnancies. This is not to say that such technology may not be utilised for other purposes within the livestock industry and beyond. Previous intelligence has demonstrated that there may be a market for mass produced genetically cloned livestock (HSDBi %2313664),

 which are being established in China to address the rising global demand for meat. And conceptual schemes to use natural environmental management to tackle climate change using mammoths would in reality only become feasible through using artificial wombs.

 The resource demands and financial risks of livestock breeding, such as feed and veterinary bills may be either partly or completely reduced through artificial wombs. Breeding cycles may no longer be seasonal, and the number of live young could rise overall.

 Livestock produced in such a way may represent a halfway house between the real and the synthetic, and may therefore be seen as more palatable to consumers, who currently aren’t completely sure about lab grown meat. Artificial womb technology may also impact

 on human reproduction.People currently excluded from biological parenthood through infertility or other reasons may take advantage of artificial wombs. As the technology matures to a stage of full ectogenesis it is conceivable that given the choice some women

 may opt out of pregnancy yet still become mothers. Men may also be able to skip courtship on the road to becoming fathers. Wealthy people could pay to have more children than they might conceive naturally.There may be developmental or behavioural impacts of

 any offspring, animal or human that haven’t been being biologically attached to a mother. Practical and ethical issues around such things as abortion and adoption may lead to social division, legal and regulatory challenges. The impacts on population dynamics

 as a whole may also bring consequences for resource use and environmental impacts.
Primary Article Title: An artificial womb successfully grew baby sheep - and humans could be next
Secondary_URLs:
Harrop&%2358; Are we ready to confront ethics of artificial wombs? - Everett Daily Herald 03/01/2019

Glimpse&%2358; how an army of resurrected mammoths could curb global warming - Futurism 27/09/2018

Could artificial wombs replace women in the future? - BabyGaga 15/02/2019

Would you eat `meat' from a lab? Consumers aren't necessarily sold on `cultured meat' - The Conversation 23/04/2018
Keywords: "artificial womb" birth baby embryo premature health pregnancy biology research farming agriculture livestock children child parent wealth lamb Biobag mammoth China food meat clon cloning "synthetic meat" lab sheep grown protein ethic abortion fetus adoption population society law regulation men women sex ectogenesis

Summary Sentence: Identifies practical applications for quantum computing (in general).
Justification:
This article gives examples of areas where quantum computing can be applied. As quantum is both abstract and evolving these can act as starting point to begin talking to BRMs about potential applications of this technology in a business context. This can

 also be used from a scoring perspective to help identify potential relevance to the business.
Primary Article Title: 6 Practical Examples Of How Quantum Computing Will Change Our World
Author: Marr, B
Keywords: Quantum Examples "PoC inspiration"

Summary Sentence: Changes in societal structure could mean that a new drug designed to combat feelings of loneliness may have a growing market, but this may also bring unintended environmental impacts.
Justification:
The most recent ONS survey shows that the number of one person households in the UK is rising. The same survey also reveals that one-person households have the lowest well-being of all household types. While it may not be living alone that causes these

 feelings, the growing number of one person households could suggest that loneliness may also increase, impacting on mental health. Data from the USA suggests that society is experiencing a ‘loneliness epidemic’. A consequence of this is that despite wanting

 to connect more, loneliness makes people more anxious and defensive, hindering the social connections that lonely people desire. The answer could come in the form of a treatment based on the pregnenolone, a hormone primarily produced by the adrenal gland.

 Pregnenolone has been associated with stress reduction. Experiments in the US is trialling the effects that pregnenolone has on lonely people, with a look to developing medication. While this may lead to a positive outcome for mental health, there is research

 that identifies pregnenolone as a major endocrine disrupting chemical, accounting for most of the anti-mineralocorticoid (diuretic) activities present in raw wastewater. As such, increased pregnenolone levels in wastewater from increased use as a medicine

 could have potentially cause stress for aquatic wildlife and other organisms, and should therefore should be of interest to the Environment Agency. It should be noted that there are potential non-chemical alternatives to fighting loneliness that technology

 could promise, such as the US based app Join Papa that enables lonely elderly people to summon college age company to aid with housework, get shopping or simply 'hang out'. The students are paid for participation.
Primary Article Title: Can a pill fight loneliness?
Secondary_URLs:
New Cigna study reveals loneliness at epidemic levels in America - Cigna 01/05/2018

Occurrence of androgens in sewage treatment plants influents is associated with antagonist activities on other steroid receptors - Water Research 15/04/2012

Senior citizens are using an app to order "on-demand grandkids" - Futurism 24/02/2019

The cost of living alone - Office for National Statistics 04/04/2019
Keywords: pollution chemistry health illness medicine "mental health" loneliness water quality wastewater treatment EDC endocrine disruption USA ONS pregnenolone anti-mineralocorticoid diuretic hormone "adrenal gland" drug medicine medication wildlife organism biodiversity regulation "sharing economy" app smartphone elderly "Join Papa"

Summary Sentence: Concerns of executive and undergraduate business students have now gone beyond how business actions impact a corporation's sustainability performance to how those actions increase or decrease environmental and societal turbulence.
Justification:
This survey data suggest undergraduates (future managers) and executive MBA students (current managers) expect to have sustainability methodologies embedded in their management education because both groups believe that the global supply chain practices

 have contributed to global turbulence and that sustainable supply chain actions could help to reduce that turbulence. Exposure to supply chain sustainability examples in management education increases global awareness and empathy in current and future managers,

 but female managers were found to be more likely to adhere to the tenets of managing for sustainability suggesting that gender diversity in their supply chain teams would mitigate risks.
Primary Article Title: Managing in turbulent times&%2358; The impact of sustainability in management education on current and future business leaders
Author: Rosanna Cole, Brent Snider
Keywords: Corporate Sustainability, Climate Change, Environmental Pressures

Summary Sentence: The more plant species that grow in grasslands and forests, the more insect species that find a habitat there, but the presence of more plant species also increases the number of insect individuals.
Justification:
This study analysed the relative importance of key components of plant diversity as drivers of herbivore, predator, and parasitoid species richness in experimental forests and grasslands. It evaluated extensive data on plant and insect diversity from two

 of the world's largest biodiversity experiments, the Jena Experiment and BEF-China, designed to investigate the effects of plant diversity on other organisms and the functioning of the respective ecosystem. The data showed that a reduction in plant species

 richness (number of species) caused by, for example, the intensive use of agricultural and forest land, can lead to reduced insect abundance (number of individuals), which in turn reduces insect species richness. It is not only the loss of plant species that

 drives this, but also the associated loss of structural diversity (such as low and high plants).
Primary Article Title: Multiple plant diversity components drive consumer communities across ecosystems
Author: Andreas Schuldt, Anne Ebeling, Matthias Kunz, Michael Staab, Claudia Guimarães-Steinicke, Dörte Bachmann, Nina Buchmann, Walter Durka, Andreas Fichtner, Felix Fornoff, Werner Härdtle, Lionel R. Hertzog, Alexandra-Maria Klein, Christiane Roscher, Jörg Scha
Keywords: Biodiversity Loss, Ecosystem Functioning

Summary Sentence: The lag in the replenishment of life following mass extinctions is caused by the slow rate of evolution rather than adverse environmental factors.
Justification:
Mass extinction may be expected to be followed by rapid speciation from surviving species, but the fossil record contains many instances where speciation is delayed. The probable explanation for this delay is that extinctions eliminate morphospace (the

 possible forms, shapes or structures of organisms), as they curtail diversity, and the delay in diversification is a result of the time needed for new innovations to rebuild morphospace, which can then be filled out by newly evolved species. To test this hypothesis,

 the study reconstructed the impacts of the meteor strike in the Cretaceous period on foraminifera plankton, which showed that increases in complexity precede changes in diversity, indicating that plankton colonised new morphospace, then slowly filled it in

 over millions of years. On this basis the authors of the study suggest the current loss of biodiversity caused by climate change is likely to take millions of years to recover from.
Primary Article Title: Morphospace expansion paces taxonomic diversification after end Cretaceous mass extinction
Author: Christopher M. Lowery and Andrew J. Fraass
Keywords: Biodiversity Loss, Climate Change, Mass Extinction

Summary Sentence: Analysis of 29 selected small waterways across 10 countries in the European Union showed all the sampled streams were contaminated with pesticides and, in most of the cases, veterinary drugs.
Justification:
This research found herbicides, fungicides and insecticides, as well as antimicrobial drugs used in livestock present in the waterways sampled, with more than 100 pesticides and 21 drugs were detected in the 29 waterways analysed, including the UK. A quarter

 of the chemicals identified are banned, while half of the streams analysed had at least one pesticide above permitted levels, and all the streams contained complex mixtures of these substances, the impact of which was unknown. Herbicides were the main contributor

 to the total amount of pesticides found in the samples, with terbuthylazine present in all the samples and the neonicotinoid insecticides imidacloprid and clothianidin were the pesticides most frequently present above regulatory limits. The majority of the

 veterinary drugs detected were antimicrobials, most being antibiotics. The detection of many pesticides that have long been banned was not necessarily due to continued illegal use, but could be the result of leaching of persistent chemicals that linger in

 soils.
Primary Article Title: Screening of pesticides and veterinary drugs in small streams in the European Union by liquid chromatography high resolution mass spectrometry
Author: Jorge Casado, Kevin Brigden, David Santillo, Paul Johnston
Keywords: Pesticides, antimicrobial resistance, pollution

Summary Sentence: A UN report suggests failure to enforce environmental law is a significant blocker to a more sustainable future.
Justification:
In developed nations there can often be a perception that environmental laws slow down growth. This has led to under resourcing of environmental bodies, reducing their ability to enforce regulations. Combined with a lack of understanding of sustainability

 and the economic benefits it can deliver, has meant many nations have failed to access the benefits of green growth. This has been highlighted in the opportunities being missed from not implementing low carbon economies (HSDBi 15128). Unless implementation

 and enforcement is strengthened, it doesn’t matter how many rules and regulations you have, or how thorough they are, they are likely to fail. Does this mean environmental regulators should focus more resource on implementation and enforcement in order to

 achieve the most benefits for the environment?
Primary Article Title: Environmental rule of law
Secondary_URLs: Failure to enforce environmental law `widespread', UN study finds - IEMA 28/01/2019
Keywords: law enforcement regulation sustainability

Summary Sentence: The growing home air purification sector may bring with it concerns for waste management.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as it has regulatory interests in both air quality and waste management. Globally the market for domestic air purifiers is growing. Much of this growth is centred on Asian countries where

 urban air quality is noticeably poor and the logistics of purifying the relatively small indoor spaces where people spend the majority of their time make sense. However there is also a growing number of air purification devices available on the UK market.

 Recently one London school installed air purification technology to reduce PM2.5 levels in classrooms due to health concerns. One design of air purifier features a charcoal filter which captures air impurities such as particulate matter, heavy metals from

 brake wear, polycyclic aromatic compounds from wood and coal fires, nitrosamines from cigarette smoke and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). These substances exist in the air at low concentrations, but these become concentrated within the filter. When the

 filters are replaced the old ones end up in landfill&%2358; if large numbers of households install purification technology then this could equate to a concentration of toxic material in landfill, rather than in the air. As public awareness of the health impacts

 of poor air quality grows and the availability of purification technology increases, this could emerge as an issue in the UK, particularly if national policy fails to address air pollution issues to a level the public deem is satisfactory.
Primary Article Title: Air purification is catching on - but it may be doing more harm than good
Author: Lewis, A
Secondary_URLs: London school fits air purifiers in classrooms to protect children from toxic air - Evening Standard 22/12/2017
Keywords: "air quality" "air pollution" pollution "air purification" "air purifier" domestic health household indoor government policy regulation filter brake dust charcoal nitrosamine cigarette smoke urban London school PM2.5 VOC "heavy metal" "particulate matter"  "polycyclic aromatic compound" wood coal fire waste landfill

Summary Sentence: A city is Japan is to use artificial intelligence to identify and intervene in incidences of school bullying.
Justification:
The AI will analyse data from 9000 historic reported bullying incidents collected over six years in schools in the city of Otsu in Shiga Prefecture. The AI will produce statistical analysis from factors such as time, location, school grade, gender of victims

 and perpetrators and school absenteeism to help local authorities and teachers identify forms of bullying that tend to escalate, and therefore help better direct attention. The Environment Agency may wish to consider if similar technology could aid in identifying

 and preventing an escalation of bullying incidents in the workplace, as opposed to the school environment. Similar technology could also help to identify and prevent other health safety and well-being issues from current data collection that may be harder

 to identify through non-analytical means.
Primary Article Title: City of Otsu to use AI to analyze past school bullying cases with an eye on future prevention
Keywords: workforce employee employer bullying abuse automation data "artificial intelligence" Ostu Japan school education analysis Shiga

Summary Sentence: The next generation of virtual reality environments that are in development could create a virtual workspace that mimics the best aspects of physically sharing workspace.
Justification:
The Environment Agency supports flexible and remote working arrangements, and therefore should be interested in technologies that can bridge any productivity gaps that result from teams not sharing physical workspace. The Glimpse Group based in New York

 USA is working toward a collaborative workplace simulation that could one day replace physical offices and eliminate commutes. Described as “Skype meets the Empire State Building” their platform is hoping to bring together people to collaborate in a virtual

 ‘face-to-face’ environment via digital avatars. Rather than scheduling Skype calls or chatting over email, remote employees would be able to interact with each other and collaborate on projects as though they were all present in the same place, working on

 the same and multiple screens. Currently the experience is limited by interface technology (particularly headsets) that restricts comfortable use to around 90 minutes. Microsoft recently unveiled a new development for its Holoens 'holoportation' suite, whereby

 it is possible to use a combination of mixed reality and artificial intelligence to deliver a realistic hologram of a speaker and translate their speech into another language - in the case of this demonstration, japanese. Recently a surgeon performed a remote

 operation through utilising 5G internet technology, emphasising that presence is increasingly unnecessary for many jobs, not just white collar office work. Further advances could well see moving between multiple VR environments and the real world becoming

 more seamless, leading to virtual presence being as impactful as real presence and rendering commuting, and owning or renting physical office space redundant for many areas of work.
Primary Article Title: Microsoft has a wild hologram that translates HoloLens keynotes into Japanese
Author: Warren, T
Secondary_URLs:
I tried a VR app meant to replace offices, and it was glorious - Futurism 01/02/2019

Surgeon performs World's first remote operation using '5G Surgery' on animal in China - The Independent 17/01/2019
Keywords: workforce employment employee employer building asset office "virtual reality" VR avatar productivity presence collaboration Skype "Empire State Building" 5G internet surgery surgeon China health "Glimpse Group" headset travel transport communting Microsoft Hololens holoportation hologram "artificial intelligence" "mixed reality" translate language japanese

Summary Sentence: A new web based platform developed by a collaboration between government and the private sector opens the door to better global freshwater ecosystem monitoring.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this partnership as inspiration for how its own monitoring activities could develop in the future. The development also suggests ways in which private enterprise could potentially present a challenge to some

 public sector monitoring programmes. UN Environment, Google and the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre developed a free web based platform to show how water ecosystems are changing over time. The platform utilised Joint Research Centre's expertise

 in satellite data and data analysis, Google expertise in cloud computing and UN Environment’s scientific knowledge. The platform brings together over 11 million images and over 200 public datasets to create a web-based interface that shows 35 years of water

 history, including information for every month. The new platform uses a data mining algorithm—Global Surface Water Explorer. By providing satellite images accompanied by downloadable statistical data and trend analysis, the platform can people understand changes

 in the spatial extent of open water bodies; identify new or lost water bodies; and identify where changes are happening to seasonal water bodies. The app could be practical community level to identify where there may be a problem with freshwater systems, which

 in turn can highlight where more research may be needed. It is hoped to expand the project to air quality and oceans, among other sustainable development topics in the future.
Primary Article Title: Plugging the data gap&%2358; Google, European Commission's Joint Research Centre and UN Environment unveil freshwater monitoring app
Keywords: environmental monitoring data private sector UN "United Nations" "Joint Research Centre" government freshwater ecology data satellite "remote sensing" "open data" algorithm "Global Surface Water Explorer" community app platform web internet "sustainable development"

Summary Sentence: New EU law aims to increase the life of household appliances.
Justification:
The law means that from 2021 manufactures are obliged to make household appliances easier to repair. Improving access to manuals and spares may prolong the life of appliances, reducing the amount of white goods waste so that resources can be used more efficiently.

 However some campaigners believe the law didn’t go far enough due to industry lobbying. The rules mean only professional repairers will have guaranteed access to the spares and manuals. This will prevent independent repairers and consumers accessing the benefits

 and will mean repairing continues to be expensive. Better designed and more easily recycled products could improve the waste treatment of household appliances, reducing the burden on the environment.
Primary Article Title: Right to repair enshrined in EU law
Keywords: circular economy waste pollution recycle EU law legislation electric electronic WEEE industry

Summary Sentence: Levels of salt in rivers and water bodies worldwide is rising, bringing with it concerns for environmental quality and human health.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is a regulator of discharges to water among other interests, and may therefore need to consider the impacts of salt in the wider context of environmental monitoring and protection. Research suggests that “freshwater salinisation

 syndrome” is on the rise across the World. Levels of salt in freshwater are increasing, leading to mobilisation of heavy metals, nutrient pollution and other contaminants that create new "chemical cocktails" in rivers, streams and reservoirs, which present

 a danger to drinking water, wildlife and riverine ecology. The sources of increased salt levels include road salt (sodium chloride). Other salts are found in fertiliser runoff, water softeners, fracking brine and sewage discharges. An increase in impervious

 surfaces also prevent salts being absorbed by soil and contribute to higher levels in water. Another study estimates that future salinity levels could increase 50 per cent by the end of the century, rendering water unsuitable for human use. Proposed solutions

 include considering chemical mixtures and interactions instead of focussing regulation around single chemicals. Practical measures include a more responsible use of road salt, better buffers around water bodies, reducing impervious surfaces and seeking salt

 free alternatives to road building materials which release salts as they break down.
Primary Article Title: More salt in our water is creating scary new `chemical cocktails'
Author: Lohan, T
Secondary_URLs:
Predicting combined effects of land use and climate change on river and stream salinity - Philosphical Transactions of The Royal Society B 03/12/2018

Novel `chemical cocktails' in inland waters are a consequence of the freshwater salinization syndrome - Philosphical Transactions of The Royal Society B 03/12/2018
Keywords: water pollution salt "freshwater salinisation syndrome" "chemical cocktail" "heavy metal" pollutant health drinking water wildlife ecology nutrient fertiliser farming contaminant  fracking wastewater waste regulation climate change

Summary Sentence: Emulsifiers used as food additives may be impacting on anxiety and social behaviour in humans and wildlife.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as a regulator of water treatment and waste management may need to consider if these impacts could manifest from current practices. Emulsifiers are added to food to improve texture and extend shelf life. Research on mice has shown

 that emulsifiers impact on behaviour through causing gut inflammation that triggers local immune cells to produce signalling molecules that can affect tissues in other places, including the brain. What’s more different responses were observed between male

 and female mice, suggesting that gender. Researchers added the emulsifiers, polysorbate 80 and carboxymethylcellulose, to the drinking water of male and female mice. After 12 weeks, they observed that gut microbiota of males and females altered in different

 ways. This could translate into different impacts on behaviour. The ‘gut-brain axis’ is an increasing area of interest for medical research, giving weight to the idea of the gut being a second brain. Changes to gut microbiota can therefore impact on brain

 activity and mental function. The experiment on mice suggests that emulsifiers may induce similar impacts on humans. However there is also a consideration that emulsifiers may not be removed during water treatment, or may enter the environment through food

 waste pathways and represent an additional chemical based stress for wildlife.
Primary Article Title: Emulsifiers may promote anxiety-related behaviours, make one less social
Secondary_URLs: Dietary emulsifiers consumption alters anxiety-like and social-related behaviors in mice in a sex-dependent manner - Nature 17/01/2019
Keywords: health food additive emulsifier brain but microbiome anxiety behaviour bacteria mice pollution pollutant water quality water treatment waste compost land regulation "polysorbate 80" carboxymethylcellulose animal wildlife monitoring

Summary Sentence: New developments from Apple suggest that the technology company sees future business opportunities stemming from climate change and environmental incidents.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be mindful of these developments that offer an insight into the future of incident management and environmental monitoring, as well as the potential for partnership or competition in key business areas. Recent

 developments have seen other technology companies, including Google, venturing into air quality monitoring (%2314849), water quality monitoring (MIGHT ADD THIS AS AN HSDBi ARTICLE,) and flood forecasting (%2315059). According to recent filings to CDP, an environmental

 impact assessment company, Apple sees itself benefitting from the extreme weather effects of climate change as mobile communication becomes important during these events. Customers may have an increasing need for “confidence and preparedness”, which Apple

 products such as the iPhone can help fulfill. Users may increasingly value immediate and reliable communications with emergency services and loved ones. Phones can provide emergency aid instructions, plus light and sound to attract attention, and can be kept

 charged with minimal energy use. Apple has also recently filed a patent for a poisonous gas sensor that is integral to a smartphone or smart device, just as GPS is today. The sensor is made from a silicon-based substrate with gas sensing electrodes on top.

 A third filtering layer would only let in gases of interest, which could include sulphur dioxide, methane, and carbon monoxide (CO). While this sensor seems to have been developed as a survival device (carbon monoxide kills around 50 people per year in the

 UK and hospitalises hundreds more), it may also have application as a passive air quality sensor. If fitted as standard, as GPS is these days then it could open up the potential of millions of air quality sensors that would give a more detailed picture of

 air pollution that could be of interest to environmental regulators. However there may be issues around data sharing, and intellectual access, and even the potential of private companies offering a competing ‘service’ of air quality monitoring and reporting,

 bringing into question who is the authoritative voice on some environmental issues.
Primary Article Title: Apple is working on tech that'd let your iPhone detect poison
Secondary_URLs:
Two men dead from suspected carbon monoxide poisoning in London - The Guardian 08/04/2018

One of Apple's next health sensors for iDevices could save your life by detecting invisible deadly gases - Patently Apple 24/01/2019

Apple thinks climate change disasters will increase Its brand value - Motherboard 21/03/2019
Keywords: technology smartphone Apple iPhone "climate change" incident flood disaster light communication energy emergency monitoring "air quality" air pollution pollutant "carbon monoxide" patent "sulphur dioxide"  SO2 methane GPS sensor regulation "citizen science" data government

Summary Sentence: Calyxt’s soybean oil might be the first gene-edited food to reach the U.S. market following the U.S. Department of Agriculture announcement that genetically edited crops don’t require any additional oversight.
Justification:
A US food service company has started using an oil made from genetically edited soybeans in its sauces, dressings, and fryer, which is claimed to have health benefits, although the name of the company has not been revealed. The agriculture company Calyxt

 used gene editing to deactivate two genes in soybean to create a soybean oil with no trans fats and fats that are believed to be more healthy than those found in traditional soybean oils. The oil also has the economic benefit of a longer shelf life.
Primary Article Title: The first gene-edited food has reached US restaurants
Author: KRISTIN HOUSER
Keywords: Gene editing, Food, Health Benefits

Summary Sentence:
Although pesticides are typically regarded as negligible sources of nutrients, this study suggests that the recent and rapid rise in glyphosate use, which contains a small amount of phosphorus, has magnified its relative importance as a source P to soils

 and watercourses
Justification:
Regulations to limit phosphorus pollution have focused on fertilisers that remain the largest artificial source of phosphorus. However, the global use of glyphosate has increased 15-fold in the past two decades resulting in the herbicide's relatively small

 phosphorus (P) content starting to add up, reaching levels comparable to other sources, such as detergents, which are of concern to regulators. Glyphosate's capacity to degrade rapidly is often used to argue against potential toxicological effects, but the

 P it contains persists in the environment and can influence soil P accumulation and losses to surrounding freshwater systems. In some catchments, decades of phosphorus-based fertilizer use have led to a saturation of the soil's capacity to hold the nutrient,

 increasing the likelihood that any additional phosphorus applied to the land will run off into waterways. The study's authors suggest glyphosate inputs should be considered in P assessments and the management of catchments with significant levels of arable

 farming.
Primary Article Title: The overlooked impact of rising glyphosate use on phosphorus loading in agricultural watersheds
Publisher: Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment
Author: Marie‐Pier Hébert  Vincent Fugère  Andrew Gonzalez
Keywords: Eutrophication, Phosphorus, Pesticides, Glyphosate

Summary Sentence: The impacts of automation on the workplace will not be felt evenly across society, according to recent findings.
Justification: This should be of interest to the Environment Agency as it may present both challenges and opportunities for workplace diversity. One recent piece of US focussed research from the Brookings Institution suggests that automation is likely to impact non-white, less economically secure workers more. The task based research indicated that around between 44 and 47 per cent of tasks performed by Hispanic, Black and Native American workers could be automated over the next twenty years, compared to 40 per cent of tasks performed by white workers. Youth was also a factor with younger workers aged between 16 and 24 likely to have half their tasks automated over the same period. The research also identified men as slightly more likely to be impacted by automation than women. Another piece of research conducted by PWC drew similar conclusions. PWC identified three waves of automation, each of which would impact on workplace demographics in different ways. The first ‘algorithm wave’ (automation of simple computational tasks and analysis of structured data) and second ‘augmentation wave’ (automation of repeatable tasks, exchanging information through dynamic technological support, and statistical analysis of unstructured data) are most likely to impact on women, who tend to work in process led tasks. However as the third ‘autonomy wave’ (automation that involves problem solving in dynamic real-world situations with responsive actions) arrives, men are more likely to be replaced as women find work on roles more suited to the characteristics of caring and empathy. While both these forecasts are based on technological capability, rather than political or legislative drivers that could temper or counteract the impacts of automation, any workplace planning activities may need to be mindful that there is significant potential for demographic disruption from artificial intelligence, machine learning and robotics. Indeed, a further piece of economic analysis looking at the economic impacts of automation between 1993 and 2007 provides verifiable evidence that this trend may in fact already well underway. In the first economic analysis of the contribution of industrial robots across 17 countries investigators found that their introduction into the workplace had reduced the market share of low-skilled workers. To the extent that social minority groups are over represented in this group, they may be being disproportionately impacted. The research didn’t find a reduction in the total number of people employed though, suggesting that anxieties that automation might lead to higher rates of joblessness overall may be unfounded.
Primary Article Title: Robots will take jobs from men, the young and minorities
Author: Simonite, T
