Summary Sentence: For the first time in the history of capitalism the World is moving en masse towards less efficient sources of energy.
Justification:
The implications of this trend are huge, transcending concerns for environmental regulation and protection, and highlight that a significant shift in how policymakers need to consider issues such as climate change, unemployment and productivity as one issue,

 rather than in isolation. As the global population grows and the economy with it, there is an increasing demand for energy to power everything from agriculture to infrastructure to entertainment. Every energy source currently employed on Earth uses energy

 in its extraction and transportation - for example something needs to power the machinery that drills the oil well. This energy is measured by the Energy Return On Investment (EROI). A high EROI means that a high ratio of energy is produced in relation to

 the energy put into the production. EROI for fossil fuels such as oil and gas have historically been reasonably high. However over time average EROI has started to fall, meaning that it is becoming increasingly energy inefficient to extract these sources.

 Renewable sources of energy including PV, wind and biomass, with the exception of hydropower, have a relatively low average EROI&%2358; this is also falling, implying that fossil fuel use is implicit in mineral extraction, manufacturing and distribution of renewable

 sources such as PV and wind (which often rely on rare metals and minerals for components). Despite producing a better quality electricity with fewer externalities (such as pollution and climate change) the EROI of renewables is complicated by the intermittent

 nature of production. Overall the ‘sink costs’ of the current economic system are not being addressed by that system. Recent volatility in political and economic systems is seen to have a root cause in ecological systems. As the ecological and economic costs

 of industrial overconsumption continue to rise, as indicated by EROI, economic growth is placed in jeopardy, in turn, creating political strain. Yet these external costs aren’t acknowledged by current economic models. Other models such as a ‘postcapitalism’

 (%2313391) based on an emancipation of labour through technology-centric solutions also require an exponential growth of energy demand. The only sustainable solution therefore is for any economic transition to involve lowering energy use through reductions in

 construction and transport and more localised production of goods and services. Such a move can only be seen to happen through concerted efforts at government level where economic activity is driven by a focus on ‘living a good life’ rather than profit. Such

 a political move would be likely to impact on all areas of government work, including the Environment Agency’s approach to regulation and flood management.
Primary Article Title: This is how UN scientists are preparing for the end of capitalism
Author: Ahmed, N
Secondary_URLs: EROI of different fuels and the implications for society - Energy Policy 01/01/2014
Keywords: energy economics "energy return on investment" EROI sustainability growth government market transition postcapitalism "climate change" pollution PV wind hydropower "fossil fuel" oil gas coal mineral metal regulation flooding flood management

Summary Sentence: One UK energy company is about to make energy completely free and unlimited to customers - in exchange for more data on their usage habits.
Justification:
This new arrangement has the potential to disrupt the energy sector significantly, and may lead to increased energy use, with the associated environmental impacts such as increased greenhouse gas emissions. 2019 is touted as the year where an energy company

 will offer customers a ‘bundle’ energy deal, where they can have unlimited electricity usage in exchange for installing monitoring devices that track usage with increased granularity than previously seen. This data is made accessible to the energy company

 develop more efficient operations and improve demand predictions, which save them money. While it is instinctive to think that this arrangement may lead to increased energy consumption, the opposite may occur. The increased flow of data could help energy companies

 to better target customers with energy saving information and even devices. Third parties may also be able to deliver similar services through access to the data. It remains to be seen if customers will be encouraged to share more data with their energy companies,

 but if such a scheme is accepted by consumers it could revolutionise current business models around energy services. It has previously been suggested that an alternative business model based on device need rather than energy demand could also reduce use, but

 this would require users to relinquish some privacy and autonomy to energy companies (%2312058 ), similar to what may about to be realised in the UK.
Primary Article Title: In 2019, an energy giant will offer free, all-you-can-eat electricity
Author: wwelser, W
Keywords: energy electricity utility utilities "energy company" data monitoring "smart meter" analysis efficiency autonomy privacy regulation "greenhouse gas" 2019 IOT "internet of things"

Summary Sentence: Scientists in Finland have developed a new wood based material that could replace clothing materials like cotton and synthetic fibres.
Justification:
The material is called Loncell and is made from waste wood, recycled newspaper, cardboard and old cotton textiles. It is much less environmentally damaging than conventional textiles. By contrast the fashion industry causes 10% of global carbon emissions

 and uses nearly 70 million barrels of oil each year to make polyester fibres, which can take more than 200 years to decompose. Plastic microfibres from synthetic clothing are also part of the problem of human-made materials that wash up along ocean shores.

 It is thought that materials like loncell may be a more realistic mechanism for addressing the environmental impact of fashion as people are generally unlikely to reduce clothing consumption as fashions change. The Environment Agency should be interested in

 this development as a regulator of both the waste, paper and textile sector, as it could bring significant changes to all.
Primary Article Title: Wooden clothes on the recycled Christmas list?
Author: Pickles, M
Keywords: waste resources textile wood cotton polyester clothes clothing fashion consumer plastic microfibre microplastic synthetic loncell newspaper cardboard regulation behaviour

Summary Sentence: An newly devised iron based molecule could function as a photocatalyst for fuel production and for use in photovoltaic (PV) cells.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as currently renewable energy technology is heavily reliant on rare earth metals and minerals. Replacing these with a substance as ubiquitous as iron may allay concerns about resource consumption

 and waste management. Photocatalysts rely on molecules known as metal complexes that currently often contain rare metals such as iridium, ruthenium and osmium. Research into advance molecule design has shown that it is possible to replace rare metals with

 iron. The researchers believe that their iron molecule has potential as a photocatalyst for solar fuel production, either as hydrogen from water or methanol from carbon dioxide. The new molecule also has potential applications in light emitting diodes (LEDs).
Primary Article Title: Brilliant iron molecule could provide cheaper solar energy
Secondary_URLs: Luminescence and reactivity of a charge-transfer excited iron complex with nanosecond lifetime - Science 18/01/2019
Keywords: energy waste catalyst irion molecule metal resource iridium osmium ruthenium rare earth hydrogen methanol "carbon dioxide" photovoltaic PV solar fuel photocatalyst LED regulation

Summary Sentence: Examples of bacteria based protein production that consume less resources than conventional means are emerging.
Justification:
Development of technologies like this could become crucial to global food production with far reaching implications for current farming practices and land management and therefore has significance for the Environment Agency. One food startup backed by

 US food giants is working on cultivating protein from a bacteria first discovered in the volcanic hot springs of Yellowstone National Park. The bacteria would be fermented in a similar manner to beer, and the protein collected through further processing. Another

 company based in Finland has started producing bioprotein using only wind power, air and water. Solar Foods uses wind power to electrolyse water, combining the resultant hydrogen with carbon dioxide to produce methane, and hope to be producing on a commercial

 scale by 2021. The methane is then fed to a protein producing bacteria. Solar Foods claim that their approach is 10 times more efficient than current photosynthesis processes that produce plant based protein sources such as soy. Despite the positive environmental

 credentials of such a scheme, success will no doubt rely on consumer acceptance.
Primary Article Title: Solar Foods readies hydrogen-to-protein pilot
Author: Deign, J
Secondary_URLs:
A food startup backed by 2 industry giants is diving into the alt-meat market with a 'super protein' enabled by a discovery in Yellowstone's volcanic hot springs - Business Insider 04/02/2019

How engineers are turning wind into protein to alleviate world hunger - Interesting Engineering 28/02/2019

Summary Sentence: New developments in materials science suggest a more sustainable future of the construction industry.
Justification:
Such developments may impact on the Environment Agency’s own endeavours towards a sustainable construction and maintenance of its assets, including hard flood defences. Researchers in South Africa have developed a process for manufacturing bio-bricks from

 urine. The bricks are created through a natural process called microbial carbonate precipitation, similar to how seashells are formed. Loose sand is colonised with a bacteria that produce the enzyme urase, which breaks down urine to produce calcium carbonate,

 cementing the sand into whatever shape is required. By-products include nitrogen and potassium, which could be reused in fertliser manufacturing. Conventional bricks are energy intensive, requiring a kiln-firing, whereas bio-bricks can be produced at room

 temperature. There are currently practical issues around collection and social acceptance of urine based bricks that may block realisation for the meantime. In the USA scientists have developed a material that reacts with carbon dioxide to grow, strengthen

 and repair itself. The polymer made from aminopropyl methacrylamide (APMA) performs a similar process to how plants incorporate CO2 to grow. The material doesn’t require fossil fuels for manufacture and could have a range of applications. It is not yet strong

 enough for building applications but it could have a use in repairing cracks and damage. Creating construction materials like these that utilise plentiful resources without the energy and resource footprint of conventional construction materials may become

 more important when framed against the need to move towards a circular economy with sustainable resource use.
Primary Article Title: World-first&%2358; bio-bricks from urine
Author: Swingler, H
Secondary_URLs: Self-healing material can build itself from carbon in the air - MIT 11/10/2018
Keywords: construction building chemistry resources waste urine brick asset carbon dioxide self healing cement bio-brick sand bacteria enzyme urase "microbial carbonate precipitation" seashell fertliser nitrogen potassium energy "South Africa" carbon CO2 gel polymer repair maintenance "circular economy" "aminopropyl methacrylamide" APMA sustainable flooding

Summary Sentence: Hollywood is embracing the hologram.
Justification:
As the ability to manipulate sound and vision digitally increases so does the need for performers to embrace the digitally generated world. This is leading to an emerging industry within entertainment. There is already a need for digital post production

 to ‘de-age’ actors, and recent films such as Star Wars and Fast and Furious digitally recreated deceased actors who played iconic roles within each franchise. Actors are apparently digitally preserving themselves (or at least highly accurate visual representations

 of themselves) so that they are still able to perform in the future, even if they die. This is not limited just to film - a hologram representation of deceased singer Amy Winehouse is set to tour in the near future to raise money for a charity established

 in her memory. The technologies at the cutting edge of entertainment tend to trickle down to the masses overtime as costs fall. Technologies such as Microsoft’s Hololens (%2313878) are already using representations of real people in their virtual reality (VR)

 environments. And the digital material that people generate over a lifetime such as emails, social media posts and photographs could be mined by algorithms to create a representation of that person’s intelligence (%2313539). Together these developments present

 possibilities for knowledge based businesses to divorce people and their intelligence from geography and time, allowing them to access both even if people are incapacitated or may no longer be associated with that business. Whilst this idea certainly raises

 questions around data protection and ethics, it could also mean that business knowledge lost through retirement, redundancy and other workforce disruptions could be maintained and extracted easily through conversational means, and would mean that any loss

 of knowledge and expertise through real world workforce shrinkage would be bolstered by a cohort of experienced virtual staff.
Primary Article Title: Actors are digitally preserving themselves to continue their careers beyond the grave
Author: Winick, E
Secondary_URLs:
Amy Winehouse is coming back as a `hologram' for a 2019 world tour - Digital Trends 14/10/2018

Meet the company resurrecting dead celebrities and digitally cloning living ones - Digital Trends 28/10/2018

Summary Sentence: A substance similar to THC found in cannabis has been identified in liverwort.
Justification:
The substance called perrottetinene exhibits analgesic and anti-inflammatory properties which may be superior to those of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), currently used for some medicinal conditions centred around pain relief. Cannabis and Radula perrottetii

 liverwort are the only two plants producing psychoactive cannabinoids, which whilst can give people a ‘high’ in large doses, has pain relieving properties in low doses. Perrottetinene however appears to have a weaker psychoactive effect but be more potent

 in offering pain relief. As liverwort only grows naturally in New Zealand, Japan and Costa Rica and large amounts of perrottetinene were required for the experiments the chemical was produced via synthesis methods, suggesting that any commercial development

 would not involve the same agricultural impacts of commercial cannabis production. The interest in cannabinoids in medical and recreational use is growing. The UK has now allowed doctors to prescribe medical cannabis, and the World Health Organisation is advocating

 a rescheduling of cannabis under International drug treaties. With the possibility of wider cannabinoid use there is also a potential for environmental impact, particularly to the aquatic environment, as the impacts of other narcotics (including cannabis)

 (%2314955) and painkillers such as ibuprofen (%2311111) suggest. The Environment Agency and partners should therefore be mindful of the potential impacts of new pharmaceutical impacts with potential mass use as they progress towards realisation.
Primary Article Title: Liverwort could prove to be more medically effective than cannabis, research suggests
Secondary_URLs:
World Health Organization recommends reclassifying marijuana under international treaties - forbes 01/02/2019

Doctors can prescribe medical cannabis from November in UK - BBC 22/02/2019

Uncovering the psychoactivity of a cannabinoid from liverworts associated with a legal high - Science Advances 24/10/2018
Keywords: chemical health medicine regulation water water treatment cannabis cannabinoid THC tetrahydrocannabinol "Radula perrottetii" liverwort Perrottetinene narcotic synthesis farming agriculture "New Zealand" Japan "Costa Rica"  aquatic wildlife medicine medical health fish analgesic anti-inflammatory UK WHO

Summary Sentence: A Canadian start-up is attempting to harness the power of bacteria to turn food waste into a cheap biodegradable plastic suitable for everyday use.
Justification:
The Toronto company, called Genecis, uses bacterial action to turn kitchen waste into compostable, biocompatible plastics called PHAs (polyhydroxyalkanoates). PHA is already on the market and used in medical applications ranging from heart valves to dissolving

 sutures. It is normally made from food crops such as sugarcane and corn, which makes production costs greater than using fossil fuels. Genecis hope to address this issue through using food waste as the raw material. Food waste is first processed by other bacteria

 to break it down into digestible pieces. The plastic making bacteria then consume this was, creating PHAs as ‘body fat’ essentially. The PHA is then extracted from the bacteria and converted into pellets which can then be used in conventional plastic production.

 The company is looking to soon move from a laboratory setting to a large scale test production plant in the near future. The Environment Agency should be interested in this development. There is currently a great deal of interest in reducing single use plastics,

 and solutions such as this are therefore a potentially attractive prospect. However diverting food waste plastics production could deprive other potential routes of feedstock, such as incineration for energy, anaerobic digestion (AD) for gas energy production

 and nutrient return via composting and waste to land.
Primary Article Title: Greener straws? Bacteria help turn food waste into compostable plastic
Author: Chung, E
Keywords: waste plastic bacteria food corn sugar PHA polyhydroxyalkanoates Genecis Canada Toronto biodegradable "anaerobic digestion" AD incineration energy EfW compost farming agriculture nutrient regulation

Summary Sentence: A new form of political alignment is emerging, based on geography rather than social class, and central to this is the economic productivity of urban areas.
Justification:
Many have previously foreseen the technological developments of the third industrial revolution as agents to free people from conventional notions of when and where work ‘happens’. In a recent academic paper, respected futurist Andrew Curry makes the case

 that despite the availability of technology, urban areas are growing like never before. Because people are free to choose where and how they work, talented people (particularly younger workers) are opting to live in cities where a ‘thick’ labour market and

 high population density and diversity promotes knowledge exchange and innovation - Google’s focus on quality physical work environments is cited as an example of this paradox. The benefits of the urban economy are found to trickle beyond the knowledge economy

 and into less skilled aspects of the workforce. Even ‘the precariat’ )characterised by job and social insecurity and a lack of work based identity), exemplified by ‘gig economy’ workers tend to accept lifestyle impacts to remain close to the urban networks

 that provide income. This can be seen to be reflected in recent polling data from UK (EU Exit referendum), though the indications of a longer‐term divide emerging between citizens residing in locations strongly connected to global growth and those who are

 not goes back much further (2005). USA (presidential election) and beyond also show that progressive and inclusive voting tendencies were strongly associated with urban productivity, regardless of socioeconomic status - though youth did have some influence.

 This is thought to represent the cusp of a political transition from materialist to post-materialist values across the generations. There are several potential future implications that may manifest. Urban areas are likely to maintain economic inertia. However

 the cost of living may be a limiting factor which may see urban areas with high graduate concentrations such as Bristol, Manchester and Leeds in the UK become increasingly important economic centres (this could also lead to increased population pressures in

 satellite settlements, as exemplified by the reported youth based ‘renaissance’ of places like Margate and Halifax. In Ireland the economic pressure of high living costs in Dublin have seen 1,000 civil servants (equivalent to 1 in 16) apply for transfers out

 of Dublin in the past 12 months. Political change may come from demographic change. The demographic weight of younger voters, combined with a progressive political agenda could see new political movements emerge with a swell of support for policies that reject

 the neo-liberal agenda of ‘competitiveness and growth for more socially cohesive ideas. The growing economic and political weight of cities may lead to more alliances that bypass national governments in order to promote more progressive agendas, as exemplified

 by the C40 cities and The Carbon Neutral Cities Alliance (%2314489) taking action on climate change. Another writer sees the growing importance of cities leading to a disintegration of national borders. Half the World’s population is already urban, and the economic,

 social and cultural connections we have to urban areas are often far more impactful on our lives than national issues. Political borders often align with economic, social and cultural borders, further highlighting how borders could shift to have more city

 or regional influence. We may therefore have more administrative borders, but with greater freedom of movement between them as cities are more likely to see the value in collaboration. Nations may still have some role in terms over fiscal and military policy.

 There is little mention of the fate of rural areas within these articles. One may conclude that the countryside’s fate is sealed in terms of economic competition, though there are some suggestions that current planning restrictions may be impacting on the

 growth and sustainability of rural communities, further promoting the growth of urban economies. There are implications for resource planning and likely locations of environmental pressures for the Environment Agency. There may also be interest in terms of

 recruitment and attracting new talent. The increasing autonomy of city and regional at a political level may also suggest that the Environment Agency may be able to achieve more of its strategic objectives through local partnering, rather than national level

 initiatives.
Primary Article Title: The city, the country, and the new politics of place
Author: Curry, A

Summary Sentence: A student has devised a way to store digital information in the form of a chemical powder.
Justification:
This development suggests alternative ways that digital storage can be resourced, other than rare metals and minerals, which has implications for waste reuse and recycling. Currently large quantities of heavy metals are needed to manufacture storage devices

 such as USB sticks and hard drives. At the same time servers require large quantities of energy to function. In an attempt to explore alternatives, student Annelies Landuyt at Ghent University has been experimenting with a process for storing data chemically,

 in the form of a powder. Using biochemical analysis and bespoke computer programs the students were able to read text and QR codes from encoded powder, and translate these into e.g. a web address. This is still in early stages of development, but seen alongside

 other developments such as DNA data storage (%2313922), exotic particles (%2315007) and even light (%2314906), biochemical data storage may suggest a future route for low energy, low resource digital storage needs.
Primary Article Title: A USB stick? In the distant future, a little powder should suffice
Secondary_URLs: Multifunctional sequence-defined macromolecules for chemical data storage - Nature 26/10/2018
Keywords: waste resources data electronics WEEE storage DNA light exotic particles powder chemistry biochemical analysis QR code text "heavy metal" mineral manufacturing server USB stick hard drive digital computer hardware Ghent "Annelies Landuyt" energy cost

Summary Sentence: Using a synthetic rabbit gene, scientists have engineered a house plant that can remove pollutants from the air.
Justification:
The houseplants have been engineered so that they can remove the pollutants chloroform and benzene. The plants have so far only been used in the lab and will need further testing to see if they can replicate the process in a house. The researchers chose

 pothos ivy as the plant to use as it is easy to grow and is unlikely to flower in a temperate region. This reduces the risk of modified genes being spread by pollination if they are only used in temperate areas. Further research is being planned to see if

 the concept can be used for other pollutants such as formaldehyde by using different genes. Although only at the concept stage, if engineered plants such as these become more widespread, without proper controls there is a risk their genes could be spread.

 It is unclear what implications any cross breeding with native plants could have.
Primary Article Title: Scientists have combined a house plant with a rabbit gene
Keywords: GM genetic modification synthetic biotechnology innovation plant health air pollution biofilter exposure toxin toxic

Summary Sentence: Plant based alternatives to plastic are not always better for the environment.
Justification:
Plastic pollution is a worldwide problem that has been receiving more and more attention from both public and governments. Greater awareness of the environmental and human health implications of plastic is driving research into improving recycling and reuse

 as well as finding alternatives to plastic. Bioplastics such as polylactide are based on renewable plant biomass such as maize and switchgrass. Although the feedstock is renewable unlike traditional plastic, there will be trade-offs in terms of the land and

 water that will need to be used to continually produce these. In addition to this the temperature needed to biodegrade polylactide means that it is unlikely to biodegrade in the average household compost heap. Consequently this does not help with the problem

 of plastic waste persistence. Using alternatives as feedstock such as waste biomass, for example crop residues, could make bioplastics more sustainable. The authors suggest the best policy currently is for governments to promote the use of plastic sparingly

 and to focus on improving waste treatment.
Primary Article Title: More bioplastics do not necessarily contribute to climate change mitigation
Keywords: plastic waste treatment pollution water land air renewable sustainable sustainability security food climate global warming degrade

Summary Sentence: A US startup has developed a biological process to create animal free gelatine.
Justification:
This is an example of a growing number of companies offering chemically identical, animal free products that collectively challenge the future of the livestock industry, and therefore may impact on agriculture and its regulation. The company, called Geltor,

 grows the protein collagen in a laboratory without any need for animals. Collagen is used in foods, cosmetics, musical instrument strings and is a constituent of gelatine. Geltor takes carbon, nitrogen and oxygen and converts them into collagen using microbial

 fermentation. Note that this isn’t a collagen substitute, but collagen itself, chemically identical to the livestock derived substance The company sees itself as offering a sustainable alternative to the livestock industry and hopes to tap into the growing

 interest in vegan food and products. There are already solutions out there for lab grown meat (eg %2314245) and leather (%2314625). Geltor therefore contributes to the idea that there’s little that cannot be derived from non animal sources that the livestock industry

 currently provides.
Primary Article Title: Lab-grown gelatin is the fake food of the future, one start-up believes
Author: Colville, W
Keywords: food farming agriculture regulation livestock meat gelatine leather microbiology "synthetic biology" collagen cosmetic industry biocehmistry fermentation carbon nitrogen oxygen US Geltor

Summary Sentence: New battery technology may provide power and absorb industrial carbon dioxide simultaneously.
Justification:
The Environment Agency May need to consider how this development could impact on regulating carbon capture and storage (CCS). The lithium-based battery absorbs carbon dioxide (CO2) into a water-based amine called 2-ethoxyethylamine. This is mixed with

 a non-aqueous liquid electrolyte, alongside a carbon cathode and a lithium anode. Every time the battery discharges the carbon dioxide builds up as a solid mineral carbonate on the cathode. The inert carbonate can then be used as a source of carbon for industrial

 purposes. The system has the potential to overcome problems of current CCS technology, namely the energy costs in deploying them.
Primary Article Title: MIT unveils early-stage carbon-eating battery
Author: Deign, J
Secondary_URLs: Tailoring the Discharge Reaction in Li-CO2 Batteries through Incorporation of CO2 Capture Chemistry - Joule 21/09/2018
Keywords: energy regulation power industry battery "energy storage" "carbon dioxide" CO2 "carbon capture and storage" CCS cathode anode chemical chemistry mineral carbonate chemical amine 2-ethoxyethylamine non-aqueous liquid electrolyte carbon lithium

Summary Sentence: Adapting to a low carbon economy may promote significant economic growth.
Justification:
Energy, cities, food and land use, water and industry, are the sectors explored in this report. It discusses ways to speed up the adoption in these areas to access the economic benefits quicker. Investment and infrastructure development in the next few years

 will play an important role in society’s ability to limit climate change as well as adapt to the changes we cannot alter. The benefits of a low carbon economy are demonstrated so that governments and business can see the finical gains that can be made with

 these changes. The four areas that are thought to be most important for governments, business and finance to prioritise are&%2358; carbon pricing and disclosing climate related risk; acceleration of investment in sustainable infrastructure; utilise the private sector

 and innovation; ensure equality of change for all.
Primary Article Title: Low-carbon growth is a $26 trillion opportunity
Keywords: climate change global warming economy money finance investment government wealth growth adaptation adapt green low carbon

Summary Sentence:
All the data including size-resolved viability and time-resolved bacterial aerosol dynamics together with their growth conditions detected in the air suggested that airborne bacteria in the size range of 0.56- 1μm could have played important roles for

 haze formation in Beijing. The results about time- and size-resolved bacterial aerosol dynamics from this work provide a fresh understanding of aerosol chemistry especially in highly polluted air.
Justification: Furthers understanding of air pollution.
Primary Article Title: Time and size resolved bacterial aerosol dynamics in highly polluted air&%2358; new clues for haze formation mechanism
Author: Ting Zhang, Xinyue Li, Minfei Wang, Haoxuan Chen, Maosheng Yao
Keywords: Bacteria feed and multiply in polluted air and may be exacerbating smog. Air samples collected reveal that particles of bacteria were far larger and more numerous when  the haze was bad than at other times.

Summary Sentence: Further examples of applications demonstrate how robots and machine learning could impact on the workplace.
Justification:
Some of these could have direct implications for the Environment Agency’s current remit around environmental regulation and site inspection. Anybiotics have recently trialled their Anymal quadruped robot to complete an autonomous inspection of world's

 largest offshore converter platform at a North Sea wind farm. After spending time to learn and map its surroundings, Anymal conducted a site inspection, checking 16 inspection points, some of which included levers, oil levels, thermal measurements, gauges,

 and water levels. In Japan a new cafe has opened staffed entirely by robots. The robots however are controlled remotely by humans with people with paralysis. This project demonstrates how robotic technology could give independence and access to people who

 may be currently prevented from engaging with the workplace. The idea of remote controlled robots to perform tasks is also being explored by a Japanese company called Mira Robotics that has developed a unit that can be operated by a human to fold laundry.

 A Stanford University study has demonstrated that machine learning could be a valuable tool for resource-pressured environmental regulators. In an experiment based on past infraction data, modelling showed that machine learning was twice as likely to predict

 violations of environmental permits compared to humans, and therefore could be a useful tool in deploying constrained resources.
Primary Article Title: Stanford students deploy machine learning to aid environmental monitoring
Author: Jordan, R
