Summary Sentence: Several companies around the world are entering the cannabis sector - for both recreational and medicinal uses.
Justification:
As well as Altria (maker's of Marlboro cigarettes), Coca Cola and Corona beer, Imperial tobacco are investing in a UK biotech company called 'Oxford Cannabinoid Technologies'. Whilst Canada is only the second country in the world to legalise cannabis,

 the level of investment in research both around the world and in particular in the UK, suggests that early consideration of the regulatory and environmental impacts of cannabis production could be warranted. In the US, cannabis growers are deploying IOT (internet

 of things) technologies to make the greenhouses used in cannabis production more power, water and nutrient efficient. As a potentially valuable, but environmentally challenging, crop the Environment Agency should consider the implications before widespread

 production occurs in the UK.
Primary Article Title: Cannabis firm confirms investment talks with Marlboro maker
Secondary_URLs: Cannabis Growers Embrace IOT for Energy Efficiency - gtm 14/12/2018
Keywords: cannabis tobacco Marlboro Imperial Coca-Cola farming agriculture crops energy "internet of things" IOT "energy efficiency" "recreational cannabis" "medicinal cannabis"

Summary Sentence: In Yorkshire, water bills based on meter readings have increased by up to 35 per cent making water unaffordable for some.
Justification:
For the poorest families, water bill arrears are now the most common form of debt. The number of people now on reduced rates because they cannot afford their bills has risen by 50 per cent in the last year equating to 400,000 people. As periods of drought

 become more prevalent across the UK as a result of climate change, the cost of water could rise even further making water resources a luxury that only the wealthy can afford.
Primary Article Title: Water bill 'too expensive' to flush toilet
Keywords: water "water resources" affordability "water meters" "water bills" poverty debt "human rights" "climate change" drought monopolies

Summary Sentence: An online game helped students sort waste more accurately - improving their accuracy even when gaming stopped.
Justification:
The experiment used a simple game that gave players different types of waste and the option of four different disposal methods. If they choose the wrong method, they were shown the correct choice. Immediate feedback is proven to aid learning and improve

 task performance. After feedback was removed from the game, participants continued to improve their score demonstrating that the effects of gamification can be long term. Given the complexity of current recycling rules in the UK, games such as this could provide

 the support needed to improve recycling rates - especially amongst the younger generations who could develop better awareness and complicity for life.
Primary Article Title: Online game trains players how to sort waste correctly
Secondary_URLs: Providing immediate feedback improves recycling and composting accuracy. - Journal of Environmental Management 20/12/2018
Keywords: waste recycling gamification refuse rubbish "waste disposal" landfill education training

Summary Sentence: Hypoxia is usually associated with coastal waters, however new research suggests that hypoxic dead zones also occur in nutrient rich urban streams.
Justification:
In the US it has been found that intense storm flows erode stream channels creating deeper pools that trap nutrient rich water. The bacteria in this water consumes more dissolved oxygen resulting in hypoxia until the next storm flushes the pools out. Hypoxia

 results in the death of fish and other aquatic animals as reported in some coastal waters. Furthermore, the growth of algae that supports stream food webs was also slower where streams are vulnerable to storm flows. While this study reflects the situation

 with small streams fed by urban watersheds, the research team suggest this has wider applicability through dam building and dam removal. Natural flood defences that reduce the flow of water by creating artificial pools of water could potentially be affected

 by this problem if they are on watersheds impacted by high nutrient release.
Primary Article Title: Hypoxic dead zones found in urban streams, not just at the coast
Secondary_URLs: Scoured or suffocated&%2358; Urban stream ecosystems oscillate between hydrologic and dissolved oxygen extremes. - Limnology and Oceanography 03/12/2018
Keywords: hypoxia water "water quality" streams storms run-off watershed urban nutrients pollution "dead zones" fish aquatics

Summary Sentence: This review sets the range of climate change impacts on human health, food, water, economy, infrastructure and security, including drought, heatwaves, wildfires, precipitatio, floods, storms, sea level rise and changes in ocean chemistry.
Justification:
This systematic review details the 467 ways of how climate hazards have already had an impact set out in the peer reviewed literature. The analysis suggests that ongoing climate change will pose a rising threat to humanity that will be greatly aggravated

 if substantial and timely reductions of greenhouse gas emissions are not achieved. The study predicts that by 2100 the number of hazards occurring concurrently will increase, making it more difficult to manage these pressures. Even under strong mitigation

 scenarios, increasing cumulative exposure to the multitude of climate hazards will impact countries, particularly in tropical coastal areas.
Primary Article Title: Broad threat to humanity from cumulative climate hazards intensified by greenhouse gas emissions
Author:
Review Article | Published: 19 November 2018

Broad threat to humanity from cumulative climate hazards intensified by greenhouse gas emissions
Camilo Mora, Daniele Spirandelli, Erik C. Franklin, John Lynham, Michael B. Kantar, Wendy Miles, Charlotte Z.
Keywords: Climate Change

Summary Sentence: Sixty nine different medications have been found in river dwelling insects in an Australian study.
Justification:
Insects from six waterways in the Melbourne area were tested for pharmaceuticals. The different medications found within the insects included antidepressants, antibiotics and painkillers as well as many other types. The highest levels of contamination were

 found in insects at wastewater outfalls, however even those from pristine environments such as a national park still contained some level of contamination. It is thought that underwater larvae ingest the pharmaceuticals, which then accumulate in the insects

 such as spiders and fish that consume them. There are some small studies that suggest there could be impacts on organism health, but far more needs to be understood, including what impacts combinations of pharmaceuticals could have. The highly populated cities

 of the UK, together with an aging population, could mean that levels of pharmaceuticals particularly near wastewater treatment outfalls could be at similar or even higher levels.
Primary Article Title: More than 60 prescription drugs are getting into river foodchains
Keywords: pharma drug river water quality monitor waste wastewater treatment pollution health biodiversity contaminate

Summary Sentence: Plants may experience nitrogen deficiency in a warming climate which would affect their ability to absorb CO2 and produce protein.
Justification:
A lot has been published about the impacts of excess nitrogen from modern farming on the water environment, however nitrogen deficiency in a warming climate may be a problem in some areas as well. In natural environments such as grasslands and forests that

 are not fertilized, warmer climates are resulting in longer growing periods, which result in higher demands for nitrogen that cannot be met. With low supplies of nitrogen, plants cannot absorb the same amount of CO2, which also means that they cannot produce

 the same level of proteins. This has a direct impact on the food chain that these environments support. This research adds to the growing evidence base on the impacts of climate change on biodiversity and food security.
Primary Article Title: Nitrogen study casts doubt on ability of plants to continue absorbing same amounts of CO2
Keywords: primary production food security health biodiversity fertilizer Nitrogen climate warming air carbon agriculture

Summary Sentence: In the US, research to find an ecologically friendly alternative deicer to salt, has resulted in problems for nearby aquatic organisms.
Justification:
Beet juice deicer is a fully biodegradable alternative to traditional road salt and is considered a more ecologically friendly alternative. Researchers used mayflies as a water pollution indicator species as they are particularly sensitive to runoff contaminants

 such as salt. The results indicate that following exposure to beet juice deicer, the insects retained more fluid and had elevated salt levels. Furthermore, the insects excreted potassium from their gills which, while not unusual, is surprising for beet juice

 as the potassium concentrations were low and should not have caused such a marked effect. More research is needed to understand why the insects reacted negatively to beet juice however, this research does demonstrate that a product should be tested on a range

 of organisms and in combination with other substances before being declared ecologically friendly.
Primary Article Title: Plant-based 'road salt' good for highways but not for insects
Keywords: deicer salt "aquatic insects" "beet juice" "beet juice deicer" road-salt insects

Summary Sentence: Tri(2,4-di-t-butylphenyl) phosphate (TDTBPP) - a previously unsuspected pollutant - has been found in homes and the natural environment.
Justification:
TDTBPP is known to be toxic but very little is known about how it gets into the environment or our homes. The study, conducted in the US, found surprisingly high levels and at multiple locations. The chemical is often used in the production of plastic

 and electronics and was found in particularly high concentrations in house dust. The next stage of this research is to better understand the effects of this chemical on people.
Primary Article Title: High levels of previously unsuspected pollutant uncovered in homes, environment
Secondary_URLs: Study uncovers high levels of previously unsuspected pollutant in homes, environment - Indiana University Bloomington 30/10/2018
Keywords: tri(2,4-di-t-butylphenyl) phosphate TDTBPP pollution chemicals "air quality" contamination plastics electronics dust toxicity pollutant

Summary Sentence: Plastic particles may now be widespread in the human food chain.
Justification:
A small study of people from Europe, Japan and Russia has found microplastics in their stool. Although only 8 participants were analysed, all had plastic in their stools with an average of 20 plastic particles for every 10g of excreta. The test was only

 looking for ten types of plastic, and found nine of these, including Polypropylene and polyethylene terephthalate. This adds to the growing evidence of the influence of plastic on both humans and the environment. Little is known on the impacts of plastic in

 the human food chain. This research suggests there are multiple types of plastic that will need to be studied in order to assess if any or a combination of any could have negative consequences.
Primary Article Title: Microplastics found in human stools for the first time
Secondary_URLs: Even our own bodies now contain plastic waste - Guardian 29/10/2018
Keywords: human health plastic waste sea ocean water quality marine food

Summary Sentence: It is estimated that 10% of the plastic in the world’s oceans comes from commercial fishing fleets.
Justification:
Plastic fishing nets and other equipment can break or become abandoned when no longer of use. This abandoned plastic is known as ‘ghost gear’, and can lay unseen and cause marine animals to become entangled. Eventually this material will break down into

 smaller pieces known as micro plastics, which are small enough to be consumed and enter the food chain. There is currently no way to trace who the original owners of the ghost gear are, so collection and disposal is very expensive and usually not undertaken.

 The ghost gear that is recovered will often just be incinerated or sent to landfill, even though it could be repurposed for other uses such as textiles. As the UK wishes to reduce the amount of plastic waste entering the environment, it may take the opportunity

 of EU exit to explore options to reduce this problem.
Primary Article Title: This is the deadly ocean plastic pollution you never hear about
Keywords: waste pollution plastic microplastic health fishing fish marine water quality nets food chain disease chemical

Summary Sentence: A new technology to increase food production using drought-fighting microbes that naturally live in soil.
Justification:
Researchers at the University of Delaware have discovered that plants treated with a particular strain of bacteria (Bacillus subtilis) can trigger stomata to close - keeping pathogens out and protecting from dehydration. having determined how the bacteria

 works on plants, the research team were keen to better understand its effects on soil and green water (water in the soil that is available to plants). Specifically, if the bacteria could change the soil's chemistry, pore distribution and structure. Further

 research demonstrated that the bacteria does reduce evaporation and improves the soil's ability to hold water. By understanding the chemistry between plant roots and soil, new technologies could be developed that increase food production whilst decreasing

 the use of chemical fertilizers.
Primary Article Title: Drought fighter found in soil
Secondary_URLs: Plant Growth-Promoting Rhizobacteria (PGPR) Reduce Evaporation and Increase Soil Water Retention - Water Resources Research 19/04/2018
Keywords: soil microbes drought "climate change" water "green water" irrigation bacteria fertilizer "soil property" "soil chemistry" plants roots crops agriculture "food security"

Summary Sentence: Growing evidence suggests open plan offices may be bad for health and wellbeing.
Justification:
Open plan offices are now a popular format, with the UK in particular embracing the trend with more than twice as many open plan offices as the global average. The individual private office of the past has now been exchanged for vast, light, open plan office

 space. It was thought that the open plan office would foster collaboration, by breaking down barriers between teams and management as they are all working together. Many critics argue that this is not the case, and that instead they create an uncomfortable

 atmosphere. This can lead to a sense of loss of ownership and control over personal space, and therefore adds to workplace stress and ultimately reduces productivity. For all the research conducted on workplace layouts, there have only been a few studies looking

 at the health implications of open plan offices. These studies suggest that compared to individual offices, open plan offices are not beneficial to employee health, wellbeing and productivity. The short term financial benefits of open plan may be negated by

 increased staff sickness absence, and lower job satisfaction and productivity. These studies may be of interest to those considering workforce planning, and how workplace tension could be affecting retention.
Primary Article Title: Open plan offices should be banned immediately
Secondary_URLs:
Office design and health&%2358; a systematic review - New Zealand Medical Journal 04/12/2018

Does working in an open-plan office affect your health? - Vice News 04/12/2018
Keywords: wellbeing health sick ill communication collaboration noise sound office workplace work

Summary Sentence: What could space mining mean for the environment?
Justification:
Extracting valuable resources such as rare earth metals from asteroids or the moon are the aims of emerging space mining industries, likely driven by the projections that it could become a trillion dollar industry. Although currently economically and technologically

 challenging, growth has been seen in this sector fueled partly by increasing investments by governments and also current space missions to assess viability of extractions. Luxembourg released a 200 million euro fund for space mining in 2016, and a Japanese

 space mission recently landed on an asteroid in the hopes it can collect material for research purposes. Although the reality of asteroid mining is likely some time off, the Environment Agency may still wish to engage in conversation to ensure any industry

 that develops as a result of this is done in such a way to protect the environment. There are many unknowns with space material, such as what if any microbes they may contain. Furthermore any materials mined off planet and then used on earth, such as metals,

 will have an impact on the environment during both production and end of life treatment.
Primary Article Title: First-ever grad program in space mining takes off
Secondary_URLs: Scottish entrepreneur aims to take on the asteroid mining industry - Digit 31/07/2018
Keywords: pollution mining waste pollution resource metal water travel space bacteria microbe microbial

Summary Sentence: The understanding of the role of diet, both in terms of a cause of, and reaction to, climate change are the subject of recent research.
Justification:
The implications of this group of studies could relate to the work of the Environment Agency and partners in terms of agricultural regulation, land management and food production and regulation. The link between climate change and the decreasing nutritional

 value of food has been highlighted previously (%2314723, %2310296). Poor nutrition in food due to climate change could cause illness in humans by making food more toxic (%2313996), with similar impacts for wildlife too (%2313743). It is becoming increasingly apparent

 that reducing the amount of meat and dairy in human diets could lead to significant reductions of greenhouse gas emissions. The average EU citizen generates 1,070 kilograms in gas emissions each year, of which 75 % comes from meat and dairy production. Impacts

 are still felt even when import distances are taken into account, meaning that even locally produced meat and dairy are more impactful overall that importing fruits and vegetables. A shift from meat and dairy to fruit and vegetable products – a shift to much

 healthier eating – could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by up to 56% and other environmental pressures by up to 22%. Rising levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere have been found to impact the nutritional value of crops, reducing protein, iron and

 zinc by up to 17% under 2050 expected levels of CO2. This has the potential to lead to zinc, iron and protein deficient diets, the implications of which include wound healing, infections and diarrhoea, stunted growth, and complications in pregnancy and childbirth.

 The impacts are most likely to be experienced in developing countries. Eating more to compensate could lead to other health issues such obesity alongside a decrease in yields from climate change impacts of heat stress and drought. At the same time energy consumption

 from food is increasing due to people getting bigger. Humans have on average grown 1.3 percent taller and 14 percent heavier between 1975 and 2014. The conclusions are based on demographic studies of data from 186 countries. Based on anticipated gains in weight

 and height, the average near-future human will be bigger than their 2018 counterpart and, as a result, will require more food. This could cause additional pressures to the future food supply, which haven’t yet been properly considered, alongside more well

 known factors such as climate change and population growth.
Primary Article Title: Climate change will make hundreds of millions more people nutrient deficient
Author: Davis, N
Secondary_URLs:
The role of trade in the greenhouse gas footprints of EU diets - Global Food Security 01/12/2018

Soon, the Average Human Will Be Taller, Heavier. That Will Lead to Increased Food Demand - Smithsonian 13/11/2018

Impact of anthropogenic CO2 emissions on global human nutrition - Nature 27/08/2018

Change of diet helps to slow climate change - Climate News Network 01/11/2018

Food security for an aging and heavier population - Sustainability 15/10/2018
Keywords: "climate change" food farming "food supply" nutrition diet human size weight calories zine protein iron meat "greenhouse gas emission" GHG dairy import height weight export trade transport "carbon dioxide" CO2 health obesity disease yield drought "heat stress" "heatwave" crop agriculture demographics population

Summary Sentence: An artificial intelligence image analysis method has been developed using photographs to assess the importance of particular landscapes.
Justification:
Flickr, Instagram and Facebook have millions of photos uploaded on a daily basis. Using these pictures could help us understand the cultural significance of a particular landscape. Researchers collected social media images for the Mulde basin in Saxony

 and analysed them using an image recognition algorithm based on deep convolutional neural networks. The team then divided the images into thematic clusters. This approach gave 80 per cent accuracy but the research team are confident that this level of accuracy

 could be improved as the technology advances. The Environment Agency may find this technology useful for the protection and enhancement of the environment or, potentially as a way to monitor sites for regulatory purposes. This could also be used as a tool

 within the natural capital programme.
Primary Article Title: Photos in Social Media Reveal Socio-cultural Value of Landscapes
Secondary_URLs: Mapping cultural ecosystem services 2.0 - Potential and shortcomings from unlabeled crowd sourced images - Ecological Indicators 31/10/2018
Keywords: AI "artificial intelligence" photographs images recognition algorithm "social media" landscape land-use "land development" socio-cultural value "natural capital"

Summary Sentence: Are we prepared for an increase in weather related migration?
Justification:
It is widely accepted that changes in climate have resulted either directly or indirectly to mass migration and civil unrest in some developing countries. Although very sensationalist, this article draws attention to the fact that people in developed nations

 such as the US are now actively considering migration as they experience more frequent extreme weather events that disrupt their lives and damage their properties. Projections of increased temperatures, uncertain weather patterns and rising sea levels means

 climate migrations could be something that picks up pace in the future. If climate migration develops in the UK, this movement could put pressure on certain areas. This trend is being labelled as climate gentrification, where house prices in better protected

 locations increase, pushing out the less socioeconomically to areas of higher flood risk as the properties become less desirable. Developing our understanding of climate migration is important if we wish to ensure our communities continue to be protected and

 grow in a sustainable manner.
Primary Article Title: 'We're moving to higher ground'&%2358; America's era of climate mass migration is here
Secondary_URLs: Flood threat may result in people being moved to new areas - Guardian 26/11/2018
Keywords: migration climate change weather storm flooding civil unrest economy political

Summary Sentence: Pigs store less protein in their bodies at temperatures above 25 degrees Celsius.
Justification:
Research over the last decade has demonstrated that pigs become lethargic and thin at temperatures over 25 degrees Celsius and as a result, store less protein. Furthermore, pigs become less fertile and those piglets that are born will be fewer, grow slower,

 have less protein and produce inferior eggs and sperm as adults. This will result in pork becoming more expensive as they will require more food, energy, water and labour to raise. While wealthy countries may be able to absorb these costs, poorer countries

 that rely on pork such as Vietnam and the Philippines, may struggle with food security issues. Alternative protein sources may become necessary if pig farming becomes unsustainable as an industry.
Primary Article Title: A Warming Climate Could Make Pigs Produce Less Meat
Keywords: pork pigs farming "climate change" "food security" food meat protein fertility temperature "temperature rise"

Summary Sentence: Three people were able to communicate using just their brainwaves through a social media platform.
Justification:
Experimental technology is investigating the possibility of direct brain-to-brain communication. BrainNet can modulate electrical brain signals and implant those signlas directly into another brain. The sender wears an electroencephalogram (EEG) which

 can record electrical activity and decode those signals before sending them to the recipient through transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) gear. The system sends the information via magnetic pulses - triggering flashes of light called phosphenes. The process

 was tested using three participants. The participants played a game where two individuals could see a falling block that needed to be rotated to fit into a gap at the bottom of the screen. The third player cannot see the gap so relies on the other two players

 to turn the block correctly. All the players sit in separate rooms. The experiment was conducted with five groups of three people and was 80 per cent accurate. The researchers state this approach is scalable - resulting in a potential social network for brains.

 This could have implications for how we communicate both in the workplace and externally during incidents.
Primary Article Title: First direct brain-to-brain "social network" is a true meeting of minds
Secondary_URLs: BrainNet&%2358; A Multi-Person Brain-to-Brain Interface for Direct Collaboration Between Brains - Cornell University 23/09/2018
Keywords: "social networks" brains thoughts communication internet BrainNet brainwaves "brain-to-brain"

Summary Sentence: Pesticide residues in food, tobacco and marijuana are accumulating in adults and children and causing a risk to health.
Justification:
A US study suggests that children and smokers are being exposed to the highest levels of pesticides residues. Children are at risk because for their bodyweight, they are consuming twice as many calories as adults resulting in twice the level of exposure.

 This brings their exposure up to the same levels as those adults that smoke. The regulated limits are not being breached however, it is the 'cocktail' of chemicals that re being absorbed that is of most concern as it s difficult to understand the effects of

 chemical combinations in long-term exposure.Marijuana consumption is on the increase in both recreational and medicinal applications.The study suggests that for recreational users, the effects are the same as for smokers of tobacco however, because most marijuana

 is smoked without the use of a filter, the implications for exposure may be higher. For medicinal cannabis, the risk is that those using the product are already vulnerable due to long-term health issues which, may be compounded by the ingestion of higher levels

 of pesticides. There is also speculation that Coca-cola are considering using cannabis in their soft drinks. Although the manufacturer has stated they have no interest in pursuing this at the current time, they are following the market movements closely and

 would not rule this out in the future.
Primary Article Title: Children and smokers face pesticide danger
Secondary_URLs: Coca-Cola Dipping Into the Cannabis Infused Drink Market - forbes 27/09/2018
Keywords: pesticides residues pollution health cannabis marijuana children smokers medicine agriculture farming chemicals "chemical combinations" "chemical cocktail"

Summary Sentence: Highly intensive farming methods may not cause as much pollution, water scarcity and soil erosion as previously thought, challenging the long held belief than 'eco-friendly' farming practices are better for the environment.
Justification:
While this research uses sparse data and does not consider soil health or pesticide exposure, it does however raise interesting questions around our current belief that intensive agriculture is more detrimental to the environment than more 'eco-friendly'

 practices. The authors have measured greenhouse gas emissions, fertilizer and water use in both systems. In previous studies, researchers have estimated the environmental cost in terms of land area - resulting in a possible overestimation of the impact of

 intensive farming. In this study, when looking at quantity of food produced, intensive agriculture may actually produce less pollutants, less soil loss and use less water. Furthermore, the benefits of not destroying more of the natural world for agriculture

 could outweigh the costs of more intensive farming. Organic farming on the other hand, uses more land to produce the same yield so may prove more environmentally costly in the longer term.
Primary Article Title: 'High-yield' farming costs the environment less than previously thought-and could help spare habitats
Secondary_URLs: The environmental costs and benefits of high-yield farming - Nature 26/11/2018
Keywords: farming agriculture sustainability "food security" water pollution pesticides fertilizer "intensive farming" "land use" efficiency resources

Summary Sentence: A US insurance company has announced that it will only sell ‘interactive policies’ that involve fitness tracking equipment.
Justification:
Customers will have to share health and fitness data with insurer John Hancock, and in return will receive discounts for logging healthy behaviours. Customers are able to opt out but will not receive any such benefits. Data suggests that customers participating

 in similar schemes live between 13 and 21 years longer than the rest of the insured population, which also makes customers more profitable for the insurance companies. There are concerns from some corners about how the customer data is used, even though it

 is currently a relatively small portion of the personal data used in formulating life insurance policies. As such practices become the norm people may be penalised for not sharing. People who are found to exhibit signs of pre-existing conditions may similarly

 face penalties and even barriers to insurance. The limitations of fitness trackers may mean that some fitness activities don’t register, therefore dictating how people keep themselves fit, which in turn may be able to keep up with research in this area. This

 development should be of interest to all employers, including the Environment Agency as it could set a precedent for sharing personal data for health monitoring in an attempt to optimise the health and safety of its workforce, particularly as this workforce

 starts to mirror the UK’s ageing population.
Primary Article Title: John Hancock adds fitness tracking to all policies
Secondary_URLs: What happens when life insurance companies track fitness data? - The Verge 26/09/2018
Keywords: health wellbeing safety data workforce employer employee insurance life fitness tracking fitbit "John Hancock" exercise monitoring privacy
GT: health and safety, workforce, data, monitoring

Summary Sentence: Applying the principles of blockchain technology to corporate structures could result in ownerless companies.
Justification:
This should be of interest to the Environment Agency as such arrangements could present barriers to effective regulation. In a blockchain based company concepts of incorporation around tax and shares are obsolete, as those involved deal directly in virtual

 cryptocurrencies. Future companies may appear more like trust funds that have no owner, just a set of instructions on how to divide company income. The idea of distribution may extend to company employees, who may be scattered across the globe, working with

 colleagues without ever meeting or knowing the true identities of with whom they’re working. Internal politics and decision making chains may have to be written in code rather than ingrained in hierarchy or culture. The hardware that underpins blockchain companies

 may also be distributed. Platforms such as Golem and Filecoin utilise spare server space on their user network’s computers, effectively providing decentralised competition to web hosting services such as Amazon’s AWS. The flexibility of staff, hardware and

 software (through open source code) may present competitive services to more incumbent companies. Such competition may extend beyond computer based services and into other industries, including manufacturing and primary industries such as farming and forestry.

 The latter is exemplified by a art project called terra0. The collaboration between artists and a developer is intended to challenge views on nature and culture. Terra0 is essentially a forest that can autonomously sell it’s trees, accumulating wealth which

 it can eventually use to purchase itself and become a self owned economic unit. Based on blockchain technology activities such as contacting a logging company, or ordering replanting only occurs when certain conditions are met, which could include tree maturity,

 volume (provided by monitoring equipment) and market price are favourable. On completion of purchase the forest essentially gains the ability to own, raising questions on the definition of personhood in legal terms, and is this respect is reminiscent of previous

 initiatives to give elements of nature human rights, such as rivers in India (%2314369) and New Zealand (%2314299). While there are potential advantages of ownerless companies, there are also downsides, such as presenting barriers to accountability (and therefore

 prosecution) and exploitation by criminal activity - the same rules that govern the forest’s protection could be hacked and exploited to encourage premature deforestation, for example. There are however management platforms emerging designed to bring governance

 and digital jurisdiction to blockchain based organisations, (such as Aragon). These may provide an indication of how environmental regulation may need to adapt to continue to function effectively in a decentralised economy.
Primary Article Title: Blockchain, Inc&%2358; a look at the ownerless company of tomorrow
Secondary_URLs: How artists are bringing blockchain to their neck of the woods - Ozy 24/10/2018
Keywords: regulation blockchain decentralisation "distributed ledger" algorithm Golem FileCoin Aragon terra0 agriculture farming forestry manufacturing workforce employee share tax wage "virtual currency" cryptocurrency India "New Zealand" legal legislation ganges person timber wood crime data hack hardware software "open source" code automation

Summary Sentence: An algorithim has been developed in the US that can predict how likely a water facility is to fail an inspection.
Justification:
Hurricane Florence caused a serious pollution problem in the US when it displaced the contents of hog farm manure pools into nearby waterways. Due to "overextended and underfunded" regulation, controlling such sites is problematic. To address this issue,

 Stanford University have designed an algorithm that can catch two to seven times more infractions than current regulation. Using data from previous inspections, the model can predict which sites are likely to fail an inspection based on criteria such as location,

 type of facility and previous performance. Knowing which facilities are likely to fail enables regulators to focus on those sites that are likely to require inspection. It is acknowledged that algorithms are not the 'perfect' solution and can perpetuate bias

 but the researchers can address this using randomised samples and updated risk factors. Whilst this approach is still in its infancy, further work with the EPA could help refine the algorithm and potentially allow better regulation despite a reducing number

 of regulators.
Primary Article Title: Stanford students deploy machine learning to aid environmental monitoring
Secondary_URLs: Machine learning for environmental monitoring - Nature 01/10/2018
Keywords: algorithm modelling "machine learning" water "water quality" regulation regulators inspections "public health" "environmental health"

Summary Sentence: Indoor fish farms could become far more productive due to advancements in circulation and filtration systems.
Justification:
A Norwegian firm are planning to build the world's largest aquaculture tank in the US - taking indoor fish farming to a new level of production. The aim is to meet the needs of a growing population while reducing the environmental impacts on wild salmon

 populations. Land based indoor systems could reduce pollution to waterways and save water through a recycling system. However, the system does rely on the capacity of local infrastructure - including the water supply. Whilst the wastewater could be used for

 irrigation, it is still a more water thirsty process than sea based salmon farms. The US facility is due to open in 2019 and if successful, could pave the way for similar sized facilities to enter the UK - requiring increased levels of regulation.
Primary Article Title: The future of fish farming may be indoors
Keywords: fish "fish farming" salmon food "food security" pollution "water pollution" "water resources"

Summary Sentence: A growing number of weeds are becoming resistant to the effects of glyphosate.
Justification:
There is concern about the effects of glyphosate on the environment and human health. However, recent studies conclude that more strains of weed are becoming resistant to the herbicide with both pigweed and junglerice displaying this resistance. Junglerice

 is a type of grass that is found growing amongst rice, corn, vegetables and on roadsides and gardens. In the US, junglerice has displayed resistance to various herbicides but not glyphosate until now. For the two locations where this resistance has been found,

 the magnitude of resistance was found to be between four and seven times greater than susceptible populations. In conclusion, the research team suggests that integrated methods should be introduced to deal effectively with junglerice by using a wide range

 of chemical, mechanical and cultural tools.
Primary Article Title: Glyphosate resistance in junglerice confirmed
Secondary_URLs: Glyphosate-Resistant Junglerice (Echinochloa colona) from Mississippi and Tennessee&%2358; Magnitude and Resistance Mechanisms. - Weed Science 21/11/2018
Keywords: junglerice glyphosate herbicide "herbicide resistance" farming "food security" food agriculture crops

Summary Sentence: A new approach to developing antidepressant drugs using CRISPR gene editing technology could work by targeting different neuroreceptors to conventional treatments.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as previous research has demonstrated how trace concentrations of medicines used currently to treat mental health issues can impact on wildlife behaviour (%2315055, %2312213, %2310874, %238932) if not

 removed through wastewater treatment. Most antidepressant drugs target serotonin receptors to boost serotonin chemical levels in the brain, regulating mood and behaviour. Some of the most common drugs for this approach are Prozac, Paxil and Zoloft, to support

 a treatment which has gone unchanged for several decades. The new approach targets delta type GABA receptors with naturally found brain chemicals called neurosteroids that generally help slow down the cognitive processes associated with overwhelming negative

 thoughts and feelings. CRISPR has been used to mutated GABA receptors to isolate and test their role in brain functioning, which has been useful as previously it has been hard to differentiate the different impacts that GABA receptors have on brain function.

 The results of this have led to a study of the impact of natural neurosteroid brexanolone in treating postpartum / postnatal depression. Further studies are needed to explore further how activating delta-type receptors has antidepressant effects, using more

 compounds which in turn could lead to more potent drugs with more more selective impacts and fewer side effects. It is not clear what impacts these new types of drugs could have on wildlife behaviour through water quality, but considering the current intelligence

 around impacts of Prozac and other antidepressants then it must be considered that there may be a risk of behavioural change.
Primary Article Title: New approach to developing antidepressants
Author: Dryden, J
Secondary_URLs: Chemogenetic isolation reveals synaptic contribution of δ GABAA receptors in mouse dentate granule neurons - Journal Of Neuroscience 03/08/2018
Keywords: health medicine drug "mental health" depression "postnatal depression" postpartum Prozac Paxil Zoloft serotonin antidepressant delta-type receptor GABA CRISPR "gene editing" natural neurosteroid chemical chemistry "water quality" "wastewater treatment" waste water pollution biodiversity wildlife behaviour fish brain aquatic regulation

Summary Sentence: Corporations are taking steps to enforce codes of ethics around the use of artificial intelligence.
Justification:
Scientists at tech firm IBM have developed a new safeguard to make artificial intelligence more safe, transparent, fair, and effective. They propose developers need to publish a Supplier’s Declaration of Conformity (SDoC) before they sell the related algorithm.

 The SDoC would openly demonstrate how the algorithm performed at standardised tests covering performance, fairness and risk factors, and safety measures. IBM believe that transparency like this could help build public trust and reassure prospective clients

 that a particular algorithm would perform as intended without negatively impacting on citizens of concern. The SDoC would reveal such a risk, allowing the client to make an informed decision on putting the algorithm to use. Chinese tech giant Baidu has become

 the first Chinese member of the US-led artificial intelligence (AI) group, The Partnership on AI (PAI). Founder members include Google, Facebook, Amazon, IBM and Microsoft, and Apple joined in 2017. The group now consists of 70 organisations that work together

 to decide best practices on AI technology and assess the impact of AI on society. Baidu’s commitment to PAI could be seen as an important step in creating a global consensus on the societal and economic impacts, as well as the technological impacts, of AI

 deployment.
Primary Article Title: To build trust in artificial intelligence, IBM wants developers to prove their algorithms are fair
Author: Robitzski, D
Secondary_URLs: Baidu becomes first Chinese company to join US-led AI ethics group - Silicon Republic 18/11/2018
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" AI data ethics code IBm Baidu Facebook Google Amazon Apple China "Supplier’s Declaration of Conformity" SDoC "Partnership on AI" PAI workforce employee employer regulation

Summary Sentence: An Israeli based start-up is attempting to overhaul the legacy of landline based emergency call systems and deliver a more efficient service that cuts response times and could save lives.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider how the services offered by Carbyne could impact on incident management situations. Carbyne founder Amir Elichai was inspired to set up the company after being mugged on a beach and experiencing

 a delay in getting a response from the emergency services that allowed the assailants plenty of time to flee. He has developed services that focus on ‘time to dispatch’ – the duration from when the call is placed to the moment services are sent to the field.

 Rather than the caller handing over these details Carbyne gives the operator direct access to information on the caller’s smartphone such as position from GPS (they have also developed their own indoor positioning system) and live video streaming which gives

 the operator a much faster appreciation of the situation. If voice is not available then communication is available through instant messaging. Combining these aspects has cut response time by between 60 and 65 per cent. Carbyne have several municipal partners

 around the world and are looking to partner with other location based services such as Waze and Uber, and have an app that people can download to speed up emergency service access. There is often a need for a greater flow of data and information between the

 public and emergency responders during an incident, and services similar to Carbyne could offer a way to harness this potential. it may also prove a useful tool for reporting pollution incidents or breaches of environmental regulation as they happen, giving

 the Environment Agency and others valuable evidence for prosecution.
Primary Article Title: He got mugged, then revamped 911 for the next generation
Author: Blum, B
Secondary_URLs: Carbyne wants to replace outdated 911 systems - TechCrunch 19/07/2018
Keywords: "incident management" emergency flooding emergency monitoring services 999 911 Carbyne communication data information people smartphone app Waze Uber

Summary Sentence: A glucose powered medical monitoring implant that identifies diseases has been developed.
Justification:
his research may be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as it may provide a mechanism for live biological monitoring of animals and people, giving an earlier indication of environmental issues. Unlike superficial disease detection sensors

 the new sensor sits under the skin and can be powered indefinitely from using glucose naturally flowing through the blood on in lactate in the skin. The electronics involved are non toxic, and it is thought the sensor could be produced cheaply at scale.
Primary Article Title: Sugar-powered biofuel cell sensor detects and prevents disease
Secondary_URLs: From battery enabled to natural harvesting&%2358; enzymatic bioFuel cell assisted integrated analog front-end in 130nm CMOS for long-term monitoring - IEEE Transactions Of Circuits and Systems. 24/09/2018
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" monitoring biology sensor energy biological fuel cell glucose animal diabetes health regulation wildlife livestock farming

Summary Sentence: This study examines exposure to chemical and biological elements at the personal level and how this changes from individual to individual.
Justification:
A re-engineered air quality monitoring device was used to detail the human ‘exposome’. The human exposome refers to all the bacteria, viruses, chemicals, plant particulates, fungi, and microscopic animals that enter our personal space. Air quality is usually

 explored on a broad level, looking at exposure at such a personal level is a new concept and could have an impact on the monitoring and regulation responsibilities of the Environment Agency. By monitoring and recording exposure and health symptoms at the individual

 level, allows researchers to assess the likely pollutants that could be causing any negative impact on health. Although based in the US, the study highlights the variance of exposure between individuals, even in a relatively small geographic area. Also of

 interest are the household spikes of exposure to pollutants and how the weather can affect exposure. If this type of technology becomes mainstream, you could see a population that becomes more aware of the pollutants around them and therefore more engaged

 in protecting their immediate environment.
Primary Article Title: We are bombarded by thousands of diverse species and chemicals
Secondary_URLs: Dynamic human environmental exposome revealed by longitudinal personal monitoring - Cell 07/11/2018
Keywords: pollution bacteria air quality waste industry treatment health monitor virus "personalised health" medicine bacteria microbiology disease

Summary Sentence: A variety of freshwater insects have been found to consume microplastic, with those that have a flying lifestage creating a pathway for plastic to enter the terrestrial foodchain.
Justification:
Macroinvertebrates were studied above and below five waste water treatment works (WwTWs) in South Wales. Approximately 50% of those studied contained microplastic particles (MPs). Evidence of MP ingestion was found at all sites and across all insect species

 studied regardless of feeding method. The presence of the WwTWs appeared to have no impact on the microplastic levels within the insects. A laboratory based study by Reading University has shown that MPs consumed by mosquitos can move between life stages.

 The researchers show that small pieces of plastic consumed by the water based mosquito larvae were still present in the body of the mosquito once it matured into its flying life stage. This offers a pathway for freshwater plastic pollution to enter terrestrial

 foodchains. Plastic pollution in freshwater environments is still a relatively new area of research. These studies are only small, but the evidence collected suggests that more research is needed to understand the fate of MPs in freshwater environments together

 with how these MPs could affect the health of the organisms in the food chains that consume them.
Primary Article Title: Microplastics found in 50% of freshwater insects in Wales, research reveals
Secondary_URLs:
Up and away&%2358; ontogenic transference as a pathway for aerial dispersal of microplastics - Biology Letters 19/09/2018

Microplastic ingestion by riverine macroinvertebrates - Science of the Total Environment 20/07/2018
Keywords: plastic pollution health waste industry water freshwater marine microplastic food monitor policy

Summary Sentence: The ‘silver tsunami’ of a global ageing population could present a care crisis, or millions of new jobs, depending how organisations approach the issue.
Justification:
The World will have 200 million more elderly people by 2030, and only five per cent of the World’s population currently have elderly care in their national legislation. The growing need for care could create a growth in jobs within this sector, but only

 with the right incentives and support from government. Without these care of elderly people is likely to fall to younger relatives, who may not be able to provide adequate care due to work pressures, which may also cause a drop in productivity. Italy already

 allows workers to take three days a month to look after family members without impacting wages or benefits. It may be that in the absence of a more integrated care system that employees need to take more time off to take care of dependents, which may be supported

 through changes to workforce terms and conditions. Alternatively there may be more employee absences, paid or unpaid. This may impact on the productivity of any organisation, including the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: Ageing populations could create a care crisis-or millions of jobs
Author: Graham, T
Keywords: workforce employee leave population ageing care support health healthcare older ageing population productivity staff employer union

Summary Sentence: A commercial venture between a vehicle manufacturer, a hydrogen energy provider and a logistics consortium is to put 1000 hydrogen powered trucks on the roads of Switzerland over the next five years.
Justification:
H2 Mobility Switzerland is an association of fueling station operators, fuel wholesalers, logistics, distribution, and retail companies that own more than 1,500 fueling stations and 1,700 heavy duty trucks. The size of the commitment is significant enough

 to lead a countrywide self-perpetuating hydrogen infrastructure without government support, which has never been tried before anywhere in the world. The stations could be profitable filling up just ten trucks a day and would give other non associates the confidence

 t make the transition to hydrogen. The consortium is also committed to producing 100 per cent renewable hydrogen throughout. The trucks are to be provided by Hyundai Hyundai’s XCient platform. The 18 ton FCEV (fuel cell electric vehicle) features two 95 kW

 fuel cell stacks, 32 kg tank capacity, and 400 km (250 mile) range. The hydrogen will be supplied by Swiss company H2 Energy AG. This is of interest to the Environment Agency and partners as it firstly demonstrates how a transition to a new energy paradigm

 can happen very quickly, which may bring regulatory challenges. Secondly, it may also indicate that hydrogen could become a viable fuel alternative for the Environment Agency’s vehicle fleet, should a similar initiative occur in the UK.
Primary Article Title: Hyundai Motor and H2 Energy will bring the World's first fleet of fuel cell electric truck into commercial operation
Secondary_URLs:
This week in hydrogen - Ammonia Energy 27/09/2018

1,000 fuel cell trucks for Switzerland - LinkedIn 19/09/2018
Keywords: energy hydrogen fuel cell transport vehicle truck Hyundai "H2 Energy AG" pollution Switzerland logistics freight FCEV "fuel cell electric vehicle" "H2 Mobility Switzerland" government finance fleet

Summary Sentence: Advances in clothing and personal equipment, from the military to high end fashion suggest future impacts for employees working in the field.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider how these examples may become incorporated into their own workforces to optimise health safety and productivity. The Australian Government Department of Defence has unveiled how its unmounted personnel

 may operate in the future. Clothing may respond to injury such as automatically deploying tourniquets. Clothing would respond to environmental conditions such as as temperature and humidity by automatically opening and closing its structure, and respond to

 lighting conditions to either become more or less visible, depending on mission circumstances. Vision would be enhanced through augmented reality, allowing a better flow of information between the field and command centres. Features would be powered by self

 generating features in shoes and clothing. Operatives may also be able to deploy and control small drones residing within their clothing. Bristol University have developed trouser that can assist people with mobility issues. The trousers mimic leg muscles,

 expanding and contracting by computer control to enable to the user to assisted walking. A photoactive rechargeable nanofibrous membrane developed in California could provide a biosecure clothing barrier for field operatives, protecting them from exposure

 emerging infectious diseases without the need to constantly deploy antibacterial agents such as triclosan. An Israeli fashion student has produced a range of 3D printed fashion concepts designed to increase personal protection. These include a fabric that

 can deploy an array of defensive spikes, or a safety rope. She is also developing a range of 3D printed‘ smart jewelry’ containing sensors that send a message to a trusted individual if the wearer gets in trouble.
Primary Article Title: The next generation soldier - towards 2035
Secondary_URLs:
Israeli fashion designer creates 3d-printed clothing, jewelry that helps protect women from danger - NoCamels 02/11/2018

Robotic trousers could help disabled people walk again - The Conversation 14/09/2018

Nanofibrous membrane could offer bioprotection - Physics World 19/03/2018
Keywords: workforce employee field operations clothing equipment health safety textile defence Australia environment temperature humidity light visibility emergency incident drone energy shoe piezoelectric "augmented reality" AR data communication ageing walking muscle computer assisted walking nanofibre nanofibrous disease infection AMR bacteria triclosan biosecurity "3D printing" sensor monitoring danger smartphone text

Summary Sentence: Opportunities and risks in the field of using geoengineering to mitigate the impacts of climate change are coming to the fore.
Justification:
Whilst there are significant possible benefits in geoengineering, the external consequences in terms of pollution may need to be considered, and therefore could be of interest to the Environment Agency. Solar geoengineering involves spraying chemicals

 such as sulphate particles into the air to deflect the sun’s energy from the Earth’s surface and therefore reduce temperatures. Several trials of geoengineering have been conducted previously (%2314312, %2313269) and schemes have been considered at the highest

 levels of academia. New research has shown that while reducing heating effects in this way could help crops to cope with the temperature rises associated with climate change, it would also scatter the sunlight reaching the surface, impairing photosynthesis

 and leading to a null effect overall. The recent Paris climate talks proposes 116 strategies to prevent the Earth warming above the 2 degree Celsius threshold, 101 are based on technologies to remove carbon dioxide already in the atmosphere. (%23 13814). Other

 geoengineering schemes involve removing carbon dioxide from the air either mechanically (%2314814) or chemically through mineral absorption, using crushed rock (%2314604). Scientists have recently produced a substance to enhance the natural CO2 absorption that

 occurs during magnesite crystallisation. When magnesite crystallises, it absorbs CO2 at a 2 to 1 ratio&%2358; this means that for every half ton of atmospheric CO2, one ton of magnesite is required. The process normally takes hundreds to thousands of years to occur,

 but with the use of polystyrene microspheres as a catalyst the process could be significantly quickened to around 72 days. The polystyrene microspheres can be reused, streamlining the process and putting less strain on magnesite resources.
Primary Article Title: A disappointing new problem with geo-engineering
Author: Meyer, R
Secondary_URLs:
Scientists produce mineral in lab that can remove CO2 from the atmosphere - Interesting Engineering 16/08/2018

Estimating global agricultural effects of geoengineering using volcanic eruptions - Nature 02/11/2018
Keywords: geoengineering "climate change" pollution air sulphate energy pollutant farming photosynthesis plant sunlight regulation crop rock "carbon dioxide" CO2 magnesite catalyst polystyrene microsphere crystalise

Summary Sentence: Microscopic devices as small as a grain of salt could be the monitoring devices of the future.
Justification:
‘Smart dust’ - microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), often called motes - could be of use for environmental monitoring, and therefore should be of interest to the Environment Agency. It is unclear what the environmental impacts of deploying these devices

 might be, and as such this may be of equal interest. MEMS could be equipped with a range of sensory equipment such as sensors, cameras and communication mechanisms, along with computational power, all packed into a few millimetres of space. MEMS could be 3D

 printed and incorporated into other devices in the process, or as standalone units. Applications could include environmental and agricultural monitoring, tracking waste shipments, anticipating infrastructure failures and healthcare. Data collection and transmission

 could occur in a range of environments - their small size would allow them to be suspended in the air just like real dust, expanding the internet of things (IOT) by several orders of magnitude There are concerns about data privacy, cost and control of MEMS

 once deployed into the environment. However there is seemingly little knowledge on the environmental impacts of MEMS could be on health, biodiversity and waste management of smart dust at end of life.
Primary Article Title: Smart dust is coming. Are you ready?
Author: Marr, B
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" data "smart dust" "microelectromechanical systems" MEMS motes sensor transmit communication camera waste agriculture crop farming health "internet of things" IOT  "3D printing" biodiversity regulation

Summary Sentence: The decision to remove net neutrality laws in the United States has impacted the ability of emergency services to respond to incidents, according to a Fire Department in California.
Justification:
The UK currently maintains net neutrality laws through its membership of the European Union, but this could change in the future, leading to UK emergency responders including the Environment Agency having similar experiences. Net neutrality laws were established

 to ensure that internet service providers treated all users equally, prohibiting blocking of certain services, slowing down particular websites, or charging more to access them. Last December the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) voted to end net neutrality,

 despite vehement opposition and threats of legal action. This paves the way for service providers to tailor access to favour particular companies, organisations or doctrines to the detriment of other users. Today the internet is now a fundamental tool in emergency

 response. Recently the Santa Clara County Fire Department claims to have experienced a ‘throttling’ of its internet services from its provider Verizon, despite paying for ‘unlimited’ data. This impacted on the performance of a command and control vehicle attending

 a major emergency. Verizon confirmed the throttling, but rather than restore the normal service they indicated that the Department would have to upgrade to a more expensive data plan. Verizon have since apologised and agreed to remove the throttling. But Santa

 Clara Fire believes it likely that similar future circumstances could compromise emergency response and public safety if used as a technique to coerce public agencies into higher-cost data plans, now net neutrality has been repealed.
Primary Article Title: Verizon throttled fire department's "unlimited" data during Calif. wildfire
Author: Brodkin, J
Secondary_URLs: The FCC just killed net neutrality - Futurism 14/12/2017
Keywords: "incident management" fire internet data "net neutrality" emergency response safety USA California "Santa Clara" "internet service provider" Verizon "Federal Communications Commission" FCC  throttling cost finance government law legal

Summary Sentence: A review examining the rising use of Gadolinium and its unknown potential as a water pollutant.
Justification:
Gadolinium (Gd) is a metal element increasingly used for industrial and household purposes such as in TV’s, radars and microwaves. Gd is also used in medicine as a contrast agent for MRI scanning. Gadolinium based contrast agents (GBCAs) are injected into

 a patients to show contrast as part of the MRI. They are used as they are not metabolised by the body and are so are thought to be less toxic than other alternatives. Gd is not metabolized by the body and does not degrade during the waste water treatment process,

 which means it ultimately ends up in aquatic environments. This review notes that Gd has been found in surface waters, sediments and living organisms. There is some evidence that Gd may accumulate in tissue and bone, but this is very limited. The environmental

 fate of Gd is also poorly understood, but with growing use, the authors argue it warrants further investigation to ensure human health and the environment are not unduly harmed.
Primary Article Title: Gadolinium as a new emerging contaminant of aquatic environments
Keywords: metal pollution pollutant aquatic water human health bioaccumulation waste sewage WWT chemical

Summary Sentence: Analysis of Twitter data from California’s 2015 wildfire season have indicated that the social media platform can help to improve predictions of air quality impacts as well as improve emergency responses.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may see similar benefits from applying the same principles to other incident management activities involving air pollution. Analysis of 39,000 tweets that included the names of the state’s most destructive wildfires

 were geocoded to match the locations of air quality monitoring stations. The tweets are were analysed for mentions of health impacts, and it was found that the data provided could be used to help predict air quality impacts in more remote locations. In addition

 tweet analysis for mentions of concern for the wellbeing of firefighting crew gave additional insight into people’s proximity to the fire, which also suggested that tweets could also have potential in linking people who need help with people who have the resources

 to offer assistance. Whilst this and other studies (%2314538) show that social media does offer up significant potential for monitoring and engagement in incident and emergency situations it should also be noted that other research has indicated that active

 Twitter users can spread significant volumes of false information during disasters (%2314689).
Primary Article Title: Tweets prove to be reliable indicator of air quality conditions during wildfires
Secondary_URLs: Using social media to predict air pollution during California wildfires - US Department of Agriculture (USDA) 18/07/2018
Keywords: "incident management" "social media" Twitter tweet data monitoring "pollution incident" "air pollution" "air quality" fire wildfire California response workforce emergency

Summary Sentence: A new branch of chemistry promises a future where organic matter such as sugar could be converted into jet fuel using nothing but light.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested to consider how a sustainable method for producing combustion fuel like this could impact on other transport and energy strategies, policies and regulations, especially around agriculture and air

 pollution. The aim of Bioinspired Light-Escalated Chemistry (BioLEC) is to investigate how to use the energy of two photons, the tiniest quantifiable units of light, to power chemical reactions. In theory an organic plant based molecule such as a sugar or

 alcohol that contains a chain of carbon atoms connected to an oxygen and hydrogen atom could be converted to jet fuel, but the carbon-carbon bond is extremely difficult to break. However targeting the carbon chain with a photon would weaken the bond, while

 introducing a second photon could break the chain completely, making is much easier to discard the oxygen and reassemble the carbon and hydrogen atoms to make a jet fuel. Scientists are currently investigating using catalysts exposed to a very particular amount

 of light in order to break the bonds through using a technique called pulse radiolysis that concentrates a beam of electrons at molecules. The resulting reactions can give scientists a better idea on how to harness the power of BioLEC to produce fuel from

 organic matter. Enabling the chemistry that could manufacture jet fuel from abundant natural materials would lead to a cheap, plentiful source of clean energy. It could also be adapted to break down the byproducts and other waste of industrial plants, and

 possibly convert these to other abundant and inexpensive biodegradable compounds or even fuels. However, the process would still produce carbon emissions from combustion of the fuels, so would have to be considered in a sustainable life cycle context in order

 to offer a clean alternative to conventional fossil fuels.
Primary Article Title: Sugar, light, and a new type of chemistry - what it may take to wean us off fossil fuels
Author: Robitzski, D
Keywords: energy chemistry fuel "fossil fuel"  "jet fuel" regulation "Bioinspired Light-Escalated Chemistry" BioLEC carbon oxygen hydrogen atom catalyst photon jet fuel "pulse radiolysis" electron research sugar alcohol organic waste "water quality" industry pollution pollutant "water treatment" biodegradable

Summary Sentence: Artificial sweeteners have been found to be toxic to gut bacteria.
Justification:
The results of this study should be of interest to the Environment Agency as artificial sweetener chemicals have been identified as emerging pollutants, and may therefore be impacting on bacterial communities in the environment. The study found that six

 FDA approved sweeteners and ten sports supplements containing the sweeteners were toxic to digestive bacteria at concentrations of only one mg./ml. The sweeteners used in the study were aspartame, sucralose, saccharine, neotame, advantame, and acesulfame potassium-k.

 The bacteria had been genetically altered to be bioluminescent, which also suggests that such bacteria could be used to indicate the presence of sweeteners in the environment. Acesulfame in particular has previously been identified as being a persistent chemical

 in the environment (%2314559), suggesting that it may have uses as a trace chemical of anthropogenic impact on water pollution.
Primary Article Title: Artificial sweeteners have toxic effects on gut microbes
Secondary_URLs: Measuring Artificial Sweeteners Toxicity Using a Bioluminescent Bacterial Panel - Molecules 25/09/2018
Keywords: pollution chemical sweetener aspartame sucralose saccharine neotame advantame acesulfame potassium-k food sugar health microbe gut digestive system bacteria bioluminescence monitoring water pollutant

Summary Sentence: As the technology industry starts to consider the ethical implications of artificial intelligence (AI) some commentators are looking at the geopolitical implications of AI technology
Justification: AI guru Kai-Fu Lee sees the future of AI technologies being dominated by two countries&%2358; the USA and China. Both countries lead the World in terms of numbers of AI and machine related patents filed. China is likely to develop the best technology for two reasons. Firstly China has tended to display what could be simplistically termed a ‘copycat culture’ of developing and testing multiple product iterations in a live environment, which pushes risk and innovation. Secondly there is a ‘data gap’ between the USA and China, the latter having unprecedented amount of digital data available about its citizens, enabling services to be more precisely tailored to individual needs. Another difference is that USA technology is delivered via a platform model eg through Facebook, Apple or Google, whereas China’s approach is to use their technology to support local partners. Alphabet chaiman and Google founder Eric Schmidt now refers to the latter as an "AI company" and no longer a data company, for example. Whilst Europe most resembles the platform model concerns about data privacy may hinder AI development for commercial purposes and instead reposition AI development for social purposes, such as healthcare. The concern for data protection can be seen from the recent General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) laws, which Apple’s CEO Tim Cook has recently suggested need to be similarly adopted by the US to prevent the ‘weaponisation’ of personal data by commercial interests. Note that many US websites have chosen to block European visitors rather than have to comply with GDPR, perhaps illustrating the different regional and cultural attitudes to personal data collection and how this could splinter the internet as we know it. The consequence of these differences may manifest globally as three internet systems&%2358; USA & Australasia; China and southern Asia; and Europe. Tim Berners Lee’s concept of a decentralised internet (%2315078) may help to allay European data concerns. Lee also acknowledges the negative impacts that AI could bring to the global jobs market, though some commentators disagree with the scale of impact. One of the strengths of China in the AI arms race, according to John Loeffler, is that it doesn't have the kind of established industries that could be greatly impacted by AI, unlike Europe which relies heavily on the financial sector for example and therefore may show reluctance to embrace AI. The current politic climate surrounding immigration in the USA and Europe may also make it comparatively easier for China to recruit talent. While Kai-Fu Lee (in this article) sees AI through a social and commercial lense, another commentator considers the implications of AI development on the wider issue of national security and resilience. Tech entrepreneur Ian Hogarth compares AI development to the nuclear arms race, where there is a technology with the potential for the greater good, or for mass destruction. In order to remain economically competitive and defend themselves from hostile entities nations may have to invest significantly in AI development on a scale that could compare with other national priorities including military hardware and climate change adaptation. Despite having a disproportionately high concentration of AI talent in the UK, such as the Google backed start-up DeepMind, Hogarth sees risk in a lack of strategic direction from both government and opposition who are distracted by more short term cost considerations such as EU Exit and nationalisation of the railways. AI could impact on the Environment Agency and partners in many ways operationally, such as making the current workforce more efficient and reducing costs. However from a geopolitical standpoint, superior AI in the hands of hostile agencies may represent a threat to IT systems and infrastructure which is becoming increasingly ‘smart’. AI may also represent competition to other government strategic priorities which may include climate change adaptation or agricultural sustainability.
Primary Article Title: The great AI duopoly
Author: Gardels, N
Secondary_URLs:
Will China's AI industry win humanity's final arms race? - Interesting Engineering 27/02/2019

Tim Cook blasts 'weaponisation' of personal data and praises GDPR - BBC 24/10/2018
