Summary Sentence: New evidence suggests that exposure to soluble silver had different effects on the organs of zebrafish compared to silver nanoparticles.
Justification:
Research has previously suggested that the presence of silver nanoparticles is not harmful to fish. This research suggests that the distribution and effects of silver depend very much on the form that is ingested. Soluble silver caused short term alterations

 after three days of exposure in the liver, gills and intestines of the fish that and was reversed when the fish were reintroduced to clean water after 6 months. For the fish exposed to silver nanoparticles, the alterations were noticed 21 days after exposure

 but affected 799 genetic sequences compared to 410 for the soluble silver. The distribution of silver differed depending on whether it was soluble or in the form of nanoparticles and for both pollutants, damage to the gills was permanent. This research indicates

 that there is still a lot to learn about the effects of silver nanoparticles - this research used levels that would be found in typical wastewater from treatment plants - indicating that there is no safe level for fish at this time.
Primary Article Title: Silver nanoparticles are toxic for aquatic organisms
Secondary_URLs: Waterborne exposure of adult zebrafish to silver nanoparticles and to ionic silver results in differential silver accumulation and effects at cellular and molecular levels. - Science of the Total Environment 29/10/2018
Keywords: nanoparticles silver "silver nanoparticles" pollution fish wastewater treatment zebrafish fish water freshwater rivers

Summary Sentence: Higher levels of PFAS in the environment may be linked to increasing cases of hyperthyroidism in older cats.
Justification:
Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are prevalent in the environment through a number of products including carpets, furniture, paper and insecticides (amongst others). In the US, blood samples were taken from older cats to determine the level of

 exposure to PFAS and then compared to the number of incidences of hyperthyroidism. According to the research team, cats are a good sentinel species to study emerging pollutants such as PFAS. While this research is preliminary, if a link is confirmed, this

 may have implications for the Environment Agency and the control of these substances in the environment.
Primary Article Title: Chemicals linked to endocrine disorder in older pet cats
Secondary_URLs: Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances in Northern California cats&%2358; Temporal comparison and a possible link to cat hyperthyroidism. - Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry 29/10/2018
Keywords: PFAS "perfluoroalkyl substances" "polyfluoroalkyl substances" pollution "endocrine disorder" hyperthyroidism cats felines

Summary Sentence: Climate change could cause a reduction in pore size of soil that could intensify the water cycle resulting in flash flooding and erosion.
Justification:
Scientists have been looking at the effect of climate change on macroporosity - the pores that allow water to be absorbed, carrying nutrients to plants and eventually replenishing aquifers. Using a 50-year old collection of soils from the US, combined

 with atmospheric data, the researchers found that macropores were more likely to develop in drier climates and that macroporosity changed over a shorter timescale than previously thought. Using climate projections, the researchers concluded that increased

 humidity by 2100 would reduce soil macroporosity across most of the US. The scientists suggest that macroporosity should be included in global climate models to be better prepared for future flooding events.
Primary Article Title: Climate-induced soil changes may cause more erosion and flash flooding
Secondary_URLs: Climate-induced changes in continental-scale soil macroporosity may intensify water cycle - Nature 29/10/2018
Keywords: flooding "flash flooding" macropores macroporosity soil climate "climate change" "water cycle" "climate projections" "climate model"

Summary Sentence: Tim Berners Lee is spearheading a movement to ‘turbocharge’ the emergence of a decentralised internet that could challenge the current systems and take control from corporations and give it to individuals.
Justification:
A decentralised internet, also referred to as ‘Internet 3.0’ (%2314269) envisages an internet where people have full control of their data and the web itself remains free and open. Technologies such as distributed ledgers, blockchain and dApps (distributed

 applications) are some of the concepts and technologies that could contribute to this move. Berners Lee is now on a one year sabbatical to work on Inrupt, the first start-up built of a decentralised web platform called Solid that he’s been developing with

 MIT. The power of Solid is demonstrated by an app that collects together lots of web applications, such as Google Drive, Microsoft Outlook, Facebook owned WhatsApp. The difference to other platforms is that all the personal data is held in a Solid pod (personalised

 online data store) and not with the service provider. Another development in the pipeline is an Alexa like personal assistant called Charlie, but where users have control of the data they submit. Other tools will be made available via Inrupt to help developers

 build more decentralised applications, and Berners Lee is seeking venture capital to continue growing his development team. Solid and Inrupt aren’t the only developers in the decentralised and distributed web space. Another example is Japanese company LINE

 that is developing a range of blockchain based dApps that are working towards flattening the relationship between developer and user, and also uses its own token system for both payment and reward in using its services, whilst protecting personal data. The

 rise of a decentralised internet as envisioned by Berners Lee and others is that these services represent direct competition and threat to the current platform providers that generate their wealth from user data such as Facebook and Google. This has recently

 been brought into focus by the Facebook / Cambridge Analytica scandal, demonstrating how personal data can be used to for unintended purposes. This also means that third parties that use their data for communications, advertising and marketing purposes may

 also be compromised, as may intelligence services, without significant changes to business models or legislations. Some manufacturers are already gearing up hardware in preparation for a decentralised internet, such as HTC's blockchain powered smartphone (%2314770).

 Considering the significant disruption that centralised commercial internet services have brought to the World, a decentralised service model could be equally disruptive, though with different consequences.
Primary Article Title: Exclusive&%2358; Tim Berners-Lee tells us his radical new plan to upend the World Wide Web
Author: Brooker, K
Secondary_URLs: LINE officially joins the decentralised community with 5 new dApps and a global digital token - e27 26/10/2018
Keywords: internet "Tim Berners-Lee" "world wide web" decentralisation decentralised blockchain government regulation Amazon Alexa Charlie dApp Inrupt Solid data companies corporation privacy Facebook Google Amazon Microsoft "Cambridge Analytica" trust government marketing WhatsApp LINE "Internet 3.0"

Summary Sentence: The efficiency of emergency readiness and response is being improved in some areas of the World through embracing the concept of ‘social capital’.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider how community incident preparation could be further enhanced through embracing a social capital model. The overarching theme of social capital is self-reliance and empowering communities so that

 they need less assistance from governments and other organisations. In self organising communities where people look out for their neighbours as well as themselves during natural disasters the impacts have been found to be significantly lower, even reducing

 the loss of life considerably.
Primary Article Title: The secret to surviving a disaster could start next door
Author: Van Houten Maldonado, D
Keywords: "incident management" emergency disaster "social capital" community action neighbour trust organisation government self-reliance preparedness

Summary Sentence: Clothing rental may be emerging as a contender to clothing ownership.
Justification:
This growing trend and example of the sharing economy has environmental implications due to the large resource footprint of clothing production and may also impact on the Environment Agency regulated industries of waste and textile production. Whilst renting

 clothes such as tuxedos and wedding dresses is not a new concept, the idea of more every day clothes being provided via a rental service is reasonably novel. It has been calculated that doubling the number of times a garment is worn decrease its environmental

 footprint by 44%. Companies such as Rent The Runway have been offering the online based service since 2009. Another company called YCloset based in China has grown to 10 million registered customers recently, mainly women, though not all have used the service

 yet. Both companies are moving to a subscription service for every day clothes rather than a one off payment for special occasion garments. YCloset’s recent social media campaign involving social media influencer Jiang Chacha was designed to allay customer

 concerns about cleanliness, preparing the clothing rental subscription service to go mainstream. The service gives customers access to higher quality and designer items, and one CEO suggests that people may eventually spend half of their clothes budgets on

 renting rather than buying. A similar baby clothes rental business was set up (%2314364) to address the relatively few times that baby clothes are worn due to growth, but price may have been a factor in widespread adoption. There are also suggestions that new

 materials could lead to self healing clothes, reducing the need for replacement and consequent waste management issues around landfill, though this development is perhaps further in the future (%2314084). The current surge in interest could therefore make clothing

 rental more mainstream, reducing environmental impacts of textile production, reducing waste and moving to a more circular economy.
Primary Article Title: Will we soon be renting rather than buying our clothes?
Author: Hooker, L
Keywords: "sharing economy" "circular economy" waste landfill clothes clothing textile "social media" "environmental impact" resources baby consumer purchase subscribe subscription service fashion designer water energy land farming agriculture cotton "Rent The Runway" YCloset subscription rent online women influencer "Jiang Chacha" China USA regulation

Summary Sentence: Replacements for BPA in plastics may also have negative health impacts.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should have an interest in the health and environmental impacts of chemicals that may experience widespread use. Evidence on the endocrine disrupting properties of bisphenol(A) (BPA) have led to legislative steps to remove

 its use, mainly from plastics and packaging. Similar compounds to BPA from the same family such as BPS, BPF and BHPF are being used as replacements, but evidence of similar impacts (%2314305, %2314277, %2313012) could suggest that they too may face restrictions

 in use in the future. But another study has found that another BPA replacement may not be safe. In 2003 researchers found that BPA was leaching from laboratory mice cages, increasing chromosomal abnormalities in females and their offspring. The impacts have

 been seen across generations of mice, even when the offspring have no exposure to BPA. In more recent studies the researchers have observed similar results, even though the plastic cages are BPA free. It was found that the mice were chewing the cages, leading

 to their BPA alternative diphenyl sulfone being leached out. They believe that polysulfone degrades into BPS, causing the abnormalities, and may be causing similar impacts to all animals that are exposed to it, including humans, though there is currently not

 the research to establish any impact. The results also raise concerns about the reliability of BPA research as this impact of sulfone may have unwittingly influenced results.
Primary Article Title: BPA substitutes may be just as bad as the popular consumer plastic
Author: Service, R. F
Secondary_URLs: Replacement bisphenols adversely affect mouse gametogenesis with consequences for subsequent generations - Current Biology 24/09/2018
Keywords: health pollution pollutant chemical plastic BPA bisphenol(A) BPS BPF BHPF biology hormone EDC endocrine disruption meiosis estrogen mice mouse generation chromosome chromosomal "diphenyl sulfone" polysulfone sulfone e

Summary Sentence: A would be nation of spacefarers has recently appointed its first official head of state.
Justification:
Igor Ashurbeyli, a Russian computer scientist and engineer, has served as Asgardia’s de-facto leader was formally inaugurated earlier this year. Ashurbeyli is apparently a technology billionaire with a focus on aerospace. As well as funding research he

 chairs the Nonprofit Non-Government Expert Society on Space Threat Defense (ESSTD), with has special consultative status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC). His vision for Asgardia is to eventually have a self sustaining, self governing

 network of space colonies. A nation needs a territory, and the existing land assets on our planet have been divvied up. Asgardia has already started to launch its own satellites, which Ashurbeyli sees as the first pieces of sovereign territory. They plan to

 have ‘Spacebook’, a global internet online in 5-7 years, space arks in 15 years and a permanent settlement on the Moon in 25 years. Ashurbeyli seems well aware of the technological and environmental challenges that forming a space nation present. However 200,000

 people have already signed up to become citizens of Asgardia. New nations have been proposed in the past living outside of current jurisdictions either in the physical world, such as the controversial micronations Sealand and Liberland, or the floating nations

 proposed by the SeaSteading Institute(%2314256). Virtual nations such as BitNation (%2315065) are also seemingly gaining momentum, partly out of discontent with current political systems. While the technological challenges far surpass other alternative nations,

 the concepts that Asgardia proposes may prove attractive for some in society, particularly the legal and political ramifications of services that a space nation may offer Earthbound citizens and countries. The recent news of an Israeli privately funded mission

 to the Moon in 2019 also demonstrates that space exploration - and maybe one day colonisation - may be one day achievable without state support.
Primary Article Title: We talked to the new leader of space nation Asgardia about what the future holds
Author: Robitzski, D
Secondary_URLs:
Israeli space probe to land on Moon in 2019 - BBC 10/07/2018

WELCOME TO SEALAND&%2358; the utterly bizarre independent micronation that's been sitting off the British coast for over 50 years - Business Insider 26/08/2018

Liberland&%2358; the bitcoin nation welcoming mellow new citizens - The Week 19/02/2018
Keywords: nation country government politics space Asgardia BitNation Seasteading Liberland Sealand satellite moon colonisation Israel "Igor Ashurbeyli" sapcebook internet territory land sea ocean

Summary Sentence: Anglian Water are investing in solar with energy storage at one of their treatment plants.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may be interested in this realises example of energy storage in a water treatment context as it may suggest a future mechanism for improving efficiencies in its own infrastructure, such as pumping stations. Employing energy storage

 machine will allow Anglian Water to take advantage of the solar energy they generate as well as wholesale energy prices, reducing site electricity costs by 50% per annum by 2040 and the site’s reliance on the grid. In addition, the RedT system can also be

 used for energy trading and emergency site back-up. Anglian Water has become the first water utility to benefit from AI-powered energy storage infrastructure, and is part of a strategy for delivering Carbon Neutrality by 2050. Further roll outs across the

 business are scheduled for the next 18 months and beyond.
Primary Article Title: Anglian Water signs deal with `flow machine' maker redT to optimise PV across multiple sites
Author: Pratt, D
Keywords: regulation energy water "water treatment" "energy storage" "energy trading" solar PV emergency incident "carbon neutrality" 2050 2040 asset battery utility "Anglian Water" redT AI "artificial intelligence" infrastructure pumping flood efficiency cost

Summary Sentence: A new battery design made from lithium - NOT lithium ion - is being heralded as a paradigm shift in energy storage.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may be interest in the waste management implications of battery materials at end of life, including fire risk, as well as the potential for energy storage to contribute to a low carbon economy. Lithium-ion batteries charge quickly

 but can explode or catch fire if exposed to open air. It also requires regular charging and can degrade quickly due to overcharging. By contrast the new battery design employs a ceramic, solid-state electrolyte that can harness the power of lithium-metal batteries

 without any of the negatives of lithium-ion. As such the new design could double battery output, extending the run time and range of devices such as smartphones and electric vehicles (EVs). Another alternative to lithium-ion batteries could be zinc-air batteries.

 A company. NantEnergy recent unveiled a rechargeable zinc-air battery that costs significantly less that lithium ion batteries. At around $100 per kilowatt-hour, the cost is low enough to compete with other fossil fuel based sources that provide energy in

 the absence of solar or wind renewables.
Primary Article Title: New super-battery that doesn't catch fire described as a `paradigm shift'
Author: Gorey, C
Secondary_URLs: Cheaper battery is unveiled as a step to a carbon-free grid - The New York Times 26/09/2018
Keywords: energy "energy storage" battery lithium "lithium ion" waste fire risk incident regulation operator ceramic solid-state electrolyte lithium-metal smartphone "electric vehicle" EV fossil fuel wind solar NantEnergy zinc-air cost

Summary Sentence: Once illegal recreational drugs are increasingly been seen, and used, for medicinal reasons.
Justification:
Research shows that traces of narcotics can impact on aquatic biodiversity, therefore the Environment Agency and partners may need to be mindful of the pollution impacts of social change in this area. A boom in ketamine use has been identified in the United

 States. Ketamine, most commonly used as a veterinary tranquiliser has also been misappropriated for recreational use. The current boom in the USA however is related to medical use for treating mental health conditions, migraines and as a painkiller. Ketamine

 clinics have sprung up across the country in recent years, offering patients treatment courses of proprietary blends.There are concerns about the effectiveness of ketamine treatments, alongside worries of proper patient screening and inadequately qualified

 staff. The internet has also helped to spread the popularity of medicinal ketamine, regardless of evidence of effectiveness. Much like ketamine there is some intelligence to suggest that people are turning to psychedelics such as MDMA and hallucinogenic psilocybin

 mushrooms for use in alternative therapies, employing 'LSD guides' to help them through the healing process and deal with mental health issues. Unlike psychotherapists, however, underground guides have no accredited educational institutions, no licensing.

 In the UK there are some reports that a small but increasing number of women are 'microdosing' (%2313654) magic mushrooms and LSD to enhance energy levels, alertness and allowing them to play with their children in a more fulfilling way, with the suggestion

 that microdosing may be 'going mainstream'. Back in the States academics are calling for psilocybin mushrooms, so called ‘magic mushrooms’ to be reclassified, as the evidence suggests that it is not open to high abuse and may have medicinal uses in treating

 some mental health conditions, such as alleviating their end-of-life anxiety and depression. Researchers have had success using medicinal magic mushrooms in controlled settings, where the dose is regulated and administered by a trained clinician, a psychologist

 or trained therapist guides the recipient through the experience, and there’s very specific goals for the therapy. It is unclear if psilocybin has the environmental persistence of other substances, yet still represents a trend in a growing interest in using

 narcotics for medicinal treatments.
Primary Article Title: Is the ketamine boom getting out of hand?
Author: Thielking, M
Secondary_URLs:
Researchers want doctors to be able to prescribe magic mushrooms for depression - Motherboard 01/10/2018

Welcome to the trip of your life&%2358; the rise of underground LSD guides - The Guardian 08/12/2018

'It makes me enjoy playing with the kids'&%2358; is microdosing mushrooms going mainstream? - The Guardian 03/05/2019

A behavioral and molecular analysis of ketamine in zebrafish - Synapse 18/10/2018

Summary Sentence: Walmart is distributing 17,000 Oculus Go virtual reality (VR) headsets to its US retail outlets for use in employee training.
Justification:
The Environment Agency already engages with e-learning packages and therefore should be interested in how this area is advancing. The headsets are supported with 45 activity based training modules developed specifically for Walmart that intend to train

 staff in the areas of new technology, compliance and soft skills such as customer service. Training in the VR environment allows users to make mistakes in safety and has a bigger impact that other e-learning. In tests employees felt more confident in dealing

 with real world situations following the training. Walmart’s VR training programme also meant that staff were competent in operating ‘Pickup Tower’ instore collection points before the physical towers had been installed. This development has a similar resonance

 for workplace impact as Microsoft’s move into using VR as a tool to create and explore content within its Sharepoint sites (%2314778). Virtual reality is also being used to help people conquer their fear of public speaking.Using an app developed by UK company

 VirtualSpeech, Swedish researchers demonstrated that a VR environment can be used successfully to help people overcome anxiety about speaking in a range of workplace scenarios. The virtual reality experience may be enhanced further through stimulating senses

 other than vision. For example recently developed ultra-light gloves produces realistic haptic feedback which allow users to experience the sensation of touching and holding objects in virtual environments. The glove, called DextrES is made of cotton and thin

 elastic metal strips. The glove weighs eight grammes yet can provide up to 40 Newtons of holding force from 200 vlts and few milliwatts of power. under 8 grams – but also provides feedback that is extremely realistic. The glove is able to generate up to 40

 Newtons of holding force on each finger with just 200 Volts and only a few milliwatts of power. is made of cotton with thin elastic metal strips running over the fingers.
Primary Article Title: Walmart deploys 17,000 Oculus Go headsets to train its employees
Author: Gagliordi, N
Secondary_URLs:
Conquer your fear of public speaking by practising in virtual reality - New Scientist 05/10/2018

Ultra-light gloves let users "touch" virtual objects - ETH Zurich 15/10/2018
Keywords: VR "virtual reality" workforce training Walmart Oculus Go Facebook customer service technical Microsoft Sharepoint employee employer e-learning compliance "Pickup Tower" haptic glove DextrES touch sense hold VirtualSpeech public speaking

Summary Sentence: A newly devised steel production method that utilises electricity instead of carbon to process iron ore into steel could significantly reduce carbon dioxide emissions from industrial operations.
Justification:
As a regulator of industrial emissions from the metals sector the Environment Agency should be interested in emerging technologies like this that can reduce impacts. The new process employs an electrolytic cell, similar to a battery, to separate oxygen

 from the iron mix, replacing the role that carbon monoxide has in conventional production, binding with oxygen to be released as CO2. Chromium based alloys are used as anode and cathode. A current is passed through these which heats the mix of metals and minerals

 within the furnace. Oxides within the furnace act as solvents, dissolving iron oxide. The freed oxygen ions rise to the top of the furnace, whilst the molten metal drains to the bottom. Ingredients such as carbon, needed to give steel strength, can be added

 as the metal cools. The process is still at the small scale experimental stage, but plans are ahead to increase production capacity. Should this become realised, along with a willingness in the industry to change tried and tested practices, switching to the

 electrolytic cell system could reduce global CO2 emissions by five per cent. Regulation may have a role in encouraging the adoption of this or similar ‘carbon free’ steel production systems.
Primary Article Title: A new way to make steel could cut 5% of CO2 emissions at a stroke
Author: Temple, J
Keywords: regulation steel industry emission air pollution pollutant "carbon dioxide" CO2 "climate change" "greenhouse gas" GHG oxygen iron metal steel chromium furnace "iron oxide" alloy anode cathode electricity energy ion "iron oxide" furnace molten mineral "electrolytic cell"

Summary Sentence: A business leader has laid out the risk that fake data presents to an increasingly automated business community.
Justification:
Automation is likely to impact on many sectors, including the Environment Agency’s data and evidence driven work, which would then ultimately impact on decision making. Yann Lepant of Accenture outlines the business threat of fake data. The amount of data

 that can be generated and collected far surpasses human capability to process it it, therefore automation is the solution to delivering productivity and value from the data. But automation also relies on good data to be effective. If this data is unverified,

 outdated, biased, taken out of context, or even maliciously tampered with, problems can arise. One example given is Amazon’s battle with fake reviews undermining their credibility. Businesses can take steps to limit the risks, including verifying third party

 data, ensuring that data is used in the right context, and more sophisticated cyber security. Technologies like blockchain for example could help manage provenance and context to some extent.
Primary Article Title: Why fake data could be the biggest threat to decision making
Author: LePant, Y
Keywords: data security cybercrime "cyber attack" "fake data" "yann LePant" AI "artificial intelligence" "machine learning" Amazon blockchain "distributed ledger" decison making management

Summary Sentence: Cockle derived sugars are as effective at treating cancer as traditional chemotherapy drugs and may be particularly suitable for children due to their low toxicity and low dosage rates.
Justification:
A low toxicity alternative to traditional chemotherapy would be good news for the environment. Cockles are plentiful but the environmental impact on species numbers may need to be considered if this treatment proves successful. So far the therapy has been

 successfully tested against leukaemia, colon, breast and lung cancers. The reason this treatment is so suitable for children is because it minimizes damage to healthy cells - reducing the impact on a growing and developing body over the longer term. While

 this research is encouraging, there is still some way to go before this treatment will be available to the public.
Primary Article Title: Could the next anti-cancer drug be made from seafood?
Secondary_URLs: Antiproliferative Activity of Glycosaminoglycan-Like Polysaccharides Derived from Marine Molluscs - Marine Drugs 10/02/2018
Keywords: marine "marine molluscs" cancer chemotherapy tumours seafood cockles sugars cockle-chemo "common cockle" shellfish drugs toxicity polysaccharides

Summary Sentence: Silicon Valley start-ups are increasingly turning their attention to the waste industry.
Justification:
Considering the disruption that the sector has brought to all aspects of life, the Environment Agency and partners may need to consider how some of the products and services being developed may come to impact on waste management. Some of the drivers leading

 to an increase in waste include&%2358; the rising value of the waste removal and disposal sector; increasing populations producing more waste; the increased profile of the environment, sustainability and the circular economy in public consciousness; and improved

 logistics that offer a constant stream of raw materials. The science underpinning a lot of developments however is not particularly new. There are significant developments across the waste-to-fuel and waste-to-product industries, in the form of thermal (pyrolysis,

 hydrothermal, gasification) and non-thermal technologies. Companies are targeting a variety of waste types, including household waste, (plastics and organics), as well as agricultural waste (like wood) and livestock waste (like manure). Waste is then converted

 into products, including synthetic crude oil, natural gas, electricity, refined products (from diesel to high-value waxes) and specialty chemicals. Challenges still remain around securing financial backing, fluctuating waste prices and upscaling new developments.

 However support for these technologies and processes are accelerating, as due to the local and regional nature of these projects, it is unlikely for global forces to derail progress - an example given is China aggressively entering the market and undercutting

 prices as they did with solar a decade ago.
Primary Article Title: Bioproducts are seeing major tailwinds in renewable tech
Author: Dickson, T & Brentan Alexander, B
Keywords: waste "Silicon Valley" investment startup fuel energy wood manure diesel technology USA California economics China solar sustainability "circular economy" population regulation

Summary Sentence: A blockchain based nation offers alternatives to current society is emerging in the physical and virtual world.
Justification:
Some of the ideas that these movements carry could challenge the current role and tax income streams of governments, and therefore could also impact on the Environment Agency and partners. Bitnation is a blockchain powered government service platform that

 believes virtual governments could replace nation states by offering decentralized public services and globalized identities. It was founded by Susanne Tarkowski Tempelhof. Bitnation currently has around 180 volunteer run embassies in the physical world, and

 a global membership of 5,3000 mainly concentrated in Europe. Bitnation already offers people, amongst other things, citizenship of a virtual nation state. Other services include marriages (including the world’s first Blockchain Marriage), blockchain land titles

 and birth certificates. There is also a Bitnation cryptocurrency that functions as a proof-of-reputation for Bitnation citizens, allowing them to use smart contracts, paving the way for legal transactions and business regulations beyond traditional nation

 states. Bitnation has also provided refugee emergency digital ID cards and Bitcoin Visa cards, for which it was awarded a UNESCO prize for Bitnation Refugee Emergency Response (BRER). Bitnation may find that its largest potential markets are in countries with

 less political freedoms than in Europe. However one of the founders sees the potential in replacing, rather than improving nation states, freeing people from being ‘prisoners of geography’ when it comes to choosing governments and services. Bitnation is gaining

 momentum against a backdrop of increased strain on nation states, characterised by events such as a rise of the far right, an influx of refugees, socioeconomic inequality and EU Exit. The concept of political and economic freedom is challenged by the Bitnation

 concept, and whilst the movement is growing around 45 per cent of the global population still lacks internet access (June 2015). However when taken in the context of digital government, as exemplified by Estonia (HSDBi %2314129) Bitnation like movements could

 similarly offer alternative third party digital government services outside of the nation state that may present a competition to government run services.
Primary Article Title: I became a citizen of Bitnation, a blockchain-powered virtual nation. Now what?
Author: Souli, S
Secondary_URLs:
Global internet usage - Wikipedia 17/10/2018

Disrupting the trust business - The Economist 15/07/2017

Here are two initial coin offerings you need to watch this summer - International Business Times 16/10/2017

Summary Sentence: The hidden benefits of rivers in reducing the risks of floods and droughts could be lost if they continue to be overlooked and undervalued according to a WWF report.
Justification:
The report, called 'Valuing Rivers', highlights how our current world view of rivers as sources of water and power increases the risk to other benefits such as fisheries, flood protection and sediment flows. It these benefits continue to be overlooked,

 it could result in further economic losses and a failure to meet sustainable development goals. Pressures from activities such as dams, irrigation, hydropower and climate change need to be addressed and this report provides a framework to improve how societies

 'measure, value and promote' rivers. It also discusses the role of new technology such as AI, remote sensing and blockchain as a way to improve monitoring.
Primary Article Title: Undervaluing hidden benefits of rivers undermines economies and sustainable development
Secondary_URLs: Valuing Rivers&%2358; How the diverse benefits of healthy rivers underpin economies - WWF 17/10/2018
Keywords: water "water resources" rivers "climate change" irrigation hydropower fisheries "artificial intelligence" blockchain drought flooding floods sediments

Summary Sentence: Air pollution may be linked to chronic kidney disease (CKD).
Justification:
The Environment Agency as a regulator of air emissions should be interested in evidence on emerging impacts. Air pollution contains toxins in particulate format (PM2.5) that can impact the kidneys if inhaled, due to the large amount of blood flow through

 the kidneys. A recent study compared rates of CKD risk between populations in mining and non-mining areas of Appalachia, USA. It found a 19 percent higher risk of CKD among men and a 13 percent higher risk in women compared with those who lived in counties

 with no mining. It is advised that people, especially those with diabetes, obesity, high blood pressure or heart disease that have an increased risk of developing CKD and should recognize the danger and take precautions, if living in heavily populated or polluted

 areas.
Primary Article Title: Why polluted air may be a threat to your kidneys
Secondary_URLs: County-level air quality and the prevalence of diagnosed chronic kidney disease in the US Medicare population - PLOS ONE 31/07/2018
Keywords: "air pollution" "air quality" emission health pollution pollutant kidney "chronic kidney disease" CKD particulate PM2.5 women mining obesity illness "heart disease" "blood pressure" regulation

Summary Sentence: The impacts of the recent heatwave on UK soils may be impacting the environment more negatively than previously thought.
Justification:
Such impacts could be exacerbated if prolonged drought becomes an increasingly common feature of the UK climate. A new study has looked at how drought impacts soil microbes, which are responsible for producing the soil, cleaning water and regulating greenhouse

 gas emissions. A study on the effects of summer drought on grassland plant communities found that drought increased the abundance of a certain fast-growing, drought-tolerant grass. Greater above ground vegetation increases the rate of evapotranspiration, lowering

 overall soil moisture. This study considered a range of direct and indirect interactions between different microbial organisms in the whole soil ecosystem, allowing estimates of current and future impacts of drought and climate change on below ground organisms.
Primary Article Title: Heatwave and climate change having negative impact on our soil say experts
Secondary_URLs: Soil bacterial networks are less stable under drought than fungal networks - Nature 02/08/2018
Keywords: "climate change" soil drought grassland microbe water "greenhouse gas" evapotranspiration organism "water resources" plant

Summary Sentence: A new study has revealed the contribution that non-food related agriculture makes to eutrophication.
Justification:
The Environment Agency, as a regulator of both farming and textile industries should be interested in this research which demonstrates that an increasing proportion of eutrophication is unrelated to food production and represents a growing area of relative

 consumer spending. Nutrient oversupply from applications of nitrate and phosphate based fertilisers can lead to run-off into water bodies causing eutrophication. Recent research has identified that crops destined to supply manufacturing, including clothing,

 make a significant contribution to eutrophication - around a third in 2011, up 28 per cent on 2000. Agriculture will most likely always be the most important cause of eutrophication, but as countries develop and people become richer, the amount of money spent

 on non-food items, such as as textiles and furniture relative to the total GDP decreases. The long, complex supply chains of many goods that extend across international borders also make tackling related pollution difficult. Both these problems may present

 both local and international challenges to regulation as wealth increases and global supply chains become more complex.
Primary Article Title: Clothing, furniture also to blame for ocean and freshwater pollution
Secondary_URLs: Trade and the role of non-food commodities for global eutrophication - Nature 14/06/2018
Keywords: farming agriculture textile food eutrophication regulation pollution marine ocean freshwater economy furniture GDP clothing supply chain wealth

Summary Sentence: In the Netherlands, following a long period of drought, the first rains washed so much cyanobacteria into the water it became too polluted for bathing.
Justification:
The Environment Agency are aware of cyanobacteria but, this new development of increased levels following prolonged periods of drought, is not currently being addressed as a potential risk. Two samples from 39 water-bodies around towns and cities in the

 Netherlands. One sample was enriched with fertilizer while the other was untreated. Those samples with the added fertilizer saw an explosion of cyanobacteria populations indicating that the fertilizer content of surface water needs to be drastically reduced

 to account for periods of drought followed by heavy rainfall.
Primary Article Title: Rainfall after drought caused explosion of cyanobacteria populations
Secondary_URLs: Response of Natural Cyanobacteria and Algae Assemblages to a Nutrient Pulse and Elevated Temperature - Frontiers in Microbiology 13/08/2018
Keywords: cyanobacteria water "water quality" "bathing water" "surface water" pollution "water pollution" drought rainfall weather "climate change" climate "global warming"

Summary Sentence: More examples of artificial intelligence (AI) being used in incident forecasting are emerging.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should consider how similar realised examples of automation could be enhancing current work within the incident management field. In Japan a new AI system has been developed that can accurately predict where radioactive

 material emitted by a nuclear accident will eventually land, over 30 hours in advance, using weather forecasts on the expected wind patterns. This tool enables evacuation plans and other health-protective measures to be implemented if another nuclear accident

 like in 2011 at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant were to occur. Similar technology could be adapted for other airbourne pollution incidents. A collaboration between India’s Central Water Commission (CWC) and Google has seen another AI system being

 used to create flood warnings to help keep people informed and prepared for flood events. These are distributed via a mobile phone text alert. The previous system’s one day lead time has been extended to three days. The AI analyses a range of elements, including

 historical events, river level readings, terrain and elevation. From the range of data maps are generated and hundreds of flood simulations are run to more accurately forecast time, location and severity of the flood event. CWC is currently trialling the system

 for the 2018 flood season. A future upscale is expected to save money as well as mitigate flood-related losses.
Primary Article Title: Government to team up with Google for flood forecasting
Secondary_URLs:
Artificial Intelligence Accurately Predicts Distribution of Radioactive Fallout - University Of Tokyo 03/07/2018

Dispersion characteristics of radioactive materials estimated by wind patterns - Nature 02/07/2018
Keywords: "incident management" "artificial intelligence" AI flooding Google India forecast alert text "mobile phone" historical event  river level terrain elevation data map  "lead time" "Central Water Commission" CWC Japan nuclear radiation radioactive waste air pollution quality pollutant health toxic weather meterology Fukushima regulation emergency

Summary Sentence: A new process to vitrify low level nuclear waste continually, rather than in batches is being developed.
Justification:
As a regulator of radioactive waste the Environment Agency may wish to consider how such a process may affect future waste management and storage issues. Vitrification has been previously identified as a means of reducing the risk and volume of high level

 nuclear waste (%2312278). The new process focuses on low level nuclear waste, of which there is a significantly greater volume worldwide. The new process is a pilot version of the Direct Feed Low-Activity Waste system that will one day process millions of gallons

 of low-level radioactive waste left over from the US nuclear weapons program. Liquid nuclear waste is filtered to remove solids and the heavy metal cesium. The liquid is then mixed with raw material for glass making, then pumped into a furnace at a steady,

 controlled rate. Borosilicate glass, which can remain stable for thousands of years was extruded periodically. Radioactive gases given off by the vitrification process were turned back into liquid by condensation, concentrated and grouted for later vitrification.

 The glass and the grout will be analyzed to determine if they meet regulatory standards for disposal.
Primary Article Title: PNNL successfully vitrifies three gallons of radioactive tank waste
Keywords: "waste management" radioactive nuclear energy "Direct Feed Low-Activity Waste" glass vitrification cesium Borosilicate glass regulation waste "nuclear weapon"

Summary Sentence: A floating dairy farm aims to allow Rotterdam to produce more of its own food locally and more sustainably.
Justification:
The farm will be based in the harbour, and initially house 40 dairy cows. The close proximity to the population that will be consuming the food, will allow a reduction in the emissions generated by transport. The sustainability will be further improved by

 producing cow feed from waste products from local industry, such as left overs from restaurants and grass clippings from green areas around the city. Vertical layers in the farm will allow the production of pondweed as an additional high protein food source

 for the cows. Some of the energy needed to run the farm will also be produced from solar panels. The launch of a floating farm in Rotterdam adds to the growing trend of alternative urban farming systems to feed ever increasing populations. If such farms become

 economically feasible in the future, it will change the way the Environment Agency will need to engage and regulate some farming practices. The enclosed nature of these farms may also bring additional benefits of a reduction in the need for some chemicals,

 and those that are used may be able to be contained and therefore treated more easily.
Primary Article Title: The world's first floating farm making waves in Rotterdam
Keywords: farm pollution diffuse incident population urban farming dairy nitrate chemical pesticide pharmaceuticals waste treatment

Summary Sentence: Understanding the cause of ‘hydraulic jumps’ - first observed by Leonardo Da Vinci - could lead to greater efficiency in water resource use.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested to consider how this discovery could reduce industrial water use. A hydraulic jump can most easily be seen when water coming out of a kitchen tap initially splays out before going down the plughole.

 The apparently harmless phenomena can cause significant waves, turbulence and whirlpools in deep water. A Cambridge based researcher has discovered that by altering surface tension and viscosity that it is possible to control the impacts of hydraulic jumps.

 He envisages that this discovery could help to reduce industrial water use dramatically as it will enable new ways to clean in industrial situations.
Primary Article Title: Household phenomenon observed by Leonardo da Vinci finally explained by Cambridge researchers
Secondary_URLs: On the origin of the circular hydraulic jump in a thin liquid film - Journal Of Fluid Mechanics 31/07/2018
Keywords: "water resources" efficiency "hydraulic jump" "Leonardo Da Vinci" industry regulation turbulence "surface tension" viscosity

Summary Sentence: Male starlings sing less to females who have consumed diluted doses of antidepressants.
Justification:
This has potential significance for the Environment Agency as the source of antidepressants in the wild is sewage treatment works. Researchers fed female birds in the laboratory low concentrations of Prozac equivalent to those found at sewage treatment works,

 where starlings gather in the wild to feed on worms, maggots and flies. It was found that male starlings were less interested in courtship, suggesting that the Prozac somehow makes female birds less attractive. This may have implications for breeding cycles

 of other birds who are similarly exposed unless greater action is taken to remove antidepressants and other chemical compounds from sewage treatment wastewater.
Primary Article Title: Male birds sing less to females on antidepressants
Secondary_URLs: Environmentally relevant exposure to an antidepressant alters courtship behaviours in a songbird - Chemosphere 26/09/2018
Keywords: "water quality" "water treatment" sewage pollution pollutant antidepressant wildlife Prozac breeding behaviour starling bird courtship worm maggot flies food biology regulation

Summary Sentence: The UK is to get its first spaceport, located in Scotland.
Justification:
While the spaceport isn’t located within England the Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider what potential environmental impacts could arrive. The spaceport will be located on the A'Mhoine Peninsula in Sutherland, northern mainland Scotland.

 Virgin Orbit are also exploring the potential of horizontal launching, via aeroplane in Cornwall. Having a spaceport is seen as important in offering a full ‘turn key solution’ to the UK’s satellite manufacturing industry, and is important in the UK’s ambition

 to capture 10 per cent of the global space market by 2030. The first launch may take place in the early 2020s. Whilst the environmental impacts of rocket launches on the UK environment are not clear at this stage it may be noted that the climate impacts of

 rockets are only starting to be properly understood. Particles of soot carbon dioxide, water, black carbon and alumina discharged by rockets into the upper atmosphere all have cause for concern around atmospheric chemistry, including ozone formation and climate

 change. According to one rocket engineer there is currently little academic consideration, nor an appreciation for how localised such impacts could be, or how they might need to be regulated.
Primary Article Title: Lift-off for Scotland&%2358; Sutherland to host first UK spaceport
Author: Amos, J
Secondary_URLs:
About us - UK Space Agency 26/09/2018

How much air pollution is produced by rockets? - Scientific American 29/11/2017
Keywords: space transport Scotland satellite rocket launch spaceport Sutherland "A'Mhoine Peninsula" "air quality" "air pollution" atmosphere ozone soot "carbon dioxide" water "black carbon" "alumina" pollutant pollution regulation "UK Space Agency" economics trade "Virgin Orbit" Cornwall

Summary Sentence: The discovery of rare earth minerals in undersea mud of the coast of Japan has sent shockwaves through related industries and the Japanese stock market.
Justification:
The reserves, found in the seabed mud off Marcus Island, have been described as ‘semi infinite’, containing 11,000 years' worth of terbium, 4,900 years of yttrium, and 930 years of dysprosium, based on current domestic consumption. These minerals and others

 are important to technology products including magnets needed to power hybrid and electric vehicles. The discovery has prompted investment in research and development of extraction techniques to realise the potential commercial value and provide Japan with

 greater resilience to the price fluctuations of raw materials. The impact may be significant both for global politics and economics. On a more localised level, realisation of extraction technology could mean that future discoveries of mineral bearing muds

 in other areas of the World, including UK waters, may more readily leave to extraction and subsequent impacts on the marine environment.
Primary Article Title: Toyota and academics lead hunt for rare earths in Japan
Author: Nihei, S
Keywords: mineral extraction mining "deep sea" mud metal terbium yttrium dysprosium ocean marine Japan magnet vehicle hybrid electric EV global politics economics resources "Marcus Island" extraction investment Toyota

Summary Sentence: Growing research into the health extending properties of pharmaceuticals could lead to a build-up of new residues in our water systems.
Justification:
Senolytics are drugs that are able to target specific cells that cause some of the symptoms associated with aging. In this study, mice were given a combination of dasatinib which is used to treat leukaemia and the plant chemical quercetin. This treatment

 was found to reduce mortality rates and improve the health of the mice. This research adds to a growing body of evidence that the pharmaceutical industry is investing in the development of new drugs to help prolong and improve the quality of human health in

 the future. It is as yet unclear which chemicals may be the most successful. However, with an aging population, it is likely that those that are approved will likely end up in higher concentrations in our water courses if they cannot be removed at waste water

 treatment plants. How these chemicals may impact on the environment and human health if they build up in our water systems on their own or in combination is something that has not yet been researched. The Environment Agency will likely need to allocate additional

 resources to explore if these chemicals pose a risk, and if so, will current monitoring be sufficient to identify the risk and how can it be mitigated against in the future.
Primary Article Title: This drug combo extends lifespan and healthspan in mice by killing `zombie' cells
Secondary_URLs:
Key aspects of human cell aging reversed by new compounds - Science Daily 07/08/2018

Senolytics improve physical function and increase lifespan in old age - Nature 26/09/2018
Keywords: medicine pollution water quality waste residue biodiversity accumulation combination health drugs pharmaceutical aging disease population senescence senolytic

Summary Sentence: The future of transport may not be electric after all.
Justification:
A top executive of the Dow Chemical Company has suggested that lithium ion batteries are a “fad of the decade” and will become unsustainable as lithium supplies dry up and end-of-life waste disposal issues arise. The inability of lithium to meet demand would

 mean that fossil fuels, including increasingly efficient diesel, remain the primary sources of fuel. New sources including methane hydrate and carbon based fuels arising from chemical research may move to the fore. An emissions testing company has similarly

 warned the UK government not to focus on electric vehicles as the solution to better air quality when better more efficient diesel technology is already here that emits a fraction of the NOx gases of older models. The company warns the government not to confuse

 the issue of CO2 reduction through electrification with air pollution issues. Regardless of power source the Danish Cyclists’ Federation have recently expressed their concern that the advent of autonomous vehicles will mean more congestion in cities, presenting

 greater danger to cyclists - this may also translate to greater air pollution overall, despite cleaner emissions, should the move to electrification not happen for the reasons stated by Dow etc above.
Primary Article Title: Electric vehicles `no solution' to UK air quality
Author: Grant, A
Secondary_URLs:
Will congestion in cities increase when autonomous vehicles take over? - CleanTechnica 10/07/2018

Batteries are a 'fad of the decade'&%2358; Dow's top executive - The Economic Times 14/07/2018
Keywords: energy transport "air quality" "air pollution" electricity electric "fossil fuel" diesel autonomous vehicles car congestion traffic regulation Dow Danish cyclists cycling Denmark UK battery lithium resource waste NOx CO2 "climate change"

Summary Sentence: There are signs that hydrogen may grow in significance as a maritime fuel.
Justification:
The World’s first autonomous hydrogen boat, Energy Observer (%2314125) is currently making its way around the globe. Energy Observer uses renewable energy in the form of on board photovoltaics and wind to power an electrolysis process that converts seawater

 to hydrogen fuel, which is stored on board. Surplus energy also powers the ship. Ongoing success of this six year journey may suggest that more commercial applications are feasible. At the same time a recently published International Chamber of Shipping report

 mentions hydrogen, ammonia, nuclear and batteries as four technologies to help meet the International Maritime Organization’s greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction targets. Ammonia could be used as a hydrogen carrier, cracked and purified on demand, generating hydrogen

 with emissions of atmospheric nitrogen. The hydrogen then feeds a fuel cell, generating power with emissions of pure water. Ammonia could also be used as a fuel itself, powering ammonia-fed fuel cells (%2314841), helping reduce the impact of shipping on air

 quality, which has been demonstrated to have health impacts on coastal communities (%2313624).
Primary Article Title: International Chamber of Shipping endorses "Reducing CO2 Emissions to Zero," with ammonia as a maritime fuel
Author: Brown, T
Secondary_URLs: The World's first autonomous hydrogen boat takes a trip round the World - Interesting Engineering 15/07/2018
Keywords: energy fuel hydrogen ammonia maritime ocean boat ship sea coast air pollution quality emission nuclear battery storage nitrogen "fuel cell" health photovoltaic electrolysis regulation

Summary Sentence: An international group of scientists has tried to gain consensus and prioritise the evidence needs for chemicals research.
Justification:
A variety of chemicals are made and used every day around the world. How these chemicals interact with the environment, and put pressure on biodiversity, health, water and many other natural processes is still something that requires a lot of research to

 fully understand. In this paper, researchers aim to frame the questions on chemicals that are most important for policy makers, industry, regulators and those that fund research. This evidence would enable those groups to make more informed decisions on chemical

 use, which would benefit the environment and people. 22 questions of priority were identified by the group, including which chemicals should we be most concerned about, chemical sustainability, impact of chemical combinations, improving communication, and

 the impacts of global mega trends. The researchers hope this paper will be the first step in a more strategic and coordinated response to managing chemicals.
Primary Article Title: Urgent change needed to regulate the environmental impacts of chemicals
Secondary_URLs:
Toward sustainable environmental quality&%2358; Priority research questions for Europe - Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry 19/07/2018

£6 million to explore impact of hazardous chemicals on UK ecosystems - NERC 09/08/2018
Keywords: chemical research priority industry regulate combination pollution waste treatment biodiversity health toxicity

Summary Sentence: Bumblebees in the UK acquire a taste for pesticides as they become more exposed to them, a behaviour showing possible symptoms of addiction.
Justification:
A team from the UK have tested bumblebee exposure to neonicotinoids by using a sugar solution as a carrier for the pesticide. They discovered that naive bees avoided the pesticide however, as individual bees are exposed more regularly to it they begin

 to exhibit a preference for the sugar solution containing the pesticide. The researchers tentatively suggest that the bees may be showing patterns of addictive behaviour but more research would have to be carried to determine if this were the case. Exposure

 to neonicotinoids is known to affect the reproductive effectiveness of the colony over time. This research may lend weight to the latest trend for the development of robotic bees.
Primary Article Title: The more pesticides bees eat, the more they like them
Secondary_URLs: Foraging bumblebees acquire a preference for neonicotinoid treated food with prolonged exposure - Proceedings of the Royal Society B 13/09/2018
Keywords: pesticides neonicotinoids bumblebees bees pollinators crops pollination "robot bees" addiction

Summary Sentence: Report into 70% of vessels implicated in illegal, unreported or unregulated fishing are registered in tax havens, report finds
Justification: Forestry Commission will be interested in illegal forestry activities that contribute to deforestation
Primary Article Title: Tax havens shielding companies responsible for deforestation and overfishing
Secondary_URLs: Tax havens and global environmental degradation - Nature 11/09/2018
Keywords: deforestation overfishing

Summary Sentence: The price of electric storage is declining, which could incentivise its use in the transport sector
Justification: As the costs of batteries declines markedly, their increased adoption could help utilities integrate intermittent renewables into the grid. Electric vehicle batteries would hence be more likely to be charged using low-carbon energy.     McKinsey analysts estimate that the total costs for energy storage systems will fall by 50 to 75 per cent by 2025, because of economies of scale and design improvements. Others forecast that grid-connected storage will grow tenfold by the same time.
Primary Article Title: Grid storage batteries help electric vehicles go truly green
Keywords: electricity storage, renewables, EVs, electric vehicles, electricity production, climate change

Summary Sentence: To achieve deep cuts in emission necessary to mitigate dangerous climate change at least cost, renewables and storage will need to be backed up by options such as nuclear and CCS
Justification:
Deep decarbonisation across the economy will be needed to produce the emission reductions necessary to achieve the aims of the Paris Agreement. Researchers at MIT have investigated the role of "firm" low-carbon technologies, including nuclear power, natural

 gas with carbon capture and storage (CCS) and bioenergy in achieving these. Their results suggest that having these available alongside "new" flexible electricity sources, such as renewables, storage, demand-side response and interconnection would reduce electricity

 costs by 10-62% across a fully decarbonised power sector. This will serve as a contribution to the debate within the energy sphere on what the best future course is for electricity decarbonisation, with some advocating that these firm solutions are avoided.
Primary Article Title: The role of firm low-carbon electricity resources in deep decarbonization of power generation
Author:
Nestor A. Sepulveda
Jesse D. Jenkins
Fernando J. de Sisternes
Richard K. Lester
Keywords: electricity production, climate change, renewables, nuclear, flexibility, CCS, decarbonisation, energy systems

Summary Sentence: Demand for energy storage systems built into households has increased in the US in 2017
Justification:
Consumers in the US installed 57.5MWh of storage capacity in 2018 Q2 than in all of 2017. Declining costs, wider availability of solar-storage systems and greater interest in home energy production have led to a significant rise in consumers installing

 systems within their own homes for electricity storage. When coupled to a home solar PV system, this allows users to use power that is produced when demand is low (such as when occupants are out at work) at another time (when they come home after nightfall).     Home storage systems have the potential to increase energy system flexibility, by reducing demand at peak times and increasing demand when it is needed. This would help to facilitate the integration of intermittent and variable renewables.
Primary Article Title: Residential Energy Storage Surging, No Longer Just a `Cool Toy'
Keywords: electricity production, electricity storage, energy storage, flexibility, electricity flexibility, smart homes, built environment, urban, power generation, renewables

Summary Sentence: Oil giant Shell is changing its business model in anticipation of future energy trends
Justification:
Energy company Royal Dutch Shell has undergone significant change in its business model in anticipation of how the future energy system might transpire. Staff are engaged in how clean energy will come to overtake fossil fuels. Because of this, Shell has

 acquired stakes in a number of renewable energy companies, and has bought energy supplier First Utility as well as an EV charge point company. It recognises that the future will use a significantly greater proportion of power generated from renewables. Key

 to this is EVs; a third of car sales could be electric by 2040, and Shell is preparing to use its network of petrol stations to provide public charging infrastructure for EVs in future.     The article raises the important question of the role large incumbent energy firms within the future transition. Shell have invested £2bn in their "new energies" business, but have many billions more still invested within conventional fossil fuels.
Primary Article Title: 'Shell is ready for the energy shocks to come'
Keywords: energy, electricity production, oil and gas, fossil fuels, business models, EVs, electric vehicles, V2G, flexibility, climate change, Paris Agreement

Summary Sentence: New wind turbine design could allow wind power to be captured in cities effectively
Justification:
Wind turbines are generally not deployed in urban areas because the non-uniform building profiles makes the wind move in ways that are incompatible with using it to produce power. However, two students have produced a new "O-Wind Turbine" design which

 may allow the untapped resource to be exploited. Doing so could potentially open up a much greater tract of land to renewable energy production.
Primary Article Title: Invention that captures wind in cities and turns it into energy is given Dyson award
Keywords: electricity production, wind power, renewables, climate change, urban environment, built environment

Summary Sentence: EU legislators may set targets for more ambitious CO2 reductions for cars and vans than previously envisaged
Justification: The largest bloc in the European Parliament (the EPP) has backed a target of 45 per cent emissions reductions in cars and vans by 2030. This is more ambitious than a 30 per cent target which featured in initial drafts.     Transport is the only major sector in the EU whose greenhouse gas emissions are increasing. The market for electric vehicles has increased significantly in recent years and is expected to do so further in future.
Primary Article Title: EU lawmakers set to back 45 percent cut target for CO2 from cars and vans by 2030
Keywords: electric vehicles, EVs, vehicle efficiency, fuel efficiency, climate change, emissions, transport, biofuel

Summary Sentence: What will be the new defining principle for political economy, which one is best fitted to meet the current economic situation?
Justification:
The defining objective of Keynesian approaches to the political economy was full employment, but this focus effectively reduced the extent to which organisations concentrated on providing a service to customers and service users and the scope for workers

 to focus on contributing to an external purpose. Neoliberalism sought to restore the focus on profitability as the over-riding objective, which changed organisational focus towards serving the owners. Commentators are now suggesting the focus of organisations

 need to change again explicitly focusing on doing good in a world beset by environmental and human rights challenges. Based on studies of what makes work meaningful for people, the author of this article suggests the overriding purpose of economic activity

 should be serving the community; with organisations finding their purposes in the roles they play within this overall provisioning; and the people who work for them finding meaning in applying themselves, with others, to their organisation’s purposes and a

 decent cause.
Primary Article Title: Work&%2358; a situation vacant
Author: Richard Dougals
Keywords: Political Economy; Corporate Social Responsibility

Summary Sentence: Global demand for cooling appliances may double by 2050, which could double energy demand for cooling
Justification:
As developing economies emerge and climate change increases global temperatures, demand for cooling is likely to increase in the future to meet the needs of air conditioning and refrigeration systems worldwide. The report from researchers at the University

 of Birmingham suggests that even if "aggressive" policy and technology improvements are aimed at reducing energy demand from cooling, overall energy demand from cooling is still projected to increase under every scenario. CO2 emissions from the sector are

 forecast to increase under the majority of scenarios. This has significant implications for future projections of climate change mitigation strategies, as the only scenarios in which CO2 emissions decline are ones in which power for cooling would consume more

 than 50% of the projected total renewables capacity. Cooling could hence "crowd out" other hard-to-decarbonise sectors.
Primary Article Title: A Cool World&%2358; Defining the Energy Conundrum of Cooling for All
Keywords: climate change mitigation, climate change adaptation, electricity production, cooling, heating, renewables, scenarios

Summary Sentence: The Chair of Reliance Industries, Mukesh Ambani, has said that 300,000-500,000 Indians are migrating to the low-cost 4G VoLTE JioPhone every day.
Justification:
Telecoms company, Reliance Industries, aims to increase its 160 m user base through it's new low-cost 4G JioPhone. It says that it has created the world's largest greenfield 4G-only LTE data network (which is apparently also 5G-ready) in 3 years, making

 data available at the lowest price in the world (apparently almost one 10th of the price in the US). It aims to "empower the equivalent of two-thirds of Europe’s population to enjoy world-class digital services in India" within the next few years. This story

 highlights how increasing numbers of people who currently don't have internet access are likely to gain online access in the next few years.
Primary Article Title: Reliance jio network may make india 4g leader in 2019&%2358; mukesh ambani
Author: ET Bureau
Keywords: 4G mobile smart phone device India emerging market digital divide online internet access

Summary Sentence: Opinion piece arguing that rapid growth of the digital economy in China, with a relaxed approach to regulation, has led to rapid economic growth and "widespread social unrest".
Justification:
According to the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, the gig economy indirectly led to an 8.1% increase in GDP in 2016 in China, and is offering greater flexibility to millennials and new opportunities for retirees to gain additional income. The author

 argues that the decentralised and capitalistic nature of the gig economy fundamentally opposes the principles of communism. They point to strikes held this summer by long-haul truck drivers, as evidence of the widespread unrest that the gig economy is creating

 in China. The drivers were protesting at increasing fuel costs, decreasing pay, and the dominance of truck-hailing logistics company, Manbang, which runs an app that connects businesses with drivers (an "Uber of trucks").
Primary Article Title: China's gig economy is driving close to the edge
Author: Viola Rothschild
Keywords: gig economy uber truck driver china haulage transport digital platform app online services strike protest lower pay
GT: Chinese truck drivers' gig economy strikes

Summary Sentence: Report from Global Commission on the Economy and Climate suggests that climate mitigation action is economically advantageous cf business-as-usual
Justification:
A report from the Global Commission on the Economy and Climate suggests that the economic benefits of climate change mitigation action have been severely underestimated, and that "bold action" could add $30 trillion to the global economy. The next 10-15

 years will see very substantial levels of investment in infrastructure (greater than the equivalent stock of existing infrastructure), and the authors argue that this represents a "use it or lose it" opportunity to ensure that this infrastructure is sustainable.

 They critique current economic models' ability to capture the potential opportunities from a "transformational shift". The modelling they have commissioned suggests an economic gain of $26 trillion through to 2030 compared with BAU.
Primary Article Title: Bold climate action could deliver US$26 trillion to 2030, finds global commission
Keywords: climate change, economic growth, technology, innovation, climate change adaptation,

Summary Sentence: Airports in the US, Canada and EU could adopt lie-detecting computer kiosks that use AI
Justification:
A CNBC report recently suggested that airports in the US, Canada and the EU could adopt lie-detecting computer kiosks which use AI to try and determine whether a person is trying to deceive officials. Face recognition has been used at airports for several

 years, however, this technology would analyse several other biological traits such as eye movements, vocal changes, odd posture, or facial movements.
Primary Article Title: A.I. border agents could use machine smarts to tell if travelers are lying
Author: Luke Dormehl
Keywords: Biometrics facial recognition lie detection airport security border control

Summary Sentence: DNV GL forecasts significant expansion in power production, along with storage and flexibility, though does not predict that global climate targets will be met
Justification:
Risk managers DNV GL produce forecasts on energy consumption and the UN SDGs. The most recent model projects that by 2050 power production will expand substantially (driven by renewables, storage and flexibility), as well as electric vehicle (EV) ownership.

 In some countries (particularly Europe) it suggests EV market share could reach 90% within 10 years in some reasons, due primarily to the cost of producing EVs to become lower than of fossil fuel vehicles (rather than because of any inherent shift in consumer

 preference).     Higher EV uptake is projected to increase demand for power generation, with renewables forecast to make up the majority of capacity and most of the remainder to come from gas. Vehicle-to-grid is projected to become increasingly important. However, the

 shift away from fossil fuels is not projected to come quickly enough to avoid dangerous climate change and meet the objectives of the Paris Accord.
Primary Article Title: 'We can afford it'&%2358; EV uptake and renewables surge to power 'massive expansion' of energy grids
Keywords: energy, climate change, electricity production, electricity generation, renewables, electricity storage, electric vehicles, EV, vehicle-to-grid, V2G, electricity flexibility

Summary Sentence: British Airways announces that personal and financial data relating to 380,000 customers was stolen during a two week period in August 2018.
Justification:
Customer data, including payment card information that would enable thieves to make unauthorised payments, was stolen from British Airways' website and mobile app over two weeks in August 2018. Latest example of large-scale theft of customer data from

 a company. Other examples include the theft of data relating to over 150,000 customers from TalkTalk in 2015, and 6m credit card records being stolen from Carphone Dixons earlier in 2018.
Primary Article Title: Hackers steal financial data in ba website attack
Author: Josh Spero
Keywords: data protection hack cybercrime cyber security online crime theft ICO retail british airways

Summary Sentence: Analysis of how existing international law created in the 'pre-cyber era' applies to cyber operations that are conducted by, and directed against, states.
Justification:
The original Tallinn Manual (published in 2013), set out how existing legislation (e.g. human rights law, space law and the law of the sea) developed in the pre-internet era applies to the most severe cyber operations (which involve the use of force or

 occur during armed conflict). This more recent report extends this legal analysis to look at more common cyber incidents that states experience on a daily basis, which fall below the thresholds of armed conflict or the use of force. This report was led by

 the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Centre of Excellence and was authored by 19 international law experts.
Primary Article Title: Tallinn manual 2.0
Secondary_URLs: What is cyberwar? Everything you need to know about the frightening future of digital conflict - Zdnet 10/09/2018
Keywords: cyber space international law pre-cyber regime cyberwar state security defence

Summary Sentence: The US have accused North Korea of orchestrating a global cyber crime wave
Justification:
The United States have accused the North Korean regime of orchestrating a wave of cyber crime across the world, including spreading the WannaCry malware in 2017, stealing $81m from Bangladesh’s central bank, and the hacking of corporate emails at Sony

 Pictures in 2014. The US justice department alleged North Korean hacker, Park Jin Hyok, was ordered by Kim Jong Un’s regime to carry out the attacks.
Primary Article Title: US accuses North Korea over global cyber crime wave
Author: Kadhim Shubber, Demetri Sevastopulo
Keywords: Hacking cyber crime malware cyber attack North Korea United States

Summary Sentence: Researchers have found a new way to arrange atoms, allowing them to be arranged in 3D arrays
Justification:
It is currently possible to arrange atoms into one- and two-dimensional arrays using optical tweezers (instruments that trap atoms using highly focused laser beams). Now, French researchers have developed a new method to arrange atoms in 3D arrays. The

 technique involves reflecting a laser off a spatial light modulator (a device that can make a light beam more or less intense), and refocusing it to form a 3D array which can trap atoms. Optical tweezers can then be used to arrange atoms in to the 3D 'scaffold'.

 Manipulation of atoms on this scale is important for applications such as quantum computing, which require the precise arrangement of atoms to programme them.
Primary Article Title: It's now way easier to manipulate individual atoms in 3D
Author: Kristin Houser
Keywords: Quantum computing atomic manipulation optical tweezers atoms 3D arrangement

Summary Sentence: Forced labour is used in a Chinese prisons and the products produced are being shipped internationally, in contravention of international trade laws.
Justification:
Many prisons in China have inmates carrying out forced labour, such as sewing socks or peeling garlic. The conditions in which these prisoners work has been documented as being inhumane. Although international trade laws does not allow for products made

 in prison to be shipped internationally, prisons in China are managing to export them through shell companies. Concerns have been raised about human rights.
Primary Article Title: Your Christmas socks&%2358; made in china... by a prisoner?
Author: Yang, Y.
Keywords: crime prison "forced labour" "prison labour" work

Summary Sentence: Discussion of different ways companies are making money from the 'epidemic of loneliness', including through new technologies.
Justification:
China and Japan have high levels of loneliness. Companies are seeking to solve loneliness and create services and products for lonely people. These include solo karaoke bars, single restaurants and individual movie screenings. There are also emerging technologies,

 such as augmented and virtual reality, which have been suggested as a means of preventing loneliness. For example, chatbots and virtual pets are used by some older people to feel less alone.
Primary Article Title: China cashes in on all the lonely people
Author: Halder, B.
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" loneliness isolation AR VR

Summary Sentence: In an experiment where artificial intelligence agents donated virtual money, those who were more similar created in-groups and donated more to each other.
Justification:
