A study created artificial intelligence agents who were tasked with donating virtual money in order to get as much money back in return. AI agents were more likely to donate to others with similar traits (denoted by an arbitrary numeric value). The AI

 agents seemed to have learned that a donation to the in-group result would in more reciprocation and that donating to others would lead to loss.
Primary Article Title: Left unchecked, artificial intelligence can become prejudiced all on its own
Author: Robitzski, D.
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" bias inequality charity finance

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed artificial intelligence which can identify objects its never seen before
Justification:
Computer vision describes a machine's ability to 'see' and interpret objects and images. However, a machine usually has to have seen the object / image previously in order to recognize it again. Researcher's from MIT have developed a new type of AI known

 as Dense Object Nets (DON) which can allow a machine to interpret an object it has not encountered before, but is similar. DON allows the machine to looks at objects as a collection of points which it can process to create a 3D model. When DON sees an object

 which has familiar characteristics to objects it's encountered, it can identify new parts of that object. For example, the AI was able to pick up a shoe which had been positioned in a different orientation to what it was used to. It could also pick up other

 shoes which were not exactly like the ones it had been trained to interpret.
Primary Article Title: MIT's new robot can visually understand objects it's never seen before
Author: Kristin Houser
Keywords: Artificial intelligence machine learning object sensing dense object nets computer vision

Summary Sentence: A network of AI agents autonomously developed in-group biases
Justification:
New research published in Scientific Reports showed how a network of AI agents autonomously developed an in-group preference for agents similar to themselves, and a bias against agents that were different. The experiment was set up so that the AI agents

 had to donate virtual money to other agents, and had to choose which other agents they donated to. The AI agents were more likely to donate to others that had been tagged with similar traits (which was done my assigning a numerical value to each agent) and

 showed a prejudice against agents that were different. Following this, leading mathematicians have called for people to be more skeptical about the algorithms used in our day to day lives.
Primary Article Title: Left unchecked, artificial intelligence can become prejudiced all on its own
Author: Dan Robitzski
Keywords: AI bias network prejudice algorithms

Summary Sentence: There have been reports of staff at the US Embassy in Cuba experiencing symptoms which some researchers have suggested may be caused by pulsed microwaves - this has been disputed by others.
Justification:
Roughly two dozen staff in the US Embassy in Cuba have reportedly experienced a "constellation of symptoms" over the past 2 years, without an obvious cause. A major medical examination of the diplomats reported that they appeared to have sustained injuries

 to widespread brain networks without an associated history of head trauma, and suggested that they could be victims of a novel agent. It has been suggested that microwaves are a main suspect. Other researchers dispute this. A panel of experts appointed by

 the Cuban government have said that the diplomats most likely suffered a "collective psychogenic disorder" brought on by stress. The news article's authors say that no microwave weapon that affects the brain is known to exist.
Primary Article Title: Scientists are now really fighting about the cause of those 'sonic attacks', and we're here for it
Author: Sarah Kaplan and Joel Achenbach
Keywords: sonic attack weapon microwaves novel arms US Cuba brain injury psychological contagion

Summary Sentence: A team of researchers in Japan aim to run an experiment to test elevator movement in space, in September 2018.
Justification:
The idea of an elevator that could carry a payload from Earth, up into orbit, is well established, however the technical challenges are huge. For example, it would have to withstand significant gravitational forces and stressed caused by strong winds,

 requiring an extremely strong material that would be light enough not to collapse under its own weight. Carbon nanotubes has been suggested as a potential candidate. Researchers at Shizuoka University are about to start testing the principle of elevator movement

 in space, in an experiment in which a scale model of a space elevator will be launched into Earth's orbit. The model consists of two cubic satellites (10 cm across), connected by a 10m steel cable. Japanese construction company, Obsayashu Corp (which is working

 with Shizuoka University), has said that it hopes to produce an operational space elevator by 2050, which would include a geostationary space station and a tether in the Pacific Ocean.
Primary Article Title: Japan is about to start testing the feasibility of a space elevator
Author: Michelle Starr
Keywords: space elevator transport satellite orbit earth carbon nanotube materials

Summary Sentence: Twitter suspends the accounts of a right-wing conspiracy theorist, following what it described as his "abusive behaviour", and faces intense political scrutiny from the US Senate.
Justification:
Twitter has permanently suspended the personal account and media outlet account of right-wing conspiracy theorist, Alex Jones, after what it described as his "abusive behaviour" on the platform. Mr Jones had already been suspended from a number of other

 platforms, including Apple and YouTube. Twitter has been accused of deliberately "shadow banning" Republicans by making their tweets harder to find. Twitter say that it had sometimes mistakenly made it harder to find tweets from some politicians, but that

 this had affected both Republicans and Democrats. This illustrates some of the challenges that social media platforms face when trying to moderate the content they host, and the growing levels of political scrutiny that they face.
Primary Article Title: Twitter bans conspiracy theorist Alex Jones
Author: Richard Waters
Keywords: social media moderation censorship online content regulation free speech abuse freedom news fake disinformation

Summary Sentence: Chinese software company, Tencent, plans to introduce a real-name verification system that will be linked to a public security database to check users' identities, in order to limit the playing time of minors.
Justification:
The Government in China has expressed concerns about the impact of computer games on children, including the potential for them to become addicted or for their vision to be affected. The Ministry of Education has said that parents should reduce the time

 that children spend on devices to 1 hour per day for pre-school children. In a climate of growing regulation, software company Tencent has announced that it plans to introduce an identity verification system that will check the real names of new users against

 a database belonging to public security authorities. Users identified as being under 12 would be limited to one hours' playing time per day. Children over 12 would be limited to two hours. This is an example of how technical tools may be used to influence/moderate

 users behaviour online.
Primary Article Title: China's tencent plans id system to limit minors' video game usage
Author: Hudson Lockett and Louise Lucas
Keywords: age verification online behaviour children computer games minors addiction screen time exposure health identification privacy

Summary Sentence: Uber plans to prevent passengers with low average ratings from using its app in Australia and New Zealand
Justification:
Uber is planning changes to its policies on the 19th September 2018, which will mean that passengers with average star ratings that fall below a certain threshold will be prevented from using the app for 6 months. They will receive a series of warnings

 before hand, along with information about how they can improve their score. Commentators have suggested that Uber's law wages have led to a shortage of drivers, and that this initiative could help to make the platform more attractive to drivers. Parallels

 have been drawn between this system and the 'social credit system' being implemented in China. Analysts say that the use of such social credit systems based on algorithms to rate the behaviour of customers and potentially restrict access to services is likely

 to rise, and may lead to the reinforcement of biases and stereotypes.
Primary Article Title: Uber to impose bans on low-rated passengers in australia and nz
Author: Jamie Smyth
Keywords: algorithms discrimination bias customer consumer rights uber gig economy social credit ranking
GT: Uber passenger ratings restrict service access

Summary Sentence: A proof-of-concept attack shows how hackers might affect the steering of an autonomous vehicle.
Justification:
Researchers from the US and China have demonstrated that a $225 piece of hardware planted on an autonomous vehicle can be used to spoof the radio signals of civilian GPS services in order to divert it, for example to an unintended destination. There are

 limitations on the use of this kind of attack, including the need to place hardware on the target vehicle, and the attacker having a general idea of the vehicle's intended destination. They are unlikely to be applicable on a large scale. This highlights the

 potential for navigation systems to be vulnerable to attacks/manipulation, which is significant given that navigation services are already very widely used and likely to find increasing application in the future, e.g. if autonomous vehicles become widely adopted.
Primary Article Title: A $225 gps spoofer can send sat-nav-guided vehicles into oncoming traffic
Author: Dan Goodin
Keywords: GPS navigation autonomous vehicle hack cyber security exploit driverless car safety law enforcement

Summary Sentence: A proof-of-concept quadcopter drone capable of airborne surveillance and carrying a warhead.
Justification:
Israel Aerospace Industries demonstrated the Rotem UAS proof-of-concept quadcopter. Reportedly, it can be put into automated observation and attack modes once a target has been designated, has automated take-off and landing control, an emergency "return

 home" feature, and can disable its warhead if an attack is aborted. This is one of a number of different drone systems that have been developed/are being developed, some of which are fixed-wing and others of which use rotors.
Primary Article Title: Israeli defense firm demos kamikaze drone bomb that can be called off
Author: Sean Gallagher
Keywords: attack drone military defence security surveillance technology warhead explosion bomb autonomous quadcopter

Summary Sentence: A flexible, flying "drone-robot" that can autonomously decided how to change shape in order to move past/through obstacles, known as DRAGON, has been developed by academics at Tokyo University.
Justification:
Japan is very advanced in its development of robotics. Social trends such as its aging population and declining workforce suggest that may become a strong market for such technology in the future. DRAGON's specific use cases are unclear at present, but

 it may be applicable to navigating through hazardous environments during rescue missions or for inspection tasks.
Primary Article Title: Flexible `dragon' drone autonomously shapeshifts to fly through tight spaces
Author: Marc Prosser
Keywords: drone flexible autonomous shapesift change shape rescue inspection hazardous environment robotics japan

Summary Sentence: China has tested the Xingkong-2 (Starry Sky-2) hypersonic experimental waverider vehicle, which can reportedly achieve a top speed six times the velocity of sound.
Justification:
State-run media have reported that China has tested a new hypersonic aircraft that in the future might be capable of carrying nuclear warheads and evading existing defence networks, such as the US' missile shields. This type of hypersonic aircraft (known

 as a waverider) rides the shock waves generated during hypersonic flight and uses a process known as compression lift to improve its lift-to-drag ratio. The aircraft's speed and unpredictable flight trajectories makes it particularly difficult for existing

 defence systems to intercept. The Director of DARPA has highlighted the number of Chinese facilities for developing hypersonics, which out-number those in the US, and says that this shows that China has made this one of its national priorities. Other countries,

 such as the US and Russia, are also developing hypersonic vehicle systems.
Primary Article Title: China hails a 'successful' test of a new hypersonic weapon that could slip a nuke past US defences
Author: Ryan Pickrell
Secondary_URLs: China just launched a hypersonic aircraft that could slip a nuke past us defences - Science Alert 08/08/2018
Keywords: aircraft missile defence hypersonic stealth aeroplane us china russia nuclear weapons defense systems waverider

Summary Sentence: It is predicted that the number of cooling devices in use across the planet will increase from 3.6 to 50 billion due to a warming planet and increased population size.
Justification:
Cooling is essential for food, medicine, industry and economic growth. With the potential for the earth to warm in certain regions beyond that at which humans can survive, cooling may mean the difference between life and death for some populations. It

 is suggested that technology efficiency and greening electricity will not be sufficient to meet this demand and meet the Paris Climate targets. A recent study has also demonstrated that during a heatwave, memory and cognitive speed is reduced compared to those

 in an air conditioned environment. The difference in cognitive ability demonstrated by students in China living in two buildings - one air conditioned and one not - was 13 per cent. It is suggested that better regulation of new builds to ensure energy efficiency

 of buildings, coupled with tighter controls over the emissions from air conditioning units, could provide part of the answer.
Primary Article Title: Global quadrupling of cooling appliances to 14 billion by 2050
Secondary_URLs: Study Shows Heat Hurts Cognitive Ability - Motherboard 10/07/2018
Keywords: climate heat "heat waves" cooling "air conditioning" "cooling devices" memory cognition workforce

Summary Sentence: A comprehensive set of criteria have been developed by an international group of researchers to help the ISA (International Seabed Authority) protect the seabed from environmental damage caused by deep sea mining activities.
Justification:
Whilst the act of deep sea mining is outside of the jurisdiction of the Environment Agency, its development would around the UK would impact on the shoreline and coastal communities. These guidelines should help identify those areas of environmental concern

 where mining should not be carried out. This new set of guidelines is in keeping with the ambitions of the 'Blue Economy' which works towards "sustainable use of ocean resources for economic growth, improved livelihood and jobs, and ocean ecosystem health.

 The paper sets out 18 quantitative metrics to enable regulators to better understand if the "number, shapes, sizes and locations" of mining sites within a designated no-mining zone would affect habitats and species that could potentially be harmed by mining

 activity. As the 'on-shore' regulator of such activity, the Environment Agency could become an advisory body to such decision-making processes. The guidelines also take into account the potential effects of climate change over the next 100 years.
Primary Article Title: Research reveals strategy for 'no-mining zones' in the deep sea
Secondary_URLs:
A strategy for the conservation of biodiversity on mid-ocean ridges from deep-sea mining - Science Advances 06/09/2018

What is the Blue Economy? - The World Bank 06/06/2017
Keywords: mining "deep sea mining" oceans sea "climate change" "blue economy" sustainability "economic growth" "environmental protection" biodiversity, marine

Summary Sentence: Excessive exposure to blue light can lead to damage to photoreceptor cells (found in the eyes) and cells from other tissues (such as hear cells and neurons), according to a recent academic publication.
Justification:
It was previously understood that exposure to blue light can have toxic effects and lead to retina damage, but the mechanism by which this occurred was not known. Researchers publishing in Nature have conducted experiments that explain how this happens.

 They hope that this will lead to therapies that slow macular degeneration (although the extent to which various eye diseases are caused by blue light is still debated). There are increasing applications for blue light, for example in mobile devices and LED

 lighting. This study suggests that exposure to such devices might have implications for health.
Primary Article Title: Blue light excited retinal intercepts cellular signaling
Author: Kasun Ratnayake, John L. Payton, O. Harshana Lakmal & Ajith Karunarathne
Secondary_URLs: Blue light is causing the human eye to attack itself - Science Alert 09/08/2018
Keywords: eye damage health blue light mobile devices LED lighting IT tech medical implications

Summary Sentence: US Vice President Pence has set out plans to establish a new military command focusing on space, and to create a "Space Force" as a sixth branch of the US military as early as 2020.
Justification:
The US administration has highlighted concerns about advances that potential adversaries (such as China) are making within space, and are have said that the US will "meet the emerging threats on this new battlefield" by establishing the United States Space

 Force. Initial plans include creating a US Space Command by the end of 2018, which would bring together space experts from across the military, and establish an acquisitions office to buy new technology (such as satellites). Critics highlight challenges to

 implementing this, which include gaining approval from Congress (which rejected the idea last year). The US is not the only state to express interest in developing its space defence capabilities, others include Russia, China and the UK.
Primary Article Title: Trump's 'space force' is serious and we just got a bunch of new details
Author: Christian Davenport and Dan Lamothe, The Washington Post
Keywords: space defence US military war conflict satellites military command force Trump Pence Russian China

Summary Sentence: Start-up company Rigetti Computing has designed a microchip for quantum computers that would be more powerful than Google's 72-qubit machine and IBM's 50-qubit machine.
Justification:
There are a number of companies and groups of academic researchers who are working to develop quantum computers. They have yet to produce a machine with a demonstrable "quantum advantage" - when a quantum computer can perform more effectively than a traditional

 computer. However, companies and others say that this development could be close. For example, Rigetti is hoping to build a functioning 128-qubit computer in the next 12 months, which might be able to put-perform conventional computers. Similarly, D-Wave System's

 CEO has said that he believes that quantum advantage might be achieved perhaps within two years. The development of quantum computers would have significant implications for security, research and other areas.
Primary Article Title: Quantum computers today aren't very useful. that could change
Author: Eric Newcomer
Keywords: quantum computer data analytics research development Rigetti D-wave security analysis computation power

Summary Sentence: A study from the US demonstrates that metabolites resulting from flame retardants, plasticizers and other chemicals can be more toxic than the parent compound.
Justification:
The Environment Agency monitors the effects of chemicals in the environment and the effects of chemical combinations. However, this research may be of particular interest as it highlights the effect of metabolites on a particularly vulnerable species.

 The researchers studied bald eagle eggs and found that the level of flame retardants they were expecting to find were very low. Further analysis explained that the reason for this low level was that the flame retardant had metabolized. Although the researchers

 do not know how this may affect bald eagle populations, other studies involving chickens have demonstrated that metabolites altered three times as many genes as the parent compound. Bald eagles are considered a sentinel species as they are at the top of the

 food chain and feed primarily on fish and wildfowl. Therefore, this study would suggest that metabolites could also effect humans and other species.
Primary Article Title: Study raises concern about flame-retardant metabolites in bald eagles
Secondary_URLs: Flame Retardant Metabolites in Addled Bald Eagle Eggs from the Great Lakes Region - Environmental Science and Technology Letters 05/09/2018
Keywords: "toxic chemicals" contaminants "flame retardants" plasticizers chemicals metabolites "land pollution" pollution metabolism

Summary Sentence: Accumulation of particulate matter on trees results in increased transpiration leading to increased levels of drought vulnerability.
Justification:
The Environment Agency has been interested in how particulate matter affects human health but little is currently known about how particulate affect plants. This research compared trees grown in greenhouses with unfiltered air and those grown in greenhouses

 where particulates were filtered out. The results show that scots pine, silver fir and common oak grown in particulate free air were less likely to release water than those grown in greenhouses with particulates. These results show that trees are more at risk

 from drought when grown in areas with higher particulates.
Primary Article Title: Particulate matter increases drought vulnerability of trees
Secondary_URLs: Camouflaged as `degraded wax'&%2358; hygroscopic aerosols contribute to leaf desiccation, tree mortality, and forest decline. - Environmental Research Letters 05/09/2018
Keywords: pollution "air pollution" drought particulates trees leaves transpiration greenhouses

Summary Sentence:
"Pebbles" is the development of a regional energy trading platform that allows users to transact with both businesses and net services on the same platform and US startup Leap, are using blockchain technology to deliver grid edge flexible energy to major

 utility companies.
Justification:
The Environment Agency have been reporting on blockchain and decentralisation over the past few months. This development project uses blockchain technology to deal with both regional and local energy businesses of distribution networks. This will allow

 different players, such as private households and businesses to flexibly trade energy with one another. Blockchain technology will be used to map the commitments between players using smart contracts. In another development, a new startup company in the US,

 Leap, has been awarded contracts to deliver 90 megawatts of energy to three major utility companies through sources of grid edge flexibility via a distributed energy exchange. Both of these examples demonstrate that decentralised energy is not only here to

 stay but is now finding a secure means of trading through blockchain technology.
Primary Article Title: Leap, a New Startup Testing Blockchain, Takes 90MW Stake in California's Distributed Energy Auction
Secondary_URLs: Go-ahead for starting the new Blockchain Research project "pebbles" - AlphaGalileo 04/09/2018
Keywords: blockchain "distributed energy" energy decentralisation power pebbles leap "energy markets" grid "national grid" trade trading

Summary Sentence: Skyrmions are quasiparticles that could reduce the energy demand for IT power by ten times.
Justification:
The carbon footprint of computing is enormous and in the last ten years, has become bigger than the carbon footprint of air travel. Skyrmions are quasiparticles that are smaller and more stable than current computing storage devices which, could make them

 ideal as the basis for the next generation of computers. Furthermore, they require ten times less energy to power them and potentially, with further development, could use even less. It is incredibly difficult to destroy a skyrmion making them incredibly safe

 storage. Also, because of their tiny size, can travel huge distances with very little energy. This could result in high density storage with very little energy consumption. The fundamental physics behind this technology is still not fully understood so skyrmions

 will not be available for a while. However, when they are, there are hopes that they could provide the computing power of a human brain as their size means they can be moved around in three dimensions resulting in immensely more computing power than current

 methods that rely on two dimensional, binary approaches.
Primary Article Title: Meet the skyrmions&%2358; exotic quasiparticles could revolutionise computing
Keywords: skyrmions quasiparticles computing energy IT computers energy data digital

Summary Sentence: Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan, is proposing relaxing population controls that have capped the number of people who can live and work there since the Soviet era.
Justification:
There are strict restrictions on who can work and live in Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan. Permits to live in Tashkent were limited to those born in the capital or whose parents who were, those married to residents and government workers. This limited

 the population growth to just just 14 percent in Tashkent between 1991 and 2017, compared to 56 percent growth in Uzbekistan as a whole. However, there are concerns that these strict controls are also limiting an economic boom as more skilled workers are needed

 in the capital and there is a brain drain with young people moving to places like Russia which no longer have such strict population controls. Temporary permits to live in Tashkent have been granted and there are proposals to grant residency to those who buy

 property there. However, due to previous population controls, much infrastructure (such as roads, sewage systems and schools) has not been increased since the 1970s and there are concerns that it will not cope with a sudden increase in population. Internationally,

 the current population controls have been criticized for violating people's human rights. With growing populations and increased attention on migration, population levels and controls may become more relevant internationally.
Primary Article Title: As China caps city populations, its neighbor rolls out the red carpet
Author: Makarenko, N.
Keywords: inequality migration "population control" population "brain drain" "city planning" infrastructure

Summary Sentence: A study has found that the number of provocative pictures women post is not correlated with gender inequality but is correlated with gender income inequality.
Justification:
A study looked at the geographic markers of 68,000 provocative pictures from Twitter and Instagram. It correlated the number of pictures taken in a geographic region (US cities and US counties) and the gender inequality and gender income inequality in

 that area. There was not a correlation between number of provocative pictures posted and gender inequality in gender, but there was a correlation with gender income inequality; more pictures were posted in areas with a greater gender pay gap. Additionally,

 analysis of sales data on beauty salons and women's clothing showed the same correlation. The researchers also found similar results tracking social media posts across 113 nations.
Primary Article Title: There's a disturbing link between women posting sexy selfies and income inequality
Author: Cassella, C.
Keywords: "gender pay gap" income gender "social media" inequality

Summary Sentence: A startup incubator announced a trial of basic income for 1,000 participants but is struggling to secure funding.
Justification:
Y combinator, a startup incubator, ran a small basic income feasibility study with a dozen people in California in 2016. In 2017 it announced a large trial with 1,000 participants (and 2,000 participants in control groups). The trial is proposed to start

 in 2019 but there are questions over whether it will secure enough funding as it will cost an estimated $60m. This lack of funding support may hinder future trials of basic income.
Primary Article Title: Y combinator's basic income experiment is off to a slow start
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: "universal basic income" "basic income" jobs employment unemployment

Summary Sentence: This example from South Africa demonstrates that decentralisation of water resources can only work if all interested parties are given an equal voice and allowed to participate fully in decision-making.
Justification:
The Environment Agency has been following the trend to a more decentralised society in areas of power, water, economics and manufacturing. Examples from Africa demonstrate that for decentralisation to be effective, local people must be allowed to participate

 in all decision-making processes. For example, new approaches to governance will be required to include groups that could have an influence over water resources and sustainability and provide technical solutions to climate change issues. While the examples

 in this article focus on developing countries, the solutions for effective water management are the same across all nations. Working towards technical solutions to impact climate change in a decentralised society, will only be effective if the right groups

 are engaged at a local level and the Environment Agency, along with other environmental bodies across the UK, has a role to play in the formation and maintenance of such groups.
Primary Article Title: Why ordinary people must have a say in water governance
Keywords: "water resources" water Africa decentralisation sustainability people communities "community engagement" "water management" "water strategy" policy resources

Summary Sentence: The new, stricter, policies in China (aimed at cleaning up the emissions from power stations) are only working for emitters in non-key areas - those where populations and pollution levels are lower.
Justification:
The problem is with sulphur dioxide emissions. The 'key' regions - those with higher populations and more pollution (such as big cities), are the areas where power plants have been lease effective at reducing emissions. The research team studied data from

 CEMS (Continuous Emissions Monitoring Systems) that can be 'manipulated' by the power plants and compared it to data from satellites that cannot. The results indicate that in 'non-key' areas, the data from CEMS and the satellites corresponded. However, in

 'key' areas it did not. The results indicate that the new policy to reduce emissions was too difficult for the 'key' power plants to meet. Furthermore, the process of collecting CEMS data is too easy to manipulate by power plans and therefore, should always

 be backed up with an independent monitoring system such as satellite data.
Primary Article Title: Checking China's pollution by satellite
Secondary_URLs: Quantifying coal power plant responses to tighter SO2 emissions standards in China - PNAS 03/07/2018
Keywords: pollution "air pollution" monitoring satellites emissions "sulphur dioxide" China "urban pollution" cities CEMS "continuous monitoring" policy

Summary Sentence: IBM show how AI powered facial recognition can trigger malware
Justification:
Security researchers at IBM have carried out a proof of concept project to demonstrate how facial recognition technology that uses AI can unlock malicious content within an application. The AI was able to monitor the user of a device through the device's

 webcam. The face of the user acted as a key to unlock malware on the device. This has potential implications for targeted malware attacks.
Primary Article Title: How AI-powered malware uses facial recognition technology
Author: Dan Patterson
Keywords: IBM malware facial recognition biometrics devices cyberattacks

Summary Sentence: The Defense Department has developed AI to detect fake video clips
Justification:
The US Department of Defence have developed the first forensic tool for detecting fake revenge porn and fake news. The fake videos are usually made by using machine learning to superimpose someone else's face onto another's. These types of video are known

 as 'deepfakes'. The US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) developed a program which can identify subtle cues in videos and detect the presence of alterations.
Primary Article Title: The defense department has produced the first tools for catching DeepFakes
Author: Will Knight
Keywords: DeepFakes artificial intelligence fake video detection fake news

Summary Sentence: Manufacturers and retailers of "smart home" devices envisage increased consumer convenience and energy savings, but the latter may not be the case
Justification:
There is a burgeoning consumer industry focusing on "Smart" homes, which contain many devices connected to the internet to increase automativity and user convenience. The paper unpacks narratives from smart home device manufacturers, finding that increased

 user convenience is envisaged. However, the authors argue that smart homes devices may change everyday practices in which increase energy consumption and household labour. They conclude by calling for increased social science research into the potential relationship

 between smart home devices and energy demand.
Primary Article Title: Convenience and energy consumption in the smart home of the future&%2358; Industry visions from Australia and beyond
Author:
Yolande Strengers
Larissa Nicholls
Keywords: smart home, convenience, energy consumption, internet of things, energy demand, user practice

Summary Sentence: California lawmakers commit to 100 percent carbon-free electricity by 2045, despite
Justification:
The State of California is about to pass a Bill which will move it toward 100% low-carbon electricity production by 2045 (with a staged implementation of 60% renewable sources by 2030). Power forms allowed under the 2045 target would include renewables,

 large hydro, nuclear, and gas with CCS.     Given that the Federal Government has reversed many Obama-era climate mitigation policies, including the flagship Clean Power Plan, the State's intervention highlights the increasing level of ambition on climate change at the sub-national level.
Primary Article Title: California Lawmakers Pass Historic Bill Mandating Only Carbon-Free Power By 2045
Keywords: climate change, electricity production, power, governance, US, renewables, nuclear, hydropower, natural gas, climate change mitigation

Summary Sentence: Banks and merchants increasingly tracking users' physical movements to help identify them to reduce fraud.
Justification:
Behavioural biometrics (e.g. the way you press, type or scroll) on a smart phone or tablet are increasingly being used by companies to verify the identity of users. Uses range from identifying automated attacks or suspicious transactions, to confirming

 the identity of individual customers. They have the potential to be a valuable security tool, but also present privacy concerns about their potential to reveal private information about individuals, for example if a biometric system can be used to detect medical

 conditions, allowing a company to infer information that a customer isn't aware of or hasn't disclosed. This could be challenging if it affects customers' abilities to access, for example, insurance.
Primary Article Title: Banks and retailers are tracking how you type, swipe and tap
Author: Stacy Cowley
Secondary_URLs: The smartphone app that can tell you're depressed before you know it yourself - MIT Technology Review 15/10/2018
Keywords: behavioural biometrics security crime fraud online device tablet smartphone biometric technology

Summary Sentence: Indian Space Agency to launch probe to Moon to search for nuclear fusion fuel
Justification:
The Indian Space Agency has announced that it will send a probe to the Moon in October 2018 to study the potential for mining helium-3, the fuel used in nuclear fusion energy production. It is estimated that there are 250,000 tonnes of the helium isotope,

 which could theoretically meet the world's current energy demand for 200-500 years. The prospect of commercial activity on the Moon raises questions over future international governance and boundaries.
Primary Article Title: The Quest to Find a Trillion-Dollar Nuclear Fuel on the Moon
Keywords: space exploration, space mining, space commerce, space, nuclear fusion, helium-3, nuclear power, moon, india

Summary Sentence: A game platform has been developed to provide police officers, aid workers and other staff with training in responding to threats from terrorism and organised crime.
Justification:
The Automated Serious Game Scenario Generator for Mixed Reality Training (AUGGMED) project has produced an online training platform that allows trainees to perform exercises within virtual reconstructions of real-world scenarios and to interact with virtual

 terrorists and real-world civilians. This aims to give them experience of operating in stressful situations and to help them improve their decision-making. AUGGMED has been used to train security officers at the Piraeus Port Authority in Greece. other systems

 have been used for training humanitarian agency staff who work in dangerous environments. According to the authors, Certain sectors such as aviation and the military have been using virtual reality and 'serious games' for some time, however discussions around

 how they can be used in other sectors such as law enforcement, construction and food safety are only taking place now. They say that one day, such technology will become a ubiquitous part of training, as cost effectiveness improves and the benefits for leaning

 and knowledge retention become even more apparent.
Primary Article Title: Counter-terrorism police are now training with virtual terrorists
Author: Jonathan Saunders
Keywords: virtual reality augmented digital learning training computing computer simulation terrorism law enforcement aid worker staff serious games humanitarian construction

Summary Sentence: A new research institute has been established in the UK to look at the social and ethical implications of data and data analysis techniques such as artificial intelligence.
Justification:
The Ada Lovelace Institute is being established by a number of partnering organizations, including the Nuffield Foundation, the Alan Turing Institute, the Royal Statistical Society and the Wellcome Trust. It aims to convene different stakeholders to develop

 a shared understanding of the ethical questions raised by the use of data and algorithms; to conduct research that will build an evidence based for how these technologies will impact society; and to promote ethical practices. This project suggests a growing

 desire among researchers, policy makers, industry and wider society to better understand the affects of data and algorithms on society.
Primary Article Title: the Nuffield foundation announces new £5 million ada lovelace institute to examine profound ethical and social issues arising from the use of data, algorithms, and artificial intelligence, and to ensure they are harnessed for social well-being
Author: The Nuffield Foundation
Keywords: data analytics artificial intelligence computing algorithm ethics social impacts implications
GT: Research data's social and ethical impacts

Summary Sentence: Analysis has revealed the types of knowledge and skills that may be desirable to future employers, and how the workforce may need to educate themselves in order to be desirable employees.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in considering these signals in its own long term workforce planning to ensure that it is an attractive employer as well as attracting the right skills to serve the future environment and economy. Analysis Nesta,

 based on looking at 41 million job adverts revealed that non-digitally intensive occupations such as teachers and chefs, could grow in the future whereas digitally intensive occupations may shrink. At the same time digital skills used in non-routine tasks,

 problem solving and digital outputs may also be in demand. Nesta’s top five promising digital skills include&%2358; animation; multimedia production; design in engineering; building and maintaining IT systems and networks; and research and quantitative data analysis.

 The least promising digital skills include&%2358; invoice processing and management of accounts using accounting software; data input and preparation of payroll and tax reports; clerical duties (e.g. typing, using a word processor, spreadsheets, email and calendar

 software); sales support and processing of orders in sales management systems; and stock and inventory management using inventory control systems. There are also signs that arts disciplines such as philosophy, English and languages may become in greater demand

 than science, technology, engineering and maths (STEM). McKinsey analysis of future skills has (amongst others) predicted that demand for arts-associated skills such as creativity, empathy, adaptability and entrepreneurship will grow at a faster rate to 2030

 than demand for skills in technology engineering data analysis, and research and development. STEAM with the A for ‘Arts’ is therefore gaining traction as a term within industry. As the power of automation grows (as exemplified by IBM’s AI that beat a human

 in a debating contest (%2314823), the human workforce will add value delivering the skills that machines can’t replicate. This means that education may need to consider equipping students with STEAM skills, and employers may need to consider STEAM skills in

 order to have a future proof workforce.
Primary Article Title: Full STEAM ahead as arts and tech shape future skills together
Author: Feest, J
Secondary_URLs: Which digital skills do you really need? - Nesta 31/07/2018
Keywords: workforce employment skill employee science engineering technology mathematics job employer STEM STEAM art English philosophy automation "artificial intelligence" AI IBM McKinsey data analysis research software digital process clerical

Summary Sentence: Cyber security researchers have found that credit card thieves are using in-app purchases within free-to-play online games to launder money from stolen credit cards.
Justification:
Investigations by the cyber security company, Kromtech, suggest that cyber criminals have developed a money laundering system that enables them to use stolen credit cards to buy in-game purchases (such as virtual gems) which can then be sold on to other

 players in exchange for real-world currencies. This process can be largely automated, allowing the scam to be run at scale. This investigation found that 3 games were being targeted - Clash of Clans, Clash Royale and Marvel Contest of Champions. It highlighted

 a number of weaknesses which help facilitate this activity, including&%2358; the ease with which email accounts can be automatically set up, and the lack of credit card validation by the platforms facilitating payments. Criminals are likely to continue to find new

 ways of using games and other online platforms to facilitate illegal activity.
Primary Article Title: Digital laundry&%2358; how credit card thieves use free-to-play apps to launder their ill-gotten gains
Author: Security Centre, Kromtech
Keywords: cyber security money laundering gaming online financial crime credit card theft data protection digital forensics cybercrime
GT: online games used for money laundering

Summary Sentence: Surveillance technology advances could be of benefit to employers concerned about the health and emotional wellbeing of their staff.
Justification:
New research has shown that a simple saliva test can indicate if someone is stressed and approaching ‘burnout’. The test identifies traces of the anti-stress hormone cortisol. While levels rise and fall during the day in healthy people, cortisol levels

 in chronically stressed people remains high throughout the day. Three samples a day would be sufficient to diagnose someone. Researchers in China have developed a different way to assess workers for stress. They have developed a device a lightweight sensor

 that monitors brain waves for signs of stress. The sensors could be fitted into a hat or helmet, wirelessly transmitting data back to an employer. Artificial intelligence (AI) then scans the data for signs of stress or anger. Ths would allow employers to intervene

 before symptoms become counterproductive. It is unclear whether the motivations for developing the brainwave sensor are due to health and safety concerns. Nevertheless similar technology could be deployed to ensure staff health and safety especially during

 recognised periods of stress such as during a major incident.
Primary Article Title: `Forget the Facebook leak'&%2358; China is mining data directly from workers' brains on an industrial scale
Author: Chen, S
Secondary_URLs:
Midday and nadir salivary cortisol appear superior to cortisol awakening response in burnout assessment and monitoring - Nature 14/06/2018

Risk of burnout can be estimated by analysing saliva samples - AlphaGalileo 15/06/2018
Keywords: workforce health safety wellbeing "well being" monitoring medicine mental stress burnout cortisol hormone brain brain wave China surveillance incident emergency hat helmet uniform

Summary Sentence: Academic research indicates that it is possible to identify individuals from the computer code that they write, using machine learning techniques.
Justification:
Academics at Drexel University and George Washington University have found that computer code can be analysed with machine learning algorithms to identify the authors of a selection of samples of code. The algorithms assessed features in the code that

 varied between author, which would be analogous in a piece of writing to features such as sentence length and vocabulary chosen. The academics say that there is potential for their work to be used to determine whether a programming student plagiarized a piece

 of code or whether developers have violated non-complete clauses in their employment contracts. It may also be useful for security researchers trying to find out who created a particular piece of malware. There is also the potential for it to lead to infringements

 of privacy, for example if it was used by an authoritarian government to identify an individual who had created a tool to circumvent censorship. There is also the potential that coders may be able to spoof their "coding signature", tricking the algorithm into

 thinking that someone else has written a piece of code.
Primary Article Title: Even anonymous coders leave fingerprints
Author: Casey Chin
Keywords: programming computer coding code digital forensics data de-anonymisation privacy intellectual property plagiarism security law enforcement teaching

Summary Sentence: Reports that over 1000 news websites have blocked access to European visitors rather than comply with GDPR legislation.
Justification:
Internet users in the Europe are reporting that they can no longer access many US news websites. One user reported that he had identified over 1000 website that could not be accessed. Sites such as the Los Angeles Times are displaying notices to visitors

 saying that their website is currently unavailable in most European countries and that they are looking for solutions. This is one example of what some people believe is a trend of increasing fragmentation of the Internet, where content and services are not

 equally available to all.
Primary Article Title: More than 1,000 u.s. news sites are still unavailable in europe, two months after gdpr took effect
Author: Jeff South
Keywords: data protection free press access information journalism news internet fragmentation balkenization web content
GT: US news websites blocking access to Europeans

Summary Sentence: Venezuela's president says that he was the subject of a failed assassination attempt involving a drone carrying explosives.
Justification:
The Government's Information Minister said that drones loaded with explosives denoted close to a military event that the President was attending in Caracas. The President was unharmed but 7 soldiers were reportedly injured. President Maduro says that evidence

 points to a right-wing plot linked to Colombia and the US state of Florida (which has a large population of Venezuelan exiles). Although it's unclear whether these reports have been independently verified, this article highlights the possibility of drones

 being used for such attacks in future.
Primary Article Title: Venezuela's maduro says drone blast was bid to kill him, blames colombia
Author: Alexandra Ulmer, Vivian Sequera
Keywords: commercial drone attack venezuela terrorism security safety

Summary Sentence: Interviews conducted with US law enforcement officials indicate that the biggest challenge they face when trying to make use of digital evidence is accessing data from telecoms service providers.
Justification:
The Centre for Strategic and International Studies, a US non-profit organization, has reported that interviews (with federal, state, and local law enforcement officials, attorneys, service providers, and civil society groups) indicate that the biggest

 challenge faced when trying to access digital data for investigations is actually accessing data from service providers (which is often not encrypted). Much of the national debate has focused on other issues, such as the challenges of accessing data that is

 encrypted, or the impact of much data being ephemeral. This report gives some insight into practitioners' views of the challenges they face in dealing with the increasing amount of digital evidence, a trend which is likely to continue in the future.
Primary Article Title: Low-hanging fruit&%2358; evidence-based solutions to the digital evidence challenge
Author: William A. Carter, Jennifer C. Daskal
Keywords: data digital forensics law enforcement security intelligence investigations crime

Summary Sentence: The growth of artificial intelligence (AI) could disrupt marketing strategies, opening the way for fact based consumerism.
Justification:
Over the last 20 years of internet development, there has been a hugely significant shift from print to online advertising. Google and Facebook’s advertising market share is worth more than all the current print media combined. As AI becomes more advanced

 and features in more of our devices, it is envisioned that this market could be completely disrupted again. Smart devices with AI will know our preferences and can be set up to do tasks such as purchasing products for us. These choices can be made automatically

 when we are running low on a product. The AI will be able to choose a product on certain features such as price, or environmental credentials, rather than what celebrity is advertising it. If this type of technology becomes successful, it could make ethical

 purchasing easy and have benefits for the environment.
Primary Article Title: Traditional advertising is soon to be history
Keywords: internet marketing environment

Summary Sentence: Another example of a new class cyber security flaw (caused by the fundamental design of computer processors) has been identified.
Justification:
Industry researchers have identified a new security flaw, Foreshadow, which allows an attacker to steal information stored inside pcs or 3rd party cloud by using a fundamental design flaw in Intel processors. This bug can be used to infer data in operating

 system memory, in the memory of a virtual machine, or for other purposes. It is one of several recently discovered hardware bugs that are caused by the inherent design of computer processors (as opposed to most bugs which originate from flaws in software design).

 This represents a new type of cyber security vulnerability, which may be increasingly exploited in the future.
Primary Article Title: Beyond spectre&%2358; foreshadow, a new intel security problem
Author: Steven J. Vaughan-Nichols
Keywords: cyber security hardware bug computer processor data protection cyber crime vulnerability flaw exploit
GT: New hardware cyber security flaws identified

Summary Sentence: A parliamentary committee report highlights how changes in the natural environment of the Artic and High North are leading to an increase in military activity in the region.
Justification:
The report concludes that the Artic and High North are central to the security of the UK and the wider North Atlantic Ocean. Environmental changes, leading to ice receding and the Artic becoming more accessible to navigation and natural resource exploitation,

 have increased military activity in this area. Russia, it says, has been at the forefront of this activity. The Committee say that this activity appears not to be just defensive and warn that the Artic is vulnerable to exploitation and that if it were dominated

 by a hostile power, it would put the security of the wider North Atlantic Ocean at considerable risk. This may indicate a wider trend of changes to climate leading to changes in international security.
Primary Article Title: On thin ice&%2358; uk defence in the arctic
Author: House of Commons Defence Committee
Keywords: Artic High North defence security russia uk NATO climate change ice recession strategic capability navigation resource exploitation

Summary Sentence: A US Government official has highlighted concerns that an object deployed by the Russians in space may be hostile.
Justification:
The US Government says that it has identified a space object exhibiting behaviour inconsistent with that seen before from objects used for on-orbit inspection or space situational awareness. Russia says is a "space apparatus inspector". The US say that

 they don't know for certain what it is and that there is no way of verifying it. They have criticised the proposed draft "Treaty on the Prevention of the Placement of Weapons in Outer Space, the Threat or Use of Force against Outer Space Objects” (PPWT) as

 having major flaws and being unviable, saying that any space arms control agreement is unverifiable at this time. This indicates that there is growing interest in space as a defence arena, and one in which new weapons and capabilities may be developed in future.
Primary Article Title: Remarks on recent russian space activities of concern
Author: Yleem D.S. Poblete, Assistant Secretary, Bureau of Arms Control, Verification and Compliance
Keywords: space defence satellite infrastructure international relations US Russia weapons

Summary Sentence: Academics have developed a system that uses W-Fi signals to detect the presence of weapons hidden in bags.
Justification:
The system was found to identify 90% of dangerous materials such as metals, and liquids, by analysing the distortions in Wi-Fi signals that occur when they encounter a nearby object. Such systems might be used in the future as an alternative to existing

 security screening infrastructure which is expensive and can be difficult to implement. This opens up the possibility for such systems to become part of standard security measures used in public places to help reduce the risk of terrorism.
Primary Article Title: Engineers discover a glaringly simple way to detect bombs and hidden weapons
Author: Kristin Houser
Keywords: security anti-terrorism measures hidden weapons detection events public places safety
GT: Wi-Fi signal used to detect weapons

Summary Sentence: Academic researchers analysing vaccine-related twitter activity found that bots disseminated anti-vaccine messages and Russian trolls promoted discord, undermining public consensus on vaccination.
Justification:
This journal article analysed vaccine-related Twitter activity between July 2014 and September 2017. It concluded that bots spread anti-vaccine content while trolls magnified the debate and increased discord by using message that were more political and

 divisive. It highlights the potential for bot activity to legitimise the debate about vaccines, potential negatively affecting public health. It also identifies the need for more research to understand how to address content that is spread by bots. This is

 another example of social media being used in a way that seems to be politically motivated and intended to undermine public confidence in existing social/governance structures.
Primary Article Title: Weaponized health communication&%2358; twitter bots and russian trolls amplify the vaccine debate
Author: David A. Broniatowski, Amelia M. Jamison, SiHua Qi, Lulwah AlKulaib, Tao Chen, Adrian Benton, Sandra C. Quinn
Keywords: disinformation twitter social media bot troll vaccination public health fake news policitcal influence public opinion

Summary Sentence: Academic research highlights the risk that machine learning algorithms used to identify skin cancer could lead to differences in the quality of diagnosis that different racial groups receive.
Justification:
There are a number of factors that can contribute to machine learning algorithms performing differently across different groups of patients, including that the data used to develop the algorithms is inherently biased as it comes primarily from fair-skinned

 populations. This study is just one example of racial disparities being observed in artificial intelligence, which also include photos of black people being mistaken for gorillas and cameras being less able to detect blinking in Asian people. It highlights

 the potential for artificial intelligence used across a range of applications to unwittingly incorporate bias into its results.
Primary Article Title: Ai-driven dermatology could leave dark-skinned patients behind
Keywords: artificial intelligence data analytics bias racial discrimincation medicine algorithm skin cancer image recognition diagnostics
GT: medical machine learning shows racial bias

Summary Sentence: Reports that Microsoft has identified Internet domains that have been used by hackers connected with the Kremlin to target Republican-supporting groups in the US.
Justification:
According to Microsoft, a group of Hackers (known variously as APT 28, Fancy Bear and Strontium) created fake websites that mimicked the addresses of the US Senate, the International Republican Institute and the Hudson Institute (two conservative think-tanks).

 Both think-tanks have been critical of Putin. A US court gave Microsoft permission to take control of six web domains. This is one of an increasing number of reports which suggest that cyber-space is increasingly being used to influence public opinion and

 spread disinformation. The reporter suggests that Russian efforts to influence American politics are growting ahead of the midterm elections in November 2018.
Primary Article Title: Microsoft alleges new russia hack targeting us political groups
Keywords: Russian US hacking political influence public opinion disinformation elections fake news websites democracy security digital forensics intelligence

Summary Sentence: A tech company plans to create a voice-activated, body-heat-powered chip that uses GPS tracking can monitor vital signs.
Justification:
A tech company in the US has announced plans to create a microchip for humans that can track an individual's location through GPS and monitor their vital signs. The microchip will also be voice-activated and body-heat-powered. It has been suggested that

 such a chip could be used to keep track of dementia suffers, who often get lost when confused. There are concerns about whether a dementia patient can consent to having a chip implanted and questions about whether an implant is necessary when there are wearables

 that offer a similar service. With rising numbers of people with dementia, different ways to monitor individuals via technology are likely to increase.
Primary Article Title: A tech company wants to implant GPS trackers in dementia patients
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: biohacking microchips dementia healthcare technology GPS

Summary Sentence: Trade tariffs, access to the Panama Canal and Russian sanctions could result in more US natural gas arriving in the European market, with consequences for European energy security
Justification:
Trade wars between China and the US may affect future trade in liquefied natural gas (LNG) between the two countries. China has to date resisted placing import tariffs on American LNG; the Chinese market for natural gas is rising and expected to increase

 substantially in coming decades as a result of a policy-induced shift away from coal for heat and power. However, the prospect of a future 25% tariff on the energy resource could affect the growing US export market, and cargoes bound for China would need to

 find new destinations in Europe, for example. Restrictions in access to the Panama Canal may also favour European destinations over Chinese ones.     The US is predicted to displace Australia as the world's second-largest LNG exporter by 2023. US producers competing for LNG contracts in Europe would be doing so directly with Russia. Russian gas generally arrives into Europe via pipeline, and the expansion

 of the Nordstream 2 pipeline has cemented the Russian state gas company as the largest exporter to Europe.
Primary Article Title: LNG&%2358; A Trade Wars story
Keywords: energy security, LNG, natural gas, pipeline, energy trade, trade tariffs, trade wars, sanctions, Russia, US, China, Trump

Summary Sentence: Up to 27% of US households do not have access to mainstream financial services, such as credit cards or loans
Justification:
A survey of American households found that 7% were unbanked (had no bank account at all) and 20% were underbanked (having a bank account but not having access to mainstream financial services, such as credit cards, loans, overdrafts or online banking).

 The main reason given for being unbanked was not having enough money to open a bank account. Being unbanked/underbanked was more common among certain groups&%2358; young, poor, uneducated, Black or Latino. Being underbanked leaves individuals vulnerable to less

 reliable forms of credit, such as loan sharks or payday loans.
Primary Article Title: One out of every 4 Americans is 'underbanked'
Author: Franco, J.
Keywords: unbanked "financial inequality" finance inequality equality banking

Summary Sentence: Wealth inequality between races in the US has increased following natural disasters
Justification:
The study looked at counties in the US who had suffered natural disasters (hurricanes, wildfires, floods and tornadoes) and the wealth of white, black, Latino and Asian residents of these counties. It found that in areas most severely affected by natural

 disasters, white residents showed an increased in wealth compared to white residents in less severely affected counties. However, black, Latino and Asian residents of counties most severely affected by natural disasters showed a decrease in wealth. These wealth

 discrepancies were even wider in areas that had received higher amounts of post-disaster federal aid. Furthermore, inequality was found to widen between homeowners and renters, and college-education and 10th-grade-educated. The authors argue that natural disasters

 and post-disaster recovery effors widen wealth inequality between races. This work has future implications for post-disaster interventions and wealth inequality globally.
Primary Article Title: Natural disasters widen racial wealth gap
Author: Howell, J., Elliott, J.
Keywords: "natural disaster" inequality "race inequality" "wealth inequality" hurricane US USA "foreign aid"

Summary Sentence: A group of 19 city authorities including the GLA have pledged that all new buildings will be 'net zero carbon' by 2030
Justification:
The C40 city group has coordinated the mayors of 19 cities, including London, in pledging that all new buildings will be 'net zero carbon' by 2030 and existing buildings will be upgraded to net zero standards by 2050. Net zero buildings encompass a range

 of energy efficiency measures and embedded small-scale generation (usually renewable) to prevent the emission of greenhouse gases arising from use of the building e.g. in heating and lighting.     The announcement highlights that climate change mitigation measures are increasingly being undertaken by actors at the sub-national level, often in lieu of action from central governments. The UK Government scrapped a UK-wide net zero carbon buildings

 policy in 2015, for example, and California has announced a series of energy and climate policies contrary to those of the US Federal Government.
Primary Article Title: From London to San Jose, global cities unite to make new buildings 'net-zero carbon' by 2030
Keywords: heating, energy efficiency, buildings, energy demand, renewable electricity, local authority, sub-national, city, urban, mayor

Summary Sentence: Blockchain could help manage energy supply chain
Justification:
The energy supply chain is complex, involves a wide number of organisations and can be expensive, management heavy and opaque. The author suggests that blockchain technology could be used to help manage the energy supply chain, in particular the 'downstream'

 processes (bringing energy to the end user). The benefits of using blockchain in this application include&%2358; increased transparency and reduction in malpractices.
Primary Article Title: Blockchain can be a solution to energy security, oil politics and geopolitics
Keywords: Bitcoin blockchain distributed ledger energy distribution supply chain

Summary Sentence: Increased use of internet of things has made put the healthcare sector at increased risk of cyber attacks
Justification:
The increased number of devices connected to the internet has increased the number of routes through which a hacker can hack into a system. According to an IMB report, healthcare is under the top 5 sectors targeted by cyber attacks, meaning that as more

 digital transformation occurs, there is a greater need for cyber security measures in the sector. The author suggests several options to counter cyber attacks in healthcare, including&%2358; reviewing IT systems and identifying vulnerabilities, having a backup ready

 in the event of a ransomware attack, and educating hospital staff on cyber security.
Primary Article Title: Tackling cyber attacks in the healthcare sector
Author: Issac Thomas
Keywords: Cyber-attack cybersecurity healthcare internet of things connected devices hacking security

Summary Sentence: Study suggests that teleological thinking (belief that there is a purpose behind natural events) is linked to belief in creationism and conspiracy theories
Justification:
Three correlational studies found an association between creationism and belief in conspiracy theories. Previously, work has found a link between teleological thinking and creationism. The research suggests all three are associated. Understanding the cognitive

 bias/hindrance that teleological thinking creates may explain the success of some media and fake news.
Primary Article Title: Creationism and conspiracism share a common teleological bias
Author: Wagner-Egger, P. et al
Keywords: "cognitive bias" "cognitive biases" creationism "conspiracy theory" conspirasists teleology

Summary Sentence: The EU-wide carbon price has increased and is expected to further do so in future
Justification:
The price of an allowance under the EU's Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) has tripled in the past year), and analysts predict it will continue to do so in future. The ETS is the cornerstone of EU climate policy and forces large CO2 emitters to pay for each

 unit they emit. Historically the price of each unit (the allowance price which is determined within the ETS market) has been low, diminishing the effectiveness of the scheme. Recent market reforms have caused the price to increase, which has caused heavily

 polluting coal plants to lose economic competitiveness over gas plants. The think tank Carbon Tracker has increased its estimates of future increases in the allowance price.
Primary Article Title: EU carbon price finally puts pressure on coal
Keywords: carbon price, cap and trade, emissions trading, ETS, carbon market, European policy, climate change

Summary Sentence: Facebook is using trustworthiness ratings of users who report content as fake news, in order to prioritise which flagged content should be manually fact-checked first.
Justification:
The propagation of disinformation online is becoming an increasing concern among politicians and others. Social media and other technology companies are coming under increasing pressure to take action to tackle its spread. They have announced a range of

 measures that they are taking to tackle it. This article gives one example. Facebook has developed a system to help decide which users to trust amongst all those who report false stories, as some users try to game the system by e.g. reporting genuine stories

 as false because they do not agree with the author's views. The user rating is one factor that is used to help Facebook prioritise which content to check first. Facebook sends content flagged as fake news to third-party organizations to check, which are often

 under-resourced non-profit orgs.
Primary Article Title: Facebook to rate users over their trustworthiness
Author: Hannah Kuchler
Keywords: fake news disinformation social media trust fact-checking freedom of speech online information censorship

Summary Sentence: The 3A Institute at the Australian National University was launched in September 2017 to work out how to manage artificial intelligence, data, and technology, and of their impact on humanity.
Justification:
Academics, policy makers, industry and others are increasingly focusing on understanding how emerging technologies used in industry (and other settings) such as artificial intelligence, robotics and sensors should be used and what impact they will have

 on society and the economy. Key questions highlighted by the Head of the 3A Institute, Professor Genevieve Bell, include&%2358; How do we regulate the interactions of autonomous systems? How do we secure these systems and make them safe? What limits should be placed

 on an object's autonomy? What rules should be applied and how will they be litigated? How do different objects with different rules engage with each other? Where do accountability and liability sit?
Primary Article Title: How brand new science will manage the fourth industrial revolution
Author: Stilgherrian
Keywords: artificial intelligence data analytics sensors industry 4.0 technology robotics social impact safety security risk trust liability accountability interoperability
GT: New institute for impact of industry 4.0

Summary Sentence: The economic value of small-scale 'embedded' generation is diminishing as a result of regulatory change
Justification:
Embedded benefits are the value obtained by electricity suppliers for contracting with small-scale generation connected at the distribution level. Small-scale generation does not attract costs for connecting to the national transmission system, suppliers

 can hence reduce or avoid costs by using them. Embedded benefits have risen in value due to a number of factors. A number of regulatory rule changes have in the last year resulted in these benefits being reduced, which could result in a lower economic favourability

 for embedded generators.
Primary Article Title: Paradise lost&%2358; the changing face of embedded benefits
Keywords: electricity, electricity production, power, electricity networks, electricity generation, electricity distribution, distributed generation, decentralised generation, renewables, CHP, climate change, markets, regulation

Summary Sentence:
Based on modelling, this study estimates that by 2100, heat stress-related annual income losses of average size dairy farms in the most affected regions of the UK may vary between £2,000-£6,000 and £6,000-£14,000 (in today’s value), in average and extreme

 years respectively.
Justification:
Dairy farming in the UK faces a major challenge in relation to heat stress in cows, given climate model projections of summer temperature increases. Heat stress in cows occurs when ambient temperature and humidity go above animal specific thresholds, they

 initially respond to mild heat stress by sweating, panting, drinking more, and seeking shade when possible, but at higher temperatures eat less feed leading to a fall in milk production. Using 11 different climate projection models, and 18 different milk production

 models, this study estimated potential milk loss from UK dairy cows as climate conditions change during the 21st century. Heat stress impacts are projected to be greatest in southern England, and although losses in milk production will be low in an average

 year, about 2.4% of production, in a 'hot' year in the 1990s, they could potentially be as high as 17%. South-west England is likely to be the most vulnerable to these impacts, because of the high density of dairy herds in this area.
Primary Article Title: Spatially explicit estimation of heat stress related impacts of climate change on the milk production of dairy cows in the United Kingdom
Author: Nandor Fodor, Andreas Foskolos, Cairistiona F. E. Topp, Jon M. Moorby, Laszlo Pasztor, Christine H. Foyer
Keywords: Climate Change, Agricultural Yield, Food security

Summary Sentence: Hydrogen derived from ammonia is tested in a hydrogen car for the first time
Justification:
Ammonia can be easily separated in to gaseous hydrogen and nitrogen by passing it over a catalyst, however, a major difficulty is separating the gases and obtaining pure hydrogen for use in a fuel cell. Last year researchers at Australia's Commonwealth

 Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) developed a metallic membrane to convert ammonia into high purity hydrogen. The membrane is designed to allow smaller hydrogen molecules through it, while blocking the larger nitrogen molecules. Now,

 the pure hydrogen obtained via this method has been used in a car and road tested for the first time.
Primary Article Title: Ammonia-derived hydrogen fuel road-tested in a world's first
Author: Matt Kennedy
Keywords: Hydrogen fuel cell car ammonia gas separation

Summary Sentence: Some plastics can't be recycled yet, however, it has been suggested that turning them back into oil could help solve the issue
Justification:
Plastic waste is a global problem&%2358; 400 million tonnes of plastic are produced globally each year, but only 10% of this is recycled. One of the main issues is that not all types of plastics can be recycled. Plastics that can be recycled normally get broken

 down into pellets and used to make other plastic products such as chairs, clothing (polyester) and packaging, but those that can't be recycled go to landfill or are incinerated. UK company Recycling Technologies have developed a machine which turns hard to

 recycle materials into oil. This oil can replace fossil fuel derived oils in the manufacture of polymers and waxes. The company are hoping to manufacture 200 machines per year to meet anticipated demand for plastic recycling.
Primary Article Title: Chemical recycling is coming of age
Author: Catherine Early
Keywords: Plastic recycling materials oil polymers landfill

Summary Sentence: Disproportionate warming of the Arctic may be affecting weather systems in North America, Europe and parts of Asia, by causing weather systems to stall and persist for longer periods, resulting in more persistent heatwaves.
Justification:
Airstreams in the upper troposphere -- called planetary waves - usually convey chains of high- and low-pressure weather systems eastwards between the equator and the North Pole, but climate change appears to be distorting these patterns causing the systems

 to slow down and become more persistent. Climate change reduces the temperature difference between the North Pole and the equator, which is the main driver of the planetary waves. Although climate models suggested these changes would occur, the observed changes

 are typically more pronounced than those seen in the models, suggesting the phenomenon is not yet fully understood. However, the study suggests the changes could lead to more persistent hot-dry extremes in the mid-latitudes posing high risks to countries in

 these areas in future.
Primary Article Title: The influence of Arctic amplification on mid-latitude summer circulation
Author: D. Coumou, G. Di Capua, S. Vavrus, L. Wang & S. Wang
Keywords: Climate Change Feedbacks, Adaptation

Summary Sentence: Since 2005, the International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium has been working to produce a high-quality annotated reference genome sequence of bread wheat for breeders, which has now been published.
Justification: Bread wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) provides about a fifth of the total calories consumed by humans, with falls in wheat yields and production affect the global economy. Improvements in wheat breeding have lagged behind those of some other crops because of the complexity of the polyploid bread wheat genome that is five times larger than the human genome and contains more than 85% repetitive DNA. This project has delivered an annotated reference sequence of wheat as a resource for breeders to drive disruptive innovation in wheat improvement through improved understanding of wheat biology and genomics-assisted breeding. It provides access to 107,891 high-confidence genes, including their genomic context of regulatory sequences. With the annotated and ordered reference genome sequence in place, researchers can now access sequence-level information to precisely define the necessary changes in the genomes for breeding programs.
Primary Article Title: Shifting the limits in wheat research and breeding using a fully annotated reference genome
Author: The International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium (IWGSC)
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification, Commodities

Summary Sentence: A toxicological study has suggested that exposure to nanoparticles should not be considered in isolation as co-exposure with other pollutants may result in synergistic toxic effects.
Justification:
Silver nanoparticles are in used in products such as refrigerators, sports clothes, cosmetics, toothbrushes and water filters for their antibacterial effect. Previous studies have suggested that silver nanoparticles may lead to the formation of free radicals

 in cells and causes changes in the form and amount of proteins, and field studies have suggested they reduce root growth in crops. This study carried out on human liver cells showed that they reacted differently when they were exposed to nanosilver alone than
