 when they were exposed to a cocktail of nanosilver and cadmium ions. In the study, 72 percent of the cells died when exposed to both nanosilver and cadmium ions. When exposed to nanosilver only, 25 percent died. When exposed to cadmium ions only, 12 percent

 died.
Primary Article Title: Co-exposure to silver nanoparticles and cadmium induce metabolic adaptation in HepG2 cells
Author: Renata Rank Miranda, Vladimir Gorshkov, Barbara Korzeniowska, Stefan J. Kempf, Francisco Filipak Neto & Frank Kjeldsen
Keywords: Nanotechnology Nanoparticles Catalysts Household Products Antimicrobial Products

Summary Sentence: A prototype flexible heat shield could reduce cost of space travel and aid future space missions
Justification:
A PhD researcher from the University of Manchester has developed a prototype heat shield for space craft. Heat shields are used to protect spacecraft as they enter a planet's atmosphere. Current spacecraft heat shields are mechanically deployed structures

 which are heavy and complicated to use. The newly developed shield is made of a flexible material and shaped like a skirt. The shield can also spin, helping spacecraft to slow down as they enter an atmosphere. It is though this shield could help make it cheaper

 to deploy small satellites into space, and could aid future space missions.
Primary Article Title: Spinning heat shield for future spacecraft
Keywords: Spacecraft shield prototype future space missions materials

Summary Sentence: Researchers have used virtual reality to help amputees overcome "phantom limb" syndrome.
Justification:
One of the issues experiences by amputees with prosthetics is that the prosthetic doesn't fit the amputee's brain's perception of their missing limb. Many amputees still feel their missing limb (known as phantom limb syndrome), and the phantom limbs are

 usually perceived to be smaller than the prosthetic limb. Now, researchers from have used virtual reality to help amputees feel as though their prosthetic limb is part of their body. The researchers gave the test subjects sensations at the tip of their phantom

 limbs by stimulating their stumps while the patients wore virtual reality goggles. The patients reported that they felt as though the hand belonged to their own body.
Primary Article Title: Virtual reality program helps prosthetic limbs feel connected to amputees' bodies
Author: Shelby Rogers
Keywords: Phantom limb virtual and augmented reality amputee healthcare

Summary Sentence: The UK Government have launched a consultation on the new Centre for Data Ethics and Innovation
Justification:
The UK Government have launched a consultation on the new Centre for Data Ethics and Innovation. The centre will aim to identify the measures needed to strengthen and improve the way data and AI are used and regulated. It will do so by bringing together

 research into the ethical and economic uses of data and AI, reviewing the existing regulatory framework and identifying gaps, and engaging industry and the public on specific issues surrounding uses of data and AI.
Primary Article Title: Centre for data ethics and innovation
Keywords: ethics innovation artificial intelligence data consultation

Summary Sentence: Research finds that people are more likely to perform better under supervision of a 'mean' robot than a nice one
Justification:
Recently published research showed that people performed better in cognitive tasks when under the supervision of a mean robot, versus under the supervision of a 'nice' robot, or no robot at all. The researchers asked 58 young adults to undertake the Stroop

 task where the participant sees a word and must state the colour of the font. This can be challenging when the the word and the colour of it are different, e.g the word 'green' written in red font. The participants performed the test alone, then under the

 supervision of a robot, which either behaved kindly or unkindly towards the participant. When the participants completed the test under the supervision of the kind robot, their performance didn’t improve, but when the unkind robot was watching, the participants'

 performance improved notably.
Primary Article Title: A mean robot supervisor could make you a better-performing employee
Author: Kristin Houser
Keywords: robots supervising workplace employee

Summary Sentence: Most countries in the EU offer a form of paternity leave parental leave but only a minority offer what the European Commission considers 'well-paid' leave
Justification:
Seventeen EU member states offer two weeks of paternity leave. However, only 13 offer what the European Commission considers 'well-paid' paternity leave (pay equaling at least 66 per cent of a worker's usual earnings). Low compensation levels are one of

 the strongest disincentives to men taking paternity or parental leave. A new EU directive proposes the introduction of paternity leave of at least 10 days around the time of the birth of the child and also suggests that compensation levels should be increased

 to at least the equivalent of the sick pay level. The new directive proposes four months as a minimal entitlement for parental leave. The directive would also establish parental leave as a right that must be used by fathers or lost as research suggests this

 could encourage fathers to be more involved in childcare. These proposed changes may shift the culture around childcare and create more gender parity in undertaking childcare responsibilities.
Primary Article Title: Potential changes to paternity and parental leave in Europe
Author: Janta, B.
Keywords: "parental leave" "gender equality" gender childcare "parental leave" "paternity leave" EU "unpaid work"

Summary Sentence: Traces of cocaine in water may be impacting on eel health and behaviour.
Justification:
Eels are of particular interest to the Environment Agency as we have regulatory responsibility to protect eels from exploitation and entrainment and improve their passage to assist their migration over barriers and weirs. A recent laboratory study exposed

 eels to a range of ‘trace’ concentrations of chemicals found in watercourses, including cocaine at a level of 20 billionths of a gram of per litre (20ng/l) for 50 days. The cocaine-exposed eels appeared “hyperactive” and their skeletal muscle showed evidence

 of breakdown and swelling.  Even after spending 10 days in clean water for “rehab” damaged muscles and increased levels of the stress hormone cortisol were still present Cortisol can cause fat wastage, which can impact on the fat reserves European eels require for successful migration.

 The impacts of other illegal drugs in water such as THC, morphine, MDMA, alongside legalised substances such as pesticides, heavy metals, phenols and antibiotics could also be affecting eels and other aquatic life, particularly as these substances interact

 with each other, resulting in unpredictable effects. Changes to medical legislation could make increase the use of cannabis and other illegal drugs (%2313458, %2314674, %2314692), increasing these impacts without further research and appropriate regulation.
Primary Article Title: Cocaine in rivers harming endangered eels, study finds
Author: Barkham, P
Secondary_URLs: Effects of environmental cocaine concentrations on the skeletal muscle of the European eel (Anguilla anguilla) - Science of the Total Environment 05/06/2018
Keywords: "water quality" pollution biodiversity eel fish fauna cocaine drug cannabis THC morphine MDMA pesticide "heavy metal" phenol antibiotic health regulation drug medicine health river sea ocean marine

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a material that can camouflage objects against infrared cameras
Justification:
Researches have developed a thin lightweight film material that allows hot objects to appear cold and cold objects to appear warm under when detected using infrared cameras.The film uses electricity to alter its properties, allowing the amount of IR radiation

 emitted by the film to be controlled. The film is made using layers of nylon, gold, polyethylene and multiple layers of graphene. The researchers found that when a voltage was applied across the film, charged molecules became incorporated in the graphene layers,

 which reduced the amount of IR radiation the film could emit. The team then set up a sensor that allowed the voltage applied to the film to be tuned to ensure the amount of IR radiation emitted matched that of its surroundings. This film has potential applications

 in camouflage against IR cameras.
Primary Article Title: Scientists develop thermal camouflage that can fool infrared cameras
Author: Nicola Davis
Keywords: Infrared detection camouflage materials graphene

Summary Sentence: Researchers have created a smart wristband which can monitor health and connect wirelessly to devices
Justification:
Most current wearable devices monitor a few physical parameters such as exercise activity and heart rate. However, the new wristband can monitor cells in the bloodstream. The plastic wristband includes a circuit board and a biosensor fitted with a channel

 (thinner than a human hair) and gold electrodes. Blood samples are collected through pin pricks and fed through the channel, allowing the device to count the number of blood cells in the sample. The number of blood cells of a certain type can be indicative

 of illness. For example, a low red blood cell count can indicate internal bleeding, and an unusually low or high white blood cell count can indicate certain types of cancer. The researchers say the wristbands could be a great alternative to bulky medical equipment.

 In the future they could be used for continuous health monitoring, and could send results directly to physicians.
Primary Article Title: Smart wristband with link to smartphones could monitor health, environmental exposures
Keywords: Wristband smart health monitoring blood sampling technology

Summary Sentence: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has recently completed an assessment of Saudi Arabia's nuclear power infrastructure
Justification:
In July 2018, a delegation from the IAEA visited Saudi Arabia to assess the country's nuclear power infrastructure. The visit took place at the request of the Saudi government. Saudi Arabia has announced plans to construct 16 nuclear power plants over

 the next 20 years, and is currently preparing to invite bids for the construction of its first one. The IAEA reported that the country has made significant progress in developing their nuclear power programme, including establishing a legislative framework.
Primary Article Title: IAEA assesses Saudi nuclear infrastructure development
Keywords: Nuclear power Saudi Arabia energy

Summary Sentence: Meadow spittlebugs, once very abundant on plants along the California coastline, are declining rapidly or vanishing from their previous habitats as a result of increasing temperatures.
Justification:
Meadow spittlebugs, sometimes called meadow froghoppers, prefer cool, wet conditions. The insects suck a plant's juice, xylem fluid, from its leaves and regurgitate plant juice to form a protective spittle layer, keeping them hydrated and hidden from predators.

 Researchers surveyed populations in 1988 and again in 2001 on seaside daisies up and down the coast and found that the distribution of spittlebugs appeared to be shifting north, or toward the pole, a pattern that other research has found for many species in

 response to climate change. However, when they resurveyed the populations in 2017 and 2018 the spittlebugs had become rare or were missing throughout most of their former range suggesting this previously widespread abundant species has not been able to adjust

 physiologically or ecologically to increased temperatures. Rapid declines in other common insect species in response to climate change could potentially have dramatic and unexpected effects on the functioning of ecosystems.
Primary Article Title: Decline of meadow spittlebugs, a previously abundant insect, along the California coast
Author: Richard Karban,  Mikaela Huntzinger
Keywords: Biodiversity Loss, Environmental Monitoring, Wildlife Populations

Summary Sentence: The US have raised concerns over Russia's alleged pursuit of space weapons
Justification:
The US has raised concerns that Russia are developing space weapons including mobile laser systems designed to destroy satellites. They also claim that a Russian inspector satellite has been acting in an 'abnormal' way. Russia have dismissed these claims

 as unfounded.
Primary Article Title: U.S. warns on Russia's new space weapons
Author: Stephanie Nebehay
Keywords: US anti-satellite weapons Russia high powered lasers satellites
GT: US warn about Russia's space weapons

Summary Sentence: Research has found that children are much more likely than adults to have their opinions changed by robots
Justification:
Researchers at the University of Plymouth conducted a study to compare how the opinions of children and adults change when being influenced by their peers vs a robot. The study found that adults were influenced by their peers, however they were largely

 able to resist being persuaded by the robot. Conversely, the children (aged 7-9) were found to be influenced by both their peers and the robot (by roughly the same amount). The researchers claim the study study provides an insight into how robots can be used

 positively in society (for example, as aids in education). However, they also say it raises concerns over the potential negative impact of robots on children.
Primary Article Title: Robots have power to significantly influence children's opinions
Keywords: Robots influence children behaviour

Summary Sentence: Companies are developing 5G smart phones and devices
Justification:
The chief technology officer of US telecommunications company, Sprint, recently announced their plans to release a 5G smartphone by mid-2019. 5G is the next generation of mobile technology and is expected to be an improvement to existing technology by

 offering faster data data transfer speeds and allowing many more devices to be connected to a network.
Primary Article Title: There's a new 5G smartphone coming, and it might finally make the next-gen network mainstream
Author: Kristin Houser
Keywords: 5G smartphones devices telecommunications mobile networks

Summary Sentence: The use of predictive policing by a UK police force has raised concerns over the technology
Justification:
Predictive policing describes the use of mathematical, predictive and analytical techniques in law enforcement. Durham Constabulary have been developing an algorithm to predict the risk posed by offenders and ensure that bail is granted to only the most

 'suitable' candidates (for example, the least likely to re-offend). The algorithm was recently altered after criticisms about its neutrality. Durham Constabulary will no longer use post codes in their algorithms as it has been argued that this perpetuates

 negative stereotypes about certain neighborhoods. Across the world police are increasingly using big data and AI to help predict spikes in crime. The types of data being used include dates, times, weather patterns, geographical information, social media messages,

 and even local sporting fixtures.
Primary Article Title: AI profiling&%2358; the social and moral hazards of `predictive' policing
Author: Mike Rowe
Keywords: Predictive policing artificial intelligence big data unintentional bias

Summary Sentence: Human-robot interactions may eventually include sex
Justification:
Technological developments in AI and soft robotics have a put sex robots on the horizon and experts have raised concerns over what impact these developments will have on human-robot interactions. Sex robots raise a number of technological and societal

 issues. For example, there are concerns around around the privacy of such technology and the risk of hacking. There are also concerns over the lack of diversity among the technology developers (who tend to be white males), and the harm this may cause, such

 as objectification. The Foundation for Responsible Robotics recently produced a consultation report that aims to encourage public debate about sex robots.
Primary Article Title: Let's talk about sex robots
Keywords: Sex robots

Summary Sentence: 3D printing has already found a number of medical applications and the number is expected to grow
Justification:
3D printing is starting to be applied in medicine and it is expected to be used for certain niche medical applications including personalized tablets and surgical modelling. In 2014, 3D printing was used to assist in the surgical separation of conjoined

 twins. 3D printed, colour coded models of the twins' organs and skeletons were generated from topography scans and used to plan and practice the separation surgery. In recent years, other types of surgery have also been practiced in this way, including brain

 and heart surgery. 3D printing is also increasingly being used to print drugs&%2358; in 2015 the US Food and Drug Administration approved the first and only 3D printed medicine.
Primary Article Title: Seeing drugs in 3D
Author: Nina Notman
Keywords: 3D printing medicine pharmaceutical surgery modelling drugs

Summary Sentence: Researchers have used quantitative analysis with case descriptions to elaborate and quantify the connections between financial flows from tax havens and environmental degradation, both from unregulated fishing and deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon.
Justification:
Researchers have linked financial flows through tax havens to activities that contribute to environmental destruction, such as growing soy and beef in deforested areas of the Amazon, and an expanding a network of largely unregulated fishing vessels operating

 under “flags of convenience”. The study found that find that between October 2000 and August 2011, 68% of all investigated foreign capital to nine focal companies in the soy and beef sectors in the Brazilian Amazon, as recorded by the Central Bank of Brazil,

 was transferred through one, or several, known tax havens. The study also showed that 70% of the known vessels implicated in illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing are, or have been, flagged under a tax haven jurisdiction, although only 4% of all

 registered fishing vessels are currently flagged in a tax haven. Complex webs of ownership allow catches to be traded, landed and in some cases disposed of outside the regulations that are supposed to prevent overfishing. The researchers suggest the overlap

 between vessels known to be operating in IUU fishing and flying flags of convenience from acknowledged tax havens shows the extent of the problem.
Primary Article Title: Tax havens and global environmental degradation
Author: Victor Galaz, Beatrice Crona, Alice Dauriach, Jean-Baptiste Jouffray, Henrik Österblom & Jan Fichtner
Keywords: Environmental Crime, Environmental Change, Deforestation, Overfishing

Summary Sentence: Studies suggest there are few areas where cultivation of the palm oil tree could be undertaken in Africa that would not cause harm to native primates
Justification:
Land conversion to oil palm continues to increase rapidly as a consequence of global demand and although the majority of this is in SE Asia, it is suggested that Africa will become a major area for future expansion of cultivation of palm oil trees, which

 are native to West Africa. This study combined information on oil palm suitability and current land use with primate distribution, diversity, and vulnerability. Comparing the two showed that there are very few places in Africa where palm oil could be cultivated

 without harming primates (just 0.13 million hectares, but 53 million hectares of land will be needed by 2050 to grow palm oil in order to meet global demand), with one of the few exceptions part of Madagascar. The study also highlighted that there are almost

 200 primate species living in Africa, and many of them are living in areas of overlap—land suitable for both primates and oil palm cultivation. Deforestation is one of the main reasons why all great apes are at the edge of extinction and the introduction of

 palm oil plantations to Africa is expected to accelerate rates of deforestation.
Primary Article Title: Small room for compromise between oil palm cultivation and primate conservation in Africa
Publisher: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author: Giovanni Strona, Simon D. Stringer, Ghislain Vieilledent, Zoltan Szantoi, John Garcia-Ulloa, and Serge A. Wich
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification, Commodities, Deforestation

Summary Sentence: Recent evidence suggests that body cameras worn by police may have security vulnerabilities
Justification:
A cyber security consultant analysed a variety of police body camera models and found a number of security flaws. These flaws could allow hackers to delete footage, edit out objects from footage, change file structures and re-upload modified footage covertly.

 Flaws with the associated apps, software and cloud services used by the cameras were also uncovered. None of the devices tested used cryptographic protections, or digital signatures on the videos. This could lead to issues around the reliability of body worn

 video evidence, and concerns over hackers accessing and using the data.
Primary Article Title: Hackers can infiltrate police body cameras to tamper with evidence
Author: Charlie Osborne
Keywords: Body worn video police security vulnerability hackers footage evidence tampering

Summary Sentence: Researchers are working on combining contact lenses with sensors for health monitoring
Justification:
Researchers at Purdue University in Indiana have come up with a new way to combine off-the-shelf contact lenses with sensors to monitor a person's blood glucose levels. The electronics of the sensor can be printed directly on to the contact lens, and separated

 from the eye by a thin layer of transparent, breathable and bio-compatible polymer. It is thought the technology could be developed for use in applications outside of blood glucose monitoring. For example, the lenses could be used to monitor ocular diseases

 or to deliver drugs directly to the eye.
Primary Article Title: How smart contact lenses will help keep an eye on your health
Author: Jo Best
Keywords: Contact lenses sensors detection monitoring glucose health

Summary Sentence: Scientists have identified how blue light causes eye damage
Justification:
Blue rays of light have shorter wavelengths and higher energy than other light waves. Blue light is emitted by the sun along with all other colours of light, and is our primary source of blue light exposure. However, blue light is also emitted by digital

 devices, such as computers, televisions, and smartphones. It is already known that blue light can damage our eyes over time by contributing to macular degradation (worsening of the vision in the centre of the visual field). Recent research from the University

 of Toledo has discovered how blue light causes this damage. Retinal is a key molecule involved in vision, and is responsible for converting light energy into electrical signals in the brain. In the lab, the researchers combined retinal with a variety of different

 cells from the body, including neurons, photoreceptor cells and heart cells. When the samples were exposed to blue light, the retinal molecules produced poisonous chemicals which killed the neighboring cells. Neither the blue light or retinal alone was responsible

 for the cell damage.
Primary Article Title: Scientists knew blue light from screens contributed to blindness. now they know why.
Author: Kristen Hauser
Keywords: Blue light retinal eye damage digital devices screens

Summary Sentence: Facebook has blocked sites that host digital blueprints for 3D printed guns
Justification:
DEFCAD is a website that distributes 3D printed gun designs and is operated by the group Defence Distributed. The group has recently been facing charges that it had allowed the transfer of weapons overseas, and several states have banned the website. Facebook

 has recently invoked its own rules against Defense Distributed, saying 'sharing instructions on how to print firearms using 3D printers is not allowed under our Community Standards'
Primary Article Title: Facebook bans sites with 3D-printed gun blueprints
Author: David Grossman
Keywords: 3D printing guns Facebook

Summary Sentence: Quantum dots could be used to treat Parkinson's after tests in mice yield positive results
Justification:
Quantum dots are tiny particles or crystals (2-10 nanometers in diameter) which have interesting semiconducting properties. Unlike most medicines, they are small enough to pass from the bloodstream in to the brain. Parkinson's disease is thought to be

 caused by a protein called synuclein folding into the wrong shape. This triggers a chain reaction of misfolding in nearby synuclein molecules, and causes a build up of long strands of the protein known as 'fibrils' which can kill neurons. Researchers in China

 recently found that in a dish, quantum dots made from graphene can bind to synuclein, stopping it from forming new fibrils. When tested in mice dosed with fibrils, quantum dots were found to minimise effects of the fibrils, which normally trigger movement

 problems. After six months the mice showed improvements in two physical tests.
Primary Article Title: Quantum dots could treat Parkinson's
Author: Claire Wilson
Keywords: quantum dots Parkinson's medicine

Summary Sentence: This study has analysed 35 years’ worth of satellite data to create a comprehensive record of global land-change during the period 1982–2016
Justification:
Changes in land use and land cover affect processes in the wider environment, including biogeochemical cycles and climate at the global scale, but quantification of global land change has been lacking. This comprehensive analysis of satellite data challenges

 other data land use change trends, highlighting that tree cover has increased by 2.24 million km2 (+7.1% relative to the 1982 level) rather than declining as a result of net loss in the tropics being outweighed by a net gains elsewhere. Across all

 the land changes, 60% are associated with direct human activities and 40% with indirect drivers such as climate change, with montane systems have gained tree cover and many arid and semi-arid ecosystems have lost vegetation cover across all climate domains.

 The data set could be used to inform modelling of land-use changes, biogeochemical cycles and vegetation–climate interactions to advance understanding of global environmental change.
Primary Article Title: Global land change from 1982 to 2016
Author: Xiao-Peng Song, Matthew C. Hansen, Stephen V. Stehman, Peter V. Potapov, Alexandra Tyukavina, Eric F. Vermote & John R. Townshend
Keywords: Land use change, climate change, global environmental change

Summary Sentence: NASA have recently announced that their SpaceX spacecraft will be ready to transport crew in 2019
Justification:
NASA's SpaceX Crew Dragon is a spacecraft designed to transport astronauts to the International Space Station from the United States. SpaceX will undergo an uncrewed test flight in November 2018, and a crewed test flight in April 2019. Following this,

 SpaceX will undergo a certification process before being ready to transport astronauts. NASA astronauts currently travel to the International Space Station using Russia’s Soyuz spacecraft, however the contract between the US and Russia that enables this is

 due to end in November 2019.
Primary Article Title: SpaceX will be ready to transport humans in April 2019, NASA estimates
Author: Kristen Hauser
Keywords: SpaceX space travel astronaut NASA spacecraft
GT: SpaceX soon ready to transport humans

Justification: Blank - DFOS
Primary Article Title: Global land change from 1982 to 2016
Keywords: Blank - DFOS

Summary Sentence: Researchers have created a chip that can be swallowed like a pill and used to identify abnormalities
Justification:
Researchers at MIT have developed a prototype of a chip that can be swallowed like a pill and used to detect bleeding in a patient's gastrointestinal tract. The chip is fitted with wells containing genetically engineered bacteria designed to react to haem

 (a protein found in red blood cells); if the bacteria in the chip come into contact with blood, the bacteria light up (bioluminescence). A photosensor within the chip detects the level of light emitted by the bacteria, and can communicate wirelessly with a

 receiver outside the body. The chip is currently limited by its size which is around 3cm x 1cm. Although it's possible to swallow, the researchers expressed concern that it could cause complications in patients who already have damaged gastrointestinal tracts.

 Researchers hope that future iterations of the device will also be able to locate the source of the bleeding.
Primary Article Title: This swallowable chip uses glowing bacteria to spot hidden illnesses
Author: Jo Best
Keywords: bioluminescence bacteria blood detection chip diagnosis device

Summary Sentence: Metals are the main constituent of of electronic waste, but experiments suggest that the digital devices of the future may be made of more ubiquitous substances.
Justification:
Researchers, also in Australia have been experimenting with encoding data into nanoparticle sized crystals using laser light. The lasers are used to alter the fluorescent properties of the salt nanocrystals in a way which replicates a binary state that

 could be used to encode data. Several bits can be stored in one crystal, leading to much higher storage densities that current media. Experiments with electron microscopes at the atomic scale have allowed scientists to move single silicon atoms within single

 hexagons of graphene. Moving silicon between neighbouring hexagons in this manner could also be interpreted in a binary system and therefore could be used to store one bit of information on high density storage media. Whilst still in the laboratory stage these

 experiments could point to a ‘post-metal’ world for many digital electronic applications, reducing the demand for rare earth elements and metals.
Primary Article Title: Using light for next generation data storage
Secondary_URLs:
Electron-beam manipulation of silicon dopants in graphene - Nano Letters 27/06/2018

Towards rewritable multilevel optical data storage in single nanocrystals - Optics Express 08/08/2018

Electron-beam manipulation of individual atoms - Next Big Future 10/07/2018
Keywords: waste digital data storage electronics WEEE nanoparticle salt nanocrystal silicon graphene STEM "electron microscope" media fluorescent laser storage density

Justification: Overcoming T cells in immune system to deliver cytotoxic drugs using nanoparticles.
Primary Article Title: Role for Nanoparticles in Cancer Treatment
Keywords: cancer; health; disease; immunology; immunotherapy; public health; drug discovery; drug development; nanotechnology
GT: summary of recent developments in cancer treatment using nanomaterials

Justification: Scenarios relating to future urban design and current, near future and far future trends in healthcare provision within cities.

Summary Sentence: Developments in e-waste mining have demonstrated that it could be significantly more profitable compared to virgin metal extraction.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as a waste regulator may have to adapt policies and procedures in light of this to enable waste mining to develop as an industry. A recent study found that extracting metals from recycled electronics is as cost effective as mining

 for virgin material - up to 13 times cheaper if one were to account for subsidies as offered in China. An experimental urban mine in Australia has automated separation of WEEE and can recover metals via a furnace. The set up costs of £280,000 for a microfactory

 could probably pay themselves off within three years. Devices are sorted by a robot, and the plastics from circuit boards are recovered as a high end 3D printing filament. And an EU project is making it easier for companies to track materials available in

 scrap devices to help target more effective recovery initiatives. As China closes its borders to e-waste for recycling and a growing interest in the circular economy, urban mining on a small scale may grow more prevalent. The decentralisation of this activity

 may therefore require a regulatory response from the Environment Agency that allows for a greater number of operators whilst still limiting the potential environmental damage of handling some of the substances in question, alongside any associated emissions

 and wastes.
Primary Article Title: E-waste mining could be big business - and good for the planet
Author: Wollacott, E
Keywords: waste resources "circular economy" China electronics electrical digital WEEE microfactory decentralisation "3D printing" robot Australia microfactory "urban mine" metal element mineral emission regulation

Summary Sentence: The role of health concerns in climate change litigation may be increasing in significance.
Justification:
A study has found that while it is of minor consequence currently, it may grow in importance as a means to protect communities from the impacts of emissions from coal fired power stations. An analysis of previous cases found that in 16 per cent of cases

 where actions was taken it was due to health impacts. As stronger links are made between air pollution (from combustion, including power stations) and health, this will also strengthen the links between climate change and human health. This link between health

 concerns air pollution and climate change could mean that emerging litigation cases could lead to more effective climate policy-making. As air quality moves up the agenda, it may become a significant lever in climate related legal action, impacting on Environment

 Agency regulated sectors.
Primary Article Title: New study addresses the role of health in climate lawsuits
Secondary_URLs: The role of health in climate litigation - American Journal Of Public Health 26/04/2018
Keywords: "climate change" litigation legislation court health "air quality" "air pollution" emission regulation coal "fossil fuel" USA energy data "power station" policy

Summary Sentence: Plant scientists and architectural designers have been working together to develop the idea of genetically modified plants that are aesthetically pleasing while at the same time monitoring the health of the home.
Justification:
Genetically engineering a plant to act as a biosensor is not a new idea, studies have been published on plants engineered to glow when too much or too little nitrogen is present. However this study looks to combine this genetic engineering with functional

 infrastructure so that plants can be used in everyday situations to alert those around when something is not right. This piece of research adds to the growing evidence we have of personal monitoring, whereby citizens are checking pollutant levels themselves,

 rather than relying on the state to ensure that safe levels are maintained.
Primary Article Title: Houseplants could one day monitor home health
Keywords: health "environmental monitoring" food farming pesticide plant "citizen science" "genetic engineering" gene pollution pollutant "heavy metals" regulation incident "air quality" "air pollution" monitoring

Summary Sentence: Cold plasma treatments offer the potential to reduce the need for antibiotics and other harmful chemicals.
Justification:
Plasma is known as the 4th state of matter, far less common than liquid, solid and gas. It can be created at low temperatures by applying an energy source to a gas to create an ionised gas. These gases have antimicrobial properties which have

 caught researcher’s attentions as they may offer hope in the fight against antimicrobial resistance. Plasma has been successfully used by the medical profession for a number of years. The types of plasma can vary depending on what they are created from, and

 thus so do their medicinal properties. This has led to Belfast University creating a partnership with a livestock organisation to investigate the potential of using cold plasma treatments in agriculture, to try and reduce the need for antibiotics and other

 chemicals in the food chain. Any reduction in antibiotics and other chemicals used to increase yields will ultimately improve the sustainability of the industry and reduce the impacts these practices have on the environment.
Primary Article Title: Wonder technology that could help fight AMR
Secondary_URLs:
New technologies&%2358; Cold plasma - Campden BRI 01/01/2018

Plasma Treatment Continues to Evolve in Wound Healing - Advanced Tissue 24/01/2018

A Blast of Cold Plasma Kills Drug-Resistant Bacteria - Popular Science 15/12/2010
Keywords: AMR resistance chemical pesticide farm agriculture antibiotic treatment health plasma healthcare

Summary Sentence: China is developing large low cost submarines unmanned submarines for a variety of functions
Justification:
China are developing large relatively low cost unmanned submarines that can perform a variety of different functions without an on-board operator, including mine placement and attacks against enemy vessels. The submarines are expected to be deployed in

 the early 2020s. The project is part of the Chinese government's plan to increase the country's naval power using AI technology. Research is also ongoing in to AI-assisted support systems for submarine operators, which is expected to help them make faster

 and more accurate judgement in combat situations. Researchers say the new submarines will challenge the Western naval advantage.
Primary Article Title: China military develops robotic submarines to launch a new era of sea power
Keywords: submarine automated naval military technology unmanned artificial intelligence

Summary Sentence: A Chinese military electronics company have developed quantum radar which could allow for detection of stealth planes
Justification:
China Electronics Technology Group Corporation (CETC), a military electronics company, are developing a quantum radar system which could be used to detect stealth planes and missiles. The technology is still under development, but the CETC has recently

 announced that the system is now capable of tracking objects at high altitude, which the company envision will be used to track objects in space. Conventional radar measures the reflection of radio waves, however, quantum radar uses entangled photons which

 cannot be spoofed. Stealth aircraft are optimised to elude radio waves from conventional radar, and would be more susceptible to detection by quantum radar.
Primary Article Title: China's latest quantum radar could help detect stealth planes, missiles
Author: Jeffrey Lin, P. W. Singer
Keywords: quantum radar stealth detection military aircraft missile defence

Summary Sentence: New technology has been developed that uses radio waves combined with AI to detect people through walls
Justification:
Researchers art MIT have developed new technology that can detect people through walls and monitor their movement. The technology uses radio waves which can pass through walls, but are reflected by human bodies. Computer algorithms are then used to analyse

 the reflected waves, focusing on key parts of the body such as the head, hands and feet. The results are visualized through stick figures on a screen. The technology could be used in a variety of applications including&%2358; search and rescue, law enforcement and

 monitoring elderly people or hospital patients. Some experts have said the technology could raise privacy concerns.
Primary Article Title: New technology can see people through walls, track their movement
Keywords: radio waves detection motion tracking artificial intelligence algorithms

Summary Sentence: Facebook recently discovered a coordinated disinformation campaign aiming to influence the US mid-term elections
Justification:
Facebook recently removed 32 accounts and pages from Facebook and Instagram that were involved in 'coordinated inauthentic behavior', aiming to influence US mid-term elections. At least 300,000 people followed one of the removed pages, which were created

 between March 2017 and May 2018.
Primary Article Title: Facebook uncovers disinformation campaign to influence US midterms
Keywords: elections social media fake news disinformation Facebook

Summary Sentence: The utility drone market is expected to grow from $110.2 million in 2018 to $538.6 million by 2023
Justification:
A new market research report from MarketsandMarkets expects the global market for utility drones to grow from an estimated $110.2 million in 2018 to $538.6 million by 2023. This can be attributed to a rising demand to minimise outages in electricity infrastructure.

 The use of drones could help keep workers safe in potentially dangerous areas by using them to investigate problems and allowing workers to perform some repairs remotely. The power sector is expected to have the largest market share of utility drones over

 the forecast period.
Primary Article Title: Utility drone market to hit $539M by 2023, driven by demand in hazardous work settings
Author: Laurel Deppen
Keywords: drones health and safety electricity infrastructure power
GT: Increased use of utility drones forecast

Summary Sentence: A new method for printing circuit boards has been developed using stamps
Justification:
Circuit boards for smartphones, tablets and other electronics are usually printed by spraying liquid metal into the desired patterns / shapes using stencils. A disadvantage of this method is that it can create rough surfaces which can lad to less efficient

 circuit connections, overheating and battery drain. A new technique for printing circuit boards has been developed, which uses nano-scale stamps to mold the metal. A laser is used to elasticate the metal for a short period of time. During this time, a stamp

 is used to shape the metal before it cools. The developers suggest the method is a more efficient way to make circuit boards, and could reduce inefficiencies in current boards, making devices faster.
Primary Article Title: Our future electronics could be printed like newspaper sheets
Author: Charlie Osborne
Keywords: electronics circuit boards smartphones devices printing lasers

Summary Sentence: Climate change, and the strategies people take to mitigate its effects, may be starting to reshape the socioeconomic landscapes of urban areas - a phenomena called ‘climate gentrification’.
Justification:
Environment Agency and partners may need to consider how activities around flood defence may contribute to climate gentrification, particularly in coastal areas.   Climate gentrification is described as climate change impacts making property more or less valuable, creating patterns of urban development that lead to displacement or entrenchment of existing populations as seen within conventional framings of gentrification.

 In a study of property prices in Miami, Florida, a city considered to be under the greatest threat from climate change and sea level rise, properties with a higher elevation were found to have experienced rising prices, whilst those at the lowest elevations

 experienced the reverse. Lower elevation properties were also found to have appreciated at a lower rate compared to those at higher elevations, attributed to ‘nuisance flooding’. Exposure to inland water bodies also had a similar influence in property value.

 Three pathways to climate gentrification were identified. The first is investors moving capital to properties with greater elevation. The second is where climate changes raises the cost of living so that only the wealthiest can remain in a location. The third

 pathway is where the environment is re-engineered to be more climate resilient, called a “resilience investment pathway.” One example could be people moving to an area with better flood protection and hard defences, as seems to have happened in Copenhagen,

 forcing less advantaged, lower-income households out of certain neighbourhoods. Climate gentrification demonstrates the ability of the both impacts of climate change, and the mitigation strategies to exacerbate patterns of inequality.
Primary Article Title: `Climate gentrification' will deepen urban inequality
Author: Florida, R
Secondary_URLs: Climate gentrification&%2358; from theory to empiricism in Miami-Dade County, Florida - Environmental Research Letters 23/04/2018
Keywords: "climate change" "sea level rise" coast urban city property wealth inequality "climate gentrification" "flood defence" Miami Florida Copenhagen flooding land value "real estate" "resilience investment pathway" resilience

 with facial recognition software.

Justification:
Suicide rates in the USA are rising and this article reviews evidence on what works in suicide prevention. A review of the suicides of 17 individuals revealed that the 'warning signs' people are told to look for were either not present or were present

 for so long before the suicide, they did not alert friends or family to the increased risk. It is suggested that guidance should be updated and more research should look at risks for those with mental health conditions.

Author: Irving, D.
Keywords: suicide "suicide prevention" prevention "mental health" "mental health condition"

Summary Sentence: Due to prison overcrowding, countries like Tanzania and Kenya, are handing out community service orders instead of prison sentences.
Justification:
A number of East African countries (including Tanzania, Kenya and Uganda) have shown an increase in the number of convictions resulting in community service instead of prison sentences. It is suggested this is due to prison overcrowding. The article discusses

 how these community service convictions may be more beneficial and teach lessons to those convicted.
Primary Article Title: East Africa tests noncustodial sentences
Keywords: prison jail crime "community service" Africa "East Africa" imprisonment "noncustodial sentences"

Justification:
Men outnumber women in the technology sector. For example, wolrdwide 9% of senior IT roles are held by women. Far fewer women worldwide engage with online technology than men. The number of women studying computer science at higher levels is also falling.

 The article discusses schemes to reduce the gender gap, such as bursaries, free training and promoting role models.

Summary Sentence: Research into the difference in male and female doctors' incomes in the US shows male doctors earn more and 30% of the difference cannot be explained by hours or specialism.
Justification:
Research into the difference in male and female doctors' incomes in the US shows male doctors earn more than female doctors (mean $297,641 vs. $206,751). On average, male doctors worked more hours, were less likely to be primary care doctors and more likely

 to perform operations. Adjusting for these factors accounted for 70% of the income difference found. 30% remains unexplained.
Primary Article Title: Differences in physician income by gender in a multiregion survey
Author: Apaydin, E., Chen, P., Friedberg, M.
Keywords: "gender pay gap" income doctors medicine gender

Summary Sentence: A horror game uses a heartrate monitor to adjust the gameplay and make it more or less scary depending on heartrate.
Justification:
A horror game is using 'biometric feedback' to adjust the gameplay to the right level for the player. It uses a heartrate monitor and can make the game more or less scary depending on the heartrate of the player. Article suggest this could be the future

 of gameplay.
Primary Article Title: This VR horror game is exactly as scary as your body can handle
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: VR AR "video game" "biometric feedback"

Summary Sentence: A company in New Zealand piloted a 4-day work week for its 240 employees for 8 weeks and there was no impact on productivity but an increase in wellbeing
Justification:
A company in New Zealand piloted a 4-day work week for its 240 employees for 8 weeks. There was no negative impact on productivity and a slight increase in job performance. The trial saw an increase in wellbeing with surveys indicating that staff stress

 levels dropping from 45 percent to 38 percent and work-life balance improving from 54 percent to 78 percent. Suggestions that this could be a future trend in work patterns.
Primary Article Title: This 4-day work week experiment went so well, the company is keeping it
Author: Dockrill, P.
Keywords: work "work-life balance" employers employees "working hours"

Summary Sentence: The genome editing tool CISPR-cas9 was used in mice to test the viability of gene drives in mammals
Justification:
The research managed to boost the inheritance rate of a mutation in a population of mice from the expected 50% of offspring to around 73%. However, the mutation was not always copied correctly and the system appeared to work better in female embryos than

 in males. Gene drives have been suggested as a way of controlling disease vectors such as mosquitos as well ass rodent pests. Their use is controversial as once released into the environment they cannot readily be reversed.
Primary Article Title: Gene drives tested in mammals for first time
Author: Ewen Callaway
Keywords: Gene drive
GT: Researchers have used a genome editing tool to boost the inheritance of a genetic trait among a population of mice

Summary Sentence: Rolls-Royce have designed a propulsion system for an airborne electric vehicle
Justification:
Rolls-Royce have made plans for an airborne electric vehicle capable of vertical take off and landing. The vehicle will generate power for its six electronic propulsors using gas turbine technology and has been designed to have a low noise profile. It

 is expected to be able to carry five people, travel at speeds of up to 250 mph and cover distances of up to 500 miles.
Primary Article Title: Rolls-Royce develops propulsion system for flying taxi
Keywords: electric airborne vehicle aviation propulsion passenger drones
GT: Propulsion system dsigned for airborne vehicle

Summary Sentence: Tiny ultra-sensitive sensors can detect early seismic activity and be used to provide earthquake warnings
Justification:
When an earthquake occurs, it's sound (seismic pressure waves) travels faster than the subsequent land movements. Researchers in Canada have developed new sensors that can detect sound waves with high sensitivity. This includes seismic pressure waves caused

 by earthquakes, and high-frequency vibration caused by the sound of a gas leak along a pipeline. The technology could be used to provide early earnings of earthquakes (of a few seconds up to minutes), allowing time to secure infrastructure (such as bridges

 and power cables) and potentially save people's lives.
Primary Article Title: Tiny sensors may avert earthquake damage, track sonar danger, 'listen' to pipelines
Keywords: earthquake sensors sound detection

Summary Sentence: Increasing use of blockchain technology across businesses worldwide could lead to new cyber vulnerabilities
Justification:
An increasing number of businesses are interested in using blockchain technology to improve their processes. Network security company RSA has warned that the increasing blockchain applications in businesses worldwide could lead to new security vulnerabilities.

 Hackers may try and find and exploit system vulnerabilities and weaknesses, and new technologies can generally lead to security blindspots.
Primary Article Title: RSA says blockchain presents a new wave of cyber-risk for global organisations
Author: Patrick Martlew
Keywords: blockchain cyber security threat network vulnerability
GT: Blockchain has the potential for cyber security vulnerabilities

Summary Sentence: Researchers in Cambridge have used three different types of stem cells from mice to create a structure that acts like an embryo and develops past a key stage (gastrulation) in embryonic development
Justification:
Gastrulation is a key stage in embryo development, when the embryo starts to differentiate into different types of cells (endoderm and mesoderm). Previously the same researchers had shown that mixing mice embryonic stem cells (ESCs) with trophoblast stem

 cells (TSCs) resulted in self-organising structures that resembled embryos. By adding a third type of stem cells (extra-embryonic endoderm stem cells) into the mix, the resulting structures not only resembled embryos, but developed past the key gastrulation

 stage. If similar results could be obtained using human stem cells then the resulting "embryos" could be used to study the early stages of human embryonic development beyond the 14 day limit currently permitted by law.
Primary Article Title: Self-assembly of embryonic and two extra-embryonic stem cell types into gastrulating embryo-like structures
Author: Berna Sozen, Gianluca Amadei, Andy Cox, Ran Wang, Ellen Na, Sylwia Czukiewska, Lia Chappell, Thierry Voet, Geert Michel, Naihe Jing, David M. Glover & Magdalena Zernicka-Goetz
Keywords: Embryology, stem cells
GT: First artificial embryo created from three different types of stem cells in mice

Summary Sentence: Researchers at University of Texas at Dallas have made artificial hair-like sensors which could be used for robotics or prosthetics
Justification:
Researchers in Texas have developed sensors, similar in diameter to hair or whiskers, which can detect force, pressure, proximity, temperature, stiffness and topography in a similar way to human skin. The 'whiskers' were created by layering a flexible

 sensor on top of a thin polymer sheet. The researchers have suggested that these hair-like sensors could be used in applications such as robotics and prosthetics.
Primary Article Title: E-whiskers may be touchstone for future of e-skin
Keywords: electronic sensors polymers materials robotics prosthetics

Summary Sentence: China is has developed tiny drones that mimic the flight of birds.
Justification:
China is trialing small bird-like for surveillance purposes and are fitted with high-definitions cameras and GPS antenna, flight control systems and satellite connectivity, The South China Morning Post has reported that over 30 military groups over 5 provinces

 have deployed these bird-like drones in recent years. the drones are reported to have wingspan of around 50cm, and flight speeds of up to 50 km/h. The project is still in its early stages of development and technology has experiences several drawbacks. For

 example, the drones can be easily hampered by high winds and are vulnerable to electromagnetic disturbance.
Primary Article Title: China looks to bolster surveillance network with birdlike drones
Author: Nick Wingham
Keywords: drones china surveillance privacy military robotics

Summary Sentence: A study has found that permafrost in the northern hemisphere stores globally significant amounts of mercury that may be released as it thaws affecting ecosystems and human health.
Justification:
This study uses a combination of modelling and measurements of levels of mercury present in permafrost cores to estimate how much mercury has been trapped in the permafrost north of the equator since the last Ice Age. The study found that approximately

 793 gigagrams is present, which is ten times greater than the level of emissions from human activities in the last 30 years, based on emission estimates from 2016. Thawing permafrost could release mercury in large enough amounts to affect ecosystems globally,

 as it accumulates in aquatic and terrestrial food chains. Mercury in some fished marine species are already at levels that may pose risks to human health and higher levels could result harmful neurological and reproductive effects on humans and animals.
Primary Article Title: Permafrost stores a globally significant amount of mercury
Author: Paul F. Schuster  Kevin M. Schaefer  George R. Aiken  Ronald C. Antweiler  John F. Dewild Joshua D. Gryziec  Alessio Gusmeroli  Gustaf Hugelius  Elchin Jafarov  David P. Krabbenhoft Lin Liu  Nicole Herman‐Mercer  Cuicui Mu  David A. Roth  Tim Schaefer  Ro
Keywords: Climate Change, Persistent Toxic Metals

Summary Sentence: Methane emissions from lakes in the northern hemisphere could double over the next 50 years because of previously unidentified feedback loop
Justification:
In the northern hemisphere, an increase in average temperature is increasing the vegetative biomass of bulrushes growing in and around freshwater lakes. When debris from these reed beds accumulates in the lake bed sediments it increases the amount of methane

 being produced by the anaerobic bacteria present. Freshwater lakes already act as a significant source of methane emissions, a GHG that causes more rapid warming of the atmosphere than CO2, and contribute to around 16% of natural methane emissions.

 The modelling carried out for this study suggests that the number of northern lakes colonised by bulrushes could double between 2041 and 2070 and this could elevate methane production by at least 73% during the growing season.
Primary Article Title: Climate-driven shifts in sediment chemistry enhance methane production in northern lakes
Author: E. J. S. Emilson, M. A. Carson, K. M. Yakimovich, H. Osterholz, T. Dittmar, J. M. Gunn, N. C. S. Mykytczuk, N. Basiliko & A. J. Tanentzap
Keywords: Climate Change Feedbacks, Carbon budgets, Mitigation

Summary Sentence: Extirpated large top predators, such as wolves, are moving back into areas they once occupied.
Justification:
Researchers have highlighted that animals such as otters, alligators, wolves and mountain lions that had their habitats and populations reduced by humans are now moving back into areas they were previously excluded from. This study suggests that this recolonisation

 of habitats is beyond what have been recognised as the ones they occupy, such as mountain lions into grassland and alligators into saltwater systems, and is a response to long term protection of these species. Recognising that these predators occupied a wider

 diversity of habitats than previously thought suggests environmental baselines (what constitutes a healthy historical state for a given ecosystem) may need to be reconsidered, the resilience of these ecosystems may be enhanced by their presence and they may

 be able to colonise a greater range of habitats to adapt to climate change impacts than previously thought.
Primary Article Title: Are the ghosts of nature's past haunting ecology today?
Author: Brian R. Silliman, Brent B. Hughes, Lindsay C. Gaskins, Qiang He, M. Tim Tinker, Andrew Read, James Nifong, Rick Stepp
Keywords: Biodiversity Loss, Environmental Monitoring, Wildlife Populations, Climate Change

Summary Sentence: Oilseed crop plants have been genetically edited to produce the omega-3 fatty acids EPA and DHA, which has had the unintended consequences of butterfly larvae feeding on the crop developing deformed wings and heavier adults.
Justification:
Omega-3 fatty acids are critical for key physiological functions in invertebrates and vertebrates, but EPA and DHA are not produced by most terrestrial plants. Changing the fatty acid profile of oil seed crops to produce EPA and DHA proportionality reduces

 the amount of alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), which is essential for the growth and survival of terrestrial insects. However, EPA and DHA are essential for aquatic species including commercially farmed fish species and these crops may be a key approach to improving

 the sustainability of aquaculture by reducing dependence on EPA and DHA from wild caught fish for aquaculture feed.  The study authors suggest the effect of changes in the fatty acid profile of oilseed crops need to be better understood as it may be impossible to prevent the spread of the edited genes from crops to wild relative species, with subsequent ecological and

 evolutionary effects.
Primary Article Title: Potential for novel production of omega-3 long-chain fatty acids by genetically engineered oilseed plants to alter terrestrial ecosystem dynamics
Author: Stefanie M.Colombo, Lesley G.Campbell, Eric J.Murphy, Sara L.Martin, Michael T. Arts
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification, Livestock Feed, Invertebrates, Ecosystem Functioning

Summary Sentence: There are signs that technology company interest in air quality monitoring.
Justification:
Previously Google have partnered with air quality monitoring company Aclima to equip its StreetView cars air quality monitoring equipment (%2313393). Later in 2018 Google are planning to map air quality in London using two StreetView cars equipped with sensors

 from a different company, AirMaps, that record air quality every 30 metres, along with 100 fixed point sensors. London mayor Sadiq Khan is calling it “the most sophisticated (network) in the World”. The hyperlocal data generated over the next year will be

 used to inform policy responses to London air quality, and shared with other members of the C40 Cities network. Aclima have also scaling up their air quality monitoring efforts, attracting a large investment in its air quality sensor and mapping network, having

 recently completed a hyperlocal air quality monitoring project (with Google, amongst others) in Austin, Texas, employing a similar method to Google’s London project. This has produced one of the most detailed urban air quality data sets ever. Fixed monitoring

 network is designed for air quality regulation, don’t always indicate air pollution to people in their immediate surroundings. Highly-localised emissions data is also quite limited, and models have to be used to fill the gaps using limited data. The platforms

 that Google and Aclima are using complements existing stationary monitoring by introducing air pollution data at street level, and may even surpass it in the future, particularly as data gathered by citizen scientists (%2314465) through their personal devices

 (%2313622, %2313145) grow in number. Google has also started estimating greenhouse gas emissions for individual cities to help local administrations take action on climate change. Estimates are based on carbon emissions from electricity and transportation data,

 including information collected by its popular mapping apps, Google Maps and Waze. More accurate estimates including heavy industry and agriculture are currently hampered by the age and quality of data. So far Google has estimates for five cities but plans

 to cover municipalities worldwide. Commercial companies have different motivations compared to the public sector. Whilst there is potential for partnership there is also potential for competition in giving an authoritative position on air pollution, plus the

 potential to challenge official views of pollution and emissions from regulated sectors. Regulators in this field, including the Environment Agency may need to consider how future regulatory activities may develop with commercial parties also involved, potentially

 providing a better and more detailed environmental monitoring service.
Primary Article Title: Aclima sucks in $24M to scale its air quality mapping platform
Author: Lomas, N
Secondary_URLs:
Google StreetView cars to help map pollution in London - TechCrunch 21/06/2018

Google's new tool to fight climate change - The Atlantic 25/09/2018

Google, Aclima, Environmental Defense Fund, and UT Austin announce results of breakthrough study mapping hyperlocal air quality - Aclima 05/06/2017
Keywords: "air quality" "environmental monitoring" "air pollution" pollution Google Aclima sensor Streetview hyperlocal data regulation commercial street level urban city neighbourhood C40 cities policy London Austin Texas car vehicle modelling monitoring network "citizen science" smartphone mobile phone "climate change" Map Waze "greenhouse gas" emission

Summary Sentence: China's government has said that it will roll out a national "social credit" system by 2020, with the aim of promoting "trustworthiness" across its economy and society.
Justification:
China is trialling a social credit system that combines credit scores with more expansive measures such as ranking calculated by companies, neighbourhoods and online payment providers. People who score highly are promoted as role-models to the community

 and receive benefits such as discounts on their heating bills. Those who score poorly are prevented from buying plane or high-speed train tickets. People's scores can be increased by helping your family in difficult circumstances, giving to charity, volunteering

 or doing exemplary business. Points may be deduced for not paying your taxes on time, or offences such as drink driving. The scheme was founded in 2014 by the State Council. Approximately 35 pilot systems have been rolled out in cities across China.
Primary Article Title: Life inside china's social credit laboratory
Author: Simina Mistreanu
Keywords: data analytics social credit china social engineering surveillance privacy freedom government governance

Summary Sentence: A study has proposed that human activities that substantially modify natural environments may lead to raised rates of cancer in wild animal populations.
Justification:
Noise, light and chemical pollution, feeding of wildlife by humans (such as bird feeders) and the effects of human disturbance of habitats on genetic diversity may potentially lead to higher cancer rates in wildlife populations outside of the areas that

 have previously been associated with these effects, such as heavily chemically polluted sites. For instance, it has been suggested that pollution from microplastics, herbicides, pesticides and artificial light exposure at night have all been associated with

 raised cancer risks in humans and it is plausible these factors extend to animal populations. Although interactions between these risk factors are poorly understood, the study suggests humans should be considered an 'oncogenic species', one that moderates

 the environment in ways that increases risks that may cause cancer in other species' populations.
Primary Article Title: Human activities might influence oncogenic processes in wild animal populations
Author: Mathieu Giraudeau, Tuul Sepp, Beata Ujvari, Paul W. Ewald & Frédéric Thomas
Keywords: Biodiversity Loss, Environmental Monitoring, Wildlife Populations

Summary Sentence: Use of technology measuring infant's health indicators, such as heart-rate, is rising.
Justification:
Technology now exists for parents and carers to take health measurements of infants (such as measuring their heart-rate, oxygen saturation or body position when they sleep). These technologies are not medical grade and do not claim to prevent conditions

 such as Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) but people are using them for peace-of-mind. In the future they may have medical capabilities.
Primary Article Title: The rise of tech nannies
Author: Apte, P.
Keywords: technology baby infant "cot death" "health technology" "health indicators" health

Summary Sentence: Cantonese is being replaced by Mandarin in Hong Kong in school lessons and in business.
Justification:
Some residents of Hong Kong are concerned that Cantonese is being replaced by Mandarin, with an influx of Mandarin speakers and the majority of primary school teaching taking place in Mandarin. There have also been videos used in schools suggesting that

 Cantonese is inferior to Mandarin. There are attempts to ensure Cantonese does not get wiped out in Hong Kong, such as reinstating old Cantonese art forms. Future of Cantonese in Hong Kong is uncertain.
Primary Article Title: Hong Kong is fighting back against a Mandarin language invasion
Author: Coca, N.
Keywords: Mandarin Chinese China "Hong Kong" language "language extinction" "language teaching" multilingualism "language policy"

Summary Sentence: A longitudinal study of 15-16-year-olds found an association between higher frequency of digital media use and symptoms of ADHD over 24 months.
Justification:
Study involved longitudinal measures of over 2,500 15-16-year-olds who did not have ADHD symptoms of ADHD. Study found an association between higher frequency of digital media use (including using social media, messaging, streaming videos, or listening

 to music online) and symptoms of ADHD over the following 24 months.
Primary Article Title: Association of digital media use with subsequent symptoms of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder among adolescents
Author: Ra, C. et al
Keywords: ADHD ADD "attention deficit" attention hyperactivity "digital media" "social media"

Summary Sentence: Academics measure changes in the quantum states of electrons in heavy metals and other materials at room temperature, bring the development of advanced quantum computing components a step closer.
Justification:
Academics in Singapore, the US and Australia have shown a practical way to observe the quantum effects of electrons in heavy metals and a type of material known as a topological insulator, which could lead to the development of advanced quantum computing

 components and devices. Topological insulators are electronic materials that have an insulating interior but can support conducting states on their surface (allow electrons to flow over the surface). The team looked at platinum metal and topological insulators

 Bi2Se3 and BiSbTeSe2. By applying an electrical current, they influenced the electron spin at the quantum level and were able to directly visualise this change using polarised light from a scanning photovoltage microscope. They were able to gather their results

 at room temperature, meaning that this method of visualisation could be applied to many other materials. They are planning further tests on more novel materials with novel spin properties and hope to work with industry to explore possible applications, focusing

 on developing devices for use in future quantum computers.
Primary Article Title: A step closer to quantum computers&%2358; researchers show how to directly observe quantum spin effects
Keywords: quantum computer spin state electon device component heavy metal topological insulator
GT: Quantum computing devices materials room temperature

Summary Sentence: Academics have developed a way of fabricating thin-film electronic circuits that can be stick onto surfaces and then pealed off again after soaking in water.
Justification:
An academic journal paper has been published which describes a new fabrication technique called transfer printing, which is more efficient in its use of silicon wafers and is therefore cheaper. This technique can be used to produce thin films that hold

 electronic circuits. These films can be pasted onto a range of objects, and can be used to sense the object's environment (e.g. temperature). In the longer-term, these stickers could be used to facilitate wireless communication.
Primary Article Title: Electronic stickers to streamline large-scale 'internet of things'
Keywords: internet of things electronic circuit wireless fabrication silicon

Summary Sentence: An off-grid ammonia powered fuel cell generator is now on the market.
Justification:
The generator comes from a company called GenCell. GenCell recently completed a deal to use their technology to power cell phone masts in Kenya, using ammonia as fuel, replacing 800 diesel generators. The shipping container sized equipment consists of

 four pieces. The first is a patented cracker that decomposes ammonia into nitrogen and hydrogen. The second is an alkaline fuel cell generator. This uses an electrolyte of potassium hydrochloride (KOH) to generate power from the hydrogen fuel. Third and fourth

 sections are for regulating power output and dissipating excess heat. A 12 ton tank of ammonia can power the fuel for a year. The roll out is expected to save $250 million compared to diesel solutions. The realisation of ammonia powered infrastructure on a

 wide scale demonstrates that the potential for ammonia as an energy storage and transport medium, as apart of a hydrogen energy economy, may becoming realised. The Environment Agency may see the impacts of a move to ammonia power on the sectors it regulates,

 and may also adopt technology similar to that described here for use with in field monitoring equipment.
Primary Article Title: GenCell launches commercial alkaline fuel cell using cracked ammonia fuel
Author: Brown, T
Keywords: energy "environmental monitoring" renewable ammonia hydrogen fuel cell regulation GenCell Kenya mobile phone infrastructure "potassium hydrochloride" KOH electrolyte diesel generator cracker nitrogen

Summary Sentence: Tiny microchips could help to embed patient data directly into their biological samples.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may be able to employ a similar idea to improve biological sampling for environmental monitoring purposes. The microchips are the same size as a flake of pepper. They can be added to a sample of blood, for example. A

 chip reader can then add additional information about the sample to the chip, such as location and test results. The same information as is added to patient’s medical record. This innovation could help reduce administrative error as well as attach additional

 information to samples. The project has Gates Foundation funding.
Primary Article Title: Microchips can permanently link patients with clinical samples
Author: Ober, H
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" data information sampling biological health medical patient microchip "Bill Gates" sample regulation

Summary Sentence: Altered gene expression caused by exposure to endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) has been found to be passed onto offspring.
Justification:
In experiments involving pregnant sows it was found that exposing them to doses of oestrogen hormone oestradiol-17β led to changes in gene expression both in the sows and in their offspring at the one year old stage. Whilst the changes in the sows were

 thought to be minimal, the results suggest that the overall impact of a lifetime’s exposure to EDCs is still unknown. The experiment has relevance to human health due to having similar hormone changes during pregnancy as pigs. The wider issue of environmental

 exposure, through food, atmosphere or water may therefore become an increasing issue for concern in the light of this and other evidence on the impact of EDCs, which also include plastics related chemicals such as bisphenol-A (BPA).
Primary Article Title: Administering hormones affects DNA
Author: Rüegg, P
Secondary_URLs: Gestational oral low-dose estradiol-17ß induces altered DNA methylation of CDKN2D and PSAT1 in embryos and adult offspring - Nature 10/05/2018
Keywords: health pregnancy hormone "endocrine disrupting chemical" EDC oestrogen pib offspring genes genetic bisphenol-A BPA oestradiol-17β  pig sow livestock regulation pollution pollutant chemical

Summary Sentence: Speech given by the UK Attorney General setting out the UK's position on applying international law to cyberspace.
Justification:
The Government set out it's view that&%2358; * International law does apply to cyber space and the question is how it applies; * States that are targeted by hostile cyber operations have the right to respond to in accordance with the options lawfully available

 to them. The UK has been working with other states to progress multilateral agreement on what responsible state behaviour in cyberspace looks like. In 2013, the UN Group of Governmental Experts on the use of cyber technologies, affirmed the application of

 existing international law to states’ cyber activities. In 2015, the UN Expert Group (including the UK, US, Russia & China) recognised that the UN Charter applies to cyberspace. The Group affirmed the relevance of a state’s inherent right to act in self-defence

 in response to a cyber operation meeting the threshold of an armed attack. It also confirmed that the fundamental protections of international humanitarian law&%2358; necessity, proportionality, humanity and distinction, apply in cyberspace. There are some areas

 in which UK Gov opinion varies from international law. E.g. It argues that a state should not be legally obliged to give prior notification to a hostile state before taking countermeasures against it. It also argues that there is no requirement for a response

 to be symmetrical to the underlying unlawful act. What matters is necessity and proportionality, which means that the UK could respond to a cyber intrusion through non-cyber means, and vice versa. The Gov also highlighted the challenge of accurately attributing

 a cyber attack when the action concerned is capable of crossing traditional territorial boundaries and sophisticated techniques are used to hide the identity and source of the operation. Those difficulties are compounded by the ready accessibility of cyber

 technologies and the resultant blurring of lines between the actions of governments and those of individuals. It has started to publically attribute attacks to state actors in some cases (e.g. WannaCry to North Korea and NotPetya to Russia) and says that it's

 important to publically scrutinise adversaries to encourage them to behave more responsibly. It also outlines various Gov investments in this area.
Primary Article Title: Cyber and international law in the 21st century
Author: From: Attorney General's Office and The Rt Hon Jeremy Wright MP
Keywords: cyber space crime security international law diplomacy internet

Summary Sentence: The BBC have highlighted several trends in the behaviour of young people that suggest they are "becoming more sensible"
Justification:
Trends highlighted include that&%2358; young people are&%2358; * drinking less * less likely to smoke * less likely to have taken drugs. There are also fewer young people being arrested and fewer teenage pregnancies. Data came from numerous sources including the ONS

 and the Home Office.
Primary Article Title: 'Generation sensible' in five charts
Keywords: Young people behaviour trends data pregnancy alcohol smoking drugs arrest
GT: Trends in behaviour of young people

Summary Sentence:
Researchers writing in the journal Science claim that global deaths from fungal infections are increasing and now exceed those from infectious diseases such as malaria. They suggest that immune-compromised patients such as people with HIV or those on cancer

 treatments are becoming increasingly at risk from fungicide-resistant fungal infections. They warn that effective clinical treatments are limited to just four classes of fungicides and that resistance to these is spreading, due in part to t
Justification: This has parallels with AMR where their widespread use in agriculture is one of the reasons cited for the spread of AMR factors in human pathogens.
Primary Article Title: Researchers issue new drug resistance warning as deaths from fungal infections exceeding malaria
Author: Matthew C. Fisher1, Nichola J. Hawkins, Dominique Sanglard and Sarah J. Gurr
Keywords: Fungicide resistance, Mortality
GT: Deaths of immunocompromised patients from drug-resistant fungal infections are increasing

Summary Sentence: Uranium could be commercially extracted from seawater using a newly developed yarn.
Justification:
