A new and relatively inexpensive source of nuclear fuel like this could lead to a greater use of nuclear energy in the future, and therefore a greater regulatory burden of radioactive waste. The ocean contains significantly more uranium than land based

 sources - about 500 times more - however it is not particularly concentrated. Researchers have developed an acrylic yarn like material which is a selective adsorbent of uranium. In laboratory experiments passing sea water through the yarn in conditions that

 mimicked the open sea produced five grammes of yellowcake - a powdered form of uranium that can be converted into nuclear fuel - over a one month period. Further refinement could lead to more significant quantities being abstracted. Marine mineral extraction

 in this form has advantages over terrestrial mining as there zero ground disturbance and little machinery required.
Primary Article Title: Seawater yields first grams of yellowcake
Author: Bauer, S
Keywords: energy waste nuclear radioactive marine ocean mining extraction uranium yarn yellowcake sea land regulation

Summary Sentence: A children's online video game was hacked, leading to a child watching her avatar being sexually assaulted by two male characters
Justification:
A report of the online game Roblox being hacked, which enabled the upload of some code that changed the game's rules and made customised animations appear. This was used to stage an attack on a seven year old's avatar. Roblox says that they use automated

 technology to track and monitor player communications, and appear to have responded quickly to the incident. This raises questions about the safety of online games for children and whether sexual violence may become more common in online gaming.
Primary Article Title: Roblox blames 'gang rape' on hacker adding code to game
Keywords: Online digital virtual sexual violance rape computer video gaming child safety

Summary Sentence: The populations of urban centres in English cities are growing rapidly.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may need consider demographic changes such as these in terms of activities to reduce the impacts of pollution, flooding and environmental incidents. Urban centres, particularly in the North of England has seen large

 urban population increases over the last 15 years or so. Cities such as Liverpool, Manchester and Sheffield have experienced an urban population growth of 181 per cent, 149 per cent and 139 per cent respectively. Whilst a large proportion of this can be attributed

 to student populations from a growth in higher education, the majority seems to come from young professionals. Expanding urban housing in these areas has been relatively easy due to a plentiful supply of brownfield land. However now this land has been utilised,

 future growth in these areas is more likely to happen in suburban areas or greenbelt land. This may also reflect changing priorities for the current young urban population as they age and think about ‘settling down’ and moving away from high density urban

 housing to lower density suburban style living.
Primary Article Title: The UK's rapid return to city centre living
Author: Swinney, P & Carter, A
Keywords: urbanisation population young housing urban development planning land suburb "green belt" pollution regulation flooding incident emergency "air quality" Liverpool Manchester Sheffield England student city

Summary Sentence:
Photosynthesis is the process by which visible red light is converted to oxygen and biochemicals by the green pigment chlorophyll-a. Researchers have now discovered that some species of blue-green algae (cyanobacter) can use a different type of chlorophyll

 (chlorophyll-f) to perform photosynthesis in near-infrared light. This occurs in habitats where shaded conditions mean that near-infrared light predominates.
Justification:
This may have agricultural implications for engineering crops that can be grown in a wider range of habitats. It also has implications for astrobiology as the search for habitable planets in distant solar systems is partly based on assumptions about the

 availability of visible red light (the so-called red limit).
Primary Article Title: New type of photosynthesis discovered
Author: Hayley Dunning
Keywords: photosynthesis, near-infrared
GT: Researchers have discovered a new type of photosynthesis that operates in near infra-red light

Summary Sentence: China is to reduce subsidies to its solar energy industry.
Justification:
The plans include reducing tariffs and subsidies to new solar generation projects. The consequences of this decision are far reaching for the global renewable economy. China currently has one of the World’s largest solar markets - new installations are

 greater here than in the rest of the World combined. Cutting financial support could bring demand to a halt. At the same time increasing protectionism in overseas markets could benefit from potentially much lower prices for photovoltaic panels etc, but this

 may not be enough to support Chinese production overall, leading to a contraction in suppliers and a slowdown in renewable growth. This may have implications for sectors impacted by the transition to a renewable economy such as power generation, refineries

 and fuel, and waste management.
Primary Article Title: China sends solar shivers with subsidy cuts
Author: Hook, L  & Hornby, L
Keywords: energy renewable solar panel photovoltaic PV China manufacturing trade protectionism tariff tax quota regulation export import "fossil fuel" emission

Summary Sentence:
Researchers looked at gene transfer between bacterial species. They found that each species contains architecture imparting sequences (AIMS) written into their genomes. It is the compatibility of these AIMs sequences that determines the probability of

 gene transfer between two bacterial species.
Justification: Gene transfer between species has important implications for controlling the spread of antibiotic resistance genes and pathogen virulence genes.
Primary Article Title: Road rules for gene transfer are written in DNA
Author: Massey University
Keywords: horizontal gene transfer
GT: The transfer of genes between bacterial species depends on the compatibility of their DNA sequences

Summary Sentence:
RNA is made of 4 bases&%2358; A, U, G and C. Modifications to one of these bases can affect the way that the genetic code is processed. The researchers looked at one modification to the A base, known as m6A. They showed that incorporating an m6A base in certain

 positions within the code affected the rate at which the resulting RNA matured. They suggested that this was a way of encrypting the genetic code so that it could not be read or used by potential pathogens.
Justification: This may have implications for genome editing technologies, for example for clinical therapies based on sequence directed techniques such as CRISPR-cas.
Primary Article Title: Researchers discover encryption system in genetic code
Author: Not attributed
Keywords: Encryption, genetic code, genome editing
GT: Researchers show that modified RNA bases affect how genes are expressed and suggest that such modifications may be a form of encryption

Summary Sentence:
Mosquitos act as vectors for transmitting a range of diseases such as malaria, dengue and zika. In this research scientists released around 3 million male mosquitos in Northern Australia that had been infected with a bacterium that rendered them sterile.

 The sterile males mated with the females producing eggs that did not hatch. This resulted in a dramatic reduction of the mosquito population in the area.
Justification:
There is considerable discussion about use of gene drive as a way of controlling disease vectors such as mosquitos. This study can be regarded as proof-of-principle that the release of large numbers of sterile males is an effective means of controlling

 such populations.
Primary Article Title: Australian scientists perform experiment successfully wiping out over 80% of disease-carrying mosquitoes
Author: Jessie Yeung
Keywords: mosquito, infectious disease
GT: Australian scientists show that large scale releases of sterile male mosquitos is an effective way of reducing mosquito populations

Summary Sentence:
A survey conducted by Ipsos on behalf of the Centre for International Governance Innovation (CIGI), in partnership with the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and the Internet Society (ISOC), found that over half of internet users

 surveyed around the world are more concerned about their online privacy than they were a year ago, reflecting growing concern around the world about online privacy and the power of social media platforms.
Justification:
The survey reached 25,262 internet users in 25 countries. It focused on five key areas&%2358; • online privacy and trust; • online influencers; • e-commerce; • the Internet of Things; and • new technologies. Key findings included&%2358; • Fifty-two percent of global

 users responded that they are more concerned about their online privacy compared to one year ago. • For 81 percent of respondents, cybercriminals were the primary source of concern regarding their online privacy. Overall, 63 percent also reported that their

 own government has contributed to their concerns regarding online privacy. • Users also expressed a high level of distrust of social media platforms, search engines and internet technology companies, with 63 percent of respondents feeling that social media

 has too much power. • Forty-two percent of those responding claim that social media influences their political views and 30 percent think that social media makes their life worse. As a result, many around the globe are changing their behaviour online, a trend

 with economic and societal implications. • Twelve percent of global internet users report making fewer online purchases. • Ten percent have closed social media accounts and seven percent are using the internet less often overall, compared to one year ago.
Primary Article Title: 2018 cigi-ipsos global survey on internet security and trust
Author: Centre for International Governance Innovation & IPSOS
Keywords: Public attitudes internet social media trust privacy e-commerce
GT: Global survey found that of public attitudes to internet security and trust

Summary Sentence:
Emryonic stem cells could help treat all kinds of disorders, and editing the genomes of these stem cells could make the treatments far more potent but a team at novartis has found that genome editing kills most human embryonic stem cells - and the ones

 that survive are more likely to have mutations in a key anticancer gene
Justification:
Genome editing has been hailed as a major potential clinical treatment for a wide range of diseases. Crispr cas is the technique used by most labs as it is quick, easy and cheap. However the Novartis research suggests that the technique triggers a response

 from the P53 gene/protein. P53's job is to trigger cell death in those cells where it detects dangerous mutations. If CRISPR triggers such a fundamental defence mechanism then this may severely limit its clinical utility.
Primary Article Title: Gene editing stem cells has cancer risk
Author: Michael Le Page
Keywords: Genome editing, cancer
GT: Gene editing embryonic stem cells could potentially form the basis of useful clinical treatments but also increase the risk of cancer

Summary Sentence: The World Health Organization has listed gaming addiction as a mental health condition for the first time.
Justification:
A draft of the WHO's 11th International Classification of Diseases describes gaming addiction as a pattern of persistent or recurrent gaming behaviour so severe that it takes "precedence over other life interests". Some countries have already identified

 it as a major public health issue. The guide contains codes for diseases, signs and symptoms, and is used by doctors and researchers to track and diagnose disease. It will suggest that abnormal gaming behaviour should be in evidence over a period of at least

 12 months "for a diagnosis to be assigned" but added that period might be shortened "if symptoms are severe". Symptoms include&%2358; ◾impaired control over gaming (frequency, intensity, duration) ◾increased priority given to gaming ◾continuation or escalation of

 gaming despite negative consequences. Digital/gaming addiction is not universally recognised. Many psychiatrists refer to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM), the fifth edition of which was published in 2013, in which internet gaming

 disorder is listed as a "condition for further study", meaning it is not officially recognised.
Primary Article Title: Gaming addition classified as disorder by world health organization
Author: Jane Wakefield, BBC
Keywords: computer gaming digital addiction world health organization mental children

Summary Sentence: A study has revealed that a single German company owns nearly have of all patented marine genetic sequences.
Justification:
Chemical giant BASF holds 47 per cent of the patents on all 862 species or marine life with genetic patents associated with them, including fish, whales and microscopic species. The entire raft of patents is held by only 10 countries, leading some to speculate

 that this could lead to inequality in accessing the potential benefits of the marine environment. Whilst patents on human gene sequencing are banned to allow for greater medical gains and there are some attempts to provide a framework for national marine jurisdictions,

 the same frameworks do not extend to the high seas. There are potential issues if a country is generating wealth from marine species that exist outside of jurisdictions but isn't then sharing the wealth globally. Similar concerns over deep sea mining have

 led to the formation of the International Seabed Authority, but its legitimacy isn't recognised by the USA, for example.The legal uncertainty as to who has a right to own the genetic material of this common heritage may lead to future issues particularly as

 the importance of the marine environment in the scope of the blue economy economy increases.
Primary Article Title: Nearly half the patents on marine genes belong to just one company
Author: Smith, R. P
Secondary_URLs: Corporate control and global governance of marine genetic resources - Science Advances 06/06/2018
Keywords: biodiversity copyright genes genetics marine fauna flora fish legislation ownership economics commerce law sea ocean treaty jurisdiction deep sea mining whale microscopic biology BASF regulation "blue economy"

Summary Sentence: New developments in artificial intelligence suggest that automation can outcompete humans on tasks requiring expert judgement and influencing, rather than tasks involving process.
Justification:
These developments suggest increasingly significant potential for automation in the workplace to enhance and replace humans in a variety of tasks. One AI system designed to complete the MRCGP exam (the Royal College of General Practitioners final test

 for trainee doctors) averaged 82 per cent on the test&%2358; the average human score is 72 per cent, demonstrating how AI can reduce the burden on health systems - and by extent, other services. IBM recently staged a debate between two humans and an AI from their

 Project Debater project, which appears as a six foot black panel with a screen animated mouth. Man and machine were both given a few minutes to prepare a debate, rebuttal and summary. Though the AI’s delivery did not rate highly with the audience, its overall

 use of evidence and persuasiveness of argument led to it winning one of two debates. More sophisticated versions that can analyse and process large and diverse data sets to help build persuasive arguments and make well-informed decisions suggest significant

 impacts on many aspects of work, including knowledge management and customer service.
Primary Article Title: Man 1, machine 1&%2358; landmark debate between AI and humans ends in draw
Author: Solon, O
Secondary_URLs: AI healthcare firm claims its chatbot can beat doctors at medical exams - Interesting Engineering 02/07/2018
Keywords: automation "artificial intelligence" AI computer data debate IBM expert human workforce employee employer algorithm knowledge service "Project Debater" "Babylon Health" "MRCGP exam" "Royal College of General Practitioners" health medicine doctor training

Summary Sentence: Nurseries claiming that a UK government policy of 30 hours free childcare a week is leaving them underfunded.
Justification:
English nurseries are reporting losses and closures have become more common according to the National Day Nurseries Association. Nurseries have blamed the policy for all children aged 3 and 4 to receive 30 hours per week of free childcare. They claim there

 is an administrative burden and that the money received from local authorities does not cover costs and is often delayed, leading to financial issues.
Primary Article Title: Is a pro-preschool policy closing English nurseries?
Author: Warwick-Ching, L.
Keywords: nursery nurseries children toddlers childcare pre-school care

Summary Sentence: Young Japanese people are moving out of larger cities into smaller towns and villages.
Justification:
There is a trend for young Japanese people in high-powered jobs in large cities to move to smaller towns and villages. Young people say they want a quieter, peaceful rural life. Some communities are trying to attract young people with the opportunities

 to develop new businesses. This could help regenerate smaller rural towns and villages in the future.
Primary Article Title: Back to the future&%2358; Japanese youth flee cities for the countryside
Author: Coca, N.
Keywords: rural "young people" urban countryside entrepreneur migration

Summary Sentence: Organisations are joining up in Los Angeles to collect food waste and turn it into free ingredients or meals for those in need.
Justification: Organisations, such as supermarkets and restaurants, are joining together to combat food waste and hunger by donating ingredients. Examples include juicing companies which give their pulp to be used in other foods rather than ending up in landfill.
Primary Article Title: Because food and people are terrible things to waste
Author: Pinchevsky, T.
Keywords: "food banks" "food waste" hunger poverty "reducing food waste"

Summary Sentence: A Dutch company that presented the world's first lab-grown beef burger five years ago says it has received funding to pursue its plans to make and sell artificially grown meat to restaurants from 2021.
Justification:
Maastricht-based Mosa Meat said Tuesday it raised 7.5 million euros ($8.8 million), mainly from M Ventures and Bell Food Group. M Ventures is an investment vehicle for German pharmaceuticals company Merck KGaA. Bell Food is a European meat processing company

 based in Switzerland. Mosa is one of one of several working to produce cultured meat for consumers concerned about the environmental and ethical impact of traditional farming. Mosa Meat aims to sell its first products in 2021, achieving industrial-scale production

 2-3 years later.
Primary Article Title: Dutch company gets funding to bring lab-grown meat to market
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification, Synthetic Meat

Summary Sentence: A laboratory study has engineered a bacterium that can make use of atmospheric nitrogen, “fixing” the nitrogen, in a significant step toward engineering plants that can do the same.
Justification: Biological nitrogen fixation is catalyzed by nitrogenase, a complex metalloenzyme found only in prokaryotes. Cyanobacteria are oxygenic photosynthetic prokaryotes, and some of them also fix N2. Here, this study demonstrates a feasible way to engineer nitrogenase activity in the nondiazotrophic cyanobacterium Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 through the transfer of 35 nitrogen fixation (nif) genes from the diazotrophic cyanobacterium Cyanothece sp. ATCC 51142. In addition, it identified the minimal nif cluster required for such activity in Synechocystis 6803. Moreover, nitrogenase activity was significantly improved by increasing the expression levels of nif genes. The O2 tolerance of nitrogenase was enhanced by introduction of uptake hydrogenase genes, showing this to be a functional way to improve nitrogenase enzyme activity under micro-oxic conditions. To date, research has resulted in engineered Synechocystis 6803 strains that, remarkably, have more than 30% of the N2 fixation activity of Cyanothece 51142, the highest such activity established in any nondiazotrophic oxygenic photosynthetic organism.
Primary Article Title: Engineering nitrogen fixation activity in an oxygenic phototroph
Author: Deng Liu, Michelle Liberton, Jingjie Yu, Himadri B. Pakrasi, Maitrayee Bhattacharyya-Pakrasi
Secondary_URLs: Researchers engineer bacteria to create fertilizer out of thin air - EurekAlert! 16/07/2018
Keywords: Sustainable intensification, Nitrogen Fixation

Summary Sentence: Climate change will increase air conditioning use, which increases emissions of air pollutants from power plants that will in turn worsen air quality with human health impacts.
Justification:
The modelling system used in this study included downscaling historical and future climate data with the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model, simulating building electricity demand using the Regional Building Energy Simulation System (RBESS),

 simulating power sector production and emissions using MyPower, simulating ambient air quality using the Community Multiscale Air Quality (CMAQ) model, and calculating the incidence of adverse health outcomes using the Environmental Benefits Mapping and Analysis

 Program (BenMAP). The modelling suggests that by mid-century, climate change alone may increase fine particulate matter (PM2.5) concentrations by 58.6% (2.50 μg/m3) and ozone (O3) by 14.9% (8.06 parts per billion by volume

 [ppbv]) for the month of July. Health impacts assessment finds that for a mid-century climate change scenario (with adaptation), annual PM2.5-related adult mortality increases by 13,547 deaths (14 concentration–response functions with mean incidence

 range of 1,320 to 26,481, approximately US$126 billion cost) and annual O3-related adult mortality increases by 3,514 deaths (3 functions with mean incidence range of 2,175 to 4,920, approximately US$32.5 billion cost), calculated as a 3-month summer

 estimate based on July modeling. Air conditioning adaptation accounts for 654 (range of 87 to 1,245) of the PM2.5-related deaths (approximately US$6 billion cost, a 4.8% increase above climate change impacts alone) and 315 (range of 198 to 438)

 of the O3-related deaths (approximately US$3 billion cost, an 8.7% increase above climate change impacts alone).
Primary Article Title: Air-quality-related health impacts from climate change and from adaptation of cooling demand for buildings in the eastern United States&%2358; An interdisciplinary modelling study
Author: David W. Abel , Tracey Holloway, Monica Harkey, Paul Meier, Doug Ahl, Vijay S. Limaye, Jonathan A. Patz
Keywords: Climate Change Adaptation; Building Performance; Air Conditioning

Summary Sentence: The Millennial generation is not managing to accumulate wealth like previous generations.
Justification:
This could have significant long term impacts on the workforce and beyond. In the UK the average accumulated net wealth between those born in the 1980s and previous decades is much lower. Whilst wages and savings have changed little, home ownership is

 much lower, due to high house prices, impacting on net wealth. The generosity of pension contributions from employers has also decreased, impacting accumulated wealth in a similar way. When longevity is factored into the equation it is possible that younger

 people could be working for much longer, and in fact there are suggestions that the idea of retirement for Millennials is under threat. Inherited wealth may therefore become more important, which may include inherited property. A consequence of lower rates

 of home ownership (and by implication, greater rates of renting) could be a shifting of the owner/occupier relationship, and therefore attitudes to flood defence. There are also potential demographic shifts for the workplace where the need for a greater provision

 for an ageing workforce.
Primary Article Title: Will Millennials ever retire?
Author: Watkins, J
Secondary_URLs: The generation gap - Economic And Social Research Council 17/07/2018
Keywords: demographics socioeconomics wealth workforce employee employer pension finance flooding property housing retirement people Millennial incident

Summary Sentence: Patients with a clinical fear of heights undertook six VR sessions with a virtual coach and showed reduce fear of heights.
Justification:
100 volunteers who had a clinically diagnosed fear of heights took part in a study where half received no treatment for their fear and half had VR treatment. The VR treatment consisted of six sessions with a virtual coach where participants faced VR scenarios

 involving height. Participants who received no treatment reported similar levels of fear for heights whilst the majority of those who received the VR sessions reported significantly less fear. VR could have a role in treating phobias and other conditions in

 the future.
Primary Article Title: VR treatment, even without a therapist, helps people overcome fear of heights
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: VR AR "VR healthcare" health healthcare phobia fear "mental health"

Summary Sentence: A commercially viable process that extracts carbon dioxide directly from the air is up and running.
Justification:
The company behind it, Carbon Engineering, has developed a four stage process. Firstly air is channeled through a honeycombed plastic slab called a contactor, where carbon dioxide reacts with aqueous potassium hydroxide to produce a potassium carbonate

 solution, which is then filtered and exposed to a slurry of calcium hydroxide. This produces potassium hydroxide, which is fed back into the first stage. Calcium carbonate pellets are also produce at this stage. These are fed into a calciner and heated, producing

 pure carbon dioxide gas which can be captured, plus calcium oxide, which can be converted back into calcium hydroxide for use in the second step. The chemical reactions have been known for a long time, but this is the first occasion where it has been realised

 at scale. The company, which counts Bill Gates as an investor estimates that Co2 can be removed for around $94 and $232 per tonne. In the face of increasing climate change it seems more possible that the World could resort to geoengineering schemes such as

 this, which may fall under the Environment Agency’s regulatory remit.
Primary Article Title: New study shows extracting carbon dioxide from air is actually feasible
Author: Miley, J
Secondary_URLs: A Process for Capturing CO2 from the Atmosphere - Joule 07/06/2018
Keywords: "climate change" pollution "carbon dioxide" CO2 extraction "carbon capture and storage" CCS "Carbon Engineering" "potassium hydroxide" contactor "calcium carbonate" calciner "calcium oxide" "Bill Gates" emission pollutant regulation

Summary Sentence: A technology to record conversations at check-outs has been patented by Walmart.
Justification: Walmart has patented a technology to record sounds at checkouts. The recordings could then be used to assess the service of workers. Walmart has said it does not plan to use the technology yet but may in the future.
Primary Article Title: Walmart patents tech for eavesdropping on workers
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: surveillance supermarkets workers "recording device" technology

Summary Sentence: Article discussing the ways that changing supermarket lay-out can reduce purchases of fatty or high sugar foods.
Justification:
Following announcements that supermarkets will remove 'junk food' from near checkout tills and end offers on 'junk food' by the end of 2018, the article discusses the effect of supermarket layouts on food choice. It notes that changing layouts and advertising

 could reduce purchases of 'junk food' and help combat obesity.
Primary Article Title: Why 'guilt-free' lanes at the supermarket could help fight obesity
Author: Cohen D.
Keywords: supermarkets obesity children behaviour "behaviour change" "reducing obesity"

Summary Sentence: People are more likely to say they will change their behaviour when confronted with the likely impact of their actions than the likely outcome.
Justification:
Study looked at how participants said they would respond when presented with different situations. Found that where participants focussed on impacts of actions (e.g. the potentially harmful impact of infecting a colleague with a cold) rather than outcomes

 (e.g. whether we will infect them if we go into work) caused them to be cautious. Researchers say it could have a role in how uncertainty and risk around infectious diseases are presented to the public.
Primary Article Title: Change health messaging to focus on potential impact to help stop the next pandemic
Author: Wigmore, G.
Keywords: "infectious disease" "public health" "public opinion" risk "behaviour change"

Summary Sentence: An app in the US is offering freelance workers a way to have work-place health and disability insurance.
Justification:
Freelance workers (such as cleaners, Uber drivers and Etsy artists) who are participating in the gig economy do not have access to standard work-place benefits. However, a new app has launched in the US where workers buy credits with each job they do to

 be able to buy different types of insurance (for example, health insurance). Article suggests this could be the future of insurance in the gig economy.
Primary Article Title: Apps that provide benefits might actually make the gig economy sustainable
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: "gig economy" "health insurance" workers Uber "freelance workers"

Summary Sentence: A study of social media use by people aged 14-17 in seven European countries found higher use of social media was linked to greater chance of being cyberbullied.
Justification:
A study looked at social media use by young people aged 14-17 in seven European countries. It found that use of social media for more than two hours a week was associated with a greater chance of being cyberbullied. There were also country differences

 with researchers finding a relatively high proportion of school children in Romania, Greece, Germany and Poland have been bullied online whereas a fewer proportion experience cyberbullying in the Netherlands, Iceland and Spain.
Primary Article Title: Longer hours on social media may increase teens' risk of cyberbullying
Author: Athanasiou, K. et al
Keywords: cyberbullying "social media" "young people" teenagers online

Summary Sentence: Emissions of CO2 and methane from wetlands and thawing permafrost as the climate warms could cut the “carbon budget” for the Paris Agreement temperature limits by around five years.
Justification:
Global methane emissions from natural wetlands and carbon release from permafrost thaw have a positive feedback on climate, yet are not represented in most state-of-the-art climate models. Furthermore, a fraction of the thawed permafrost carbon is released

 as methane, enhancing the combined feedback strength. This study focuses on two processes on the land surface&%2358; thawing permafrost and natural wetlands.These are both positive feedbacks for the climate because, as they respond to rising temperatures, they cause

 the release of more greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. Permafrost is the name given to soil that has been frozen for at least two years. It is predominantly found in the northern hemisphere – stretching across northern reaches of Russia, Canada and Alaska.

 These soils hold a huge amount of carbon, accumulated from dead plants and animals over thousands of years. The researchers used a “multi-layered soil carbon model” called JULES (Joint UK Land Environment Simulator), which has an improved representation of

 soil chemistry and the way that wetlands create methane. To estimate carbon budgets, the researchers use an “inverted” form of the model. This means, rather than plugging in pathways of future greenhouse gas emissions and seeing how global temperatures respond,

 the researchers input pathways of global temperature rise and use the model to estimate the corresponding levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The study looks at three scenarios of future global warming&%2358; holding temperature rise at 1.5°C and 2°C,

 and one where warming “overshoots” 1.5°C, reaches 1.75°C, then returns to 1.5°C. When the additional CO2 and methane emissions are incorporated, the available carbon budget shrinks substantially – falling to 533bn-753bn tonnes of CO2 for 1.5°C, or 14-20 years of emissions. The extra carbon released from thawing permafrost and warming wetlands would continue beyond the date of net-zero emissions and this would need to be countered for in order to consider carbon budgets applicable for 2100

 and beyond.
Primary Article Title: Carbon budgets for 1.5 and 2°C targets lowered by natural wetland and permafrost feedbacks
Author: Edward Comyn-Platt, Garry Hayman, Chris Huntingford, Sarah E. Chadburn, Eleanor J. Burke, Anna B. Harper, William J. Collins, Christopher P. Webber, Tom Powell, Peter M. Cox, Nicola Gedney & Stephen Sitch
Keywords: Climate Change Feedbacks, Carbon budgets, Mitigation

Summary Sentence: Because of short deadlines for reuniting migrant children and parents, DNA tests are being used instead of birth records.
Justification:
The US Human and Health services has been ordered to reunite migrant children and parents with a one month deadline. DNA tests are being used to speed the process of reuniting families, but there have been objections based on whether young children can

 give consent for their DNA to be collected and also questions about if the data will be stored after use.
Primary Article Title: US officials plan to use DNA tests to reunite migrant children with their families
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: immigration DNA "detention centre" "migrant children" "DNA test" "genetic testing"

Summary Sentence: Children born into certain neighbourhoods in Demark will be required to attend training in Danish values or their parents could have their welfare payments. stopped
Justification:
Children born into certain neighbourhoods in Demark (called 'ghettos' by local newspapers) will be required to attend training in Danish values or their parents could have their welfare payments stopped. These neighbourhoods are those with the highest

 non-Western immigrants. This new proposal is part of a the larger 'ghetto package' to encourage integration. Some have suggested that the education is indoctrination.
Primary Article Title: In Denmark, harsh new laws for immigrant `ghettos'
Author: Barry, E., Selsoe Sorensen, M.
Keywords: immigration education "immigrant children" Denmark integration education

Summary Sentence: Uganda has passed a law where citizens must pay 200 Ugandan shillings (roughly $0.05) per day to use social media platforms.
Justification:
Uganda has passed a law where citizens must pay 200 Ugandan shillings (roughly $0.05) per day to use social media platforms like Twitter, Facebook and WhatsApp. The Government says this is to cover the costs of dealing with 'gossip' from social media.

 Ugandan citizens have taken to social media to complain about the tax, saying it excludes poorer Ugandans from global conversations. Others have got round the tax by using Virtual Private Networks.
Primary Article Title: Uganda is now forcing citizens to pay a tax to use social media
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: "social media" tax Uganda Africa

Summary Sentence: A psychologist suggests that the sonic attacks of US embassy workers in Cuba and China may have been mass hysteria.
Justification:
Embassy workers in Cuba reported hearing strange noises before experiencing symptoms such as vertigo. There were suggestions that there had been a sonic attack. However, a psychologist has suggested that sonic attacks could not cause the symptoms found.

 Instead, it is possible that the workers were experiencing mass hysteria (or mass psychogenic illness).
Primary Article Title: Those 'sonic attack' victims are actually experiencing mass hysteria, expert claims
Author: Dockrill, P.
Keywords: "mass hysteria" crowd "psychogenic illness"

Summary Sentence: A replication of the 'marshmallow test' of children's delayed gratification found that children tested in the 2000s exhibit greater self-control than those tested in the 1960s of 1980s.
Justification:
A replication of the 'marshmallow test' of children's delayed gratification found that children tested in the 2000s exhibit greater self-control than those tested in the 1960s of 1980s. The children tested in the 2000s waited an average of two minutes

 longer than the children tested in the 1960s and an average of one minute longer than the children tested in the 1960s. However, a survey of adults found that they predicted children are getting less able to delay gratification as time goes by.
Primary Article Title: Children today are getting surprising results in this decades-old psychological test
Author: Dockrill, P.
Keywords: children "delayed gratification" skills self-control "child development"

Summary Sentence: A study on Skid Row in Los Angeles has found that an intervention by the health department to move 3,500 homeless people off the streets reduced costs to the county.
Justification:
A study followed an intervention called Housing for Health, run by the Los Angeles health department. The study tracked 900 people who were moved into housing after being homeless. It found that those in the programme had nearly 70 percent fewer visits

 to the emergency room in the year after they moved into supportive housing and spent 75 percent less time in the hospital. The intervention saved the county money in other 'safety-net' services.
Primary Article Title: Supportive housing reduces homelessness and lowers health care costs by millions
Author: Irving, D/
Keywords: homelessness homeless housing health "reducing homelessness"

Summary Sentence: A drug containing a marijuana compound has won US federal approval for treatment of childhood epilepsy.
Justification:
After evidence from clinical trials, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the US has approved the use of a drug containing a compound found in marijuana (CBD) for treatment of two rare forms of childhood epilepsy. Experts predict more drugs containing

 CBD will be approved soon. However, they warm that patients who many benefit from these drugs may access other forms of legal CBD which are cheaper and less regulated.
Primary Article Title: A drug derived from marijuana has become the first to win federal approval, and experts predict an avalanche effect
Author: Brodwin, E.
Keywords: marijuana drugs cannabis CBD epilepsy "medical marijuana" "medical cannabis"

Summary Sentence: Discussion article about the popularity of 'biohacking' in Sweden, where people are having microchips inserted in their bodies.
Justification:
Article discusses role of biohacking and the benefits of future digital technologies. Talks about transhumanists in Sweden who are choosing to be microchipped. Suggests that the popularity of this practice in Sweden is not due to Swedes being less worried

 about sharing personal information, but is due to a belief in digital technology.
Primary Article Title: Thousands of Swedes are inserting microchips into themselves - here's why
Author: Petersen, M.
Keywords: Sweden microchips technology biohacking

Summary Sentence: Study looking at worksite (school) healthcare services found it was cost-efficient and reduced teacher absenteeism non-significantly.
Justification:
A study in the US trialed five school-based healthcare clinics in a district of 120 schools. The worksite-based clinics were within 15 minutes drive of the school and were set up to provide provide primary care to teachers and their dependents. Healthcare

 costs dropped for those using the clinic and they had fewer inpatient/outpatient hospital admissions. Although absenteeism was lower in teachers who had access to worksite-based clinics, it was not significant.
Primary Article Title: Opening school-based health clinics can lower teacher health costs
Keywords: school education healthcare "school-based clinics" "healthcare intervention" absenteeism

Summary Sentence: Changes in land use will have a significant impact on future CO2 absorption from the atmosphere.
Justification:
This research summarises the results of five common climate models and looked at seven variables for 25 world regions to better understand the extent to which different changes in land use have an impact on CO2 storage in vegetation, and as a result on

 the concentration in the atmosphere. The scenarios differ, for example, in how much leaf area there is in relation to soil area, how much the relevant plants grow, and how long a plant grows before it dies and releases CO2 into the atmosphere. All the models

 were fed with the same assumptions to limit model-related uncertainties through the summary and detailed systematic analysis of the results. This makes the study more significant than previous investigations which were based only on individual models.increasing

 deforestation and other changes in land use will reduce the CO2 absorption capacity of these areas in the future. LULCC is projected to be a predominant driver of future C changes in regions like South America and the southern part of Africa. LULCC even cause

 some regional reversals of projected increased C sinks and greening, particularly at the edges of the Amazon and African rainforests.
Primary Article Title: Potential strong contribution of future anthropogenic land-use and land-cover change to the terrestrial carbon cycle
Author: Benjamin Quesada, Almut Arneth, Eddy Robertson, Nathalie de Noblet-Ducoudré
Keywords: Climate Change, Amazon, Carbon Cycle, Carbon Sinks

Summary Sentence: Environmentally persistent free radicals (EPFRs) could be partly responsible for some of the health problems, such as asthma, associated with particulate matter (PM) exposure.
Justification:
EPFRs are contaminants contained in PM2.5 (particulate matter less than 2.5 micrometres in size) and ultrafine particulate matter (under 100 nanometres) that form when by-products emitted from organic materials react with and form on the surface

 of particles of ‘transition metal’ oxides, such as copper or iron oxide. EPFRs survive for up to several months allowing them to be transported long distances, which increases the risk of human exposure. The study suggests that EPFRs could be responsible for

 some of the health effects, such as asthma and severe respiratory infections, currently associated with PM pollution more broadly. However, the researchers also advise treating the results of such health studies with caution. As yet, no research has made concrete,

 direct links between EPFRs and human health impacts. Studies conducted in Germany, Saudi Arabia and the US have provided figures of around 1016 to 1017 EPFRs per gram of atmospheric PM. Research suggests that EPFRs may also potentially

 form during incineration on some engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) with similar properties to metals — such as fullerenes (balls, 'cages' or tubes of carbon atoms), carbon nanotubes and nano-silica. More research is needed to understand this risk given that

 products containing ENMs on the consumer market continue to rise and that many of these will be incinerated and emitted into the atmosphere.
Primary Article Title: Environmentally persistent free radicals&%2358; insights on a new class of pollutants
Author: Eric P. Vejerano, Guiying Rao, Lavrent Khachatryan, Stephania A. Cormier, and Slawo Lomnicki
Keywords: Particulate Matter, Air Quality, Pollution, Health Effects

Summary Sentence: An Australian man with a payment chip in his hand had a conviction and fine overturned for using transport without a ticket.
Justification: A man in Australia embedded a chip from a transport card into his hand. He was convicted of travelling without a ticket and charged A$220. He appealed the conviction and it was overturned. He suggests that the law needs to catch up with new technology.
Primary Article Title: Biohacker who implanted transit chip in hand evades fine
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: biohacking transport microchips law

Summary Sentence: In the wake of detention of child migrants in the USA, there are warnings of the long-term psychological damage.
Justification:
Article reviews previous evidence that separating children from their parents causes psychological damage, including PTSD and adult addiction issues. It also notes that the strategy for dealing with child migrants mirrors domestic abuse patterns. Long-term

 effects of the experiences will not be fully known for some time.
Primary Article Title: Separating kids from parents at the border mirrors a 'textbook strategy' of domestic abuse, experts say and causes irreversible, lifelong damage
Author: Loria, K.
Keywords: immigration migration "migrant children" "child separation" PTSD "mental health"

Summary Sentence: First clinical guidelines for trans and gender diverse children and adolescents released in Australia.
Justification: In Australia, new guidelines had been released for medical practitioners for how to treat trans and gender diverse children and adolescents. Guidelines include condemning 'conversation therapies'.
Primary Article Title: Transgender kids get their own health-care guidelines
Author: Pace, C., Pang, K., Tollit, M.
Keywords: healthcare trans transgender "clinical guidelines" "healthcare guidelines" LGBT

Summary Sentence: Mindfulness is associated with decreased distress over social rejection.
Justification: Forty students took part in a game whilst in an fMRI. In the last third of game, the other players socially rejected the participant. Students' self-reported mindfulness was associated with reduced levels of distress relating to this social rejection.
Primary Article Title: Social rejection is painful and can lead to violence
Author: McNeill, B.
Keywords: mindfulness "social rejection" fMRI

Summary Sentence: Information passed between people generates inaccuracies and hysteria
Justification: A study of 154 people using social media found that information passed from person to person became increasingly more negative, and biased toward panic and fear and this effect was not mitigated when the original unbiased facts were reintroduced.
Primary Article Title: Bad news becomes hysteria in crowds, new research shows
Author: Jagiello, R., Hills, T.
Keywords: "fake news" hysteria crowds "bad news" fear

Summary Sentence: Innovations and automation and robotics are continuing to disrupt current working practices, bring both benefits and challenges to employees.
Justification:
Tech company Nvidia is developing a way to train robots to perform tasks by observing humans complete the same tasks. Initial applications are quite simple, such as picking up selected objects. However NVidia envisage there is significant potential for

 deploying this technology in manufacturing environments, and by extension, any other work environments. In China facial recognition software is being used in a school to monitor student’s faces to make sure that they are paying attention in class, and feeding

 the results back to the teacher. The system can identify a range of emotions - neutral, happy, sad, disappointed, angry, scared and surprised. A slightly different application could be in the workplace to identify stress and ensure that employee wellbeing

 is maintained.
Primary Article Title: Chinese school uses facial recognition to make kids pay attention
Author: England, R
Secondary_URLs: Nvidia is training robots to learn from watching humans - VentureBeat 20/05/2018
Keywords: automation robotic "artificial intelligence" AI workforce employee surveillance health wellbeing manufacturing Nvidia China school facial recognition emotion

Summary Sentence: A New York State apple orchard has become the first in the world to be pollinated via a drone.
Justification:
This development is significant in the context of technological change in farming and the notion of natural capital, as it suggests that some services currently provided by nature, such as pollinating insects, could be replaced by technology. Dropcopter,

 the company providing the service, used a hexacopter drone to spray pollen on about five acres of apple trees. It was part of an experiment to see if drone pollination could increase crop yields. The technology could become increasingly important over the

 next 25 years as bee populations continue to decline, in order to maintain food security and food supply.
Primary Article Title: Drone used to pollinate Central New York apple orchard
Author: Moriarty, R
Keywords: farming agriculture pollination insect wildlife "natural capital" crop yield drone "unmanned aerial vehicle" UAV apple "New York State" tree orchard regulation bee "colony collapse disorder" pesticide regulation

Summary Sentence: A 3D printed inflatable silicone material that can adjust its shape could find a use in creating adaptable environments.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may need to consider how a realisation of similar technologies could impact on waste management work, particularly around end of life vehicles. Car manufacturer BMW and MIT have partnered to develop the ’Liquid Printed Pneumatics’

 project. Through controlling airflow a system of 3D printed interjoining silicone chambers can transform their shape and stiffness into the desired shape. It is envisioned that such technology could be used to customised car interiors of the future, where

 with the advent of automation the function and arrangement of seats for example may need to change. Similar technology could also be used to transform the exterior of a car, for example moving from sports to estate car, depending in the need at that time.

 Changing the nature of materials used in car construction would also change the waste produced, reducing perhaps the quantities of hazardous substances.
Primary Article Title: BMW and MIT unveil the World's first printed inflatable material
Author: Nica, G
Keywords: manufacturing waste regulation transport car vehicle BMW MIT "3D printing" inflatable silicone "Liquid Printed Pneumatics" seating interior waste hazardous recycling

Summary Sentence: Filters inspired by jellyfish could provide a solution to the problem of microplastics.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may be interested in applying this filtration technology once it has moved beyond research and into realisation. Scientists are scouring the ocean for jellyfish that exhibit a ‘talent’ for collecting microplastics in

 their mucus. One particular species of interest is Periphylla periphylla (Crown Jellyfish). The long term aim is to develop a biofilter based on jellyfish mucus that could efficiently trap and remove microplastics from wastewater treatment plants. It is not

 clear if such a mucus would be produced synthetically or through a move towards jellyfish aquaculture. An increasing abundance or jellyfish attributed to climate change has led to other suggested uses for jellyfish products including paper (%2312542) and leather

 substitute (%2313545).
Primary Article Title: Researchers are hunting microplastic with jellyfish
Author: Benjaminsen, C
Keywords: pollution microplastic plastic pollutant ocean water quality aquaculture waste water treatment "wastewater treatment" jellyfish farming agriculture mucus "Periphylla periphylla" "Crown Jellyfish" biodiversity regulation research Norway marine

Summary Sentence: Opinion piece about the benefits of youth access to technology.
Justification: The founder of an institute to promote positive use of social media platforms writes about the possible benefits of young people having access to technology. She also presents guidance on how best to teach young people about using social media technology.
Primary Article Title: Here's what to do instead of banning kids and teens from social media
Keywords: technology "social media" "young people"

Summary Sentence: Research into the role of parks in increasing physical activity finds they are underutilised and may not increase moderate or vigorous physical activity.
Justification:
Research into the use of parks for physical activity finds that different groups use the parks to different extents with the majority of park activities geared towards young people. The use of parks for physical activity can be increased by marketing and

 on-site supervised activities.
Primary Article Title: How can neighborhood parks be used to increase physical activity?
Author: Cohen, D., Leuschner, K.
Keywords: "physical activity" parks "reducing obesity" community

Summary Sentence: In a survey of different generations, younger people showed less concern about national security threats than older generations.
Justification:
In a survey of Americans, differences in attitudes towards nation and financial security were found between three generations (Baby Boomers, Generation X and Millennials). Millenials showed less concern about national security threats (such as Islamic

 extremism and North Korea's nuclear capability) than the other generations. However, Millennials and Generation X showed more concern about financial security than Baby Boomers. The authors question if it is the age of the respondents or the generation they

 belong to which influences these attitudes. Future longitudinal research might be able to explain these differences.
Primary Article Title: Millennials worry less about national security than baby boomers do for now
Author: Martineau, M.
Keywords: "baby boomers" "generation x" millennials generations "financial security" "national security"

Summary Sentence: Many tree fungi communities in Europe have been found to be under stressed conditions due to pollution.
Justification:
The discovery has significant ramifications for future tree health as the mycorrhizal fungi in tree roots plays a crucial role in providing trees with essential nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium from the soil. The study examined 40,000

 roots from 13,000 soil samples at 137 forest sites in 20 European countries. The study identified thresholds of nutrient concentrations above which some mycorrhizal fungi are outcompeted by those that are more tolerant of pollution, such as species that can

 take advantage of the excess nitrogen from air pollution. Changes to the balance of fungal species from pollution could therefore impact on long term tree health. Further research is needed, but results so far could suggest that more stringent pollution levels

 are needed to prevent further tree damage.
Primary Article Title: Pollution hits the fungi that nourish European trees
Secondary_URLs: Environment and host as large-scale controls of ectomycorrhizal fungi - Nature 06/06/2018
Keywords: biodiversity tree health plant fungus fungal mycorrhizal fungi  nutrient phosphorus nitrogen potassium soil pollution pollutant air threshold

Summary Sentence: Consultation on the establishment of a new centre for data ethics and innovation
Justification: Blank - DFOS
Primary Article Title: Centre for data ethics and innovation consultation
Keywords: "data ethics", innovation, data, "artificial intelligence"

Summary Sentence: Carbon dioxide emissions could be transformed into high value carbon nanotubes using coatings on stainless steel surfaces.
Justification:
The high commercial value of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (cheapest carbon nanotubes on the market cost around $100-200 per kilogram) could be used as an incentive for regulated industrial sites to adopt similar technology, reducing emission impacts overall.

 The particular CNTs made by the researchers behind this discovery is that they have extremely small diameters, hence the high commercial value. The process uses electrochemistry to pull carbon dioxide (CO2) apart, before stitching the carbon back together

 as CNT with nanometer precision, on a coating on a stainless steel plate. The team envisage that similar technology could be made available at a domestic level to take CO2 out of the air and manufacture CNTs for the owner to then sell, representing a decentralisation

 of production.
Primary Article Title: "These could revolutionize the world" - Pint cracks code to cheap, small carbon nanotubes
Author: Hall, H
Secondary_URLs: Toward small-diameter carbon nanotubes synthesized from captured carbon dioxide&%2358; critical role of catalyst coarsening - Applied materials and interfaces 03/07/2018
Keywords: "air quality" "air pollution" emission regulation industry "greenhouse gas" GHG climate change decentralisation catalyst stainless steel "carbon nanotube" CNT economic value chemistry electrochemistry

Summary Sentence: Despite evidence that electromagnetic radiation could harm plants, insects, birds and other species, there is very little research underway to understand the impacts or to apply even basic pollution limits.
Justification:
A review of the impacts of electromagnetic radiation on wildlife was undertaken by EKLIPSE, an EU funded mechanism that considers policy relevant knowledge relating to human interactions with biodiversity and ecosystems. Pollution levels have been rapidly

 rising, and plans for saturating coverage of wi-fi and 5G will push levels higher still. The review found evidence that electromagnetic wireless signals, including from powerlines, radar, TV/radio broadcasting, Wi-Fi and 2G/3G/4G communications pose a credible

 threat to wildlife. While surprisingly few studies have been published, from the 97 useable papers the scientists highlighted electro-magnetic radiation as a potential risk to bird and insect orientation and movement, and to plant metabolic health. The review

 concluded an urgent need to strengthen the scientific basis of the knowledge on EMR and their potential impacts on wildlife. In particular, there is a need to base future research on sound, high-quality, replicable experiments so that credible, transparent

 and easily accessible evidence can inform society and policy-makers to make decisions and frame their policies.
Primary Article Title: The impacts of artificial electromagnetic radiation on wildlife (flora and fauna)
Author: MALKEMPER E. P., TSCHEULIN T., VANBERGEN A. J., VIAN A., BALIAN E., GOUDESEUNE L.
Keywords: Electromagnetic Radiation Pollution, Biodiversity

Summary Sentence: Two European countries are working towards nationwide free public transport.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in these initiatives in terms of the impact it has on reducing air quality issues in urban areas. Estonia has previously trialled free public transport in and around the capital city of Tallinn,

 following a referendum five years ago. In order to use the free transport, citizens need to register as a resident of Tallinn, from which the municipality benefits in €1000 tax per year. The scheme has proved so popular that the rest of Estonia has demanded

 the same free service. Germany is also to trial free public transport in five cities in order to try and address EU air pollution targets. The German government will subsidize the project with €128 million ($148 million) to help cover the income shortfall

 from cheaper tickets.
Primary Article Title: Estonia to become the World's first free public transport nation
Author: Schröter, R
Secondary_URLs: Five German cities to slash public transport fares to fight pollution - Handelsblatt Global 28/06/2018
Keywords: "air quality" air pollution transport "public transport" city urban health EU target pollutant regulation funding government Tallinn Estonia Germany

Summary Sentence: Seagrass–the aquatic plant that forms flowering undersea meadows–underpins the survival of the 25 most-fished species on our planet.
Justification:
The 72 known species of seagrass carpet coastlines across the planet, providing a safe nursery habitat and a source of food for baby fish. Now for the first time, through a global survey, the researchers have discovered that this habitat provides crucial

 support for 21.5% of the world’s largest 25 fisheries. Notably, the most-landed commercial fish globally–Walleye Pollock–relies on seagrass to support its young and other widely-consumed and commercially-valuable populations like Atlantic Cod and tiger prawns

 depend on seagrasses in the early stages of their life. The habitat has varying importance for fish across the planet, the researchers discovered&%2358; in the Indo-Pacific an estimated 746 species use seagrass habitats; in Australasia, 486; in the Caribbean 313

 species were found to be dependent on these underwater meadows to survive. In the Mediterranean alone, seagrass covers just 2% of the seafloor–and yet about 40% of fisheries landings in the region are made up of species that depend on these habitats for their

 survival. Threats to seagrass meadows include coastal development, pollution from runoff and damage by recreational boats and fishing trawlers that have already destroyed 7% of seagrass habitat globally. Another threat is climate change, which is warming coastal

 waters in many parts of the world and placing pressure on the growth of these undersea meadows.
Primary Article Title: Seagrass meadows support global fisheries production
Author: Richard K.F. Unsworth  Lina Mtwana Nordlund  Leanne C. Cullen‐Unsworth
Keywords: Fisheries, Biodiversity, Ecosystem Services, Climate Change

Summary Sentence: Virtual reality technology is becoming increasingly affordable and acceptable in the home and work environments.
Justification:
Microsoft has released a tool called Sharepoint Spaces, which allows users to easily create mix reality environments. Much like other Microsoft tools there are templates for creating 3D environments, 360 degree videos and models, which are viewed via headset

 or browser that supports WebVR. Facebook are releasing a new version of its VR headset, Oculus Go. A relatively low price point of around $200 could lead to greater adoption by users and experience developers alike, leading one commentator to see Oculus Go

 being as disruptive as the iPhone - and in fact is in direct competition with mobile devices for people’s attention. Disney are thinking about the VR experience beyond sight and sound, and are developing a haptic VR jacket that will give tactile feedback within

 a virtual environment, increasing the realism and immersible feeling that these technologies provide. The simplification of creating VR spaces could mean that the potential applications seen around training, interaction, visual exploration can be delivered

 at desk level. From a health safety and wellbeing perspective VR could help create 'safe spaces' and ‘escapes’ for a workforce, without the need for employees to leave their desk. There would also be less need for 'breakout areas' and meeting rooms if people

 could meet virtually.
Primary Article Title: Microsoft turns SharePoint into the simplest VR creation tool yet
Author: Hardawar, D
Secondary_URLs:
Disney's haptic VR jacket lets wearers feel the Force - New Atlas 30/04/2018

Facebook just created the iPhone of virtual reality - Quick Theories 22/05/2018
Keywords: technology It "virtual reality" VR workforce training Microsoft Sharepoint software visualisation wellbeing health safety model environment incident emergency office employee employer Facebook iPhone headset "Oculus Go" Disney haptic jacket

Summary Sentence: If nations meet their current emissions reduction targets under the Paris Agreement, the resulting warming will sharply curtail the environment suitable for roughly half the world’s species of insects.
Justification:
Researchers analysed the range maps of 115,000 species, including 71,000 species of plants, 31,000 insects, 8,000 birds, 1,700 mammals, 1,800 reptiles, and 1,000 amphibians and then calculated how those range maps might change in the future by outlining

 climatically suitable range for each species under different levels of warming, taking into account the ability of species to disperse to more favorable locations as the climate shifts. If countries meet their current pledges under the Paris Agreement and

 make no further emissions cuts, this is likely to lead to about 3.2 °C of warming (compared to pre-industrial temperatures) by the year 2100. Under 3.2 °C of warming, 49% of insects, 44% of plants, and 26% of vertebrate species would lose half their geographic

 range. If, instead, the nations of the world meet the overall goal of the Paris Agreement and hold warming to 2 °C then 18% of insects, 16% of plants, and 8% of vertebrate species will see their ranges shrink by half. Overall, insects are exposed to greater

 potential climatic range loss than any other animal group, and also benefit the most if warming is constrained to 1.5 °C rather than 2 °C. The half-degree difference between 2 °C and 1.5 °C of warming halves the risk to plants and vertebrates, and cuts the

 risk to insects by two-thirds. However, analysis is likely to underplay the risks to biodiversity, because it does not take into account how interactions between species could be disrupted by climate change, nor the effects of extreme weather events and fires

 that are projected to become more frequent and intense as the planet warms. In addition, a lot of scenarios for aggressive climate change mitigation call for bioenergy with carbon capture and storage, or BECCS, which involves growing trees or other biofuel

 crops in large plantations that could lead to agricultural intensification and natural landscapes being converted to biomass plantations causing biodiversity declines.
Primary Article Title: The projected effect on insects, vertebrates, and plants of limiting global warming to 1.5°C rather than 2°C
Author: R. Warren1,*, J. Price1, E. Graham2, N. Forstenhaeusler1, J. VanDerWal2
Keywords: Climate Change, Biodiversity, BECCS

Summary Sentence: The discovery of the new oxidative enzyme that catalyzes chemical reactions in Indian snakeroot and other plants could deliver faster routes to treatments for abnormal heart rhythms, high blood pressure and some mental disorders.
Justification:
Because of advances in bioinformatic and biological chemistry approaches, this study was able to identify the missing gene that encodes the oxidative enzyme among thousands of other genes from the plant. Indian snakeroot is one of the 50 fundamental herbs

 used in traditional Chinese medicine, which produces approximately 150 monoterpene indole alkaloids such as reserpine, yohimbine, and raubasine. One of the best-known alkaloids in snakeroot is ajmaline, a class Ia antiarrhythmic agent often used in diagnosis

 of patients suspected of having Brugada syndrome, a condition that causes disruption to the heart's normal rhythm. The study also found that the enzyme has an adaptable mechanism that could create a suite of structurally diverse chemical products, a sarpagan

 bridge (a key step in the biosynthesis of sarpagine- and ajmaline-type alkaloids). The sarpagan bridge enzyme bridges two carbon atoms, a reaction particularly challenging for synthetic organic chemists, and creating the complex three-dimensional structures

 found in the many class of alkaloids. It could provide the parts necessary for assembling and engineering of metabolic pathways in organisms such as yeast or tobacco plants for mass production of pharmaceutically important compounds. The researchers are currently

 collaborating with experts in synthetic biology and yeast engineering to develop this possibility.
Primary Article Title: Sarpagan bridge enzyme has substrate-controlled cyclization and aromatization modes
Author: Thu-Thuy T. Dang, Jakob Franke, Ines Soares Teto Carqueijeiro, Chloe Langley, Vincent Courdavault & Sarah E. O’Connor
Keywords: Plant-Made Pharmaceuticals, Synthetic Biology

Summary Sentence: Changing the approach to pesticides through adopting a ‘do not spray unless’ approach could lead to a 80 - 90 per cent reduction in use.
Justification: The Environment Agency and partners may be interested in the environmental benefits and reduced regulatory burdens of this approach. Researchers have been experimenting with the principles of Integrated Pest Management - so called IPM 2.0 - on potato crops, such as using resistant varieties, monitoring for naturally occurring genetic adaptations in the pathogen and a ‘do not spray unless’ strategy, where fungicides are are only applied when a resistant variety is at risk of infection due to pathogen adaptation. This led to an 80 - 90 per cent reduction of fungicide use with some species. Phytophthora infestans, the fungus-like causal organism of potato blight is a significant pest for potatoes, and therefore requires treatment. In the light of a possible link between fungicide use and bee decline, and the concept of antifungal drug resistance (%2314695), agricultural initiatives that reduce fungicide use may become a more prevalent farming practice in the future.
Primary Article Title: More sustainable potato production through extended IPM for late blight
Secondary_URLs: In bee decline, fungicides emerge as improbable villain - Cornell University 15/11/2017
Keywords: farming agriculture fungicide pesticide crop "potato blight" "Phytophthora infestans" anti fungicide resistance "Integrated Pest Management" IPM "IPM 2.0" regulation chemical pollution pollutant "water quality" plant crop disease

Summary Sentence: Poor indoor air quality may be having a range of negative impacts on workforce, ranging from poor decision making to loss if life.
Justification:
As part of a wider study on indoor air quality two conference rooms in an office complex were monitored for levels of CO2, PM2.5, VOCs, temperature and humidity. The study found that with three people working in a mid-sized conference room, CO2 reached decision

 impairing levels within 60 minutes, with cognitive performance dropping by 50 per cent. Another study of Shanghai office space (where urban air quality issues are more acute than in UK cities) found that in offices with healthy building standards implemented,

 alongside air quality monitoring equipment. Staff gained between 3.5 and 10.2 extra days of life expectancy over a full year. With air quality rising up the agenda and office conditions increasingly seen as an important factor in employer selection, similar

 measurements of indoor air quality may become a standard factor in workplace wellbeing. As a regulator of emissions the Environment Agency and partners may need to ensure they are on the front foot of these developments to ensure reputational resilience as

 well as to remain attractive to would be employees.
Primary Article Title: Offering longer life to employees
Secondary_URLs: Impaired decision making in conference rooms - LinkedIn 26/10/2016
Keywords: workforce employee employment office indoor "air quality" regulation PM2.5 CO2 TVOC temperature humidity Shanghai life expectancy "decision making" management leadership brain illness "cognitive function" monitoring

Summary Sentence: The scientific community is debating the existence of ‘obesogens’ - chemicals that can make people fat.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may have an interest in this as if a link is established there may be implications for manufacturing processes, waste management, water quality and biodiversity. There is some research to suggest that chemicals that build up in household

 dust could cause affect people’s hormones and lead to a buildup of fat in the body. However the existence, or indeed effects of these so called obesogens is debated, with some scientists believing that even if obesogens did exist, the levels critical for impact

 haven’t been established. People with obesity would most likely come into contact with chemicals through food packaging rather than household dust. Also, their impacts on weight would be relatively small compared to factors such as diet and exercise. Nevertheless,

 research from Harvard earlier this year suggest a link between perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) – widely used in products such as stain repellents and known to have a number of negative effects on human health – might lead to weight gain. The scientific community

 has previously shown concern for the lack of regulation around short-chain fluorinated chemicals such as PFAS, due to the impacts on human health in general not being well understood (%2313247). Should obesogens turn out to be a legitimate chemical group, regulation

 of waste, water treatment and environmental exposure may need establishing to prevent health impacts on humans and wildlife.
Primary Article Title: The truth about obesogens&%2358; can dust and chemicals make you fat?
Author: Davis, N
Keywords: chemicals health obesity obesogen diet household home dust PFAS perfluoroalkyl substances "short chain fluorinated chemical" regulation chemistry research waste "water quality" "water treatment"

Summary Sentence: A new catalyst that reduces the temperature and harmful by-products of splitting hydrogen from ammonia that could help to realise a hydrogen powered energy economy.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as an emissions regulator may have a future role in this sector as a hydrogen economy emerges. Ammonia is increasingly seen as a potential energy carrier for hydrogen (%2314772 ). Before the advent of renewable energy producing ammonia

 was relatively expensive and required fossil fuels. Splitting hydrogen out of ammonia produces nitrogen oxides, an air pollutant under conventional processes. The new catalyst, a crystal made from copper, silicon and other metals makes ammonia combust at lower

 temperatures and removes NOx gases as a byproduct, replacing this instead with di-nitrogen, a harmless form of nitrogen that forms the majority of our current atmosphere.
Primary Article Title: Cheap hydrogen fuel was a failed promise. But its time may have arrived
Secondary_URLs: Catalytic ammonia combustion properties and operando characterization of copper oxides supported on aluminum silicates and silicon oxides - Journal Of Catalysis 01/05/2018
Keywords: energy hydrogen chemistry ammonia catalyst metal copper oxide silicon temperature "nitrogen oxide" NOx di-nitrogen emission pollution "air quality" regulation

Summary Sentence: Varieties of wheat smuggled out of Syria could hold the answer to the crops future resilience in the face of environmental change.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may see similar strains becoming commonplace in the UK, altering the regimes of water, land and chemical use in the agricultural sector. The observed and forecast impacts of climate change on crop farming include higher temperatures,

 water resource shortages, and more problematic pests and diseases, all of which could threaten crop yields and undermine food security. Other older varieties not currently cultivated in the West that originate from the Middle East have been found to be more

 resistant to these challenges. For example, a wild relative of wheat, known as Aegilops tauschii, a common grass in Syria, was able to withstand Hessian fly infestation and common diseases such as barley yellow dwarf, mosaic virus and wheat rust. Other varieties

 that were smuggled from a Syrian seed bank include some that are resistant a virulent fungus, Fusarium head blight. As diversity in common wheat strains declines, interbreeding with other strains will become critical in ensuring wheat continues to be an important

 and resilient food crop. It should also be noted however that there are other exotic non-wheat grains and staples that also show signs of climate change resistance such as quinoa and teff (%2314267, %2312592), but these may require significant cultural changes

 to become accepted and produced at scale in the UK.
Primary Article Title: How seeds from war-torn Syria could help save American wheat
Author: Schapiro, M
Keywords: farming agriculture crop yield "food security" wheat strain Syria migration refugee seed resilience "climate change" "water resources" disease pest insect "hessian fly" "barley yellow dwarf" "mosaic virus" "wheat rust"  fungus "Fusarium head blight" "anti fungal resistance" quinoa teff grain staple behaviour "Aegilops tauschii" "Middle East" USA
GT: agriculture, food security, climate change, migration

Summary Sentence: A leading electronics manufacturer has released details of its first blockchain powered smartphone.
Justification:
HTC have announced that it is building a mobile phone called ‘Exodus’ that will be optimised for blockchain applications such as cryptocurrency wallets and decentralised app (DApp) experiences. They believe that their model will appeal to customers as

 the decentralised distributed ledger approach will allow customers to own their data and choose how to share it, something that is missing from the current centralised mobile phone market. This development is interesting for regulatory activity and workforce.

 The Environment Agency already utilises many mobile devices, and a decentralised approach may have advantages for cost savings and customer expectation. There may also be resilience in IT systems from taking a decentralised approach to data storage and retrieval,

 particularly during incident management situations. Mobile technologies have also led to an increased uptake of many platforms and applications, therefore making decentralised applications, the cornerstone of ‘Internet 3.0’ (%2314269), potentially more accessible

 to people than they are currently.
Primary Article Title: HTC announces it is building a blockchain-powered smartphone
Author: Miley, J
Keywords: mobile technology smartphone blockchain "distributed ledger" decentralisation "internet 3.0" "distributed app" DApp HTC Exodus data customer workforce employee cost operations regulation "incident management"

Summary Sentence: Slow release nutrients applied to sheets of graphene oxide could help to reduce fertiliser consumption.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should have an interest in this technology as reducing fertiliser consumption in agriculture could have positive impacts on water quality issues derived from nutrient run-off, such as eutrophication. Slow release fertilisers have

 the potential to reduce environmental impacts and save farmers money. Research found that applying micronutrients such as copper and zinc to graphene oxide sheets did just that, supplying nutrients in a more targeted fashion. It was also found that this process

 produced stronger fertiliser granules, which improved transport and spreadability.
Primary Article Title: Graphene promise for more efficient fertilisers
Secondary_URLs: Graphene oxide&%2358; a new carrier for slow releases of micronutrients - Applied materials and interfaces 21/11/2017
