Keywords: fertiliser farming nutrient micronutrient graphene "graphene oxide" agriculture farming costs "water quality" regulation eutrophication copper zinc transport pollution pollutant chemistry regulation

Summary Sentence: Tech entrepreneur Elon Musk has laid out his vision for an integrated transport system to get people from A to B anywhere on Earth in less than an hour.
Justification:
Musk proposes combining his Hyperloop high speed terrestrial transport concept with his SpaceX rockets. Passengers could be transported rapidly from urban centres to a launch pad / landing site Rockets would transport people in a similar point-to-point

 fashion as commercial aircraft, but would travel in through space at 27,000 km/h landing at a corresponding site at the destination, whereby another Hyperloop connection would take passengers to the city centre. As an indicator or travel time, New York to

 Shanghai, a distance of 11,897km (7,392 miles) would take 39 minutes. Boeing have also announced plans in introduce hypersonic flight within the next 20 to 30 years. There hypersonic aircraft could fly from London to New York in around two hours, making the

 prospect of Transatlantic day trips a reality - providing there is a customer base there prepared to pay the extra travel costs. Considering how current commercial air traffic has a small but increasingly significant impact on air quality, pollution and climate

 change through fuel emissions, there may be a need to consider what impacts a similar level of emissions in higher levels of the Earth’s atmosphere may bring. As a current regulator of air transport emissions the Environment Agency may have some role in this

 global mass transport future.
Primary Article Title: Elon Musk wants to combine Boring Company's Hyperloop with SpaceX's rockets to get anywhere on earth in less than an hour
Author: Lamber-May, F
Secondary_URLs: Flying from NYC to London in two hours is on the horizon, Boeing says - Washington Post 05/07/2018
Keywords: transport traffic aircraft plane rocket space "Elon Musk" Hyperloop "SpaceX" tunnel "Boring Company" urban city Earth atmosphere emission regulation "climate change" "air quality" pollution pollutant "New York" "Shanghai" rapid transit Boeing hypersonic London New York cost

Summary Sentence: Algae + Bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (ABECCS) consists of growing plants to remove CO2 from the atmosphere and then burning them to generate electricity, capturing the resultant carbon emissions and using some of that carbon to grow algae.
Justification:
This technology is still in development phase. The original system of BECCS (bioenergy with carbon capture and storage without growing algae) is controversial as it involves using land that could be farmed for food. However, ABECCS removes that controversy

 by providing another by-product - food. The process involves using some of the carbon dioxide (from the burning biomass part of the process) to grow algae. The algae can produce the same amount of food and biofuel as soy but using a much smaller area of land.

 There is some caution amongst experts that ABECCS is the answer to CO2 emissions and world food shortages as it has only been tested on a small scale and may not work on the scale required to reduce global warming.
Primary Article Title: The case for burning our way to a cleaner planet
Keywords: CCS "carbon capture and storage" biomass CO2 algae fuel food "food security" BECCS ABECCS "climate change" "global warming"

Summary Sentence: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have approved the use of a cannabidiol oral solution as a treatment for two rare and severe types of epilepsy.
Justification:
This is the first time that the FDA have approved a drug derived from marijuana however, the approved drug does not contain any of the compounds associated with euphoria or intoxication. The FDA state that they are committed to "advancing sound development

 programs that properly evaluate active ingredients". Following this development, the UK may come under increased pressure to provide similar approvals for drugs that are proven to have therapeutic effects. If such drugs were more consistently available, the

 Environment Agency would need to determine the effects on the environment and in particular, any potential water quality issues.
Primary Article Title: FDA approves first drug comprised of an active ingredient derived from marijuana to treat rare, severe forms of epilepsy
Keywords: cannabis marijuana drugs epilepsy medicine FDA "legalising drugs" "illegal drugs" "medical research"

Summary Sentence: Tracking indoor health quality has revealed that across the world, employees lives can be extended by employers providing better quality office environments - particularly in the area of air quality.
Justification:
As air quality issues rise up the political agenda, some companies have been tracking the air quality in their offices and estimating the number of days that this will increase the lives of their employees. The report concludes that offices should be seen

 as "active living systems" that can either benefit our lives or, be detrimental. In the future, this may result in companies being required to publish air quality results for their office spaces and may even influence which companies individuals choose to

 work for.
Primary Article Title: Offering Longer Life to Employees
Keywords: "air quality" offices workplaces staff health wellbeing "life expectancy" "health and safety"

Summary Sentence: As China continues to suffer severe water shortages, plans are in place to seed clouds with silver iodide creating snowfall over an area of Tibet three times the size of Spain.
Justification:
The system is being built from solid fuel burning chambers that emit silver iodide which, has a structure similar to ice. Once running, the system could produce an extra 10 billion cubic metres of rainfall per year. This will make it the world's biggest

 weather changing project and because it is relatively low tech, it will be cost effective to run. Furthermore, all the electrical components to the system will be solar powered. Creating such a large amount of rainfall over Tibet may bring its own problems

 relating to flooding and disease.
Primary Article Title: China Is Building a Rain-Making System Three Times as Big as Spain
Keywords: China weather rainfall rain snow clouds reseeding silver "silver iodide" agriculture food drought "food security"

Summary Sentence: Sensitive regions of the world are still at risk from the dangerous and potentially irreversible effects of climate change; even if the target of not increasing global temperature above 1.5°C over the next 100 years is met.
Justification:
Research that has developed a three-dimensional climate-carbon cycle model, and simulated the different climate futures, has suggested that regions of the world, such as the Arctic and South-East Asian monsoon region, could be damaged irreversibly as they

 are particularly sensitive to changes to global temperatures. The modelling evaluated two mitigation scenarios, with 200 gigatonnes of carbon and 307 gigatonnes of carbon post-2017 emissions respectively, quantifying the spatio-temporal variability of warming,

 precipitation, ocean acidification and marine productivity. Under rapid decarbonization decadal variability dominates the mean response in critical regions, with significant implications for decision-making, demanding impact methodologies that address non-linear

 spatio-temporal responses. Ignoring carbon-cycle feedback uncertainties (which can explain 47% of peak warming uncertainty) becomes unreasonable under strong mitigation conditions.
Primary Article Title: Climate-carbon cycle uncertainties and the Paris agreement
Author: P. B. Holden, N. R. Edwards, A. Ridgwell, R. D. Wilkinson, K. Fraedrich, F. Lunkeit, H. E. Pollitt, J.-F. Mercure, P. Salas, A. Lam, F. Knobloch, U. Chewpreecha & J. E. Viñuales
Keywords: Climate Change; Paris Agreement

Summary Sentence: Bumblebee colonies in urban areas not only produce more offspring than those on agricultural land, but have more food stores, fewer invasions from parasitic “cuckoo” bumblebees, and survive for longer.
Justification: While it is clear that urbanisation impacts species abundance and diversity, direct effects of urban land use on animal reproductive success are rarely documented. This study reared colonies from wild-caught bumblebee (Bombus terrestris) queens, placed them at sites characterized by varying degrees of urbanisation from inner city to rural farmland at 38 sites between central London and Basingstoke and monitored the production of sexual offspring across the entire colony cycle. Land-use cluster analysis identified three site categories, and this categorization was a strong predictor of colony performance. Crucially, colonies in the two clusters characterised by urban development produced more sexual offspring than those in the cluster dominated by agricultural land. These colonies also reached higher peak size, had more food stores, encountered fewer parasite invasions and survived for longer. It is likely many factors contribute to bumblebees are thriving in urban settings, but in particular cultivation of flowering plants throughout the year in villages and cities may help bumblebees, compared to fields where, if they are present at all, flowering periods are short-lived.
Primary Article Title: Lower bumblebee colony reproductive success in agricultural compared with urban environments
Publisher: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Author: Ash E. Samuelson, Richard J. Gill, Mark J. F. Brown, Ellouise Leadbeater
Keywords: Pollinators, Urban Ecology, Green Infrastructure

Summary Sentence: After many years of advocating ‘sustainable intensification’ there appears to be very limited evidence on the conditions that support positive social-ecological outcomes of agricultural intensification.
Justification:
A review of all existing studies that contain evidence of both well being and ecosystem service outcomes of agricultural intensification, found that of the 60 cases of agricultural intensification analysed, only 10 were classified as leading to ‘win-win

 outcomes’, defined by positive measures for both human well being and ecosystem services outcomes. In many cases, intensification led to negative outcomes for at least one of the ecosystem services that support sustained productivity over the long term. For

 example, agricultural intensification may help to increase average local incomes, through higher crop production, but at the cost of biodiversity loss. The analysis also revealed that, currently, scientific studies rarely measure the range of outcomes necessary

 to get a full picture of trade-offs and we therefore lack sufficient evidence for whether and how agricultural intensification can contribute to sustaining human well being and ecosystem services. For example, the study of well being was in most cases limited

 to measures of income, with barely any research that combines ecosystem service outcomes with other well being constituents such as livelihood security, education, health, or secure property rights. Only a few studies reported on the distributional equity

 of well being outcomes, but those that did found that the poorest often are disproportionately harmed by ecosystem service losses.
Primary Article Title: Social-ecological outcomes of agricultural intensification
Author: Laura Vang Rasmussen, Brendan Coolsaet, Adrian Martin, Ole Mertz, Unai Pascual, Esteve Corbera, Neil Dawson, Janet A. Fisher, Phil Franks & Casey M. Ryan
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification; Ecosystem Service Trade-offs

Summary Sentence: A global recession could be on the way, driven by political rather than economic forces.
Justification:
One commentator has described a possible scenario where in the next couple of years China triggers an economic slowdown for domestic political purposes. Current president Xi Jinping was recently able to remove the two term limit on the Chinese presidency.

 His previous election coincided with favourable economic conditions, partly delivered by his political influence. Jinping may wish to create similar conditions for the next election in 2023. The Communist party also celebrates its centenary in 2021, and the

 next People’s Congress in 2022. A positive economic position during this time would be favourable to the current government. In order to achieve growth without overheating, the government may choose to apply fiscal stimulus in 2020, but this would also mean

 intentionally slowing growth throughout 2018 and 2019. A Chinese economic slowdown could hit Germany hard, as China is a major market, which in turn could have ramifications for the European Union, with a suggestion that it could cause an economic devolution.

 Economic slowdown in China may also impact the US economy, though not to the same scale. While the author himself admits that this is a ‘black swan’ scenario, the economic and political implications might be felt throughout the sectors regulation and managed

 by the Environment Agency and partners, presenting challenges to maintaining standards in the face of a short term need for greater economic growth.
Primary Article Title: Is this how the next global recession begins?
Author: Moore II, J
Keywords: economics politics recession China Germany trade import export regulation USA fiscal "European Union" EU devolution "Xi Jinping" communist party government "black swan"

Summary Sentence: A wearable computer interface can transcribe the words a user verbalises internally but doesn’t actually speak.
Justification:
The device currently consists of a facial attachment that uses electrodes to detect neuromuscular signals in the jaw and face that are undetectable to the human eye. The machine learning system can translate changes in these as the use says words ‘in their

 head’. This technology presents a new way to interface with technology, particularly as voice activated devices are currently gaining in popularity. It may have applications for retrieving and conveying information in high noise environments, where discretion

 and secrecy is required, or where people may need assistance with communication.
Primary Article Title: Computer system transcribes words users "speak silently"
Author: Hardesty, L
Keywords: communication surveillance monitoring data information voice verbal nonverbal neuromuscular electrode accessibility secrecy wearable technology workforce noise incident emergnecy

Summary Sentence: Innovations in robotics are emerging in the home, agriculture and the space sector.
Justification:
It is possible to envisage these developments also impacting on many areas of the Environment Agency’s business, from monitoring and regulation, through to operating machinery in potentially hazardous conditions, and even office situations. Aeolus Robotics

 have developed one of the first multifunctional robots. Aeolus Robot is a child sized machine that performs domestic duties such as mopping, tidying objects off the floor, moving furniture, and retrieving drinks from the fridge using its grabbing arm — all

 without human assistance. The robot is also to remember faces and assign ownership of items to those faces. Amazon are also reportedly developing a domestic robot through a project called ‘Vesta’. Details are patchy, but the impact of a major retailer on energising

 adoption of this technology may mean robots are part of home and office sooner rather than later, particularly when considering the uptake of virtual assistant technology such as Alexa. FEDOR (Final Experimental Demonstration Object Research) is a human like

 robot destined to pilot a Russian spacecraft in the next few years. FEDOR will flying alongside human colleagues, performing duties that include piloting the spacecraft without human assistance. Another AI assistant called CIMON (Crew Interactive Mobile Companion)

 was recently sent to the International Space Station to assist astronauts through the steps outlined in a manual, show pictures of certain parts of the experiment and answer questions about it. Some companies are developing robotic applications for the farming

 sector. Swiss start up ecoRobotix has developed a herbicide spraying robot that can automatically identify weeds and apply one of two herbicides in a targeted fashion, reducing chemicals in the environment and saying the farmer money. UK based Goat Industries

 are developing a similar robot called ‘The Weedinator’ that will help grow crops, till and weed plant beds and patrol in place of a human farmer
Primary Article Title: This robotic maid takes us one step closer to `The Jetsons'
Author: Holley, P
Secondary_URLs:
ecoRobotix plans spot spraying robot for weed control - Future Farming 11/05/2018

SpaceX is flying an artificially intelligent robot named CIMON to the International Space Station - Washington Post 29/06/2018

The 'Weedinator' is an epic autonomous backyard project - Interesting Engineering 11/05/2018

Russia's robot FEDOR to be the first to fly to space on board new spacecraft - Space Daily 04/04/2018

Amazon has a top-secret plan to build home robots - Bloomberg 23/04/2018
Keywords: automation robot robotics domestic cleaning workforce human driver machine space FODOR Amazon Alexa Vesta Aeolus Russia spacecraft rocket transport incident operation plant fleet farming agriculture crop spraying herbicide weeding pollution pollutant regulation chemical "Goat Industries" Uk Swiss ecoRobotix employment unemployment employer employee CIMON "International Space Station"

Summary Sentence: Despite increasing levels of emissions, there is a lack of detailed studies on degradation, metabolisation, and bioaccumulation of the Gd complexes as  well as ecotoxicological or toxicological data obtained during long-term observation with low levels of chelates now present in aquatic environments.
Justification:
Since the 1980s, gadolinium (Gd)–based contrast agents (GBCAs) have been routinely used in magnetic resonance imaging as stable chelates of the Gd3+ ion, without toxic effects. Generally, GBCAs are considered some of the safest contrast agents.

 However, it has been observed that they can accumulate in patient tissue, bone, and probably brain (causing nephrogenic systemic fibrosis in patients with kidney failure or insufficiency and disturbance of calcium homeostasis in the organism). The GBCAs are

 predominantly removed renally without metabolization. Subsequently, they do not undergo degradation processes in wastewater-treatment plants and are emitted into the aquatic ecosystem. Their occurrence was confirmed in surface waters (up to 1100 ng/L), sediments

 (up to 90.5 microgrammes/g), and living organisms. Currently only hotspots with high levels of Gd can be marked as dangerous for aquatic environments according to environmental risk assessments without more data.
Primary Article Title: Gadolinium as a new emerging contaminant of aquatic environments
Author: Justyna Rogowska, Ewa Olkowska, Wojciech Ratajczyk, and Lidia Wolska
Keywords: Rare Earth Element, Persistent Toxic Metal

Summary Sentence: With perceived increasing security threats is space, navigation technologies that don’t have to rely on satellite networks may start to emerge.
Justification:
The Environment Agency are one of the multitude of organisations that rely on GPS for mapping, surveilling and navigation, and therefore may need to adopt alternative technologies to ensure resilience from attacks to the satellite network. Defence secretary

 Gavin Williamson recent launched a space defence strategy which included the threats posed by satellite jamming. The UK is also looking to invest in alternatives to the EU Galileo project. Whilst not an alternative satellite network, experiments with nanodiamonds

 suggest that they could be used in non satellite based navigation. Nanodiamonds exhibit ‘superradiance’ under certain conditions. In this condition nanodiamonds emit more or less light depending on their alignment with the Earth’s magnetic field. This behaviour

 could be used to develop positioning technology that functions independently of satellite networks.
Primary Article Title: Tiny diamonds light the way for new quantum technologies
Secondary_URLs: UK must counter 'threats' in space - Williamson - BBC 22/06/2018
Keywords: navigation defence satellite space "global positioning system" GPS Galileo EU nanotechnology nanodiamond superradiance magnetic field jamming cyber attack security incident emergency earth observation remote sensing surveillance monitoring

Summary Sentence: A newly identified prion disease may have been spreading through the African camel population for decades, according to new research.
Justification:
Camels are consumed for their meat and milk, and consequently camel farming has been growing as an industry. Tests have indicated that this disease may jump easily between species, making it markedly different to bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE aka

 mad cow disease). The discovery is significant as prion diseases are known to spread across species, meaning that human health could have been at risk for some time. However it is too early to tell if the disease has made the jump. As population migration

 and international trade become growing global features, the risks of zoonotic diseases impacting on humans increases (%2313451), making the impacts of the camel prion disease on human, farming and animal health increasingly likely without appropriate future

 regulation and monitoring.
Primary Article Title: Camels in Africa may have been quietly spreading prion disease for decades
Author: Mole, B
Secondary_URLs: Prion disease in dromedary camels, Algeria - Emerging Infectious Disease Journal 01/06/2018
Keywords: health illness disease prion neurological brain camel population migration zoonotic species incident farming food meat milk livestock agriculture animal human "bovine spongiform encephalopathy" BSE "mad cow disease" regulation Africa

Summary Sentence: Russia have launched a floating nuclear power plant.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may need to consider how growing examples of this innovation present both risks and opportunities in environmental protection. The Russian reactor is intended for use in supplying power to communities in hard to reach

 locations and also energy for desalination plants and oil rigs. This is not the first time that Russia has considered this technology (%239835, %232104), nor is it the first country - China has also been looking at similar technology (%2313819), whilst the USA was

 using floating reactors during the Vietnam War. The more recent examples may indicate that floating nuclear energy is gaining in significance. Floating infrastructure offers some resilience to coastal flooding events, and also allows for emergency power to

 be delivered to areas where terrestrial infrastructure has failed. There may be concerns about the impacts from pollution on the marine environment from a major incident involving floating nuclear, and perhaps different levels of risk involved in transporting

 and processing radioactive waste, all of which may impact on the the Environment Agency’s incident management and regulatory activities.
Primary Article Title: Russia launched a floating nuclear power plant this weekend
Author: Geuss, M
Secondary_URLs: Russia's floating nuclear power plant is not the first of its kind - Ars technica 30/04/2018
Keywords: regulation energy waste nuclear radioactive Russia China USA flooding coast sea infrastructure emergency power electricity pollution pollutant incident management desalination "water resources"

Summary Sentence: Self healing oxides could prevent corrosion and prevent leakage in pipeworks.
Justification:
Metals tend to oxidise when exposed to the air, resulting in rust or equivalent tarnishes, which can weaken metal. However it is also known that aluminum oxide, chromium oxide, and silicon dioxide can act as a brittle, though protective barrier. When applied

 and observed at the nanoscale, it was observed that aluminum oxide acts more like a liquid, flowing to repair any cracks appearing in the surface, effectively becoming a self healing layer. This could be a significant development for industrial processes,

 particularly those where transporting certain substances can weaken pipes, therefore preventing spillage or pollution incident. This use of nanotechnology may also be significant in moving towards a hydrogen economy, as the oxide nanolayer could help to prevent

 hydrogen or radioactive tritium (a heavy form of hydrogen that forms inside the cores of nuclear power plants) naturally passing through pipe walls.
Primary Article Title: Self-healing aluminum oxide protects against corrosion
Secondary_URLs: Liquid-like, self-healing aluminum oxide during deformation at room temperature - Nano Letters 28/02/2018
Keywords: regulation pollution energy hydrogen nuclear waste nanotechnology nanoparticle "aluminium oxide" corrosion "chromium oxide" "silicon dioxide" radioactive tritium coating incident pollutant emission

Summary Sentence: Two leading aluminium producers are developing a smelting technique that releases oxygen as a byproduct instead of carbon dioxide.
Justification:
Aluminum production uses large amounts of energy to separate aluminum from bauxite ore, producing oxygen as a byproduct which under normal circumstances binds with carbon to form carbon dioxide. In the new process developed by Alcoa and Rio Tinto the carbon

 anode used in heating bauxite has been replaced by a proprietary material, meaning that the oxygen doesn’t bond with the carbon, improving the climate change impacts of the sector’s emissions. The new company developing this technique is called Elysis. The

 process may suggest that the emissions from other industrial processes could be improved with similar applications.
Primary Article Title: Aluminum production could get much better for the environment
Author: Verger, R
Keywords: "air quality" air pollution emission aluminium regulation smelting bauxite energy cathode "carbon dioxide" oxygen "Rio Tinto" Alcoa Elysis "climate change" "greenhouse gas"

Summary Sentence: Food waste could be used as a partial replacement for petrochemical derived ingredients in car tyres.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may wish to consider how adoption of this innovation could impact on current waste regulations around tyre waste. Carbon black is used as a reinforcement and heat redirecting agent in conventional tyres, derived combusting fossil

 fuels, and can make up 30 per cent of a tyre’s composition. An alternative to carbon black has been manufactured from waste egg shells and tomato skins that has the same properties but without the fossil fuel impacts - it even means the resulting tyre is red-brown,

 rather than black.
Primary Article Title: Walk On Eggshells? Nah. But you may soon be driving on them, thanks to food waste tires
Author: Nosowitz, D
Keywords: waste food regulation tyre "carbon black" coal "fossil fuel" energy egg shell tomato

Summary Sentence: A newly developed water filtration system removes contaminants and reduces toxicity in hospital wastewater.
Justification:
Hospitals can be responsible for up to half of contaminant loads at wastewater treatment facilities. But removing them, can be difficult due to their diluted state, despite them still posing a potential biological threat. The new system is designed to

 be used at hospitals on site to pretreat water before it leaves site via the sewer system. It utilises chemical oxidation to destroy organic compounds in the water, namely via manganese oxide (MnOx) coated coir fibre filters. The filters proved very effective,

 removing 21 of 36 organic micro-pollutants by more than 94 percent after a 24-hour reaction period. Biologically active compounds were also removed below detection levels. The MnOx used in this process was derived as a waste biproduct of coal mine drainage,

 so effectively requires no virgin mineral use. Such a process may have applications beyond hospital wastewater into other sectors, and therefore may be of regulatory interest to the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: Sanitizing hospital sewage
Author: Matthews, J
Keywords: "water quality" wastewater treatment waste sewage sewerage hospital regulation chemical pollution pollutant medicine antibiotic pharmaceutical steroid "chemical oxidation" "manganese oxide" MnOx coir fibre filter coal mine mineral drain waste

Summary Sentence: Online exchange websites such as Craigslist and Freecycle can have a notable impact on household waste.
Justification:
A US based study found that whenever Craigslist entered a new geographical market it corresponded to a two to six per cent decrease in municipal waste in that market. Reuse behaviours that online exchanges generated could eliminate millions of tonnes of

 waste in landfills and save waste management costs, as well as reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and may have a role to play in fast growing urban areas in particular. A similar exchange catering to the business sector may deliver similar impacts.
Primary Article Title: Craigslist, other online exchanges, may be good for the environment
Author: Swayne, M
Keywords: waste management municipal waste household behaviour reuse website internet Craiglist Freecycle urban population city "greenhouse gas" "climate change" cost local authority

Summary Sentence: Future shortages in construction materials could be addressed through using brick and concrete alternatives made from soil.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as a regulator of the cement sector may be interested in the regulatory impacts of moving to a new construction material, which may also have implications for asset construction and management activities. Global population growth

 will increase the demand for more homes and buildings. Conventional materials such as cement, concrete and bricks require high energy levels to produce (which has climate change impacts), and the raw materials are not evenly distributed around the planet.

 One solution to this are geopolymer-stabilised soil materials (GSSM). These are manufactured in a relatively low energy process from soil, a material found almost everywhere on Earth. Soil from beneath the valuable topsoil is treated with chemicals similar

 to household cleaning products which dissolve and free the chains minerals in the clay content of the soil such aluminium, silicon, alkali metal. The resulting clay like material can be moulded and fired at around 100 degrees celsius. The process can be adjusted

 to account for varying soil content. GSSM would be a suitable replacement for concrete in low and mid rise housing, saving valuable concrete resources for more appropriate applications. It is hoped that alternatives to the household like chemicals involved

 in the process could also be extracted on a localised scale from source materials such as agricultural waste and plant ashes in a decentralised production model.
Primary Article Title: `Supermud' bricks could help tackle the world's housing crisis and cut carbon emissions that cause climate change
Author: Marsh, A & Reddy, V
Keywords: construction building concrete brick energy regulation population soil clay "geopolymer-stabilised soil material" GSSM agriculture ash farming asset flood defence cement

Summary Sentence: An academic is suggesting that the ban on using food waste as animal feed should be lifted to reduce the environmental footprint of the livestock industry.
Justification:
Food waste, aka swill was deemed to be responsible for the foot and mouth outbreak of 2001, and consequently this led to a European wide ban. However in recent years research has started to question whether the ban should continue in the light of the environmental

 pressures generated by growing crops such as soy specifically for animal feed, alongside price rises. In the same year as the UK swill ban Japan introduce a highly regulated swill regulations and procedures, and now around 40 per cent of their food waste is

 used as animal feed. There is huge potential for the UK and Europe should they chose to adapt the Japanese model, with evidence that UK farmers would be willing to use swill in replace for feed. Crucially the environmental impacts of using swill are less than

 using food waste for biogas or composting. Considering that food waste is used for energy generation through incineration and anaerobic digestion (AD) it is possible that a repeal of the swill ban could have implications for the Environment Agency’s regulatory

 role in all of these sectors.
Primary Article Title: Ban on food waste as animal feed should be reconsidered - here's why
Author: zu Ermgassen, E
Keywords: waste food farming livestock pig poultry installation swill "foot and mouth" Europe legislation Japan regulation incineration energy AD "anaerobic digestion" biogas compost crop soy

Summary Sentence: A smartphone based artificial intelligence (AI) development could give anyone the ability to diagnose plant disease simply by using the phone’s camera.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should consider how this and similar applications could deliver opportunities for our own monitoring programmes and also unlock the potential for better quality citizen science through lowering the barrier of expertise.

 Researchers trained an AI application to visually recognise soybean plant stresses using a catalogue of 25,000 photographs. The stresses included disease, nutrient deficiency and herbicide injury. The resulting programme was able to visually recognise stresses

 in images of new plants on a comparable level to human expert opinion. The system is currently only available to academics, but the researchers envisage that a version of their AI could be deployed on mobile devices, where it could be used by farmers, plant

 breeders and ordinary people to analyse and record plant stresses through digital image recognition, which may have particular relevance during an environmental incident similar to recent ash die back.
Primary Article Title: Diagnose crop disease with a smartphone
Secondary_URLs: An explainable deep machine vision framework for plant stress phenotyping - Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 16/04/2018
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" plant health "artificial intelligence" AI digital image disease stress herbicide nutrient farming farming crop plant "citizen science" smartphone app mobile regulation data soybean incident emergency ash biodiversity

Summary Sentence: A ship based reactor that converts plastic waste into fuel suggests a future direction for plastic waste management.
Justification:
The reactor uses pyrolosis, a processing heating without oxygen, to break down plastic into a hydrocarbon fuel. Previous versions of the reactor have been a lot bigger. The ship based version takes advantage of a process called "catalyzed pyrolosis" that

 utilises a metallocene catalyst deposited on a porous support structure that breaks down the plastic quickly. The effect is that the small ship based reactor can be fed a constant supply of plastic that can be converted to fuel and used on the ship. The reactor

 only works with certain types of plastics such as PET, which fortunately are more likely to float on the surface. However marine plastic wouldn’t be a viable fuel source due to the energy expended in hunting for feedstock, and other marine plastics sink, and

 therefore cannot be recovered in this way. However as a proof of concept it demonstrates how this and similar technologies (%2314048) could give plastic waste greater value in the context of a fossil fuel economy, particularly in the context of decentralisation.
Primary Article Title: Shipboard reactor could convert ocean-based plastic waste into diesel
Author: Irving, M
Keywords: waste plastic energy fuel ship  transport boat shipping pyrolosis "catalyzed pyrolosis" catalyst PET marine ocean pollution decentralisation regulation oxygen

Summary Sentence: Within US states, cities with more Democratic‐leaning voting preferences and large and rapidly growing populations tend to adopt more water conservation measures.
Justification:
Urban water supply systems in the United States are increasingly stressed as economic and population growth confront limited water resources. Demand management, through conservation and improved efficiency, has long been promoted as a practical alternative

 to building large scale energy‐intensive water‐supply infrastructure.This study examined city water policies over the course of four years to create a database of water conservation policies, the Vanderbilt Water Conservation Index (VWCI), for 195 cities in

 45 states in the contiguous United States. It also developed an associated index of the number of different categories of policies each city adopted and gathered data on the climate, water sources, population, economy, and political leanings of each city and

 its surrounding metropolitan statistical area—as reflected in the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections. Economic factors and climatic differences between cities do not correlate with the number of measures adopted, but they do correlate with the character

 of the measures, with arid cities favoring mandatory conservation actions and cities in states with lower real personal income favoring rebates for voluntary actions. The study suggests understanding relationships between environmental and societal factors

 and cities' support for water conservation measures can help planners and policy‐makers identify obstacles and opportunities to increase the role of conservation and efficiency in making urban water supply systems sustainable.
Primary Article Title: Urban water conservation policies in the United States
Author: Jonathan M. Gilligan,  Christopher A. Wold,  Scott C. Worland,  John J. Nay,  David J. Hess, George M. Hornberger
Keywords: Water demand management, policy frameworks

Summary Sentence:
The “Navion” computer chip is just 20 square millimeters and consumes just 24 milliwatts of power, or about 1 one-thousandth the energy required to power a lightbulb, but is able to process in real-time camera images at up to 171 frames per second, as

 well as inertial measurements, both of which it uses to determine where it is in space.
Justification:
The chip can be integrated into “nanodrones” as small as a fingernail, to help the vehicles navigate, particularly in remote or inaccessible places where global positioning satellite data is unavailable. It can also be run on any small robot or device

 that needs to navigate over long stretches of time on a limited power supply; for example, low-energy robotics, like flapping-wing vehicles the size of your fingernail, or lighter-than-air vehicles like weather balloons, that have to go for months on one battery,

 or medical devices like a little pill you swallow, that can navigate in an intelligent way on very little battery so it doesn’t overheat in the body. Palm sized drones could be used to fly around and snap pictures of your surroundings, like mosquito-sized

 photographers or surveyors, before landing back in your palm, where they can then be easily stored away. As small drones can only carry so much battery power, most of which is used to make its motors fly, previous designs have left very little energy for other

 essential operations, such as navigation, and, in particular, state estimation, or a robot’s ability to determine where it is in space
Primary Article Title: Navion&%2358; a fully integrated energy-efficient visual-inertial odometry accelerator for autonomous navigation of nano drones
Author: Amr Suleiman, Zhengdong Zhang, Luca Carlone, Sertac Karaman, Vivienne Sze
Keywords: Remote monitoring, drones

Summary Sentence: A new polymer that can be recycled back to its molecular state could become a replacement for plastics.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in the implications of this and similar products in the light of current interest in plastics in the environment and general future waste management. The polymer has many of the same characteristics

 as plastics, being lightweight, heat resistant, strong and durable. However unlike typical petroleum plastics, the new polymer can be broken down back to its original monomer for complete recycling without using solvents or toxic chemicals or intensive lab

 procedure at room temperature with minimal catalyst use. The polymer is still in the laboratory stage but there is investment to drive its commercial development.
Primary Article Title: `Infinitely' recyclable polymer shows practical properties of plastics
Author: Manning, A
Secondary_URLs: A synthetic polymer system with repeatable chemical recyclability - Science 27/04/2018
Keywords: waste plastic chemistry chemical industry polymer monomer toxic solvent catalyst recycling energy circular regulation

Summary Sentence: Industrial microbes could feed cattle, pigs and chicken with less damage to the environment
Justification:
This study estimated the economic and environmental potential of feeding microbial protein to pigs, cattle and chicken on a global scale. The researchers find that by replacing only 2 percent of livestock feed with protein-rich microbes, more than 5 percent

 of agricultural greenhouse gas emissions, global cropland area and global nitrogen losses could each be decreased. The study considered five different ways to breed microbes&%2358; By using natural gas or hydrogen, feed production could be completely decoupled from

 cultivating cropland. This landless production avoids any pollution due to agricultural production, but it also comes with a huge energy demand. Other processes that make use of photosynthesis by upgrading sugar, biogas or syngas from agricultural origin to

 high-value protein result in lower environmental benefits; some eventually even in an increase in nitrogen pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. Without changes to the system, the rising food and animal feed demand that comes with meat-based diets will lead

 to continuous deforestation, biodiversity loss, nutrient pollution, and climate-impacting emissions.
Primary Article Title: Decoupling livestock from land use through industrial feed production pathways
Author: Ilje Pikaar, Silvio Matassa, Benjamin L. Bodirsky, Isabelle Weindl, Florian Humpenöder, Korneel Rabaey, Nico Boon, Michele Bruschi, Zhiguo Yuan, Hannah van Zanten, Mario Herrero, Willy Verstraete, and Alexander Popp
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification, Livestock Feed

Summary Sentence: Researchers have developed a method by which hormones are eliminated from wastewater rapidly and with a high energy efficiency
Justification:
Hormones and other micropollutants may adversely affect health when residues enter the body via drinking water, but cost-effective solutions for their removal are lacking. This new membrane technology method combines the advantages of adsorption (binding)

 of micropollutants by an activated carbon adsorber with those of ultrafiltration of pollutant particles by a semi-permeable membrane. In the integrated system, the wastewater is first "pressed" through a polymer membrane in which the microorganisms and larger

 impurities are retained. Behind this membrane, a layer of special activated carbon is located, which originally was developed for air filters. Its surface has a high affinity to hormones, which means that carbon and hormone molecules readily form new compounds.

 Moreover, the activated carbon can be passed by large amounts of water and bind many molecules. The energy needed is far smaller than that of alternative methods, such as reverse osmosis. Laboratory experiments have shown that 60% of the hormone pollutants

 can be eliminated at a water volume of nine litres.
Primary Article Title: Removal of steroid micropollutants by polymer-based spherical activated carbon (PBSAC) assisted membrane filtration
Author: MatteoTagliavini, Andrea I.Schäfer
Keywords: Wastewater treatment, micropollutants, endocrine disruptors

Summary Sentence:
Results show that in the US racial identification became a significant predictor of climate change concern following Obama’s election in 2008, and that high levels of racial resentment are strongly correlated with reduced agreement with the scientific

 consensus on climate change.
Justification:
A new study examining attitudes to climate change during the Obama presidency found white Americans became significantly less concerned about climate change during the presidency, and that white racist attitudes could be helping to fuel climate denial.

 The study analysed nationally representative surveys conducted by Pew between 2006 and 2014 in which respondents were asked, among other questions, to rate the seriousness of climate change. After controlling for the expected effects of factors such as political

 partisanship, ideology, and education, the data showed that – compared to the views of respondents who identified as black Americans – white Americans became 18 percent less likely to see climate change as a very serious problem over the course of Obama's

 presidency. The study also atnalysed data collected by the American National Election Studies (ANES), which since the 1960s has asked voters questions measuring their levels of racial resentment toward African Americans, while more recently including questions

 about voters' views on climate change. The ANES data showed that as racial resentment increases among white Republican voters, they are significantly more likely to disagree that climate change is occurring, or that it's due to human activity. The results

 suggest racial attitudes and partisan identity are becoming more closely aligned and go hand-in-hand for an increasing number of issues, including environmental ones.
Primary Article Title: The spillover of race and racial attitudes into public opinion about climate change
Author: Salil D. Benegal
Keywords: Climate Change, Politics

Summary Sentence: Study looked at the how satisfied birth mothers were with decision to place child up for adoption based on a number of different criteria.
Justification:
Study looked at 223 birth mothers who had placed a child for adoption in the previous 25 years. Found that how satisfied a birth mother was with the decision varied&%2358; as age increased satisfaction decreased, as education and income increased satisfaction

 decreased. Full-time work and contact with the adopted child were both linked to increased satisfaction. 70% of birth mothers had contact with their child.
Primary Article Title: Are birth mothers satisfied with decisions to place children for adoption?
Author: Madden, E. et al
Keywords: adoption "birth mother" "biological mother"

Summary Sentence: Article reports on research that suggests you only need to a view needs to be shared by 25% of a group for the view to spread to the whole group.
Justification:
Reports on a study where 194 participants were put into online scenarios where they had to reach agreement with a group. Found that group agreement could be influenced when 25% of the group were researcher's 'confederates' who were put in to try to influence

 the group decision.
Primary Article Title: Want to change society's views? here's how many people you'll need on your side
Author: Lay, G., Cho, E.
Keywords: influence "tipping point" "group theory" group

Summary Sentence: Regardless of which treatment young people receive for anxiety, only 20% remain well over the subsequent four years.
Justification:
Study looked at 319 young people aged 10-25 who had a form of anxiety. Looked at those treated with medication, cognitive behavioral therapy or both. Follow ups carried on for four years afterwards. 20% remained well after treatment, 50% had at least one

 relapse and 30% were diagnosed as anxious at every follow-up throughout the four years.
Primary Article Title: For anxiety, a single intervention is not enough
Author: Ginsburg, G. et al
Keywords: anxiety treatment medication CBT "cognitive behavioural therapy"

Summary Sentence: Reports research on the effects of medical marijuana adverts on teenage marijuana attitudes and use.
Justification:
A study of 6,500 American teenagers in Southern California found that in 2010, 25% had seen marijuana adverts in the last three months but by 2017 that had risen to 70%. Also found that those who had seen adverts were more likely to have used marijuana

 in the previous 30 days, said they were more likely to use it in the future and expressed more positive attitudes about the drug.
Primary Article Title: Advertising and teens in the era of the 'blackout brownie'
Author: D'Amico, E.
Keywords: drugs marijuana cannabis advertisements adverts

Summary Sentence: Large survey of American citizens finds two correlates for belief in conspiracy theories&%2358; overestimating political understanding and feeling threatened by cultural change.
Justification:
Two large surveys of American citizens looked at factors influencing belief in conspiracy theories. Found that people were more likely to believe in conspiracy theories if they overestimate their political understanding and/or felt threatened by social

 and cultural changes.
Primary Article Title: These are the kinds of people who are more likely to believe in political conspiracies
Author: Cassella, C.
Keywords: "conspiracy theory" politics belief media

Summary Sentence: Moringa oleifera seed proteins have been used to create a simple, effective, and sustainable water purification device that could be used in for developing nations.
Justification: Moringa oleifera, commonly referred to as the drumstick tree, is a fast-growing, drought-resistant tree, native to the southern foothills of the Himalayas in northwestern India, and widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical areas where its young seed pods and leaves are used as vegetables. It has been traditionally used for water purification, but as this approach leaves significant amounts of nutrients it becomes contaminated again within 24 hours. This study concerns the adsorption of Moringa oleifera seed proteins to silica surfaces to create a cheap and effective water filtration medium, termed "f-sand". One of the major reasons M. oleifera is cultivated currently is for the fatty acids and oils found in the seeds, which are extracted and sold commercially. However, the study showed the presence or absence of fatty acids in the seeds has little effect on the creation or function of f-sand, so people in the region can remove and sell the commercially valuable oil, and still be able to extract the proteins from the remaining seeds for water filtration. The study also showed shown that the f-sand manufacturing process displays a high degree of flexibility and is able to work at a range of water conditions and protein concentrations.
Primary Article Title: Moringa oleifera seed protein adsorption to silica&%2358; effects of water hardness, fractionation, and fatty acid extraction
Author: Brittany A. Nordmark, Toni M. Bechtel, John K. Riley, Darrell Velegol, Stephanie B. Velegol, Todd M. Przybycien, and Robert D. Tilton
Keywords: Water purification, access to clean water

Summary Sentence: Scientists have created a genetic computer model of trees that could allow them to engineer trees for specific purposes in engineering and manufacturing.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may be interested on the impacts that engineering timber in this way could have on regulated sectors such as paper and pulp, but also construction and waste. A team at North Carolina State University have spent ten years

 examining the impacts of lignin content in wood through manipulating 21 different genes. This time consuming process can now be done via a computer model over a very short space of time. Lignin gives wood strength and therefore is desirable in some application

 such as construction, but has to be removed for applications such as paper manufacturing, using energy and chemicals in the process. Knowing how to tailor lignin levels could help to reduce the environmental impacts of manufacturing wood based products and

 help to open the doors to commercialisation of other existing technologies that are inhibited from realisation due to costs, such as wood based plastics, biodiesel, biochemicals and high strength building materials. Realisation of this also relies on the legislative

 ability to cultivate genetically modified trees, the planting of which may also have long term implications for the environment, including natural capital.
Primary Article Title: Smart wood&%2358; bioengineering trees for specific purposes
Author: Hanley, S
Secondary_URLs: Improving wood properties for wood utilization through multi-omics integration in lignin biosynthesis - Nature 20/06/2018
Keywords: regulation wood genetic engineering GM forestry lignin timber paper pulp plastic manufacturing regulation chemistry chemical biochemical energy fuel biofuel biodiesel construction building waste computer model research "natural capital" habitat economics

Summary Sentence: Autopsy data has been found to shown signs of air pollution leading to the premature onset of Alzheimer’s, even in children and babies.
Justification:
Dementia is a significant challenge for health services as well as air quality being of increasing interest to the Environment Agency and partners. A study of 203 autopsies of people aged between 11 months and 40 years in Mexico City focussed on the presence

 of two proteins strongly connected to Alzheimer’s&%2358; hyperphosphorylated tau and beta amyloid. Beta amyloid in particular is closely associated with Alzheimer’s in older people. When compared to healthy people with similar socioeconomic statuses and lifestyles

 the researchers found that the levels of hyperphosphorylated tau and beta amyloid in the autopsies were higher than the norm in 99.5 per cent of the cases, including that of the 11 month old child. The study also found that elevated levels of these proteins

 are related to exposure to fine particulate matter, notably PM2.5. The results of this study should be treated with caution due to the small sample size, however if a link is established between air pollution and the early onset of dementia like symptoms it

 may increase further pressure for stronger action and regulation on air quality.
Primary Article Title: Babies in Mexico City show signs of Alzheimer's. Blame air pollution
Author: Basu, T
Secondary_URLs: Hallmarks of Alzheimer disease are evolving relentlessly in Metropolitan Mexico City infants, children and young adults. APOE4 carriers have higher suicide risk and higher odds of reaching NFT stage V at ≤?40 years of age - Environmental Research 01/07/2018
Keywords: "air quality" "air pollution" pollution health children babies dementia Alzheimer's "particulate matter" PM2.5 protein "hyperphosphorylated tau" "beta amyloid" "Mexico City" autopsy regulation

Summary Sentence: UK band Massive Attack’s album ‘Mezzanine’ has been stored in digitally readable format in DNA, preserved inside tiny glass nanospheres.
Justification:
DNA storage has many advantages over conventional digital storage in that it does not require energy to store information, physical storage space is significantly smaller and DNA storage in theory should last forever, unlike other mediums. Mutliple copies

 can also be made easily The album was first compressed into Opus format. The zeros and ones were then represented in specially constructed DNA strands using the four building blocks of DNA&%2358; A, C, G and T. The 920,000 DNA strands will be poured into 5,000 tiny

 (nanometre-sized) glass spheres, which will then be stored in a phial of water. The Massive Attack album is reportedly one of the largest files ever stored in DNA, joining other recent examples of this technology in practice (%2313922, %2313897), including the

 potential to transfer computer viruses from DNA during sequencing experiments (%2314402). Moving to a DNA based data storage could have implications for waste management (WEEE) as conventional digital storage mediums become obsolete.
Primary Article Title: Entire music album to be stored on DNA
Author: Bergamin, F
Keywords: data storage DNA digital server nanotechnology nanosphere glass water "Massive Attack" Mezzanine cyber cost energy waste electronics regulation WEEE

Summary Sentence: In contrast to previous natural invasions where species migrated to new regions themselves, humans principally introduce modern invaders, repeatedly, and in large quantities, and in ways that can help free them from their usual enemies and competitors.
Justification:
Introduced species threaten native biodiversity, but whether exotic species can competitively displace native species remains contested. Building on theory that predicts multi-species coexistence based on a competition-colonisation tradeoff, this study

 derived a mechanistic basis by which human-mediated species invasions could cause extinctions through competitive displacement. In contrast to past invasions, humans principally introduce modern invaders, repeatedly and in large quantities, and in ways that

 can facilitate release from enemies and competitors. Associated increases in exotic species’ propagule rain, survival and competitive ability could enable some introduced species to overcome the tradeoffs that constrain all other species. Using evidence from

 metacommunity models, the research suggests how species introductions could disrupt species coexistence, generating extinction debts, especially when combined with other forms of anthropogenic environmental change. Even though competing species have typically

 coexisted following past biogeographic migrations, the multiplicity and interactive impacts of today’s threats could change some exotic species into agents of extinction.
Primary Article Title: Introduced species that overcome life history tradeoffs can cause native extinctions
Author: Jane A. Catford, Michael Bode & David Tilman
Keywords: Invasive non-native species; biosecurity

Summary Sentence: Tests to understand how the enzyme in a plastic eating bacteria work have inadvertently made it better.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may wish to consider how a commercialisation of such a process could impact on the regulation of waste management. A plastic eating bacteria was discovered in 2016. Further studies to understand the enzymes at work in

 this process led to the accidental improvement in the PET (polyethylene terephthalate) destroying substance. PET is often used for plastic bottle manufacture. It is hoped that the enzyme can be used to turn PET back to its constituent chemicals, which could

 then be recycled, reducing the need to manufacture virgin plastics.
Primary Article Title: Scientists accidentally create mutant enzyme that eats plastic bottles
Author: Carrington, D
Keywords: waste plastic recycling biology chemistry biochemistry bacteria microbe enzyme PET "polyethylene terephthalate" regulation

Summary Sentence: Antarctic fungal strains isolated from terrestrial and marine sediments were able to produce secondary metabolites with antimicrobial activity against X. citri subsp. citri, highlighting the importance of these microbial genetic resources.
Justification: A research team at the São Paulo State University's Bioscience Institute (IB-UNESP) in Rio Claro, Brazil, has identified 29 fungi with proven action against Xanthomonas citri, a bacterium responsible for citrus canker, an endemic disease in all citrus-producing countries. This study obtained secondary metabolites extracts from filamentous fungi isolated from soil and marine sediments from Antarctica and assessed their potential antibacterial activity on Xanthomonas citri subsp. citri. Researchers isolated 33 filamentous fungi from samples collected in soil under rotten wood on Deception Island and 53 filamentous fungi from marine sediments at a depth of 20 meters in Admiralty Bay, King George Island.The researchers found that 29 of the 86 Antarctic fungi they isolated (19 of marine origin and ten terrestrial) contained compounds with proven action against X. citri. Isolates that produced active metabolites against the phytopathogen were identified using molecular taxonomy (ITS‐rRNA sequencing) as&%2358; Pseudogymnoascus, Penicillium, Cadophora, Paraconiothyrium and Toxicocladosporium. The main method for currently combating citrus canker consists of spraying trees with copper compounds. The downside is that when even small amounts are used for a long period, copper accumulates in the fruit, soil and water, eventually contaminating the entire environment.
Primary Article Title: Terrestrial and marine Antarctic fungi extracts active against Xanthomonas citri subsp. citri
Author: G. Vieira  J. Purić  L.G. Morão  J.A. dos Santos  F.J. Inforsato  L.D. Sette  H. Ferreira D.C. Sass
Keywords: Bioprospecting, plant protection products, Antarctic microbes

Summary Sentence: Rice, a staple food for more than half of the world population, is an important target for iron and zinc biofortification.
Justification:
Nearly 1.6 billion people in the world are affected by anemia, to which iron deficiency anemia contributes significantly and zinc deficiency is also reported to affect one-third of the world’s population. Iron deficiency can lead to, among other things,

 anemia and zinc deficiency to a compromised immune system. Rice biofortification is therefore a sustainable approach to improving the health of the affected populations globally. Most of the commercially-bred rice varieties contain only around two μg/g iron

 in the endosperm. This explains why micronutrient deficiencies are common in countries where rice provides a major share of the daily calories. This study genetically modified one of the most commonly grown varieties of rice. The advantage over the original

 variety is that these plants are better at mobilising their cellular stores of zinc and iron and depositing in the white part of the rice grain (known as endosperm). This means that the micronutrients are transported and concentrate there. The ETH researchers

 are the first to explore this aspect of cellular transport mechanisms of iron and zinc to enrich rice with micronutrients. To achieve this enrichment, Bhullar and her team incorporated a genetic construct expressing a combination of three additional genes

 into the rice plants. One of these genes facilitates mobilisation of iron stored in the plant vacuoles, another encodes for an iron-storing protein Ferritin, and the third promotes efficient iron and zinc uptake by the roots. As recommended by the Consultative

 Group on International Agricultural Research (CGIAR), 15 μg/g dry weight (DW) iron and 28 μg/g DW zinc in polished grains are required to provide 30% of the dietary estimated average requirement (EAR). The GM rice lines have iron increases equaling more than

 90% of the recommended iron content and up to 170% of the recommended content for zinc in rice grains. These plants have so far been tested in the lab and greenhouse conditions, and it remains to be tested whether they perform similarly under field conditions.
Primary Article Title: Targeting intracellular transport combined with efficient uptake and storage significantly increases grain iron and zinc levels in rice
Author: Ting‐Ying Wu  Wilhelm Gruissem  Navreet K. Bhullar
Keywords: Biofortification, Transgenic, Rice

Summary Sentence: There are up to 100‐fold differences in environmental impacts between specific animal sourced food products and, in some cases, for the same product, depending on the production method being used.
Justification:
This study is based on nearly a decade of analysis, in which the co-authors reviewed hundreds of published life-cycle assessments for various types of animal protein production. Of the more than 300 such assessments that exist for animal food production,

 the authors selected 148 that were comprehensive and not considered too "boutique," or specialized, to inform their new study. As decisions are made about how food production expands through agricultural policies, trade agreements and environmental regulations,

 the study highlights a "pressing need" for systematic comparisons of environmental costs across animal food types. the study uses four metrics as a way to compare environmental impacts across the many different types of animal food production, including farm-raised

 seafood (called aquaculture), livestock farming and seafood caught in the wild. The four measures are&%2358; energy use, greenhouse gas emissions, potential to contribute excess nutrients—such as fertiliser—to the environment, and the potential to emit substances

 that contribute to acid rain.environmental impacts across food types by using a standard amount of 40 grams of protein, the daily recommended protein serving. Industrial beef production and farmed catfish were found to have the highest environmental impacts,

 while small, wild-caught fish and farmed molluscs like oysters, mussels and scallops have the lowest.
Primary Article Title: The environmental cost of animal source foods
Publisher: Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment
Author: Ray Hilborn,  Jeannette Banobi,  Stephen J Hall,  Teresa Pucylowski,  Timothy E Walsworth
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification, Metrics

Summary Sentence: Future research should explore integrating data on soil quality, climate, land use, economic effects, and farmer decisions to develop strategies for sustainable land use.
Justification:
Agriculture faces increasing demands for food, feed, fibre, and fuel from a growing population under the looming threat of climate change. Advances in seed technologies, equipment, and crop management offer considerable promise for increasing agricultural

 productivity and meeting these demands. But a key challenge for agriculture is to meet growing demands while protecting our natural resources. Sustainable agricultural development will call for systems approaches to allocate land among competing uses, coupled

 with the adoption of conservation technologies incentivised by cost-effective policies that have been based on evidence from sound economic, behavioral, biological, and technological research. This paper suggests directions for future research in nine key

 dimensions that can fill important gaps in the existing literature and build on new research methods and policy needs, as well as inform strategies for sustainable growth of agriculture. However, strategies to use natural resources more sustainably while meeting

 growing societal demands for food and fuel production won't be win-win opportunities for everybody. The costs of adopting alternative technologies and their environmental benefits will vary across locations and this calls for site-specific approaches, rather

 than a one-size-fits-all solution.
Primary Article Title: Sustaining our natural resources in the face of increasing societal demands on agriculture&%2358; directions for future research
Author: Madhu Khanna,  Scott M Swinton,  Kent D Messer
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification, Precision Agriculture

Summary Sentence: In a business-as-usual scenario, predicted changes in environmental exposures would lead to reductions in yields of nonstaple vegetables and legumes.
Justification:
Environmental changes, including climate change, air pollution, and water scarcity and salinization, threaten global agricultural production, food security, and health. There is evidence that environmental change will reduce the yields of starchy staple

 crops, but impacts on (nonstaple) vegetables and legumes—important constituents of healthy diets—remain largely unknown. This study systematically reviewed the available published evidence from experimental studies on the impact of environmental changes on

 yields and nutritional quality of (nonstaple) vegetables and legumes and found that environmental change would have a negative impact on yields without suitable responses from the agricultural sector. It reviewed studies published between 1975 and 2016 on

 the effects of ambient temperature, tropospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), and ozone (O3) concentrations, water availability, and salinization on yields and nutritional quality of vegetables and legumes. It estimated mean effects of standardized environmental

 changes using observed exposure-response relationships and conducted meta-analyses where possible. It identified 174 relevant papers reporting 1,540 experiments. The mean (95% CI) reported yield changes for all vegetables and legumes combined were +22.0% (+11.6%

 to +32.5%) for a 250-ppm increase in CO2 concentration, −8.9% (−15.6% to −2.2%) for a 25% increase in O3 concentration,−34.7% (−44.6% to −24.9%) for a 50% reduction in water availability, and −2.3% (−3.7% to −0.9%) for a 25% increase in salinity. In papers

 with baseline temperatures >20 °C, a 4 °C increase in temperature reduced mean yields by −31.5% (−41.4% to −21.5%). Where adaptation possibilities are limited, environmental changes may substantially reduce the global availability, affordability, and consumption

 of vegetables in the mid to long term.
Primary Article Title: Effect of environmental changes on vegetable and legume yields and nutritional quality
Publisher: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author: Pauline F. D. Scheelbeek, Frances A. Bird, Hanna L. Tuomisto, Rosemary Green, Francesca B. Harris, Edward J. M. Joy, Zaid Chalabi, Elizabeth Allen, Andy Haines, and Alan D. Dangour
Keywords: Climate Change, Agricultural Yield, Horticulture, Food security, Public Health

Summary Sentence: Water samples from UK rivers contain significantly higher concentrations of microplastics downstream from wastewater treatment plants.
Justification:
Microplastics are pieces of plastic with a diameter less than five millimetres. They come from a wide range of materials including tiny plastic beads found in health and beauty products, plastic fibres from clothing and plastic flakes that break down from

 packaging. This study measured microplastics (MPs) up- and downstream of six wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) in different catchments with varying characteristics and found that all led to an increase in MPs in rivers. Nevertheless, the data collected indicated

 that there were other important sources of MPs in the catchments studied and that these may include atmospheric deposition, agricultural land to which sewage sludge has been applied, and diffuse release of secondary MPs following the breakdown of larger plastic

 items. MPs were comprised mainly of fibres, fragments, and flakes with pellets and beads only dominating at one site. Variation in MP pollution occurred over time and this difference was greater at some sites than others. Microplastics are one of the least

 studied groups of contaminants in river systems. Finding key entry points of microplastics, such as wastewater treatment plants, can provide focus points to combating their distribution.
Primary Article Title: Wastewater treatment plants as a source of microplastics in river catchments
Author: Paul Kay, Robert Hiscoe, Isobel Moberley, Luke Bajic, Niamh McKenna
Keywords: Microplastic pollution, contamination sources

Summary Sentence: Measurements as well as model calculations equally show that the oxygen inventory of the oceans is decreasing, but models underestimate this decrease significantly making projections into the future problematic.
Justification:
The oceans are losing oxygen. Numerous studies at local, regional and global level confirm this trend. For example, a comprehensive data analysis published by Kiel oceanographers at the beginning of 2017 has shown that the oceans have lost two percent

 of their oxygen content worldwide in the past 50 years, but this is underestimated by models making future projections problematic. This study shows deficiencies of the models and also identifies drivers of deoxygenation that have been underestimated so far.

 Global warming is the main cause of marine oxygen loss, it affects the ocean in several ways including the solubility of oxygen in the water. The warmer the water, the less gas it can take up, which can explain up to 20 percent of the deoxygenation so far,

 and is well represented in the models. Warming also changes patterns of global ocean circulation and, since the complex system of surface and deep currents supplies oxygen to the deeper ocean, can affect the oxygen content throughout the ocean, but are difficult

 to represent in models. The extremely complicated interactions between biological, chemical and physical processes in the ocean are also insufficiently represented in current models. To resolve these knowledge gaps, more comprehensive observations will be

 required.
Primary Article Title: Drivers and mechanisms of ocean deoxygenation
Author: Andreas Oschlies, Peter Brandt, Lothar Stramma & Sunke Schmidtko
Keywords: Ocean deoxygenation; climate change

Summary Sentence: Computer gaming has been used to reward people for good environmental behaviour in the real world.
Justification:
Gamefication is one way that the Environment Agency and partners could harness volunteer activism and citizen science to enhance current activities. In commemoration of Earth Day the makers of Pokemon Go augmented reality (AR) game offered users a change

 from hunting virtual monsters and instead gave them the opportunity to participate in trash clearing events. If critical numbers of players participated in the real world events they were allowed access to in game rewards, which increased as more people participated.

 Gamefication of augmented reality applications such as Pokemon Go have previously been considered as potentially powerful for environmental monitoring (%2314085), helping the public to visualise environmental information (%2314059) and encouraging people to participate

 in incident related activities such as distributing bottled water or sandbag filling (%2314201), so it is interesting to see Pokemon’s Earth Day game as a realisation of this potential for environmental good coming from computer gaming in this way.
Primary Article Title: Pokémon Go will reward players for picking up trash on Earth Day
Author: Webster, A
Keywords: "incident management" incident "augmented reality" computer game gameification "Pokemon Go" "Earth Day" AR smartphone activism "citizen science" volunteer communication monitoring waste rubbish trash emergency data app
GT: incident management, gamefication, communication, behaviour change

Summary Sentence: Applications of nanotechnology to water treatment could help to remove and destroy contaminants in water, including microplastics.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may be interested to consider the applications in water treatment as a non chemically based treatment solution to improve water quality. A new ‘mat’ membrane made of titanium dioxide nanoparticles embedded into polymer

 fibres reacts in the presence of ultraviolet (UV) light. Titanium oxide becomes photcatalytic in UV light, releasing reactive oxygen species (ROS) that break down contaminants, but current processes are inefficient as the oxygen can’t be targeted to a substance

 of interest and expensive as the photocatalyst has to be separated from sewage at the end of treatment. Embedding titanium dioxide (TiO2) in a highly-porous sheet of spun polyvinyl fibres in water resulted in the destruction of endocrine disrupting chemicals

 (EDCs) in water whilst being able to retain the photocatalyst separately to the sewage. The process uses less energy than current practices and destroys more pollutants. Another promising innovation in water treatment filter made of nanoscale wires coated

 in a semiconductor that also uses sunlight to breakdown microplastic pollutants. Sunlight hits the filter, leading to electron exchange with the plastic, splitting it into CO2 and water, thus speeding up the natural decomposition of plastics in the environment.
Primary Article Title: Mat baits, hooks and destroys pollutants in water
Secondary_URLs:
Porous electrospun fibers embedding TiO2 for adsorption and photocatalytic degradation of water pollutants - Environmental Science and Technology 19/03/2018

EU testing way to use Sun to break up plastics in wastewater - KTH Royal Institute Of Technology 07/11/2017
Keywords: "water treatment" "water quality" pollution pollutant nanotechnology regulation filtration nanoparticle polymer fiber fibre decomposition nanowire photocatalyst semiconductor "titanium dioxide" TiO2 "endocrine disrupting chemical" EDC sunlight ultraviolet sewage UV oxygen "reactive oxygen species" ROS waste microplastic plastic

Summary Sentence: Adding carbon fibre to pervious concrete could make it more durable.
Justification:
This innovation should be of interest to the Environment Agency from the perspective of surface water flooding and urban runoff. There is also a potential waste issue in using carbon fibre in construction materials as it may hamper recycling at end of

 life. There may also be questions around the impact that carbon fibre could have on water quality and the surrounding environment during use. Pervious concrete is highly porous and permeable, and therefore well suited as a building material to mitigate the

 impacts of stormwater runoff. It can also help to reduce pollution by otherwise preventing water flowing along the surface picking up pollutants. However its porosity means that it is not as durable as non-pervious concrete. Researchers found that by grinding

 up scrap carbon fibre (obtained from aircraft manufacturer Boeing) and adding it to the concrete mix that it greatly increased the strength of the pervious concrete. The source of the carbon fibre in this experiment could suggest that there may be waste management

 issues around implementing use of this concrete on a large scale. Also, one source of carbon fibre could be from end of life wind turbine blades (%2314631, %2312371).
Primary Article Title: Researchers use recycled carbon fiber to improve permeable pavement
Author: Hilding, T
Secondary_URLs: Enhancing mechanical properties of pervious concrete using carbon fiber composite reinforcement - Journal Of Materials In Civil Engineering 01/03/2018
Keywords: flooding construction building asset concrete "carbon fibre" "carbon fiber" stormwater urban surface water runoff run-off pollution "water quality" pollutant waste turbine Boeing wind energy pervious porous permeable regulation incident emergency

Summary Sentence: The standards underpinning the humble barcode are about to change, offering a new degree of functionality.
Justification:
GS1 (the standards body that manages the barcode and other product coding standards) has commenced an update programme which will essentially allow anything with a barcode to have its own web address, known as ‘GS1 URI’ . Both Apple IOS and Google Android
