 smartphone operating systems have recently been given barcode reading functionality. This is mainly viewed as an opportunity for customer engagement and also an opportunity for companies and retail systems do gain data and insight on customer behaviour. Examples

 of application include scanning a QR code or a barcode on a newly purchased product to activate the warranty, paying for products directly via smartphone scanning, or accessing multimedia about a product’s sustainability. It is however possible to see other

 applications, for example in tracking shipments in that the range of functionality associated with a website could be brought to bear on a single item such as a food product or waste shipment. It is these applications that therefore may be of interest to the

 Environment Agency and partners, particularly in a waste management context. There may also be applications around asset manangement tracking.
Primary Article Title: Op-ed&%2358; why the barcode will soon become the World's largest consumer engagement platform
Author: Murphy, N
Keywords: data product logisitics transport shipment barcode "QR code" smartphone farming customer engagement Apple IOS Google Android website internet waste food communication

Summary Sentence:
Environmental and host factors explain most of the variation in ectomycorrhizal diversity, that the environmental thresholds used as major ecosystem assessment tools need adjustment and that the importance of belowground specificity and plasticity has

 previously been underappreciated
Justification:
To get nutrients from the soil, trees host fungi, known as mycorrhizal fungi, in their roots. These fungi receive carbon from the tree in exchange for essential nutrients, like nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium, which they gather from the soil. Some of

 these fungi are known above-ground from the mushrooms and truffles they form. A study of 13,000 soil samples across 20 European countries has revealed that many tree fungi communities are stressed by pollution, indicating that current pollution limits may

 not be strict enough. Recent studies have noted signs of tree malnutrition across Europe, such as discoloured leaves or leaves lost from the crown, but the mechanisms underpinning these symptoms are unclear, but this study suggests that tree characteristics

 and local air and soil quality have a large impact on mycorrhizae. The team found that the characteristics of the tree (species and nutrient status) and the local environmental conditions (atmospheric pollution and soil variables) were the most important predictors

 of which species of mycorrhizal fungi would be present and their abundances. The new study discovered 'thresholds' for phosphorus and nitrogen —concentrations above which the community of mycorrhizae changes. Some mycorrhizal fungi are outcompeted by those

 that are more tolerant of pollution, such as species that can take advantage of the excess nitrogen from air pollution, which may be more 'parasitic' mycorrhizae&%2358; those that take carbon but give little back in the way of nutrients.
Primary Article Title: Pollution hits the fungi that nourish European trees
Author: Sietse van der Linde, Laura M. Suz, C. David L. Orme, Filipa Cox, Henning Andreae, Endla Asi, Bonnie Atkinson, Sue Benham, Christopher Carroll, Nathalie Cools, Bruno De Vos, Hans-Peter Dietrich, Johannes Eichhorn, Joachim Gehrmann, Tine Grebenc, Hyun S. G
Keywords: Soil Quality, Air Quality, Tree Health

Summary Sentence: Nutrient pollution could make reefs more vulnerable to global changes associated with ocean acidification and accelerate the predicted shift from net accretion to net erosion
Justification:
Coral reefs provide critical ecosystem services including food security and shoreline protection to coastal communities. These services largely depend on the highly complex three-dimensional structure of coral reefs. For coral reefs to thrive, calcifying

 organisms, such as corals, must build the reef faster than bioeroding organisms and natural dissolution break the reef down. However, little is known about how the two stressors of nutrient pollution and acidification interact and influence coral reef ecosystem

 functioning. In nutrient polluted seawater, calcifiers were shown to be less able to capitalize on the dissolved compounds that make up the building blocks of coral reefs. Nutrient pollution reduced calcification rates—a measure of how quickly reef builders

 are creating the skeletal framework—nearly tenfold in waters that would otherwise promote reef growth, and enhanced both skeletal dissolution and the growth of seaweed competitors. This laboratory based research suggests the nutrients change the local pH environment

 by compromising how corals and other reef organisms breathe, which influences the chemistry of the reef and can make the whole system more susceptible to global threats such as ocean acidification.
Primary Article Title: Nutrient pollution disrupts key ecosystem functions on coral reefs
Publisher: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Author: Nyssa J. Silbiger, Craig E. Nelson, Kristina Remple, Jessica K. Sevilla, Zachary A. Quinlan, Hollie M. Putnam, Michael D. Fox, Megan J. Donahue
Keywords: Ocean acidification, nutrification, coral reefs

Summary Sentence: A study has demonstrated the successful incorporation of materials obtained directly from raw biomass deconstruction in the development of nanostructured pressure sensitive adhesives for use in tapes.
Justification:
When pulp and paper manufacturers process wood, the lignin is a waste product that is usually discarded in landfills or burned for heat and presents an opportunity for upcycling. Lignin shares some structural and materials property similarities with petroleum-derived

 polymers, such as polystyrene and polymethyl methacrylate, which are commonly used in adhesives and other consumer products, from packaging materials to cups. Using a commercially available catalyst material, the researchers developed a mild, low-temperature

 depolymerisation process to create monomers from lignin. This was followed by followed by minimal purification steps (filtration and extraction) to produce two aromatic compounds, 4-propylsyringol and 4-propylguaiacol, with high purity and yield. Efficient

 functionalization of those aromatic compounds with either acrylate or methacrylate groups generated monomers that could be easily polymerized by a scalable reversible addition–fragmentation chain-transfer (RAFT) process to yield polymeric materials with high

 glass transition temperatures and robust thermal stabilities, especially relative to other potentially biobased alternatives. These lignin-derived compounds were used as a major component in low-dispersity triblock polymers composed of 4-propylsyringyl acrylate

 and n-butyl acrylate (also can be biobased). The resulting PSAs exhibited excellent adhesion to stainless steel without the addition of any tackifier or plasticizer. The 180° peel forces were up to 4 N cm–1, and tack forces were up to 2.5 N cm–1, competitive

 with commercial Fisherbrand labeling tape and Scotch Magic tape, demonstrating the practical significance of the biomass-derived materials.
Primary Article Title: From tree to tape&%2358; direct synthesis of pressure sensitive adhesives from depolymerized raw lignocellulosic biomass
Author: Shu Wang, Li Shuai, Basudeb Saha, Dionisios G. Vlachos, and Thomas H. Epps
Keywords: Renewable Resources, Biopolymers

Summary Sentence: Stockton, a city in California, is testing universal basic income as a means of improving the lives of its residents.
Justification: A town in California is planning a two-year basic income trial where 100 families will receive $500 a month with no conditions or restrictions. It would be the first American city to test basic income.
Primary Article Title: Free cash to fight income inequality? California city is first in US to try
Author: Goodman, P.
Keywords: "universal basic income" "basic income" jobs employment unemployment

Summary Sentence: Several major economies rely heavily on fossil fuel production and exports, yet current low-carbon technology diffusion, energy efficiency and climate policy may be substantially reducing global demand for fossil fuels.
Justification:
A sharp slump in the value of fossil fuels would cause the 'carbon bubble' to burst resulting in stranded fossil fuel assets (SFFA), and this study posits that such a slump is likely before 2035 based on current patterns of energy use. The analysis suggests

 that part of the SFFA would occur as a result of an already ongoing technological trajectory, irrespective of whether or not new climate policies are adopted; the loss would be amplified if new climate policies to reach the 2 °C target of the Paris Agreement

 are adopted and/or if low-cost producers (some OPEC countries) maintain their level of production (‘sell out’) despite declining demand. The magnitude of the loss from SFFA may amount to a discounted global wealth loss of US$1–4 trillion; and there are clear

 distributional impacts, with winners (for example, net importers such as China or the EU) and losers (for example, Russia, the United States or Canada, which could see their fossil fuel industries nearly shut down).
Primary Article Title: Macroeconomic impact of stranded fossil fuel assets
Author: J.-F. Mercure, H. Pollitt, J. E. Viñuales, N. R. Edwards, P. B. Holden, U. Chewpreecha, P. Salas, I. Sognnaes, A. Lam & F. Knobloch
Keywords: Carbon Bubble, Renewable Energy

Summary Sentence: Accurate accounting of changes in freshwater availability is essential for predicting regional food supplies, human and ecosystem health, energy generation and social unrest.
Justification:
This comprehensive study, the first of its kind, took data from the NASA Grace (Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment) satellite mission to track trends in freshwater from 2002 to 2016 across the globe. It quantified 34 trends in terrestrial water storage

 and categorised their drivers as natural interannual variability, unsustainable groundwater consumption, climate change or combinations thereof. The trends showed a very distinctive pattern of the wet land areas of the world getting wetter, in the high latitudes

 and the tropics, and the dry areas in between getting drier. Areas in northern and eastern India, the Middle East, California and Australia are among the hotspots where overuse of water resources has caused a serious decline in the availability of freshwater

 that is already causing problems. Some of these hotspots were previously undocumented or poorly understood&%2358; a region in north-western China, in Xinjiang province, has suffered dramatic declines despite receiving normal amounts of rainfall, owing to groundwater

 depletion from industry and irrigation. This observation-based assessment of how the world’s water landscape is responding to human impacts and climate variations provides a blueprint for evaluating and predicting emerging threats to water and food security.
Primary Article Title: Emerging trends in global freshwater availability
Author: M. Rodell, J. S. Famiglietti, D. N. Wiese, J. T. Reager, H. K. Beaudoing, F. W. Landerer & M.-H. Lo
Keywords: Freshwater accounting, resource depletion, food security

Summary Sentence: An application of plastic nanoparticles could help to realise methane hydrate as a suitable energy storage medium.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may be interested in how this development could alter how natural gas is stored. Methane hydrate, also known as fire ice, is a solid formed from mixing methane gas with water molecules under certain conditions. It forms naturally

 on the sea bed. However artificially creating hydrate provides an efficient means of storing methane, but until now the formation process has been problematic due to a loss of surfactants (e.g. sodium dodecyl sulphate – SDS), metal nanoparticles (e.g. nano-Ag)

 or porous materials (e.g. activated carbon). Researchers have instead grafted SDS (-SO3–) and nano-Ag particles onto polystyrene nanospheres . As such the surfactants can exist in the liquid phase more stably and contact with the water and gas molecules more

 efficiently, making hydrate formation more efficient and avoiding foaming.
Primary Article Title: Natural gas hydrates with significant industrial feasibility for natural gas storage and transportation
Author: Wang, F
Secondary_URLs: Grafting of nano-Ag particles on -SO3--coated nanopolymers for promoting methane hydrate formation - Journal Of Materials Chemistry A 01/06/2018
