Summary Sentence: A school in China is using facial recognition technology to monitor pupils in class.
Justification:
A school in China is using facial recognition technology to monitor pupils in class. The technology can recognise the expressions of emotion and also tell when children are talking or distracted. It has previously been used to monitor exams but now is

 being used to check whether children are engaged in class.
Primary Article Title: Not paying attention in class? China's 'smart eye' will snitch on you
Author: Houser, K.
Keywords: technology "facial recognition" education classroom "artificial intelligence"

Summary Sentence: A survey looking at perceptions by the American public found that 52% could not give an answer to what they thought of when they heard 'scientific research'.
Justification:
Reports on a 2015 survey looking at perceptions by the American public. When asked what the first thing they thought of when they heard 'scientific research' 52% could not give an answer. 13% mentioned health or medical research, 5% mentioned drugs/cures/treatments

 and 4% mentioned laboratories or white coats. 52% also could not give an answer for 'scientific discoveries and advances'.
Primary Article Title: When it comes to scientific research, most Americans don't know what to think
Author: Cassella, C.
Keywords: "public opinion" science research

Summary Sentence: Participants were asked to decide whether to let five mice be electrocuted or press a button to electrocute one mouse in a trolley-style moral dilemma.
Justification:
Participants were asked to decide whether to let five mice be electrocuted or press a button to electrocute one mouse in a trolley-style moral dilemma (no electrocution actually occurred). Participants preferred to intervene 84% of the time and press the

 button. This compares to 66% of the time when asked in a though experiment.
Primary Article Title: Of mice, men, and trolleys&%2358; Hypothetical judgment versus real-life behavior in trolley-style moral dilemmas
Author: Bostyn, D., Sevenhant, S., Roets, A.
Keywords: philosophy "moral dilemma" "trolley problem"

Summary Sentence: People show the same tendency to identify correct grammar in opinions they agree with as they do with facts
Justification:
Reports on a study of 88 people who were asked to judge whether statements were grammatically correct. They were quicker at identifying correct grammar in statements that they agreed with. This phenomenon has previously been seen with people identifying

 correct grammar more quickly in facts than untrue statements.
Primary Article Title: Humans process opinions we agree with as if they were facts, study shows
Author: Cassella, C.
Keywords: facts humans processing understanding opinions bias

Summary Sentence: Finnish Government will not continue funding on a basic income trial
Justification:
The Finnish Government has been funding their social security agency to carry out a trial where 2,000 unemployed people were given a set amount of income each month without any requirements to seek employment. The trial has been going on for two years

 and the Finnish Government will not be funding the trial any further. Instead, the Government has introduced legislation which requires unemployed people to seek employment or training in order to receive benefits.
Primary Article Title: Finland to end basic income trial after two years&%2358; government rejects request for funds to expand scheme and plans stricter benefits rules
Author: Henley, J.
Keywords: "universal basic income" "basic income" jobs employment unemployment

Summary Sentence: Employee surveillance using technology measuring brainwaves.
Justification:
Companies in China are using technology that measures brainwaves to monitor workers. The article talks about the potential benefits, such as being able to intervene if a worker falls asleep in a dangerous environment. It also explores some of the criticisms,

 such as the current unregulated status of this technology.
Primary Article Title: Forget the Facebook leak&%2358; China is mining data directly from workers' brains on an industrial scale
Author: Chen, S.
Keywords: "worker's rights" "future workplace" jobs employment "future technology"

Summary Sentence: Analysis of the problems that deep learning can solve in specific use cases within organisations.
Justification: Blank - DFOS
Primary Article Title: Notes from the AI frontier&%2358; insights from hundreds of use cases
Author: Chui, M., Manyika, J., Miremadi, M., Henke, N., Chung, R., Nel, P., Malhotra, S.
Keywords: 'artificial intelligence'

Summary Sentence: Generative adversarial networks (GANs) are a new type of AI that are capable of creating highly realistic false images and video. On the other hand, GANs can also be used to detect false images and video.
Justification: Blank - DFOS
Primary Article Title: The hottest trend in AI is perfect for creating fake media
Keywords: 'fake news' 'artificial intelligence' 'neural networks'

Summary Sentence: A data register study was performed in order to identify the amounts of hazardous substances in products related to motorized transport in Norway during 2012.
Justification:
A road is not only a road. It also consists of bridges, tunnels and technical installations, that must be built, drilled and blasted, cemented, paved, painted and maintained. The dich vegetation should be maintained, the tunnels must be swept and washed

 several times during a year, the vehicles need fuel, oil and brake fluid, and treatment with car care products. The use of chemicals is involved at all levels, either directly or as an additive in various materials and equipment. Information regarding hazardous

 substances in 52 selected product categories associated with traffic-related activities was obtained from the Norwegian Product Register administrated by the Norwegian Environment Agency. Substances present on ECHA list of substances of very high concern (SVHC),

 NEA national priority list, and priority substances under the EU Water Framework Directive (WFD) were given most attention, with substances from ECHA community rolling action plan (CoRAP) also included. Results showed that selected products contained a diverse

 range of substances that were classified as hazardous to either human or environmental health. The quantities of hazardous substances in the selected products were 120 tons (SVHC), 280 tons (Norway priority list), and 2,400 tons (WFD). The Norwegian Public

 Roads Administration have made a list of hazardous substances of which more than 1 ton is in annual use in Norway. The ten most important compounds were methyl-tert-butylether (MTBE), benzene, tetrachloroethylene, hydrazine, medium chain paraffins, tetraborates,

 nonylphenols, the siloxane D5, and orange lead.
Primary Article Title: Roads and motorized transport as major sources of priority substances? A data register study
Author: Merete Grung, Hedda Vikan, Turid Hertel-Aas, Sondre Meland, Kevin V. Thomas & Sissel Ranneklev
Keywords: Persistent Pollutants; Priority Substances; Road Transport

Summary Sentence: Unmanned aerial vehicles offer the opportunity for precision agriculture to efficiently monitor agricultural land.
Justification:
Previously, drones have required an expensive multispectral camera to scan agricultural land and indicate where there is a need for additional irrigation or application of fertiliser to selected crop segments. This study demonstrates that newly-developed

 technology can deliver this information using RGB (red, green, blue) cameras, a standard accessory carried by drones. The drone flies about 20 metres above land, capturing one image of a section of a crop field every two seconds. This data is then processed

 offline and modelled into useful information through 'deep learning—a subset of machine learning in Artificial Intelligence (AI) that uses 'neural' networks capable of learning unsupervised from data that is unstructured or unlabelled. The technology identifies

 healthy plants exhibiting a high vegetation index—shown as bright green regions—and mature, stressed or dead plants and soil manifesting a low vegetation index—displayed as yellow areas.
Primary Article Title: Estimation of vegetation indices for high-throughput phenotyping of wheat using aerial imaging
Author: Zohaib Khan, Vahid Rahimi-Eichi, Stephan Haefele, Trevor Garnett and Stanley J. Miklavcic
Keywords: Precision agriculture, crop inputs, sustainable intensification

Summary Sentence: Memories can be exchanged between organisms through transferring ribonucleic acid (RNA).
Justification:
In an experiment on sea snails, a California sea hare (Aplysia californica) was trained using sensitisation that triggers an involuntary defensive reflex. RNA extracted from the snail’s central nervous system was injected into an untrained sea hare, which

 then demonstrated the same sensory reflex. Long term memory has previously thought to be stored within the connections between brain cells. The results of this experiment suggests that memories may also be stored in gene expression. While the science behind

 this discovery is in its infancy the principle poses interesting questions about the nature of memory, knowledge and experience and how these might be stored and transferred between organisms. This may develop into a useful technique in wildlife conservation,

 for example in teaching species in captivity how to fair better in the wilderness. May the Environment Agency’s extensive learning and development programmes one day amount to nothing but a few ‘memory injections’?
Primary Article Title: Memory transferred between snails
Secondary_URLs: RNA from trained Aplysia can induce an epigenetic engram for long-term sensitization in untrained Aplysia - eNeuro 14/05/2018
Keywords: workforce training memory learning development employee "sea snail" "California sea hare" "Aplysia californica" "ribonucleic acid" RNA brain cell gene expression biology wildlife conservation

Summary Sentence: Automation is showing signs of impacting on timber construction.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is engaged widely in construction activities through asset maintenance and construction and therefore may need to consider how emerging technologies as demonstrated here could benefit these in the future, as the concept of automated

 construction grows. Swiss researchers have developed a system to employ robots in assembling prefabricated timber structures. Digitalisation is already a part of prefabrication of timber buildings, with parts often being produced through computer guided systems.

 In the DFAB HOUSE project two roof mounted robot arms are used to assist in construction. The first arm guides timber through cutting and drilling, which is performed by the second robot. The two robots that collaborate to carry and position the timber pieces

 in the correct place. A human worker then appears to fix the necessary screws. On a smaller scale, another robot based project from Singapore has been devised to tackle assembling IKEA’s flat pack furniture. The system uses two robot arms and a camera to automatically

 map where the parts are located, then check that all parts are present before beginning assembly. The robots put together a Dombas chair in 20 minutes.
Primary Article Title: A robot by NTU Singapore autonomously assembles an IKEA chair
Secondary_URLs:
Robotic collaboration in timber construction - ETH Zurich 22/03/2018

Can robots assemble an IKEA chair? - Science Robotics 18/04/2018
Keywords: automation construction building asset maintenance "automated construction" robot timber IKEA Dombas Singapore Zurich "DFAB HOUSE" furniture incident

Summary Sentence: Apple continues to innovate waste management through the use of robotics.
Justification:
The tech company's latest iteration of an iPhone disassembling robot Daisy can process 200 devices an hour, improving on the previous design of ‘Liam’ (%2313876) - even cannibalising some of Liam’s parts. Daisy is able to remove high value materials with a

 speed and precision not possible with human workers, and demonstrates how greater value could be extracted from electrical waste during WEEE recycling through increasing automation in waste management.
Primary Article Title: Apple's new recycling robot can disassemble 200 iPhones per hour
Author: Miley, J
Keywords: waste automation robot recycling electrical WEEE smartphone iPhone Daisy Liam device regulation metal Apple

Summary Sentence: Solar and wind could become the dominant energy source within the next 20 years.
Justification:
Trends in renewable energy over this timescale should interest the Environment Agency and partners in the context of the 25 year Environment Plan. Solar photovoltaics (PV) and wind currently represent around seven per cent of the World’s electricity, but

 at current growth rates, including minimal growth rates for fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas, renewables could account for 100 per cent of electricity generation by 2032. Even intensive energy activities associated with heavy industry, aviation and shipping

 could become divorced from fossil fuel by renewable electricity and electrically produced synthetic fuels, plastics and other hydrocarbons. The move to greener energy could have the effect of wiping $19 trillion from fossil fuel revenues by 2040 as the World

 moves to mass electrification, digitalisation, and new technologies, including electric vehicles greater fuel efficiency. It is thought that there may be as many as 540 million electric vehicles by 2040, significantly impacting on the value of crude oil. However

 demand for gas may actually increase. The overall effect will be to lower carbon dioxide emissions by 25 per cent. In preparation for the transition to renewables one leading Spanish based energy generation company recently announced that it was ceasing to

 look for growth in its oil and gas business, and looking reposition itself as an energy company, rather than a fossil fuel producer.
Primary Article Title: Solar PV and wind are on track to replace all coal, oil and gas within two decades
Author: Blakers, A & Stocks, M
Secondary_URLs:
A greener planet could slash oil company income by $19 Trillion to 2040 - Bloomberg 22/05/2018

Repsol to end pursuit of oil growth - Bloomberg 15/05/2018
Keywords: energy "fossil fuel" renewable solar wind photovoltaic PV electricity heat industry emission "climate change" "greenhouse gas" "carbon dioxide" oil coal gas 2032 2040 economics cost "electric vehicle" EV transport emission Repsol

Summary Sentence: More deaths are caused by fungi worldwide than breast cancer or malaria, and fungi are responsible for 20 percent of annual losses in crop yields globally.
Justification:
The recent rate of emergence of pathogenic fungi that are resistant to the limited number of commonly used antifungal agents is unprecedented. The azoles, for example, are used not only for human and animal health care and crop protection but also in antifouling

 coatings and timber preservation. The ubiquity and multiple uses of azoles have hastened the independent evolution of resistance in many environments. Industrialized farming practices used to grow relatively small varieties of crops play a key role in anti-fungal

 drug resistance. A combination of more people, animals and crops moving around the world than ever before, and the overuse of existing treatments have also fueled the rise in resistance. One consequence is an increasing risk in human health care from naturally

 occurring opportunistic fungal pathogens that have acquired resistance to this broad class of chemicals. To avoid a global collapse in the ability to control fungal infections and to avoid critical failures in medicine and food security, better stewardship

 of extant chemicals is needed, along with promoting new antifungal discovery, and leveraging emerging technologies for alternative solutions.
Primary Article Title: Worldwide emergence of resistance to antifungal drugs challenges human health and food security
Author: Matthew C. Fisher, Nichola J. Hawkins, Dominique Sanglard, Sarah J. Gurr
Keywords: Anti fungal resistance, human health, food security

Summary Sentence: An experiment on sea snails has demonstrated that memories can be transferred between organisms through the injection of RNA.
Justification:
Research suggests that long-term memory may "involve changes in gene expression induced by non-coding RNAs". This finding is the result of an experiment with sea snails. Some of the snails had been trained to respond to tail stimulation with a defensive

 response. When the untrained snails were injected with the RNA of the trained snails, a similar response to the stimulus was observed. The results suggest that memory can be modified and therefore, one day, we could be able to 'download' the memories of experienced

 staff to train those new to the organisation. There may also be the opportunity to obtain memories from those present at incidents, such as flooding events, to better understand how the public respond and use that learning to provide better long-term support

 for those affected.
Primary Article Title: Memory transferred between snails
Secondary_URLs: RNA from Trained Aplysia Can Induce an Epigenetic Engram for Long-Term Sensitization in Untrained Aplysia - eNeuro 24/05/2018
Keywords: memory snails "sea snails" RNA incidents training learning "learning from experience"

Summary Sentence: New research from the US highlights how silver nanoparticles can affect the treatment of wastewater.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is currently interested in the effects of nanomaterials on the environment. This research team from Oregon suggest that conventional toxicity tests for silver concentrations may result in a false sense of security. Because silver

 has antibacterial properties and when coupled with the beneficial bacteria already in the treatment plant, too many nutrients will end up in the waterways - potentially causing eutrophication. Silver nanoparticles are now present in a range of products and

 are therefore, becoming more common in wastewater treatment plants. Ammonia oxidising bacteria are present in wastewater plants to convert the ammonia to nitrates in order to remove nitrogen from the water. The bacteria create biofilms that can ward off the

 effects of silver however, the ammonia-conversion ability is affected by the time it is exposed to silver for - not the concentration. Because the time that the bacteria are in the plant is greater than the wastewater, over time, there will be an accumulation

 of metal contaminants - including silver. Therefore, the current, short-term, toxicity tests are likely to be underestimating the toxicity risk.
Primary Article Title: Accumulating over time, even low concentrations of silver can foil wastewater treatment
Secondary_URLs: Effects of short- and long-term exposure of silver nanoparticles and silver ions to Nitrosomonas europaea biofilms and planktonic cells - Chemosphere 24/05/2018
Keywords: nanoparticles "silver nanoparticles" silver metals wastewater "wastewater treatment" ammonia nitrate nitrogen eutrophication "algae blooms" pollution

Summary Sentence: Recent evidence suggests changing patterns of legal and illegal substance use.
Justification:
Societal trends can have an impact on water quality and the biodiversity within them, and therefore may be of some interest to the Environment Agency. A recent television programme ‘Fatberg Autopsy&%2358; Secrets of The Sewers’ found that the majority of a London

 fatberg constituted non-flushable items such as wet wipes. Chemical analysis identified expected substances, such as paracetamol, prescription medications and substances used in skin creams. However there were surprising levels of hormone based gym supplements

 such as hordenine and ostarine, making up more than half of the pharmaceuticals found. Hordenine is in weight loss products, but may also originate from a breakdown of barley based compounds in beer. Ostarine, used as a muscle gain supplement, is a banned

 performance enhancing steroid. Needle exchanges have also seen increased custom for steroid administration, suggesting that this is a growing issue. The impact of hormones and endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) on biodiversity are well documented (%2313140,

 %2311736, %2312214), and further lifestyle choices such as this could exacerbate the issue. However it should be noted that plastic derived oestrogenic compounds were also found in surprisingly high quantities. The results should be treated with caution and may

 not be representative of London as a whole. While younger people may be taking steroids, there is some intelligence that substances like MDMA also known as ecstasy may becoming increasingly popular with the bored middle classes. One newspaper describes a trend

 known as ‘brieing’, where MDMA is taken with cheese at the end of a dinner party to help people ‘open up’ and improve friendships. Ecstasy in powder form attracts a premium and is growing in popularity, further suggesting a change in socio-economic status

 of users. While the impacts of ‘brieing’ on their own are unlikely to deliver any significant environmental impact, this combines with other intelligence on changing permissiveness to illegal substances (%2314524, %2314502, %2313458, %2313654, %2314147) may indicate

 emerging chemical pollutants that need to be considered for their environmental impacts, much as commonplace substances such as caffeine and ibuprofen are currently (%2313198, %2312830, %2311111). It recently came to light that the World's largest producer of legal

 cannabis is the UK, despite the UK Government maintaining that the plant has no medicinal benefits. The conflict within this now exposed situation could mean that legal cannabis based medicines and even recreational uses become commonplace in the future. It

 should be noted that both legal and illegal cannabis production in the United States has been estimated as accounting for one per cent of total energy use, mainly from indoor growing. It is not clear under what conditions legal UK cannabis is grown, but the

 total annual yield in 2015 (41,706 kg) dwarfed the US legal yield (566 kg),
Primary Article Title: Why there are more gym supplements in a London fatberg than cocaine and MDMA
Author: Saner, E
Secondary_URLs:
Women are taking MDMA wrapped in cheese and it's called brieing - Metro 16/05/2018

UK world's largest producer of legal cannabis, finds UN body - The Independent 07/03/2018

Estimated World Requirements for 2018 - Statistics for 2016 - PART II - UN International Narcotics Control Board 01/03/2018

A horizon scan of global conservation issues for 2015 - Trends in Ecology and Evolution 01/01/2015
Keywords: pollution chemical sewage "water quality" biodiversity behaviour society people UK US yield farming crop legal illegal energy "middle class" cocaine cheese brieing pharmaceutical drug narcotic steroid MDMA ecstasy hordenine ostarine gym supplement illegal regulation fatberg plastic oestrogenic London "endocrine disrupting chemical" EDC caffeine ibuprofen pollutant chemistry chemical wildlife biodiversity young needle lifestyle crime cannabis medicine legal law marijuana

Summary Sentence: As a water scarce country, South Africa will need to make tough decisions about to how to fairly allocate resources between residents, agriculture, businesses and industry.
Justification:
As the Environment Agency is currently looking at strategy around water resources in the context of drought, lessons learned from countries already experiencing these conditions could prove useful. In South Africa there is already an imbalance between

 the rich and poor with access to water for the poorer sectors of the population limited by leaking pipes and shared taps that are some distance from where many people live. To compound this, free water is limited to 200 litres per household but, there is no

 distinction between a household of ten and a household of one - meaning less affluent, large families are paying for water. The sewage systems are also failing with only the rich having flushable toilets. From an agricultural perspective, water was not limited

 quickly enough resulting in both annual and seasonal crops being processed before limitations were imposed. It is suggested that the best course of action would have been to sacrifice the seasonal crops and only irrigate the annual crops. The result is that

 temporary desalination plants had to be built that far outstripped the cost of sacrificing crops. South Africa will need to determine what its "new normal" will look like and address historical, social and structural issues to cope with future periods of drought.
Primary Article Title: Bold steps are needed toward a `new normal' that allocates water fairly in South Africa
Keywords: drought "water resources" water "South Africa" "water management" "water strategy" supply demand agriculture industry business

Summary Sentence: In Australia, academics are debating whether water could become more expensive than oil resulting in an international water market where only the wealthy can afford unlimited access.
Justification:
It is noted that water is not like oil in the sense that we have access to a free source of water - unlike oil. However, that is only the case because most countries see water as a right - not a commodity. But in times of severe drought, could that stance

 change? In South Africa, throughout the drought crisis, bottled water has stayed at the same price but, economists are considering what the tipping point would be for water-rich countries to develop an international water market. Currently, unlike other commodities,

 there is no global market for water and therefore, no fixed price for trading. If an international market were to develop, even if countries tried to keep the price of domestic water down, an over-inflated international market could force domestic prices up

 as the international market place demands on quality and quantity. In Australia, there is already a value for water and in Victoria, a tightly controlled water market allows water to be moved to more economically productive areas. The Environment Agency may

 want to consider the implications of a future where water is not a human right - but a commodity.
Primary Article Title: Will water ever be worth more than oil?
Keywords: water "water resources" commodities markets "market forces" "international water market" oil prices value trade

Summary Sentence: Research from the US suggests that during disasters, Twitter users spread mis-information at a rate of 86-91 per cent and others do nothing to correct that information.
Justification:
There has been interest at the Environment Agency in the uses of social media to get messages to the public in a timely manner during incidents. This research from the University of Buffalo examined 20,000 tweets from both Hurricane Sandy and the Boston

 marathon bombing and found that users could exhibit three types of behaviour&%2358; Spread the false news, confirm it or, cast doubt. The results show that 86-91 per cent spread the false news, only 5-9 per cent sought to confirm it and 1-9 per cent cast doubt.

 It is possible that people are more easily deceived during times of stress or, that people choose to ignore falsehoods rather than engage. Ongoing research aims to understand why twitter users ignore certain posts during emergencies and how we can stop fake

 news stories from circulating.
Primary Article Title: During disasters, active Twitter users likely to spread falsehoods
Keywords: twitter "social media" incidents "incident management" disasters "fake news" falsehoods misinformation

Summary Sentence: High levels of herbicide glyphosate have been found in wine and beer in the United States.
Justification:
The Environment Agency recommends using glyphosate for managing invasive non native plants such as Japanese knotweed, and therefore may be interesting in the findings that suggest significant levels of glyphosate are present in foodstuffs that have been

 grown organically, without direct glyphosate applications. Pressure group Moms Across America financed “Gold Standard” testing using HPLC mass spectronomy. Of the ten brands of wine tested, glyphosate levels were found to vary between 038 ppb to 23.30 ppb,

 including levels of .38 ppb and 3.42 ppb in two organic wines. Similar research on brands of beer revealed that that independent beer and organic beers have higher levels of glyphosate than conventional beer. One possible explanation is that independent and

 organic beer producers tend to use more barley, oats, rye, and wheat and brewing, which may have had more exposure to glyphosate, which is also used as a drying agent, that other ingredients such as hulled white rice. Due to the controls governing grain supply

 for brewing purposes it is concluded that the glyphosate must originate from historic applications in the soil or have been blown in from neighbouring fields. Other recent research has identified high levels of arsenic and heavy metals in some glyphosate based

 herbicides, including the household chemical RoundUp. These have apparently not been previously declared as ingredients, meaning that these potentially toxic substances are being applied to land, with potential consequences for health, land contamination and

 water quality.
Primary Article Title: Arsenic in wine? Michelob moves to organic? Why the alcohol industry is making changes
Author: Honeycutt, Z
Secondary_URLs:
Toxicity of formulants and heavy metals in glyphosate-based herbicides and other pesticides - Toxicology Reports 08/01/2018

Arsenic and heavy metals found in herbicide sprayed on food crops - Moms Across America 08/01/2018
Keywords: food drink farming herbicide chemical health biodiversity cancer glyphosate RoundUp regulation invasive plant crop wine incident beer organic wheat rice oat barley arsenic "heavy metal" "water quality" pollution pollutant contaminated land

Summary Sentence: The first extensive field trial of methods to control the invasive plant Japanese knotweed have recently concluded that eradication is impossible, but there may be more effective control methods.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this research as it advises landowners on methods to control Japanese knotweed. The trial took place between 2011 and 2016 in Wales, utilising 58 trial plots at a cost of £1.2 million. The researchers trialled

 19 different eradication techniques, none of which proved to be effective. This is due to knotweed having significant biomass under the soil, making total eradication impossible with current technologies. The most effective control method was using glyphosate

 based herbicide. However it was noted that there is controversy around the chemical glyphosate due to its potential impacts on food and drink (%2314688), biodiversity (%2314252) and health (%2314393, %2313981). There seems to be no mention for the potential to manage

 knotweed through treating it as a foodstuff (%2314115). The trials discovered that seasonality and the growing cycle of the plant influence how effective glyphosate application can be, and from this they have developed a patent pending approach called ‘The 4-Stage

 Model™’. The team is also producing more up to date guidance based on their research, which the Environment Agency may wish to incorporate into its own guidance.
Primary Article Title: We've found the best way to control Japanese knotweed
Author: Jones, D & Eastwood, D
Secondary_URLs: Optimising physiochemical control of invasive Japanese knotweed - Biological Invasions 23/04/2018
Keywords: "invasive species" plant "japanese knotweed" glyphosate chemical "water quality" regulation "The 4-Stage Model™" soil eradicate health biodiversity

Summary Sentence: Many countries in the world have been, or are, experiencing major drought and the UK will need to also be prepared for such an eventuality without harming the environment or, driving up the costs of water.
Justification:
The Environmental Change Institute at the University of Oxford have recently published a strategic water planning report that complements the recent work done by the Environment Agency on State of the Environment - water resources. In keeping with State

 of Environment reporting, the researchers discuss the need to convince people to use less water and investing in long-term leakage reduction solutions. The research team came to this conclusion by making use of the National Infrastructure Systems Model (NISMOD)

 to assess different investment options. They also compared options available to individual water companies compared to options that could be adopted on a national scale. The conclusion is that water supply in England could be "future-proofed" without a huge

 cost to the taxpayer or, causing environmental damage - if we act early enough.
Primary Article Title: Postponing Day Zero&%2358; Investment in water efficiency will keep taps running
Secondary_URLs: Navigating the water trilemma&%2358; a strategic assessment of long-term national water resource management options for Great Britain - Water and Environment Journal 02/05/2018
Keywords: water "water resources" drought "climate change" leaks infrastructure "water useage" "water charges" "environmental impact"

Summary Sentence: In the US, solutions to the problems of climate change, infrastructure and rising costs of water resources are being considered by the Columbia Water Center.
Justification:
Despite the growing problems of how to provide water during times of drought and changing rainfall patterns coupled with an ageing infrastructure that is no longer fit for purpose, many water companies are seeing these problems as an opportunity for positive

 change. The UK may benefit from being aware of this analysis following the recent publication of our State of Environment Water Resources report and the similar problems highlighted within. Water management practices in the US have declined in recent years

 with ratings for dams, drinking water and wastewater all receiving D ratings. Solutions offered to change these ratings to A's, include&%2358; Creating national level governance - such as in the UK - to allow water companies to work together; increase the budget

 for water infrastructure (currently the US spend less than Vietnam; make it easier for private investors to understand how their many is being spent to attract more capital; and look to the past AND future to better understand current risks.
Primary Article Title: America's water infrastructure is failing-but here's how we could start to fix it
Keywords: water "water resources" infrastructure drought rainfall "climate change" resources investment "water infrastructure"

Summary Sentence: As global demand and prices for finite metals increase, the economics for restarting ancient British mines start to look more favourable.
Justification:
Rising demand for metals in electric cars and renewable energy technologies means that global prices have seen a sharp increase over recent years. New survey methods make it easier for companies to assess potential deposits, and backing from some MP’s

 in the wake of EU exit suggests there is a growing support base for this industry. The exploration for lithium has already been raised as an area that may require Environment Agency resource to manage in the future (HSDBi 14248). This latest article suggests

 that other metals such as tin and tungsten may also see an increase in applications for mining, as firms are already seeking financing. If such mines do reopen in the future, waste water will need to be pumped out and treated before any new mining can continue.

 Abandoned mines have been and continue to be a source of water pollution in many areas. To prevent this problem in the future, any new mining activity will need protections in place to ensure correct monitoring and treatment during active mining and once the

 site closes.
Primary Article Title: Britain looks to ancient mines for electric future
Keywords: Tin Tungsten metal Lithium battery storage pollution pollutant bioavailable "energy storage" "energy efficiency" "fossil fuel" oil coal nuclear battery regulation "climate change" waste WEEE electricity industry mine mining

Summary Sentence: There are signals that access to clean water, clean air and a healthy environment, currently considered human rights, may become a paid privilege.
Justification:
Access to clean water and sanitation is a human right recognised by the United Nations in 2010. However clean water is also a limited resource. The combined pressures of drought, population increase and outdated infrastructure have put tremendous pressure

 on local supplies, and Cape Town could effectively run out of water in the near future. How people respond to this situation is linked to wealth. Richer people could take steps to drill their own boreholes, order deliveries of bottled water or hire desalination

 machines - all at inflated prices. The less well off may be forced to make stark choices between purchasing water and other basics, including food. As the pressures of climate change become more acutely felt on a global scale, the idea of a global water market

 could arise, where countries with plentiful water supplies sell to countries who do not. This could cause the domestic price of water to escalate rapidly. Countries without water would be prepared to pay a premium. This could mean that water is exported to

 where it is most profitable, like gas and oil are, leaving people in home countries also paying more for water. In this situation only the rich will be able to secure access to clean water. There are also signals that access to clean air may similarly come

 with a financial premium. Indoor air quality in China is starting to become a way for businesses and schools to differentiate themselves from competitors. Shanghai’s new Cordis Hongqiao hotel is fitted with filtration technology and accurate air pollution

 monitors in each room, to the effect that indoor air quality is ten times better than outside. Relocation companies are also offering clean indoor air quality provision as one incentive to attract overseas talent to work in China, and many office buildings

 are also pursuing clean indoor air accreditation. Such benefits are likely to only be felt by the wealthy for the immediate future, though it could be expected for indoor air quality technology to trickle down to many more public spaces, shops and factories.

 Indoor air quality may become an additional factor in choosing where to take one’s business, providing one can afford to make a choice. Access to clean air, unlike water, is not a human right, though there are groups out there, including the UN suggesting

 that it should be, as part of the right to access a healthy environment.
Primary Article Title: How clean indoor air is becoming China's latest luxury must-have
Author: Roxburgh, H
Secondary_URLs:
UN moves towards recognising human right to a healthy environment - The Guardian 09/03/2018

Divided by drought - Washington Post 23/02/2018

The right to breathe clean air - United Nations Environment Programme 01/12/2017

Will water ever be worth more than oil? - University Of Melbourne 06/03/2018
Keywords: water air "water resources" pollution pollutant Pm2.5 "human right" "United Nations" economics world market supply demand export import "Cape Town" wealth inequality "air quality" China Shanghai "Cordis Hongqiao" hotel filter indoor outdoor consumer business school privilege technology employment office factory regulation health illness poverty sanitation
GT: air quality, water resources, human rights, economics

Summary Sentence: Giant hammerhead flatworms, or land planarians, up to 40 cm (over 1 foot) in length, have been reported in France and overseas French territories.
Justification: Several invasive flatworms, including the New Guinea flatworm, Platydemus manokwari, have already been reported from France. Most of these species, however, are small animals, less than 5 cm (2 in) in length. However, species of the genera Bipalium and Diversibipalium, or bipaliines, are giants among land planarians (family Geoplanidae), reaching length of 1 m; they are also easily distinguished from other land flatworms by the characteristic hammer shape of their head. Bipaliines, which have their origin in warm parts of Asia, are invasive species, now widespread worldwide. Hammerhead flatworms are predators of soil animals, including earthworms, and thus are a possible threat to the biodiversity of native animals and to soil ecology, although the ecological impact has yet to be studied. Based on contributions from citizen science, five species of hammerhead flatworms are reported by this study from metropolitan France in Europe and from French overseas territories in the Caribbean, South America, Africa and Oceania. Molecular studies, based on the Cytochrome Oxidase Type 1 sequences, show that the species show no genetic variation. Bipalium kewense had a single haplotype, found in 5 continents. The species are clonal (genetically identical) and reproduce asexually. The researchers believe the species may have been present in France for up to 20 years without being noticed or any biosecurity response being initiated.
Primary Article Title: Giant worms chez moi! Hammerhead flatworms (Platyhelminthes, Geoplanidae, Bipalium spp., Diversibipalium spp.) in metropolitan France and overseas French territories
Author: Jean-Lou Justine​, Leigh Winsor, Delphine Gey, Pierre Gros, Jessica Thévenot
Keywords: Invasive non-native species; biosecurity

Summary Sentence: Initiatives to democratise access to 3D printing and cell culture technology could impact on all the sectors associated with additive manufacturing, including health and food.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may see this is a sign that the move towards 3D printing as commonplace is accelerating, bringing forward potential regulatory challenges and opportunities around the decentralisation and democratisation of manufacturing and food production.

 Researchers have developed a low cost, syringe-based, large volume extruder (LVE) bioprinter through modification of a commercial plastic printer. Commercial bioprinters cost between $10,000 and $200,00. The new bioprinter can be built by an individual for

 around $500. Crucially the researchers have released the complete plans as open source, meaning anyone can use them for free. The LVE also allows printing of artificial human tissue on a larger scale and at higher resolution than previously, allowing for researchers,

 makers, and professionals to experiment with 3-D printing biomaterials and fluids.To quote developer Adam Feinberg; “It’s about democratizing technology and trying to get it into more people’s hands.” In Japan a non-profit start-up called the Shojinmeat Project,

 owned by Tokyo-based Integriculture, has provided students access to high-tech, microwave-sized heated boxes for culturing cells at home. The idea is to take what the students learn about growing cell cultured meat and incorporate it into future product development.

 A secondary goal is to foster curiosity around the possibility of cultured meat. The company also helps to engage on a cultural level through selling cultured meat related merchandise including comic books featuring characters from the projects literature

 and website. The idea is that if primary school children can engage with cultured meat, then why can’t adults? Shojinment is also engaging with Buddhist organisations. Integriculture has also submitted a patent for cultured foie-gras, that pate like texture

 of which requires less technological know how constructing the texture of meat. Acceptance of cultured meats is key to their success. A recent survey found that 65 percent of 673 surveyed US individuals would probably or definitely try cultured meat while

 only 8.5 percent said they definitely would not.
Primary Article Title: 3-DIY&%2358; printing your own bioprinter
Author: Forney, E & Durham, E
Secondary_URLs:
Large volume syringe pump extruder for desktop 3D printers - HardwareX 22/05/2018

Attitudes to in vitro meat&%2358; A survey of potential consumers in the United States - PLOS ONE 16/02/2017

A Japanese food startup is giving high school kids meat-growing machines - Quartz 16/10/2017
Keywords: "additive manufacturing" "3D printing" cell culture meat "open source" data syringe-based "large volume extruder" LVE bioprinter bioprinting health heart decentralisation democratisation food meat protein "Shojinmeat" education school children young people Manga comic behaviour psychology in-vitro Integriculture Tokyo Japan Buddhist religion Buddhism biomaterial foie-gras patent data
GT: additive manufacturing, food, behaviour, open source

Summary Sentence: CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing technology has been used to develop a variety of rice that produces 25-31 percent more grain, which would have been virtually impossible to create through traditional breeding methods.
Justification:
Crop growth and yield are controlled by several phytohormones and their overlapping signal networks. Abscisic acid (ABA) is a key phytohormone that controls plant growth and stress responses. It is sensed by the pyrabactin resistance 1 (PYR1)/PYR1-like

 (PYL)/regulatory components of the ABA receptor (RCAR) family of proteins. Gene editing was used to silenced suites of pyrabactin resistance 1 (PYR1)/PYR1-like (PYL)/regulatory components of ABA receptor (ACAR) genes, or simply, PYL genes. These genes enhance

 tolerance of abiotic stresses, such as drought, soil salinity and other environmental factors, but also inhibit growth. Of several varieties created, one produced a plant that had little change in stress tolerance but produced 25 percent more grain in a field

 test in Shanghai, China, and 31 percent more in a field test conducted on China's Hainan Island. The improved rice plants created in these experiments come from a common research line. The next step is to use CRISPR/Cas9 to edit the same genes in elite varieties

 of rice to determine if those will also show similarly improved yield.
Primary Article Title: Mutations in a subfamily of abscisic acid receptor genes promote rice growth and productivity
Publisher: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author: Chunbo Miao, Lihong Xiao, Kai Hua, Changsong Zou, Yang Zhao, Ray A. Bressan, and Jian-Kang Zhu
Keywords: Gene editing, crop yield; rice production

Summary Sentence: A briefing for policy makers produced by the Wellcome Trust, setting out recommendations on UK/EU science and innovation post-Brexit.
Justification:
This briefing was informed by consultation across Europe, and was delivered in partnership with the Royal Society. Their recommendations include&%2358; * securing a deal that includes a path towards Associated Country status for the UK in FP9 * that after Brexit,

 the UK and EU should continue to cooperate on pre-competitive research regulation * full researcher mobility between the EEA and UK after Brexit * In the longer-term, EU and Associated Countries should work together to secure Europe’s position as a world-leading

 location for science by developing the European Research Area (ERA).
Primary Article Title: Wellcome brexit briefing for policymakers
Author: Wellcome Trust
Keywords: brexit policy science innovation research wellcome recommendations
GT: brexit policy implications science health biological sciences

Summary Sentence:
A strategy from the Ministry of Defence that sets out the components of its new core research portfolio, the S&T capabilities that are required for UK defence and security, and the importance of collaboration with industry, academia and their international

 partners.
Justification:
The strategy sets out the MOD's vision for science and technology to play a central role in defence thinking and culture, directing and applying innovative research and thinking to meet the current and future strategic needs of defence and security. It

 includes an overview of the MOD's research portfolio and the types of technologies they are developing. Chemical & biological capabilities, information interoperability & communications, and senor & targeting concepts all received the highest band of research

 investment (£15m +).
Primary Article Title: Mod science and technology strategy 2017
Author: Ministry of Defence
Keywords: Ministry of Defence MOD emerging technologies technology strategy research innovation development portfolio
GT: Ministry of Defence Science Technology Strategy

Summary Sentence: Although the percentage of land included in the global protected area network has increased from 9 to 15%, a third of this area is influenced by intensive human activity.
Justification:
A major shift in conservation efforts took place in the 1990s, following the signing of the Convention on Biological Diversity in 1992. To date, some 200 nations have agree to the treaty, which aims to set aside 17 percent of the world’s land in parks

 and other sanctuaries by 2020. The goal of these efforts is to protect biodiversity, or the variability of organisms in planet’s ecosystems. Protected areas are the primary defense against biodiversity loss, but extensive human activity within their boundaries

 can undermine this. Using the most comprehensive global map of human pressure, this study suggests that 6 million square kilometers (32.8%) of protected land is under intense human pressure. Among the pressures infringing on protected spaces are mining, logging,

 farming, the development of roads, the building of power lines and light pollution. For protected areas designated before the Convention on Biological Diversity was ratified in 1992, 55% have since experienced human pressure increases. These increases were

 lowest in large, strict protected areas, showing that they are potentially effective, at least in some nations. The researchers suggest transparent reporting on human pressure within protected areas is now critical, as are global targets aimed at efforts required

 to halt biodiversity loss.
Primary Article Title: One-third of global protected land is under intense human pressure
Author: Kendall R. Jones, Oscar Venter, Richard A. Fuller, James R. Allan, Sean L. Maxwell, Pablo Jose Negret, James E. M. Watson
Keywords: Protected Areas, Biodiversity Loss

Summary Sentence: Ecopotential uses satellite data from powerful Sentinel satellites launched by the European Space Agency in 2014, which allows researchers to observe minute variations in protected habitats with sensors that can focus on areas as small as 10 square metres.
Justification:
ECOPOTENTIAL is a large European-funded H2020 project that focuses its activities on a targeted set of internationally recognised Protected Areas, blending Earth Observations from remote sensing and field measurements, data analysis and modelling of current

 and future ecosystem conditions and services. ECOPOTENTIAL considers cross-scale geosphere-biosphere interactions at regional to continental scales, addressing long-term and large-scale environmental and ecological challenges. Environmental change is happening

 more quickly than previous studies envisaged, with protected areas — and the species they shelter — under pressure from a number of different angles at once. Climate change isn’t the only problem, although it is significant. Increased use of land for agriculture,

 encroachment by invasive species and poaching are combining to accelerate its impact. It has the effect of reducing the net benefits these environmental resources offer humans — so-called ‘ecoysystem services’ — such as providing and purifying our air and

 water, capturing carbon dioxide gas, preventing soil erosion and providing practical resources like raw materials, wood and food.
Primary Article Title: Earth observations show Europe's natural wealth in steep decline
Author: Klotz, F
Keywords: Earth Observation, Biodiversity Loss, Protected Areas

Summary Sentence:
Just months before the world's first wind monitoring satellite enters orbit, scientists have finalised a climate model with exceptional resolution, and the new tools will help identify how climate change impacts weather-related natural disasters like storm

 surges, hurricanes and heatwaves.
Justification:
Typical climate algorithms simplify portions of the sky as single pixels spanning volumes some 100-kilometres across. But thanks to work done through a project called EUCLEIA, coordinated by the Met Office, climate scientists can now zoom into details

 less than half that size. Building on the statistical predictions of the EUCLEIA approach, the follow-up project EUPHEME is now helping to manage some of the impacts that climate change is having on society. As part of its 18-country strong consortium, the

 Met Office is fine-tuning the new climate model further with complex phenomena such as climate feedback mechanisms and air movements in the upper atmosphere. The European Space Agency (ESA) is also preparing to launch Aeolus – the first satellite to observe

 wind speeds directly from space. The Aeolus satellite packs a powerful laser that pulses ultraviolet light into the atmosphere. A 1.5 metre telescope on board will collect the reflected beam, allowing scientists to identify wind speeds from tiny shifts in

 the light’s frequency. The satellite will be used to study the air currents high above the tropics, which largely drive European weather.
Primary Article Title: Supercomputers and space-based laser to help predict extreme weather events
Author: Gonzalez, J
Keywords: Extreme Weather, Climate Change Modelling

Summary Sentence: The University of Zurich has made key discoveries into the mechanism of our sense of self through the administration of LSD.
Justification:
The use of (currently) illegal drugs as medications has been raised before. This research focuses on how a potent psychedelic drug, in this case lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) can alter our sense of self. The results of this research suggest that by

 using LSD, brain receptors can be manipulated to create a more stable sense of self that could be used to treat psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia and depression. As the evidence for these drugs builds, the argument for legalisation will get stronger.

 For example, Alfie Dingle was recently in the news in his quest to obtain cannabis oil to treat his severe epilepsy.
Primary Article Title: Breakthrough study reveals how LSD dissolves a person's sense of self
Secondary_URLs:
Role of the 5-HT2A receptor in self- and other-initiated social interaction in LSD-induced states - a pharmacological fMRI study - JNeuroSci 21/05/2018

Alfie Dingley's medical cannabis petition handed to government - BBC 21/05/2018
Keywords: drugs "illegal drugs" "psychiatric disorders" LSD schizophrenia cannabis brain "sense of self" self-awareness

Summary Sentence: Researchers from Japan have developed autonomous molecular robots that can swarm in response to chemical or physical stimuli.
Justification:
The robots measure just 25 nanometres by 5 micrometres and can swarm in a similar way to ants, birds or fish. They work on a molecular system comprising the basics of a robot - actuators, information processors and sensors. The difference between these

 robots and standard robots is that the actuators are made up of kinesins, the information processors, DNA and the sensors, cellular proteins. The main challenge is to construct a large number of robots that can be programmed to perform self-assembly. This

 was resolved by introducing the DNA which, can hybridize when they have a complementary sequence. This is the first evidence that it is possible to use DNA computing to programme swarming behaviour in molecular robots and could lead to the development of nano

 machines. The applications are endless but could be used by the EA to clean up chemical spills, assess the use of illegal chemicals or pesticides or monitoring air quality and water quality.
Primary Article Title: Letting molecular robots swarm like birds
Secondary_URLs: DNA-assisted swarm control in a biomolecular motor system - Nature 21/05/2018
Keywords: nano-machines nanotechnology DNA "molecular robots" swarms robotics "swarm robots" robotics autonomous "swarming behaviour"

Summary Sentence: Developments in artificial intelligence connected with speech could elevate voice as a means of interaction with IT, but there is also the possibility of an increasing spread of misinformation and mistrust.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may need to consider optimising services for voice interaction to meet customer expectation whilst also being aware of the impact that automation could have on the workforce. At the same time communications and engagement

 activities need to be mindful of the current and future capabilities, as well as the potential for mistrust and "fake news" that technology like this could generate, which may be harmful particularly during times of major incident. Chinese search giant Baidu

 has improved its voice cloning software to the point where ‘Deep Voice’ need to hear only a few seconds of someone’s voice before it can clone the speech pattern use it to replicate any speech. The system can also take a piece of recorded speech and convincingly

 alter the gender and accent of the original voice. Cornell University have developed a neural network called Tacotron 2 that can synthesise speech direct from text at a better quality than professionally recorded speech. Google recently demonstrated a new

 function of Google Assistant that can make phone calls on behalf of the owner. In the demonstration Google Assistant called a hair salon to arrange an appointment using a natural sounding voice, complete with ‘ums’ and ‘ahs’. At no point did the person at

 the other end realise they were interacting with computer software - despite unanswered accusations that Google faked the call. Microsoft have also developed a similar digital assistant in China, known as XiaoIce.
Primary Article Title: Baidu's voice cloning AI can swap genders and remove accents
Author: Greene, T
Secondary_URLs:
Like a phone call&%2358; XiaoIce, Microsoft's social chatbot in China, makes breakthrough in natural conversation - Microsoft Network 03/04/2018

Did Google fake its Duplex AI demo? Firm is accused of misleading viewers during its unveiling of its 'horrifyingly' life-like voice assistant - The Daily Mail 18/05/2018

Natural TTS synthesis by conditioning WaveNet on Mel spectrogram predictions - Cornell University 16/12/2017

Google Assistant to make phone calls for owners - BBC 08/05/2018
Keywords: automation voice "fake news" misinformation customer interaction Baidu Google text gender accent workforce incident people Microsoft China XiaoIce

Summary Sentence: A biofriendly material made from wood outperforms Styrofoam as an insulator and could provide a plastic free alternative construction material.
Justification:
Nanowood is made from natural wood. It is treated to remove all lignin, which in a thermal conductor. The remaining cellulose fibres bond with each other delivering a material with a high mechanical strength. In experiments Nanowood blocked at least 10

 degrees more heat than styrofoam or silica aerogel - which currently holds the Guinness World Record for ‘best insulator’. Nanowood is also 30 times stronger than Styrofoam, aerogel or other cellulose foams. Nanowood is white, so it also reflects sunlight

 effectively, and is fully biodegradable. And unlike glass or wool Nanowood does not release fibres that can cause allergic reactions or breathing difficulties.The reduced need for plastic plus the demand for timber that Nanowood might generate may help to

 address current waste issues and agriculture futures issues currently on the political agenda, as well as help to reduce energy use. It is expected that the material will be commercially available within the year (2018-2019) and in the future may suit being

 made from fast growing trees such as balsa.
Primary Article Title: Sturdy insulator made of wood
Secondary_URLs:
Could `Nanowood' replace Styrofoam? - Smithsonian 26/03/2018

Anisotropic, lightweight, strong, and super thermally insulating nanowood with naturally aligned nanocellulose - Science Advances 09/03/2018
Keywords: wood Nanowood waste plastic construction insulation Styrofoam "silica aerogel" "Guinness World Record" agriculture wood woodland forestry land lignin cellulose energy balsa 2018 2019 tree

Summary Sentence: A 3D printer that incorporates four different additive manufacturing applications could pave the way for complex object creation from multiple materials in a single stage.
Justification:
Such a process could mean that more manufacturing can happen in a single location and encourage a decentralisation of production with less waste material, such as making a mobile phone from plastic and metal circuitry in one. However incorporating multiple

 materials into a single item could complicate recycling at the end of life stage. The new 3D printer has so far demonstrated creating a light emitting diode (LED), with circuitry inside a plastic case. A printed a layer of conductive ink inside a rubber material

 has also demonstrated the printer’s possibile use in creating flexible electronics.
Primary Article Title: Four-in-one 3D printer paves way for custom-made robots and phones
Author: Zastrow, M
Keywords: "additive manufacturing" "3D printing" plastic metal ink rubber circuit electronic "mobile phone" LED waste WEEE recycling regulation decentralisation manufacturing

Summary Sentence: A research team has developed the first insect size flying robot that can manoeuvre wirelessly without being tethered to a power source.
Justification:
Small flying robots could provide added dimensions to environmental data for monitoring purposes. Recently US retailer Walmart filed a patent for robotic insects designed to pollinate crops (%2314610), and previous research has developed small flying robots

 for surveillance purposes (%236809). This recent development is a progression towards the realisation of this concept. The ‘RoboFly’ as it is known weighs slightly more than a toothpick. It has flapping wings powered by a small photovoltaic cell on the top,

 which gathers energy from an invisible laser beam. Future versions could harness energy from the sun, radio waves or even an onboard battery. Currently RoboFly can only take off and land, and drifts to the ground when out of the laser beam’s range. The team

 see one future use of RoboFly in detecting methane leaks from pipes. However the notion of independent flight for insect sized robots suggests that automated pollinators may be able to move beyond the conceptual stage, hedging against the well document bee

 colony collapse, which threatens food security and agricultural livelihoods. There may also be concerns on the impact on the environment from electronic waste if such robots malfunction etc.
Primary Article Title: The first wireless flying robotic insect takes off
Author: McQuate, S
Keywords: automation robot RoboFly monitoring surveillance methane wireless pollination insect Walmart patent incident management "bee colony collapse disorder" farming food crop agriculture regulation solar photovoltaic laser waste

Summary Sentence: Religious belief in young people across Europe is falling overall, with the potential for Europe to become a ‘post-Christian’ society.
Justification:
Analysis of views expressed by young people aged 16-29 across Europe show that on the whole religious affiliation is on the decline, though this differs significantly between countries. . The UK has one of the highest proportion of young people identifying

 with no religion. Religious values of Christian parents are not being retained by their children. Religions other the christianity have higher retention rates, but these too show a similar decline. One researcher suggests that Christianity will have vanished

 from Europe within 100 years. Judeo-christian values are central to the moral and legal position of many European societies. The church (HSDBi %2312704) along with other religious groups (%2313425) have been at the front of environmental action, including the

 divestment movement, aiming to remove investment from the fossil fuel industry (%2314232). Many Christian values also run parallel to the values of environmentalism, and leaders such as the Pope and leader UK church figures have championed environmental issues.

 The strength of this influence may be lost, which in turn may contribute to the environment’s position on the political agenda, though environmental issues are generally already more important for younger than older people.
Primary Article Title: 'Christianity as default is gone'&%2358; the rise of a non-Christian Europe
Author: Sherwood, H
Keywords: religion christianity christian muslim islam belief influence communication divestment Europe "young people" UK moral ethic

Summary Sentence: Alternative proteins are gaining ground with consumers, and are on the brink of becoming mainstream in some Western countries.
Justification:
Changes to agriculture brought on by a move away from convention sources of protein such as livestock are likely to alter the environmental pressures caused by the farming sector, and therefore the way in which the Environment Agency regulates it. Canada’s

 largest grocer has added cricket powder to its shelves. The insect based alternative protein’s appearance in Loblaw stores suggests that there is a growing acceptance and a desire to experiment with alternative proteins that may translate into a wider shift

 in market forces. Another company is hoping that pet food based on alternative proteins may be another way to introduce the idea to human consumers. Wild Earth are to launch a line of slaughter free pet food where the protein is manufactured through growing

 and harvesting living cells derived from donor animals. Their products in development include a mouse meat based cat food and a dog food made from cultivating koji fungus.
Primary Article Title: Loblaw adds cricket powder to President's Choice line
Author: Sagan, A
Secondary_URLs: Lab-grown dog food is first step to a clean meat empire - Neo.Life 14/03/2018
Keywords: food farming meat protein livestock regulation insect cricket Canada Loblaw grocer supermarket retail powder pet food cell culture fungus koji cat dog mouse behaviour consumer diet "Wild Earth"

Summary Sentence: Scientists have created a new form of metal with a molecular structure inspired by Japanese basket weaving.
Justification:
Kagome patterns are created from interlocking triangles. They have inspired the creation of an electrically conducting crystal, made from layers of iron and tin atoms, with each atomic layer arranged in the repeating pattern of a kagome lattice. Arranging

 the metals in kagome patterns at the atomic scale in has produced electromagnetic conditions that could potentially be used to create perfect conductivity at room temperature, which in turn could lead to significant energy efficiency savings. There is still

 much research to do before kagome metals see every day usage. There may also need to be some assessment of the potential environmental impacts of such a material entering future waste streams.
Primary Article Title: Physicists discover new quantum electronic material
Author: Chu, J
Secondary_URLs: Massive Dirac fermions in a ferromagnetic kagome metal - Nature 19/03/2018
Keywords: energy electronic metal conductivity efficiency kagome basket Japan "kagome lattice" tin iron atom crystal electromagnetic waste pollutant impact

Summary Sentence: Realised examples of 3D printed construction are emerging around the World.
Justification:
These developments may be of particular interest to the flood management community as they suggest novel approaches for both constructing and maintaining hard flood defences and other Environment Agency assets, with the possibility of reducing waste, time

 and costs. The prototype of a cement based 3D printed dwelling designed to address global homelessness has been constructed in Austin, Texas. The home cost $10,000 to construct and took 12 hours to build, but costs could come down to as little as $4,000. El

 Salvador, Belize and Haiti will be some of the first countries to benefit from the partnership of construction firm icon and charity New Story’s partnership.A five room house in Nantes, France has recently been constructed and will soon have residents, making

 it the first 3D printed home designed to be permanently occupied. The project called Yhnova used a printer called BatiPrint3D to complete the initial shell of the property using a polymer material. Concrete was then filled into hollow walls for insulation,

 taking 18 days in all. Nante Metropole are now looking at the feasibility of constructing a whole housing development using additive manufacturing. A bus shelter in Shanghai has recently been installed as a demonstration unit. The shelter was constructed ‘overnight’

 using recycled materials.
Primary Article Title: World's first 3D-printed home unveiled in France
Author: Drury, C
Secondary_URLs:
3D-printed bus shelter goes into service - New Atlas 29/12/2017

3D-print a home in 24 hours, a game changer for global homelessness - DesignBoom 12/03/2018
Keywords: "3D printing" construction house housing home homelessness Austin Texas cement concrete Nantes Metropole icon "New Story" charity "El Salvador" Belize Haiti BatiPrint3D Yhnova concrete polymer Shanghai Winsun asset flood defence maintenance

Summary Sentence: IBM recently launched it’s annual “5 in 5” - five technologies that may impact over the next five years.
Justification:
Several of these may have applications within the Environment Agency’s work. Artificial intelligence (AI) powered robot microscopes could bring a new dimension to monitoring the water environment. Many existing monitoring technologies rely on knowing what

 it is you want to find, meaning substances that aren’t of immediate interest aren’t detected. Plankton however are sensitive to whatever chemicals are present in the water. Through using the AI powered microscopes to examine plankton behaviour it may be possible

 to gain a great understanding of pollutants in water in real time. IBM envisages this technology for the marine environment, but it may also have similar applications for monitoring biology in freshwater. Cryptographic anchors - ink dots or tiny computers

 the size of a grain of salt - could become embedded in a myriad of objects. IBM has already developed the small computer which has the processing power of 1990s computer costs around ten cents to produce and literally looks like a grain of salt. Alongside

 technology such as blockchain, cryptographic anchors will help to ensure the authenticity of manufactured components, genetically modified products, identify counterfeit objects demonstrate food provenance. There may also be applications for waste shipment

 tracking, alongside tracking Environment Agency assets.
Primary Article Title: IBM has built the world's smallest computer
Author: Fadilpašić, S
Secondary_URLs: IBM AI predictions include AI powered ocean microbots and unbiased AI - Next Big Future 19/03/2018
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" "artificial intelligence" AI automation robot microscope plankton pollution pollutant ocean marine sea computer "cryptographic anchor" blockchain waste provenance food manufacturing counterfeit regulation biology "water quality" freshwater IBM "5 in 5"

Summary Sentence: Geoengineering solutions to reduce the rate of polar ice melting should warrant more serious consideration, according to a group of academics.
Justification:
The Environment Agency has a keen interest in sea level rise and its impacts on the resilience of coastal flood defences and the communities they protect. Whilst there have been many concepts of geoengineering solutions to climate change, (HSDBi %2314604,

 %2313844, %2313261, %2312917, %2313945), with some experimentation (%2314377, %2314312) and limited application, this new research suggests a practical and relatively simple engineering solution to reduce ice sheet melting. Building a small wall at the snout of the ice

 sheet would reduce the influence of warmer water beneath the immediate surface of the ocean, reducing its melting influence on the ice sheet and allow it to recover. Other solutions could include buttressing the ice shelves where they start to float building

 artificial islands in the sea; and drying glacier beds through draining or freezing the thin film of water they slide on. However it is recognised that geoengineering addresses symptoms, not causes and is not replacement for continued efforts to reduce the

 cause of climate change, namely greenhouse gas emissions. The consequences of employing geoengineering schemes, particularly those involving injecting substances in the the atmosphere (HSDBi %2313269) are also not fully understood.
Primary Article Title: Wolovick&%2358; geoengineering polar glaciers to slow sea-level rise
Secondary_URLs: Geoengineer polar glaciers to slow sea-level rise - Nature 14/03/2018
Keywords: geoengineering glacier ice "sea level" "climate change" polar ice glacier current temperature island draining buttress flooding coast flood incident emergency defence asset

Summary Sentence: New technology to evaluate the effects of chemicals on humans could help make testing cheaper and quicker.
Justification:
However this development may also increase the pace and reduce the costs, or bringing new substances are brought to market without time to consider environmental impacts. Researchers at MIT have combined human tissue linked by microfluidic channels that

 together replicate the interactions of multiple organs. Such a system can reveal how a drug may impact on one organ over time, but also how its effects might migrate to other organs. It is possible to measure both exposure and metabolisation in this way, and

 could help testing drugs designed for humans that can’t be tested on animals due to the differing immune systems. Testing on humans is also complicated by genetic differences and the varying levels of other substances in the body between subjects. The ‘body

 on a chip’ reduces these problems. Testing costs can be reduced using this system, and it may mean the the pace of safety trials can be cut. However this may mean that time needed to explore the full environmental impacts of new treatments is compromised.
Primary Article Title: "Body on a chip" could improve drug evaluation
Author: Trafton, A
Keywords: health chemical drug medicine test treatment organ human "body on a chip" tissue microchannel pharmaceutical regulation pollution pollutant

Summary Sentence: Increased understanding of crop genetics promises crops with greater drought resistance, bigger yields, and more resilient strains.
Justification:
Such discoveries could help to address future global issues around water and food scarcity and pollution from the industrialised application of nitrogen based fertilisers, all of which have relevance to the Environment Agency’s regulatory activity. Researchers

 in Japan have found that two key enzymes are critical for plant growth in nitrogen deprived environments. Understanding how these further could pave the way for plants that can thrive in nutrient poor conditions, or alternatively crops that require far less

 applications of fertilisers than currently, which may help to improve associated water quality impacts such as eutrophication. Farming uses 90 per cent of freshwater globally. Altering the gene expression of crops could also reduce water consumption by 25

 per cent, through ‘tricking plants to partially close their stomata during photosynthesis. Successful experiments on tobacco plants promis applications to other important crops. Sorghum is already an important drought tolerant plant. Genetic experimentation

 has produced grains from both types of flower on the sorghum plant (sessile spikelet (SS) and pedicellate spikelets (PS)), which would normally only produce grains from the SS, tripling yields. Application of nitrogen fertilizers delays flowering, leaving

 crops vulnerable to late-season cold weather, which can impair grain development. Only 40 per cent of applied fertiliser is taken up by plants. Recent work on nitrogen transportation in rice has identified nitrogen transporter OsNRT1.1A as affecting nitrogen

 use and flowering time. Genetically altering rice to produce more OsNRT1.1A. The resulting plants grew taller, were greener, and produced more biomass, compared with regular rice grown on the same amount of nitrogen. They also pulled more nitrate and ammonium

 out of their growing medium. In field trials the OsNRT1.1A-overexpressing plants showed 30-60 per cent higher yields in fields with high and low levels of nitrogen fertilization and flowered one to two weeks earlier than the control plants. These examples

 demonstrate how genetic altered crops can help to address many concerns around future farming and food supply, providing legislation and regulation allows for their development to move beyond the laboratory stage.
Primary Article Title: The secret to tripling the number of grains in sorghum and perhaps other staple crops

Keywords: farming food "water quality" crop yield agriculture regulation sorghum rice gene genetic biology modification nitrogen nitrate "climate change" eutrophication nutrient transporter "water resource" grain "sessile spikelet" SS "pedicellate spikelet" PS OsNRT1.1A stomata photosynthesis

Summary Sentence: A petrochemical plant recently narrowly avoided a serious incident caused by a cyber attack.
Justification:
Previous horizon scanning work has identified the potential risk of cyber attack in causing an environmental incident (HSDBi %2314394, %2313704, %2313671, %2313555, %2313054). The privately owned site, located in Saudi Arabia, was attacked in August 2017. Analysis

 of the code revealed that the intent of the attack was not merely to disrupt operations, but to trigger an explosion. It would have been successful, were it not for a mistake in the attackers code. Thousands of industrial plants worldwide use the same computer

 software supplied by an American company, suggesting that the same route of attack could be exploited at multiple sites. The investigation is ongoing with few details emerging, but the scale, sophistication and intent suggest to the authorities that the attack

 was likely supported at a government level. There may be a role for the Environment Agency to ensure that resilience to cyber attack is more carefully considered by all site operators in light of this Saudi attack.
Primary Article Title: A cyberattack in Saudi Arabia had a deadly goal. Experts fear another try
Author: Perlroth, N & Krauss, C
Keywords: incident emergency cyberattack "cyber attack" internet terrorism explosion site operator regulation petrochemical government crime pollution emergency "Saudi Arabia"
