Summary Sentence: Norfolk County Council is looking towards consumer assistive technologies such as Amazon’s Alexa to help deliver public services.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this example of third party artificial intelligence (AI) being used to deliver public services as it may help inform their own developments. Customer expectation of how services are delivered

 is expected to change in the future, and voice interactions is one aspect of this. There may also be cost savings in embracing the possibilities offered by virtual assistant technologies exemplified by Alexa and Google Assistant. Norfolk is already using telecare

 sensors and detectors, GPS location devices and home activity monitors – to help deliver care to 2,000 people. They are considering following the example set by Hampshire on how Alexa software to support people with disabilities to enable them to perform tasks

 such as switching on appliances using voice commands. Other forms of interaction and interrogation of knowledge bases is like to increasingly happen through Alexa and other platforms, and may be a future area of delivering ‘digital by default’ for the wider

 public sector. Organisations may have to optimise their digital services to reflect this change, regardless of who the provider is, and the Environment Agency being no exception.
Primary Article Title: Norfolk Council looks at Alexa for social care
Author: Say, M
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" AI Amazon Google Alexa "virtual assistant" healthcare Norfolk Hampshire digital service telecare disability sensor detector GPS workforce employee

Summary Sentence: A new technology that outperforms blockchain could become the new standard for operating distributed ledgers.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners are already exploring blockchain applications in various business areas, and therefore may be interested in exploring the technology behind hashgraph, which may have the potential to ‘leapfrog’ blockchain implementation.

 Hashgraph’s inventor is Leemon Baird, and hashgraph appears to superior to blockchain in many ways. It is able to handle over 250,000 transactions per second, compared to blockchain handling around seven per second. Hashgraph is also fairer than blockchain

 by reducing the cost of verifying transactions, and more secure (asynchronous byzantine fault tolerant). Unlike blockchain, verifying hashgraph transactions doesn’t slow the system down or require vast amounts of energy to complete, and therefore has superior

 environmental credentials. Hashgraph works by using a gossip protocol. One computer tells another that a transaction has occurred, and then each computer tells another in the network and so on until every node in the network is aware that the transaction has

 happened. In addition to this each message is transmitted with two ‘hashes’ attached that take up almost no additional data. From analysing these it is possible to model how information has spread and when the network reached a consensus that the transaction

 had happened. There isn’t the bottleneck associated with blockchain’s ‘proof of work’, meaning many more transactions can be processed within a certain timeframe. This makes hashgraph more suited to high volume transactions. Baird’s company already have investment

 and interest from financial institutions. It remains to be seen if hashgraph gains ground on blockchain in which many institutions are already heavily invested.
Primary Article Title: Can hashgraph unseat blockchain as the favoured tech for cryptocurrencies?
Author: D'Monte, L
Secondary_URLs: What is hashgraph? - Hidden Forces 20/03/2018
Keywords: "distributed ledger" blockchain hashgraph "Leemon Baird" cryptocurrency transaction "proof of work" "asynchronous byzantine fault tolerant" energy security

Summary Sentence: The long term sustainability of sea turtle demographics is may by threatened by climate change as warmer seas produce greater numbers of females.
Justification:
Whilst the Environment Agency and partners don’t have specific requisites to protect sea turtles, this new discovery adds to a growing body of evidence (HSDBi %2312062, %2313438, %2314447, %2314593) that climate change could bring a negative impact to the life

 cycle of marine species, the effects of which could be felt by species of interest such as salmon, trout and eels.There may also be repercussions for the sustainability of commercially important fish stocks and aquaculture. Warmer sand temperatures are thought

 to be responsible for turning one of the World’s largest turtle hatching grounds, the northern Great Barrier Reef, almost entirely female - as high as 99 per cent in some cases. While populations may boom in the short term due to increased proportions of females,

 climate change may impact faster than turtles can adapt to it in the long run. Artificially lowering the incubation temperature of the sand at turtle rookeries has been suggested as one mitigation technique.
Primary Article Title: Warm temperatures turning sea turtle population almost entirely female
Author: Walter, K
Secondary_URLs: Environmental warming and feminization of one of the largest sea turtle populations in the World - Current Biology 08/01/2018
Keywords: "climate change" biodiversity turtle sand temperature breeding gender sex female population deomgraphic salmon trout eel fish aquaculture food marine wildlife conservation Australia "Great Barrier Reef" rookery

Summary Sentence: Researchers at MIT have developed technology to allow driverless cars to navigate unmapped roads using a combination of new sensing technology and GPS
Justification: Blank - DFOS
Primary Article Title: A new mit project could bring driverless cars to rural roads
Author: Kristin Houser
Keywords: automated vehicles, self-driving cars, sensors, navigation, artificial intelligence, mapping
GT: automated vehicles, self-driving cars, sensors, navigation, artificial intelligence, mapping

Summary Sentence: The study considers the potential for making deep reductions in household water consumption and water lost from customer supply pipe leaks up to 2065.
Justification:
Pressures of increased demand, driven largely by population growth, and the effects of climate change on resource availability will have long term impacts on the water sector’s ability to deliver services that are resilient and affordable. This study commissioned

 by OFWAT estimated future household demands through the use of scenarios and modelling of water use in the home. The research suggests it is possible to achieve average household consumption of between 50 and 70 l/head/day in 50 years without a reduction in

 the level of utility or quality of water use, but this will not be delivered by the industry working in isolation.Technologies and services exist now that can deliver these savings if implemented more widely; for instance, mandating water labelling for water-consuming

 products to help consumers select suitably water efficient products. However, delivering long term deeper demand savings requires greater awareness of water scarcity issues in the UK, combined with greater leadership in moving this whole area forward. Actions

 are required now to move beyond ‘business as usual’ and start to deliver the reductions needed to meet future long term challenges.
Primary Article Title: The long term potential for deep reductions in household water demand
Author: Rob Lawson, Dene Marshallsay, Daniele DiFiore, Sarah Rogerson, Shana Meeus, Joseph Sanders and Bruce Horton
Keywords: Demand Reduction, Water Efficiency, Water Scarcity

Summary Sentence: Transgenic potato tubers have exhibited a significant improvement in vitamin B6 content, reaching as high as a 150% increase, compared to the control potatoes.
Justification:
Vitamin B6 is a vital metabolite required for living organisms as a cofactor in several metabolic biochemical reactions and recognized as a potent antioxidant molecule which modulates the expression of the proteins responsible for the scavenging of cellular

 reactive oxygen species. It is well established that the microorganisms and plants can synthesize the B6 de novo and all animals, including humans, must acquire it from the plant dietary resources. However, the bioavailability of the vitamin in the edible

 portions of the commonly consumed plants is insufﬁcient to meet the daily recommended doses. The transgenic tubers developed exhibit considerably improved vitamin B6 accumulation (up to 107–150%) in comparison to the untransformed controls potato. This increase

 in vitamin B6 was also correlated with the increased mRNA expression of PDXII gene. The prominent increase in the B6 content of transgenic potato was also associated with the capability to survive under abiotic stresses, therefore, the transgenic lines were

 able to withstand various abiotic stresses imposed by salinity (NaCl) or methyl viologen (MV). The study demonstrated that overexpression of PDXII gene under the control of a constitutive promoter enhanced the accumulation of the vitamin B6 which also augmented

 the tolerance under various abiotic stresses in potato (Solanum tuberosum L.).
Primary Article Title: Overexpression of PDX-II gene in potato (Solanum tuberosum L.) leads to the enhanced accumulation of vitamin B6 in tuber tissues and tolerance to abiotic stresses
Author: Deepak Singh Bagria, Devanshi Chandel Upadhyayaa, Ashwani Kumarb, Chandrama Prakash Upadhyayaa
Keywords: Transgenic plants, biofortification

Summary Sentence: This study suggests continued business-as-usual emissions will likely disrupt many marine ecosystems, reducing the benefits of MPAs that have been suggested as means of adaptation for marine biodiversity.
Justification:
This research shows that despite local protections, the warming associated with continued business-as-usual emissions (RCP8.5) will likely result in further habitat and species losses throughout low-latitude and tropical MPAs. With continued business-as-usual

 emissions, mean sea-surface temperatures within MPAs are projected to increase 0.035 °C per year and warm an additional 2.8 °C by 2100. Under these conditions, the time of emergence (the year when sea-surface temperature and oxygen concentration exceed natural

 variability) is mid-century in 42% of 309 no-take marine reserves. Moreover, projected warming rates and the existing ‘community thermal safety margin’ (the inherent buffer against warming based on the thermal sensitivity of constituent species) both vary

 among ecoregions and with latitude. The community thermal safety margin will be exceeded by 2050 in the tropics and by 2150 for many higher latitude MPAs, with MPAs in the Arctic and Antarctic regions at greatest risk. Species living in many MPAs exist in

 small populations with low genetic diversity, and it's highly likely they won't be able to adapt to ocean warming with subsequent effects on food chains and ecosystems.
Primary Article Title: Climate change threatens the world's marine protected areas
Author: John F. Bruno, Amanda E. Bates, Chris Cacciapaglia, Elizabeth P. Pike, Steven C. Amstrup, Ruben van Hooidonk, Stephanie A. Henson & Richard B. Aronson
Keywords: Climate Change, Marine Biodiversity Adaptation

Summary Sentence: Understanding how anthropogenic CO2 emissions will influence future precipitation is critical for sustainably managing ecosystems, particularly for drought-sensitive tropical forests.
Justification:
Climate models predict that an increase in greenhouse gases will dry out the Amazon rainforest in the future while causing wetter conditions in the woodlands of Africa and Indonesia. This study suggests that the plant physiological response to increasing

 CO2 is a primary mechanism responsible for this pattern. When more CO2 is present, stomata do not open as widely, which reduces the amount of water evaporated into the atmosphere via transpiration. According to the research, this small

 process at the plant level, multiplied across the rainforest, will cause changes in the atmosphere, affecting the way winds blow and the flow of moisture coming from the ocean. Applying a simulation design in the Community Earth System Model in which CO2 increases are isolated over individual continents, it demonstrates that different circulation, moisture and stability changes arise over each continent due to declines in stomatal conductance and transpiration. The sum of local atmospheric responses over individual

 continents explains the pan-tropical precipitation asymmetry. In other tropical forest regions across Asia and the Indian Ocean, the heating compared to the nearby ocean will enhance a natural ocean-land breeze, pulling in more moisture from these neighboring

 ocean systems to increase rainfall over the forests This analysis suggests that South American forests may be more vulnerable to rising CO2 than Asian or African forests.
Primary Article Title: Forest response to rising CO2 drives zonally asymmetric rainfall change over tropical land
Author: Gabriel J. Kooperman, Yang Chen, Forrest M. Hoffman, Charles D. Koven, Keith Lindsay, Michael S. Pritchard, Abigail L. S. Swann & James T. Randerson
Keywords: Climate Change, Amazon

Summary Sentence:
An enhancement of the natural process of the chemical weathering of rocks could remove substantial amounts of CO2 from the atmosphere, aiming to offset some unavoidable anthropogenic emissions in order to comply with the Paris Agreement, while

 at the same time it may decrease ocean acidification.
Justification:
This study provides the first comprehensive assessment of economic costs, energy requirements, technical parameterization, and global and regional carbon removal potential. The crucial parameters defining this potential are the grain size and weathering

 rates. The main uncertainties about the potential relate to weathering rates and rock mass that can be integrated into the soil. The discussed results do not specifically address the enhancement of weathering through microbial processes, feedback of geogenic

 nutrient release, and bioturbation. As well as dunite rock, predominantly bearing olivine (in the form of forsterite) as the mineral that has been previously proposed to be best suited for carbon removal, the study also covers basaltic rock. The results show

 that enhanced weathering is an option for carbon dioxide removal that could be competitive already at 60 US $ t−1 CO2 removed for dunite, but only at 200 US $ t−1 CO2 removed for basalt. The potential carbon removal on cropland areas

 could be as large as 95 Gt CO2 a−1 for dunite and 4.9 Gt CO2 a−1 for basalt. The best suited locations are warm and humid areas, particularly in India, Brazil, South-East Asia and China, where almost 75% of the global potential can be

 realized.
Primary Article Title: Potential and costs of carbon dioxide removal by enhanced weathering of rocks
Author: Jessica Strefler, Thorben Amann, Nico Bauer, Elmar Kriegler and Jens Hartmann
Keywords: Geoengineering, enhanced rock weathering

Summary Sentence: Zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles in food packaging could be negatively impacting on nutrient absorption in humans.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this research as the implications could apply to other animals that come into contact with ZnO nanoparticles, either through water pollution or waste. This particular research established a link

 between nutrient absorption in the intestine with ZnO nanoparticles in food packaging. ZnO is used in certain canned foods due to its antimicrobial properties and to prevent staining from foods containing sulphur. While it is already established that ZnO can

 kill cells, this research looked at how ZnO impaired cell function. It was found that ZnO remodelled or caused loss of microvilli, the tiny projections on the surface of the intestinal absorptive cells that help to increase the surface area available for absorption.

 Lower surface area tends decrease nutrient absorption. There were also some indications that the ZnO nanoparticles could cause inflammation at high doses, increasing intestinal permeability, which could lead to unwanted compounds entering the bloodstream.

 The scale and long term impacts of this are currently not known. This study may prove grounds for future research to establish if ZnO nanoparticles may be impacting on creatures other than humans in the environment. **ORIGINAL ARTICLE RETRACTED** - see related

 articles in all references tab for more details. Although the article has been retracted, it is possible that some of the findings could still apply.
Primary Article Title: Food packaging could be negatively affecting nutrient absorption in your body
Secondary_URLs:
Environmental dynamics of metal oxide nanoparticles in heterogeneous systems&%2358; A review - Journal of Hazardous Materials 08/05/2018

https&%2358;//www.nutraingredients.com/Article/2018/05/02/Gut-health-study-recalled-after-zinc-levels-in-tuna-miscalculated - NutraIngredients.com 08/05/2018

Retracted Article&%2358; ZnO nanoparticles affect intestinal function in an in vitro model - Food And Function 20/02/2018
Keywords: nanoparticle nanotechnology "zinc oxide" ZnO intestine food additive chemical nutrient absorption antimicrobial AMR sulphur canned microvilli "cell function" biology biodiversity health pollution pollutant "water quality"

Summary Sentence: Global change is causing freshwater species to be lost twice as fast as in any other ecosystem, and new research, which studied Welsh rivers and streams for over 30 years, has found that the number of specialist invertebrates are dwindling.
Justification:
The data revealed that specialist organisms, like predatory flatworms, certain stoneflies or caddis larvae, are in sharp decline, as their precise needs make them vulnerable to changes in climate. Not only is the change in their environment causing their

 numbers to decrease, but once these species become scarce they have limited ability to recolonise their previously occupied habitats. The study used use 30 yr of invertebrate data from a metacommunity of 10 streams in Wales, UK, combined with regional surveys,

 to examine temporal changes in multiple biodiversity measures at local, metacommunity, and regional scales. There was no change in taxonomic or functional α‐diversity and spatial β‐diversity metrics at any scale over the 30‐yr time series, suggesting a relative

 stasis in the system and no evidence for on‐going homogenization. However, temporal changes in mean species composition were evident.
Primary Article Title: Lifting the veil&%2358; richness measurements fail to detect systematic biodiversity change over three decades
Author: Stefano Larsen  Jonathan M. Chase  Isabelle Durance  Steve J. Ormerod
Keywords: Freshwater Biodiversity Loss, Species Richness, Ecosystem Functioning

Summary Sentence:
Along urbanised coastlines, urban infrastructure is increasingly becoming the dominant habitat, but these structures are often poor surrogates for natural habitats, and a diversity of eco‐engineering approaches have been trialled to enhance their biodiversity,

 with varying success.
Justification:
Over 50% of the human population now lives in urbanised areas, with areas within 100 km of the coastline particularly heavily developed, housing over 40% of the global population and 60% of its largest cities. In addition to introducing pollutants, such

 as heavy metals, nutrients, artificial light and sound, to marine and coastal habitats, urban environments introduce infrastructure. This infrastructure is used for a range of purposes including coastal protection (e.g. seawalls, breakwaters, groynes), boating

 or recreational activities (e.g. marinas, piers, pontoons), supply of energy or resources (e.g. oil, gas platforms) and enhancement of fisheries yield (e.g. artificial reefs). This results in modification of ecological connectivity, ecosystem functioning and

 services, and the physico‐chemical environment. This study undertook a quantitative meta‐analysis and qualitative review of 109 studies to compare the efficacy of common eco‐engineering approaches (e.g. increasing texture, crevices, pits, holes, elevations

 and habitat‐forming taxa) in enhancing the biodiversity of key functional groups of organisms, across a variety of habitat settings and spatial scales. All interventions, with one exception, increased the abundance or number of species of one or more of the

 functional groups considered, but the magnitude of effect varied markedly among groups and habitat settings. This indicates the importance of developing site‐specific approaches that match the target taxa and dominant stressors. Furthermore, because different

 types of intervention are effective at enhancing different groups of organisms, ideally a range of approaches should be applied simultaneously to maximise niche diversity.
Primary Article Title: Eco-engineering urban infrastructure for marine and coastal biodiversity&%2358; Which interventions have the greatest ecological benefit?
Author: Elisabeth M. A. Strain  Celia Olabarria  Mariana Mayer‐Pinto  Vivian Cumbo Rebecca L. Morris  Ana B. Bugnot  Katherine A. Dafforn  Eliza Heery  Louise B. Firth Paul R. Brooks  Melanie J. Bishop
Keywords: Ecological Engineering, Urban Ecosystems, Biodiversity

Summary Sentence: This study highlights artificial light as a driver of vegetation change in urban, suburban and semi-natural ecosystems, and where possible, of minimising or excluding artificial light from habitats of conservation importance.
Justification:
While in recent years there have been advances in understanding the effects of artificial light at night on the behaviour and physiology of animals in the wild, much less is known about the impacts on wild plants and natural or semi‐natural vegetation

 composition. In a long‐term experimental field study, a semi‐natural grassland was exposed to artificial light at intensities and wavelengths typical of those experienced by roadside vegetation under street lighting. It affected the trajectory of vegetation

 change, leading to significant differences in biomass and plant cover in the dominant species. Changes in flowering phenology were variable between years, with grass species flowering between 4 days earlier and 12 days later under artificial light. Opportunities

 to reduce the ecological consequences of artificial light at night range from novel adaptive lighting dimming technologies, to switching lighting off for all or part of the night or simple shielding to direct light only where it is most needed.
Primary Article Title: Artificial light at night alters grassland vegetation species composition and phenology
Author: Jonathan Bennie  Thomas W. Davies  David Cruse  Fraser Bell  Kevin J. Gaston
Keywords: Light Pollution; Biodiversity; Conservation

Summary Sentence:
This study highlights the consequences of focussing on key specific conservation triggers such as the rarity of a species or its financial impact - for example the amount of weed seeds (which impact on crops) eaten by birds - without also looking at the

 wider, cultural value of a species and its importance to society.
Justification:
A major task for decision makers is deciding how to consider monetary, cultural and conservation values of biodiversity explicitly when planning sustainable land use. Constructing ecosystem-level indices, requires weighting the relative contribution of

 species to the different values. Analysing 38 species of farmland bird - all of which breed in the UK - the study scored them according to the three key values; conservation priority, economic value and cultural value. Using poetry as an indicator of the cultural

 value of this set of birds over a long time span, the team analysed the number of mentions of each species in a poem, taken from a database of over a million poems. They found that by focusing singularly on rarity or extent of decline (common features of conservation

 schemes), weed seed predation or poetry only a small subset of species was important for each value. However, a larger proportion of the 38 species were important when contribution to all three types of values was considered simultaneously. The study suggests

 acknowledging the importance of the range of biodiversity values that are apparent from different perspectives is critical if the full value of biodiversity to society is to be realised.
Primary Article Title: Species contributions to single biodiversity values under-estimate whole community contribution to a wider range of values to society
Author: Matthew Hiron, Tomas Pärt, Gavin M. Siriwardena & Mark J. Whittingham
Keywords: Economic valuation, biodiversity, cultural ecosystem services

Summary Sentence: Airponix technology uses a nutrient-rich 'fog' instead of soil to grow vegetables, promising yields up to 50 times higher than commercial growers.
Justification:
British start-up Airponix will harvest its first large crop of potatoes grown without soil with minimal costs and environmental degradation. The nutrient-rich fog is sprayed out of modified inkjet printers down long polythene tunnels of crops, as well

 as not requiring arable land, it uses 85% less water than conventional agriculture and little energy to operate. Labour is reduced as harvesting is a clean process and the potatoes don't need washing and the crop does not require herbicides, fungicides or

 pesticides. The spray technology produces tiny droplets better suited to conventional crops such as rice and wheat than existing aeroponic methods and could be used in arid or degraded regions.
Primary Article Title: Green growth&%2358; British soil-free framing start-up prepares for first harvest
Keywords: Controlled Environment Farming; Aeroponix

Summary Sentence: A newly developed technology that removes phosphorus from stored livestock manure could help to improve water quality and recover precious resources.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in the regulatory applications within the agricultural sector. Excess phosphorus originating from applications to land of manure and slurry can lead to water quality issues such as eutrophication. A new system

 devised by Penn State University and the U.S. Department of Agriculture called MAPHEX (MAnure PHosphorus EXtraction) is a three stage process designed to process manure on dairy farms. The three stage process involves liquid-solid separation with an auger

 press and centrifuge; chemical treatment with the addition of iron sulphate; and finally filtration with diatomaceous earth. MAPHEX has been designed as a mobile unit to serve clusters of small to medium farms, and would need to become permanently installed

 for larger farms. During tests with dairy hear sizes ranging from 150 to 2,700 cows, approximately 98 percent of the phosphorus was removed from manure slurries, along with 93 percent of the solids at a cost of $750 per cow, making for challenging economics

 currently unless the regulation is there to support its use. The system may also have applications in reducing the impact of farming related pollution incidents.
Primary Article Title: New Penn State-USDA patented technology removes phosphorus from manure
Author: Mulhollem, J
Keywords: "water quality" farming agriculture regulation livestock dairy manure phosphorus nutrient eutrophication waste pollution incident slurry land field fertiliser MAPHEX "MAnure PHosphorus EXtraction" centrifuge auger "iron sulphate" USDA filtration "diatomaceous earth" diatomite mineral cow

Summary Sentence: The World’s first combined heat and power (CHP) scheme that utilises concentrated solar power (CSP) and a biomass boiler has become operational in Denmark.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may wish to consider how further developments of this technology could impact on regulatory activity. The scheme is to provide power in the town of Brønderslev, and can be seen as an example of decentralisation. The scheme uses Organic

 Rankine Cycle (ORC) (HSDBi %2311144) to turn the energy into district heating and electricity. The CSP plant occupies 26,929m2 and consists of 40 rows x 125m U-shaped mirrors that collect the sunrays throughout the day and reflect them onto a receiver pipe.

 This receiver pipe is surrounded by a special glass vacuum tube and inside this runs – only heated by the sun – thermal oil with temperatures up to 330 °C. The system is designed to either provide the energy needed to drive a turbine and produce electricity,

 or deliver lower temperatures for use in heating systems. When combined with biomass the system provides extreme flexibility to take account of current community demand and reduce associated CO2 emissions.
Primary Article Title: A world first renewable energy system inaugurated in Denmark
Secondary_URLs: Organic Rankine cycle - Wikipedia 30/04/2018
Keywords: energy "fossil fuel" decentralisation solar CHP "combined heat and power" CSP "concentrated solar power" "organic Rankine cycle" ORC biomass Denmark electricity heaty turbine "carbon dioxide" "greenhouse gas" GHG regulation Brønderslev

Summary Sentence: Article about research from Loughborough University found that to avoid collisions with cyclists, autonomous emergency breaking systems need to be able to detect cyclists over a much larger field of view than is needed to detect pedestrians.
Justification:
The rise of automatic emergency braking, also known as autonomous emergency braking, offers an opportunity to make manual driving much safer long before the advent of self-driving cars. UK accident data was analysed to show that cars tend to encounter

 many more cyclists than pedestrians at road intersections. That might lead engineers to design a car’s software to prioritize keeping a lookout for cyclists coming from the side when a car is edging into an intersection or roundabout. The results could also

 prove helpful for self-driving cars that usually have sensors covering a 360-degree field of view. That’s because such research could help prioritize the operation of the image-recognition and decision-making software, assuming that not all sensor data collected

 can be fully processed in real-time. Developments in road vehicle automation are relevant in light of the accident in March 2018,which involved a self-driving Uber car and lead to the death of a cyclist.
Primary Article Title: Accidents show smart cars need wide vision to spot cyclists
Author: Jeremy Hsu
Keywords: Autonomous vehicle emergency breaking driverless car road accident

Summary Sentence: Three commercially released facial-analysis programs from major technology companies demonstrate both skin-type and gender biases.
Justification:
Three commercially released facial-analysis programs from major technology companies demonstrate skin-type and gender biases, according to a new paper researchers from MIT and Stanford University will present later this month at the Conference on Fairness,

 Accountability, and Transparency. The three programs’ error rates were tested and the researchers' found that&%2358; in determining the gender of light-skinned men the programs' error rates were never worse than 0.8%. However, for darker-skinned women, the error

 rates were more than 20% in one case and more than 34% in the other two. The findings raise questions about how today’s neural networks, which learn to perform computational tasks by looking for patterns in huge data sets, are trained and evaluated. For instance,

 according to the paper, researchers at a major U.S. technology company claimed an accuracy rate of more than 97 percent for a face-recognition system they’d designed. But the data set used to assess its performance was more than 77 percent male and more than

 83 percent white. The three programs were general-purpose facial-analysis systems, which could be used to match faces in different photos as well as to assess characteristics such as gender, age, and mood. All three systems treated gender classification as

 a binary decision — male or female — which made their performance on that task particularly easy to assess statistically. But the same types of bias probably afflict the programs’ performance on other tasks, too.
Primary Article Title: Study finds gender and skin-type bias in commercial artificial-intelligence systems
Keywords: AI, gender, ethnicity, bias

Summary Sentence: An AI tool has been developed that is capable of predicting the onset of psychosis.
Justification:
An artificial intelligence (AI) tool has been developed that is capable of predicting with relative precision the onset of psychosis in a patient. This builds upon previous work that constructed a predictive model. By training the AI using what they’d

 learned from the 2015 study, the researchers were able to build a retrospective model of patient speech patterns, which could’ve predicted the eventual onset of psychosis in patients with an 83% accuracy. Had it been applied to the patients from the first

 study, the AI would’ve predicted with 79% accuracy which patients eventually developed psychosis.The tool may help to overcome subjectivity in mental health assessments; traditional approaches to evaluating patients are quite subjective. The researchers believe

 that using AI and machine learning as tools for so-called computational psychiatry could eliminate this subjectivity and improve the chances of accurate assessments.
Primary Article Title: Prediction of psychosis across protocols and risk cohorts using automated language analysis
Author:
Cheryl M. Corcoran
Facundo Carrillo
Diego Fernández‐Slezak
Gillinder Bedi
Casimir Klim
Daniel C. Javitt
Carrie E. Bearden
Guillermo A. Cecchi
Keywords: AI, mental health, psychosis

Summary Sentence: Report by the House of Lords Ad Hoc Committee on the policy implications of Artificial Intelligence
Justification:
This Lords Committee spent approximately a year looking at AI and its implications for policy makers. Its conclusions included that&%2358; * UK is in a strong position to be among the world leaders in the development of AI * AI has the potential to offer significant

 economic opportunities * Many of the hopes and the fears presently associated with AI are out of kilter with reality (such as super-intelligence and a world without work) * AI will have significant implications for the ways in which society lives and works,

 and may accelerate the digital disruption in the jobs marke * In order to encourage adoption across the UK, the public sector should use targeted procurement to provide a boost to AI development and deployment * There is no consensus regarding the adequacy

 of existing legislation should AI systems malfunction or underperform.
Primary Article Title: AI in the uk&%2358; ready, willing and able?
Author: House of Lords Select Committee on Artificial Intelligence
Keywords: Disruptive technology data digital artificial intelligence employment social impact

Summary Sentence: Algorithms used to predict the likelihood that a defendant will commit a crime, has been shown to be no more accurate than people with little, or no, criminal justice expertise.
Justification:
In the United States, algorithms are commonly used to predict the likelihood that a criminal defendant will commit a crime, and these predictions influence pre trial, parole, and sentencing decisions. Commercial software, such as the widely used COMPAS

 system, promises to make these predictions more accurate than human judgments. Dressel and Farid show that COMPAS's impressive-sounding 137-feature black box is nearly equivalent to a trivial linear classifier using two features, and both approaches are no

 more accurate or fair than predictions made by people with little or no criminal justice expertise.
Primary Article Title: Algorithms fail to improve predictions
Author: Clauset, Aaron
Keywords: Algorithm, accuracy, prediction, crime

Summary Sentence: Conversations between adults and children are more important to children's language development that the number of words they hear in their first 3 years of life.
Justification:
MIT cognitive scientists have now found that conversation between an adult and a child appears to change the child’s brain, and that this back-and-forth conversation is actually more critical to language development than the difference in size of vocabulary

 (following the 1995 study that found that children from higher-income families hear about 30 million more words during their first three years of life than children from lower-income families). The findings suggest that parents can have considerable influence

 over their children’s language and brain development by simply engaging them in conversation, the researchers say. This has important implications for how children are taught in early childhood, and specifically in pre-school settings. It may also have implications

 for advice given to parents and teaching and learning tools.
Primary Article Title: Back-and-forth exchanges boost children's brain response to language
Keywords: Education, educational attainment, learning, children

Summary Sentence: Mushroom based substances could be key to the sustainable materials of the future.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in the growing number of examples of fungi based materials being developed, as they have implications for a range of business interests, from agriculture, waste management and even incident response. This article

 highlights the work of a student studying for a PhD in mechanical engineering and her interest in fungi based materials. Different fungi specialise in ‘eating’ different materials, ranging from sawdust to plastic to heavy metals and oils. Through careful selection

 and possibly some genetic manipulation it is possible to use fungi to turn potentially problematic materials into useful resources, or sustainable alternatives to common products. The student has been testing the outputs from two companies (Mycoworks and Evocative

 - Modern Meadow (HSDBi %2314625) is another company not referenced here) who are producing leather alternatives from mycelium, the roots of the mushrooms, with much less environmental impact than real leather from livestock farming.. She also highlights uses

 in construction, taking materials such as sawdust or cardboard and converting them into more durable building materials. She suggests that the applications to cardboard in particular could give homeless people more robust and durable accommodation. Mushrooms

 could also have a role in cleaning up oil spills. Straw bales soaked in crude oil from a spill could be injected with a specific mushroom spore that will eat up the oil, breaking down any potentially problematic substances along the way. The remaining material

 could then be used as fertiliser. Similar applications could be developed for contaminated land and sewage related pollution.
Primary Article Title: From pollution cleanup to building houses, what can't mushrooms do?
Author: Brice, A
Keywords: waste resources material sustainable mushroom fungi mycelium construction incident emergency industry farming agriculture regulation leather livestock homelessness oil spill "contaminated land" sewage plastic metal toxic fertiliser straw MycoWorks "Modern Meadow" Evocative

Summary Sentence: Marine zooplankton may considerably alter the physical and biogeochemical structure of the water column, with potentially widespread effects owing to their high abundance in climatically important regions of the ocean
Justification:
Biologically generated turbulence has been proposed as an important contributor to nutrient transport and ocean mixing. However, to produce non-negligible transport and mixing, such turbulence must produce eddies at scales comparable to the length scales

 of stratification in the ocean. It has previously been argued that biologically generated turbulence is limited to the scale of the individual animals involved, which would make turbulence created by highly abundant centimetre-scale zooplankton such as krill

 irrelevant to ocean mixing. Swarms of krill migrate daily in vertical columns, feeding at the ocean surface by night, before retreating hundreds of metres deep by day. To assess whether this could have a significant effect on ocean mixing, this study placed

 brine shrimp in vertical tanks filled with salt water, and induced the animals' day/night migrations up and down via lights mimicking the rise and fall of sunlight.  The water flow was filmed with the aid of dyes and tiny glass beads to help visualise the strength of the eddies the swarms generated, which showed that the animals' passing didn't just distribute water in small, localised regions, but churned significant

 volumes of proxy ocean. The results illustrate the potential for marine zooplankton to considerably alter the physical and biogeochemical structure of the water column, with potentially widespread effects owing to their high abundance in climatically important

 regions of the ocean.
Primary Article Title: Vertically migrating swimmers generate aggregation-scale eddies in a stratified column
Author: Isabel A. Houghton, Jeffrey R. Koseff, Stephen G. Monismith & John O. Dabiri
Keywords: Ocean Productivity, Ocean Climate Modelling

Summary Sentence: A new approach to plant protection involves vaccinating plants against pathogens with double-stranded RNA molecules that can be sprayed directly on the leaves
Justification: Novel technologies are being sought to replace the traditional pesticides used to protect plants, particularly edible plants such as cereals. Emerging strategies for crop protection involve the external treatment of plants with double‐stranded (ds)RNA to trigger RNA interference. However, applying this technology in greenhouses and fields depends on dsRNA quality, stability and efficient large‐scale production. RNA interference is an innate defence mechanism of plants, animals and other eukaryotic organisms against pathogens. The vaccine can be targeted to the chosen pathogen by using RNA molecules which share sequence identity with the pest's genes and prevents their expression. Double-stranded RNA molecules have been produced through chemical synthesis, both as drug molecules and for research purposes, but such production methods are inefficient and expensive for plant protection. This research developed a new production method for double-stranded RNA molecules. The method uses the RNA amplification system of a bacteriophage, i.e. a bacteria-destroying virus, and the RNA production takes place in bacterial cells.The study multiplied the dsRNA sequences homologous to tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) and the produced TMV‐derived dsRNAs was shown to inhibit TMV propagation when applied to infected Nicotiana benthamiana plants.
Primary Article Title: Synthetic biology approach for plant protection using dsRNA
Author: Annette Niehl,  Marjukka Soininen,  Minna M. Poranen,  Manfred Heinlein
Keywords: Plant Vaccination, RNAi, Novel Plant Protection Method

Summary Sentence: Innovative approaches to collecting street litter could help reduce resource pressures and remove potentially toxic material from the environment.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in these developments from a waste management and water quality perspective. A designer is developing a range of products made from recycled chewing gum. Chewing gum is a problematic waste, but it can be recycled

 if collected. Anna Bullus has developed the infrastructure and industrial connections needed to recycle the synthetic rubber base of chewing gum into a range of plastic and rubber like products, such as reusable cups, shoe soles and wellington boots. Crucially

 her business model revolves around a behaviour change for people, namely using her chewing gum collection containers (also made of recycled chewing gum) when disposing of their gum. Such increasing streaming of waste collection is also a necessary step in

 moving towards a circular economy. Related to this is another startup that is leveraging the potential of animal infrastructure in waste management. Crowded Cities is proposing to train crows to collect cigarette butts from the streets and return them to a

 specially designed collection point called a Crowbar that verifies that a cigarette butt has been returned before rewarding the crows with food. Cigarette butts can pose a risk to the environment as plastic litter but also due to their toxic chemical (HSDBi

 %239602) and metal (HSDBi %2314047) content. However they also show potential for use in construction materials (HSDBi %2314380 & %2314144) and as an energy storage medium (HSDBi %2312800), providing there is a cost effective incentive to collect and separate this waste

 stream. Crows are intelligent, social animals. The company believe that trained crows will demonstrate to other crows to collect cigarette butts in exchange for food, expanding the impact of the scheme significantly.
Primary Article Title: World Hacks&%2358; a surprising new afterlife for chewing gum
Author: Shaw, D
Secondary_URLs: The bizarre project to teach CROWS to clean up city streets by collecting cigarette butts in exchange for treats - The Daily Mail 13/10/2017
Keywords: waste recycling collection "circular economy" material resource "chewing gum" litter "cigarette butt" cigarette energy pollution pollutant toxic regulation "water quality" construction "Crowded Cities" Crowbar "animal infrastructure" crow bird clothing "Anna Bullus" design

Summary Sentence: Scientists are working to make lithium batteries safer, reducing the risk of explosion and fire.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may be interested in this research as there is already concerns around the flammable potential of lithium batteries at end of life and this risk these could pose to waste management activities. While lithium is an ideal metal for

 conducting electricity at high capacity, however despite its wide use in rechargeable batteries it is unsuited for this use due to safety risks. During the charge and discharge cycle lithium undergoes ‘thermal runaway’, whereby lithium dendrites are deposited,

 eventually penetrating the separator, causing and potentially an explosion or fire. With the prevalence of lithium ion batteries on the rise, there is a need to solve this basic problem. One research team have been experimenting with adding types of magnesium

 salts called magnesium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide that can combine with lithium, which successfully halted lithium dendrite formation. Further work is needed to devise a way to actually reverse dendrite formation which is needed in rechargeable batteries,

 but this line of research provides a possible way to mitigate waste management concerns around lithium ion batteries for the future.
Primary Article Title: Scientists take step toward safer batteries by trimming lithium branches
Secondary_URLs: Suppressing the effect of lithium dendritic growth by the addition of magnesium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide - Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics 05/12/2017
Keywords: energy waste battery rechargeable lithium fire explosion incident emergency regulation "lithium ion" magnesium salt "magnesium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide" "lithium dendrite" "thermal runaway"

Summary Sentence: The development of a new type of resin could help to close the sustainability loop on wind turbine manufacturing.
Justification:
The development of a new type of resin could help to close the sustainability loop on wind turbine manufacturing. This development should be of interest to the Environment Agency from a waste management perspective. As renewable energy grows there are

 likely to be more wind turbines in existence. Turbine blades are made from a composite material with a shelf life of around 20 to 25 years, which can be shortened by exposure to the environment - lightning strikes can shorten blades lifespan (HSDBi %2312444)

 leading to more frequent replacement, for example. The composite nature of blades construction and lack of suitable facilities makes them difficult and uneconomic to recycle, meaning many are currently destined for landfill (HSDBi %2312371). The newly developed

 lightweight, liquid thermoplastic resin, called Elium, allows for seamless blending with glass or carbon fibres, enabling recycling at end of life. Elium.generates its own heat which allows fibreglass turbine blades to cure at room temperature without creating

 flaws. This allows for continuous reinforcement of a blade, reducing the need for multiple materials, meaning recycling is much easier.. Current production has been on test sized components, with a look to moving to commercial sized production soon.
Primary Article Title: New recyclable resin makes wind turbine blades much more sustainable
Keywords: energy renewable wind turbine waste "carbon fibre" fibreglass resin curing Elium recycling sustainable "circular economy" weather lightning landfill regulation blade manufacturing

Summary Sentence: A study has suggested It is possible to limit warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial temperatures without using negative emissions from bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS).
Justification:
Mitigation scenarios that achieve the ambitious targets included in the Paris Agreement typically rely on greenhouse gas emission reductions combined with net carbon dioxide removal (CDR) from the atmosphere, mostly accomplished through large-scale application

 of bioenergy with carbon capture and storage, and afforestation. However, CDR strategies face several difficulties such as reliance on underground CO2 storage and competition for land with food production and biodiversity protection. The question arises whether

 alternative deep mitigation pathways exist. This study explores alternatives including lifestyle changes, agricultural intensification and lab-grown meat, as well as an even more rapid adoption of renewables and energy efficiency. Some of these have tended

 to be excluded from the scenarios previously used, because they are hard for scientists to model. As integrated assessment models select technologies on the basis of relative costs, they normally concentrate on reduction measures for which reasonable estimates

 of future performance and costs can be made. This implies that some possible response strategies receive less attention, as their future performance is more speculative or their introduction would be based on drivers other than cost, such as lifestyle change

 or more rapid electrification.
Primary Article Title: Alternative pathways to the 1.5°C target reduce the need for negative emission technologies
Author: Detlef P. van Vuuren, Elke Stehfest, David E. H. J. Gernaat, Maarten van den Berg, David L. Bijl, Harmen Sytze de Boer, Vassilis Daioglou, Jonathan C. Doelman, Oreane Y. Edelenbosch, Mathijs Harmsen, Andries F. Hof & Mariësse A. E. van Sluisveld
Keywords: Climate Change, Mitigation Pathways, BECCS

Summary Sentence: An electronic ‘glass’ that can replicate the taste of a range of drinks has been developed.
Justification:
This is the latest of examples of electronic taste devices that could eventually impact the food industry. The glass, known as the Vocktail (Virtual Cocktail) consists of a cocktail glass attached to a 3D-printed structure which electronics for multisensory

 stimulation. The Vocktail has scent cartridges and micro air pumps. LEDs are used to change the colour of the water in the glass, and electrodes on the rim can vary their current to stimulate the sensation of sweet, sour, salty and bitter. Working in combination

 these elements can fool the brain into tasting a drink virtually. Customised ‘drinks’ could be shared digitally so that others can experience the same taste. The Vocktail echoes similar innovations in this field from the same researchers, such as facial electrodes

 that could enable the wearer to taste and chew in a virtual environment. Applications for this technololgy could include virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR), dieting or to enhance sensations of taste and smell that have been impaired by illness,

 and advertising. From the perspective of Defra and partners, ‘digital food’ may have potential in marketing UK farming produce globally. It could be used to enhance the palatability of certain foods that may have lower environmental impact but also lower appeal.

 And activists could utilise the technology to convey the scale of odour problems from sites of high public interest to the World, which may lead to political pressure for such issues to be resolved, for example.
Primary Article Title: Say goodbye to cocktails and hello to the Vocktail&%2358; a virtual cocktail
Author: Berboucha, M
Secondary_URLs:
Virtual sweet&%2358; simulating sweet sensation using thermal stimulation on the tip of the tongue - Association for Computing Machinery 16/10/2016

Vocktail&%2358; a virtual cocktail for pairing digital taste, smell, and color sensations - Association for Computing Machinery 23/10/2017

Face electrodes let you taste and chew in virtual reality - New Scientist 04/11/2016
Keywords: food drink "virtual reality" digital activism health diet illness VR "mixed reality" "social media" waste operator installation trade export marketing regulation odour Vocktail electronics "3D printing"

Summary Sentence: New research confirms that urban agriculture could make a significant contribution to food production whilst delivering a range of ecosystems services.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may need to consider how a growing urban farming sector may impact on current regulations around agriculture and installations, plus the extent how the impacts of rural agriculture could change. Using a range of data including population,

 weather and land cover, researchers estimated that urban farming could contribute as much as 180 million metric tons of food a year, around 10 per cent of the global output of legumes, roots and tubers, and vegetables. Additional benefits include reducing

 the urban heat-island, avoiding stormwater runoff, nitrogen fixation, pest control, and energy savings, making urban agriculture potentially worth up to $160 billion annually. This demonstrates that urban natural capital could be greatly improved to deliver

 a range of benefits, and that by using a data driven approach it may be possible to determine a better between urban infrastructure and green space, be it for agriculture or natural habitats.
Primary Article Title: Big data suggests big potential for urban farming
Author: Crawford, A
Secondary_URLs: A global geospatial ecosystem services estimate of urban agriculture - Earth's Future 10/01/2018
Keywords: farming agriculture urban food vegetable root tuber legume "big data" land use land cover regulation water quality rural "natural capital" "ecosystems services" habitat planning

Summary Sentence: Europe is taking steps towards electrifying shipping.
Justification:
While this could deliver significant improvements to carbon budgets and air quality in coastal areas, it is not without technical and regulatory challenges. Shipping emissions currently fall outside of the Paris Climate Accord, and EU emissions regulation

 - as air transport emissions used to before falling under Environment Agency administered regulation. Shipping constitutes around three per cent of global carbon emissions. However as terrestrial CO2 emissions decrease this could increase to 17 per cent by

 2050. The cruise ship industry has also come under the spotlight in recent times for the amounts of carbon dioxide, sulphur dioxide and other pollutants (a mid-size cruise ship burns through as much as 150 tonnes of fuel a day, emitting as much particulate

 matter as one million cars).Countries such as Norway with a plentiful supply of renewable hydropower and a high demand for short sea journeys are embracing innovations in battery technology to develop electric boats for inshore use where it is easy to charge

 the boats at each end of their short journeys. One electric ferry reduced CO2 emissions by 95 percent and operating costs by 80 percent. And later in 2018 five part EU financed all-electric, driverless, emissions-free barges will ship freight along canals

 linking the ports of Amsterdam, Antwerp, and Rotterdam. Despite these signs decarbonising and electrifying long range ocean going vehicles presents more of a challenge. Aside from the technological challenges the current political climate discourages the move.

 Shipping emissions fall outside of the Paris Agreement. The EU has established monitoring criteria and energy efficiency standards with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) but there has been resistance from the industry, leading to threats from the

 EU to include the sector’s CO2 pollution in its emissions-trading scheme. Previous research (HSDBi %2313624) has suggested that air along coasts contains hazardous nanoparticle pollution from sea traffic and may be responsible for 10,000 premature deaths a year

 from the North and Baltic seas alone. Populations tend to be concentrated in coastal areas, and as interest in air quality moves up the political agenda there may be increasing pressure to reduce and regulate emissions from the shipping sector.
Primary Article Title: Europe takes first steps in electrifying World's shipping fleets
Author: Hockenos, P
Secondary_URLs: NABU 2017 cruise ship rankings&%2358; still dirty - Nature 05/09/2017
Keywords: "air quality" shipping freight water sea ocean marine regulation emission pollution pollutant health coast population EU energy renewable hydropower IMO "International Maritime Organization" transport battery "carbon dioxide" "sulphur dioxide" nanoparticle

Summary Sentence: New techniques to produce graphene could lead to industrial scale production of superconductors and edible electronics.
Justification:
The environmental impacts of increasing amounts of graphene in the world may need to be considered by the Environment Agency and partners from a production regulation and waste management perspective. Rice University has developed a technique that deposits

 windblown carbon atoms onto a hydrocarbon substrate to produce large sheets of graphene cheaply. So far the process has only been computer modelled, but it could lead to commercial scale roll to roll production. Rice University has also developed a technique

 to ‘print’ an electricity conducting layer of graphene onto any substance that contains carbon. The process uses lasers to burn graphene into the substance, , producing laser-induced graphene (LIG). One application could be to burn electronic tags or sensors

 directly onto the surface of foodstuffs that could help with food provenance and bacterial detection respectively, or produce flexible electronics on organic based textiles such as cotton. Elsewhere it has also been discovered coupling graphene with a material

 called praseodymium cerium copper oxide (PCCO) unlocks its potential as a superconductor. This could have environment relevant applications in increasing the efficiency of power lines, long term energy storage and molecular electronics amongst others.
Primary Article Title: Graphene on toast, anyone?
Author: Williams, M
Secondary_URLs:
Graphene's sleeping superconductivity awakens - University of Cambridge 19/01/2017

p-wave triggered superconductivity in single-layer graphene on an electron-doped oxide superconductor - Nature 19/01/2017

Laser-induced graphene by multiple lasing&%2358; toward electronics on cloth, paper, and food - ACS Nano 12/04/2018

Evolutionary selection growth of two-dimensional materials on polycrystalline substrates - Nature 12/04/2018

Graphene grows stronger against the wind - Rice University 12/03/2018
Keywords: graphene electronics "laser-induced graphene" LIG food monitoring bacteria production energy storage battery power line efficiency grid infrastructure superconductor "praseodymium cerium copper oxide" PCCO textile waste WEEE

Summary Sentence: Cellular agriculture has so far tended to focus on edible protein production (ie meat), but the same techniques are also being used to produce other animal product substitutes.
Justification:
As this technology evolves and prices come down the case for mass livestock farming becomes increasingly thin. Such an impact could have significant impacts on the farming industry, including how agriculture is regulated and how the environmental impacts

 manifest, environmental impacts of the leather industry are second only to the oil industry. . Two companies who are making strides into this field are profiled here. Modern Meadow has devised a process for 3D printing liquid biofabricated leather made from

 lab grown collagen.The material, called Zoa has the same properties as animal skin, but without the environmental or animal welfare impacts, as production uses much less resources and the final product is biodegradable. The is also less waste as pieces can

 be produced to the exact size and shape needed for manufacturing goods. Another company called Geltor recently produced a biofabricated leather cover for a new book on cellular agriculture, derived from jellyfish. Their process involves engineering yeast cells

 to produce a jellyfish derived collagen, which is then separated and moulded into shape. The process can be adapted to produce different collagens from different species, depending on the properties required of the end product. They even produced leather from

 preserved mastodon protein as a proof of concept.
Primary Article Title: How Modern Meadow is fabricating the animal-free leather of the future
Author: Anzilotti, E
Secondary_URLs:
San Leandro lab's secret foray yields animal-free leather - San Francisco Chronicle 15/01/2018

Bolt Threads debuts new 'leather' made from mushroom roots - forbes 16/04/2018
Keywords: farming "cellular agriculture" "3D printing" "biofabricated leather" "Modern Meadow" livestock cattle grazing collagen cow jellyfish mastodon Zoa Geltor regulation oil environmental impact "animal welfare"

Summary Sentence: A biologically inspired membrane intended to cleanse carbon dioxide almost completely from the smoke of coal-fired power plants has been developed that can capture 90 percent of production at a relatively low cost of $40 per tonne.
Justification:
The conventional process for CO2 capture involves reversible absorption, which consumes high amounts of energy and is costly with a high environmental impact. More efficient and environmentally friendly separation processes are needed, and in this context,

 membrane separation represents a promising approach due to its greater energy efficiency, processability, and lower maintenance costs. Researchers term the 18 nanometers thick water-based membrane a "memzyme" because it acts like a filter but is near-saturated

 with an enzyme, carbonic anhydrase. Evaporation-induced self-assembly is used to creates a close-packed array of silica nanopores designed to accommodate the carbonic anhydrase enzyme and keep it stable. Carbon dioxide passes rapidly through the membranes,

 driven solely by a naturally occurring pressure gradient caused by the large number of carbon dioxide molecules on one side of the membrane and their comparative absence on the other. The chemical process turns the gas briefly into carbonic acid and then bicarbonate

 before exiting immediately downstream as carbon dioxide gas; the gas can be harvested with 99 percent purity. The enzyme is reusable, and because the water serves as a medium rather than an actor, does not need replacement.
Primary Article Title: Ultra-thin enzymatic liquid membrane for CO2 separation and capture
Author: Yaqin Fu, Ying-Bing Jiang, Darren Dunphy, Haifeng Xiong, Eric Coker, Stan Chou, Hongxia Zhang, Juan M. Vanegas, Jonas G. Croissant, Joseph L. Cecchi, Susan B. Rempe & C. Jeffrey Brinker
Keywords: Carbon Capture

Summary Sentence: Rapid increases in air pollution levels may be as harmful to human health as sustained high levels, suggesting that residents of cities with relatively clean air could be at risk.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners are increasingly involved in air quality as it rises up the public agenda and so may need to consider if current measures and regulations are properly adequate to protect human health. There is already significant evidence

 to link high levels of air pollution to heart attacks and other diseases. This new study reflects an apparent risk from rapidly increased pollution levels that don’t exceed EU limits. Focussing on data from the German city of Jena, air quality levels on the

 days preceding a patient's heart attack were compared to concentrations in the previous and following weeks. It was found that increases of nitric oxides of more than 20 μg/m3 within 24 hours were associated with a more than doubled risk of heart attack, suggesting

 rate of pollution rise may be as important to human health as overall concentration. It is suggested that further studies in other cities are needed, and if the similar results are seen that the EU may need to impose statutory limits on rapid increases of

 nitric oxides, the majority of which comes from vehicle emissions.
Primary Article Title: Rapid pollution increases may be as harmful to the heart as absolute levels
Secondary_URLs: Rapid increases in nitrogen oxides are associated with acute myocardial infarction&%2358; A case-crossover study - European Journal Of Preventative Cardiology 15/02/2018
Keywords: "air quality" pollution health illness heart attack cardiac arrest pollutant diesel "nitric oxide" regulation EU Jena Germany

Summary Sentence: Studies on the environmental impacts of emerging transport technologies on emissions and energy consumption suggests that they could both help and hinder the desire to reduce carbon greenhouse gas emissions and air quality impacts.
Justification:
These findings should be of interest to the Environment Agency and partners involved in regulating and improving urban air quality in particular, but there might also be implications for logistics and travel the Environment Agency itself, such as the transport

 hierarchy for staff travel and the future methods used in transporting water samples and other materials, for example. Some companies such as Amazon are already taking steps to move towards using drones (UAVs) for order fulfillment. Recent modelling for two

 US states found that overall electrically powered drones are more efficient on a weight per mile basis than vehicle transportation, but this can vary depending on factors like package weight, urban or rural setting and how power source. Drones tended to be

 more efficient delivering smaller packages in urban settings, even with the footprint of extra supporting infrastructure. However electrically powered vehicles produced less emissions in more rural settings or where package weights were greater. Ride sharing

 services such as Lyft and Uber have also been scrutinised in several US cities.. It was found that, rather than replacing private car journeys, ride sharing was used to take additional journeys, sometimes as a replacement for public transport and even walking.

 Ride sharing also involved ‘dead miles’, passenger-less journeys made on the way to a pick up. Overall vehicle miles traveled (VMT) in cities seem to have grown with the advent on ride sharing apps. Use of these services is also heavily skewed towards the

 young and affluent, potentially reducing the profitability of public transport and jeopardising this service to those not within this demographic. Without a move away from fossil fuel powered vehicles this research suggests that ride sharing may add to vehicle

 emissions in urban areas where ride sharing becomes prevalent. Perhaps in recognition of these impacts, ride sharing company Lyft has recently announced that it is introducing a scheme to offset the carbon emissions of the rides it provides through investments

 in renewable energy, reforestation etc.
Primary Article Title: The ride-hailing effect&%2358; more cars, more trips, more miles
Secondary_URLs:
Lyft launching program to offset carbon emissions of on-demand taxi ride service via "green" investments - PlanetSave 20/04/2018

Disruptive transportation&%2358; the adoption, utilization, and impacts of ride-hailing in the United States - University Of California Davis 01/10/2017

Delivering packages with drones might be good for the environment - The Conversation 14/02/2018

Energy use and life cycle greenhouse gas emissions of drones for commercial package delivery - Nature 13/02/2018
Keywords: transport energy emission "air quality" "climate change" "carbon dioxide" "greenhouse gas" GHG vehicle "sharing economy" Uber Lyft ride car fossil fuel "electric vehicle" EV drone logistic delivery truck urban rural infrastructure regulation wealth young people "public transport" regulation health pollution pollutant "carbon dioxide" CO2 energy reforestation renewable

Summary Sentence: Researchers have used world-first genome mapping technology to confirm the bollworm has been spreading rapidly in Brazil and hybridising with the earworm.
Justification: Helicoverpa armigera and Helicoverpa zea (commonly known as the cotton bollworm and corn earworm, respectively) are the world’s greatest caterpillar pests of broad-acre crops, causing in excess of US $5 billion in control costs and damage each year across Asia, Europe, Africa, America and Australia. The cotton bollworm is notoriously quick to generate and disseminate pesticide resistance throughout its range and has a wider host range than the native corn earworm. The hybrid caterpillar is retaining the strongest characteristics of both species posing a real threat that hybridization between the two species increases the opportunity for novel, agriculturally problematic ecotypes to emerge and spread through the Americas and cause widespread crop destruction.
Primary Article Title: Hybridization and gene flow in the mega-pest lineage of moth, Helicoverpa
Publisher: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Author: Craig J. Anderson, John G. Oakeshott, Wee Tek Tay, Karl H. J. Gordon, Andreas Zwick and Tom K. Walsh
Keywords: Agricultural pest, pesticide resistance

Summary Sentence: A new biophotovoltaic fuel cell is five times more efficient than current designs, making it a viable alternative to synthetic photovoltaic devices.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this development as a viable organic alternative to solar panels based on silicon and metals may influence future waste management scenarios, as there is already mounting concern around the impact of end-of-life

 PVs. Biophotovoltaics (BPVs, aka biological solar-cells) are emerging as a low cost and environmentally friendly alternative to solar panels. They work by harnessing photosynthesis in microorganisms such as algae and it into electricity. The new BPV has a

 two chamber system that separates electron generation and conversion to power, which greatly increases efficiency through optimum design of each system. This also creates the potential for battery like energy storage in one chamber. BPVs are not as efficient

 as PVs. But because algae grow and divide naturally it also means that new energy producing systems can effectively be ‘grown’ wherever they are needed, reducing set up costs and promoting a decentralisation of energy systems, which can be applied to developing

 and/or remote communities. Further innovation could see BPVs increasingly part of the energy mix.
Primary Article Title: Harnessing the power of algae&%2358; new, greener fuel cells move step closer to reality
Secondary_URLs: Enhancing power density of biophotovoltaics by decoupling storage and power delivery - Nature 09/01/2018
Keywords: energy waste regulation solar "fuel cell" biophotovoltaic BPV "biological fuel cell" PV silicon metal algae microrganism electron photosynthesis electricity decentralisation cost

Summary Sentence: The impacts of household chemicals on health and the environment may be gaining in significance.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may be interested in these findings as it may suggest where regulatory effort needs to be directed in the future to improve air quality. Studies in the USA have found that household chemicals including paint, personal

 care and cleaning products may be contributing as much particulate matter and ozone formation as diesel and gasoline (petrol) burning vehicles. This has only become apparent in recent times as vehicle derived emission levels have decreased enough to make other

 sources more visible. The study focussed on levels volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in Pasadena California. VOC molecules in air samples were traced back via a database of VOCs and their sources. Household products were found to be responsible for 38 per

 cent of emissions, compared to 33 per cent from fossil fuels. Many VOCs aren’t regulated for their contribution to particulate matter in the US. This study highlights where future research may be needed, considering the impact of particulate matter on health.

 Other respiratory impacts from household chemicals have been identified in a long term health study. Long term lung function has been found to decline in people who are more regularly exposed to household cleaning products compared to those who are not. This

 impact is bias towards women, and offers further evidence to suggest that cleaning products may need to be regulated or formulated differently in the future to avoid impacts on air quality and health.
Primary Article Title: Household products make surprisingly large contributions to air pollution
Author: Hamers, L
Secondary_URLs:
Women who clean at home or work face increased lung function decline - American Thoracic Society 16/02/2018

Volatile chemical products emerging as largest petrochemical source of urban organic emissions - Science 16/02/2018

Cleaning at home and at work in relation to lung function decline and airway obstruction - American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine 09/04/2018
Keywords: air quality pollution urban chemical "fossil fuel" gasoline petrol diesel "particulate matter" PM VOC "volatile organic compound" health respiratory household pollutant cleaning paint cosmetic cleaning women USA "Los Angeles" Pasadena ozone chemistry regulation

Summary Sentence: A new database charts the amount of precious metals and circulation and what could be recovered from end-of-life vehicles and electronic equipment.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this as the quantities of metal currently being lost to landfill etc are significant, and quantifying them could encourage novel waste management and recovery practices that may need regulating. The Urban Mine

 Platform is the only such database in the world that tracks the amount of metals in the urban mine - metals currently in circulation. It reveals, for example, that 20 tonnes of gold goes unrecovered every year, mainly through vehicle scrappage. It is also

 thought that by 2020 there will be around 18,000 tonnes of neodymium in the active vehicle fleet - nine times the amount present in the year 2000. As electronic devices, including vehicles, mobile phones and wind turbine, become increasingly complex and technologically

 advanced, the quantities of rare earth elements and metals that include gold, cobalt and lithium in our devices will also increase, as will the demand for them. Europe doesn't have significant reserves of these substances and so needs either to rely on imports

 (which has strategic risks) or increase the recycling capacity and move towards a circular economy approach. The outputs from the Urban Mine Platform (produced by the European research project Prosum) could help to accelerate the move towards increased recycling

 and recovery of metals from vehicles in particular which currently do not have the same regulatory incentives as WEEE, and also the elements are not found in large concentrations within a vehicle - for example a car may contain a couple of grams of gold but

 spread over many components.
Primary Article Title: Untapped gold mine is lost from end-of-life vehicles
Keywords: waste metal element "rare earth" mineral gold colbalt lithium neodymium WEEE electronic vehicle energy "wind turbine" mobile phone recover recycling "circular economy landfill regulation "urban mine" "Urban Mine Platform" Prosum Europe car EV transport

Summary Sentence: Supplies of lithium and cobalt could become critical by the 2050s, with batteries and other devices needing to be fashioned from other non-critical elements such as sodium, magnesium, zinc, calcium and aluminium.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as a regulator of electronic waste (WEEE) may be interested in considering how the future demand and supply for economically important minerals may influence waste management regulation and infrastructure. Recent scenario analysis

 suggested that by 2050 demand for lithium and cobalt could outstrip supply, mainly due to increased use of battery technology for energy storage and transport. Demand for cobalt could be twice as high as supplies&%2358; the situation for lithium would not be as

 pressured due to larger physical reserves, but globals politics of the countries in which reserves are located could hinder access (see also HSDBi %2314589). . This highlights the importance of developing battery technologies that utilise more abundant and less

 politically restricted elements such as sodium-ion and magnesium-ion and other materials (HSDBi %2314602) to mitigate against these economic effects.
Primary Article Title: Scenario 2050&%2358; lithium and cobalt might not suffice
Secondary_URLs: A cost and resource analysis of sodium-ion batteries - Nature 13/03/2018
Keywords: mineral resource waste lithium cobalt energy storage battery electronic demand supply politics geography sodium magnesium aluminium WEEE regulation recycling circular economy scenario 2050

Summary Sentence: Successful trials last summer showed that hydrogen peroxide was effective against the golden algae, Prymnesium parvum and that fish and macroinvertebrates were unharmed by the treatment.
Justification: Prymnesium parvum is a toxin-producing microalga that causes harmful algal blooms globally, which often result in large-scale fish kills that have severe ecological and economic implications. A major fish kill attributed to P. parvum occurred in Spring 2015 on the Norfolk Broads, a low-lying set of channels and lakes (Broads) found on the East of England. This research set outs new understanding of the algae, confirms the effectiveness of monitoring for early warning of blooms using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR), and highlights trials of using hydrogen peroxide to control blooms. Current management methods for control of harmful algal blooms range from the use of clay flocculants, algaecides, and even the manual relocation of affected fish to safer waterways. Although hydrogen peroxide has not previously been used to tackle blooms of P. parvum, it has been used to effectively treat blooms of cyanobacteria and toxin-producing dinoflagellates
