Primary Article Title: Insights into toxic Prymnesium parvum blooms&%2358; the role of sugars and algal viruses
Author: Ben A. Wagstaff, Edward S. Hems, Martin Rejzek, Jennifer Pratscher, Elliot Brooks, Sakonwan Kuhaudomlarp, Ellis C. O'Neill, Matthew I. Donaldson, Steven Lane, John Currie, Andrew M. Hindes, Gill Malin, J. Colin Murrell, Robert A. Field
Keywords: Harmful Algal Blooms, Ecosystem Management

Summary Sentence: Discovering how to make proteins exist outside of the body could lead to more effective strategies for tackling pollution incidents.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may be interested in this development as there are direct applications in its incident management and site regulation work. Proteins can perform a range of functions, such as transporting molecules and attacking infection, but they

 tend to fall apart when outside of the body. A team of scientists has found a way to overcome this. Statistical analysis of proteins identified the characteristics needed to prevent protein collapse outside of the body. They used this research to fashion a

 synthetic structure from a protein like substance called random heteropolymers (RHPs), which are constructed of chains of four kinds of monomers, in a similar way to how natural proteins are made of chains of amino acids. The RHPs were combined with a protein

 called organophosphorus hydrolase (OPH), which degrades the toxic elements of chemicals used in insecticides and chemical weapons, and this was fashioned into a mat. When the mat was immersed in a bath of insecticide it quickly neutralised the toxicity by

 around 10 per cent of its own weight in minutes. Further development of this process could deliver an effective material for use in toxic spills and other similar pollution incidents, and also as a preventative measure in regulated installations. It may also

 have possible uses in agriculture and water treatment.
Primary Article Title: Researchers create a protein `mat' that can soak up pollution
Author: Israel, B
Secondary_URLs: Random heteropolymers preserve protein function in foreign environments - Science 16/03/2018
Keywords: pollution toxic protein incident management chemical "random heteropolymer" RHP "organophosphorus hydrolase" OPH insecticide regulation farming water treatment agriculture pollutant

Summary Sentence: Marine life is controlled by multiple physical and chemical drivers and by diverse ecological processes that are being altered by climate change and other human drivers of environmental change.
Justification:
Identifying the influences of multifaceted ocean change, from local to global scales, is a complex task. To guide policy‐making and make projections of the future of the marine biosphere, it is essential to understand biological responses at physiological,

 evolutionary and ecological levels. This research study contrasted and compared different approaches to multiple driver experiments that aim to elucidate biological responses to a complex matrix of ocean global change. It presents the benefits and the challenges

 of each approach with a focus on marine research, and guidelines to navigate through these different categories to help identify strategies that might best address research questions in fundamental physiology, experimental evolutionary biology and community

 ecology. This will help meet the requirements of the Sustainable Development Goals and other critical international agreements and platforms that are related to climate change, biodiversity, and ecosystem services.
Primary Article Title: Experimental strategies to assess the biological ramifications of multiple drivers of global ocean change - a review
Author: Philip W. Boyd  Sinead Collins  Sam Dupont  Katharina Fabricius  Jean‐Pierre Gattuso Jonathan Havenhand  David A. Hutchins  Ulf Riebesell  Max S. Rintoul  Marcello Vichi Haimanti Biswas  Aurea Ciotti  Kunshan Gao  Marion Gehlen  Catriona L. Hurd Haruko Ku
Keywords: Oceans, Climate Change, Monitoring

Summary Sentence: People are turning to robots and drones to remove rubbish from waterways.
Justification:
The Environment Agency has previously seen examples of automation encroaching into waste management, and these examples demonstrate the possibility of automation being used as a viable technology in managing waste and sources of water quality and potential

 threat to biodiversity, such as plastics. One crowd funded project is attempting to raise the funds necessary to build as remote controlled ‘trashbot’ to remove trash from the Chicago River. The robot will be able to be controlled via a web browser, potentially

 allowing anyone in the World to help collect waste from the river, meaning that direct activism is no longer constrained by geography In Norway the Oslo Port Authority is turning to drones to clear out ‘underwater islands of trash’ that have accumulated in

 the fjords over the past few decades. Recent deaths of dolphins and whales in the area attributed to waste, along with rising environmental concerns around plastics and other problems have spurred the authorities into taking action with unmanned drones. Other

 recent examples of this approach to waste collection exist, such as Baltimore's "Mr Trash Wheel" and Santa Cruz based "Hector the Collector".
Primary Article Title: Trash-collecting river robot can be controlled by anyone via the web
Author: Holloway, J
Secondary_URLs:
Trash in the fjords? Norway turns to drones - The Seattle Times 09/03/2018

Robot trash collector scours the waters of the Santa Cruz small craft harbor - Huffington Post 06/12/2017

Googly-Eyed Trash Eaters May Clean a Harbor Near You - National Geographic 17/02/2017
Keywords: waste trash rubbish garbage sea ocean river lake waterway "water quality" automation drone robot trashbot crowdfunding Chicago Norway fjord plastic dolphin whale biodiversity regulation internet website citizen science activism volunteer Baltimore "Mr Trash Wheel" "Professor Trash Wheel" "Santa Cruz" "Hector The Collector"

Summary Sentence: The average age of the UK population is not equally spread, with some urban areas having a notably older and younger population than others.
Justification:
A recent study of urban areas with populations over 135,000 people identified some marked differences between cities. Coastal towns tend to have older populations, attributed to ‘the retirement factor’, whereas younger towns were associated with universities,

 migrant populations and high-skilled, high paying jobs. Should this trend continue it may have implications for government funding, some of which is allocated for specific issues such as education, which might have more value being used in health and social

 care. A more decentralised and autonomous approach to funding could help to address these issues, and in this sense could have implications for environmental protection work, including flood management, industrial investment and urban planning.
Primary Article Title: Where are the UK's youngest and oldest city populations?
Author: Carter, A & Swinney, P
Keywords: population demographic age city urban planning industry jobs land use housing health social education funding flooding regulation regional decentralisation decentralised young old

Summary Sentence: A Swiss University has developed a commercialised system for producing hydrogen in a decentralised system from renewable hydrocarbons.
Justification:
Such a system could fall within the Environment Agency’s remit to regulate industrial processes and emissions. The system developed by TU Graz is based on previous technology used to make hydrogen for airship use in the 19th century, where coal was used

 as a heat source and a reducing agent in an inefficient blast furnace system. The new process is much more efficient. It involves heating a renewable hydrocarbon such as biogas or bioethanol, which is converted into a synthesis gas in a bioreformer. This gas

 then interacts reduces an iron oxide at high temperature. The iron is then reoxidised with steam, producing hydrogen. Due to the relative potential abundance of renewable hydrocarbon this process can be scaled down and localised, supporting a decentralisation

 agenda and a move towards fuel cell technology for energy in transport and the home.
Primary Article Title: Sustainable solution for decentralised hydrogen production
Keywords: energy renewable hydrogen decentralisation hydrocarbon biogas bioethanol chemistry Graz "fuel cell" coal steam iron oxide regulation emission air

Summary Sentence: US retail giant Walmart has filed a patent for autonomous robot bees.
Justification:
The robot bees would be designed to act as pollination drones, carrying pollen between the flowers of plants and crops. Whilst the commercial reason behind this innovation is not stated, it could be assumed that robotic bees , or other insects could be

 used in a wider context to mitigate against falling bee population numbers, which may be due to a variety of reasons, including pesticide use (eg HSDBi %2314252, %2313919, %2313812), and preserve crop yields and food security, and so may become a feature of the

 agricultural environment in the future. Such an introduction may also provide opportunities for environmental monitoring and data acquisition to air regulation for the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: This giant US retailer has hinted that it's building crop-pollinating robot bees
Author: Garfield, L
Keywords: automation robot bee insect pollen pollination "colony collapse disorder" pesticide farming agriculture food security supply crop plant patent Walmart drone regulation data monitoring

Summary Sentence: A new design of wind turbine helps to harvest ammonia from the air and use it as an alternative energy storage medium to battery storage.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this renewable energy concept, and may need to consider any implications for ammonia emissions from regulated installations. The idea of using ammonia as a storage medium goes back several decades,

 but its adoption was hindered by the notion that fossil fuel would be the feedstock, offsetting the cheaper tanker and pipeline transportation costs of ammonia compared to natural gas and oil. The advent of renewable energy sources such as wind and solar,

 plus the growing interest in the hydrogen economy, changes this situation. A Belgian company has proposed a novel ocean based turbine design called a Dualtower. The legs of the turbine are constructed of interlocking gas tanks called “duplex constructive pressure

 vessels”, where one tank is located inside another. The turbine at the top of the tower drives gas extraction and separation technology that stores nitrogen in the outer part of the tanks and hydrogen in the inner parts. Periodically a tanker ship would siphon

 off the nitrogen and hydrogen, and convert it to ammonia on board before returning to port, where the ammonia could be piped to where it is needed and the hydrogen extracted, with minimum alterations needed to existing gas and oil infrastructure. It is feasible

 that other terrestrial sources of ammonia, either from atmospheric extraction or emissions utilisation, could also incorporate similar technology.
Primary Article Title: Renewable ammonia energy, harvesting large-scale wind
Author: Brown, T
Keywords: energy renewable ammonia hydrogen nitrogen wind turbine Dualtower “duplex constructive pressure vessel” ship electrolysis gas oil "fossil fuel" solar tanker ocean sea pipeline infrastructure battery emission pollution regulation installation pollutant pig poultry air

Summary Sentence: According to a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), last year, nationwide tests discovered 221 instances of 'unusual' germs - bugs resistant to all, or most antibiotics tested on it.
Justification:
More than 23,000 Americans die each year from infections caused by germs resistant to antibiotics. While antibiotic resistance (AR) threats vary nationwide, AR has been found in every state. And unusual resistance germs, which are resistant to all or most

 antibiotics tested and are uncommon or carry special resistance genes, are constantly developing and spreading. Lab tests uncovered unusual resistance more than 200 times in 2017 in “nightmare bacteria” alone. With new resources nationwide, early and aggressive

 action—when even a single case is found—can keep germs with unusual resistance from spreading in health care facilities and causing hard-to-treat or even untreatable infections. For example, CDC estimates show that this aggressive approach could prevent 1,600

 cases of CRE* in one state over three years.
Primary Article Title: Containing unusual resistance
Keywords: Antibiotic Resistance

Summary Sentence: Electronic waste—including discarded televisions, computers and mobile phones—is one of the fastest-growing waste categories worldwide, but it is now cheaper to recover gold, copper and other metals from e-waste than obtaining these metals from mines.
Justification:
Projections indicate that about 50 million tons of e-waste will be discarded around the world in 2018, according to the United Nations' Global E-waste Monitor report. This type of waste contains a surprising amount of metal. For example, a typical cathode-ray

 tube TV contains almost a pound of copper and more than half a pound of aluminum. This research obtained data from eight recycling companies in China to calculate the cost for extracting such metals from e-waste, a practice known as "urban mining." Expenses

 included the costs for waste collection, labor, energy, material and transportation, as well as capital costs for the recyclers' equipment and buildings. These expenses are offset by government subsidies and by revenue from selling recovered materials and

 components. The data are confined to the cases of copper and gold extracted and processed from e-waste streams made up of recycled TV sets, but these results indicate a trend and potential if applied across a broader range of e-waste sources and metals extracted.

 If these results can be extended to other metals and countries, they promise to have positive impact on waste disposal and mining activities globally, as the circular economy comes to displace linear economic pathways.
Primary Article Title: Urban mining of e-waste is becoming more cost-effective than virgin mining
Author: Xianlai Zeng, John A. Mathews and Jinhui Li
Keywords: E-Waste, Metal Recovery, Economics, Circular Economy

Summary Sentence: More examples of blockchain applications are emerging that go beyond verifying financial transactions.
Justification:
Blockchain has been used to independently verify the results of Sierra Leone’s presidential election. This was done by a third party observer as a proof of concept, rather than the government itself, but the results suggest that this could be a viable

 future use. Blockchain is also making inroads into the motor industry. One manufacturer is proposing employing a blockchain based system to help ensure that the cobalt used in its batteries is ethically sourced. Another is testing blockchain to reward careful

 and environmentally friendly drivers with its new virtual currency. An in the US the first real estate transaction has been completed using a blockchain based system. All of these examples offer suggestions of how blockchain could impact on the Environment

 Agency’s activities, from reducing the environmental impact of it’s vehicle fleet, environmentally responsible procurement and administering permits and other similar documentation.
Primary Article Title: UK firm pilots using blockchain to help BMW source ethical cobalt
Author: Lewis, B
Secondary_URLs:
Sierra Leone secretly holds first blockchain-audited presidential vote - CoinDesk 08/03/2018

Hold up&%2358; what actually happened in Sierra Leone's "blockchain" election? - Futurism 02/04/2018

Auto giant behind Mercedes-Benz launches crypto coin to reward eco-friendly driving - Coin Telegraph 05/03/2018

First US real estate transaction in blockchain completed&%2358; what's next? - Zero Hedge 08/03/2018
Keywords: blockchain "real estate" property election "Sierra Leone" government car coin driving provenance ethical cobalt battery automotive manufacturing fleet vehicle regulation permit

Summary Sentence: A European project to produce rare earth metals from 100 per cent recycled materials is reaching realisation.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in this project as an example of a circular economy in action. Global politics and economics may make it harder for the UK to guarantee a reliable supply of exotic substances in the future (HSDBi %2314589)

 , so recycling of current resources may increase significantly. Rare earth magnets are important components in wind turbines and disk drives, amongst other things. Around 80 per cent of current supplies of materials such as neodymium and dysprosium come from

 China. The REProMag manufacturing project has developed a zero waste manufacturing process for precision components through a three stage process called SDS (shaping, debinding, sintering. First the elements of interest are extracted from old components and

 converted into polymer bound pellets of powder, which can then be used in injection moulding or 3D printing. Once formed a debinding process removes the polymer before sintering to improve density and strength. Because the process uses recycled materials and

 produces no waste it reduces overall consumption and avoids the environmental impacts of virgin mineral extraction.
Primary Article Title: Manufacturing innovation set to take the 'rare' out of rare-earth magnets
Keywords: waste metal mineral "rare earth" magnet China recycling "circular economy" electronics energy turbine wind WEEE regulation "3D printing" polymer neodymium dysprosium SDS shaping debinding sintering REProMag

Summary Sentence: Spreading crushed basalt rock on cropland could be an effective measure in reducing carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere whilst simultaneously improving farmland.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this geoengineering like proposal and any impacts it could have on regulating materials spread to land and water quality through runoff, as well as an interested in the climate change mitigating potential.

 Basalt rock contains high levels of silicate minerals that can remove CO2 from the air as they weather. The CO2 dissolved in rainwater naturally gets converted into bicarbonate, which flows away into the ocean. This process has been occuring naturally for

 millennia. However researchers have proposed that this effect could be accelerated through applying crushed basalt to cropland, which significantly increases the surface area of basalt in contact with the atmosphere. Limestone is already added to farmland

 to counteract changes to soil pH from fertiliser addition. Swapping to basalt would have the same effect with the additional benefit of trapping CO2 from the air. A global application could remove between 0.5 and 4 billion tonnes of CO2 from the air, depending

 on the energy type and level consumed in quarrying, crushing and transporting basalt.
Primary Article Title: Crush the right rock and spread it on farms to help soil and the climate
Author: Johnson, S K
Secondary_URLs: Farming with crops and rocks to address global climate, food and soil security - Nature 19/02/2018
Keywords: "climate change" "carbon dioxide" CO2 emission capture basalt silicate bicarbonate geology chemistry geochemistry geoengineering farming farmland agriculture crop pH acidity limestone fertiliser regulation "water quality" runoff field spreading

Summary Sentence: In the US, industry officials representing gene editing companies are lobbying government to take responsibility for the regulation of gene edited animals from the FDA to the Department of Agriculture.
Justification:
Such a move could free up gene editing companies to create "more useful farm animals" animals such as cows with no horns and male pigs that do not reach sexual maturity. The lobbyists are keen to have authority moved from the FDA as regulation currently

 prohibits such genetic alterations. The Department for Agriculture however, have already allowed genetically modified plants to be sold without any form of regulation suggesting that if they had control of livestock, regulation in this area would similarly

 disappear. The Environment Agency may need to consider whether this could have any impact on our imports post Brexit.
Primary Article Title: Farmland gene editors want cows without horns, pigs without tails, and business without regulations
Keywords: "gene editing" "genetic modification" animals livestock farming pigs cows farmers Brexit "EU Exit"

Summary Sentence: A new proton battery has been developed that could address the environmental and safety issues associated with lithium battery technology.
Justification:
The new battery works by using a carbon electrode for solid state storage of hydrogen, combined with a reversible fuel cell, to create a rechargeable unit. This results in a much more efficient battery than conventional hydrogen - similar to that of a

 lithium ion battery and with development, it is suggested that this battery could potentially store more energy than lithium ion batteries. The next stage for the development team is to scale up the battery for use as medium scale storage on electrical grids

 and, to power electric cars. This technology could potentially replace lithium technology and prevent a potentially difficult waste issue for the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: All power to the proton&%2358; researchers make battery breakthrough
Keywords: batteries battery lithium proton "proton batteries" "rechargeable batteries" waste WEEE pollution hydrogen

Summary Sentence: A water harvester, that can pull water from the air, is being developed in the US for NGOs and government organisations addressing drought.
Justification:
The water harvester is a textile comprised from a mesh of carbon nanotubes. One side of the mesh is hydrophilic and the other side, hydrophobic. As water settles on the mesh, surface tension creates a natural 'push-pull' effect that mineralizes the water

 as it passes through - forming droplets that can be captured and stored for later use. The process does not require power but the efficiency can be increased if a small fan run by a solar panel is incorporated. For drought stricken places such as California

 and South Africa, this technology would prove much cheaper and more energy efficient than other options such as desalination plants. The developers of this product plan to get a family sized version to market imminently and are now working on a scaled-up version

 that could produce up to 1,000 litres per day that could serve a larger enterprise such as a winery. This technology illustrates how decentralisation and water independence could be the answer for those experiencing water shortages but also raise the question

 of how such independence could be effectively regulated by the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: A nanotech device harvests water in the driest places
Keywords: water "water resources" "water independence" nanotechnology "carbon nanotubes" decentralisation drought climate

Summary Sentence: Test cases are being taken to courts around the world in an attempt by activists to hold corporations and governments to account for not doing enough to address climate change, pollution and extreme weather events.
Justification:
Two examples of this trend include&%2358; action taken by Greenpeace in the Philippines against 47 corporations known as the 'Carbon Majors' and, the third court appearance for the UK government over air pollution violations. In the first example, Greenpeace

 have asked the Philippines Human Rights Commission to look into whether the Carbon Majors are responsible for breaches of human rights against the Philippines people during severe typhoons that denied them the right to life, health, food, water, sanitation,

 adequate housing and self-determination. This action could potentially affect climate change litigation across the world. In the second example, the courts have ruled that the UK government's air quality policy is unlawful following a challenge by activist

 group ClientEarth. They have won two previous hearings forcing the government to create new plans for reducing nitrogen dioxide. As interest in sustainability increases amongst the public, this type of challenge is likely to become more prevalent and the Environment

 Agency may find itself more vulnerable to pressure from activists in the future.
Primary Article Title: Why the world is looking to the Philippines for climate justice
Secondary_URLs: Air pollution&%2358; UK government loses third court case as plans ruled 'unlawful' - The Guardian 28/03/2018
Keywords: litigation climate "climate change" pollution "air pollution" law justice activists policy corporations government planning

Summary Sentence: Agricultural waste is being used to create non-structural components (such as bumpers) for vehicles.
Justification:
This will help reduce CO2 emissions across agriculture and transport by reducing the amount of agricultural waste going to landfill or being burnt. Also, because the materials are lighter in weight than traditional materials, the overall weight of the

 vehicles will be less - resulting in less fuel use and less CO2 emissions. The materials are also produced using less energy and are easier to recycle at end of life because they are biodegradable.
Primary Article Title: UK team uses biomass to create lightweight composites
Secondary_URLs: Exploring the potential of waste leaf sheath date palm fibres for composite reinforcement through a structural and mechanical analysis - Composites Part A&%2358; Applied Science and Manufacturing 31/12/2017
Keywords: waste vehicles composites agriculture "circular economy" sustainability biomass transport landfill "agricultural waste"

Summary Sentence: Amphibians represent an important bellwether of global change, scientists say, due to their particularly high sensitivity to disturbances in their environment.
Justification:
Human activities continue to erode the tree of life, requiring prioritisation of research and conservation. There are more than 7,000 amphibian species on Earth, including frogs, toads, caecilians, newts, mudpuppies, and hellbenders. This study constructed

 the first comprehensive family tree for nearly all amphibious species alive today. The researchers used the data to examine historical diversification patterns of amphibians as well as species' level of isolation on the family tree, also called evolutionary

 distinctness. Amphibians are the most ancient group of terrestrial vertebrates surviving today, with origins reaching back more than 300 million years. The authors found that select members of this group alive today carry more than 100 million years of evolutionary

 history distinct to only them. The long, separate path of these species may have resulted in the evolution of key functions for varied ecosystems. By providing a phylogenetic estimate for extant amphibians and identifying their threats and evolutionary distinctness,

 the study offers a preliminary basis for a quantitatively informed global approach to conserving the amphibian tree of life.
Primary Article Title: The interplay of past diversification and evolutionary isolation with present imperilment across the amphibian tree of life
Author: Walter Jetz and R. Alexander Pyron
Keywords: Amphibians, Extinction, Biodiversity Loss

Summary Sentence: Research has has identified a previously unknown family of bacteria and complex enzymes that break down plant biomass and appear to be critical for ruminants to be herbivorous.
Justification:
Studying the digestive systems of ruminants like cows, sheep, and even reindeer may help improve understanding of ruminant nutrition. The previously unknown family of bacteria discovered in this study appears to actively degrade plant biomass in the stomachs

 of ruminants using complex enzymes that are different from those that are already well known. Understanding these bacteria could help the design of animal feeding strategies and commercial systems for biofuels and waste management.
Primary Article Title: Candidatus Paraporphyromonas polyenzymogenes encodes multi-modular cellulases linked to the type IX secretion system
Author: A. E. Naas, L. M. Solden, A. D. Norbeck, H. Brewer, L. H. Hagen, I. M. Heggenes, A. C. McHardy, R. I. Mackie, L. Paša-Tolić, M. Ø. Arntzen, V. G. H. Eijsink, N. M. Koropatkin, M. Hess, K. C. Wrighton and P. B. Pope
Keywords: Ruminant Microbiome

Summary Sentence: Research has found that African swine fever could survive in a simulated feed shipment across the ocean, which suggests that feed may be a potential way that pathogens such as African swine fever virus spread.
Justification:
African swine fever is caused by infection with ASF virus (ASFV), which can have fatality rates of up to 100%. The virus causes acute disease in domestic pigs and wild boar, and may cause varying clinical signs that are similar to other pig diseases such

 as high fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. Pigs may also die suddenly without clinical signs. Since 2007, ASFV, has spread throughout Eastern Europe and Russia but is not present in the UK. There are many countries, including the US and China, that are

 currently free of ASFV but if infected would have significant effects on global food supplies. Research is focusing on how to prevent this virus from being introduced, by understanding and further defining the risk of ASFV transmission when consumed in feed,

 which is only a recently identified risk factor for the introduction of swine pathogens.
Primary Article Title: Survival of viral pathogens in animal feed ingredients under transboundary shipping models
Author: Scott A. Dee , Fernando V. Bauermann, Megan C. Niederwerder, Aaron Singrey, Travis Clement, Marcelo de Lima, Craig Long, Gilbert Patterson, Maureen A. Sheahan, Ana M. M. Stoian, Vlad Petrovan, Cassandra K. Jones, Jon De Jong, Ju Ji, Gordon D. Spronk, Luke
Keywords: African Swine Fever

Summary Sentence: A microbial resistant geopolymer concrete has been developed for the manufacture of wastewater treatment plants.
Justification:
This new type of concrete could increase the lifespan of wastewater treatment plants and be used to refurbish those that are currently damaged. This would reduce the costs of repair and potentially reduce the requirement for building new facilities. Microbial

 induced concrete corrosion (MICC), is caused by biogenic transformation processes that causes damage to concrete and metal. This results in corrosion rates at a rate of one centimetre per year - resulting in an overall lifespan of wastewater plants of under

 10 years. An increase in the lifespan of wastewater treatment plants could require less inspections and result in less incidence of leaks and pollution issues.
Primary Article Title: Combating Sulphuric Acid Corrosion at Wastewater Plants
Keywords: wastewater water sewage "water treatment" "sulphuric acid" corrosion concrete "hydrogen sulphide" microbes

Summary Sentence: A central challenge for synthetic biology has been the efficient conversion of abundant feedstocks into the final product, particularly when the feedstock is not something the bacteria or yeast normally "eat."
Justification:
Implementation of heterologous catabolic pathways has so far relied on constitutive gene expression without consideration for global regulatory systems that may enhance nutrient assimilation and cell growth. Using novel nutrients can lead to inefficiencies

 when the nutrient metabolic pathways are not linked to downstream pathways for stress-responses, cell growth and other functions important for the health of the organism. This study took a set of regulatory genes, called a GAL regulon, that normally processes

 galactose - a favorite on the yeast menu of nutrients - and replaced some of the genes with those that become activated by, and direct the breakdown of, xylose. All other genes in the GAL regulon were unchanged. In doing so, they preserved a more natural interaction

 between the genes that govern feeding and those that govern survival. The new synthetic regulon, dubbed XYL, enabled the yeast cells to grow more rapidly and to higher cell densities. One application would be biofuels, as xylose is a sugar derived from the

 otherwise indigestible parts of plant material.
Primary Article Title: A semi-synthetic regulon enables rapid growth of yeast on xylose
Author: Venkatesh Endalur Gopinarayanan, Nikhil U. Nair
Keywords: Synthetic Biology, Feedstocks

Summary Sentence: The proportion of large fish in the North Sea may decrease as climate change unfolds, by as much as 60% in some areas.
Justification:
Indicators based on fish size are widely used in the study and management of wild populations exploited by commercial fishing. The Large Fish Indicator (LFI) is one such example, determining the biomass of fish above a certain size in a community, and

 used to inform policy and guide the fishing industry. These types of indicators have not previously been used alongside predictions of future conditions in line with expected climate change, but fish size closely reflects the environment, and a warming world

 will change the conditions in which fish live. Using modelling and comparison with real-life surveys, the researchers demonstrated they can simulate how fish size is changing in the marine environment, under the pressures of fishing and environmental factors.

 This form of modelling, combining important indicators and environmental change, can help with sustainable exploitation of fished stocks by helping policy makers consider how wild populations will be impacted by changing, warmer and more acidic oceans into

 the future.
Primary Article Title: Climate change alters fish community size-structure, requiring adaptive policy targets
Author: Ana M Queirós  José Fernandes  Lily Genevier  Christopher P Lynam
Keywords: Climate Modelling, Fisheries

Summary Sentence: A robotic system that could replace humans to visually check metal components is being tested in Sheffield.
Justification:
The automated visual inspection system that was developed in Canada can mimic the way humans see flaws in objects but without getting tired or bored of the task over long periods of time. The system may need borderline cases to be verified by a human,

 but that person could work remotely removing the need for humans on the production line. This could have implications for the automation of regulation and the move towards decentralisation. The Environment Agency may need to consider how it would implement

 regulation in manufacturing sites that are fully automated.
Primary Article Title: Robotic system promises to increase speed and accuracy of visual inspections
Keywords: decentralisation automation robots "artificial intelligence" AI technology "visual inspection" inspection regulation

Summary Sentence: Mayors in the US are opposing the Trump Administration's attempts to repeal the Clean Power Plan demonstrating how local politics and decentralisation can lead to good outcomes for the environment.
Justification:
Decentralisation is gaining traction as local government in the US aim to protect their citizens by opposing policies from the Trump administration that they fel are not in the best interests of their citizens. A letter signed by 244 mayors and representing

 more than 51 million Americans, has been sent to the EPA and states that as the legal authority of cities only extends as far as state government and federal law allows, the local efforts to address climate change are affected by any changes to policy such

 as the Clean Power Plan.
Primary Article Title: Hundreds of U.S. Mayors Collectively Oppose Trump Reversal of Clean Power Plan
Keywords: decentralisation government policy "climate change" Trump "local government" Mayor "Clean Power Plan" politics

Summary Sentence: Silver nanoparticles have been shown to impact on wheat growth, and also interfere with the genes related to combating pathogens and dealing with stress.
Justification:
As crops come into contact through slurry spreading on land (an Environment Agency regulated process), however currently nanoparticles are not regulated like other forms of metal with known impacts. Silver nanoparticles find their way to land through sewage,

 and also through their use in some pesticides due to their biocidal properties. Plants have not evolved to cope with silver toxicity, as silver is not naturally found in high concentrations in soils. Silver nanoparticles are likely toxic to plants because

 of the release of silver ions and the properties related to their small size. In a laboratory trial wheat plants were exposed to two forms of silver&%2358; a nanoparticle suspension solution containing pristine metallic silver (AgNP) and sulphidised silver (Ag2SNP);

 a solution containing ionic silver (AgNO3); plus a control group with no silver added. Subsequent analysis showed that nanoparticles accumulated within the wheat roots, and may have responsible for reduced secondary root growth and greater growth of root hairs,

 related to low water and low nutrient exposure. Analysis of gene expression also an impact on genes that control the defence against pathogens and mechanisms that cope with stress. The researchers involve suggest that the that the influence of nanoparticles

 could be having on plant and crop growth requires further study to better understand real world conditions and the full toxic impacts, as this study shows that there are clear phytotoxic effects of silver nanoparticles, especially in silver sulphide form.
Primary Article Title: Silver nanoparticles can have complex and toxic effects on wheat roots
Secondary_URLs: Silver nanoparticles and wheat roots&%2358; a complex interplay - Environmental Science and Technology 26/04/2017
Keywords: waste nanoparticle nanosilver farming agriculture textile clothes yield plant crop pesticide biocidal biocide growth gene pathogen stress nutrient regulation water root toxic slurry "water treatment" metal "metallic silver" AgNP "sulphidised silver" Ag2SNP "ionic silver" AgNO3

Summary Sentence: The move to a fossil free economy may see different resources become more in demand, which will impact on the nations that contain them.
Justification:
Countries such as Venezuela, Iran and the USA hold the greatest reserves of oil, natural gas and coal respectively. However a renewable energy economy would likely see an increased need for silicon for solar panels, plus lithium, copper and rare earth metals

 for batteries, cabling and magnetics (used in wind turbines) respectively. This could introduce a new range of players into the mineral economy. For example, Chile has the world’s largest lithium reserves by far. Silicon is found in Norway and Brazil, and

 there are high resources of rare earth minerals in Vietnam. The countries that have the greatest spread of all these resources are the USA, China and Russia. Whereas the World currently has OPEC (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries), 14 countries

 controlling over half of world oil production, a similar organisation based around minerals needed for renewables could shift economic power away from the Middle East to Africa, South America, as well as USA, Russia and China. A key difference between both

 industries is that the metals and minerals in renewable energy can theoretically be recycled. In a future where economic power develops similar to the OPEC model, recycling and recovery could become increasingly essential to European countries that currently

 lack significant reserves, making an effective circular economy model increasingly necessary to regional and national security.. The Environment Agency as a waste regulator would likely have a key role in this.
Primary Article Title: Meet the new `renewable superpowers'&%2358; nations that boss the materials used for wind and solar
Author: Barron, A
Keywords: energy waste resources regulation security defence battery lithium metal cable copper "rare earth" magnet turbine silicon photovoltaic PV solar panel USA Russia Norway Brazil Iran China OPEC "Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries" "Middle East" trade politics Chile Africa "South America" oil "fossil fuel" gas coal recycling Europe "circular economy"

Summary Sentence: A spin out company form Oxford University has developed the technology to turn waste from plastic, tyres and biomass into high quality transportation fuels and chemicals.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may need to consider the potential impacts of a widespread adoption of this technology on waste management, as some of source materials such as tyres, are classified as hazardous waste. The low energy process in question converts

 plastics and other hydrocarbons into fuels etc, utilising pyrolysis, a process that employs heat to decompose the plastics in the absence of oxygen, forming an oil like substance called pyrolysis oil. While pyrolysis oil is not a new substance its wider use

 is now possible due to the new process that purifies and upgrades to oil into gasoline, diesel and jet fuels. Previous examples have also demonstrated using pyrolysis to extract fuel from other waste materials such as wood (HSDBi %2312630) and plastic bags (HSDBi

 %2312413), and to remove hydrocarbons from contaminated soil (HSDBi %23123459). The company is working to improve the commercial viability of their process, which could impact significantly on plastic waste in the future, providing that hydrocarbon based fuel

 and plastics remain a feature of current energy and manufacturing.
Primary Article Title: Oxford Sustainable Fuels to tackle plastic crisis by recycling waste into fuels
Keywords: waste energy fuel hazardous waste tyre plastic biomass hydrocarbon "Oxford Sustainable Fuels" OSF pyrolysis heat decompose fuel diesel jet fuel gasoline petrol "pyrolysis oil" regulation wood "contaminated land"

Summary Sentence: As the exponential cost reduction of silicon based solar panels looks to be coming to an end, researchers are looking to employ more exotic materials.
Justification:
These developments should interest the Environment Agency, since the move to renewable energy may have positive impacts on emissions due to a declining fossil fuel industry. But more complex composition of solar panels could complicate waste management practices

 further down the line. The environmental impacts of production and use may also be a factor. Perovskite is currently the material showing the most promise, potentially allowing for cheap, highly efficient solar coatings that could be unspooled from a printer

 “much as newspaper is printed.” Perovskite captures energy from a different part of sunlight’s wavelength than silicon, so could ‘piggyback’ on existing cells to increase efficiency. However there are already emerging health and environmental concerns around

 perovskite manufacture. Lead halide perovskite contains lead, representing approximately one third by weight of the absorber layer. Their imminent commercial upscaling of production is raising concerns about the potential impacts. Reflecting on historical

 and current impacts of lead poisoning new research wishes to create awareness and caution toward lead halide perovskite alongside ambiguity in currently policies and regulations, with a look to stimulating discussion on how the technology can move forward

 without creating environmental damage. There is some evidence that perovskites can be made lead free (HSDBi %2310298), but it is unclear if these are suitable for photovoltaic energy.
Primary Article Title: After the 'sunrush'&%2358; what comes next for solar power?
Author: Vaughan, A
Secondary_URLs: Environment versus sustainable energy&%2358; The case of lead halide perovskite-based solar cells - MRS Energy And Sustainability 17/01/2018
Keywords: energy chemistry perovskite solar panel PV photovoltaic silicon manufacturing regulation production efficiency lead halide pollution pollutant health emission chemical Pb

Summary Sentence: A digital platform for public consultations opens up the number and range of participants with an interest in planning issues.
Justification:
The Environment Agency is often involved in public consultations, and historically has also experimented with digital consultation platforms in the past, such as VEPS (Virtual Environmental Planning System) and therefore should be interested to see a successful

 realised implementation of this technology. The platform, from a start up called CoUrbanize, allows developers to question community members about what they’d most like to see on a site, such as howa site can represent the history of the neighborhood, or whether

 there should be outdoor market space. Comments can be represented geographically via a mapping interface. Because online comments are written it leads contributors to be more thoughtful and articulate in their responses, resulting in better quality data. People

 can build on each others comments, and it also removes some cultural blockers as people can comment in the language they wish. The online nature also means that time and geography are no longer barriers to input as they are in conventional consultations. Physical

 meetings tend to attract older members of the community who have the free time and therefore are not representative. Engaging with the public in this way has been found to reduce the barriers to development that often arise as everyone (with internet access

 at least) has the opportunity to contribute. Similar platforms may help aid Environment Agency involved consultations over new developments.
Primary Article Title: This site lets you have a voice in urban planning without attending inconvenient meetings
Author: Peters, A
Secondary_URLs: VEPS - Virtual Environmental Planning System - European Community Initiative INTERREG IIIB 01/12/2008
Keywords: planning consultation urban internet CoUrbanize YIMBY people community demographic map computer website regulation flooding

Summary Sentence: A species of oceanic diatom was exposed to increased seawater acidity — akin to the projected ocean acidity levels by the end of the century — that hindered diatoms from getting the iron they need to grow.
Justification:
Carbon dioxide in the air naturally reacts with sea water, producing carbonic acid and incrementally increasing the acidity of the seas. However, this increase in carbonic acid results in fewer carbonate molecules (technically a carbonate molecule that's

 negatively charged, or an ion) available.The researchers found that fewer carbonate molecules interfere with diatoms' ability to "grab" onto iron; in large areas of the ocean, the scarcity of iron controls the growth and productivity of phytoplankton. Acidification-driven

 declines in the concentration of seawater carbonate ions is likely to have a negative effect on this globally important eukaryotic iron acquisition mechanism. Falling diatom populations could stoke a vicious "feedback loop," wherein there's fewer diatoms to

 suck carbon out of the air and eventually sequester it near the ocean floor, particularly in areas already low in iron. Accordingly, there will be more carbon dioxide left in the atmosphere, further acidifying the oceans and making it more difficult for diatom

 populations to grow.
Primary Article Title: Carbonate-sensitive phytotransferrin controls high-affinity iron uptake in diatoms
Author: Jeffrey B. McQuaid, Adam B. Kustka, Miroslav Oborník, Aleš Horák, John P. McCrow, Bogumil J. Karas, Hong Zheng, Theodor Kindeberg, Andreas J. Andersson, Katherine A. Barbeau & Andrew E. Allen
Keywords: Acidification; Phytoplankton; Global Carbon Cycle

Summary Sentence: Data from 19 industries—among them car manufacturing, electronics, pharmaceuticals, plastics, chemicals, and food processing—that introduced industrial robots showed a one-for-six robot-for-humans swap.
Justification:
As robots and other computer-assisted technologies take over tasks previously performed by labour, there is increasing concern about the future of jobs and wages. This study analysed the effect of the increase in industrial robot usage between 1990 and

 2007 on US local labour markets. Using a model in which robots compete against human labor in the production of different tasks, it showed that robots may reduce employment and wages, and that the local labour market effects of robots can be estimated by regressing

 the change in employment and wages on the exposure to robots in each local labour market—defined from the national penetration of robots into each industry and the local distribution of employment across industries. Using this approach, the study estimated

 large and robust negative effects of robots on employment and wages; one more robot per thousand workers reduces the employment to population ratio by about 0.18-0.34 percentage points and wages by 0.25-0.5 percent.
Primary Article Title: Robots and jobs&%2358; evidence from US labor markets
Author: Daron Acemoglu, Pascual Restrepo
Keywords: Automation, employment, wages

Summary Sentence: Long-term monitoring is essential to effective environmental policy
Justification:
Using air pollution in the United States as a case study, this paper highlights the success of cleanup strategies backed by long-term environmental monitoring to demonstrate that environmental policy guided by science saves lives, money, and ecosystems.

 Air pollution has been linked to illness and premature death. When it falls on forests and freshwaters, it also compromises habitat, water quality, and ecosystem services. Reducing air pollution is good for human health and keeps industries like forestry,

 tourism, and fisheries viable. Since the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts enacted in the 1970s, monitoring sites have recorded declining concentrations of airborne pollutants such as sulphur, nitrogen, mercury, and lead. Precipitation has become less acidic,

 improving water quality in lakes and streams. Visibility-limiting haze and concentrations of ground-level ozone have also decreased.
Primary Article Title: Air pollution success stories in the United States&%2358; the value of long-term observations
Author: Timothy J. Sullivana, Charles T. Driscollb, Colin M. Beierc, Dallas Burtrawd, Ivan J. Fernandeze, James N. Gallowayf, David A. Gayg, Christine L. Goodaleh, Gene E. Likensi, j, Gary M. Lovetti, Shaun A. Watmoughk
Keywords: Environmental Monitoring, Environmental Poicy

Summary Sentence: 3D printed ‘drug factories’ could transform pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturing.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may need to consider the environmental consequences of a decentralisation of chemical production, as suggested by this new development. A team at Glasgow University have presented a new model for drug production using

 additive manufacturing. The 3D printer uses digital code to create a portable factory, which can then be used to produce the medicine in question through adding constituent chemicals in a predefined order. This approach could mean that drugs could be produced

 outside of conventional production environments. It could also mean that small runs of chemicals that are outside of patent, or no longer available through other channels could be produced on demand. The concept would be supported by a library of open source

 drug formulas, described as as ‘Spotify for chemistry’. As a proof of concept the team developed and digitised the remote bench scale manufacture of the muscle relaxant baclofen. This innovation has the potential to democratise both the location and economics

 of drug production through distributing plans and code via the internet. It could also mean that the production of banned, toxic and hazardous substances could also happen outside of regulated facilities, and may therefore present an environmental risk in

 some circumstances.
Primary Article Title: Chemical 'MP3 player' breakthrough converts digital code into pharmaceuticals
Secondary_URLs: The art of manufacturing molecules - Science 19/01/2018
Keywords: chemistry chemical pharmaceutical medicine drug "3D printing" "additive manufacturing" manufacturing digital data code plan "open source" internet toxic substance hazardous regulation factory patent decentralisation pollution pollutant

Summary Sentence: The Internet of Things (IOT) and smart technology could help better protect National Parks whilst driving down costs and enhancing visitor experience.
Justification:
A move towards a smarter and better connected rural landscape could also provide opportunities for better environmental monitoring for the Environment Agency and partners. A new report outlines approaches and revenue streams that the UK could leverage

 through IOT, such as informing rangers on footpath condition, reduce road miles through sending alerts on when waste bins need emptying and automatically making bookings for visitors at pubs and restaurants based on their location. The vision of a ‘Smart Park’

 is being explored by the Lake District National Park and Lancaster University. As urban areas become increasingly smart there is a risk that rural areas become left behind. Initiative such as this could help the Environment Agency to explore further potential

 benefits to monitoring, enforcement, regulation and incident management through engagement with the data and devices of Smart Parks and other rural digital infrastructure.
Primary Article Title: Report calls for National Parks to get smart
Keywords: data monitoring "Internet Of Things" IOT smart "national park" rural regulation incident emergency enforcement cost efficiency "Lake District"
GT: Internet Of Things, rural areas, monitoring

Summary Sentence: Japan is to lift a current ban on growing human organs in animals, US researchers have merged a sheep embryo with human stem cells, and Israeli scientists can grow new bones in the lab.
Justification:
There is huge potential in creating human organs in animals to fulfill shortages in transplant organs. Genetic engineering could allow organs containing a person’s DNA to be grown in an animal such as a pig. The resultant organ, because it contains the

 recipient’s genetic material, has a lower risk of being rejected by the host body (HSDBi %2314328, %2313711). The change to policy in Japan still forbids creating animals with high cognitive abilities. Researchers at Stanford University, having already merged

 human and pig genes have now successfully done the same thing with sheep, again with human organ transplants in mind. The ethics of a possibly growing aspect of agricultural practice, compared to the potential for human benefits may create political tension

 in the UK, should developments take a similar path.An industrial approach to fulfilling organ demand could have some relationship with installations regulation, which currently covers intensive pig farming. Other research has focussed on creating human ‘spare

 parts’ in laboratory conditions, therefore sidestepping the host animal issue. An Israeli company has perfected a technique for growing new bones. Liposuction extracts fat cells from the patient’s body, from which damage control cells are isolated. Following

 growth in a bioreactor to form thousands of tiny, living bone particles called BonoFill, the cells are injected back into the patient, where new bone growth occurs. The technique could be particularly relevant to older people and children with cleft palates.

 Trials are currently underway, and the team hopes to develop similar processes for replacing fat and cartilage.
Primary Article Title: Japan to lift ban on creating human organs in animals
Author: Jiji, K
Secondary_URLs:
Israeli biotech company successfully grows bones in lab - Times Of Israel 13/02/2018

Towards xenogeneic generation of human organs - American Association for the Advancement of Science 18/02/2018
Keywords: health organ disease illness transplant farming pig animal genetics DNA Japan USA Stanford sheep stem cell Israel bone laboratory patient liposuction fat cartilage regulation ethics welfare government ageing older children

Summary Sentence: Novel catalysts could help to reduce the energy costs of ammonia manufacture and lead to a decentralisation of fertiliser production.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may wish to consider how a realisation of this technique could impact on nitrate budgets and other aspects of farming related environmental impacts. Ammonia is currently produced using the Haber-Bosch process, which requires high energy

 for heat and pressure, using an iron catalyst. Because of the energy requirements for ammonia production fertilisers tend to be produced at scale and large factories before being transported to the point of use. The developments of these catalysts facilitate

 the prospect of ammonia production at a much smaller scale, and on site, such as a farm. Researchers have found that catalysts of calcium amide with a small amount of added barium (Ba-Ca(NH2)2) with ruthenium nanoparticles immobilised onto it is significantly

 more efficient than current catalysts, allowing ammonia production to occur under 300 degrees Celsius. Another catalyst, lanthanum–cobalt–silicon (LaCoSi), has similar effects. This means that the energy requirements of ammonia production could be significantly

 reduced, bring down costs. Easier ammonia production could also facilitate the move to a hydrogen based energy economy. An ammonia molecule is one nitrogen atom bonded with three hydrogen atoms. As it has high hydrogen content and is a liquid at room temperature,

 ammonia is a contender for an energy carrier and energy storage medium for hydrogen fuel cells. Decentralised ammonia production may fragment regulatory effort for the Environment Agency and could increase the amount of fertiliser entering the environment

 if prices are lower, which may have particular consequences for water quality.
Primary Article Title: Highly efficient ammonia synthesis catalyst developed
Secondary_URLs:
Self-organized ruthenium-barium core-shell nanoparticles on a mesoporous calcium amide matrix for efficient low-temperature ammonia synthesis - Angewandte Chemie 02/02/2018

Ternary intermetallic LaCoSi as a catalyst for N2 activation - Nature 22/01/2018
Keywords: energy fertiliser farming decentralisation agriculture nitrogen ammonia nitrate "water quality" pollution pollutant chemical chemistry manufacture regulation hydrogen energy catalyst "Haber-Bosch" pressure "calcium amide" barium (Ba-Ca(NH2)2) ruthenium nanoparticle lanthanum–cobalt–silicon (LaCoSi) eutrophication

Summary Sentence: Advances in material science and architecture could see wood used increasingly as a substitute for other materials.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may wish to consider the waste management implications of increased wood use, and what this could also mean for land use and forestry. Wood may all become increasingly attractive as an alternative to conventional construction materials

 used in asset construction and management, but with a lower environmental footprint. A newly discovered process has the potential to transform almost any type of wood into a material that is stronger than steel, and other hi tech alloys. The two step process

 increases the density of wood first by boiling it in a solution of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and sodium sulphite (Na2SO3), a chemical treatment similar to one used in paper manufacturing This partially removes lignin and hemicellulose polymers that stiffen a

 plant’s cell walls but leaves cellulose (another natural polymer) intact. The second step involves compression and gentle heating that encourages chemical bonds to form between hydrogen atoms and atoms in adjacent nanofibres of cellulose, greatly strengthening

 the material. The densified wood can be moulded into any shape, making it attractive as a lightweight alternative to metals such as steel, and is more easy to recycle than composite materials. Wood is also the material of choice for a proposed skyscraper in

 Japan, which would be the tallest wooden building in the world, and the tallest in the country. The Tokyo based project is attempting to popularise more use of wood in construction and stimulate the rural economy through increasing the demand for timber. Steel

 is also used in the building with wood incorporated into the structural framework. As sustainability rises up the agenda, wood may gain popularity as a construction material, providing that is also sustainably managed. There may be opportunities to improve

 resilience to soil erosion and run-off. More forestry could also bring changes to the rural economy as other industries, such as agriculture change focus through factors such as EU Exit.
Primary Article Title: Stronger than steel, able to stop a speeding bullet-it's super wood!
Secondary_URLs:
Tokyo plans world's tallest wooden skyscraper by 2041 - DesignBoom 15/02/2018

Processing bulk natural wood into a high-performance structural material - Nature 07/02/2018
Keywords: wood timber forestry tree construction architecture asset building material EU cellulose paper pulp regulation lignin hemicellulose polymer "sodium hydroxide" NaOH "sodium sulphite" Na2SO3 steel flood

Summary Sentence: Recent developments in decentralised energy storage further the domination of centralised fossil fuel based power generation.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as a regulator of the power sector may need to consider what impacts these changes could have, and where a decentralised infrastructure could bring resilience in incident management. At the vanguard of these developments is Tesla.

 Following a high profile, though relatively low capacity battery storage installation in South Australia to mitigate against short term grid failure (HSDBi %2314287), Tesla is committing to a new project in the same state. This one will install solar panels

 with battery storage in 50,000 homes over the next five years to create ‘the world’s largest virtual power plant’. The South Australian government funded project will cost $800 million, financed through investment and electricity sales. The networked Powerwall

 system will charge up when demand and electricity rates are low and discharge when demand and prices are high, providing up to 250 megawatts of energy, 20 per cent of the state’s daily use and apparently equivalent to a coal power station. Tesla has also recently

 struck a deal with a major retailer in the USA to sell it’s home solar and battery system, including it’s Solar Roof tile system, making access (and prices) increasing attractive to the consumer. In the UK a power infrastructure developer has recently signed

 a deal with GE to provide a 41-megawatt battery storage plant which could provide affordable, on-demand power to around 100,000 U.K. homes.
Primary Article Title: Tesla's latest South Australia battery project to rival the capacity of a coal plant
Author: Fehrenbacher, K
Secondary_URLs:
Arenko taps GE for 41-megawatt UK battery project - greentech 12/02/2018

Tesla expands sales of solar gear at Home Depot - Bloomberg 01/02/2018
Keywords: energy renewable decentralisation "energy storage" battery tesla "South Australia" Powerwall USA "Home Depot" solar roof UK power station regulation coal fossil fuel emission resilience incident emergency

Summary Sentence: Further examples are emerging on the positive and negative impacts that artificial intelligence (AI) could have on the workplace.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners are already in the process of trialling automation for some aspects of work, and therefore should also be considering the potential workforce impacts beyond the technology. AI is increasingly being used in recruitment.

 Examples include video based screening interviews where algorithms are used to shortlist applicants based on their responses and applications that automatically check the veracity of applicant CVs. It is argued that these applications help to remove unconscious

 bias from the interview process, but the anecdotal evidence of one job seeker suggests that using automated technology means that applicants are unprepared and do not receive the feedback they need to improve their prospects. AI may also find uses in dealing

 with workplace conflict. An app called Spot uses an AI based interface to interview victims of workplace discrimination and harassment, creating detailed reports that can be sent anonymously or otherwise, up the management chain. Spot makes sure the right

 questions are asked and doesn’t ask leading questions that can jeopardise investigations. Spot can be accessed by a victim immediately an incident has taken place, an advantage over reporting to a human. Spot also removes any discomfort a victim may have in

 talking directly to someone. The reports also legitimise their complaints and cannot be ignored if part of a process that requires action from management. There is also the opportunity to digitally track and manage workplace harassment to get a better idea

 of the scale of the issue.
Primary Article Title: This AI bot fights workplace harassment
Author: Matchar, E
Secondary_URLs: 'I didn't even meet my potential employers' - BBC 06/02/2018
Keywords: "artificial intelligence" AI workplace workforce employee interview recruitment "human resources" video harassment bullying conflict management app Spot report employer "unconscious bias" CV feedback skill

Summary Sentence: A non-hormone based male contraceptive pill based on arrow poison is in development.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested in considering the impact that such a contraceptive pill could make to water quality and biodiversity when compared to the impacts of hormone based female contraception that has been linked to sex

 changes in frogs, for example. The pill in development is based on ouabain, a plant extract used by African warriors as a heart stopping poison. Ouabain disrupts sodium and potassium ions movement through cells through disrupting proteins that transport the

 ions in and out of cells. It is also known to impact on another transporter called α4, which is found only in mature sperm cells. Due to the risk of heart damage ouabain itself is not directly suitable as a contraceptive source, so a chemical derivative of

 ouabain has been created that hinders sperm mobility while being administered. Tests are ongoing in rats currently. There are hormone based male contraceptives nearer to market based on the sex steroids testosterone and progestins, but these come with side

 effects, just as oestrogen based female pills do, and may also have endocrine disrupting properties. With a growing interest in non hormone based contraception in women (HSDBi %2314527), and few current pathways for male birth control, solutions similar to ouabain,

 if they catch on socially, may bring with them positive impacts for water quality and aquatic biodiversity.
Primary Article Title: Promising male birth control pill has its origin in an arrow poison
Author: Georg, G; et al
Secondary_URLs: Design, synthesis, and in vitro and in vivo evaluation of ouabain analogues as potent and selective Na,K-ATPase α4 isoform inhibitors for male contraception - Journal Of Medical Chemistry 01/01/2018
Keywords: "water quality" biodiversity "endocrine disruption" "endocrine disrupting chemical" EDC hormone chemistry biology chemical human oestrogen pill women female contraception male health pregnancy sperm protein ouabain poison Africa arrow plant steroid testosterone progestins frog animal fauna biodiversity pollution pollutant "water treatment" regulation transporter sodium potassium ion α4

Summary Sentence: A Korean university has developed the technology to be able to print batteries directly onto A4 paper using a conventional printer.
Justification:
This breakthrough could help remove the blockers to cheaper, more widespread electronics production, but may also signal a potential issue for electronic and related waste in the future through more decentralised production. It may also mean that waste

 becomes more challenging to recycle due to the increasingly composite nature of materials. Electronic circuits could effectively be printed onto any surface using variations of the same technique, which may enable the future of the internet of things (IoT)

 and flexible, wearable electronics.
Primary Article Title: Printable battery, selected for top 100 national R&D achievements
Author: Joo Hyeon Heo
Keywords: waste electronics WEEE paper printer decentralisation manufacturing battery energy regulation recycling "internet of things" IOT flexible wearable textile
GT: waste, electronics, internet of things. regulation

Summary Sentence: A Beligan company’s new turbine design could revolutionise the small scale hydropower industry.
Justification:
This may be of interest to the Environment Agency as the turbine design may fall outside of the current assumptions and regulations of hydropower installation and water resources extraction, in the face of micro generation and decentralisation. The company

 behind the turbine is called Turbulent. Their turbine design micro hydropower design is based around a whirlpool, where the turbine blade spins along a vertical axis. The turbine makes use of small rapids or waterfalls, where there is a height difference of

 five feet. Structures do not need to be built within the river itself. Land adjacent to these is dug up and the turbine and generator are installed. A small wall diverts some of the river water into the turbine, similar to other turbine designs. Turbulent’s

 turbine has one single moving part, and it’s concrete basin design should last 100 years. What’s more the turbine design is ‘fish friendly’, allowing fish to pass through the whirlpool without getting injured. Depending on size Turbluent can generate 15, 30,

 and 100 kilowatts.
Primary Article Title: Fish-friendly whirlpool turbine makes hydropower green again
Author: Cooke, L
Secondary_URLs: Turbulent website - Turbulent 13/03/2018
Keywords: energy renewable hydropower Turbulent whirlpool turbine fish friendly biodiversity efficient regulation decentralisation electricity generation river engineering water resources extraction abstraction

Summary Sentence: Scientists from the University of Manchester tested river sediments at 40 sites throughout Greater Manchester and found "microplastics everywhere".
Justification:
The article reports catchment-wide patterns of microplastic contamination, classified by type, size and density, in channel bed sediments at 40 sites across urban, suburban and rural river catchments in northwest England. To analyse river sediments, researchers

 isolated patches of riverbed and measured the concentration within those patches. Some urban "hotspots" contained hundreds of thousands of plastic particles per square metre. This included a site at the River Tame in Denton - a downstream, suburban stretch

 of river - that contained more than half a million plastic particles per square metre. The researchers carried out their first set of samples prior to the winter floods of 2015 and 2016. The team returned to the sites to see if the levels of plastic had changed

 after the flood events. This revealed that the floods had "flushed out" approximately 70% of the microplastics stored on these river beds, equivalent to almost a tonne of plastic, or nearly 50 billion particles. It also eradicated microbead contamination at

 seven sites. Many of the particles this study detected were so small, they would simply slip through the standard filtration nets that are used to sift microplastics out of the ocean implying this method maybe underestimating marine microplastic pollution

 by several orders of magnitude.
Primary Article Title: Microplastic contamination of river beds significantly reduced by catchment-wide flooding
Author: Rachel Hurley, Jamie Woodward, James J. Rothwell
Keywords: MIcroplastic Pollution; urban contamination hotspots

Summary Sentence: A new study led by the University of Stirling highlights improvements in the way conflicts between wildlife conservation and farming are managed worldwide.
Justification:
The management of conflicts between wildlife conservation and agricultural practices often involves the implementation of strategies aimed at reducing the cost of wildlife impacts on crops. The study looked at how governments from Scotland, Norway, Sweden

 and Denmark were tackling increased damage and financial losses caused by a rising number of large grazing birds landing and feeding on their land. For example, in some cases, population numbers are controlled through culling and, in others, compensation is

 paid for damage to crops. In recent decades, there has been a rapid increase in the number of large grazing birds - such as geese and cranes - across Europe. Many of these species have benefited from European Union legislation preventing them from being hunted

 in their wintering and breeding sites, as well as improvements in agricultural land quality, giving them access to better forage along their migration routes. On the Scottish island of Islay, for example, the cost of conflict between farmers and good conservation

 is in excess of £1 million a year. Vital to the success of strategies is the perception that changes in management efforts are synchronised relative to changes in impact levels, but the study showed inconsistent patterns of synchrony and asynchrony between

 changes in population counts and impact management effort relating to population harvesting, monetary payments or scaring practices.
Primary Article Title: Time series analysis reveals synchrony and asynchrony between conflict management effort and increasing large grazing bird populations in northern Europe
Author: Jeremy J. Cusack, Brad Duthie, Sarobidy Rakotonarivo, Rocío A. Pozo, Tom H. E. Mason, Johan Månsson, Lovisa Nilsson, Ingunn M. Tombre, Einar Eythórsson, Jesper Madsen, Ayesha Tulloch, Richard D. Hearn, Steve Redpath, Nils Bunnefeld
Keywords: Conservation Management, Human Wildlife Conflict, Monitoring, Adaptation

Summary Sentence: Chinese and Austrian scientists have enabled quantum key encryption using satellites.
Justification:
The prospect of quantum computing could have significant impacts for the Environment Agency, amongst others, as it could mean significant increases in processing power, but it could equally mean significant threats to cyber security if quantum encryption

 is not developed in parallel. The two nation team used China’s quantum satellite “Micius” to transmit a quantum key between the two countries, which was then used to securely send images and videos. Micius creates secure keys between the two locations, and

 relays data between them. Further development could see this as a standard for quantum encryption, however there may be questions on the reliability of using a satellite based system during times of incident.
Primary Article Title: China's "Micius" completes intercontinental quantum key distribution
Secondary_URLs: Satellite-relayed intercontinental quantum network - Physical Review Letters 13/03/2018
Keywords: "information technology" cybercrime "cyber crime" data security China Austria quantum satellite Micius incident emergency regulation

Summary Sentence: Investment analysts are proposing that a tax on meat would discourage overconsumption and reduce the environmental impacts of meat production.
Justification:
As a regulator of the agricultural industry the Environment Agency and partners may need to consider the regulatory impacts that such a tax could have on the farming sector’s size and profitability. Farm Animal Investment Risk and Return (FAIRR) have produced

 a report that explores taxing meat production could mitigated the global challenges of obesity, antimicrobial resistance, greenhouse gases and water resource use. This follows others considering using fiscal policy to reduce meat in people’s diets (HSDBi %2314200,

 %2314078, %2312347). Similar schemes have been successful for reducing consumption of tobacco and sugar, and also for reducing carbon. Any revenue generated from such a tax would be spent on healthcare. However meat is more complex. Whilst meat production have

 environmental implications and health impacts, moderate meat consumption is healthy. In some parts of the world meat consumption is encouraged to improve diets. A meat tax may not impact greatly those who can afford meat, and punish those who need to increase

 meat consumption to improve poor diets. Other incentives such as ‘nudges’ may be more effective than a meat tax on its own. However, any strategies to reduce meat consumption could translate to changes in farming practices that may produce different environmental

 impacts than currently seen, such as a reduction in pollution incidents or greater volumes of pesticide use.
Primary Article Title: Experts say we should tax meat eaters the same way we tax smokers
Author: Del Bello, L
Secondary_URLs: The livestock levy&%2358; are regulators considering meat taxes? - Farm Animal Investment Risk and Return 12/03/2018
Keywords: health "climate change" food meat farming tax obesity regulation behaviour fiscal policy tobacco carbon sugar diet agriculture incident pollution pollutant water quality
GT: farming, climate change, health, regulation, finance

Summary Sentence: A mix of factors is contributing to an increasing mortality rate of trees in the moist tropics, where trees in some areas are dying at about twice the rate that they were 35 years ago.
Justification:
Tree mortality rates appear to be increasing in moist tropical forests (MTFs) with significant carbon cycle consequences. This study analysed several factors affecting trees in the moist tropics, including rising temperatures and carbon dioxide levels,

 drought, fires, more potent storms, insect infestation, and the abundance of woody vines known as lianas. Nearly all of these factors are increasing the rising rate of mortality of trees in the moist tropics, but "Carbon starvation" due to lack of food and

 "hydraulic failure" due to a lack of water are likely to be the main cause. When conditions become hot and dry, trees conserve moisture, and they do so by closing their stomata. That closure, though, means the trees can't absorb carbon dioxide. And if stomata

 remain closed for a long enough time, it can result in carbon starvation. Even with the closure of their stomata, plants still lose water when it's hot and over a long period it can result in hydraulic failure - a lack of water a tree needs to survive.
Primary Article Title: Drivers and mechanisms of tree mortality in moist tropical forests
Author: McDowell, N., Allen, C. D., Anderson-Teixeira, K., Brando, P., Brienen, R., Chambers, J., Christoffersen, B., Davies, S., Doughty, C., Duque, A., Espirito-Santo, F., Fisher, R., Fontes, C. G., Galbraith, D., Goodsman, D., Grossiord, C., Hartmann, H., Holm
