Keywords: Tree mortality; climate change; carbon cycle

Summary Sentence: An architectural firm has proposed a floating city design concept for an area of New York.
Justification:
The housing complex consists of four tower structures attached to the dilapidated Pier 40 on the Hudson River. The towers are connected by ground level community spaces and elevated pathways, with the latter becoming more important as the lower areas are

 lost under rising water levels attributed to climate change. In reality Pier 40 already has uses, this is purely an architectural exercise. However with increasing pressures on land from growing populations and sea level rise, floating urban infrastructure

 is becoming increasingly attractive to cities and governments as a way to meet the demands of urbanisation by generating revenue from underutilised space and ensure communities are resilient to climate change and flooding related incidents. The Environment

 Agency may wish to consider whether it should advocate for further consideration of l;arge scale floating cities architecture as a flood management structure.
Primary Article Title: New York architecture firm proposes floating housing complex
Author: Dovey, R
Keywords: flooding "climate change" city urban architecture tower floating city "sea level rise" incident emergency planning government construction building "New York" "Hudson River" "Pier 40"

Summary Sentence: Research has shown krill are capable of digesting microplastics before excreting them back into the environment in an even smaller form.
Justification: Here, by exposing Antarctic krill (Euphausia superba) to microplastics under acute static renewal conditions, the study provides evidence of physical size alteration of microplastics ingested by a planktonic crustacean. Every year, more than eight million tons of plastic ends up in the ocean, costing billions of dollars in damage to marine ecosystems and studies estimate this results in the mortality of one million sea birds, 100,000 sea mammals and untold numbers of fish. Despite a growing body of research, there are still considerable knowledge gaps regarding spatial patterns and abundance of microplastics in the marine environment.This study found that fragments excreted by krill were, on average, 78 percent smaller than the original beads with some reduced by 94 percent. While this could hasten microplastic degradation in the environment, there is also the potential for toxins to be passed down the food chain as the smaller excreted particles become available to organisms that would not be able to ingest larger one
Primary Article Title: Turning microplastics into nanoplastics through digestive fragmentation by Antarctic krill
Author: Amanda L. Dawson, So Kawaguchi, Catherine K. King, Kathy A. Townsend, Robert King, Wilhelmina M. Huston & Susan M. Bengtson Nash
Keywords: microplastic pollution; krill

Summary Sentence: Smart land use planning could ease the conflict between agricultural production and nature conservation
Justification:
The uneven spatial distribution of both yield gaps and biodiversity provides opportunities for reconciling agricultural intensification and biodiversity conservation through spatially optimized intensification. Increasing agricultural production usually

 leads to negative side effects in agricultural landscapes, such as local decline in wildlife and loss of ecosystem functions. However, this study suggests that 88% of expected biodiversity loss under future agricultural intensification could be avoided if

 global land use was spatially optimised. It would require species rich countries, mainly in the tropics, to forego future production and economic development opportunities to safeguard the world's biodiversity, but these countries are often highly dependent

 on agriculture; 61% of projected biodiversity loss could be avoided through nationally focused optimisation, 33% of which is in just 10 countries. The researchers such targeted efforts to improve capacity for integrated land-use planning for sustainable intensification

 focused in these countries, including the strengthening of institutions that can arbitrate sub-national land-use conflicts, may offer an effective avenue to better reconcile future trade-offs between agriculture and conservation.
Primary Article Title: Winners and losers of national and global efforts to reconcile agricultural intensification and biodiversity conservation
Author: Lukas Egli, Carsten Meyer, Christoph Scherber, Holger Kreft, Teja Tscharntke
Keywords: Sustainable Intensification; Integrated Land Use Planning

Summary Sentence: A drug used to treat diabetes has been shown to reverse memory loss in mice under laboratory conditions.
Justification:
With an ageing population not only in the UK but across the world, this research could have wide implications for the Environment Agency from workforce planning to water quality issues. Diabetes drugs that are found to have more than one use has been seen

 before (Metformin - another diabetes drug - can increase life expectancy). This research suggests that only a very specific diabetes drug containing GLP-1, GIP and Glucagon - known as a triple receptor - has the protective effects on neurons in the brain.

 A recent trial using this drug on Parkinson's patients yielded positive results. Whilst more work needs to be done to establish how humans will react to the drug and at what stage of the disease it would need to be administered to be effective, the results

 to date are promising. It may be prudent to consider the potential environmental impacts of this substance, which may grow in use due to ageing populations.
Primary Article Title: Scientists claim they found a drug that "significantly reverses memory loss"
Secondary_URLs: Neuroprotective effects of a triple GLP-1/GIP/glucagon receptor agonist in the APP/PS1 transgenic mouse model of Alzheimer's disease - Brain Research 08/03/2018
Keywords: Alzheimer's memory "memory loss" cognition drugs diabetes metformin medication medicine age ageing "ageing population"

Summary Sentence: Triodos is the first mainstream UK bank to develop a crowdfunding platform for customers to invest directly in organisations that deliver environmental, sustainable or social benefits.
Justification:
This is another example of decentralisation as customers invest directly in companies that have been chosen for the credibility of their business model, the sustainability impact of their business and the viability of their management team to deliver.

 Triodos claim this approach champions social investment, allowing customers to 'shape the future world they live in'. This may well put pressure on other mainstream banks to provide similar schemes for customers in-line with the government's call last year

 to allow customers access to social impact investments.
Primary Article Title: Triodos pioneers sustainable crowdfunding platform
Keywords: finance banking crowdfunding decentralisation investment sustainability banks business equity bonds savings

Summary Sentence: Researchers have published a paper providing evidence that a ‘cooling-off effect’ can lead to increased public acceptance of new environmental technologies over time.
Justification:
This paper analyses how new information shapes public perception of a controversially discussed technology over time. The public perception of a new environmental technology plays an important role in the development of relevant policy. If a novel technique

 is not acceptable to the general public, it is unlikely to be widely deployed. Acceptance is often measured using one-shot public-perception surveys, in which respondents are asked to state their acceptance at a single point in time. However, there is evidence

 from fields outside environmental technology that public opposition is liable to change over time, often declining as negative emotions ‘cool off’. This study used solar radiation management (SRM), a controversial climate-engineering technique, as a test case.

 SRM seeks to counteract global warming by injecting sulphate aerosols into the stratosphere; while potentially highly effective at reducing global warming, it comes with unknown risks. They found that, following a cooling-off period of either one month, 12

 months, or 18 months, acceptance of SRM increased significantly — and that the longer the cooling-off period, the larger the increase. However, several traits appear to influence individual vulnerability to the cooling-off effect&%2358; groups associated with smaller

 changes in acceptance over time included people who scored higher for reflectivity and patience; men; and individuals with higher levels of education. Overall, the acceptance of more reflective respondents was less likely to increase than that of less reflective

 respondents.
Primary Article Title: Exploring public perception of environmental technology over time
Author: Carola Braun, Katrin Rehdanz, Ulrich Schmidt
Keywords: Novel technologies; geoengineering

Summary Sentence: A proposed cap and trade scheme could be the answer to water conservation issues in California.
Justification:
Cap and trade schemes have been used to reduce other environmental impacts such as emissions. It is therefore of interest to the Environment Agency to explore if such a scheme could provide the necessary incentives for better water resource management

 in the future. California has been experiencing a sustained period of drought over the past few years. The state dictated water conservation goals, but these were met with varying success across the state as different operators such as water companies took

 different approaches. A team at Stanford University have suggested that cap and trade based on local supply and demand issues would be more effective. Such a scheme would help to account for behaviour towards water use. For example wealthier communities tend

 to use more water as they have bigger gardens to water. Putting a price on water use in this way could encourage more social responsibility to water use that could transcend socioeconomic boundaries. Giving water companies targets to meet, rather than imposing

 measures to meet them (such as hosepipe bans) could encourage more innovation in meeting them. Income generated from cap and trade by a community could be used to finance new initiatives that help address water demand in the face of population growth and an

 infrastructure not currently designed for the realities of new norms of climate.
Primary Article Title: Share the wealth&%2358; a cap-and-trade system of water conservation and resiliency?
Author: Derouin, S
Secondary_URLs: Coordinating water conservation efforts through tradable credits&%2358; a proof of concept for drought response in the San Francisco Bay area - Water Resources Research 01/09/2017
Keywords: "water resources" drought "climate change" incident emergency economics "cap and trade" regulation "water company" state government California socioeconomic wealth community demand regulation income behaviour incident emergency

Summary Sentence: A ‘nanofoam’ catalyst made of nickel and iron could lead to cheap and efficient hydrogen production.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may be interested to consider how this development could lead to larger scale hydrogen production and a move towards a hydrogen energy economy. Clean and renewable hydrogen production is currently tied to electrolysis, where hydrogen

 is extracted from water. This process requires catalysts to make it efficient which are commonly made from rare earth metals such as platinum. Scientists are experimenting with cheaper catalyst materials such as molybdenum sulfide, and hybrid solid-state electrolyzers.

 In this recent experiment scientists produced a nickel and iron nanofoam, a material which resembles a sponge at the atomic level and has a large surface area. Experiments showed that the foam performed better than the more expensive catalysts but for a fraction

 of the cost. While the researchers haven’t outlined their production process they state that the nanofoam can be made cheaply, quickly and can be scaled up to industrial production. The Environment Agency may also wish to consider if disposal of nanofoam may

 present any waste or pollution issues at the end of life, should this method of hydrogen production become realised.
Primary Article Title: Metallic nanofoam wrings hydrogen out of water more efficiently
Secondary_URLs: Ultrafine and highly disordered Ni2Fe1 nanofoams enabled highly efficient oxygen evolution reaction in alkaline electrolyte - Nano Energy 07/03/2018
Keywords: energy hydrogen electrolysis catalyst platinum "molybdenum sulphide" "hybrid solid-state electrolyzers" nanofoam sponge nickel iron cost efficient water electricity waste pollution pollutant regulation

Summary Sentence: Artificial sweeteners could have multiple applications in environmental monitoring, but may also represent an environmental risk.
Justification:
The range of applications described could all have impacts on the Environment Agency’s work in maintaining water quality and incident management. Several chemicals are used as tracers in water quality monitoring, such as caffeine. Detecting these chemicals

 in water suggests that there is a problem with wastewater pollution somewhere along the line as the source is likely to be man made. Artificial sweeteners such as acesulfame, but also Sucralose in particular are even more stable chemicals in nature, as organisms

 do not recognise these chemicals as food, therefore they aren’t broken down by biological processes during water treatment. Sucralose has been monitored as a tracer chemical previously, but it could also be used as an indicator. If sucralose concentrations

 reach a certain level it suggests that other chemical concentrations are approaching levels where eutrophication can occur. Sucralose levels could also be used to indicate the potential of the formation of disinfection by-products during water treatment. These

 are chemicals formed through the reaction of disinfectants used during water treatment with other compounds in the water to produce potentially toxic substances. Sucralose may also indicate the concentrations of bacteria in wastewater outflow. This could for

 example help to steer policy on how wastewater is impacting on habitats, such coral bleaching. Despite all the potential uses there are concerns that there is little assessment of the environmental impacts of artificial sweeteners. Their chemical stability

 and increasing use means that environmental levels may increase over time. Some studies have suggested that sucralose exposure impacts on aquatic biodiversity, impeding crustacean speed, causing oxidative stress in fish, and interfering with photosynthesis

 in aquatic plants. Further research may be needed both in terms of the monitoring benefits and environmental risks to ensure that suitable regulations are put in place in the future.
Primary Article Title: Artificial sweeteners are used to track water pollution
Author: Cernansky, R
Keywords: "water quality" pollution water "water treatment" wastewater sweetener sucralose acesulfame chemical pollutant tracer indicator caffeine biodiversity monitoring regulation bacteria disinfection by-product toxic substance crustacean carp fish insect flea coral organism digestion sugar food "oxidative stress"

Summary Sentence: Nearly a fifth of Europe's wood beetle species face extinction because the old, decaying trees they depend on have been cleared from forests
Justification:
Saproxylic beetles are insects that depend on dead and decaying wood for at least part of their life cycle, and play important ecological roles in European habitats. Eighteen percent of the 700 beetle species surveyed were found to be at risk, but the

 percentage is likely higher because there was not enough data to classify a quarter of those examined. The 3,000 known species of saproxylic beetles need dead and decaying wood at some point during their life cycles. The insects also play a crucial role in

 recycling nutrients, and provide a key food source for birds and mammals. They interact with other organisms such as mites, nematodes, bacteria and fungi, assisting in their dispersal across the landscape and a few are also pollinators. Logging, tree loss

 and wood harvesting all contribute to the loss of habitat for the beetles, other major threats include urbanisation and tourism development, and an increase in wildfires in the Mediterranean region. Conservation efforts need to focus on long-term strategies

 to protect old trees and deadwood across forests, pastureland, orchards and urban areas and there should be inventories of ancient and veteran trees for each European country, to ensure these trees are protected in all landscapes.
Primary Article Title: European red list of saproxylic beetles
Author: Cálix, M., Alexander, K.N.A., Nieto, A., Dodelin, B., Soldati, F., Telnov, D., Vazquez-Albalate, X., Aleksandrowicz, O., Audisio, P., Istrate, P., Jansson, N., Legakis, A., Liberto, A., Makris, C., Merkl, O., Mugerwa Pettersson, R., Schlaghamersky, J., Bo
Keywords: Loss of species, ecosystem function

Summary Sentence: The impact of aerosol emissions on global weather may have previously been underestimated.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may be interested in these conclusions from two different studies that look at the impact of air pollution derived from small particles on weather and climate. One study links ultrafine particles from air pollution in

 South American cities with more intense storms in the Amazon, which can have repercussions for global climate and weather systems. Previously tiny particles were thought to be too insignificant to impact on cloud formation, but this new study shows that, for

 the Amazon at least, that this is not the case. Another study links aerosol pollution with a heightened risk of lightning strikes. The scientists involved came to this conclusion through mapping patterns of cloud to ground lightning strikes and air pollution.

 This discovery has implications for cloud formation and climate change models, but also for human impacts in the developing world where lightning strikes are more associated with fatalities - 3,000 a year in India alone. Aerosols have previously been suspected

 of having a link to lightning strikes, but this is some of the first real evidence that this is the case, and is yet another reason for limiting anthropogenic air emissions.
Primary Article Title: Pollution boosts risk of lightning
Author: Cartwright, J
Secondary_URLs:
Substantial convection and precipitation enhancements by ultrafine aerosol particles - Science 26/01/2018

Global association of aerosol with flash density of intense lightning - Environmental Research Letters 17/11/2017

Tiny pollutants intensify storms in the Amazon - Sci Dev Net 07/02/2018
Keywords: "air pollution" "climate change" weather meteorology incident rainfall lightning global emission regulation Amazon pollutant aerosol microscopic incident emergency

Summary Sentence: Industrial scale renewable energy to hydrogen plants are starting to take shape.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners should be interested to see how this sector develops as it could present new environments in which site based regulation will occur, and possibly signal the demise of other currently regulated sectors based around fossil

 fuels. One example is in Australia, near Port Lincoln, SA. The plant will use a combination of wind and solar to create hydrogen, which will be used to power a 10MW hydrogen-fired gas turbine and a 5MW hydrogen fuel cell which will both supply power to the

 grid. The plant will also produce ammonia as a byproduct for fertiliser production. There are also considerations as to how best export surplus hydrogen to more developed overseas markets. Meanwhile Dubai is making plans for the region’s first solar powered

 hydrogen electrolysis facility to test and showcase producing hydrogen from solar energy, storing and then deploying hydrogen for re-electrification, transportation or other industrial uses.
Primary Article Title: Coming up&%2358; a solar-powered hydrogen plant in Dubai
Secondary_URLs: Bigger than LNG? SA to get first "green hydrogen" plant - InDaily 12/02/2018
Keywords: energy hydrogen fuel cell installation regulation operator Dubai Adelaide "South Australia" "Port Lincoln" electrolysis turbine grid electricity storage export fertiliser ammonia emission solar wind renewable transport

Summary Sentence: A new approach to graphene filtration has produced that can make Sydney Harbour water drinkable after just one pass.
Justification:
The Environment Agency and partners may consider how further development and realisation of graphene filtration technology could impact on a range of regulatory applications such as pollution prevention and water treatment. The new filter is made from

 a version of graphene that the developers called ‘GraphAir’, produced from soybean oil without the need for vacuum processing or high temperature kilns, both of which are central to the conventional chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technique currently used

 in graphene production. The thin Graphair membrane features microscopic nanochannels that allow pure water to pass through but trap all other substances. Graphair continued to work even when covered with pollutants, reducing maintenance requirements. As a

 proof of concept stunt the researchers treated Sydney Harbour water to that it was fit to drink. The team sees primary applications in the developing world for securing safe drinking water, but are looking for industrial partners to explore other avenues including

 community and domestic water treatment and filtration, as well as treating seawater (desalination applications presumably) and industrial effluents.
Primary Article Title: Tiny membrane makes Sydney Harbour "drinkable"
Author: Bick, M
Secondary_URLs:
CSIRO makes high-quality graphene with soybeans - Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation 31/01/2018

Anti-fouling graphene-based membranes for effective water desalination - Nature 14/02/2018
Keywords: water "water quality" "water treatment" graphene Graphair filtration nano channel soybean pollution pollutant desalination industry effluent regulation incident "Sydney Harbour" "chemical vapour deposition" CVD decentralisation

Summary Sentence: Two Chinese companies are developing small scale nuclear energy technology for local heating purposes.
Justification:
The Environment Agency should be interested in this development of decentralisation in energy provision as it could represent a change to how the nuclear industry is currently regulated. One feasibility studies has looked at the potential of using NHR200-II.

 It was found to be suitable for low-temperature heating reactor technology, providing heat, water and steam for residential heating and industrial processes in remote areas. It can be constructed near to end-users in around two to three years if done on a

 mass scale. Another company has trialled its Yanlong small district heating reactor in Beijing, providing heating to the equivalent of 50 homes. If working at full capacity the same system could provide heating for 200,000 urban households, with zero emissions.

 The Yanlong deep pool system doesn’t produce electricity, only heating. District heating systems are gaining ground in Scandinavia and Russia, and may also start to appear in the UK. The emission free aspect of using nuclear energy in this way may appeal to

 concerns over urban air quality, but an increasing number of sites operating with radioactive material could represent challenges for waste management under the current regulatory paradigm.
Primary Article Title: Nuclear reactors for heating can be mass produced and each would take two years to build
Author: Wang, B
Keywords: energy nuclear heating power urban air quality pollution pollutant emission regulation radioactive waste Yanlong "deep pool system" "district heating system" Scandinavia Russia "low-temperature heating reactor" NHR200-II China Beijing household decentralisation

Summary Sentence: A platform for startups that customise everything from diet to workouts, or family planning to personal fashion, based on an individual’s genetic code is being set up in the US.
Justification:
Helix differentiates itself from other genetics testing companies with a new type of testing methodology, called “next generation sequencing”, which provides more data than existing sequencing tests including all 22,000 protein coding genes and “additional

 regions known to be of interest”. Once users pay the $80 to have their exome sequenced by Helix, they never have to take another genetic test for a service that’s listed on the Helix platform, but Helix is not developing any product itself other than the marketplace

 for companies to sell services. Helix is working with the Mayo Clinic, a Helix investor and one of the leading medical research institutions in the U.S., for a range of new services and Helix has also partnered with other groups on population health services

 that could have broad implications for the industry. This includes the Renown Institute for Health Innovation to offer gene sequencing services to 40,000 Nevadans to begin conducting population health models based on the results of the genetic tests Helix

 will perform. Through co-operation with another partner, Illumina Accelerator, Helix hope to provide breakthrough startups with the resources, infrastructure, and support to transform their ideas into compelling consumer applications and services that make

 genomics relevant and accessible to every person based on their unique interests. They will also give researchers and clinicians access to the genetic information if their customers give permission.
Primary Article Title: Helix holds first close on a planned $200 million investment in its genetic services marketplace
Keywords: Personalised Genetic Medicine

Summary Sentence: A team of researchers from Harvard University is close to recreating a near-complete genome of the little bush moa&%2358; a flightless bird native to New Zealand that was wiped out in the 13th century due to overhunting.
Justification:
High throughput sequencing (HTS) has revolutionized the field of ancient DNA (aDNA) by facilitating recovery of nuclear DNA for greater inference of evolutionary processes in extinct species than is possible from mitochondrial DNA alone. Most studies of

 the DNA of extinct species have relied upon mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), since mtDNA occurs in high copy number per cell and is therefore more readily recovered than nuclear DNA from subfossil substrates where aDNA is often highly degraded. High throughput sequencing

 (HTS) has revolutionized the field of aDNA by allowing recovery of these short segments of nuclear DNA. Unlike mtDNA, which is uniparentally inherited and represents only a tiny fraction of the total genomic 'blueprint' in an individual, nuclear DNA can provide

 much more detail concerning the evolutionary history and unique adaptations of extinct species. Extinction of all moa species is thought to have closely followed Polynesian settlement of New Zealand in the late 13th century as the result of direct human exploitation

 compounded by anthropogenic land-use changes and impacts associated with introduced species. The results indicate that the little bush Moa's genes strongly resemble the modern emu’s, which suggests a possible means of recreating a Moa like species by starting

 with an emu and trying to make it as moa-like as possible. This suggests that 'resurrecting' extinct species may be possible in the near future increasing debates about the ethics and ecological implications of doing so.
Primary Article Title: First nuclear genome assembly of an extinct moa species, the little bush moa (Anomalopteryx didiformis)
Author: Alison Cloutier, Timothy B. Sackton, Phil Grayson, Scott V. Edwards, Allan J. Baker
Keywords: Species Resurrection

Summary Sentence: The 263 known viruses that circulate in humans represent less than 0.1 percent of the viruses suspected to exist that could jump from other species and infect people.
Justification:
Nearly all recent pandemics have a viral etiology with animal origins, and with their intrinsic capacity for interspecies transmission, viral zoonoses are prime candidates for causing the next great pandemic. The ability to mitigate disease emergence is

 undermined by poor understanding of the diversity and ecology of viral threats, and of the drivers of their emergence. Global Virome Project (GVP) seeks to identify the bulk of this viral threat and provide timely data for public health interventions against

 future pandemics. The international collaboration will survey viruses harboured by birds and mammals to identify candidates that might be zoonotic, or able to jump to humans. Based on the viral diversity in two species known to host emerging human diseases

 — Indian flying foxes and rhesus macaques — the team estimates there are about 1.67 million unknown viruses still to be discovered in the 25 virus families surveyed. Of those, between 631,000 and 827,000 might be able to infect humans. The project aims to

 identify approximately 70% of these potential threats within the next 10 years, focusing on animals in places known to be hot spots for the emergence of human-infecting viruses.
Primary Article Title: The global virome project
Author: Dennis Carroll, Peter Daszak, Nathan D. Wolfe, George F. Gao, Carlos M. Morel, Subhash Morzaria, Ariel Pablos-Méndez, Oyewale Tomori, Jonna A. K. Mazet
Keywords: Zoonoses, Global Pandemic

Summary Sentence: Oceans cover more than two-thirds of the planet’s surface, and industrial fishing occurred across 55% of that area in 2016.
Justification:
More than half of the world's oceans are subject to industrial-scale harvest, spanning an area four times that covered by terrestrial agriculture. Although fishing is one of the most widespread activities by which humans harvest natural resources, its

 global footprint is poorly understood and has never been directly quantified. This study processed 22 billion automatic identification system messages and tracked >70,000 industrial fishing vessels from 2012 to 2016, creating a global dynamic footprint of

 fishing effort with spatial and temporal resolution two to three orders of magnitude higher than for previous data sets. The data showed that industrial fishing occurs in >55% of ocean area and has a spatial extent more than four times that of agriculture.

 Much of the fishing was concentrated in countries’ exclusive economic zones — ocean regions within about 370 kilometers of a nation’s coastline — and in certain hot spots farther out in the open ocean including the northeastern Atlantic Ocean and the nutrient-rich

 upwelling regions off the coasts of South America and West Africa. Five countries, China, Spain, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea, accounted for nearly 85% of fishing efforts on the high seas, the regions outside of any country’s exclusive economic zone. Tracking

 the fishing footprint in space and time could help guide marine environmental protections and international conservation efforts for fish at a time of rising ocean temperatures, acidification and increasing human activity on the high seas.
Primary Article Title: Tracking the global footprint of fisheries
Author: David A. Kroodsma, Juan Mayorga, Timothy Hochberg, Nathan A. Miller, Kristina Boerder, Francesco Ferretti, Alex Wilson, Bjorn Bergman, Timothy D. White, Barbara A. Block, Paul Woods, Brian Sullivan, Christopher Costello, Boris Worm
Keywords: High Seas, Fisheries, Marine Conservation

Summary Sentence: Bacteria could be used to detoxify industrial wastewater and generate electricity simultaneously.
Justification:
Warm and salty wastewater is the byproduct of many Environment Agency regulated industries, such as fossil fuel production, food processing and textile production. Researchers have been experimenting with types of bacteria that can tolerate extreme heat

 and saline conditions (extremophiles) whilst transferring electrons (exoelectrogenes), which we collected from rock pools in the Red Sea brine pools. Some of the bacteria were introduced to prototype microbial electrolysis cells (MECs),also known as fuel cells.

 MECs consist of glass bottles filled with wastewater, containing graphite and stainless-steel electrodes. Exoelectrogenic bacteria oxidize organic matter in the wastewater, generating electrons that are transported to the positive electrode. When a small voltage

 is applied to the system, the electrons combine with protons in the water at the negative electrode, producing hydrogen gas, which can be syphoned off for energy generation. Bacteria used in the test were able to stand salinity levels of up to 25 per cent.

 The team is now looking at the potential of other Red Sea bacteria in MECs that can convert waste products, such as carbon dioxide, into commercially valuable chemicals, such as methane and acetate.
Primary Article Title: Briny pool bacteria can clean up and power up
Secondary_URLs: Enrichment of extremophilic exoelectrogens in microbial electrolysis cells using Red Sea brine pools as inocula - Bioresource Technology 01/09/2017
Keywords: energy waste industry regulation brine saline salt wastewater bacteria extremophile exoelectrogene "Red Sea" "microbial electrolysis cell" MEC oxidisation hydrogen electron proton graphite steel voltage eletricity waste "carbon dioxide" emission chemical methane acetate

Summary Sentence: The advent of quantum computing could mean that the data security of blockchain systems becomes threatened.
Justification:
Blockchain technology is currently as a way to bring both security and transparency to a range of transactions. Current encryption technology is based on factoring a number that is the product of two large primary numbers. Calculating these requires a

 great deal of time and processing power, and so makes for the basis of a solid encryption. Quantum computers are much faster, meaning that this factoring can happen much quicker - seconds, rather than years - rendering current encryption obsolete. As the world,

 including Defra, moves towards blockchain based systems may be worth considering how these systems could be future proofed by including quantum proof encryption. There is already one project, The Quantum Resistant Ledger team, that is working on quantum-resistance

 blockchain technology.
Primary Article Title: Is quantum computing an existential threat to blockchain technology?
Author: Sharma, N
Keywords: data security blockchain quantum encryption "Quantum Resistant Ledger team" incident emergency

Summary Sentence: The variability of silver nanoparticle content in commercial products has been found to vary considerably.
Justification:
This should be of interest to the Environment Agency as past research has demonstrated that silver nanoparticles have may be detrimental to plants and wildlife (HSDBi %2310908 & %2312457), therefore it is important to understand the quantities that may be

 entering the environment. Humans are exposed to silver nanoparticles from many products, including spray disinfectants, fabrics, plastics, antibacterial coatings and dietary supplements. Researchers characterised the nature of silver nanoparticles in 22 products,

 considering total silver, fractionated silver (particulate and dissolved), primary particle size distribution, hydrodynamic diameter, particle number, and plasmon resonance absorbance. They found that a high degree of variability between stated levels of silver

 and actual levels - only seven of the 22 products had levels within 20 per cent of the stated amount. There were also significant variations in the relative percentages of particulate to soluble silver in many products reporting to be colloidal silver (silver

 particles in liquid, often taken as a dietary supplement). Particle size was also found to vary considerably. The lack of standardisation is of concern due to the rapidly growing nature of this sector presenting a challenge to assess overall levels and range

 of impacts that silver nanoparticles from consumer products could be having on the environment.
Primary Article Title: Characterization of engineered nanoparticles in commercially available spray disinfectant products advertised to contain colloidal silver
Author: Rogers, K. J; et al
Keywords: silver "colloidal silver" nanoparticle nanotechnology products AMR "anti-microbial resistance" biodiversity chemical chemistry plant animal wildlife water quality pollution pollutant spray disinfectant fabric plastic, antibacterial coating dietary supplement regulation manufacturing health antibacterial

Summary Sentence: Farming with crushed silicate rocks offers a simple but effective action to improve soil health.
Justification:
Managed croplands worldwide are already equipped for frequent rock dust additions to soils, making rapid adoption at scale feasible, and the potential benefits could generate financial incentives for widespread adoption in the agricultural sector. The

 magnitude of future climate change could be moderated by immediately reducing the amount of CO2 entering the atmosphere as a result of energy generation and by adopting strategies that actively remove CO2 from it. Biogeochemical improvement of soils by adding

 crushed, fast-reacting silicate rocks to croplands is one such CO2-removal strategy. This approach has the potential to improve crop production, increase protection from pests and diseases, and restore soil fertility and structure. Through enhanced rock weathering,

 carbon absorption can be achieved without competing for additional land and water. The crushed rock method also reduces the need for fertilizers and pesticides and decreases the cost of food production. However, there are still obstacles to be surmounted.

 Audited field-scale assessments of the efficacy of CO2 capture are urgently required together with detailed environmental monitoring. A cost-effective way to meet the rock requirements for CO2 removal must be found, possibly involving the recycling of silicate

 waste materials. Finally, issues of public perception, trust and acceptance must also be addressed.
Primary Article Title: Farming with crops and rocks to address global climate, food and soil security
Author: David J. Beerling, Jonathan R. Leake, Stephen P. Long, Julie D. Scholes, Jurriaan Ton, Paul N. Nelson, Michael Bird, Euripides Kantzas, Lyla L. Taylor, Binoy Sarkar, Mike Kelland, Evan DeLucia, Ilsa Kantola, Christoph Müller, Greg Rau & James Hansen
Keywords: Soil Fertility, Carbon, Agriculture, Biogeochemical Improvement, Crop Production, Input Reduction

Summary Sentence: New research on ice sheet melting implies that sea level could rise at a greater rate than currently thought.
Justification:
This has implications for the Environment Agency in terms of coastal flooding, including planning the resilience of coastal flood defence structures.New analysis predicts that sea level will rise by two feet by 2100, but that this rate could increase if

 the melting of polar ice caps continues to intensify. This could be as high as 10mm per year by the end of the century, equating to a sea level rise of 65cm. Given the large changes in ice sheet melting seen in recent years, the authors believe this may be

 a conservative estimate.
Primary Article Title: As ice sheets melt faster, sea level rise is accelerating every year
Secondary_URLs: Climate-change-driven accelerated sea-level rise detected in the altimeter era - Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 09/02/2018
Keywords: "climate change" "sea level" ocean marine flooding coast incident asset flood defence construction ice glacier melt 2100 polar ice cap
GT: sea level rise, coastal flood management

Summary Sentence: A project to examine the technical feasibility of extracting rare minerals from mine wastewater is about to enter a second stage.
Justification:
The US project is looking to extract valuable earth elements from Acid Mine Drainage (AMD), a by-product of coal mining. Rare earth elements have a high commercial value, for use in electronics. The USA current imports the majority of its rare minerals

 from China. The new process has the potential to generate wealth from a problematic pollution source, without producing further environmental degradation often associated with rare earth element extraction. If the technology is proven the next stage is to

 move it into the marketplace. Applications of this technology in the UK may have the potential to reduce the impact of similarly problematic sources, and therefore may have regulatory impacts for the Environment Agency.
Primary Article Title: WVU study of rare earth elements moves to second phase
Keywords: "water quality" resources waste minerals minewater "rare earth element" coal mining regulation treatment "Acid Mine Drainage" AMD metal incident

Summary Sentence: Farmers in the USA are finding themselves at the front of the ‘right to repair’ movement.
Justification:
The ability for citizens to have the legal rights and access to the technical documentation to be able to repair their purchases could be central to the adoption of a more circular economy, reducing the need to replace products when they break. As the

 world becomes more connected through the internet of things (IOT) there are likely to be increasing numbers of devices, and therefore increasing volumes of electronic waste if repair is not a legal or economically viable option to people. John Deere tractors

 are one of the many companies who use legal action to prevent customers from having the technical knowledge needed for repair, which would otherwise push them to approved repair outlets. Other companies include Apple, Samsung and Tesla. Taking a tractor out

 of action at critical times is expensive and time consuming. Farmers have therefore been turning to pirated diagnostic software and other techniques in order to be able to carry out repairs for themselves at a fraction of the cost. This necessity is building

 into a political movement. 18 states are currently considering “fair repair” bills, which would require manufacturers to sell repair parts and tools to the masses, would require them to make repair manuals available to the public, and would require them to

 provide circumvention tools for software locks that are specifically designed to prevent third party repair. Big Tech is naturally lobbying to prevent this occurring. Companies such as IFIXIT are turning the repair movement into a legitimate business. Their

 business model is to document gadget dismantling and repair via social media, and then sell people the parts and specialist tools needed to do things like replace a smartphone screen. At the heart of their business model is the same right to repair ethos that

 is growing in the US farming community. As a stunt IFIXIT recently ‘tore down’ an iPhone X on the day of release and shared their findings. These stories not only have waste implications but also highlight an example of the influence of a decentralisation

 agenda that undermines the traditional business models of copyrighting and planned obsolescence.
Primary Article Title: Leading a revolt against Big Tech's repair monopolies
Author: Koebler, J
Secondary_URLs: We flew around the World to watch the annual race to tear down the iPhone - Motherboard 15/02/2018
Keywords: waste electronics agriculture "internet of things" IOT smartphone software pirate diagnostic law  lobby legislation regulation WEEE components farmers "right to repair" USA Apple "John Deere" Tesla Samsung iPhone IFIXIT hack

Summary Sentence: Wood biomass is the most abundant feed stock envisioned for the development of modern biorefineries, but the cost-effective conversion of this form of biomass into commodity products is limited by its resistance to enzymatic degradation.
Justification:
An international team of researchers, including scientists from the University of York, has discovered a set of enzymes found in fungi that are capable of breaking down one of the main components of wood. The discovery of this unique enzyme activity advances

 knowledge on the degradation of woody biomass in nature and offers an innovative solution for improving enzyme cocktails for biorefinery applications. Current wood biorefineries have to use pre-treatment processes, making the conversion of wood into fuels

 and products expensive and energy-consuming. The research has shown that the family of enzymes, called lytic polysaccharide monooxygenases (LPMOs), are capable of breaking down xylans - carbohydrate molecules commonly found in wood biomass that are particularly

 resistant to degradation. The enzymes could now potentially be used to sustainably convert wood biomass into valuable chemical commodities such as biofuels.
Primary Article Title: Lytic xylan oxidases from wood-decay fungi unlock biomass degradation
Author: Marie Couturier, Simon Ladevèze, Gerlind Sulzenbacher, Luisa Ciano, Mathieu Fanuel, Céline Moreau, Ana Villares, Bernard Cathala, Florence Chaspoul, Kristian E Frandsen, Aurore Labourel, Isabelle Herpoël-Gimbert, Sacha Grisel, Mireille Haon, Nicolas Lenfa
Keywords: Biorefining, woody biomass, enzymes

Summary Sentence: Polish authorities are using drones mounted with sensors to find and prosecute those involved with illegal air emissions.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as an emissions regulator may wish to contemplate if this realised example of automation and how it may have applications in the UK. Poland has a problem with households burning illegal fuels, which impacts on air quality. By using

 a drone with air quality sensors the local police in the mining town of Katowice have already fined someone the equivalent of $150 for burning illegal fuel. The unmanned drone’s on board sensors reportedly track certain kinds of smoke, and can actually evaluate

 various chemical makeups with its onboard sensors.
Primary Article Title: Katowice (Poland) is using drones to locate illegal emissions sources
Author: Ayre, J
Keywords: regulation prosecution "air quality" emission pollution pollutant "unmanned aerial vehicle" drone UAV Poland Katowice household fuel monitoring smoke chemical

Summary Sentence: Plans to build the world’s first hydrogen powered steel plant have been set in motion.
Justification:
Swedish steelmaker SSAB plan to build the plant and run tests between 2020 and 2024, with a look to making their entire production fossil fuel free by 2035. The hydrogen will be produced using fossil fuel free electricity. SSAB is currently one of Sweden’s

 biggest producers of carbon dioxide emissions. The success of the pilot project and subsequent roll out may be significant for the steel industry and other sectors that rely on fossil fuel for energy. Coal and coke are also transported to Sweden for production

 from as far away as Australia. The Environment Agency may therefore see similar operators following suit, impact on industrial emissions regulation.
Primary Article Title: Swedish steel plant to run on hydrogen
Author: Karagiannopoulos, L
Keywords: regulation energy steel hydrogen Sweden SSAB electricity "fossil fuel" Australia coal coke energy regulation emission air pollution "carbon dioxide" "climate change" 2020 2024 2035

Summary Sentence: Automating wildlife population monitoring
Justification:
Knowing how many individuals are in a wildlife population allows informed management decisions to be made and remotely piloted aircraft have been promoted as cost-effective way to collect population data. Ecologists are increasingly using technologies,

 such as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA) or drones, for wildlife monitoring applications but the validity of these approaches have gone untested. Using replica seabird colonies, a study has compared the accuracy of RPA approaches with traditional ground-based

 counting methods. The RPA-derived data was, on average, shown to be between 43% and 96% more accurate than traditional counting method, and the counts from the remotely sensed imagery could be semi-automated with a high degree of accuracy. This increased accuracy

 and precision of this data provides greater statistical power to detect fine-scale population fluctuations allowing for more informed and proactive ecological management.
Primary Article Title: Drones count wildlife more accurately and precisely than humans
Author: Jarrod C. Hodgson, Rowan Mott, Shane M. Baylis, Trung T. Pham, Simon Wotherspoon, Adam D. Kilpatrick, Ramesh Raja Segaran, Ian Reid, Aleks Terauds, Lian Pin Koh
Keywords: Population Monitoring

Summary Sentence: Social media, citizen science and artificial intelligence (AI) could be combined to improve flood data collection.
Justification: A team at the University of Dundee have done&%23160;this very thing to produce an early warning system for flood prone urban communities. Urban flooding is deemed to be difficult to monitor due complex data collection and processing. Current recording systems such as remote sensing and insurance reports don’t provide real time commentary that is often needed. Through turning to Twitter, the team were able to extract keywords related to flooding, and also extract locational information. Computer vision techniques were also applied to the ‘MyCoast’ app, a US based citizen science platform that documents tides, storm damage, beach cleanups and more. This extract flooding related images that had been shared. This data was then compared with official records of precipitation and road closure reports. The researchers found a high correlation between flood related tweets and precipitation, and MyCoast information and road closures. This suggests that Twitter and MyCoast data sources could be reliable complimentary monitoring sources during flood events, at the large scale and micro level respectively. By using the tools of social media, computer vision and AI to monitor water penetration of urban environments it may allow organisations responsible for flooding, such as the Environment Agency to improve forecasting models and early warning systems to help authorities and residents prepare for an incident.
Primary Article Title: Twitter + citizen science + AI = improved flood data collection
Secondary_URLs: Hyper-resolution monitoring of urban flooding with social media and crowdsourcing data - Computers & Geosciences 15/02/2018
Keywords: incident flood flooding "social media" "artificial intelligence" AI "computer vision" Twitter MyCoast photo image "citizen science" emergency data analysis rain precipitation road monitor response urban forecast people storm USA
GT: incident, citizen science, social media, artificial intelligence

Summary Sentence: Several architectural concepts suggest how to construct incident proof buildings in the future.
Justification:
Recent events such as Hurricanes Harvey and Sandy have generated interest in the architectural community in disaster proof homes. One solution is a hurricane proof house that floats on close to shore water. These ‘liveable yachts’ can endure extreme weather

 by engaging a hydraulic system that anchors the building to the seafloor whilst raising it above the normal water level to prevent flooding. The structures are equipped with solar power and rainwater harvesting systems, and may be available for purchase soon

 to ‘high end’ customers. Another concept involves a rotating house that is ‘screwed’ deeper into the ground by strong winds, effectively removing the structure from the onslaught of a hurricane. The architect behind this concept has also designed an earthquake

 proof hotel that breaks apart by the means of hydraulics whenever an earthquake is detected as being imminent. Such innovations may need to become incorporated more into future housing and other construction projects to ensure that developments are ‘future

 proofed’ to the impacts of climate change related incidents. The Environment Agency may need to consider where it has influence in introducing more innovation into architecture and building design, even possibly as an alternative to flood defences in certain

 development proposals.
Primary Article Title: These disaster-proof homes could be the future of modern architecture
Author: Rogers, S
Secondary_URLs: These $2 million hurricane-proof floating homes will go on sale next year - Interesting Engineering 13/02/2018
Keywords: architecture construction incident emergency flooding hurricane earthquake development 'living yacht' structure hydraulic planning
GT: architecture, incident management, construction, flooding, climate change

Summary Sentence: The International Seabed Authority (ISA) has granted over 25 contracts to various countries for deep sea and seafloor mineral exploration.
Justification:
This may be a signal that commercial scale deep sea mining is soon to become realised. Countries so far involved include Russia, China and several European nations. Previous attempts to commercially exploit deep sea minerals have failed, but emerging technologies

 are making the prospect increasingly possible. Japan recently extracted gold and zine using a track driven autonomous vehicle. Similar machines are being used in Cornwall to extract value from flooded mines and mining waste dumped into the sea. Future demands

 for energy storage and phosphorous from agriculture are seen as two economic drivers from the renewed interest in underwater mining. A Canadian project is looking to extract minerals from thermal vents by 2020 in the seas around Papua New Guinea, where minerals

 are known to exist in high concentrations. Trials of three different drilling machines is set to complete in Q1 2018. As demands for rare metals and minerals increases, so does the economic viability of deep sea mining. Marine mineral extraction may prove

 to be competition to terrestrial activities, and/or may present a risk to marine environments, suggesting that environmental regulation may have an increasing offshore remit in the future.
Primary Article Title: A sea change for mining
Author: Hosie, Ewen
Secondary_URLs: Oceanfloor mining for minerals towards the scale of ocean oil drilling - Next Big Future 15/02/2018
Keywords: regulation mining marine mineral extraction deep sea ocean automation technology phosphorus food agriculture farming manganese energy storage Canada "Papua New Guinea" Cornwall tin Japan gold zinc "water quality"

Summary Sentence: Airplanes with tail mounted electric turbofans could reduce overall fuel consumption.
Justification:
As a regulator of emissions from the aviation industry the Environment Agency may be interested in innovations that have the potential to reduce fuel consumption and therefore air pollution from this sector. NASA’s STARC-ABL (single-aisle turboelectric

 aircraft with aft boundary layer) concept has been modelled where the turbofan, known as BLI (boundary-layer ingesting) sucks in the slow moving air around a plane’s body and converts it into thrust. This reduces energy consumption by around ten per cent overall.

 NASA is preparing to test the STARC-ABL later this year.
Primary Article Title: NASA X-plane concept converts boundary layer air into thrust
Keywords: aviation "air quality" "air pollution" emission aircraft aeroplane airplane NASA regulation STARC-ABL "single-aisle turboelectric aircraft with aft boundary layer" fuel  BLI "boundary-layer ingesting" electric turbofan

Summary Sentence: Global Invasive Species Impacts
Justification:
The Global Register of Introduced and Invasive Species (GRIIS) provides the first country-wise checklist of introduced (naturalised) and invasive species. The movement of species by humans beyond their historical geographic ranges, and the resulting negative

 impacts that some of these species have, remains among the key threats to biodiversity and ecosystems. For example, 3.9% of the world's vascular plant species have been established and naturalised outside of their native ranges by humans. Species populations,

 species richness, composition and ecosystem function are impacted by alien species at multiple spatial scales. Cross-border trade and transport is the principal driver of new species introductions, and knowing which species are where is therefore central to

 evaluating risk to biodiversity and ecosystems, identifying priority species and slowing the rate of new invasions. Across 20 countries used as exemplars GRIIS checklists found 6,414 species listed and 11,320 records; more than 80% of these species had invasive

 environmental impacts in at least one or two countries. Beyond country use, these data will be used for reporting on the global status of biological invasion and to support indicators of biological invasion.
Primary Article Title: Introducing the Global Register of Introduced and Invasive Species
Author: Shyama Pagad, Piero Genovesi, Lucilla Carnevali, Dmitry Schigel, Melodie McGeoch
Keywords: Invasive Species, Data

Summary Sentence: Several examples are emerging of novel materials integrated into clothing textiles.
Justification:
These could present new regulatory responsibilities in textile manufacture and also new challenges in waste management due to the increased complexity of composite materials. Computer scientists at the University of Washington have managed to encode data

 using offf-the-shelf conductive thread woven into a fabric. No batteries or power sources are needed. Electromagnetic sensors can read the data, and in a demonstration model how been used for door security as a replacement for ID cards. The fabric can be washed

 and ironed without loss of data. A team from Cambridge University have managed to print fully integrated electronic circuits onto fabric. This is achieved through the ink which contains a mixture of graphene and another conductive material, hexagonal boron

 nitride (h-BN).m This new method betters previous attempts as it does not involve using toxic solvents. The process is scalable and so could readily be applied to commercial manufacture of electronic circuits on textiles. Whilst not strictly an electronics

 application, a team from UCLA have developed a new polymer that produces a cooling effect when a current is fed through. The polymer represents a breakthrough the electrocaloric effect, where applying a current to some materials results in a drop of temperature

 as the molecules in the material ‘suck’energy from the surrounding environment as they attempt to break free from the molecular structure. The results gained from the new polymer are promising enough to consider applications in refrigeration and air conditioning,

 but it is suggested that the cooling properties could also be incorporated into clothing, such as the brim of a sun hat.
Primary Article Title: How to store information in your clothes invisibly, without electronics
Author: Langston, J
Secondary_URLs:
Highly efficient electrocaloric cooling with electrostatic actuation - Science 15/09/2017

Graphene-based inks form basis for integrated circuits on fabric - The Engineer 09/11/2017

Flexible cooling strip breakthrough for heat removal - TreeHugger 26/09/2017

Fully inkjet-printed two-dimensional material field-effect heterojunctions for wearable and textile electronics - Nature 31/10/2017
Keywords: textile clothing cloth clothes regulation waste electronics cooling "air conditioning" refrigeration energy electricity electronic WEEE conductive thread graphene "hexagonal boron nitride" "h-BN" polymer "electrocaloric effect"

Summary Sentence: New research suggests that air pollution is helping to mitigate the effects of global warming and that removing those particulates, could result in a net warming effect of one degree Celsius.
Justification:
The human emission of aerosols (largely released by industrial activity) such as sulphates reflect sunlight away from the earth effectively cooling the climate. As industry seek ways to reduce or eliminate these aerosols, the real effect of GHGs on temperature

 rise will become apparent. This latest study looks at how much of an increase in global temperatures could be expected if all air pollution were to be stopped and has concluded it could be as much as one degree Celsius. What the study doesn't address is when

 these effects could be felt. On a more positive note, as GHGs tend to be released in conjunction with other particulates, a reduction in one would coincide with the reduction of the other - perhaps resulting in a smaller increase in overall global temperatures.
Primary Article Title: Cleaning up air pollution may strengthen global warming
Keywords: "air pollution" GHGs sulphates particulates aerosols "global warming" pollution industry

Summary Sentence: A novel approach to electrolysis produces hydrogen at a rate four times greater than current highly efficient methods.
Justification:
Such a process could bring the world closer to a practical large scale hydrogen economy. The new process relies on a Hybrid Solid Electrolysis Cell (HSOC). A conventional SOC consists of two electrodes and an electrolyte in solid state.   Existing SOECs allow either only one of the hydrogen or oxygen ions to be transported to the other electrode. During water electrolysis SOEC electrolytes transport oxygen at the anode to produce hydrogen. The opposite occurs at the cathode, resulting in

 oxygen production. In the HSOEC the electrolytes can transport both hydrogen and oxygen, allowing both to form at the cathode and anodes, increasing production greatly. The hybrid system also uses less energy. The HSOEC used in these experiments was made of

 perovskite and mixed ionic electrodes, and yielded 1.9 L per hour of hydrogen at a cell voltage of 1.5 V at 700 °C.
Primary Article Title: A new strategy for efficient hydrogen production
Author: Hyeon Heo, J
Secondary_URLs: Hybrid-solid oxide electrolysis cell&%2358; a new strategy for efficient hydrogen production - Nano Energy 02/02/2018
Keywords: energy hydrogen electrolysis electrolyte oxygen cathode anode perovskite "Hybrid Solid Electrolysis Cell" HSOC "Solid Electrolysis Cell" HSOC efficiency water resources regulation

Summary Sentence: Panasonic is due to start selling household hydrogen fuel cells in the UK in 2018.
Justification:
As these systems currently rely on natural gas for power the Environment Agency may wish to consider the overall impacts on the energy sector and related issues such as air quality. Hydrogen fuel cell systems are known as ene farms in Japan, where they

 are already 200,000 home fuel cell systems. The ene farm extracts hydrogen from a natural gas supply. The hydrogen is then mixed with oxygen from the air to produce electricity. Excess heat used to supply a home with hot water. Demand for them is expected

 to grow, since they help reduce carbon dioxide emissions compared with using electricity from power companies. An Ene-Farm can deliver 95 per cent efficiency, compared to the Japanese grid which delivers heat and power with 40% efficiency. Houses running an

 ene farm effectively cut their carbon footprint in half. Households can save money by running it overnight and taking advantage of lower energy prices, and then using the power from the fuel cell during the day. They also offer resilience to power cuts from

 the main grid. Many homes are already connected to the gas grid, meaning that installation and application could potentially be wide reaching. Panasonic aims to sell tens of thousands of units within Europe by the 2020s. A system would cost around 25,000 euros.

 From looking at the current situation in Japan, whilst the technology is sound, the uptake on a wide scale is hampered by economics. That said, applying similar systems in the UK that rely on natural gas could have several implications. It could hamper a move

 away from fossil fuels to renewables as methane gas is needed for feedstock. This could come from onshore gas, anaerobic digestion (AD), and possibly even ammonia, alongside conventional sources, all of which the Environment Agency currently has a regulatory

 role.
Primary Article Title: Panasonic cranks up market exposure for home fuel of the future
Author: Watanabe, C
Secondary_URLs:
On the ground in Japan&%2358; residential fuel cells - Ammonia Energy 18/05/2017

Japanese makers of home-use fuel cells plugging into Europe - Nikkei 11/03/2017

Why have I never heard of the Ene-Farm? - Make Wealth History 11/08/2017
Keywords: energy renewable hydrogen gas methane regulation "ene farm" "fuel cell" oxygen efficiency heat Japan resilience grid "energy storage" battery cost consumer utility "anaerobic digestion" AD ammonia farming livestock Panasonic Europe

Summary Sentence: Nissan has announced its 'Energy Solar Initiative' combining solar panels with an energy storage system for domestic use.
Justification:
Nissan has spent many years researching how to use battery packs from vehicles as home or business energy storage solutions. It is not clear from this press release if they have succeeded in this endeavour or, if the batteries have been sourced from elsewhere.

 However, the home management system provides the user with the choice as to where their power comes from and, can save excess energy in batteries or, use it to power an electric vehicle - providing individuals with the opportunity to move towards decentralised

 energy production in their home. Currently, the system is only available in the UK and could save home owners up to 66 per cent on energy bills.
Primary Article Title: Nissan Energy Solar plugs into home green-energy business
Keywords: "solar power" solar energy power batteries decentralisation "battery storage" off-grid

Summary Sentence: This new option for the decomposition of the human body may be on offer in the future.
Justification:
Liquid cremation involves the use of potassium hydroxide and high pressures to dissolve a body after death, as an alternative to using heat. It is currently being undertaken in the US, and is marketed as a process that is better for the environment as

 less emissions are produced than traditional cremation. After the soft tissues of the body are dissolved, all that is left is the skeleton and any implants that the person has had. These can then be separated and the bones ground up to provide the ashes. The

 liquid residue is collected, and the company in the UK wished to dispose of this once treated, into the local waste water supply. The local water authority have currently refused permission for this discharge, as they are waiting for guidance from Defra. If

 this type of treatment is permitted in the future, the Environment Agency will likely wish to ensure the safe storage of potassium hydroxide, so there are no neat leaks to the environment. The ability to separate metal implants offers the possibility of reducing

 the impact of mercury emissions which would be beneficial. A better understanding of the composition and pH of the effluent to be discharged would be useful to ensure it is not harmful to receiving water courses.
Primary Article Title: Council plan to liquefy bodies in eco-friendly alternative to cremation hits blockage
Secondary_URLs: Dissolving the dead - BBC 22/05/2017
Keywords: death heavy metal waste water quality treatment ethics potassium hydroxide alkali mercury emissions energy

Summary Sentence: Digital contraception for women appear to be on the rise.
Justification:
With the suggested links between female contraceptive pills and endocrine disruption in aquatic biodiversity the Environment Agency and partners should consider if this emerging social trend, and example of digital drugs (HSDBi %2312445, %2314310 ) may develop

 to a significant level as to reduce overall environmental impacts on water quality. The popularity of non chemical contraception is growing, based on a growing awareness of the negative sides and health risks of taking hormone based contraceptives. USe of

 the contraceptive pill has fallen by 600,000 from 2011 to 2015, allegedly over fears of links to breast cancer, blood clots and depression. One particular app, called Natural Cycles, has seen its user base grow from 5,000 to 125,000 in a year. The app is based

 on the rhythm method, aka fertility awareness method that uses an awareness of a woman’s natural cycle to know when she is most likely, and unlikely to conceive. A phone app uses an algorithm to monitor this based on body temperature, which can indicate when

 ovulation has occurred. One study has found that Natural Cycles is 93 per cent effective. There are however concerns that using non physical barriers may increase the risk of STDs, played out by recent research that reveals that many young people are less

 likely to practice safe sex with a new partner. The high rate of effectiveness and growing uptake may signal that the impacts of hormones from contraceptive pills in the environment may start to decrease in the future.
Primary Article Title: Return of the rhythm method - how natural contraception went digital
Author: Saner, E
Secondary_URLs:
Natural Cycles - Natural Cycles 30/01/2018

me.mum - me.mum 30/01/2018

Fertility awareness apps can increase risk of STDs, women told - The Times 19/12/2017

Almost half of under-25s 'never use a condom with a new partner' - BBC 15/12/2017

600,000 women ditch the pill after fears over links to breast cancer, blood clots and depression as use of fertility app soars - The Daily Mail 10/12/2017
Keywords: health women fertility pregnancy contraception contraceptive pill "Natural Cycles" me.mum chemical pharmaceutical medicine smartphone app temperature monitoring "water quality" hormone oestrogen "endocrine disrupting chemical" EDC biodiversity wildlife water treatment regulation pollution pollutant sex condom STD disease "digital drug" "Lutenizing hormone" "Lutenising hormone" LH

Summary Sentence: Applications of automation may be coming to the waste recycling industry sooner rather than the later.
Justification:
The Environment Agency as a waste regulator may wish to explore how applications of robotics, artificial intelligence (AI) and other automotive technologies could change the economics and productivity of the waste sector and explore where there may be

 opportunities to improve regulation. China has recently taken steps to close down the amount of waste it imports from the rest of the world. This is due to the quality of recyclable material not being to a sufficient standard. This is causing many economies

 to rethink their business models on waste disposal. One of the reasons that China rejects waste is to due to insufficient quality - many commodities such as plastic can be contaminated with a range of other waste materials. Unless nations can improve the purity

 of its waste then China won’t take it. Automation may be the answer to this conundrum. While a human worker can pick about 30 pieces of recyclate from a conveyor belt per minute, a new generation of recycling robots can pick 80 pieces a minute using multiple

 arms and image recognition. This technology is generally more expensive than human workers, but China’s stance on poor quality waste imports could mean that the technology is employed sooner. There is in fact one example already in the UK where a robot is

 being used to identify recyclables and sort them. Oregon-based Bulk Handling Systems’ (BHS) Max-AI AQC (Autonomous Quality Control) uses a vision system to identify recyclables and sort them out. The system mirrors the neural framework of the human brain to

 identify recyclables in a similar manner to a person. When the recyclables have been identified by the vision system, a robotic sorter then does the picking. The sorting robot is to be installed in early 2018 at a commercial recycling business in Maldon Essex.
Primary Article Title: First Max robot set for UK MRF
Author: Slow, E
Secondary_URLs: China's Ban On "Foreign Waste" May Aid the Spread of AI in the US - Futurism 19/12/2017
Keywords: waste automation recycling China economics quality robot "artificial intelligence" AI Maldon Essex Oregon "Bulk Handling Systems" BHS "Max-AI AQC" "Autonomous Quality Control" vision image recognition regulation

Summary Sentence: A financial venture is using the blockchain to leverage investment in green energy.
Justification:
The company is called WePower, and has built its technology on the Etherium blockchain platform. An investor buys a token that represents 1KW of green energy at below market value. An energy provider takes that token, along with others and uses the money

 to construct a source of renewable energy generation, such as solar panels.As soon as the plant is connected to the grid and starts selling energy the smart contract that underpins the platform starts to pay investors back at a higher market rate. A portion

 of the value of all energy generated is fed back into the tokens, meaning that they increase in value and become more attractive for investment from larger energy companies. Investors can convert that into fiat or cryptocurrency. This should be of interest

 to the Environment Agency as another example of green finance that utilises blockchain technology. However it is not clear what the energy demands of managing the system are - BitCoin for example uses significant power to process.
Primary Article Title: Forget Bitcoins; invest in green renewable energy with WePower tokens
Author: Alter, L
Keywords: blockchain WePower BitCoin energy renewable finance investment Ethereum "smart contract" regulation

Summary Sentence: A growing use of illegal steroids in the UK could be contributing to serious consequences for public health.
Justification:
The Environment Agency may have an interest in this, as increasing public use could raise environmental levels of steroids, some of which have already been identified as having detrimental environmental effects. Anabolic steroids are normally only available

 legally through medical professionals. However there are concerns that many people, which according to the testimony of a dealer, are typically young males, are obtaining steroids illegally to aid muscle growth purely for cosmetic purposes. Social media is

 blamed for creating issues with body confidence. Health impacts include thickening of heart walls, and an increased risk of developing fatal heart attacks or strokes. Research already exists to show that certain anabolic steroids and pharmaceutical products

 last longer in the environment than previously known. One steroid, trenbolone acetate, along with some other pharmaceutical products, were found to never fully degrade in the environment, and in fact can partially regenerate themselves (HSDBi %2312214, 13223).

 The fact that these chemicals transform, under certain conditions, may mean that they avoid detection, which in turn may account for unexplained observations of endocrine disruption in aquatic organisms. Without a clear assessment of the level of illegal steroid

 use it would be challenging to assess whether this social phenomenon may result in increasing impacts on aquatic wildlife if the steroids are not adequately removed by current water treatment technologies.
Primary Article Title: Steroid abuse 'raising health risk for thousands'
Secondary_URLs:
Environments, risk and health harms&%2358; a qualitative investigation into the illicit use of anabolic steroids among people using harm reduction services in the UK - British Medical Journal 04/06/2014

Steroids may persist longer in the environment than expected - Science Daily 26/01/2018
Keywords: health chemical steroid pollution biodiversity "water quality" anabolic steroid pharmaceutical "trenbolone acetate" zombie degrade regenerate youth young men heart stroke "social media" illegal crime drug narcotic regulation endocrine disruptor EDC cancer muscle image chemical "water quality" pollution pollutant water treatment

Summary Sentence: A recently developed app allows ordinary Word documents to be turned into actions for chatbots and voice activated assistants such as Google Home and Amazon Echo / Alexa.
Justification:
As voice becomes increasingly important as a means for people to interact digitally, applications like this may become increasingly important in aiding the Environment Agency in making its predominantly text based information more readily accessible to

 employees and customers alike. The tool is called Albert. Essentially Albert looks at the structure of a document to see how it could be turned into an interrogatable piece of information for a user. Albert then picks out choice questions so that it knows

 what a user might refer to when asking a question. The developers CEO envisaged that Albert could be useful, for example by a AirBnB property owner for converting a guest handbook into a more digestible form for typical questions such as “What’s the Wifi code?”.

 But Albert has also been proved to be able to offer a similar level of utility for technical manuals. It is possible for someone to easily add alternative questions such as “How do I connect to the internet?” through the comments feature in Word, meaning that

 programming skills are not a barrier to providing useful content. Such a system may be of benefit to National Customer Contact Centre in dealing with public enquiries, and even replacing some services. It could also be a time saver for employees consulting

 technical manuals and texts for specific pieces of information, helping to unlock knowledge that may currently be inaccessible.
Primary Article Title: This tool lets you create Google Assistant actions from a Word document
Author: Hughes, Matthew
Keywords: "knowledge management" customer employee AI "artificial intelligence" voice search internet Google Home Echo Alexa Albert

Summary Sentence: An academic has laid out a case for the UK to not pursue carbon capture and storage (CCS) as a climate change mitigation strategy but instead focus on energy efficiency.
Justification:
In a recent editorial Tom Baxter questions the rationality of CCS. CCS requires extra energy in current practices, amounting to 16 per cent extra gas use in a natural gas power station. This increase other emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides

 and particulate matter by the same amount. Also the amine solvent used in the process may have health impacts. Baxter acknowledges that oxy-combustion systems - where carbon dioxide (CO2) is recycled to improve combustion efficiency - show potential, but in

 practicality the costs of retrofitting existing power stations are prohibitive. Baxter suggests that behaviour change, such as not overfilling kettles, could achieve more for greenhouse gas reduction than CCS schemes, and that the government should focus on

 energy efficiency, rather than CCS, to reduce carbon emissions. This would involve embracing renewables alongside new technologies and materials for harness combined heat and power. The Environment Agency would likely have a role in regulating CCS in the UK,

 so needs to be aware of the whole life environmental impacts compared to other solutions.
Primary Article Title: It's time to accept carbon capture has failed - here's what we should do instead
Author: Baxter, T
