Keywords: energy regulation "carbon dioxide" emission CO2 "greenhouse gas" "carbon capture and storage" CCS renewable heat power behaviour change psychology  air quality pollution pollutant "sulphur dioxide" "nitrogen oxide" "particulate matter"

Summary Sentence: Cryptocurrency could potentially offer new revenue streams to speed up investment in environmentally beneficial projects and facilitate positive behaviour change.
Justification:
Financing green business can often be difficult due to the uncertainties in new technology and the longer term payback of the investment. Having the technology is not enough, the funding is also needed to develop the green businesses of the future. Currently

 with added risk comes added expense, often pushed on to the consumer or taxpayer, as seen with the push for green energy translating into higher prices. This has led to many questioning why they should be the ones footing the bill when they do not get the

 benefits from profits once the technology becomes established. As the growth of new cryptocurrencies rises, it is envisioned that new green currencies will evolve, making use of smart contracts to incentivise more environmentally friendly behaviour and investment.

 A successful green currency could be something that the Environment Agency wishes to engage with in the future as a way to raise funds for projects or encourage behaviours that benefit the environment. An increase in the rate of uptake of new technologies

 is also something that could impact on the regulatory role of the Environment Agency both positively and negatively.
Primary Article Title: 2018 will usher in the green cryptocurrency revolution
Secondary_URLs: What are the alternative cryptocurrencies to Bitcoin? - World Economic Forum 11/01/2018
Keywords: blockchain "distributed ledger" regulation finance virtual currency energy BitCoin investment funding bank banking policy economics

Summary Sentence: As data becomes easier to collect, share and process, the ethics of its use may be called into question.
Justification:
The Chicago police department are already using an algorithm to assess the data they collect to rate those that have been arrested with a score of 1-500. This score is then used to determine how the individual in question may be approached in future or

 their likelihood of reoffending, thus affecting police behaviour towards the individual in the future. The algorithm which is used to determine this score is secret, leading sceptics to question the ethics and biases that may be contained within a system that

 citizens cannot challenge. Opponents believe that even if the algorithm is unbiased, the data collected by the police force is subject to human bias as many arrests are down to a police officers discretion. The citizen score is a similar system that is being

 developed in China, but uses data such as shopping habits, social media use and even family connections to rate citizens. This score will then be used to determine how trustworthy the individual is and thus what access they may have to jobs and even travel.

 The potential to use exiting Environment Agency data to identify those more likely to violate permits is probably already available. However the ethics and transparency of such systems appear not to be advanced enough to be accepted in the UK, though may be

 something the Environment Agency will need to explore in the future.
Primary Article Title: The police are using computer algorithms to tell if you're a threat
Secondary_URLs:
China's "social credit system" will rate how valuable you are as a human - Futurism 02/12/2017

Big data meets Big Brother as China moves to rate its citizens - Wired 21/10/2017
Keywords: regulation permit crime compliance China "big data" data protection privacy commerce government "black market" "Social Credit Scheme" SCS credit "social media" score e-commerce bank internet

Summary Sentence: Researchers in the US are creating plastics out of biomass.
Justification:
With plastics becoming a bigger issue in the media, there are increasing efforts to find a green solution that is both environmentally friendly and cost effective. Using a plant derived solvent, the research team have developed a cheap and high-yielding

 methodology for producing FDCA (furandicarboxylic acid) - one of the 12 chemicals that the US Department of Energy have identified as "critical" to develop a green chemical industry. FDCA is the precursor to the production of PEF - the green replacement for

 PET. While many of the big companies such as Coca-Cola have committed to developing a plant-sourced version of PET, to date, the cost of producing FDCA has been prohibitive. It also requires large amounts of solvent in the manufacturing process making less

 environmentally desirable. This latest research uses fructose which, can be converted into FDCA . The solvent used in this process can be easily separated as it solidifies to a white powder on cooling and can be reused. With further work, the team are hopeful

 this form of FDCA could be comparable in cost to the fossil fuel based alternatives.
Primary Article Title: Bio-renewable process could help `green' plastic
Secondary_URLs: Toward biomass-derived renewable plastics&%2358; Production of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid from fructose. - Science Advances 22/01/2018
Keywords: plastic "plastic waste" PET PEF FDCA "fossil fuels" waste pollution biomass bio-renewable "green plastic"

Summary Sentence: The University of Madrid have developed a motivational recognition system that provides real time data on how satisfied employees are using an electrocardiogram sensor, an emotion recognition system through image processing and data analysis.
Justification:
Many organisations, including the Environment Agency, use surveys to assess how satisfied staff are. However, such systems rely on staff recall and cannot be relied upon to identify short-term issues caused by a spontaneous event. The system developed

 in Madrid called Maslow 4.0, takes physiological data from employees and feeds this directly to a server meanwhile, a camera captures images of the employee and uses signal processing to understand what emotions the individual is feeling and ultimately, how

 satisfied they are at that moment in time. The results of both processes are then feed to a server that uses a mathematical model and algorithm to create a motivational map of employees. The positive aspects of this system is that real-time data can mean that

 issues are identified quickly and the source of dissatisfaction can be dealt with. However, this process is in itself highly intrusive and individuals may not want to be monitored for fear of being removed from their job as they are not fully satisfied and

 therefore, not as productive as their colleagues. In comparison Amazon has patented a wristband that can precisely track where warehouse employees are placing their hands and uses vibrations to nudge them in a different direction, streamlining order fulfilment

 but creating a further layer of surveillance.
Primary Article Title: Motivational recognition for the industry of the future
Secondary_URLs: Amazon patents wristband that tracks warehouse workers' movement - The Guardian 01/02/2018
Keywords: motivation effectiveness satisfaction surveys staff employees workforce Amazon wristband warehouse vibration employee monitoring

Summary Sentence: Following concerns voiced by Mark Carney over the ability of the financial sector to address long-term investments in climate change, Green bonds may deliver the behavioural change required.
Justification:
Investment is key to ensuring the success of climate change solutions. Two years ago, Mark Carney coined the phrase "tragedy of the horizons" in a speech at Lloyds Bank to describe the dilemma of encouraging investment in long-term climate change solutions.

 Behavioural economics suggests that traditionally, people have difficulty with long-term thinking and therefore long-term investments however, recent changes in both behaviour and the financial system may be about to address this issue. A key factor to investment

 is risk assessment. Recent changes in thinking have moved this type of risk assessment from purely financial to ESG (environmental, social and governance). Green bonds have not only been used to raise longer-term finance with low risk, but have the capacity

 to address risk and stability which considers long-term climate change - affecting how people think about money and returns. Green bonds offer similar returns to normal bonds but also provide a green return - creating a social and environmental conscience

 in the financial sector. To achieve the ambitions set out in the 25-year environment plan, such green investment is crucial.
Primary Article Title: Green bonds are taking off-and could help save the planet
Keywords: finance investment "green bonds" "climate change" investment funding banking policy regulation economics "behavioural economics"

Summary Sentence: A study carried out by the University of Manchester suggests that of the nine ways to generate electricity, shale gas ranks seventh.
Justification:
This is the first time a holistic study has been carried out looking at all aspects of sustainability in relation to electricity generation. As such, this study could help Defra and the Environment Agency make better informed decisions regarding the future

 regulation of shale gas. The study looked at 18 sustainability indicators including environmental, economic and social factors with all the indicators weighted as equally important. For shale gas to rise up the list, several improvements would need to be put

 in place including a 329-fold improvement in environmental impacts and a 16-fold improvement in employment within the industry. It is suggested that a simpler way to improve its rating would be to combine shale with other forms of electricity generation. The

 other forms of electricity generation considered were&%2358; coal, nuclear, natural gas, liquefied natural gas (LNG), solar photovoltaics (PV), wind, hydro and biomass. It is hoped that the results of this study will help policy makers, NGOs, industry and customers

 better informed.
Primary Article Title: Shale gas is one of the least sustainable ways to produce electricity, research finds
Keywords: "shale gas" fracking electricity "electricity generation" sustainability industry customers consumers NGOs policy "policy makers" energy "energy generation"

Summary Sentence: A new study suggests that in the EU alone, the production, useage and disposal of microwave ovens releases as much carbon dioxide as seven million cars.
Justification:
Little is known about the environmental effects of microwave ovens on the environment despite accounting for the highest percentage sales of all ovens sold in the EU. The study, carried out by the University of Manchester, used life-cycle assessment (LCA)

 to determine their environmental impact. Twelve factors were assessed including climate change, toxicity and waste management. The main issues identified were materials used for manufacture, the manufacturing process and end of life waste management. There

 are also concerns that microwaves now have a reduced life span of six to eight years when compared to the 10 to 15 year life span seen in the 1990's. When this is coupled with reducing costs and a trend for consumers to view such items as status symbols and

 fashion items, it can be seen that microwave ovens not only have a shorter shelf-life but are not even reaching that shelf-life before being replaced.
Primary Article Title: Microwaves could be as bad for the environment as cars, suggests new research
Keywords: microwaves "microwave ovens" "electrical waste" EE EU "climate change" "end of life" electronics manufacturing toxicity electricity

Summary Sentence: A bictoin millionaire has funded research into MDMA (aka ecstasy) as a therapeutic drug for PTSD prompting a wave of further donations that could see MDMA available as a prescription drug in the near future.
Justification:
MDMA is in the final phase of clinical trials as a treatment for PTSD through a company called MAPS based in the US. Following 35 years of research, MAPS are now working with the FDA for approval to use the drug as part of psychotherapy treatment. Following

 this, MAPS will need to carry out Phase 3 clinical trials before the drug can be made available on prescription. MAPS has had many donations for its work through cryptocurrencies and this may be a new trend that sees more new and novel drugs available to the

 public at a faster rate than previously anticipated. Whilst the delivery of new treatments and therapies is of benefit to society, the effects of new drugs, or known drugs but in greater quantities, could pose a threat to the environment. For example, Green

 Lifestyle magazine point out that the production of MDMA results in destruction of virgin rainforest and potential water pollution risks when disposing of MDMA.
Primary Article Title: How the cryptocurrency boom is helping make MDMA a legal prescription drug
Secondary_URLs: Eco side effects of drugs - Green Lifestyle 16/01/2018
Keywords: bitcoin cryptocurrency donations research MDMA PTSD "prescription drugs" "legalising drugs" "drug development" ecstasy

Summary Sentence: In the US, 'storm survivors' are seeking help from therapists to deal with the distress of flooding events.
Justification:
Whilst the focus following a flood is usually insurance, repairs and advice on future-proofing communities from further flooding events, in the US, survivors of Hurricane Harvey are also receiving free counselling from both government and private-funded

 programmes. The mental effects of flooding (grief, anxiety, depression and fear of storms) can progress through several stages and last for months. For example, one study on the impacts of another hurricane, Hurricane Sandy, found that 14.5 per cent of adults

 were suffering from PTSD (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder) six months after the event. One commentator asserts that "implementing targeted psychosocial care is both a humanitarian need and an economic necessity—saving lives, jobs and families." Whilst long-term

 therapy is usually not required, short-term treatment involving the opportunity to be open about feelings and share the experience with others can have a beneficial effect. With more emphasis on mental health within the organisation, the Environment Agency

 may wish to consider how it deals with mental health issues created by flooding and other incidents outside of the organisation. This is also a wider issue for health services to consider, particularly as future climate predictions suggest that the number

 and scale of severe weather events is likely to grow in the future.
Primary Article Title: Hurricane Harvey survivors feel grief, distress months later
Secondary_URLs: The trauma after the storm - Scientific American 07/11/2017
Keywords: flooding incidents "incident management" "mental health" counselling storms hurricanes "Hurricane Harvey" therapy "Hurricane Sandy" PTSD "Post Traumatic Stress Disorder" health government climate change flooding emergency

Summary Sentence: Acidic, radioactive liquid waste could be cleaned up using a particular strain of yeast that has proven to be resistant to acute and chronic forms of gamma radiation.
Justification: In the event of a radioactive liquid waste spill, a particular strain of yeast known as Rhodotorula taiwanensis MD1149 has proved highly resistant to gamma radiation. This strain of yeast can also attach itself to various substrates - including sand and rocks - slowing the migration of radioactive substances into the environment. This could provide a relatively inexpensive, and less hazardous, method to clean-up radioactive waste and protect water resources following a major incident.
Primary Article Title: Yeast may be the solution to toxic waste clean-up
Secondary_URLs: Prospects for Fungal Bioremediation of Acidic Radioactive Waste Sites&%2358; Characterization and Genome Sequence of Rhodotorula taiwanensis MD1149 - Frontiers in Microbiology 15/01/2018
Keywords: "incident management" "toxic waste" "radioactive waste" yeast "incident management" "radioactive contamination" "water resources" "water pollution" "land pollution" pollution

Summary Sentence: A candidate for the city council of Boulder, Colorado promised to let an app control all his voting decisions.
Justification:
Camilo Casas devised an smartphone app that would have allowed his constituents to vote on every issue facing him as a councillor. Mr Casas would then see which option won and vote accordingly on council business. Unfortunately for Mr Casas he did not

 get elected, garnering less than one per cent of the vote. However this story highlights the disruptive potential that digital could bring to politics, and therefore regulation, in the future.
Primary Article Title: Colorado political candidate promises to give his seat to an app
Author: Matsakis, L
Secondary_URLs: 2017 Coordinated Election, November 7, 2017 - Boulder County Colorado 15/01/2018
Keywords: politics government regulation population Boulder Colorado election digital app smartphone "Camilo Casas" local regional

Summary Sentence: A pair of Canadian chemistry professors have created a mobile environmental monitoring unit.
Justification:
The mobile laboratory in a van contains a mobile mass spectrometer that measures the masses of molecules within a sample to determine their chemical identities in the field, rather than take samples back to the laboratory. The van can collect data continuously

 on the move and all results are georeferenced, so can be mapped and visualised. The van also contains a suite of meteorological and air and water quality sensors that can be used for rapid in-field analysis and continuous process monitoring by piping a continuous

 stream of water samples through the equipment in the van. The professors can see their innovation being useful in a pollution incident or for providing information on a remediation site. It could also be used to help identify leaks in a community, such as

 methane. Further development will concentrate on water quality monitoring. Similar developments which may deliver disruptions for the current Environment Agency monitoring paradigm where water samples are transported to the laboratory for analysis rather than

 being completed in the field.
Primary Article Title: Mobile lab maps out contaminants on the go
Author: Walter, K
Keywords: "environmental monitoring" "air quality" "air pollution" emission regulation "water quality"  van vehicle "mass spectrometer" mobile incident methane gas leak pollution pollutant Canada laboratory land contaminated land remediation

Summary Sentence: A driverless, electric mobile market known as 'Robomart' has been designed as a way to compete with traditional online delivery services at a fraction of the cost.
Justification:
Another example of how autonomous vehicles may be utilised in the future resulting in less air pollution and waste for the Environment Agency. Currently, the traditional method of supermarket delivery is limited by the following factors&%2358; First, although

 fresh items make up 60 per cent of grocery sales, only five per cent are ordered by the public for online delivery. This is because customers would prefer to select their own produce to ensure that items have a reasonable sell by date and that the selection

 of fruit and veg is correct. Second, the requirement of a picker and driver for each order pushes the price of the service up. Robomart is summoned using a smartphone app and delivers fresh produce to the door of the customer where they can select the items

 they want. A bill is created at the time of choosing produce and a receipt sent to the customer. Robomart is five times cheaper to operate than conventional delivery and 65 per cent of women in a US survey have stated they would use such a system at least

 once a week. The system can also collect data on customer requirements for business planning purposes and is capable of communicating with customers (and if necessary the police). A prototype has been created and the manufacturers are awaiting an Autonomous

 vehicle testing permit before running a trial in San Francisco.
Primary Article Title: Robomart's autonomous rolling produce market makes convenience stores more convenient
Keywords: "autonomous vehicles" deliveries groceries food Robomart shopping "autonomous market vehicle" autonomous vehicles vans "commercial vehicles" pollution "air pollution"

Summary Sentence: The Carbon Trust CEO, Tom Delay, predicts that sustainability in 2018 will be driven by increasing financial disclosure, a tipping point for clean technology and global sustainable leadership in the developing world.
Justification:
Financial disclosure&%2358;  Corporations will more transparent on climate risks and there will be more financial disclosure from Boards on sustainability issues to customers and investors.    Tipping point&%2358;  Low-carbon technologies will continue to decrease in price. For example, off-shore wind reached an all time low strike price in the UK during 2017, battery storage for EVs is improving and the cost of lithium ion batteries has fallen by 73 per cent over

 the past seven years. With reducing costs, Delay predicts that such technologies will begin to feature in strategic business planning.      Global sustainable leadership&%2358;  With the UK distracted by Brexit and the US increasing fossil fuel investments under Trump, Delay suggests that Latin America and China are stepping forward to lead global sustainability. China in particular will be phasing out diesel vehicles and spending

 $363 billion on renewable power by 2020.
Primary Article Title: Transparency, Trump and tipping points&%2358; The key trends that could define sustainability in 2018
Keywords: sustainability "green economy" leadership "financial disclosure" "electric vehicles" batteries "wind power" renewables "fossil fuels" forecasting "horizon scanning"

Summary Sentence: A $23 million emergency fund has been put in place in Michigan to investigate PFAS contamination in the water supply.
Justification:
PFAS (Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) have been found at military bases and at a disused industrial dump site for a shoe manufacturer. 1,000 homes with private wells near the dump site have been checked for PFAS with the chemicals identified at 14

 of 28 sites with some homes having hundreds of times the recommended advisory level. Erin Brockovich has recently been encouraging affected residents to join a class-action lawsuit ensuring this issue will probably result in mainstream media attention.  (Also see %2312850)
Primary Article Title: Michigan scrambles to address chemical contaminants in water
Keywords: "water quality" contaminants pollution "water pollution" perfluoroalkyl substances" "polyfluoroalkyl substances" PFAS groundwater

Summary Sentence: In the US, shale gas has successfully been converted into products such as methanol and gasoline whilst consuming the CO2 produced in the process.
Justification:
This process can also be used for coal and biomass giving it wide-reaching application. The technology is called chemical looping and uses metal oxides under high pressure to burn fossil fuels and biomass without oxygen from air (the metal oxide provides

 the oxygen for the reaction). Whilst not presented as a long-term solution, the research team suggest this process could be used as a stop-gap until renewables are more widely available and affordable. Chemical looping has also been used by the research team

 to produce syngas and could potentially result in the development of carbon dioxide as a raw material for producing a wide array of everyday products.
Primary Article Title: A fossil fuel technology that doesn't pollute
Keywords: "fossil fuels" "carbon dioxide" CO2 syngas renewables "metal oxides" biomass "shale gas" "chemical looping"

Summary Sentence: Exploiting 'fourth generation district heating', or 'urban energy' in new builds, will provide the opportunity to free up the electricity grid for alternative uses such as transport.
Justification:
Fourth generation heating (or urban energy) are low temperature heating grids that distribute the waste heat created by facilities such as fridges, freezers and IT server rooms. These systems are currently being tested in new housing schemes in Denmark

 and Norway. If adopted across cities and towns in the UK, this will result in benefits for society as a whole and the Environment Agency as a business. Current models suggest that by installing a district heating grid, heat losses can be reduced by a third

 whilst reducing reliance on peak load sources in the primary district heating grid. This will reduce reliance on fossil fuels and consequently, greenhouse gas emissions. Lower temperature heat distribution systems have three main benefits&%2358; First, providing

 the opportunity to use waste heat from low temperature sources such as fridges in supermarkets; second, providing increased generation capacity and more efficient renewable heat sources such as solar and heat pumps and; third, lower installation and running

 costs. The research team suggest that all housing developers should be considering urban energy to provide greater flexibility throughout the whole energy system.
Primary Article Title: Our cities are hidden power stations
Keywords: heating energy power renewables grid electricity "fossil fuels" cities towns "power generation"

Summary Sentence: Pressure exerted by glaciers has an impact on the flow of magma therefore, as the earth warms and glaciers melt, there will be more frequent and bigger volcanic eruptions.
Justification:
The relationship between magma flow beneath the surface of the earth and glacier pressure not only affects the voids and gaps where magma can flow to the surface but also, how much magma the crust can hold. When compared to periods of time where the earth

 was cooler, it can be seen that as the ice cover increased, the number and intensity of volcanic eruptions decreased. Whilst there was a 600 year time lag between decreasing temperatures and increased volcanic activity, the time difference between increasing

 temperatures and increased volcanic activity appears to be shorter (although the authors do not suggest by how much). Volcanic eruptions are known to increase air pollution over vast areas therefore, this could result in a worldwide decline in air quality.
Primary Article Title: Climate change likely to increase volcanic eruptions, scientists say
Keywords: "air quality" "air pollution" volcano eruptions glacier temperature "increasing temperature" "decreasing temperature"
